                                US Official News

                            December 16, 2013 Monday

Alabama: Huntsville Man Must Pay $3.7 Million to IRS for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 327  words

DATELINE: Montgomery


United States Attorney's Office for the Northern District of Alabama has issued
the following press release:

A federal judge this week sentenced a Huntsville man to five years' probation
for tax evasion but ordered him to pay $3.7 million in restitution to the
government, announced U.S. Attorney Joyce White Vance and Internal Revenue
Service Criminal Investigation Special Agent in Charge Veronica Hyman-Pillot.

U.S. District Judge Abdul K. Kallon sentenced PAUL BRACY JR., 71, on one count
of tax evasion. The U.S. Attorney's Office charged Bracy in July. Bracy owned
several small businesses: Bracy's Vending and the Green Room Lounge in Madison
County and PBS Blues Bar in Macon County. Bracy also owned four pieces of real
property, two in Madison County, one in Choctaw County and one in Mobile County.

According to court documents, the IRS was about to determine Bracy was
personally responsible for $60,995 in unpaid taxes associated with businesses he
owned, when Bracy conveyed the four pieces of real property, via "sham
transactions," to others in order to avoid IRS seizure of the properties to
satisfy the outstanding tax amount. As part of his plea agreement, Bracy agreed
to pay the $3,747,650 in restitution to the government.

"Most citizens diligently pay their taxes," Vance said. "The willful failure of
others to do so is patently unfair and criminal. We will aggressively seek to
investigate and prosecute those individuals."

"Business owners have a responsibility to withhold income taxes for their
employees and then remit those taxes to the Internal Revenue Service,"
Hyman-Pillot said. "The failure to pay over withheld taxes is a serious offense.
IRS Criminal Investigation vigorously pursues anyone who collects taxes and
fails to timely remit those taxes."

The IRS-CI investigated the case, which the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
Northern District of Alabama prosecuted.

For more information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/usao/aln/

                      The Meadville Tribune (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            December 14, 2012 Friday

Former Crawford County jail doc gets five months for tax evasion

BYLINE: Keith Gushard, The Meadville Tribune, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 266 words


Dec. 14--ERIE -- A physician from Linesville who formerly was the attending
physician at the Crawford County jail, was sentenced this morning in federal
court in Erie to five months in federal prison for income tax evasion.

Calling it "a case of greed," U.S. District Judge Sean McLaughlin sentenced Dr.
Richard Moran of Linesville to five months in jail to be followed by seven
months house arrest and then one year of supervised release and a $7,500.

Moran could have received up to three years in jail and a $250,000 fine after
pleading guilty in June to on one count of filing a false federal income tax
return for the 2005 tax year.

While Moran pleaded guilty to filing false income tax return for the 2005 tax
year, in his plea agreement with the federal government Moran also admitted
responsibility for filing false income tax returns in 2006, 2007 and 2008.

Moran admitted to underreporting his income by about $100,000 a year in each of
those years.

Moran had been the physician for the Crawford County Correctional Facility for
about 20 years, until Crawford County commissioners relieved Moran of duties in
September following his plea agreement.

In early September, commissioners approved a contract with Prime Care Medical
Inc. of Harrisburg to have the company provide physician services for the county
jail in Saegertown until Prime Care's full medical services contract began in
October.

See Saturday's Tribune for more details.

                        The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD)

                             July 6, 2005 Wednesday

Tax evasion arrests in Maryland climb under Schaefer directive

BYLINE: Dori Berman

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 537 words


Comptroller William Donald Schaefer said a crackdown by his enforcement division
resulted in increases in arrests for fuel tax evasion and alcohol tax violations
in the fiscal year that closed last week.

The Comptroller of Maryland Regulatory and Enforcement Division -- which
Schaefer has made a priority, a spokesman said --saw a 79 percent jump in the
number of arrests for fuel tax evasion and a 10 percent rise in arrest for
alcohol tax evasion during the fiscal year that ended June 30. Arrests from
cigarette smuggling dropped, but remained at high levels.

The increased arrests are "because of our enforcement efforts," said Michael D.
Golden. "The comptroller has made it one of his goals since becoming comptroller
in 1999 to level the playing field and make sure all the tax laws are being
followed."

Golden said the comptroller could not yet determine how much revenue could be
recovered because it will take time to settle the cases.

Enforcement agents arrested 86 people for violations of motor fuel tax laws.
Almost half of those were for diesel fuel dyed red to mark it as untaxed.
Off-road vehicles -- such as farm and construction equipment -- may use the dyed
fuel, but trucks that use the state's roadways must use clear diesel, taxed by
both federal and state levies. Violators are found through random stops and
testing.

Suppliers dye the fuel marked for tax-exempt status, and the fuel is then
available at some service stations.

Schaefer's office said nearly all of the violators were truckers or trucking
companies.

While a trucking industry representative said it is unusual for trucking
companies to violate diesel fuel tax laws, the industry supports strong
enforcement efforts.

Evasion "depletes highway trust fund revenues," said Bob Pitcher, vice president
of state laws for the American Trucking Associations. "It is less widespread
than it used to be on account of some measures that have been taken on the
federal and state levels. Maryland is one of the more aggressive states."

Maryland has also become more aggressive toward cigarette smuggling.

The number of arrests dropped from 177 in fiscal year 2004 to 122 in fiscal year
2005, but the numbers have drastically increased since Schaefer was elected.
Only seven smuggling arrests were made in fiscal year 1999, the year Schaefer
took office. Last year saw the highest number of arrests.

"The signal has gotten out there clearly that we are going after cigarette
smugglers," Golden said. Because states to the north of Maryland have higher
cigarette taxes, Golden said it is likely the smugglers are just passing through
Maryland from states like North Carolina, where the per pack cigarette tax is
five cents. Rhode Island has the highest tax at $2.46. Maryland's tax is $1 per
pack.

Meanwhile, arrests for alcohol tax violations increased by 10 percent following
three years of decline. Most of those arrests were for retailers not purchasing
from wholesalers, refilling or tampering with bottle contents, unlicensed sales
and possession of untaxed alcohol. Schaefer recently announced his office will
expand an audit program of alcohol retailers that has shown success in four
state jurisdictions.

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                          September 29, 2004 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Contractor's tax evasion sentence toughened;
Judge shows displeasure with ruling by appeals court on Derbes case

BYLINE: Christopher Walker

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 577 words


The Patriot Ledger BOSTON - An openly reluctant federal judge toughened a tax
evasion sentence for a prominent Quincy road contractor, but still refused to
order any jail time. U.S. District Judge Richard Stearns sentenced Frank Derbes
- co-owner of Derbes Brothers Inc. - to spend three months in a halfway house
and three extra months under house arrest for a 2002 federal tax evasion
conviction.

The judge's decision yesterday follows an Appeals Court ruling overturning
Stearns' original decision last year to sentence Derbes to nine months of house
arrest and 15 months of probation. Derbes has already served the full nine-month
house arrest term of the original sentence, in which he was monitored by an
electronic bracelet but could leave home to go to work.

Stearns made little effort to hide his displeasure at the Appeals Court ruling
during a brief hearing yesterday, at one point suggesting that the new sentence
for Derbes "was more than he actually deserves."

Prosecutors had sought at least a 13-month prison term for Frank Derbes, whose
brother, Robert, completed a one-year prison term this summer for similar tax
fraud charges. When Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Pineault held out the
possibility that the government may object to the refined sentence, Stearns
bluntly told the prosecutor:

"I think the government just ought to drop it at this point."

The two Derbes brothers pleaded guilty to evading more than $500,000 in federal
income taxes. Prosecutors alleged the brothers invented fake expenses and wrote
checks to subcontractors, but instead of sending the checks, they had someone
endorse them, cash them and hand the money back to the company.

Prosecutors also charged that over the same time period, Frank Derbes took
checks made out to his company and instead of depositing them into Derbes Bros.
accounts, cashed many of them at a Quincy check cashing company, according to
court records. Robert Derbes also did not deposit some checks into the company's
accounts, records state.

As result, the company's earnings were under-reported by several hundred
thousand dollars.

Derbes' attorney, William Cintolo, described a family trying to get itself and
its business beyond a mistake they admitted to years ago. Based in South Quincy
for more than 40 years, Derbes Brothers is one of the South Shore's largest road
contractors. While the brothers pleaded guilty to the charges, they have always
disputed a number of the figures offered by federal prosecutors and deny that
they tried to benefit personally by evading taxes.

"I just want to get on with my life," Frank Derbes said after the hearing,
saying he doesn't plan to appeal the new sentence.

Stearns originally sentenced Derbes to probation and house arrest based on
health issues and concerns that the business could fail if one of the brothers
was not involved at all times. The appeals court ruled that Stearns used only
thin evidence to support departing from sentence guidelines.

The appeals court also suggested that there was nothing in court records to
suggest that the federal prison system wouldn't be able to properly care for
Derbes' health problems.

The Derbes Brothers, once the city's primary road contractor, is now also in a
$1 million legal fight with the city. The company claims it was cheated out of
money for work performed over several years, while the city argues the company
charged for work it never did. Christopher Walker may be reached at
cwalker@ledger.com.

                              The Washington Post

                  September 17, 1994, Saturday, Final Edition

Educator Gets Term for Tax Evasion;
U.S. Judge Rejects Probation for Alexandria Guidance Official

Steve Bates, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C2

LENGTH: 456 words


A federal judge sentenced a prominent Alexandria educator to 60 days in jail
yesterday for tax evasion, brushing aside supporters' claims that he can do more
good by staying on the job.

James E. McClure, 55, of Springfield, guidance director at T.C. Williams High
School, began serving his sentence immediately. He had pleaded guilty to one
count of tax evasion after being indicted on four counts.

Dozens of Alexandria residents had sent letters to District Court Judge Albert
V. Bryan Jr., urging him to put McClure on probation rather than in jail. Bryan
acknowledged those pleas yesterday, but he rejected the assertion by McClure's
attorney, Thomas Hill, that McClure's crime was "an aberration" and that he
deserved to receive probation because of his service to the community.

"This was not an aberration; this was cheating," Bryan said. "When he cheats on
his taxes, he cheats everybody in this room."

McClure, who has a reputation for helping students and parents through crises,
admitted underreporting his taxable income by more than $ 125,000 over four
years and providing false documents during an audit in an attempt to support
deductions. As part of his plea bargain, he has agreed to pay back taxes.

Assistant U.S. Attorney David Barger asked Bryan yesterday to impose jail time.
"One of the messages that needs to be sent to youth is that they must take
responsibility for their actions," Barger said.

"I'm deeply sorry for my irresponsible actions and the impact they have had on
the community I have served for 26 years," McClure said before he was sentenced.

Meanwhile, Alexandria school officials said yesterday that they have not decided
whether to ask the state Board of Education to revoke McClure's teaching
license, which likely would cost him his job. Alexandria officials also have the
options of demoting McClure, cutting his pay and firing him. School Board
Chairman V. Rodger Digilio said the board would await a recommendation from
Acting Superintendent Maxine J. Wood.

Digilio said McClure probably would be allowed to take paid leave while he is in
jail. His salary is about $ 65,000 a year.

McClure's supporters expressed disappointment after he was jailed. "I'm very
upset about it," said city resident Carol LaSasso, who added that "the community
is prepared to accept him back in the same capacity."

But School Board member Patricia Hennig said the sentence shows that "no one is
above the law; no one is allowed to cut their own rules."

Last week, McClure was transferred from the high school to a temporary
assignment at the school system's headquarters.

McClure began working for the school system in 1968 and has been the guidance
director at T.C. Williams since 1973.

                           January 19, 2017 Thursday

Scranton funeral director charged with tax evasion

BYLINE: Terrie Morgan-Besecker, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 236 words


Jan. 19--Scranton funeral director Al Hughes was indicted on charges he evaded
taxes on about $1.25 million he pilfered from several funeral homes.

Federal prosecutors say that from 2009 to 2014, Mr. Hughes cashed hundreds of
customers' checks intended for funeral home services and deposited the money
into his personal account.

According to the indictment, Mr. Hughes reported income totalling $268,164 over
that time period, knowing that his actual income was "substantially" more. The
document does not specify the amount he actually earned.

He faces five counts of tax evasion charges. He pleaded not guilty today.

Mr. Hughes was a key witness in the 2011 corruption trial of former Lackawanna
County commissioners Robert Cordaro and A.J. Munchak, who were convicted of
extorting money from companies that did business with the county. Prosecutors
said Mr. Hughes acted as the go-between in passing money from the businesses to
Mr. Cordaro.

The indictment of Mr. Hughes which was issued Tuesday but remained sealed until
today. U.S. District Magistrate Judge Karoline Mehalchick arraigned and released
him. Court documents do not indicate if he was required to post bail.

                                US Official News

                           November 27, 2012 Tuesday

Tennessee: Supreme Court affirms disbarment of attorney who pleaded guilty to
willful tax evasion

LENGTH: 253  words

DATELINE: Nashville


Administrative Office of the Courts, State of Tennessee has issued the following
news release:

In a unanimous opinion, the Tennessee Supreme Court ruled today that the
Chancery Court for Carter County properly disbarred Thomas Ewing Cowan from the
practice of law in Tennessee.

In 2009, Mr. Cowan pleaded guilty in federal district court to the felony
offense of willful attempt to defeat or evade the payment of taxes, for which
Mr. Cowan was sentenced to one year of imprisonment and ordered to pay $270,000
in restitution.

A disciplinary hearing panel convened by the Board of Professional
Responsibility (BPR) found Mr. Cowan's admitted tax evasion and several other
aggravating factors, including a prior disciplinary history, called for a
suspension of Mr. Cowan's law license.

On appeal by the BPR, the chancery court modified the determination of the panel
and disbarred Mr. Cowan, relying on the American Bar Association's Standards for
Imposing Lawyer Sanctions. The chancellor emphasized that willful tax evasion
requires an affirmative act and that Mr. Cowan had not acknowledged the
seriousness of his misconduct.

The Supreme Court affirmed the chancery court's judgment disbarring Mr. Cowan
from the practice of law. The Court noted that other states have disbarred
lawyers for willful tax evasion and Mr. Cowan had a significant history of
ethical violations, including two suspensions, three public reprimands, and
fifteen private admonishments.

For more information please visit: http://www.tsc.state.tn.us

                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                             April 15, 2011 Friday

Indicted capitalist Carlow crushed businesses, spirits

BYLINE: Brian Bowling and Carl Prine

LENGTH: 1018 words


A day after he and his housemate were indicted on federal tax evasion charges,
Michael P. Carlow was at his sparse office in a closed Neville Island cement
plant.

In the past 20 years, Carlow has gone from the heights of the Frick Building,
Downtown, to a federal prison in Morgantown, W.Va., to the drab office near
Neville Island's southeastern tip.

Along the way, he went from being called a savior of several struggling
companies to the man responsible for their corpses, including the D.L. Clark Co.
of Clark Bar fame, Pittsburgh Brewing and its Iron City Beer, and City Pride
Bakery -- viewed as the model for a rebirth of manufacturing in Pittsburgh.

On Wednesday, a federal grand jury indicted Carlow, 60, of Upper St. Clair and
his housemate, Elizabeth G. Jones, 50, on charges of tax evasion and conspiracy.
The nine-count indictment claims the pair used a series of companies to hide
Carlow's assets to prevent the Internal Revenue Service from seizing his money
and properties to satisfy the $6.4 million he still owes in unpaid taxes,
penalties and interest from his 1990s business dealings.

The news elated some and dredged up bitter memories for others.

Chuck Geiger, 67, of Brighton Heights is still angry about Carlow's role in the
demise of City Pride, an employee-owned Lawrenceville business that grew out of
the closure of 100-year-old Braun bakery.

Geiger and 43 other former Braun employees had pooled their money and their
sweat to line up public and private investors, get letters of intent from Giant
Eagle, Shop 'n Save and other potential customers, and build the bakery from the
ground up. Investors included the state, which kicked in about $1.1 million, and
a group of nuns, he said.

"We spent a couple of years working around the clock to build it up," he said.

Then, almost overnight, Carlow gained control of the company in 1993, Geiger
said. Eleven months later, Carlow shut it down.

"He ruined everything," Geiger said.

Carlow spent six years in prison after he pleaded guilty in May 1996 to eight
charges, including bank fraud, tax evasion, wire fraud and embezzling from an
employee benefit fund. The charges came out of a $31 million check-kiting scheme
Carlow used to fuel his purchases.

Sitting in a paper-strewn office powered by a portable generator, Carlow on
Thursday declined to talk on the record. Wearing a long-sleeved Ralph Lauren
polo shirt, bluejeans and running shoes, he politely fended off questions while
sitting at a worn meeting table.

The office lies a couple of hundred yards from a padlocked double gate watched
by a security guard. The guard and Carlow were the only two people in evidence
at the plant that GMI Land Co. bought from Kosmos Cement Co. in June 2007.

Several of Carlow's more recent business ventures, allegedly orchestrated
through Jones, have suffered similar fates.

In 2008, Platinum Funding Group of New York funneled $25 million to Jones for
the purchase of Cumberland Valley Fabricators, a metal shop in Maryland, and
Waddell Construction, a Northern Virginia contractor -- two firms that annually
combined for more than $20 million in revenues, records show.

Both companies soon plummeted into insolvency. Platinum founder Eyal Levy was
elated yesterday when he learned from a Trib reporter that Carlow and Jones had
been charged.

"That's fantastic!" said Levy. "They stole from us. It is about time."

Levy estimated that Platinum lost more than $1 million in the deal the venture
capital firm made with Jones that was brokered through Carlow.

Richard Waddell, founder of Waddell Construction, said Carlow snookered him,
too.

"I really don't want to talk about it," he said. "But everyone needs to
understand that he took me for $1.5 million."

Downtown attorney Richard J. Parks said Florida-based Utica Leasco, an equipment
rental company, is in for nearly $3 million with Jones for the former Neville
Island cement plant, and his clients have not been paid anything by Jones in 30
months. The company wants either its money back or the property to be sold in a
sheriff's sale.

"We've been trying to get a solution for 2 1/2 years for this, and Carlow is
still there," said Parks. "That's how slowly the system works."

Hearing that Carlow was selling parts of the plant for scrap, Utica Leasco sent
a crew to inspect the 11-acre site. The crew discovered that much of the salvage
had indeed been trucked away, Parks said.

A court order allows Neville Island Supply, another Carlow company, to grind
slag aggregate to make cement, but the stainless steel flails inside the drum
that do the grinding were sold for scrap and so was the copper wiring needed to
power the equipment, according to Parks.

Carlow first came to Pittsburgh's attention in 1991 when he bought the D.L.
Clark Co. and seemingly rescued its trademark Clark Bar from extinction. The
next year, he bought Pittsburgh Brewing, which made Iron City Beer. His stated
intent was to turn the floundering companies around, and civic leaders hailed
him as a savior of the hometown brands.

At the same time, Geiger and his colleagues had City Pride bakery up and
running. While the company was not perfect, Geiger doesn't believe its financial
condition was as bad as press stories at the time made it sound. He doesn't know
directly because he was in charge of shipping and receiving rather than
finances, but he knows they were busy and their customers were happy.

Their efforts attracted national attention, and Geiger ended up traveling to
Chicago and New York to talk with other bakery employees trying to save their
companies, and he was interviewed by ABC News anchor Peter Jennings.

"As far as I'm concerned, we were doing pretty good," Geiger said.

When Carlow gained control of the company, he brought in his own people, and
sales fell when the bakery started producing inferior bread, Geiger said. Carlow
said at the time that the company had lost $4 million over the 11 months he
owned it.

Geiger said he and the other original investors eventually lost all their money
and effort they had put into the company.

"He ran us into the ground," Geiger said.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 April 6, 2001, Friday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

VICTIMS AND WATCHDOGS DESCRIBE TAX EVASION SCAMS ON THE INTERNET;
WITNESSES TELL SENATE PANEL THAT IRS SHOULD DO MORE TO WARN GULLIBLE

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A5

LENGTH: 481 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTONWARNINGS; TAX EVASION; SCAMS; SCHEMES FRAUD; CONTACT
INFORMATION; INTERNAL REVENUE; SERVICE


Tax evasion scams are spreading on the Internet, victims and self-appointed
watchdogs told the Senate Finance Committee on Thursday. The witnesses said the
IRS isn't doing enough to pursue promoters or warn gullible taxpayers.

Aaron Bazar of North Potomac, Md., said he lost $ 8,000 after responding to an
unsolicited e-mail touting what appeared to be a way to legally eliminate
federal income taxes - but was actually an illegal pyramid scheme.

His skepticism wavered when he was given evidence that other people had done the
same thing. He was also shown false claims that the 16th Amendment creating the
income tax was never properly ratified or that paying taxes is purely voluntary.

"If somebody wants to steal from people, the Internet is the place to do it,"
said Bazar, who quit the scheme months later after making no money. "The chances
of getting caught, in my opinion, are virtually nil."

Official estimates are difficult to find, but IRS Commissioner Charles Rossotti
said there could be as much as $ 3 trillion in assets hidden in offshore bank
accounts, one popular way of avoiding taxes. Senators cited an independent
estimate that $ 300 billion a year in taxes are avoided through phony trusts,
fake charity or religious setups and offshore accounts.

"We've got a problem," said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont.

While these tax scams have been around for years, they are being marketed
globally via the Internet. The IRS points to its 117 criminal convictions and a
raid Feb. 28 by agents on dozens of promoters as evidence that it is making
inroads. There is also information warning taxpayers about trusts and other
scams on its own Internet site.

"We are definitely focused on this in both public education and enforcement,"
Rossotti said.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, chairman of the Finance Committee, said taxpayers
should take care themselves when tempted to sign up for anything that appears to
give a free tax ride. Taxpayers can be liable for penalties of 75 percent of the
underpaid taxes in addition to the taxes owed.

Grassley suggested these tips:

* Check with an accountant or attorney before signing over any money. Be
particularly wary if the promoter says the scheme is one your accountant or
attorney won't understand. Or you can check with the IRS and report suspected
fraud at 800-829-0433.

* While trusts can be a valid form of estate planning, some are thinly veiled
tax avoidance scams marketed under these names: pure trust, common law trust,
constitutional trust, complex trust, sovereign trust, unincorporated business
organization and pure equity trust.

* Watch for warning signs, such as a promise to reduce income or self-employment
tax, deductions for personal expenses paid by a trust, use of back-dated
documents, high fees to be offset by tax benefits and use of post office boxes
as trust addresses.

                          The Calgary Herald (Alberta)

                             January 3, 2014 Friday
                                 Early Edition

Beanie Baby billionaire seeks probation for tax evasion

BYLINE: David Voreacos, Bloomberg

SECTION: CALGARY BUSINESS; Pg. C6

LENGTH: 450 words

DATELINE: NEWARK, N.J.


H. Ty Warner, the billionaire creator of Beanie Baby plush toys, asked a U.S.
judge to give him probation, not prison, for evading taxes on secret Swiss
accounts that held as much as $107 million US.

Warner, 69, faces 46 to 57 months in prison under non-binding guidelines when
he's sentenced Jan. 14 in Chicago. The maker of plush toys, who also runs
hotels, wants U.S. District Judge Charles Kocoras to impose a term of probation
with community service, according to a Dec. 31 court filing.

Warner is among more than 100 people prosecuted in the past five years during a
U.S. crackdown on offshore tax evasion. His lawyers argued that "dozens of
individuals who engaged in the exact same conduct with respect to undisclosed
overseas accounts" got probation.

"This case concerns an isolated event in Ty's otherwise law-abiding life, during
which he has paid approximately $1 billion in taxes," according to the filing.
"There is no reason to believe prison time is necessary to prevent him from
engaging in tax evasion again."

Warner owns TY Inc., which makes Beanie Babies, and Ty Warner Hotels &; Resorts,
the operator of the Four Seasons Hotel in New York and other facilities. He
pleaded guilty Oct. 2 to evading $5.5 million US in taxes on assets in Swiss
accounts he hid from the Internal Revenue Service.

Under the federal guidelines, Kocoras can consider such factors as other
sentences around the U.S., Warner's charitable gifts, and his pledge to pay
penalties, back taxes and interest of more than $69 million. Warner also asked
the judge to weigh that he was denied entry into an IRS amnesty program that has
let more than 38,000 Americans with offshore accounts avoid prosecution.

Warner's name was on a list of account data for 285 Americans that his former
bank, UBS, gave to the Justice Department in avoiding prosecution in February
2009. Zurich-based UBS, the biggest Swiss bank, also paid $780 million US and
admitted to fostering tax evasion. UBS later turned over 4,450 more names.

After Warner applied for the voluntary disclosure program in September 2009, the
IRS rejected him because it wasn't available to those already known to the
agency, the filing said. A U.S. pre-sentence report cited by Warner's lawyers
said the IRS had learned of his Swiss accounts "a few years before UBS turned
over client account information" to the U.S.

"Ty's behaviour was no different legally or factually from that of tens of
thousands of taxpayers who were never sentenced - or even prosecuted - because
they were admitted into IRS voluntary disclosure programs," according to the
filing, known as a sentencing memorandum.

Warner's lawyers proposed that the judge impose "substantial community service."

                                US Official News

                           February 14, 2017 Tuesday

Washington: Albuquerque-Area Construction Contractor Pleads Guilty to Federal
Tax Evasion and Fraud Charges

LENGTH: 439  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



  Joseph Dubois, 37, of Albuquerque, N.M., pled guilty last week in federal
court to evading federal taxes evasion and fraudulently presenting a fictitious
surety bond. The guilty plea was announced by U.S. Attorney Damon P. Martinez,
Special Agent in Charge Ismael Nevarez Jr. of the Phoenix Field Office of IRS
Criminal Investigation, and Special Agent in Charge David A. House of the
Department of the Interior, Office of Inspector General.





 Dubois, the owner and operator of Regency Development Group (RDG), a
construction contractor located in Albuquerque, was charged by felony
information with tax evasion and presenting a fictitious surety bond. According
to the information, Dubois evaded his federal corporate tax obligations from
Nov. 2011 to Oct. 2013, by opening and concealing a new bank account to
circumvent tax liens, removing and dissipating assets to avoid their seizure,
and by underreporting income and gross receipts. The information also alleged
that Dubois created a materially false document, a surety bond, and fraudulently
presented it as an actual security and financial instrument under the authority
of a surety company.



 On Feb. 8, 2017, Dubois pled guilty to the two charges in the information. In
entering the guilty plea, Dubois admitted that as owner and operator of RDG, he
evaded payment of $237,251 in federal employment taxes for tax years 2010
through 2012. Specifically, Dubois admitted that from Nov. 2011 through Oct.
2013, he opened a bank account which he used to divert funds in an attempt to
circumvent liens and levies, and to evade payment of his tax liabilities. Dubois
also acknowledged underreporting income and gross receipts to the IRS.



 According to Dubois's plea agreement, in Dec. 2011, RDG entered into contracts
with the Ramah Navajo School Board to renovate a building at the Pine Hill
School. The contracts required RDG to obtain and provide a surety bond. On Feb.
10, 2012, Dubois produced a materially false and fictitious surety bond which
appeared to be an actual security under the authority of the Western Surety
Company.



 At sentencing, Dubois faces a statutory maximum penalty of 25 years in federal
prison. A sentencing hearing has yet to be scheduled.



 This case was investigated by the Albuquerque office of IRS Criminal
Investigation and Department of the Interior, Office of Inspector General, and
is being prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeremy Pena.

                     The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

                             July 6, 2016 Wednesday

Former Sonoma County developer Jay Soderling sentenced to three years for tax
evasion

BYLINE: Mary Callahan, The Press Democrat, Santa Rosa, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 248 words


July 06--Former Sonoma County developer and savings and loan officer Jay Scott
Soderling, whose history of financial fraud dates back to the mid-1980s, was
sentenced Tuesday to three years in federal prison for tax evasion and
conspiracy to defraud the United States government by hiding assets, the U.S.
Attorney's Office said.

The Santa Rosa man and his wife, Jessica Lynn Soderling, were convicted after a
five-day trial in December of shifting money into different accounts to avoid
detection, thus allowing him to claim he could not pay $90,000 in back taxes
even as he purchased a luxury sports car and a boat, authorities said.

Soderling's trail of deceit dates back at least to the 1980s when he and his
brother were convicted of looting $16.5 million from investors in their company,
Golden Pacific Savings and Loan. He has served at least two stints in federal
prison already. Soderling will serve three years of supervised probation and has
been ordered to pay restitution of $345,697, federal authorities said.

Jessica Soderling, convicted of a single count of conspiracy, was sentenced in
April to three months of probation and ordered to pay restitution of $153,242,
the U.S. Attorney's Office said.

brother were convicted of looting $16.5 million from investors in their company,
Golden Pacific Savings and Loan. He has served at least two stints in federal
prison already. Soderling will serve three years of supervised probation and has
been ordered to pay restitution of $345,697, federal authorities said.

Jessica Soderling, convicted of a single count of conspiracy, was sentenced in
April to three months of probation and ordered to pay restitution of $153,242,
the U.S. Attorney's Office said.

                              May 23, 2016 Monday

Sandy resident faces tax evasion charges in Nevada

BYLINE: The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; State

LENGTH: 184 words


A Utah resident and former attorney for the IRS has pleaded not guilty to a
federal court indictment in Nevada charging him with tax evasion.

A grand jury in Las Vegas indicted Craig P. Orrock, 68, Sandy, on two tax
evasion counts and one of attempting to interfere with the IRS' administration
of tax laws.

The April 28 indictment alleges that from 2001 to 2010, Orrock attempted to
evade paying taxes owed for the years 2000 through 2006 by filing false
bankruptcy petitions and fraudulent tax returns and offers to settle with the
IRS. He also allegedly tried to evade taxes due for the year 2007 by concealing
his ownership of property held in the name of a straw owner.

Asked to comment on the allegations, Orrock said in a text message, "In my
opinion this investigation started after I and several seniors that were the
victims of a Las Vegas Ponzi scheme requested a congressional investigation of
Las Vegas IRS for arbitrarily denying them tax refunds they were lawfully due."

If convicted, he faces up to five years in prison on the tax evasion charges and
up to three years on the interference count.

                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                           February 2, 2012 Thursday

Stillwater couple pleads guilty to mortgage fraud, tax evasion

BYLINE: By John Welbes jwelbes@pioneerpress.com

SECTION: BREAKING; Business

LENGTH: 449 words


After initially facing federal charges on numerous fraudulent mortgage deals
dating to 2001, James and Teresa Hoffman cut a deal and pleaded guilty Friday to
lesser crimes.

Appearing in federal court in Minneapolis, the Stillwater couple admitted to
their respective roles in a scheme to sell their Hastings home to straw buyers
for more than it was worth, reap a cash windfall and then not pay taxes on the
gain.

The Hastings home sold in one instance for $1.2 million, and $219,429 in excess
cash was pocketed by the Hoffmans.

James Hoffman, 51, pleaded guilty to an illegal monetary transaction and tax
evasion, which could put him behind bars for 5 to 6-1/2 years. Teresa Hoffman,
52, could spend 18 months to two years in prison for her guilty plea to one
count of tax evasion.

Both are expected to seek shorter prison terms at their sentencing hearings in
coming weeks.

The Hoffmans initially were indicted in October on multiple charges of
defrauding mortgage lenders out of more than $5 million over several years - a
list of crimes that could have put them in prison for more than 20 years.

In late January, though, federal prosecutors filed new charging papers that
trimmed the number of charges and apparently paved the way for a plea deal.

At Friday's hearings, prosecutors said that with the guilty pleas, they would
agree not to pursue charges against a relative of the Hoffmans.

James Hoffman's plea to an illegal transaction is tied to a $20,125 check he
wrote so that his college-age child could attend a "Semester at Sea" program.
The money came from the proceeds of an alleged mortgage fraud.

The Hastings home was sold several times to straw buyers, each time generating
excess cash from the unsuspecting lender. James Hoffman also pleaded guilty to
evading $249,000 in taxes between 1997 and 2012, tied to a company he controlled
at the time.

Teresa Hoffman's guilty plea resulted from a failure to pay $258,561 in federal
taxes - cash generated fraudulently.

Their case has a court-appointed receiver who controls the Hoffman's assets
derived from their criminal activity. On Friday, James Hoffman's attorney, Peter
Wold, asked that the conditions of his release, prior to sentencing, allow
Hoffman to travel to Wisconsin. That was opposed by David MacLaughlin, the
prosecutor on the case, because all the fraudulent assets had been kept at
Wisconsin banks.

U.S. District Court Judge David Doty agreed to restrict James Hoffman to travel
in Minnesota.

Teresa Hoffman avoided any limits on her travel while on release, though
MacLaughlin said she can't take trips at "someone's bidding to squirrel money
around."

John Welbes can be reached at 651-228-2175. Follow him at Twitter.com/jwelbes .

                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                           October 13, 2011 Thursday

Man to repay more than $178G in fraud of Salem, N.H. firm

BYLINE: By Lisa Redmond, lredmond@lowellsun.com

SECTION: NEWS; Local

LENGTH: 331 words


BOSTON -- A 65-year-old Windham, N.H., man will spend a year in federal prison
and have to repay the IRS more than $178,000 after pleading guilty to tax
evasion and conspiracy charges.

In U.S. District Court recently, Christopher McGadden, of 3 Granite Hill Road,
was sentenced to a year in federal prison followed by two years of supervised
release, a $7,500 fine, and restitution to the IRS in the amount of $178,735.
McGadden is scheduled to begin his sentence on Nov. 8.

Last March, McGadden, the general manager of Xcel Fire Protection Inc., pleaded
guilty to charges of conspiracy to defraud the U.S. government and tax evasion.

According to the U.S. Attorney's Office, McGadden allegedly participated in a
conspiracy with real-estate broker Raymond Stebbins, 69, of Quincy, to divert
funds from Xcel, a fire-protection sprinkler business based in Salem, N.H. and
Weymouth, to various corporate bank accounts, which the two men then used to pay
themselves. But in doing so they failed to report that income to the IRS.

Prosecutors allege the conspiracy began in 2001 and continued until May 2009.

Stebbins is charged with conspiracy, tax evasion, false statements and theft of
public money. He has pleaded innocent to the charges. Stebbins' case is pending.
His next court date is Dec. 12 for status.

According to prosecutors, Stebbins allegedly submitted fictitious invoices to
Xcel billing for goods provided and/or services rendered by one of several
companies operated by Stebbins. McGadden made sure the fake invoices were paid
to Stebbins.

Stebbins allegedly opened several business bank accounts which were used to
deposit checks from Xcel. Stebbins would allegedly cash the checks, keeping a 10
percent fee for himself and giving McGadden the remaining 90 percent. Stebbins
allegedly also diverted checks from Xcel custmers to his business accounts,
sharing that money in a 90/10 spit with McGadden.

Neither Stebbins or McGadden allegedly reported the funds on their IRS tax
returns.

                             National Post (Canada)

                   August 15, 2002 Thursday National Edition

Tyco wants tax case dropped: Former CEO first in state to be charged on sales
tax evasion

SOURCE: Bloomberg News

BYLINE: David Voreacos and David Glovin

SECTION: Financial Post: U.S. Business; Pg. FP12

LENGTH: 530 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK

NEW YORK - Dennis Kozlowski, the former head of Tyco International Ltd. who's
accused of evading sales tax on US$13.2-million of art purchases and tampering
with evidence, will ask a judge to dismiss the tax charge, his lawyer said
yesterday.

Mr. Kozlowski, who made more than US$300-million in his last three years as
Tyco's chief executive officer, was indicted June 4 for conspiring with dealers
to avoid paying more than US$1-million in New York state sales tax on art he
bought for his Manhattan apartment. He was later accused of removing a phony
shipping document from company files in Boca Raton, Fla.

After a court hearing yesterday, Mr. Kozlowski's lawyer, Stephen Kaufman, said
he will ask State Supreme Court Justice Michael Obus to dismiss the tax case,
focusing in part on the argument that Mr. Kozlowski is the first buyer to face
sales tax evasion charges in New York.

"Frankly, I think it's silly," said Manhattan defence lawyer Stanley Arkin, who
briefly defended former Tyco general counsel Mark Belnick in a civil suit by the
company claiming he got millions in unapproved payments. "It's the buyer who's
getting the tax benefit, not the seller."

Mr. Arkin said the law doesn't distinguish between the buyer and the seller in a
sales tax evasion case. "They both work together to screw the state," he said.

In the mid-1980s, Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau prosecuted the
most elite jewelers in New York, including Cartier Inc., Tiffany & Co., and Van
Cleef & Arpels. They were accused of shipping empty boxes to out-of-state
addresses to help their clients avoid sales taxes. The three stores paid
millions in fines.

Mr. Kaufman claims Mr. Kozlowski is the first purchaser in New York indicted for
failure to pay sales taxes.

"It's unusual," he told reporters. "It's unique."

"That argument is somewhat disingenuous," said Tom Curran, a Manhattan criminal
defence attorney who worked under Mr. Morgenthau as a securities fraud
prosecutor for three years. "They're basically saying, 'It's unfair that you
targeted me as opposed to the other wrongdoer.' The prosecutors would say,
'We'll get to them whenever we get to them."'

Mr. Curran theorized that perhaps Manhattan prosecutors were able to charge Mr.
Kozlowski because of information furnished by art dealers. "You don't look the
other way on a buyer when we talk about a tax evasion of the size we're talking
about," he said.

Mr. Morgenthau's office will respond to Mr. Kozlowski's claim after receiving
papers from his lawyers, spokeswoman Barbara Thompson said.

Bermuda-based Tyco, a conglomerate created through hundreds of acquisitions, is
under investigation by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission for alleged
accounting irregularities. Manhattan prosecutors are also investigating the
company, the Wall Street Journal has reported.

Mr. Kozlowski, who remains free on US$3-million bail, is accused in a 14-count
indictment of conspiring with art dealers to dodge New York's sales tax. He's
also charged with removing a document that falsely indicated five paintings had
been shipped from New York to Tyco's U.S. headquarters in Exeter, N.H.

                   August 15, 2002 Thursday National Edition

Tyco wants tax case dropped: Former CEO first in state to be charged on sales

                               The New York Times

              February 13, 1988, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

Financier Avoids Jail in Deal to Aid Homeless

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1063 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, Feb. 12


The financier Victor Posner avoided a jail sentence today on Federal tax evasion
charges when he agreed to spend $3 million to help homeless men, women and
children in south Florida and to devote 20 hours a week for five years to
working with them.

Federal District Judge Eugene Spellman set those terms in sentencing Mr. Posner
to five years' probation. He also ordered him to pay fines, penalties and
interest, expected to total $3.8 million. Mr. Posner pleaded no contest on Sept.
29 to 10 counts of tax evasion.

Federal prosecutors had asked for a prison sentence for Mr. Posner, 69 years
old. The Miami Beach industrialist was accused of evading more than $1.2 million
in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land donated to Miami
Christian College.

Faced 40 Years in Prison

Assistant United States Attorney Neil Cartusciello told the court: ''Mr. Posner
lied to the Internal Revenue Service and he corrupted others. In his statement
to the probation officers he makes the same claims and tells the same lies. He
doesn't show he's remorseful, that he's sorry.''

With a no-contest plea, a defendant does not admit guilt but indicates he will
offer no defense. For sentencing purposes it is the same as a guilty plea or
conviction.

Mr. Posner (pronounced PAHZ-ner) faced a maximum sentence of 40 years in prison,
the prosecutors said.

Judge Spellman said that if he had decided on a prison sentence, Mr. Posner
would have served no more than six to nine months because of his age.

Instead, Mr. Posner was given 60 days to develop a plan to help the homeless.
The $3 million he will spend carrying out that plan will not be tax deductible,
the judge said. In addition, he must provide a total of 5,000 hours of community
service.

''It was a unique settlement to a unique case,'' said Edward Bennett Williams of
Washington, Mr. Posner's chief defense counsel. Judge Spellman indicated during
today's hearing that Mr. Williams had proposed the unusual alternative sentence
privately last month.

Judge Spellman sternly warned Mr. Posner not to challenge the terms of his
probation and asked him if he understood that once he agreed to it terms the
sentence was ''non-negotiable and unappealable.''

Mr. Posner responded, ''Yes, Your Honor.''

If Mr. Posner attempts to challenge the terms - for instance, by filing for
bankruptcy protection - he will go to prison, the judge said.

Mr. Posner will have to repay the $1.2 million in taxes, as well as a $600,000
penalty and interest that is expected to be about $2 million. In addition he was
fined $75,000. He must also pay the costs of his prosecution, which may reach $1
million, Federal officials said.

The defendant, a short man with wavy silver hair and a ruddy complexion,
responded softly and affirmatively when Judge Spellman asked him if, as an
alternative to going to prison, he would allow the court to order that he pay a
sum of money far beyond the limits set by law to finance the project for the
homeless.

Mr. Posner, one of the highest-paid American executives, with a salary estimated
at $8.5 million in 1986, controls 40 public companies. His personal fortune has
been estimated at $180 million.

Some Posner Holdings

Among his diverse holdings are the Chesapeake Financial Corporation, which owns
the Royal Crown Companies and Arby's Inc.; the DWG Corporation; the NVF
Corporation and the Pennsylvania Engineering Corporation. He also holds
controlling interests in Sharon Steel, an NVF unit, and the Graniteville
Company, a DWG textile unit.

Sharon has filed for Federal bankruptcy protection, as has Mr. Posner's Evans
Products Company.

Mr. Posner's 1985 takeover of the Fischbach Corporation is being studied by
Federal investigators to determine whether improper insider trading took place.

The son of a Russian immigrant, Mr. Posner dropped out of high school and
started his business career selling real estate in Baltimore. He was a
millionaire by the age of 25.

A Nine-Year Legal Battle

The sentencing ended a nine-year legal battle. Mr. Williams contended today that
Mr. Posner's case was the only instance in the 75-year history of the graduated
Federal income tax in which a taxpayer had been prosecuted for overstating the
value of a charitable gift.

Mr. Posner and William Scharrer, a Miami real estate broker, were charged with
conspiring to set a false appraisal of $125,000 an acre on a 16-acre tract of
land Mr. Posner donated to Miami Christian College in 1975. Records showed that
he had purchased the tract for $2,500 an acre in 1967.

Mr. Scharrer was convicted of aiding and abetting in tax violations in 1984 and
was sentenced to 18 months in prison, an outcome he is appealing. Mr. Posner was
tried separately and convicted in 1986, but Judge Spellman set aside the verdict
and declared a mistrial when it was learned that jurors were exposed to
prejudicial information during the trial, including newspaper accounts of the
proceedings.

Problems of Homeless Cited

During today's hearing, Judge Spellman said that the problems of the homeless
were worsening daily and that thousands of children were without shelter or day
care. He then outlined his plan.

He ordered Mr. Posner to develop a proposal within 60 days on ways to address
the problems of the homeless, submit it to an advisory committee of community
leaders for approval and then be prepared to spend ''at least $3 million'' to
implement it.

''It is contemplated,'' the judge said, ''that your personal participation over
the five-year period will be 5,000 community hours - about 20 hours a week.''

Employee Assistance Ruled Out

Mr. Posner was cautioned not to use current or former employees to assist him in
the project, which the judge described as ''one you personally and financially
take part in.''

The judge directed that Mr. Posner spend five hours a day for one day in each of
the next eight weeks at Camillus House, a downtown Miami mission for the
homeless.

He said Mr. Posner could put in his community service in Dade County, where
Miami is situated; Broward County, which contains Fort Lauderdale, or Palm Beach
County.

Outside the courtroom Mr. Posner would not comment on the sentence other than to
say he had a long history of contributing to charities.

''He is very enthusiastic about this work,'' Mr. Williams said as his client
smiled.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                               The New York Times

               July 23, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition
                              Correction Appended

IMPEACHMENT OF U.S. JUDGE PASSES HOUSE

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1281 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 22


The House of Representatives impeached a Federal official for the first time in
50 years today, charging a judge from Nevada with tax evasion and bringing
''disrepute'' on the Federal judiciary.

The 406-to-0 vote, in effect an indictment, opens the way for a Senate trial of
the 69-year-old judge, Harry E. Claiborne of Las Vegas. He is serving a two-year
Federal sentence for tax evasion but has refused to resign and continues to
collect his $78,000 salary at the Maxwell Air Force Base stockade in Montgomery,
Ala.

The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said the trial would probably
not begin until the fall.

Judiciary in 'Disrepute'

In refusing to give up his post, Judge Claiborne contends that he was the victim
of a vendetta by Government prosecutors who were angered by his actions in the
courtroom. He was convicted of failing to pay taxes on more than $100,000 in
income.

The four articles of impeachment, which repeat the tax charges and also accuse
Judge Claiborne of bringing ''disrepute'' on the Federal court system, are the
equivalent to the counts of a grand jury's indictment.

Acting as a trial jury, the Senate must now decide if the charges warrant
removal of Judge Claiborne from a job he could otherwise return to after leaving
prison. Federal judges are granted lifetime tenure.

No one defended Judge Claiborne in the debate this evening. Instead, House
members rose somberly to agree that Judge Claiborne had disgraced the judiciary
and should have resigned long ago.

''Judge Claiborne is more than an embarrassment,'' said Representative Hamilton
Fish, a Republican from upstate New York. ''He is a disgrace - an affront to the
judicial office he was appointed to serve.''

Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, said there
was ''a sense of urgency to impeach Claiborne.''

''Every day that passes,'' he said, ''law-abiding and hard-working taxpayers pay
nearly $217 to Claiborne in salary.''

Robert W. Kastenmeier, a Wisconsin Democrat who will act as one of the
prosecutors against the judge, said: ''Let a trial commence in the United States
Senate. Judge Claiborne should be impeached and removed from office.''

Appointed in 1978

Judge Claiborne, who had been a well-known and respected criminal defense lawyer
in Nevada, was appointed to the bench in 1978 by President Carter, and he was
named chief judge in 1980.

In 1984, Judge Claiborne became the first sitting Federal judge in the nation's
history to be found guilty of a felony, convicted of filing false income tax
returns.

Prosecutors charged that he failed to pay taxes on $106,000 in income he
received in 1979 and 1980 for legal work performed before he became a judge.

He is the 11th Federal judge impeached by the House and the first since Judge
Halsted L. Ritter of Florida was convicted of tax evasion at a Senate trial in
1936. Judge Ritter and three other Federal officials, all of them judges, have
been removed from office by the Senate.

The cumbersome machinery of impeachment was last set in motion in 1974 for
President Nixon, but his resignation ended Congressional efforts to try Mr.
Nixon for his part in the Watergate scandal.

High Crimes and Misdeameanors

The first three articles of impeachment against Judge Claiborne are based on the
judge's criminal conduct and conviction. They charge that he is ''guilty of
misbehavior and was and is guilty of a high crime and misdemeanor, and by such
conduct, warrants impeachment and trial and removal from office.''

The final article says Judge Claiborne's actions have ''brought disrepute on the
Federal courts and the administration of justice.''

Under the Constitution, impeachable crimes are defined as ''treason, bribery, or
other high crimes and misdemeanors.''

Congressional aides said the articles of impeachment would be formally presented
to the full Senate within a week. At a meeting Thursday, the Senate Rules
Committee is scheduled to discuss trial procedures.

Dale Tate, a spokesman for Senator Dole, said the Senate leadership would
probably appoint a 12-member committee to hear the evidence against Judge
Claiborne. ''The committee would actually do the gumshoe work,'' she said.

Once the panel completes its work, the full Senate will convene to hear final
arguments and vote, she said.

Work Could Go On

Lawmakers have said the case would not necessarily hold up legislation, since
other business could be handled during recesses in the trial. ''The hope is this
won't take terribly long,'' Ms. Tate said.

Under the Constitution, conviction would require concurrence of two-thirds of
the senators present for the vote.

In many ways, the trial would be like any other: witnesses would testify and be
cross-examined. The Senate is expected to appoint a presiding officer, possibly
Vice President Bush, to serve as a judge and rule on motions of evidence.

House members serve as prosecutors, or managers, and Representative William J.
Hughes, the New Jersey Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary
subcommittee on crime and a former prosecutor, has been selected to lead a
nine-man prosecution team.

The other Democratic members are Peter W. Rodino Jr. of New Jersey, the chairman
of the Judiciary Committzee; Mr. Kastenmeier; Romano L. Mazzoli of Kentucky, and
Dan Glickman of Kansas.

The Republicans are Mr. Fish, the ranking minority member of the Judiciary
Committee; Michael DeWine of Ohio, Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, and Thomas N.
Kindness of Ohio.

The trial is expected to offer Judge Claiborne a forum for his charges that
Federal agents and prosecutors broke the law in the investigation that led to
his conviction.

Judge Claiborne was tried twice. The first ended with jurors unable to agree on
the charges, which ranged from tax evasion to the taking of bribes from Joseph
Conforte, the owner of a brothel near Reno. At the second trial, the Government
abandoned counts involving Mr. Conforte's testimony and confined its evidence to
the tax charges.

IMPEACHMENT: 13 PREVIOUS CASES

The House of Representatives voted yesterday to impeach Federal District Judge
Harry E. Claiborne of Nevada, who has refused to resign despite a conviction and
prison term for tax evasion. Below is a list of all previous cases sent to the
Senate for trial after impeachment by the House.

William Blount: Senator from Tennessee, charges dismissed in 1799.

John Pickering: Federal judge in New Hampshire, removed from office in 1804
after charges of irregular judicial procedures, loose morals and drunkenness.

Samuel Chase: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, acquitted in 1805.

James Peck: Federal judge in Missouri, acquitted in 1831.

West Humphreys: Federal judge in Tennessee, removed from office in 1862 for
advocating secession and accepting office as a Confederate judge.

Andrew Johnson: President of the United States, acquitted in 1868.

Mark H. Delahay: Federal judge in Kansas, resigned in 1873 before Senate trial,
charged with misconduct in office and intoxication.

William Belknap: Secretary of War, acquitted in 1876.

Charles Swayne: Federal judge in Florida, acquitted in 1905.

Robert Archbald: Associate judge of the United States Commerce Court, removed
from office 1913, charged with using improper influence and accepting favors
from litigants.

George English: Federal judge in Illinois, resigned in 1926 before Senate trial
began, charged with partiality, tyranny and oppression.

Harold Louderback: Federal judge in California, acquitted in 1933.

Halsted Ritter: Federal judge in Florida, removed from office in 1936, charged
with filing false tax returns. (Source: United Press International)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: August 11, 1986, Monday, Late City Final Edition

CORRECTION:
A listing by United Press International on July 23, of Federal impeachments that
preceded Judge Harry E. Claiborne's, incompletely described the outcome of the
1876 move to impeach Secretary of War William W. Belknap. The House voted
unanimously for impeachment, and Mr. Belknap resigned the same day. The Senate
failed to muster the two-thirds needed to convict him; most of those voting for
acquittal said they did so because the Senate had no jurisdiction over an
official who had resigned.

Rodino Jr. (NYT/Paul Hosefros) (page B8)

                                US Official News

                           February 14, 2017 Tuesday

Albuquerque-Area Construction Contractor Pleads Guilty to Federal Tax Evasion
and Fraud Charges

LENGTH: 447  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, District of New Mexico has
issued the following news release:



  Joseph Dubois, 37, of Albuquerque, N.M., pled guilty last week in federal
court to evading federal taxes evasion and fraudulently presenting a fictitious
surety bond. The guilty plea was announced by U.S. Attorney Damon P. Martinez,
Special Agent in Charge Ismael Nevarez Jr. of the Phoenix Field Office of IRS
Criminal Investigation, and Special Agent in Charge David A. House of the
Department of the Interior, Office of Inspector General.









 Dubois, the owner and operator of Regency Development Group (RDG), a
construction contractor located in Albuquerque, was charged by felony
information with tax evasion and presenting a fictitious surety bond. According
to the information, Dubois evaded his federal corporate tax obligations from
Nov. 2011 to Oct. 2013, by opening and concealing a new bank account to
circumvent tax liens, removing and dissipating assets to avoid their seizure,
and by underreporting income and gross receipts. The information also alleged
that Dubois created a materially false document, a surety bond, and fraudulently
presented it as an actual security and financial instrument under the authority
of a surety company.







 On Feb. 8, 2017, Dubois pled guilty to the two charges in the information. In
entering the guilty plea, Dubois admitted that as owner and operator of RDG, he
evaded payment of $237,251 in federal employment taxes for tax years 2010
through 2012. Specifically, Dubois admitted that from Nov. 2011 through Oct.
2013, he opened a bank account which he used to divert funds in an attempt to
circumvent liens and levies, and to evade payment of his tax liabilities. Dubois
also acknowledged underreporting income and gross receipts to the IRS.







 According to Dubois's plea agreement, in Dec. 2011, RDG entered into contracts
with the Ramah Navajo School Board to renovate a building at the Pine Hill
School. The contracts required RDG to obtain and provide a surety bond. On Feb.
10, 2012, Dubois produced a materially false and fictitious surety bond which
appeared to be an actual security under the authority of the Western Surety
Company.







 At sentencing, Dubois faces a statutory maximum penalty of 25 years in federal
prison. A sentencing hearing has yet to be scheduled.







 This case was investigated by the Albuquerque office of IRS Criminal
Investigation and Department of the Interior, Office of Inspector General, and
is being prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeremy Pena.

Florida: Federal Jury Finds Tarpon Springs Woman Guilty Of Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 258  words

DATELINE: Tallahassee


United States Attorney's Office for the Middle District of Florida has issued
the following press release:

United States Attorney A. Lee Bentley, III announces that a federal jury has
found Nova A. Montgomery guilty of five counts of tax evasion and five counts of
failure to file an income tax return. She faces a maximum penalty of five years'
imprisonment for each tax evasion count, and one year in prison for each count
of failing to file a tax return. The jury returned the verdict on October 10,
2014, and a sentencing hearing is scheduled for January 12, 2015.

According to testimony and evidence presented at trial, Montgomery was
self-employed as a distributor for a multi-level marketing company that sold
nutritional and other products. Between 2002 and 2012, she received commissions
and other income exceeding $2.7 million. Montgomery set up a complex corporate
structure that made it appear that she personally received virtually none of the
income from the commissions and sales. Further, on February 12, 2009, in the
midst of an Internal Revenue Service audit, Montgomery filed false and
fraudulent federal income tax returns claiming that she had no income for 2002
through 2006. In addition, she failed to file personal income tax returns for
2008 through 2012.

This case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service - Criminal
Investigation. It is being prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorney Mark
E. Bini.

Washington: Broken Arrow Woman Sentenced for Bank Fraud and Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 364  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

A former manager of a credit union was sentenced on Tuesday to serve 27 months
for each count of bank fraud and tax evasion, announced U.S. Attorney Danny C.
Williams Sr. for the Northern District of Oklahoma and Special Agent in Charge
R. Damon Rowe of the Dallas field office for the Internal Revenue Service
Criminal Investigation.

Eva Barroso, 54, of Broken Arrow, was sentenced to serve 27 months in federal
prison by U.S. District Judge Chief Judge Gregory K Frizzell for one count each
of bank fraud and tax evasion. At the time of the scheme, Barroso worked as a
commercial services manager for Oklahoma Central Credit Union (OCCU) where her
duties included marketing and servicing commercial loans. The Court entered a
criminal forfeiture money judgment against the defendant in the amount of
$238,177.42 representing proceeds obtained as a result of his bank fraud scheme.
Barroso was also ordered to make restitution in the amount of $238,177.42 to
OCCU and $57,360.50 to the Internal Revenue Service.

According to court documents, from July 2, 2009 to March 19, 2012, as part of
the scheme, Barroso fabricated at least three false loans in the name of nominee
entities and individuals without the knowledge and authorization of the
purported borrower. Barroso admitted that she made various material false
representations in obtaining these loans. She used the proceeds of these loans
for her own personal benefit, including making ATM withdrawals at various
casinos. To further the scheme, Barroso used some of the money to make payments
on prior loans.

In addition, during the 2010 calendar year, Barroso willfully evaded a large
part of income tax by failing to report to the Internal Revenue Service a total
of $152,098.13 which was the money she fraudulently obtained from the scheme.

The case was investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Internal
Revenue Service Criminal Investigation and was prosecuted by Assistant United
States Attorney Jeffrey Gallant and Catherine Depew on behalf of the United
States.

For more information please visit: http://www.fbi.gov

                             March 3, 2009 Tuesday
                                 SOONER EDITION

CASTRONEVES TAX TRIAL STARTS IN MIAMI COURT

BYLINE: From local and wire dispatches

SECTION: SPORTS; MORNING BRIEFING; Pg. D-6

LENGTH: 508 words


On top of the world a few months ago, Brazilian race car driver and "Dancing
with the Stars" champ Helio Castroneves faces possible prison time if convicted
at a tax evasion trial that began yesterday in Miami with selection of a jury.

An ethnically diverse panel of five men and seven women was chosen to hear the
case, with attorneys' opening statements set for today.

Castroneves, a two-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, smiled broadly as he
entered a federal courthouse. Prosecutors say Castroneves, his business-manager
sister Katiucia and Michigan attorney Alan R. Miller conspired to hide about
$5.5 million in income from the Internal Revenue Service using offshore
accounts.

Under federal sentencing guidelines, Castroneves, 33, could get more than six
years in prison if convicted of conspiracy and tax evasion from 1999-2004.

More auto racing

Organizers for the NASCAR Nationwide series race signed a three-year deal to
keep an event at Gilles Villeneuve in Montreal.

Tennis

Fourth-ranked Andy Murray will miss Britain's Davis Cup match against Ukraine
this week because of a lingering virus. No replacement has been named.

* Serena Williams wore down sister Venus to win the one-night exhibition Billie
Jean King Cup, finishing off the return of women's tennis to Madison Square
Garden in New York a 6-4, 6-3 victory. Serena Williams won $400,000 of the $1.2
million purse.

Venus Williams reached the final by beating Jelena Jankovic, 6-4, and Serena
advanced with a 6-3 win over Ana Ivanovic.

Horse racing

Nearly a year after the first fatal injury at America's most famous horse race,
Churchill Downs announced it is beefing up safety requirements ahead of this
year's Kentucky Derby. The company is enacting more than 20 changes, ranging
from enhanced drug testing to limits on whips and racing ages.

College football

An Alabama football booster who won $5 million in a slander lawsuit against the
NCAA has given up collecting the money and will instead push for a new trial. A
lawyer for Ray Keller, an Alabama timber dealer, is seeking a second trial. A
judge threw out the verdict and Keller appealed. But he has now dropped the
appeal, and Keller hopes for a second trial. It's possible jurors could award
Keller more money in a retrial.

Track and field

British sprinter Dwain Chambers says in his autobiography he was a "walking
junkie" with so many drugs in his luggage that he feared being arrested while
going through airport security. Chambers, who served a two-year ban for doping
from 2003-05, details his drug use in the book "Race Against Me: My Story,"
which goes on sale Monday.

* The IAAF is launching a "Diamond League" of at least 12 international meets in
2010 -- including two in the United States -- seeking to pit the biggest stars
against each other on a regular basis.

Luge

Robby Huerbin, a North Hills High School graduate, won the junior national (20
and under) championships gold medal over the weekend at Park City, Utah. By also
winning a seeding race a month ago, Huerbin finished first in the overall season
rankings.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           January 12, 2008 Saturday
                                  City Edition

Fisher will get new hearing;
Judge cancels trial in ex-insurance official's state tax-evasion case.

BYLINE: Nolan Clay, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 13A

LENGTH: 282 words

DATELINE: TULSA


TULSA - Former Insurance Commissioner Carroll Fisher wasn't in court to see it,
but a judge Friday called off his tax-evasion trial.

Associate District Judge Dana Kuehn ruled Fisher instead will get another
preliminary hearing in the tax case to determine if the evidence is sufficient
for trial. She refused to dismiss the felony charge altogether.

The decision had no effect on Fisher's conviction in a campaign-corruption case.
Fisher, 67, remains in prison in that case and is serving a three-year term. He
chose not to come to court Friday.

The tax-evasion trial had been set to begin Feb. 11.

Assistant Attorney General Joel-lyn McCormick said prosecutors do not view
Friday's decision as a defeat. She said they want a trial conviction to stand up
on appeal.

Fisher is charged in the tax case with filing a false state tax return that
understated his 1999 income. Fisher allegedly should have paid an additional
$4,688 in state taxes.

An Oklahoma County judge last year moved the case to Tulsa. That judge ruled
that Fisher must be prosecuted in the county where he signed the 1999 return.

Fisher had already had a preliminary hearing on the tax case in Oklahoma County.
The Tulsa judge, Kuehn, ruled Friday that Fisher is entitled to another hearing
because of the move.

She noted that a key issue at any preliminary hearing is whether the case
belongs in that county. She said a Tulsa County preliminary hearing judge needs
to decide that issue in Fisher's case.

Fisher still faces a bribery trial in May and two other trials later - all of
them set to take place in Oklahoma County.

Fisher, a Democrat, was insurance commissioner for nearly six years before
resigning in September 2004.

                               The New York Times

                            February 11, 2002 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

Fugitive in Tax Evasion Case Is Apprehended in Costa Rica

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

SECTION: Section A; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 293 words


The leader of what the government says is a huge tax evasion scheme that
prospered for more than two decades has been arrested in Costa Rica on a
fugitive warrant, a federal prosecutor said last night.

Keith Anderson, 60, of Santa Ana, Costa Rica, was arrested on Saturday by agents
from Interpol and the Internal Revenue Service, said Benjamin B. Wagner, a
federal prosecutor in Sacramento. Mr.

Anderson is being held as a fugitive on a money laundering indictment by a grand
jury in California.

The I.R.S. has been seeking him for 11 months as part of what it has called the
largest enforcement action in its history.

Mr. Anderson is the founder of Anderson's Ark & Associates, an organization with
offices nationwide that helps people create offshore trusts to escape taxation.

His organization teaches members that Christians are not required to pay taxes,
that those who do sin and that the United States government is, in Mr.
Anderson's words, "a criminal organization."

The indictment of Mr. Anderson also named his brother, Wayne Anderson, 56, of
Squaw Valley, Calif., and Richard Marks, 58, of Los Osos, Calif. Both were
arrested during government raids last March and are being held in jail pending a
trial set to begin on May 7. Also indicted was Karolyn Grosnickle, 59, of
Hoodsport, Wash., who was arrested days after those raids. She is charged with
running daily operations.

In addition to the money laundering charge, the Anderson brothers, Ms.
Grosnickle and others are under investigation for tax evasion, Mr. Wagner said.
The money laundering charges grew out of a sting operation by I.R.S. criminal
investigators who said they recorded meetings at which the defendants told of
how they helped drug dealers launder money and avoid taxes.

                      Courier Mail (Queensland, Australia)

                             May 2, 1998, Saturday

Clinton friend faces tax evasion charge

SOURCE: QNP

BYLINE: SKOTNICKI T

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 553 words


PRESIDENT Bill Clinton's close friend Webster Hubbell was charged with tax
evasion yesterday in what is being seen as an attempt to obtain new evidence
damaging to the first couple.

A former senior Justice Department official, Hubbell has already served 21
months in jail on charges that he cheated clients at the Rose law firm in Little
Rock where he was a senior partner along with Hillary Clinton.

The former golfing buddy of the President now has been charged with tax evasion
over consulting fees and income he received before he began serving his
sentence.

Whitewater prosecutor Ken Starr brought the charge of tax evasion against the
former associate attorney-general, his wife Suzy and two of the couple's tax
advisers.

They are charged with 10 counts relating to allegedly false tax returns on more
than a million dollars of income from 1994 to 1997 _ on which it is claimed they
now owe $894,000 in tax and penalties.

Hubbell claimed yesterday that he was innocent and the charges were an attempt
to get him to lie about the President and Mrs Clinton.

"This has obviously been a very difficult day . . . especially since the office
of the independent counsel has decided to indict my wife and two of my best
friends," he said.

"Obviously, it's apparent to me that they think by indicting my wife and my
friends that I will lie about the President and the First Lady. I will not do so
and my wife would not want me to do so."

The charges come at a time when Mr Starr's investigation appears to be
intensifying, with Mrs Clinton having been required to provide several hours of
taped testimony to the Whitewater grand jury last weekend.

And on Thursday, it was reported that a federal judge has rejected former White
House intern Monica Lewinsky's bid for immunity from prosecution over claims
that she committed perjury and attempted to obstruct justice in the Paula Jones
case.

The decision paves the way for Ms Lewinsky to give evidence before a Washington
grand jury where she will be asked about her alleged affair with the President
and whether she was asked to lie about it.

A brief statement issued by the White House stated that the Clintons were
saddened by the latest development and the new charges faced by the Hubbells.

Earlier in the day, Mr Clinton _ in his first solo press conference of the year
_ directly attacked Mr Starr.

He said he felt "terrible" about legal fees his friends and associates had
incurred because of the probe.

Mr Clinton said Mr Starr, by contrast, "has an unlimited budget and can go on
forever _ 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 years, spend $40 million today, $100 million
tomorrow".

He said, however, it would not be appropriate for him to ask Attorney-General
Janet Reno to dismiss the counsel.

Mr Clinton faced a barrage of questions about Ms Lewinsky and the attacks on his
character but he refused to be drawn.

He said he had already denied the underlying charge and had received legal
advice not to discuss the matter further while there was an investigation under
way. "In the circumstances, I think it is good advice," the President said.

Mr Clinton said the barrage of criticism "used to distress me greatly", but not
anymore.

"They can affect my reputation; they can do nothing for good or ill to affect my
character," he said.

Probation Ordered for Tax Evasion

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B03; CRIME AND JUSTICE

LENGTH: 99 words


A Falls Church pharmacist convicted of federal tax evasion was sentenced
yesterday to two years of supervised probation, with four months of electronic
monitoring at home.

Thanh Dinh Nguyen, 50, who owned the Eden Pharmacy in the Vietnamese shopping
strip Eden Center, also was ordered to pay $ 81,000 in back taxes and fines by
Chief Judge James C. Cacheris of the U.S. District Court in Alexandria.

Nguyen, who pleaded guilty in July to one count of tax evasion, admitted
depositing income from the pharmacy into a personal bank account and failing to
report it on his tax returns.
