                         Sunday Herald Sun (Australia)

                            December 5, 2010 Sunday
                               1 - FIRST Edition

HOGAN: PAY ME COMPO AND SAY SORRY I have become Mr Tax Evasion Hoges says his
career is ruined

BYLINE: ROSIE SQUIRES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1622  words


Los Angeles

SUPERSTAR larrikin Paul Hogan is demanding an apology and multi-million dollar
compensation payout from the Government, saying his reputation has been trashed
by a failed criminal tax investigation that has left him bitter, angry and
without work.

In an exclusive interview with the Sunday Herald Sun in his Malibu home, the
Crocodile Dundee creator candidly revealed how his life had been turned upside
down by the now abandoned five-year criminal investigation.

Hogan said while he and his mate and business partner John ``Strop'' Cornell
initially celebrated when the secretive case against them was dropped last week,
he was annoyed at losing his chance to defend himself in court.

``I wanted to be exonerated because I didn't do anything wrong and that's hard
for people to believe because where there is smoke, there is fire,'' Hogan said.

``I have been publicly declared to be a criminal, a fraud, money launderer and
tax evader. I became Mr Tax Evasion.

``Every time there was a story about some poor old pensioner who gets caught for
tax evasion my name would somehow get into it too.''

He said he could never recover his battered reputation.

``If you google Hogan and tax, there are about 270,000 articles.''

As his name was dragged further into the mud over the past five years, Hogan,
whose lawyers are still to negotiate a multi-million dollar settlement with the
Australian Tax Office, said the job offers also dried up.

``I used to have a lot of calls from around the world to be a pitch man. I would
receive many invitations a month to be involved in well paying advertising
work,'' he said.

``Now that has been destroyed. No one calls me and I haven't spoken to my agent
in months.

``I'm black-marked.''

Ironically, one of the rare calls he has received was from Australia to help
with the bid to host the FIFA World Cup.

In a wide-ranging interview, Hogan opened up about the turmoil since 2005 when
armed officials raided the home of his Australian-based accountant Tony Stewart.
Hogan revealed:

THE Australian Tax Office almost shut down the filming of a movie to quiz him
over his tax affairs.

HE wants to sue the former adviser the Australian Crime Commission relied on for
information.

HE found out the ACC had dropped the case against him on the internet.

HE wants to return to live in Australia, but fears being accused of doing so to
avoid tax.

DESPITE still being in dispute with the Australian Government, he was to link up
with Julia Gillard on the FIFA World Cup bid.

The 71-year-old star said he would seek a formal apology from the ACC and
reimbursement of the near $10 million he has spent on legal fees fighting
allegations that he deliberately cheated on tax.

Hogan said that his tax affairs were always complicated because at the height of
his popularity he was earning money in so many different countries.

``It's a very confusing tax situation . . . I can't complain about the ATO
checking up on me, but it was how they did it,'' he said.

``The first time I became aware was when I was told my accountant's house was
raided -- no sit down chat.

``That's why I wasn't thrilled with (the ACC's) pathetic, insulting dropping of
charges -- I wanted my day in court.

``The most personal thing was the public slandering of my name. Suddenly people
stopped asking me to do things. My name has been demolished by the ACC inquiry.

``For five years people have been too scared to deal with me for fear of being
brought into the inquiry.

``It's bullying and thuggery. Guilty until proven innocent.''

ACC chief John Lawler told the Sunday Herald Sun the case was dropped because it
was ``not justified in the public interest having regard to a range of
factors''.

``On the material presently available to the ACC, including documents recently
obtained as a result of overseas inquiries, the ACC has concluded that there are
insufficient prospects of securing convictions to justify continuing with its
investigation at this time.''

THE high-profile, but very secretive Operation Wickenby was launched in a blaze
of publicity in 2004 as a multi-agency investigation into offshore tax fraud and
money laundering.

The investigation -- run by the ATO, the ACC and the Australian Federal Police
-- was sparked by the discovery of files naming high-profile Australians on the
laptop of Swiss-based financier Phillip Egglishaw. Among the names on the
computer were Hogan, Cornell and Stewart. Cornell is also no longer being
probed.

So they raided Stewart, ``instead of a phone call saying, `Mr Hogan, we are a
bit confused about your tax affairs because you do pay tax in two and sometimes
three countries. We would like to discuss with your financial people why your
name is on his laptop','' Hogan said.

``They have nothing on me, they never had anything on me. They aren't going to
get me because I haven't done anything wrong . . . I honestly haven't done
anything wrong.''

Asked if he paid the appropriate amount of tax, Hogan said: ``They should have a
statue of me in the Australian Tax Office.

``Tax has been such an insignificant part of my life. My job has been to
entertain people . . . not to sit around working out tax results. And they have
painted this picture like the two of us are down in the chooks yard with Vinni
my cousin working out the tax scheme.

``I haven't even tried to minimise tax -- which is perfectly legal. Jesus, I
paid bloody millions in tax.''

Continued page 7

From page 6

While the ACC has dropped off, Hogan is still battling the ATO.

``It's not over. I wouldn't say it was over unless they apologise. Until they
say . . . we are sorry. We are sorry for five years we called you a thief and
sorry we contacted the Swiss Government and told them you were a money
launderer,'' he said.

Ignoring advice from his US-based lawyer who sat in on the interview, Hogan
explained for the first time how he believed he had come to be involved in
Operation Wickenby.

`FROM what I understand my name gets dragged into this because it's found on a
laptop. Then they try every which way to get me including taking a statement
from an ex-adviser.

``They have nothing on me, they never had anything on me. They are just trying
to live up to their promise years ago of scalps,'' Hogan said.

``But they aren't going to get me because I haven't done anything wrong. Despite
the thousands of press articles that say I have, I honestly haven't done
anything wrong.''

Hogan said he plans to sue his former financial adviser, John Gibb, who
testified against him last year.

``If I had known that the ACC and ATO were relying so heavily on a ex-adviser
who I fired 20 years ago, I could have provided them with a bit of background,''
he said.

It is understood in a statement to the ACC in December last year, Mr Gibb said
from about 1986 he advised Hogan he was acting illegally.

It was that piece of evidence that allowed the ATO to demand tax bills dating
back to 1986, which would leave Hogan owing the ATO upwards of $100 million.

But in a contrary statement to an Australian Government Solicitor on July 15
last year, Mr Gibb said that a top QC, believed to be the late Graham Hill, had
given the green light to Hogan's activities.

Mr Hill was widely regarded a one of Australia's best tax lawyers. That part of
Mr Gibb's evidence was not included in the December statement.

Hogan revealed that in its pursuit of him, the ATO was prepared to disrupt the
filming of a movie.

``One of their classy moves was when I was shooting Charlie and Boots in
Australia.

``In the last couple of days they sent up a summons that said you have to appear
tomorrow, we want to talk to you. I said, `I am doing a movie, I will be
finished in a few days' and they said no.

``My lawyer had to go and fight them because they would have had to hold the
production while I was down talking to the tax people.

``But the tax office didn't care, they were punishing Instinct films for hiring
me and what's that saying to them? Don't hire Hoges, he's likely to be pulled
off the shoot. That was bullying.''

Hogan said it was convenient the ACC dropped the case just in time for him to
appear in Australia's bid for the FIFA World Cup in 2022.

``It's such a bitter irony: one side of the Government has been persecuting me
while the other has asked for help,'' he said.

Hogan said he chose to donate his time on the FIFA campaign to support his
country.

HUNTING DOWN DUNDEE

1988: Hogan moves to US, but continues to pay tax in Australia.

2002: Hogan moves back to Australia.

2004: Swiss accountant Philip Egglishaw is raided and his laptop seized during a
visit to Australia. Information on it allegedly related to Hogan, business
partner John Cornell and accountant Tony Stewart.

- Wickenby tax investigation is launched.

2005: Hogan returns to America because wife Linda's mother falls ill with
cancer.

- Hogan's accountant Tony Stewart is raided by 10 armed federal police officers.
Australian Crime Commission seizes hundreds of thousands of documents.

2006: Hogan's lawyers challenge the ACC seizure of documents.

2009: Hogan's former accountant John Gibb makes two contrary statements with
authorities in exchange for immunity from prosecution. One claims Hogan's
activities were illegal, the second concedes they had been approved by top QCs

2010: ACC launches lawsuit in the Federal Court aimed at forcing Cornell, Hogan
and Stewart to abandon any attempts to stop documents seized from Stewart's
house being used in the investigation.

- Hogan arrives in Australia for the funeral of his mother, Florence.

- Hogan served with a Departure Prohibition Order and forced to stay in
Australia. Allowed to return to LA to wife and son Chance after a two-week
prohibition.

November 2010

- ACC drops criminal investigation into Paul Hogan and John Cornell. ATO to
continue investigation.

                              July 4, 2008 Friday

Mesa man indicted in tax evasion case: Records say Stacey failed to file returns
from '95 to '03

BYLINE: Eddi Trevizo, The Tribune, Mesa, Ariz.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 338 words


Jul. 4--A Mesa businessman was indicted on multiple charges of fraud, tax
evasion and interference with the IRS in U.S. District Court in Arizona on
Thursday.

John D. Stacey, 36, of Mesa faces 11 charges including multiple counts of
fraudulent use of Social Security, income tax evasion and corrupt interference
with the due administration of the Internal Revenue Service.

Stacey owned several paving businesses in the Valley, including A to Z Paving,
Triple A Paving, Texas Paving, Pave Your Way Construction, and A to Z Paving
Engineering LLC. According to authorities, he failed to report individual income
returns from 1995 to 2003.

The charges stem from a civil investigation that claims Stacey failed to report
or pay his 1995-97 tax liabilities, and that Stacey falsified information given
to an IRS civil auditor from 1998 through 2003, according to court documents.

Indictment records said that Stacey deposited business receipts into bank
accounts held under his mother's name, provided false Social Security numbers
and employer identification numbers when conducting financial and business
transactions, and filed bankruptcy and financial disclosure statements that
understated his assets and income.

Stacey could face a maximum potential sentence of five years in federal prison
for the tax evasion charge, three years in prison for the corrupt endeavor
charge, and five years in prison for each fraudulent use of a Social Security
number charge, court authorities said.

If convicted, Stacey also faces a fine of $250,000 for each charged count.

Stacey will receive a summons and be arraigned at a later date.

                               The New York Times

                 June 29, 1995, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Ex-Clinton Confidant Gets 21 Months

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH

SECTION: Section B;   Page 6;   Column 1;   National Desk

LENGTH: 845 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 28


Webster L. Hubbell, who once stood at the pinnacle of the legal establishment in
Arkansas and Washington, was sentenced today to 21 months in prison for mail
fraud and tax evasion after the Whitewater independent counsel declined to
recommend a lighter sentence on the basis of Mr. Hubbell's cooperation with
investigators.

Mr. Hubbell, once one of President Clinton's closest confidants, will be the
most prominent person to go to prison as a result of the inquiry into the
Whitewater real estate venture and other matters led by the independent counsel,
Kenneth W. Starr. But Mr. Hubbell was not involved in the Whitewater Development
Company, of which Mr. Clinton and his wife, Hillary, were partners, and the
charges were not directly related to Mr. Starr's investigation of whether a
failed savings and loan institution improperly funneled money into Whitewater.

At the sentencing, in Little Rock, Ark., Judge George Howard Jr. of Federal
District Court declined to impose a fine against Mr. Hubbell and ordered him to
make restitution for less than a third of the money he took. Federal guidelines
for a plea-bargained case like that of Mr. Hubbell's call for a prison sentence
of 21 to 27 months, leaving the judge with little flexibility once the
prosecution declined to recommend a reduction.

When Mr. Hubbell, a former Associate Attorney General and Chief Justice of the
Arkansas Supreme Court, pleaded guilty last December, admitting to bilking his
former law firm and clients of almost $400,000, he agreed to cooperate with
prosecutors. But lawyers familiar with the case said that Mr. Starr's decision
not to recommend a reduction in Mr. Hubbell's sentence was a sign that his
cooperation with the authorities had yielded little new substantive information.

Mr. Hubbell, in an emotional presentation to the court, said his behavior
resulted from being overwhelmed by his financial situation. "I was miserable, I
was being being torn apart," he said.

Mr. Starr told the court that the sentencing of someone who once was the Chief
Justice in Arkansas was a "sobering and humbling part of the justice process."

Mr. Hubbell had asked the court to reduce his sentence to no more than 16 months
because of his charitable activities. He and his lawyers, in papers filed with
the court last week, argued that he had "devoted such a large part of his life
doing for others -- making his community a better place to live."

The White House had no comment on the sentence, but issued a statement saying
"the President and the First Lady look forward to the day when Mr. Hubbell can
rejoin his family and his community."

Mr. Hubbell and Hillary Rodham Clinton were partners in the Rose Law Firm until
they resigned at the end of 1992. In the spring of 1993 he became the No. 3
person at the Justice Department. But he was never able to clear up his
financial dealings with his former firm.

Mr. Hubbell resigned from the department in March 1994 after the firm threatened
to file a complaint with the Arkansas bar association. He continued for some
time to tell friends that the problem was simply a billing dispute.

A close examination of his records, however, first by his former partners and
then by the independent counsel, showed a four-year pattern of
misappropriations. Lawyers for Mr. Starr and Mr. Hubbell now say the exact
amount is $482,410, just under the $500,000 level that would, under the Federal
guidelines, trigger a slightly longer sentence. Mr. Hubbell's failure to report
his misappropriations as income for the years 1989 to 1992 resulted in a tax
deficiency of $143,747, according to court papers filed by Mr. Starr.

Last year, as the independent counsel prepared to indict him, Mr. Hubbell
suddenly pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with the Whitewater prosecutors
in their investigation. His friends, who believed in his innocence, say they
were puzzled by his last-minute plea. And prosecutors had little insight into
what their new witness might disclose, said people familiar with the case.

Six months later, and despite numerous conversations with their new witness, the
independent counsel's office found itself unwilling to endorse Mr. Hubbell's
plea for a reduced sentence. In his court filing, Mr. Starr took note of Mr.
Hubbell's civic involvement but noted that some of Mr. Hubbell's
misappropriations had gone to charities, and cited the high standard for
granting exceptions to sentencing guidelines used by the United States Court of
Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which has jurisdiction over Arkansas.

Judge Howard, a 71-year-old Arkansan who was named to the Federal bench by
President Jimmy Carter in 1980, said that after reviewing Mr. Hubbell's finances
he decided against a fine, although he ordered Mr. Hubbell to repay $135,000
over a period of five years.

Ronald M. Clark, managing partner of the Rose Law Firm, said Mr. Hubbell had not
had any discussions with the firm about paying back the money he took.

The Bureau of Prisons has not yet said where Mr. Hubbell will serve his
sentence.


NAME: Webster L. Hubbell

Richmond businessman arrested in tax evasion case

BYLINE: By Roman Gokhman Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BREAKING; My Town; Crime; Contra Costa; News; Local; Business

LENGTH: 192 words


PLEASANT HILL   The chief executive officer of a Pleasant Hill design firm was
arrested this afternoon on three counts of income tax evasion, the state
Franchise Tax Board announced.

Philip Leech, of Richmond, is also the chief financial officer at In & Out
Designs Inc. and is the third high-ranking official from the firm to be arrested
over the company's failure to pay its taxes from 2001 to 2003.

Owners Rick and Kathy Powers, both 55, pleaded no contest earlier this year to
felony counts of diversion of construction funds and state income tax evasion.
Their sentencing is still pending.

The tax board said Leech, 46, is also liable because it is his responsibility to
ensure the corporation's taxes are filed.

In & Out Designs reportedly earned more than $1.3 million in taxable income
between 2001 and 2003, the FTB reported. The corporation owes the state more
than $122,000 in tax.

Leech allegedly ignored FTB's notices to file the delinquent returns. Each count
carries a maximum of three years in state prison. He was booked at the County
Jail in Martinez and his bail was set at $20,000. An arraignment was not
scheduled as of Tuesday evening.

                              The Washington Post

                            October 4, 2007 Thursday
                                Regional Edition

Cash and a Cruise Traded for Contracts;
Silver Spring Man Pleads Guilty to Bribery in Record Maryland Corruption Case

BYLINE: Ruben Castaneda; Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FINANCIAL; Pg. D04

LENGTH: 757 words


The former owner and chief executive of a Silver Spring company admitted in
federal court yesterday that he bribed a government contracting official with
cash and paid for her passage on a Caribbean cruise in exchange for contracts to
provide security at federal buildings in Maryland and California worth more than
$130 million.

Michael B. Holiday, 50, of Silver Spring, a former Montgomery County police
officer, gave the official $35,000 stuffed in a shopping bag and another $10,000
in an envelope, according to a factual summary that Holiday acknowledged was
accurate. He pleaded guilty to bribery and tax evasion in U.S. District Court in
Greenbelt.

U.S. Attorney Rod J. Rosenstein said that, as measured by the value of the
contracts secured through bribery, it is the largest public corruption case ever
prosecuted in Maryland.

"Government employees are given broad discretion about how to spend taxpayer
money," Rosenstein said in an interview. "Their decisions must be based on which
contractor provides the best service to the public at the lowest price, not on
which contractor offers the best bribe to the employee at the highest price."

Holiday's company, Holiday International Security, which changed its name to
USProtect after Holiday sold it in 2003, has provided armed and unarmed security
guards for 18 federal agencies at 120 installations in 32 states and
territories, Rosenstein's office said.

Criminal charges were also filed yesterday against Dessie Ruth Nelson, the
former General Services Administration contracting official Holiday said he
bribed. Charging documents allege that Nelson, 65, of Oakland, Calif., accepted
more than $100,000 in bribes from Holiday and evaded taxes on the bribe
payments.

Another former official with the security company, Richard S. Hudec, 44, of
Naples, Fla., was charged yesterday with tax evasion and improperly concealing
material information from federal contracting officials, including prior
convictions for felony fraud, in connection with contracts worth more than $150
million.

U.S. District Judge Deborah K. Chasanow scheduled Holiday's sentencing for Jan.
23. Holiday remains free under the supervision of federal pre-trial services
officials, said Bruce V. Marcus, Holiday's attorney.

"Other than the unfortunate circumstances surrounding his business, Mr. Holiday
is a well-respected individual," Marcus said.

According to a Montgomery County police spokeswoman, Holiday was an officer with
the department from 1980 until he resigned in 1992. Marcus said Holiday had a
"stellar" record as a police officer.

In addition to bribery and tax evasion, Holiday pleaded guilty to transporting
child pornography by computer.

In April 2004, an undercover FBI agent, as part of an investigation into child
pornography, entered an Internet chat site called "Special Interests -- daddy we
shouldnt," according to the factual summary. In the chat room, the agent sent a
message: "room topic vids to trade."

That afternoon, Holiday sent the agent a computer message offering to trade
videos. Holiday later sent the agent an e-mail with an attached video file that
showed a prepubescent girl performing oral sex on an adult man, according to the
summary, which Holiday signed.

The tax evasion charge stems from Holiday's admitted failure to file federal
income tax returns each year from 2001 to 2004. According to the summary, he
received "substantial compensation" from the security firm during that time and
failed to pay more than $400,000 in federal taxes,

The summary says that Nelson twice awarded Holiday's company contracts for work
in California in instances in which it was not the lowest bidder, once in 2000
and once the following year. In 2002, Nelson helped the company win a contract
to provide security at Social Security Administration facilities in Baltimore,
the summary said.

Efforts to reach Nelson and Hudec yesterday were not successful. Nelson's home
phone number in Oakland is not listed, and there is no listing for Hudec in
Naples. Messages left seeking comment from their attorneys were not immediately
returned.

According to the complaint against Hudec, the company changed its name after it
was purchased by Hudec's wife. Company filings to federal agencies falsely
certified that neither it nor its principals had prior criminal and civil fraud
judgments.

Rosenstein announced the plea agreement and charges at a news conference in
Greenbelt. In the interview, he said the cash-stuffed shopping bag and envelope
"really demonstrate the egregious nature of this scheme."

                               The New York Times

                October 22, 1992, Thursday, Late Edition - Final
                              Correction Appended

Ex-I.R.S. Agent Is Indicted On Affidavit

BYLINE: By RONALD SULLIVAN

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 477 words


A dismissed Internal Revenue Service agent has been indicted on Federal charges
of obstructing justice and making false statements against a defendant who died
of AIDS after the agent helped bring charges against him of tax evasion, money
laundering and drug dealing.

The indictment of the agent, Frank T. Primerana, follows a Justice Department
investigation into charges that defendants in the case were illegally singled
out for arrest on drug charges because they were gay.

But the indictment against Mr. Primerana, announced on Oct. 14, made no mention
of those accusations, and the agent was not charged with violating the rights of
the defendant, William A. Nachman. Mr. Primerana is scheduled to be arraigned
today in Federal court in Manhattan.

Charge Caused Concern

The investigation was begun when a co-defendant in the case, Bruce Mailman,
filed an affidavit in February with a Federal judge in Manhattan asserting that
homosexuals were illegally singled out by Mr. Primerana. Mr. Mailman's charge
that their prosecution had involved an assistant United States Attorney who had
been suspended in 1991 was said to have caused concern among Federal
law-enforcement officials.

Mr. Mailman's affidavit said that the former prosecutor, James J. McGuire, who
prosecuted him and Mr. Nachman, told him he was "indicted because he was gay and
that the Government was interested in penetrating the gay community."

Mr. Mailman's lawyer, James LaRossa, said he had no explanation for why the
grand jury failed to charge Mr. Primerana with violating his client's civil
rights. "I can only assume the grand jury considered the other charges against
Mr. Primerana to be more serious," he said. He added that he was preparing a
civil suit against Mr. Primerana.

At the time Mr. Mailman filed his affidavit, Otto G. Obermaier, the United
States Attorney in Manhattan, said the Public Integrity Section of the Justice
Department was investigating the charges. About a week later, a judge dismissed
all charges against Mr. Nachman and Mr. Mailman, and two other defendants, Boris
I. Fedushin and Carlos Insignares.

Not a Target

But Mr. McGuire said yesterday that prosecutors in the Public Integrity Section
had told him he was not a subject of any investigation.

"The fact that these defendants were homosexuals had nothing to do whatsover
with their prosecution," Mr. McGuire said in an interview yesterday. "The fact
they were gay was completely irrelevant."

Mr. Primerana could not be reached yesterday.

Mr. Mailman was indicted a few months later.

Mr. Nachman, who was free on bail, died of AIDS on March 22, 1991.

Mr. Mailman's lawyer, Mr. LaRossa, said his client, who is also a homosexual,
had pleaded quilty to a tax violation charge in 1991 out of fear that he would
be railroaded into prison if tried on the drug charges.

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: November 6, 1992, Friday

CORRECTION:

An article on Oct. 22 about the indictment of a former Internal Revenue Service
agent on charges of obstruction of justice referred incompletely to the
background of a man who has accused the agent, Frank T. Primerana, of singling
him out for prosecution because he is gay. The defendant, Bruce Mailman, was
indicted on charges of tax evasion, but the charges were later dropped.

                  April 3, 1992, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Former Mayor of Waterbury Found Guilty of Corruption

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 473 words

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 2


The former mayor of Waterbury, Joseph J. Santopietro, was convicted today on
Federal charges of conspiracy, bribe-taking and tax evasion in a case that
rocked the city he once led.

A jury of eight women and four men took just under 11 hours to convict Mr.
Santopietro, who is 33 years old, on 15 separate charges that he used his office
to arrange favorable deals for developers, obtain fraudulent loans, accept
bribes and steal Federal money meant for job-training. He was also convicted of
three counts of tax evasion and filing false tax returns. He was cleared of
three additional counts of accepting bribes.

"He's very upset right now," said Hugh F. Keefe, Mr. Santopietro's lawyer. Mr.
Keefe produced no witnesses, and the former mayor, who showed little reaction as
the verdict was announced, did not testify at the trial. He denied the charges
and his lawyer said in closing arguments that the Government's case was
contrived.

Held Until Sentencing

Mr. Santopietro was taken from the courtroom in handcuffs and leg irons after
Judge T. F. Gilroy Daly granted a prosecution request that the former mayor be
held in custody until his sentencing. He is being held in the Bridgeport
Correctional Center and a hearing was scheduled for Friday to set a sentencing
date.

Holly Fitzsimmons, the assistant United States Attorney who led the prosecution
of Mr. Santopietro and seven co-defendants, said the verdict marked "a good day,
because the system worked."

Mr. Santopietro, hailed as a rising star in Waterbury's Republican Party after
he was elected in 1985, at the age of 26, to that city's highest office, faces
prison terms totaling a maximum of 129 years, but the sentence was expected to
be about 12 years.

He was accused of participating in a conspiracy that began barely a month after
he was sworn in as Mayor, and that involved his inner circle of political
advisers as well as a group of Republican aldermen and other officials.
Investigators said Mr. Santopietro accepted more than $170,000 in bribes from
developers over a three-year period. He was arrested in September amid his
re-election campaign, and two months later lost his bid for a fourth term.

Witnesses at the five-week trial included bank officials and developers, as well
as former associates of Mr. Santopietro who cooperated with the Government after
being charged with crimes themselves. A series of tape-recorded conversations
between Mr. Santopietro and other Waterbury officials had the former mayor
bragging that he could orchestrate a cover-up to throw investigators off the
case.

Those convicted with him today included his younger brother, Jeffrey; four other
Waterbury elected officials, Paul R. Vitarelli, Robert A. Giacomi, Fred L.
Giusti and Mr. Giacomi's brother, Jack; and former mayoral aid Perry A.
Pisciotti.

               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                            July 16, 2008 Wednesday
                                National Edition

Capone's legacy rules tax regime; Evasion led to downfall of ultimate gangster

BYLINE: Vern Krishna, Financial Post

SECTION: LEGAL POST; Vern Krishna; Pg. FP7

LENGTH: 803  words


Even in death, Alphonse "Scarface" Capone's legacy in tax law thrives in Canada.
The Internal Revenue Service of the United States recently released its papers
concerning the investigation and conviction of Capone for income tax evasion --
the only crime for which America's most notorious criminal was ever convicted.
The IRS said there were no issues of confidentiality and privacy. Since Capone
never filed a tax return, no one could claim privacy rights in respect of his
financial affairs.

Scarface Al was a legendary gangster. His brief stint in organized crime, only
about seven years, supported Hollywood, which recounted his exploits of
bootlegging, gambling and prostitution and made icons of some of Canada's most
famous families. The Untouchables, a television series and later a feature film,
and the The St. Valentine's Day Massacre, a classic movie, would not have been
possible without Capone's larger-than-life exploits in Chicago. Even the phrase
"big fellows" (or "bigfellas") to describe crime bosses, originated in an IRS
tax memo describing the principal players in Capone's exploits.

Capone did not start at the top of his profession. He worked his way up from the
bottom. He came to Chicago from New York as an apprentice hoodlum in 1920 -- one
year after the enactment of the Volstead Act enacted Prohibition -- as a protege
of John Torrio, a lieutenant in the family of organized crime. He apprenticed as
a bouncer in a notoriously tough joint, the "Four Deuces."

After Torrio's injuries in a gun battle, "Big Shot" Capone took over his
administrative duties. He was renowned for his lavish spending and bribery of
city officials. When the authorities arrested Capone on a vagrancy charge, the
state attorney had to dismiss the case because there was not a single policeman
in Chicago who could identify Capone.

The enactment of Prohibition propelled Capone's life as a vice overlord. The
Volstead Act gave the Commissioner of Internal Revenue the primary
responsibility for the law.

Despite all his notoriety and power, Capone's criminal reign was relatively
short: His reign as vice overlord began in 1924 and continued up to the time of
his conviction for income tax invasion on Oct. 17, 1931. The United States
repealed the Volstead Act in 1933, two years after Capone's conviction. He
reigned supreme for only seven of the 14 years of Prohibition.

Capone was shrewd. He did not trust banks and never had a bank account. He
endorsed only one cheque in his entire life. He conducted all of his financial
transactions in cash -- a lesson modern day criminals emulate and that led to
the money-laundering laws in Canada. The IRS could not find a single transaction
where Capone purchased securities.

Capone's propensity for secrecy and lack of documentation became an
insurmountable hurdle for federal agents investigating his crimes.

The agents analyzed bank accounts, interviewed witnesses and secured every scrap
of evidence, all with the objective of eventually prosecuting him.

The income tax prosecution of Capone was quite remarkable. Absent a paper trail,
it was difficult to secure the proper evidence to convict Capone and his
colleagues of income tax evasion. Persons who had knowledge of their financial
transactions were reluctant witnesses for fear of the potential consequences.

Philip D'Andrea -- ostensibly a personal bodyguard -- sat immediately behind
Capone in the courtroom during his trial. D'Andrea was more than just a
bodyguard. His primary function was to stare down witnesses and intimidate them
in the courtroom. He carried a .38-calibre revolver inside his belt and in a
vest pocket he carried a supply of extra cartridges. The judge eventually had
him removed from the court.

Capone was eventually sentenced for tax evasion to 10 years in a federal
penitentiary and one year in the Cook County jail upon completion of his federal
sentence. He was fined US$50,000.

After the successful conclusion of the investigations in Chicago in 1931,
federal agents instituted an intensive drive against racketeers, who were also
evading income taxes on illegal gains in New York City. There were approximately
250 individuals convicted in New York. The attorney-general convicted not only
the racketeers, but also various New York City officials.

The conviction of Al Capone on tax evasion had important consequences for the
income tax system. His conviction inspired colleagues to engage in "voluntary
disclosure" of undeclared income to avoid similar prosecutions.

Capone's colleagues paid hundreds of thousands of dollars to avoid similar
prosecution. We see Capone's legacy in Canada's current voluntary-disclosure
program.

--- - Prof. Vern Krishna, CM, QC, FCGA, is counsel at Borden Ladner Gervais LLP
and executive director of the CGA Tax Research Centre at the University of
Ottawa.

                                US Official News

                             May 28, 2016 Saturday

Former University of Miami Director of Finance Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion
Charges

LENGTH: 361  words

DATELINE: New York



 Office for the United States Attorneys, Southern District of Florida has issued
the following news release:



  A former University of Miami Director of Finance pled guilty to tax evasion
charges for failing to report to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) $2.3 million
that she embezzled from the university.





 Wifredo A. Ferrer, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida,
and Kelly R. Jackson, Special Agent in Charge, Internal Revenue Service,
Criminal Investigation (IRS-CI), made the announcement.



 Kimberly Jean Miller, 58, pled guilty to four counts of tax evasion, in
violation of Title 26, United States Code, Section 7201.



 According to court documents, from 2002 until 2012, Miller was the director of
finance at the University of Miami's Rosensteil School of Marine and Atmospheric
Science (RSMAS). The defendant's job responsibilities included overseeing the
payment of RSMAS's vendor invoices. Between 2002 and 2012, Miller used her
authority at RSMAS to embezzle $2.3 million from the University of Miami by
falsifying invoices from a vendor called International Assets. Specifically,
Miller altered the International Assets invoices so that the company name would
appear as "Inter, Inc." and the checks would be mailed back to RSMAS, instead of
to International Assets directly. Miller then deposited the "Inter, Inc." checks
into a business bank account in the name Intercontinental Oceans, Inc., a
company Miller opened in 1993.



 Between 2008 and 2011, Miller prepared her own tax returns and knowingly failed
to report to the IRS the money she had unlawfully obtained through her
embezzlement scheme. Miller owes the IRS an additional $329,020 in income taxes
for her 2008 through 2011 tax returns.



 Sentencing is scheduled for August 16, 2016 before U.S. District Judge Robert
N. Scola, Jr.  At sentencing, Miller faces a maximum statutory sentence of five
years in prison per count.



 Mr. Ferrer commended the investigative efforts of IRS-CI.  The case is being
prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Amanda Perwin.

FAIRFIELD RESIDENT SENTENCED TO FEDERAL PRISON FOR TAX EVASION

LENGTH: 223  words

DATELINE: Hartford


United States Attorney's Office for the District of Connecticut has issued the
following press release:

Deirdre M. Daly, United States Attorney for the District of Connecticut,
announced that ROBERT JOSEPH PARKER, 52, of Fairfield, was sentenced today by
U.S. District Judge Janet Bond Arterton in New Haven to 18 months of
imprisonment, followed by three years of supervised release, for tax evasion.

According to court documents and statements made in court, PARKER earned income
by providing information technology services to various businesses.  Between
1996 and 2012, PARKER did not pay any federal income tax on approximately $2
million of income he received in his own name, and in the name of his alter ego
entity known as Success Zone, LLC.

As part of his sentence, PARKER was ordered to pay $1,869,419 in taxes, interest
and penalties for himself personally for tax years 1996 through 2012, and for
Success Zone, LLC, for tax years 2003 through 2012.

On March 5, 2014, PARKER waived his right to indictment and pleaded guilty to
one count of tax evasion.

This case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service - Criminal
Investigation Division and was prosecuted by Senior Litigation Counsel Richard
J. Schechter.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 11, 2012 Wednesday

Duluth woman charged with tax evasion

BYLINE: Mark Stodghill, Duluth News Tribune, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 426 words


April 11--With April 15 around the corner, the Minnesota Department of Revenue
issued a news release Tuesday announcing that a Duluth woman has been charged
with eight felony crimes for failing to pay income taxes and filing false or
fraudulent returns.

Pattie Lyn Fralich-Peterson, 51, is accused of filing the fraudulent returns for
tax years 2005 through 2008.

Fralich-Peterson is scheduled to make her first appearance in State District
Court in Duluth on April 24. She has no criminal record in Minnesota or
Wisconsin, according to court records. She has had eight conciliation court
cases filed against her in Minnesota. She couldn't be reached for comment.

According to the criminal complaint:

A revenue tax specialist completed an investigation of Fralich-Peterson on Aug.
16, 2010. The investigator alleged that Fralich-Peterson substantially
overstated her income tax withholdings by her employer and underpaid her
Minnesota income taxes for four years. The total overstatement of state
withholding is alleged to be $6,452, causing her to receive larger refunds than
she was entitled to.

Between Jan. 20 and Jan. 23 of this year, a special agent with the revenue
department criminal investigation division contacted Fralich-Peterson by
telephone. The complaint alleges that she admitted to preparing the tax returns
in question herself and filing them over the internet. She admitted that the
discrepancies between the withholding shown on her income tax returns and the
withholding shown on her W-2s were substantial. She said she couldn't explain
why there were substantial differences between the tax returns and the W-2s, why
there were similar errors on each of her tax returns for 2004-2008, nor why all
of the errors were in her favor.

The Minnesota Department of Revenue has a 24-hour tip line for anyone who
suspects an individual or business is violating tax laws at (651) 297-5195 or
(800) 657-3500. Tipsters may remain anonymous and can also e-mail the department
at tax.fraud@state.mn.us Last year, citizen tips resulted in 89 percent of the
department's case referrals.

In its news release, the revenue department said: "While most taxpayers comply
with tax laws voluntarily, the Minnesota Department of Revenue takes progressive
enforcement action against noncompliant taxpayers ensuring tax laws are fairly
administered, collecting no more and no less than taxpayers owe."

                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                             October 3, 2008 Friday

Tax charges denied

BYLINE: From news service reports

SECTION: SPORTS

LENGTH: 654 words


Helio Castroneves -- winner of both the Indianapolis 500 and reality TV show
"Dancing with the Stars" -- pleaded not guilty in Miami federal court Friday to
multimillion-dollar tax-evasion charges alleging use of offshore accounts.

The famed Brazilian driver, who owns a Coral Gables, Fla., mansion sporting his
auto-racing trophies and two checkered flags from his Indy 500 victories, was
ordered to post a $10 million bond to gain his release before trial.

The 33-year-old race car driver appeared in court in handcuffs and leg chains.
His lawyer, Mark Seiden, said Castroneves would be heading to Atlanta for a
weekend race.

His bond allows him to travel for work in the United States but not overseas.

The Team Penske star is charged with failing to pay taxes on more than $5
million in income during a four-year period. His sister, Kati Castroneves, and
his lawyer, Alan Miller, are accused of assisting him in the alleged tax-evasion
scheme.

Kati Castroneves, the driver's business manager, and Miller did not enter pleas
but were released on bonds of $2 million and $250,000, respectively.

The three defendants used an offshore corporation set up in Panama to pull off
the scheme, according to an indictment filed Thursday.

"It is particularly pernicious when individuals with access to offshore accounts
use that to avoid paying taxes," said Miami U.S. Attorney R. Alexander Acosta.

Castroneves' attorney, Mark Seiden, said his client didn't knowingly violate any
laws.

"Mr. Castroneves is a professional racing driver. He relied on the advice of tax
lawyers and accountants in doing his tax planning," Seiden said. "It is our
position that he has not violated any laws and that he relied upon their advice
in good faith."

But Acosta said Castroneves lied to his tax preparers, claiming he had no
control over the Panamanian company when he actually did.

Castroneves was born in Sao Paulo. Race-car driving has made him a rich man.

He won the Indianapolis 500 in 2001 and 2002. He was the fifth driver to achieve
that milestone in consecutive years. He also finished second to teammate and
countryman Gil de Ferran in 2003.

He became a bona fide American celebrity last year after winning the fifth
season of ABC's reality TV show "Dancing with the Stars" with partner Julianne
Hough.

Earnhardt runs into trouble: Dale Earnhardt Jr. had better days at Talladega.

Earnhardt's No. 88 Chevrolet blew an engine in the first practice on the Alabama
track and blew a tire in the second, and it cost him any shot of starting in the
front of the field.

When the right tire exploded in the afternoon practice, it triggered a multicar
wreck that affected Tony Stewart, Kasey Kahne, David Reutimann and a few others.
Earnhardt spun and hit the wall, debris flying all over the track and collecting
other drivers up in the mess as well. His car was towed off NASCAR's biggest
track.

Stewart and Kahne connected, and Stewart's No. 20 Toyota slid down the track and
into the grass.

Earnhardt, who already had to start in the back because of the engine change,
was forced to go to his backup car. It was the same car he used in Daytona to
win the 150-mile qualifying race.

"I feel like we'll definitely mentally be stronger for Sunday because of what
happened today," Earnhardt said.

Stewart upset: Don't look for Tony Stewart crew chief Greg Zipadelli to try and
play nice with Brian Vickers' team any time soon. Zipadelli was steamed after
what he said was Vickers' refusal to cooperate in the pits last week in Kansas.

Stewart was delayed three times getting out back on the track because Vickers --
who was pitted in front of Stewart -- had issues getting out his pit stall.
Stewart nearly made contact with Vickers' gas man during one early pit stop.

Zipadelli said if Vickers and his team didn't want to work together, "that's
their prerogative."

"I can't get mad about it," Zipadelli said. "But what I'll do is I won't ever
cut them any slack again."

                           September 9, 1989 Saturday

Bakker aides sentenced to more than 17 years

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 511 words

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, NC


Reuter
  CHARLOTTE, N.C.

Two of Jim Bakker 's former aides were sentenced to more than 17 years
in jail and fined $500,000 each on tax evasion charges yesterday as a
minister appealed to the television evangelist to repent.

'Greed, lust and power. It happens. It happens to the best of us,'  Rev. Alan
Foor, a United Church minister from Beavertown, Pa., declared at  Mr. Bakker's
fraud trial. 'Jim and (his wife) Tammy had better look at  the humble lifestyle
of Jesus Christ.'     In a separate courtroom, former Bakker aides David and
James Taggart  received their sentences for using church credit cards to buy
furs, jewels  and a condominium at the Trump Tower in New York.

The two men said Mr. Bakker's PTL ministry had known about the
purchases.

David Taggart , 32, the evangelist's former personal assistant, was
sentenced to 18 years and five months in jail and fined $500,000. His
brother James, the former PTL interior decorator, was sentenced to 17
years and nine months, and fined $500,000.

Both men were convicted in July on five counts of tax evasion and
conspiracy, charges that carry a maximum penalty of 25 years.

Assistant U.S. Attorney David Brown said Federal Judge Robert Potter
imposed the maximum penalty allowed under new federal sentencing
guidelines. He praised the sentences, saying they send a message that
white-collar criminals face the same penalties as those who commit crimes
such as bank robbery.

Mr. Bakker, on trial in the same courthouse, is accused of overselling
subscriptions for a time-share scheme at the PTL's huge Heritage USA theme
park, 20 kilometres from Charlotte. In return for $1,000, buyers were
entitled to three nights of lodging annually for the rest of their lives
at a park hotel.

Testifying yesterday, Mr. Foor said his subscription was for a hotel
that was never completed, and he was not able to obtain a refund of the
$1,000 fee.

'I feel robbed and cheated,' he said. 'I do forgive them for the  drug and
sexual thing, but I have a hard time dealing with the misuse of  money.'
Tammy Faye Bakker entered hospital at one point to obtain treatment for  abuse
of prescription drugs. Mr. Bakker was forced to resign from PTL  after it was
revealed he had had an affair with church secretary Jessica  Hahn.

Mr. Foor said that after Mr. Bakker resigned he made 'dumb excuses . .
. about millions of dollars in ministry money unaccounted for and said the
devil got into the computer.

'How dumb does he think we are that he can pass everything off on the  devil
question?'     Appearing earlier, former PTL budget director Mark Burgund said
the  ministry tried to get a $50-million loan in Switzerland after local banks
refused because its cheques kept bouncing.

He said an unidentified Swiss corporation agreed to make the loan on
condition that the ministry set up a company in Switzerland and transfer
all PTL assets to it.

The condition was not acceptable, he said, so PTL turned down the
offer.

Mr. Bakker could face 120 years in jail and a $5-million fine if
convicted on all of the 24 counts of fraud and conspiracy he faces.

                               The New York Times

               March 12, 1987, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

BROOKLYN FUEL DISTRIBUTOR PLEADS GUILTY IN TAX PLOT

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 462 words

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 11


A gasoline distributor pleaded guilty today to evading millions of dollars in
state fuel taxes in what state officials called one of the largest gasoline
bootlegging operations in the nation.

Under the terms of the plea, the distributor, David Bogatin, 41 years old, of
104 Amherst Street in the Manhattan Beach section of Brooklyn, will be sentenced
to up to eight years in state prison and must pay almost $5 million in
restitution to the state and Federal governments.

Mr. Bogatin faces additional Federal and local penalties on other aspects of the
gasoline scheme, which prosecutors said sought to confuse tax auditors by
generating vast quantities of paperwork through the repeated sale and resale of
bulk gasoline. The restitution amount represents the government revenue
estimated to have been lost from the improper sale of approximately 15 million
gallons of gasoline from 1982 to 1985.

The penalties are among the heaviest ever imposed in a state tax-evasion case,
state officials said. And Mr. Bogatin's admission of guilt, entered in Albany
County Court, was a key element in efforts to break a network of illegal
activity that law enforcement officials said was run by a group of Russian and
eastern European immigrants with links to organized crime.

Gas Distributor 'Cartel'

Nathan Riley, a spokesman for state Attorney General Robert Abrams, said Mr.
Bogatin, a Russian immigrant, was part of a cartel of dishonest gas distributors
that prosecutors believe operated under the direction of Michael Franzese, a
reputed captain of the Colombo organized-crime family. Mr. Franzese is now
serving a 10-year sentence for a Federal racketeering conviction.

The tax-evasion scheme, Mr. Riley said, took advantage of state laws that from
1982 to 1985 required that taxes be paid by a wholesaler before gasoline was
sent into the retail-distribution chain. Although a single gasoline shipment may
be owned by several wholesalers at different times, the law stated that only one
dealer was required to pay the tax.

To confuse state tax auditors, Mr. Riley said, Mr. Bogatin and other dealers set
up a series of dummy distributorships and sold gasoline among them in a series
of quick transactions - as many as six in a week - creating voluminous paperwork
that left sequences of ownership and tax responsibility in doubt.

The scheme allowed Mr. Bogatin to amass a fortune, including six condominiums in
Trump Tower in midtown Manhattan, the authorities said.

The investigation of Mr. Bogatin's business dealings was conducted by the Long
Island Oil Industry Organized Crime Task Force, a joint Federal, state and local
law-enforcement effort that was established in November 1982 to combat illegal
practices by gasoline distributors on Long Island.

Washington: Albuquerque Businessman Pleads Guilty to Federal Tax Evasion Charge

LENGTH: 405  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



 James E. Coleman, Jr., the former president and owner of Sneakerz, Inc., a
corporation that operated "Sneakerz Sports Bar" in Albuquerque, N.M., pleaded
guilty this morning in federal court to a tax evasion charge, announced U.S.
Attorney Damon P. Martinez and Ismael Nevarez Jr., Special Agent in Charge of
the Phoenix Field Office of IRS Criminal Investigation.

Coleman, 58, was charged in Nov. 2014, in a four-count indictment alleging tax
evasion and subscribing false tax returns charges.  Counts 1 and 2 charged
Coleman with evading $166,320.00 in federal corporate taxes in calendar years
2008 and 2009 by filing false tax returns that underrepresented his
corporation's taxable income.  Count 1 charged Coleman with evading $90,661.00
in federal taxes by falsely claiming that his corporation had $621,064.00 in
taxable income in calendar year 2008 despite knowing that the corporation had
$886,128 in taxable income for that year.  Count 2 charged him with evading
$75,659.00 in federal taxes by falsely claiming that his corporation had
$731,581.00 in taxable income in calendar year 2009 despite knowing that the
corporation had $932,235.00 in taxable income for that year.  Counts 3 and 4
charged Coleman with filing individual tax returns for calendar years 2008 and
2009 that falsely reported that Coleman received no dividend income and no
business income during those two calendar years. During today's proceedings,
Coleman pled guilty to Count 1 of the indictment and admitted evading a total of
$1,045,939.00 in federal corporate and personal taxes between calendar years
2002 and 2009.  In his plea agreement, Coleman acknowledged underrepresenting
Sneakerz's gross receipts to the IRS with the intention of evading his corporate
tax liability.  He also admitted falsely underrepresenting the income he derived
from Sneakerz on his personal tax returns.   At sentencing, Coleman faces a
maximum statutory penalty of five years in federal prison.  Coleman also will be
subject to an order requiring that he pay restitution in an amount to be
determined by the court. This case was investigated by the Albuquerque office of
IRS Criminal Investigation and is being prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney
Jeremy Peña.

Arizona: Former Head of Operations at New York Brokerage Firm Pleads Guilty to
Tax Evasion and Filing False Tax Return

LENGTH: 298  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Justice has issued the following news releae:

A former resident of North Bellmore, New York, pleaded guilty today in the U.S.
District Court for the Eastern District of New York in Long Island to one count
of tax evasion and one count of filing a false federal income tax return,
announced Acting Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo of the Justice
Department's Tax Division.

According to the indictment, Dominick Pannitti, 38, was head of operations at a
securities brokerage firm located in Syosset, New York. The brokerage firm used
an automated system designed to adjust customers' trading accounts for amounts
less than $1,000. During 2005 and 2006, Pannitti used the automated system to
credit his own trading accounts-set up in the name of a corporation that he
owned-more than 850 times in increments of less than $1,000. Pannitti was not
entitled to most of these credits, which totaled more than $570,000. Pannitti
failed to report the income on his 2005 and 2006 federal income tax returns.

Pannitti faces a statutory maximum sentence of five years in prison and up to a
$250,000 fine for the tax evasion count and a statutory maximum sentence of
three years in prison and up to a $250,000 fine for the false return count at
his sentencing before U.S. District Judge Arthur D. Spatt.

Acting Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo commended the special agents of
IRS-Criminal Investigation and the FBI, who investigated the case, and Trial
Attorneys Mark Kotila and Jeffrey Bender of the Tax Division, who are
prosecuting the case. Ciraolo also thanked the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
Eastern District of New York for their substantial assistance.

TAMPA BAY AREA

Feds Move To Dismiss

One of the founders of the Hooters restaurant chain appears to have won his
legal battle against the federal government. On Thursday, the U.S. attorney's
office filed a motion to dismiss criminal tax-evasion charges against Lynn
"L.D." Stewart. Stewart faced two counts of federal tax evasion and two counts
of filing a false tax return. However, jurors in his November trial were unable
to reach a verdict, and a judge declared a mistrial.

John Fitzgibbons, Stewart's attorney, said a federal judge was expected to
approve the government's motion by today.

WellCare Adding 50

WellCare Health Plans said it will add 50 more pharmacy technicians at its
Renaissance Centre campus in Tampa.

They will handle calls from doctors' offices and pharmacies to discuss Medicare
prescriptions.

For information or to apply for a job, visit WellCare's job fair from 2:30 to
7:30 p.m. Tuesday at the Renaissance Centre, 3725 Henderson Road.

Walter Unit Closing

Mueller Water Products, part of Tampa-based Walter Industries, said Thursday
that it will close a Dixon, Ill., valve manufacturing plant by the end of 2006,
affecting 107 employees.

MTS CFO Leaving

MTS Medication Technologies of St. Petersburg, which makes medicine packaging
systems, announced Thursday that Chief Financial Officer Michael Branca will
leave March 17. Controller Terri Dunbar will oversee financial operations until
a replacement is named.

NATION

FTC Fines ChoicePoint

ChoicePoint agreed Thursday to pay $15 million to settle Federal Trade
Commission charges that the data warehouser's record-handling procedures
violated consumers' privacy rights when thieves infiltrated ChoicePoint's
database.

But another investigation of ChoicePoint's top two officers by the Securities
and Exchange Commission looms, and some Washington lawmakers say tougher
regulations are still needed to prevent another breach.

Chipolte IPO Sizzles

Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill, owned by McDonald's Corp., doubled in price
Thursday in their trading debut on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares in the
initial public offering were priced at $22 Wednesday evening but had doubled by
closing to $44 a share.

                              The Washington Post

                     July 16, 1992, Thursday, Final Edition

Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Mail Fraud, Tax Evasion

Sharon Walsh, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FINANCIAL; PAGE D10

LENGTH: 620 words


For years, crime really did pay for Washington attorney Herbert Lawrence Fox.

With more than $ 1.5 million in funds stolen from his law firm and his clients
from 1986 to 1991, Fox bought three Jaguars, expensive jewelry and gifts, took
vacations to Europe and the Caribbean and decorated a beach house in Nags Head,
N.C., and a home in Alexandria.

Yesterday, Fox, 52, tanned and soft-spoken, pleaded guilty in U.S. District
Court in Washington to mail fraud and tax evasion as part of a plea bargain
agreement in which he admitted using three different schemes to defraud his
former firms -- Winston & Strawn of Chicago and Bishop, Cook, Purcell & Reynolds
of Washington -- and clients.

As part of the plea agreement, the former senior partner has turned over to the
federal government his personal belongings, including houses, works of art, a
silver service for 24, cars and personal jewelry. Proceeds from his pension fund
also will go to the government. The cash value of his life insurance policies
will be used to pay his attorney's fees.

Even his wedding ring had to be sold, but the government allowed his wife to buy
it back.

"Your honor, Mr. Fox has, in effect, been stripped of everything but his
underwear," said Peter F. Vaira, Fox's attorney. "He's turned it all over to the
government."

Fox is scheduled to be sentenced Sept. 30 and could receive up to 10 years in
prison and criminal fines of $ 500,000 in addition to the restitution. Fox, who
specialized in representing cities in waste disposal cases, has stopped
practicing law and is unemployed, Vaira said.

Gary Fairchild, managing partner of Winston & Strawn in Chicago, said yesterday
that the firm has cooperated with the government in the case and intends to file
a civil lawsuit against Fox, who had become part of the firm when Bishop, Cook
and Winston & Strawn merged in early 1990.

It was Winston & Strawn that notified investigators when they found
discrepancies in Fox's accounts. Fairchild said the firm is in the process of
reimbursing clients.

Fox used several methods to make extra cash over the five-year period, according
to the government's evidence.

In one, he funneled payments through Keefe Co., a Washington lobbying firm. Fox
presented bills to both Bishop, Cook and Winston & Strawn on Keefe Co.
stationery falsely saying that Keefe had done work for clients.

Once the payments were made by the law firms from client funds, Keefe Co. paid
the money -- about $ 1 million over five years -- to Fox, members of his family
and others, according to court documents.

Keefe Co. has not been charged with any wrongdoing and prosecutors declined
yesterday to comment on whether the company is part of an ongoing investigation
of the case. B. Michael Rauh, an attorney for Keefe, could not be reached for
comment.

A receptionist at Keefe said all the principals of the firm, including Chairman
Robert J. Keefe, were in New York at the Democratic convention and could not be
reached.

Fox also submitted false expense account reports and vendor bills. One phony
invoice indicated that local transportation worth more than $ 20,000 had been
provided to Fox's local clients. The law firms charged client accounts.

A California car dealer who sold Fox a 1991 Jaguar submitted the transportation
bill, which was used as partial payment for the car.

In another case, Fox submitted more than $ 10,000 in expenses for hotels and
meals in Paris and London while working for clients. In fact, the expenses were
for a European vacation taken by Fox and family members.

Fox, a former Internal Revenue Service bureau chief, did not pay taxes on much
of the income he fraudulently received, according to the plea agreement.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS, DC NEWS

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                             August 14, 2011 Sunday

Escort service manager serving prison time for tax evasion loses appeal

BYLINE: By Melinda Rogers The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; State

LENGTH: 404 words


The former office manager of Salt Lake City-based escort service Companions on
Friday lost her bid to have her three-year prison sentence for tax evasion
overturned by the 10th Circuit Court of Appeals in Denver.

Jodi Hoskins, 35, was sentenced to three years in federal prison by U.S.
District Judge Dee Benson in July 2010 and ordered to pay about $736,000 in
restitution for failing to pay taxes. Hoskins worked as a "phone girl" at
Companions booking escorts for private sessions and bachelor parties.

At a January 2010 bench trial, Benson ruled Hoskins underreported the gross
receipts for the business owned by she and her husband, Roy B. Hoskins, on her
2002 individual income tax return.

The 2002 return reported $902,750 in gross receipts from Companions, but an
investigation determined that Companions received at least $1 million in
credit-card payments alone that year, court documents state. Because the company
reported it received 50 to 70 percent of its payments in cash, investigators
estimated Companions' 2002 receipts at $2.1 million --more than $1.2 million
more than the amount claimed by the Hoskinses.

Benson ruled the government proved that Hoskins intended to evade the payment of
taxes owed by her husband, Roy Hoskins, 38, who owned and operated Companions
until 2006.

Jodi Hoskins claimed on appeal there was insufficient evidence to support her
conviction. She claimed when she signed her 2002 tax return, she didn't
understand the legal consequences of underreporting income. She also argued
through her attorney, Andrew McCullough, that the district court's calculation
of the government's tax loss was wrong and that Benson erred when applying a
sentencing enhancement for failing to report sources of income derived from
criminal activity, according to court documents.

The appeals court rejected the claim. Jodi Hoskins will serve the rest of her
prison sentence in Dublin, Calif., before she is released in August 2012.

Benson in May 2010 sentenced Roy Hoskins to 60 months in prison incarceration
after he pleaded guilty to tax evasion. Benson ordered him to pay $817,895 in
restitution. The appeals court also rejected a claim from Roy Hoskins to have
his sentence overturned. He is housed in a federal prison in northern California
and is scheduled for release in May 2014.

                          The Calgary Herald (Alberta)

                           October 29, 2009 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Ex-client of UBS gets house arrest for tax fraud

BYLINE: Tom Brown, Reuters

SECTION: CALGARY BUSINESS; Pg. D10

LENGTH: 457  words

DATELINE: MIAMI


A former client of UBS AG who co-operated in a U.S. probe of the Swiss bank's
ties with wealthy Americans hiding money overseas was sentenced Wednesday to one
year house arrest and a fine for a multimillion-dollar tax evasion scheme.

Steven Michael Rubinstein, 55, was the first former customer of UBS to be
sentenced for tax fraud following a protracted U.S. legal battle with the bank
that ended in August with an agreement to crack open Switzerland's long
tradition of bank secrecy.

Rubinstein, a Florida accountant who pleaded guilty to a single count of tax
evasion in June, was sentenced to a total of three years of probation including
12 months of house arrest. He was also ordered to pay a $40,000 fine.

UBS settled a sweeping U.S. criminal probe earlier this year by paying a $780
million penalty and admitting it helped U.S. citizens evade taxes.

It then ended a related civil suit in August by agreeing to turn over the names
of 4,450 wealthy U.S. clients with undisclosed offshore accounts.

Rubinstein's sentence, handed down by a federal court judge in Miami, was in
line with the Justice Department's recent request for leniency for Rubinstein
due to what it described as his substantial cooperation in a probe centring on
Americans with undisclosed offshore accounts at UBS.

The U.S. government had alleged that Rubinstein, who worked for a company in the
yacht business, evaded taxes on $3 million by stashing funds in a British Virgin
Islands corporation set up through a UBS account that was active from 2001 to
2008.

He had faced a maximum sentence of three years in prison, but the Justice
Department called for no more than a 12-month sentence in a court filing last
Friday.

Federal Court Judge Marcia Cooke called the sentence reduction unusually lenient
in her remarks to the courtroom on Wednesday but said no one should
underestimate the value of Rubinstein's co-operation with authorities in their
crackdown on tax evasion.

"Thousands if not millions of taxpayers now know what the legal landscape is,"
said Cooke. "We will not tolerate offshore tax evasion."

Her remarks came after Rubinstein, who had posted $12 million bail after his
arrest, voiced contrition for his tax dodging and vowed that he would never
stray outside the law again.

"I'm embarrassed and ashamed to be standing here before you," said Rubinstein.
"I will continue to assist the government in any manner requested."

Jeffrey Chernick, another former UBS client who has pleaded guilty of tax
evasion, is due to be sentenced in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, on Friday for
hiding more than $8 million from U.S. tax authorities.

The Justice Department has also asked for a reduced sentenced for Chernick,
citing his co-operation in UBS-related criminal investigations.

Former Wal-Mart vice-chairman pleads guilty to wire fraud, tax evasion

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: FINANCIAL POST; Pg. FP6

LENGTH: 120  words


Former Wal-Mart Stores Inc. vice-chairman Tom Coughlin yesterday admitted to
misappropriating company funds, pleading guilty to five counts of wire fraud and
one of tax evasion. Mr. Coughlin, who joined the company in 1978 and worked
closely with legendary founder Sam Walton, faces up to five years in prison
and/or a $250US,000 fine for each count of wire fraud, and up to three in prison
and/or a $100US,000 fine for tax evasion. Mr. Coughlin entered his guilty plea
in U.S. District Court in Fort Smith, Ark. Judge Robert Dawson ordered the
14-page plea agreement placed under seal, saying he was "concerned, deeply
concerned" about pretrial publicity in the case. Sentencing was postponed
pending a pretrial report.

                  The Register-Herald (Beckley, West Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 16, 2009 Friday

Former ACE Adventures employee indicted on tax evasion charge

BYLINE: Michelle James, The Register-Herald, Beckley, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 346 words


Oct. 16--A former employee of ACE Adventures was indicted Thursday in federal
court in Charleston on charges of tax evasion and providing false statements.

According to the indictment, Carl W. Steward, 59, who now lives in Asheville,
N.C., engaged in several fraudulent schemes aimed at defrauding ACE.

Among those, the indictment states, is improperly diverting ACE income to his
personal bank accounts and orchestrating a "kickback" scheme through which he
had many ACE vendors return a portion of their proceeds to him.

Steward opened a checking account in Oak Hill in the name of the Society for the
Preservation of Vaudeville and Variety Arts Inc., a nonprofit entity in Florida
with whom he had no connection.

Steward then directed ACE-related work to a third-party vendor in exchange for
"commissions" to SPVVA, according to the indictment.

The indictment also states that in 2000 the third-party entity paid $46,000 in
kickbacks for receiving the ACE contract.

Steward was fired from ACE in 2003 and, in response to a civil suit filed
against him by his former employer, he produced tax returns from 2000 to 2004,
although he had never actually filed his taxes during those years.

In 2005, Steward filed false returns for 2002 and 2003 and has yet to file for
2000 and 2001, the indictment said.

Steward's false statements charge stems from information he provided to an IRS
agent in 2006, at which time he said he had filed returns for all four years.

Should Steward be convicted of all four charges, he faces 25 years in prison.

ACE's civil suit against Steward resulted in a $2.3 million verdict in its
favor.

                                The New York Post

                             August 4, 2006 Friday

BETONSPORTS KINGPIN IS FIGHTING EXTRADITION

BYLINE: JANET WHITMAN

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 33

LENGTH: 376 words


Indicted online gambling kingpin Gary Kaplan remains out of the reach of U.S.
law enforcement and getting Costa Rican authorities to hand him over is far from
a sure thing.

Kaplan, who moved his sports-betting operation to Costa Rica in 1997, is wanted
by federal authorities on 20 charges - involving racketeering, conspiracy, tax
evasion and moving gambling paraphernalia across state lines.

But the feds will have to show that the former New York bookie broke Costa Rican
law to persuade the government there that he should be extradited.

The gambling charges are off the table. Betting over the Internet and through
toll-free numbers - as the Kaplan's company BetonSports.com does - is a
legitimate business in Costa Rica.

"The only charge that he could be incriminated on is tax evasion," Moises
Vinzenzi, one of Costa Rica's top criminal defense attorneys, told The Post.
"But they're working here and paying taxes here."

Vinzenzi, who fought the extradition of phony plastic surgeon Dean Faiello in
2004, said yesterday that he has spoken with an associate of Kaplan and may be
taking up the case if the feds seek an extradition order.

The Justice Department in St. Louis, Missouri, which brought the charges against
him and BetonSports in mid-July, may not know of his whereabouts.

Justice Dept. spokeswoman Jan Diltz declined to comment.

Kaplan, who is said to travel with a posse of a dozen gun-toting bodyguards, may
be holed up in one of his Costa Rican homes. He's also been rumored to be in
Israel.

Also on the lam are Norman Steinberg, co-owner with Kaplan of Millennium
Sportsbook, Gibraltar Sportsbook and North American Sports Association, and
Peter Wilson, media director for BetonSports. Eight others have been arrested in
the case, including BetonSports CEO David Carruthers, who is in a St. Louis
jail.

Kaplan, a Brooklyn native, got permanent residence status from Costa Rica's
immigration department in July 2003, about a year and a half after he first
applied.

Perhaps worried that the feds were on to him, the 47-year-old asked for Costa
Rican citizenship just this month. Citizens of the country can't be extradited.
Kaplan's application is still pending.

with Juan Manuel Campos in Costa Rica

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

            October 18, 2002 Friday Illinois Five Star Lift Edition

LAW & ORDER

SECTION: METRO ; Law & Order Column; Pg. C2

LENGTH: 711 words


ST. LOUIS

Businessman gets two-year sentence in bankruptcy and tax-evasion case

Richard E. Gray, the former chairman of an aluminum siding company in Fenton,
was sentenced Thursday in federal court in St. Louis to two years in prison for
tax evasion and a bankruptcy-related crime. Gray, 55, formerly of New York, had
been chairman of HomeStar Industries of Fenton, which was forced into bankruptcy
in 1997 by creditors.

Authorities said that in the months before the bankruptcy, the company's former
owner died, and HomeStar received more than $1 million in life insurance
proceeds. Gray defrauded the creditors and customers by transferring those
proceeds to other companies and accounts he controlled, according to the U.S.
attorney's office.

When Gray was asked about it in the bankruptcy case, prosecutors said, he made
false statements under oath to disguise the transfers as a loan.

He pleaded guilty July 24 to one count of making false statements under oath
during bankruptcy proceedings. Gray also pleaded guilty to one count of tax
evasion. He evaded paying income taxes for the years 1984 through 1987 in the
total amount of $370,927, according to the U.S. attorney's office. Gray's
attorney, David Harlan, said he and his client had no comment.

ALTON

Officials identify baby who died at home

Authorities identified a 4-month-old baby who died Wednesday morning at an Alton
residence as Tequila McGee.

Alton police were called to the house, in the 1100 block of Pearl Street, about
11:30 a.m. Wednesday by Tequila's baby sitter, who said the child had been found
in her bed not breathing. Efforts to revive the baby failed, and she was
pronounced dead at a hospital.

Police originally called the death suspicious because of the baby's age. An
autopsy Wednesday night found no signs of foul play, but lab tests are still
pending, police said.

GRANITE CITY

Mother of accident victim sues police officer, city

The mother of a man killed last year in a collision with a Granite City police
car filed a lawsuit Wednesday in Madison County Circuit Court seeking $200,000
each from the city and the police officer who drove the patrol car.

David Ortiz, 24, of Granite City, was killed Oct. 21 when he turned his car into
the path of Sgt. Kenneth Rozell's unmarked police car, authorities said.
Rozell's warning lights were on as he headed down Madison Avenue to the scene of
an armed robbery, police explained.

The suit claims that Rozell had a known history of traffic violations but the
Granite City Police Department never disciplined him for them. Officials said
Thursday that an investigation found that Rozell had not violated any department
policies.

PONTOON BEACH

Woman struck at charity roadblock files suit

Granite City resident Lea Haddix, who was hit by a pickup last October while
collecting donations at an intersection in Pontoon Beach, filed suit Thursday in
Madison County Circuit Court against Pontoon Beach, Granite City Elks Lodge No.
1063 and Rodney L. Wright, the driver who hit her.

The suit claims the village erred by allowing volunteers to collect donations
without providing any safety instructions or requiring them to follow state laws
about charity roadblocks. The Elks Lodge sponsored the donation drive.

Wright, 74, of Granite City is facing reckless driving charges for the accident,
which also injured Thomas Boushard of Granite City.

JEFFERSON COUNTY

De Soto teenager dies in crash on Highway 21

A De Soto teenager is dead after the pickup he was driving swerved into oncoming
traffic and collided with another vehicle early Thursday morning. It was the
latest of several deaths in recent years on Highway 21, Jefferson County's
so-called "Blood Alley."

Matthew Steven Baisch, 19, was found dead at the scene. Rodney Louis Kelly, 18,
also of De Soto, was a passenger in Baisch's car and was treated at St. John's
Mercy Medical Center in Creve Coeur and released. The driver of the second car,
Marcaline Rion, 33, of Hillsboro, was treated at St. Anthony's Medical Center in
south St. Louis County and released.

Police said Baisch's truck crossed the center line and struck Rion's northbound
car at about 2:15 a.m., just north of Lake Lorraine Road in central Jefferson
County.

                               The New York Times

                 June 19, 1999, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Judge Says Hirschfeld Can Defend Himself

BYLINE: Reuters

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 165 words


Abe Hirschfeld, the real estate mogul who offered Paula Jones $1 million to end
a lawsuit against President Clinton, was declared fit to defend himself on state
tax-evasion charges yesterday.

Judge Bruce Allen of State Supreme Court in Manhattan said he had been assured
of Mr. Hirschfeld's fitness and tentatively set a trial date of June 24.

Mr. Hirschfeld plans to call as witnesses former Presidents Jimmy Carter and
George Bush, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Donald Trump and the Rev. Al Sharpton,
according to a witness list he filed with the court.

Since May 1997, when Mr. Hirschfeld pleaded not guilty to a 123-count
indictment, he has fired at least 10 lawyers. In addition to tax evasion, the
indictment charges him and several of his business corporations with scheming to
defraud.

Separately, Mr. Hirschfeld is charged with plotting to have a business partner
killed. In that case, he is accused of having paid $75,000 to an intermediary to
arrange the killing.
