                                US Official News

                             June 25, 2016 Saturday

Albuquerque Businessman Pleads Guilty to Federal Tax Evasion Charge

LENGTH: 410  words

DATELINE: New York



 Office for the United States Attorneys, District of New Mexico has issued the
following news release:



  James E. Coleman, Jr., the former president and owner of Sneakerz, Inc., a
corporation that operated "Sneakerz Sports Bar" in Albuquerque, N.M., pleaded
guilty this morning in federal court to a tax evasion charge, announced U.S.
Attorney Damon P. Martinez and Ismael Nevarez Jr., Special Agent in Charge of
the Phoenix Field Office of IRS Criminal Investigation.





 Coleman, 58, was charged in Nov. 2014, in a four-count indictment alleging tax
evasion and subscribing false tax returns charges.  Counts 1 and 2 charged
Coleman with evading $166,320.00 in federal corporate taxes in calendar years
2008 and 2009 by filing false tax returns that underrepresented his
corporation's taxable income.  Count 1 charged Coleman with evading $90,661.00
in federal taxes by falsely claiming that his corporation had $621,064.00 in
taxable income in calendar year 2008 despite knowing that the corporation had
$886,128 in taxable income for that year.  Count 2 charged him with evading
$75,659.00 in federal taxes by falsely claiming that his corporation had
$731,581.00 in taxable income in calendar year 2009 despite knowing that the
corporation had $932,235.00 in taxable income for that year.  Counts 3 and 4
charged Coleman with filing individual tax returns for calendar years 2008 and
2009 that falsely reported that Coleman received no dividend income and no
business income during those two calendar years.



 During today's proceedings, Coleman pled guilty to Count 1 of the indictment
and admitted evading a total of $1,045,939.00 in federal corporate and personal
taxes between calendar years 2002 and 2009.  In his plea agreement, Coleman
acknowledged underrepresenting Sneakerz's gross receipts to the IRS with the
intention of evading his corporate tax liability.  He also admitted falsely
underrepresenting the income he derived from Sneakerz on his personal tax
returns.



 At sentencing, Coleman faces a maximum statutory penalty of five years in
federal prison.  Coleman also will be subject to an order requiring that he pay
restitution in an amount to be determined by the court.



 This case was investigated by the Albuquerque office of IRS Criminal
Investigation and is being prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeremy Peña.

                                US Official News

                           December 30, 2014 Tuesday

Washington: Countries Affected by Ebola Lose $1.4 Billion Annually to Debt,
Corruption and Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 472  words

DATELINE: Washington


Common Dreams has issued the following news release:

New reports show that the Ebola-affected countries of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra
Leone lose an average of $1.4 billion each year to corruption, debt payments and
tax evasion. Global Financial Integrity (GFI) calculates the three countries
lost about $1.3 billion per year to corruption and tax evasion in the decade
leading up to the Ebola outbreak. New World Bank data indicates the countries
spent over $80 million on debt payments in 2013, the year the outbreak began.
According to the World Bank, the countries spent a total of $270 million on
public health in 2012.

"Debt, corruption and tax evasion are part of why people die in West Africa,"
stated Eric LeCompte, Executive Director of Jubilee USA, a religious development
coalition. "The money was there to contain Ebola and save more people from
preventable diseases."

Guinea, where the outbreak began, spent more on debt payments in 2012 than it
spent on public health. Guinea spent $207 million on debt payments in 2013 and
2012. According to the Financial Times, the three countries owe the
International Monetary Fund (IMF) nearly $480 million. Sierra Leone spent $2.3
million paying off debts since the IMF announced a debt relief plan in November
and will spend nearly $2 million more before the end of the year. The three
countries accrued much of their current debt burden during civil wars,
dictatorships and one-party rule. US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew brought
Jubilee USA's plan for debt relief to the November G20 meetings held in
Brisbane, Australia. The G20 made a financing commitment to the three Ebola
affected countries of 300 million dollars in debt relief, grants and new loans.
The IMF could announce the financing plan as early as January.

"Winning debt relief and stopping tax evasion provide long term monies for
healthcare and development," said LeCompte, who serves on United Nations Expert
Groups that address debt and illicit finance. "More people die from preventable
diseases annually in these countries than from Ebola."

According to GFI, developing countries lose nearly $1 trillion each year to
illicit flows. From 2003 - 2012, Liberia lost more than $900 million annually on
average, while Guinea lost more than $300 million. In 2013, the G8 signed a
joint declaration calling on the international community to curb corruption and
corporate tax avoidance. This past August, during the White House Africa Summit,
the Obama Administration announced a committee to make recommendations to
address these outflows.

"There's broad consensus that we need to keep money from flowing out of
developing economies," added LeCompte. "There's so much the international
community can do."

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

            The Fayetteville Observer (Fayetteville, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 19, 2011 Thursday

Fayetteville preacher pleads guilty to tax evasion

BYLINE: Drew Brooks, The Fayetteville Observer, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 504 words


May 19--A Fayetteville preacher linked to a company investigated for health care
fraud has pleaded guilty to filing a false income tax return.

Earlene McKeithan Baggett pleaded guilty at a federal court in Raleigh on
Monday, according to U.S. Attorney George E.B. Holding.

Baggett is accused of lying about her income in 2008 and 2009 while working at
Learning Links Educational Network Services Center and AME Zion Church, and
collecting retirement benefits from the state.

According to Holding's office, Baggett received about $34,000 a year from the
state in disability benefits and failed to report and pay taxes on any of her
church income and much of the money she received from Learning Links.

In 2008 and 2009, she told the N.C. Retirement Systems Board that she had no
income, prosecutors said. Baggett is estimated to have earned $115,000 in
unreported income in 2009.

She pleaded guilty to U.S. District Judge Terrence W. Boyle and faces up to
three years in prison and a fine of $100,000 at sentencing in August,
prosecutors say.

Baggett was charged earlier this year following an investigation that began last
year while federal agents were looking into allegations of fraud at Learning
Links.

Baggett worked as medical director for Learning Links, according to the
government.

The investigation into Learning Links ended late last year after its owner,
Sandra Elliott, was sentenced to a decade in prison and ordered to pay nearly
$1.9 million in restitution.

Elliott pleaded guilty to aiding and abetting health care fraud following the
joint federal and state investigation into the company, which opened in 2006.
She received the maximum prison term allowed under her charge.

The company, which claimed to provide early intervention treatment for children
with developmental delays, anger problems and other special needs, operated
three locations in Fayetteville, one in Dunn and had plans to open others,
according to Holding's office.

The company relied on payment from government-run benefit programs, but
investigators said that some children who allegedly received services weren't in
the state on the billed date of service or were billed for several months after
ending treatment.

According to investigators, the total fraud was calculated to be nearly $2
million, with $1,172,647 in losses attributed to the Tricare program and
$712,548 in losses attributed to Medicaid.

Investigators discovered the fraud in 2009, when a search of Learning Links
locations confirmed that the centers employed unlicensed personnel, provided
unwarranted therapy and billed for services not rendered.

fraud has pleaded guilty to filing a false income tax return.

Earlene McKeithan Baggett pleaded guilty at a federal court in Raleigh on
Monday, according to U.S. Attorney George E.B. Holding.

Baggett is accused of lying about her income in 2008 and 2009 while working at
Learning Links Educational Network Services Center and AME Zion Church, and
collecting retirement benefits from the state.

According to Holding's office, Baggett received about $34,000 a year from the
state in disability benefits and failed to report and pay taxes on any of her
church income and much of the money she received from Learning Links.

In 2008 and 2009, she told the N.C. Retirement Systems Board that she had no
income, prosecutors said. Baggett is estimated to have earned $115,000 in
unreported income in 2009.

She pleaded guilty to U.S. District Judge Terrence W. Boyle and faces up to
three years in prison and a fine of $100,000 at sentencing in August,
prosecutors say.

Baggett was charged earlier this year following an investigation that began last
year while federal agents were looking into allegations of fraud at Learning
Links.

Baggett worked as medical director for Learning Links, according to the
government.

The investigation into Learning Links ended late last year after its owner,
Sandra Elliott, was sentenced to a decade in prison and ordered to pay nearly
$1.9 million in restitution.

Elliott pleaded guilty to aiding and abetting health care fraud following the
joint federal and state investigation into the company, which opened in 2006.
She received the maximum prison term allowed under her charge.

The company, which claimed to provide early intervention treatment for children
with developmental delays, anger problems and other special needs, operated
three locations in Fayetteville, one in Dunn and had plans to open others,
according to Holding's office.

The company relied on payment from government-run benefit programs, but
investigators said that some children who allegedly received services weren't in
the state on the billed date of service or were billed for several months after
ending treatment.

According to investigators, the total fraud was calculated to be nearly $2
million, with $1,172,647 in losses attributed to the Tricare program and
$712,548 in losses attributed to Medicaid.

Investigators discovered the fraud in 2009, when a search of Learning Links
locations confirmed that the centers employed unlicensed personnel, provided
unwarranted therapy and billed for services not rendered.

                             Daily News (New York)

                          January 15, 1997, Wednesday

COURTHOUSE SONG & DANCE
COP'S TAX-EVASION TRIAL A ZINGER

BYLINE: By GREG B. SMITH and STEPHEN McFARLAND

SECTION: News; Pg.  5

LENGTH: 376 words


A city cop who failed to convince the IRS that he is exempt from the income tax
went to trial yesterday on tax-evasion charges and tried to arrest the judge.

That stroke of genius didn't work any better.

Officer Adalberto Miranda barraged Manhattan Federal Judge Denny Chin with
pseudo-legal babble so insistently that he was finally removed from the
courtroom by U.S. marshals.

"Mr. Miranda, I don't know what is going on in your head," sighed an exasperated
Chin. "I don't know who is giving you these ideas."

Miranda is one of 15 current and former cops busted in July for contending that
the government has no right to tax them. At the time, Mayor Giuliani announced
that as many as 700 more city workers have sought to pull the same scam.

Eight of the cops have pleaded guilty to tax evasion. Miranda and six others
chose to take their chances with juries. One of the cops has been convicted.

All have claimed that the U.S. Constitution forbids the taxation of wage
earners. Phrasing their arguments in fractured courthouse-ese, each has
described himself as "an American man now in an area known geographically as New
York" and has denied being a citizen.

Minutes after Miranda's trial kicked off yesterday, the cop announced that he
was dismissing Chin from the case.

As the judge attempted to swear in the jury, Miranda rose to declare that he "no
longer recognized" his attorney, Edward Panzer, and that he also had decided
Chin was unfit to hear his arguments.

"You are emotionally upset, and your mental temperament is impaired, so I recuse
you," Miranda said.

He then launched a tirade of broken lawyerspeak, demanding that Chin sign a
"reaffirmation of oath" and then tried to arrest him.

"You have the right to remain silent," he advised the judge.

"Mr. Miranda, please," Chin said.

"Your judgment is impaired, and I recuse you," Miranda said.

Panzer asked for a mistrial. But Chin indicating that he suspected Miranda's
bizarre performance was merely to foreshadow a group-defense strategy on the
part of the other accused cops said nothing doing.

Instead, he ordered the marshals to remove Miranda to an adjoining room, from
which he could listen to the rest of the trial on headphones.

                               The New York Times

                  April 2, 1991, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Federal Judge Narrows Case Against Flake

BYLINE: By M. A. FARBER

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 826 words


A Federal judge substantially narrowed the prosecution's embezzlement and tax
evasion case yesterday against the Rev. Floyd H. Flake and his wife, Margarett,
and indicated that he might dismiss all charges against Mrs. Flake.

The rulings and remarks from the bench by Judge Eugene H. Nickerson, who is
presiding over the four-week-old trial in Federal District Court in Brooklyn,
were so broad that jubilant defense lawyers said the case had been "gutted,"
apparently leaving the jury to decide only relatively minor tax charges.

The United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Andrew J.
Maloney, whose office brought the case, said in an interview yesterday that he
would "not argue with that interpretation." He said prosecutors had no regrets
in bringing the case against the Flakes -- "we think it's a good case" -- but
were now "considering our options."

A Ministerial Account

Mr. Flake, a United States Representative from Queens as well as pastor of the
Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church, and his wife are charged with 17
counts of conspiracy, embezzlement, tax evasion and filing false official
statements. The Government contends that Mr. and Mrs. Flake evaded taxes on
$228,000, which was deposited in a ministerial expenses fund that prosecutors
say was a "sham" account to conceal personal expenditures.

The defendants have denied any wrongdoing. Their lawyers assert that if the
Flakes made any mistakes on their taxes, they were unintentional and the matter
should have been resolved by the Internal Revenue Service without a criminal
prosecution.

Yesterday, with only one Government witness left to testify, Judge Nickerson
said he was "concerned" about continuing the case against Mrs. Flake. Although
she signed joint tax returns with her husband, she did not, according to the
testimony, help prepare them. Few witnesses have said they even talked to Mrs.
Flake about matters relevant to the case.

Judge Nickerson scheduled argument for today on whether there was "sufficient
evidence to hold" Mrs. Flake in the case. And he asked prosecutors to address
the question of whether, if he dismisses all charges against Mrs. Flake, he must
also throw out the conspiracy count against her husband, the only named
co-conspirator.

The prosecution's case against both the Flakes has appeared weak from the start,
with all but a few of the witnesses saying they were ignorant of how the
ministerial expenses fund was handled. On cross-examination, most of the
witnesses, including a number who held senior positions at the Allen Church, had
nothing but good to say about the 46-year-old pastor and his 42-year-old wife.

In his opening statement, Mrs. Flake's lawyer, Theodore Wells, said this was "a
strange case," with the "strangest" element being Mrs. Flake's indictment. Mr.
Wells and Mr. Flake's lawyer, Gustave H. Newman, have speculated that Mrs. Flake
was indicted only in an effort by the Government to pressure Mr. Flake into
pleading guilty. Yesterday, Mr. Wells said "the entire house of cards has
collapsed" for the prosecution.

On Thursday, Judge Nickerson indicated that prosecutors were on shaky grounds
with the embezzlement and false-filing charges against the Flakes. Those
charges, he said, hinged on whether the ministerial expenses fund was really a
personal account of the Flakes in which all deposits were subject to taxation,
as the Government asserted, or was an official church account, as the defense
maintained, from which some personal expenditures might have been taxable. The
evidence, the judge said, was that it was a church account.

Yesterday, Judge Nickerson made it formal, ruling that the fund was a church
account. Because Federal law, unlike state law, does not cover embezzlement from
a church account, the embezzlement and false-filing counts against the Flakes
are almost certain to be dropped this week.

A Defense Calculation

The ruling had another devastating impact: it barred prosecutors from trying to
show the jury that the Flakes had evaded taxes on all but an estimated $50,550,
or 22 percent, of the $228,000 that went into the ministerial expenses fund. The
$50,550 -- including allowances and Christmas and vacation bonuses -- was a
defense calculation of taxable but unreported income by the Flakes between 1983
and 1988, the years covered by the indictment

Mr. Newman, Mr. Flake's lawyer, estimated that under the worst of circumstances
Mr. and Mrs. Flake might owe the I.R.S. $15,000. "Nobody," he said outside the
court, "has ever heard of a criminal case brought over $15,000."

The last prosecution witness, who was ready to take the stand yesterday, is
scheduled to be an analyst from the I.R.S. But Judge Nickerson said the analyst
could not testify until the prosecution removed from charts or reduced most of
the figures the analyst was going to explain.

It was unclear whether the defense intends to call any witnesses.

                            June 10, 2015 Wednesday

Pawcatuck man acquitted in federal tax evasion case

BYLINE: Karen Florin, The Day, New London, Conn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 231 words


June 10--A Pawcatuck businessman who had been charged with failing to pay taxes
on more than $1.2 million in income was found not guilty Monday in U.S. District
court.

Pierce Hall, co-owner of Allied Snow Plow and New England Construction, had been
charged with filing false tax returns for the years 2003 and 2004. The
government alleged he under-reported his income by $524,294 in 2003 and $745,000
in 2004. He faced up to six years in prison if convicted.

During a nine-day trial before U.S. District Judge Vanessa L. Bryant, Hall
testified he paid approximately $100,000 to a bookkeeper and accountant to
handle business records while he worked in the field, according to his attorney,
Jeremiah Donovan. A jury deliberated about two hours Monday before returning the
not guilty verdicts.

"Through no intent whatsoever, one of their accounts was not put into Quick
Books (accounting software)," Donovan said. "What he'll do now is what he wanted
to do years ago, sit down and reach an agreement with the IRS as to what is
owed."

Assistant U.S. Attorney Neeraj Patel and senior attorney Richard Schecter had
prosecuted the case.

"As always, we respect the jury's verdict," said a statement from the U.S.
Attorney's office.

Torres sets American mark in 50-meter butterfly

BYLINE: Wire services

SECTION: SPORTS

LENGTH: 587 words


Dara Torres' last-minute decision to try the 50-meter butterfly turned out
better than she imagined.

Torres set an American record Friday morning, then improved that time in the
evening final at the Texas Senior Circuit No. 2 meet at Texas A&M.

The 42-year-old Torres, who won three silver medals in Beijing last summer, says
she's hardly worked on the butterfly since 2000. She only entered the event on
Thursday because she's been fighting a bronchial infection and didn't think she
had the stamina to compete in the 100 free and withdrew.

But Torres breezed to victory in the 50 fly, touching the wall in 25.72 seconds
to beat her record time of 25.84 seconds from the morning preliminaries.

"I really wasn't expecting to even go that fast," she said. "Sometimes, when you
don't expect to do anything, good things happen. You don't put so much pressure
on yourself."

Both her times beat Jenny Thompson's American record of 26.00 seconds, set in
Barcelona in 2003. Marleen Veldhuis of the Netherlands set the world record of
25.33 seconds in April.

Federal prosecutors in Miami dropped the remaining tax evasion conspiracy charge
against two-time Indianapolis 500 champion Helio Castroneves and his sister,
clearing the Brazilian driver of all the charges that once threatened to derail
his career. Castroneves, 34 and one of the favorites for Sunday's Indy 500, and
his 35-year-old sister Katiucia, were acquitted of other tax evasion charges by
a jury April 17.

attorney said. Las Vegas attorney Gabriel Grasso said he had been replaced by
Malcolm Lavergne, a move he attributed to an unspecified rift with Simpson's
longtime Miami-based lawyer, Yale Galanter. Simpson, 61, is serving nine to 33
years in Lovelock State Prison.

Tennis

Jelena Dokic's father was charged with threatening the Australian ambassador in
Belgrade, Serbia. Police found rifles and hand grenades during the search of his
house. Damir Dokic could face up to eight years in prison for "endangering
security" of the ambassador and unlawful possession of weapons, his lawyer,
Bosiljka Djukic, told The Associated Press. Dokic was arrested after he
reportedly said he would blow up Ambassador Clair Birgin's car if she did not
stop negative articles about him from being published in Australia. Jelena Dokic
had given interviews to Australian media, saying her father had beaten her.

          Hantuchova 6-4, 6-7 (2), 6-1 to advance to the final of the Warsaw

Basketball

Former Atlanta Hawks and Stanford swingman Josh Childress asserted that violence
he witnessed in the stands while playing in Greece's top professional league
won't influence his decision on whether to stay in Europe for another season.
"Yes, there was unnecessary violence. It obviously doesn't help the game,"
Childress said. "It doesn't help the players, but that will not have an effect
on my decision about where I play next year."

On Thursday night, the opening game of the Greek finals was interrupted for
nearly 20 minutes with 1:25 to play. Olympiakos fans threw a flare, plastic
bottles and other items at Panathinaikos' bench during a timeout, sending the
players scampering for safety. A timekeeper was slightly injured.

                                   USA TODAY

                             May 31, 2007 Thursday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Ernst & Young partners indicted;
Four face charges over marketing of tax shelters

BYLINE: Edward Iwata

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 429 words


In a long-running federal crackdown on tax fraud, four current and former Ernst
& Young tax partners were indicted Wednesday on suspected tax evasion and other
charges for marketing tax shelters to wealthy clients.

The men were charged with eight counts of tax evasion, conspiracy to defraud the
Internal Revenue Service and other charges.

The indictment named Martin Nissenbaum, 51, of Brooklyn, a well-known financial
author and Ernst & Young tax partner; Robert Coplan, 54, of Plano, Texas, a
former Ernst & Young tax partner and former IRS branch chief; Richard Shapiro,
58, of Rye Brook, N.Y., an Ernst & Young tax partner; and Brian Vaughn, 39, of
Calhoun, La., a former Ernst & Young tax partner.

All four pleaded not guilty in federal court on Wednesday.

Nissenbaum is the co-author of several popular books, including Ernst & Young's
Personal Financial Planning Guide and Ernst & Young's Retirement Planning Guide.
He has been widely quoted in the media, including USA TODAY.

The men schemed to sell fraudulent tax shelters from 1998 to 2004 to rich
individuals with more than $10 million in taxable income, said U.S. Attorney
Michael Garcia in New York and acting IRS Commissioner Kevin Brown.

Within the firm, the group called itself VIPER -- for "Value Ideas Produce
Extraordinary Results."

According to the indictment, the men used clients' letters and other documents
to make it appear that the tax shelters were legitimate investments meant to
create trading profits, rather than tax losses.

The indictment also charges that Coplan, Nissenbaum, Shapiro and eight other
Ernst & Young partners used a tax shelter in 2000 to eliminate $3.7 million of
their taxes.

In a statement, Nissenbaum's attorneys, Brian Linder and Charles Clayman, said
they gave the government evidence "that Mr. Nissenbaum did not engage in any
unlawful activity. Mr. Nissenbaum expects to be acquitted at trial of these
unwarranted charges."

Attorneys for the other men could not be reached for comment.

Ernst & Young spokesman Charles Perkins told Bloomberg News that the men were
"part of a small group within the firm, disbanded years ago," that developed the
transactions. Ernst & Young changed its tax practices in a 2003 agreement with
the IRS, he said.

The federal government has targeted questionable tax shelters. In 2003, Ernst &
Young agreed to pay $15 million to settle an IRS probe into questionable tax
shelters. Last year, KPMG paid $460 million and admitted to fraudulent acts in
the marketing of some tax shelters. Sixteen former KPMG executives face a
criminal trial later this year.

                               The New York Times

             September 17, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

CITY CRACKS DOWN ON TAX CHEATS WHO CALL THEIR 2d HOUSES HOME

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 808 words


A judge, a television personality, corporate executives and government employees
are among 145 New York City residents caught evading the city income tax by
falsely claiming resort homes on Long Island as their primary residences, the
authorities said yesterday.

''Ultimately, this will involve tens of millions of dollars'' and thousands of
cases, the city Finance Commissioner, Abraham Biderman, said. ''For those who
have not been paying their taxes, the vacation is now over.''

The investigation, officially dubbed the Vacation Hideaway Project, is a joint
effort of city and state tax auditors. The biggest catch so far was one evader
with a $2.5 million annual income who owed $348,000 in city taxes, penalties and
interest for 1982 and 1983, the officials said. They said the 145 evaders agreed
to pay sums that averaged $10,000. Another 10 accused of evading taxes are
contesting the decision.

No Names Released

None of the names on the list were released by officials, who cited
confidentiality provisions of the tax laws. A few cases are being turned over to
District Attorneys and the Attorney General for possible prosecution, Mr.
Biderman said, and the name of anyone indicted would become public. He said
criminal tax-evasion cases are hard to prosecute, however, because intent must
be proved.

Nearly 2,000 additional cases, almost all involving people who say they live on
the East End of Long Island, are under review, the officials said. Mr. Biderman
said that target was chosen as ''a very fertile area.''

''We found it hard to believe that so many people were commuting to and from
places like East Hampton every day,'' he said, ''and indeed they were not.''

Different Tax Rates

Commuters who do not live in the city are taxed only on their wages and
salaries, while city residents are also taxed on unearned income. Tax rates are
also higher for residents, rising as high as 4.3 percent, while commuters pay
0.45 percent on wages and 0.65 percent on self-employment income.

For example, someone with an income of $65,000 in wages and $10,000 in interest
would pay $2,285 in city taxes as a resident but only $292.50 as a nonresident.

Residency laws are complex, but officials said that anyone who spends more than
183 nights a year in the city is legally counted as a resident.

Officials expect to uncover thousands more violators as the investigation
expands to upstate counties, Connecticut and New Jersey. Those falsely listing
out-of-state addresses as their permanent residences would be evading New York
State as well as city taxes.

''To those tax cheats out there, get to us before we get to you - if you don't,
our next press conference may be about you,'' said the State Taxation and
Finance Commissioner, Roderick G. W. Chu. He announced the audit crackdown with
Mr. Biderman and Mayor Koch at City Hall.

''Some people think it's fashionable to cheat on their taxes,'' Mr. Koch said.
It's not - it's selfish, immoral and against the law. Tax evasion is not a
victimless crime. It means fewer cops on the beat, more homeless on the street
and higher taxes for noncheaters.

''We intend to make sure that everybody pays his fair share. We're not going to
let millionaires use posh Hampton estates as hideaways for tax evasion.''

The investigation, conceived by a member of the city's auditing staff, Marvin
Goldstein, started with a computerized list of all those who worked in the city
and paid city income taxes. Home addresses were checked for zip codes from the
East End, Mr. Biderman said, and a list was compiled of people who said they had
their principal residences there but worked most of the year in the city. #2,113
Questionnaires Sent A questionnaire was then sent by the city to 2,113 people on
the list. They were asked if they had another residence in the city, how many
days a year they spent out of the city, where their children went to school, and
whether they had a rent-controlled apartment.

''A lot of them, as soon as they got a call, they said, 'You know what, I think
we made a mistake,' '' Mr. Biderman said.

Of the first 185 cases audited, 30 were ascertained to be legitimate
long-distance commuters and 10 are contesting the city's claims as to their true
residence. But 145 admitted they were city residents and agreed to pay.

The delinquent residents were assessed $1.6 million in taxes, penalties and
interest for 1982-83. They are also amending their returns to pay corrected
taxes for the years since then, the officials said.

Among those caught were accountants, bankers, doctors, lawyers, professors, and
employees of local, state and Federal government - ''pillars of their
community,'' Mr. Biderman said. The average income of the group was $133,000,
and 80 percent turned out to live in Manhattan. The rest were scattered in the
other boroughs.

Marine guilty of murder in retrial for 2006 killing

CAMP PENDLETON "" A military jury has found a Marine sergeant guilty of murder
in the retrial of a major Iraq war-crimes case involving the 2006 killing of a
retired Iraqi policeman.

The jury of three enlisted men and three military officers deliberated for more
than three hours Wednesday before reaching a verdict in the case of Sgt.

allegations that Hutchins and his squad killed 52-year-old Hashim Ibrahim Awad

to make it look like he was an insurgent.

in the handling of his case. He served more than half of his 11-year sentence.

by then-Gov. Phil Bredesen.

cents per pack. The lawsuit says Armstrong failed to report more than $318,000
in income from the scheme.

and fell about 10 feet.

his leg. Cleveland Metroparks Zoo officials say the cheetahs didn't approach the
family.

                            August 27, 2013 Tuesday

Hawaii: Former Utah Chiropractor Sentenced to Prison for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 299  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Department of Justice, The State of Hawaii has issued the following news
release:

The Justice Department and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) announced that
today Douglas R. Madsen, a former chiropractor from Ephraim, Utah, was sentenced
by the U.S. District Judge Clark Waddoups to 33 months in prison and
resitutition of over $500,000 following a conviction for attempted evasion of
payment of income tax in the District of Utah.

On Jan. 12, 2012, a jury convicted Madsen of one count of tax evasion.
According to court documents, Madsen owed approximately $1.3 million in assessed
income tax, interest and penalties for the years 1995 and 1999 to 2004.
Madsen's tax debt had grown, by the trial date, to over $1.7 million, after
accrued interest.

The evidence presented at trial established that Madsen used nominee trusts to
conceal the ownership of numerous acres of property, ultimately causing the
transfer of that property to Grand Scale Inc., a Washington state corporation of
which he was the president, vice president, secretary, treasurer and chairman of
the board.   In addition, the evidence showed that Madsen used other entities to
encumber property and cloud equity in that property through use of mortgages and
Uniform Commercial Code financing statements.   Madsen was previously held in
civil contempt by the U.S. District Court for the District of Utah for failure
to comply with court orders with respect to an IRS summons.

Assistant Attorney General for the Justice Department's Tax Division Kathryn
Keneally commended the efforts of Tax Division Trial Attorneys Jennifer R.
Laraia and Leslie A. Goemaat, who prosecuted the case, and special agents of IRS
- Criminal Investigation, who investigated the case.

For further information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/

                             June 5, 2013 Wednesday

Former Albany anesthesiologist takes stand in tax evasion trial

BYLINE: J.D. Sumner, The Albany Herald, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 336 words


June 05--ALBANY, Ga. -- A former Albany anesthesiologist already plagued by
legal issues in state court took the stand in federal court Wednesday to defend
himself against an indictment contending he evaded paying taxes and defrauded
the federal government.

Dr. Robert Sperrazza has pleaded not guilty to a five-count indictment brought
by the U.S. Attorney's Office that charges he intentionally misreported
information on tax returns going back to 2005 and that he intentionally
structured cash withdrawals from a corporate account to avoid reporting
requirements by the bank to the Internal Revenue Service.

On Wednesday, Sperrazza took the stand in his own defense, testifying that while
he did routinely cash large sums of cash -- in varying amounts between $3,000
and $9,900 -- it was only on the advice of a bank manager.

Since Sept. 11, 2001, U.S. law requires banks to note anyone who withdraws more
than $10,000 in cash. Any attempt to intentionally skirt that reporting
requirement by regularly withdrawing amounts under $10,000 runs afoul of federal
statutes.

Sperrazza also testified that he remembers being given slips by bank officials
documenting the cash withdrawals, but over the course of several residential
moves -- and possibly during the many visits of federal agents through his
property, he said -- the slips have been misplaced.

Sperrazza, once Palmyra Medical Centers' only anesthesiologist and the founder
of Southwest Georgia Anesthesiologists LLC., now lives in Panama City Beach,
Fla., where he enjoys limited medical privileges after being placed on
suspension and probation by the Florida medical board in 2011.

He pleaded guilty to misdemeanor counts related to improper possession of
prescription drugs in Dougherty Superior Court in 2012 in which he was sentenced
to 12 months probation.

If convicted of the federal charges, Sperrazza is facing federal prison time.

                            April 11, 2012 Wednesday

Duluth woman charged with 8 felonies for tax evasion

BYLINE: Mark Stodghill, Duluth News Tribune, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 426 words


April 11--With April 15 around the corner, the Minnesota Department of Revenue
issued a news release Tuesday announcing that a Duluth woman has been charged
with eight felony crimes for failing to pay income taxes and filing false or
fraudulent returns.

Pattie Lyn Fralich-Peterson, 51, is accused of filing the fraudulent returns for
tax years 2005 through 2008.

Fralich-Peterson is scheduled to make her first appearance in State District
Court in Duluth on April 24. She has no criminal record in Minnesota or
Wisconsin, according to court records. She has had eight conciliation court
cases filed against her in Minnesota. She couldn't be reached for comment.

According to the criminal complaint: A revenue tax specialist completed an
investigation of Fralich-Peterson on Aug. 16, 2010. The investigator alleged
that Fralich-Peterson substantially overstated her income tax withholdings by
her employer and underpaid her Minnesota income taxes for four years. The total
overstatement of state withholding is alleged to be $6,452, causing her to
receive larger refunds than she was entitled to.

Between Jan. 20 and Jan. 23 of this year, a special agent with the Revenue
Department criminal investigation division contacted Fralich-Peterson by
telephone. The complaint alleges that she admitted to preparing the tax returns
in question herself and filing them over the Internet. She admitted that the
discrepancies between the withholding shown on her income tax returns and the
withholding shown on her W-2s were substantial. She said she couldn't explain
why there were substantial differences between the tax returns and the W-2s, why
there were similar errors on each of her tax returns for 2004-2008, nor why all
of the errors were in her favor.

The Minnesota Department of Revenue has a 24-hour tip line for anyone who
suspects an individual or business is violating tax laws at (651) 297-5195 or
(800) 657-3500. Tipsters may remain anonymous and also can e-mail the department
at tax.fraud@state.mn.us Last year, citizen tips resulted in 89 percent of the
department's case referrals.

In its news release, the revenue department said: "While most taxpayers comply
with tax laws voluntarily, the Minnesota Department of Revenue takes progressive
enforcement action against noncompliant taxpayers ensuring tax laws are fairly
administered, collecting no more and no less than taxpayers owe."

Woman pleads guilty to tax evasion;

BYLINE: LORI PILGER

SECTION: NEBRASKA; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 286 words


The wife of a former North Platte doctor has pleaded guilty to felony tax
evasion as part of a plea agreement that involves nearly $1 million in
restitution.

Susan Baisden-Koning is set for sentencing in October, when she could get as
many as five years in prison.

"I believe it's the right thing to do," she said when asked why she was entering
the plea.

The indictment says she and her husband, Dr. Michael Koning, and her brother,
Lowell Baisden, a former California CPA who since has lost his license, were
behind a scheme to cheat the IRS of more than $1.5 million in taxes by
concealing Koning's income and by helping other North Platte residents do the
same.

Her husband and brother were indicted along with her in 2009 and are set for
trial in August. Lowell Baisden also was indicted twice more in 2010 on
allegations involving North Platte couples Dr. Michael and Deanna Trierweiler
and Drs. Walter and Deborah Weaver.

At the hearing Tuesday in U.S. District Court in Lincoln, Assistant U.S.
Attorney Steven Russell said Baisden-Koning and her husband, then an
anesthesiologist in North Platte, claimed to live in Colorado on their 2003 tax
return.

In the same return, he said, the couple also failed to report Koning's wages of
$935,959 at Anesthesia Consultants of Nebraska Inc. in North Platte.

While Baisden-Koning's plea was to a single count of tax evasion that year,
Russell said the conduct went on from 1999 to 2003, and the criminal tax loss
amounted to $989,000.

She and her husband no longer live in Nebraska.

A lawsuit they filed against Baisden in 2008 accusing him of accounting
malpractice has been stayed pending the criminal proceedings.

                          Reading Eagle, Pennsylvania

                            October 10, 2005, Monday

Exeter resident indicted for tax evasion

BYLINE: By Dan Kelly

LENGTH: 432 words



A 71-year-old Exeter Township man who allegedly swindled $ 15 million from a
Florida man has been indicted for tax evasion.

Thomas E. Mason, formerly of the first block of Scotland Drive, filed a tax
return Feb. 20, 2001, that grossly understated his actual income, according to
court records.

Internal Revenue Service agents said Mason reported his 2000 annual income at $
21,295 when he actually had deposited $ 15 million that he allegedly swindled
from Randy E. Stelk of Ponte Vedra, Fla., into his personal accounts.

Separately, Stelk is awaiting trial on charges that he stole the money that was
given to Mason.

According to records, Mason told Stelk he could guarantee huge returns on
investments in overseas charity projects but they required that large sums be
invested, records show.

After instructing Stelk to wire the $ 15 million to a Wachovia Bank account in
Mason and Stelk's names, Mason simply transferred the money to his own accounts
in the bank, according to court records.

Mason was unavailable for comment.

After repeatedly demanding that his money be returned, Stelk sued Mason in U.S.
District Court in Philadelphia on Oct. 4, 2000, asking a judge to order Mason to
refund the money.

A judge imprisoned Mason for contempt of court on May 25, 2001, for failing to
return the money despite promising to do so in several different hearings. Mason
remained in the Federal Detention Center in Philadelphia for 32 months until he
finally agreed to have a $ 7 million judgment entered against him in federal
court.

Mason also agreed to sell his home in Exeter and return thousands of dollars he
gave to his wife and children as gifts.

Investigators said the IRS and FBI launched an investigation of Mason's finances
after they learned of the lawsuit Stelk filed against Mason.

Meanwhile, Stelk was arrested in Florida and charged with stealing the $ 15
million he gave to Mason from Future First Financial, a Florida insurance
company where he was president.

Stelk is charged with aggravated white-collar crime, racketeering and three
counts of grand theft. He is in prison awaiting trial. He is being held on $ 10
million bail. He was unavailable for comment.

Bay Area Doctor Pleads Guilty To Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 545  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, Northern District of
California has issued the following news release:



  Dr. John Compagno pleaded guilty today to tax evasion announced United States
Attorney Brian J. Stretch and Internal Revenue Service, Criminal Investigation,

 According to the plea agreement, Compagno, 70, of Napa, Calif., is a medical
physician specializing in Pathology.  Compagno is the owner and operator of

Inc., West Coast Pathology Laboratory, Inc., and Histopathology Reference
Laboratory, Inc.  In his plea agreement, Compagno admitted he submitted both

 For the tax years 2005 through 2011, Compagno caused a corporate tax return

Washington: Former University of Miami Director of Finance Sentenced for Tax
Evasion

LENGTH: 338  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



 A former University of Miami Director of Finance was sentenced to 37 months in
prison, to be followed by 1 year of supervised release for committing tax
evasion and failing to report to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) $2.3 million
that she embezzled from the university.



 Wifredo A. Ferrer, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida,
and Kelly R. Jackson, Special Agent in Charge, Internal Revenue Service,
Criminal Investigation (IRS-CI), made the announcement.

 Kimberly Jean Miller, 58, previously pled guilty to four counts of tax evasion,
in violation of Title 26, United States Code, Section 7201.

 According to court documents, from 2002 until 2012, Miller was the director of
finance at the University of Miami's Rosensteil School of Marine and Atmospheric
Science (RSMAS). The defendant's job responsibilities included overseeing the
payment of RSMAS's vendor invoices. Between 2002 and 2012, Miller used her
authority at RSMAS to embezzle $2.3 million from the University of Miami by
falsifying invoices from a vendor called International Assets. Specifically,
Miller altered the International Assets invoices so that the company name would
appear as "Inter, Inc." and the checks would be mailed back to RSMAS, instead of
to International Assets directly. Miller then deposited the "Inter, Inc." checks
into a business bank account in the name Intercontinental Oceans, Inc., a
company Miller opened in 1993.

 Between 2008 and 2011, Miller prepared her own tax returns and knowingly failed
to report to the IRS the money she had unlawfully obtained through her
embezzlement scheme. Miller owes the IRS an additional $329,020 in income taxes
for her 2008 through 2011 tax returns.

 Mr. Ferrer commended the investigative efforts of IRS-CI.  The case was
prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Amanda Perwin.

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                            August 14, 2004 Saturday
                                 South Edition

Prosecutors target Plymouth man;
Reject ruling by judge who didn't follow federal guidelines in gambling case

BYLINE: Sue Reinert

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 645 words


The Patriot Ledger

Prosecutors want a harsher sentence for a Plymouth man convicted of hiding
profits from his gambling business. U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan's office has
appealed the two-year probation term given to Donald Willis for tax evasion.

The appeal comes while federal sentencing guidelines are in legal limbo after
the U.S. Supreme Court cast doubt on their validity and several judges,
including two in Boston, have rejected them.

U. S. District Judge Nancy Gertner, one of the judges who said last month she
will no longer follow the guidelines, ruled in January that Willis, 69,
qualified for leniency because of his age and poor health.

She ordered him to serve two years of probation with six months of the time in
home confinement, and repay $362,000 to the Internal Revenue Service.

Willis had faced a minimum of 21 months in prison under sentencing guidelines.

Willis pleaded guilty last year to four counts of tax evasion for failing to
report more than $955,000 in income from his sports gambling business.

He admitted leading a Waltham-based gambling operation that prosecutors said
raked in millions of dollars over 10 years. Three other men, including Willis'
brother, Paul, of Braintree, also pleaded guilty to federal charges, and seven
others have admitted offenses in state court.

All 11 were originally arraigned on state charges but federal prosecutors took
over four cases. Sullivan's spokeswoman, Samantha Martin, declined to comment on
the reason.

Only one of the convicted men has been sentenced to prison time. A federal judge
ordered George Chute of Dedham to serve 15 months in prison, pay a $400 fine,
return $53,000 to the government and serve one year of probation.

Chute admitted running the day to day operations of the gambling ring while
Willis directed the business, prosecutors said.

Willis' lawyer, Peter T. Elikann, said Willis' sentence met the federal
guidelines.

"We had requested a departure, which was granted due to severe health issues in
this man in his 70s," Elikann said.

Martin also declined comment on the Willis case.

Elikann submitted statements from Willis' doctors that his numerous ailments,
including high blood pressure, circulatory disease, lymphoma and arthritis,
could threaten his life without regular medical attention that he could not get
in prison.

In response, prosecutors called Willis' medical problems "moderate" and said the
prison system could take care of them. Government investigators also interviewed
Willis' doctors and reported that some of the physicians got their picture of
prison life from old movies and television.

Both sides' contentions made sense, Gertner wrote in her decision.

"The issue is one of degree," she said. Willis suffered from "an inordinate
number of potentially serious conditions" that would "invariably get worse,"
given his age, Gertner wrote.

He was not likely to reoffend, while a prison term "could be a death sentence,"
Gertner said. She deducted seven points from his offense level under the
guidelines in order to give him probation instead of prison.

Gertner sentenced Willis in January but did not issue a written decision until
June. Prosecutors appealed last month. Meanwhile, Willis has not started his
sentence, Elikann said. The First Circuit Court of Appeals is considering the
appeal in the midst of "a great deal of turmoil and uncertainty as to sentences
in federal court" because of the recent decisions, Elikann said.

In June, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that juries, not judges, must decide facts
that could increase felons' sentences. Since then, a number of judges, including
Gertner and U.S. District Court Chief Judge William Young, have called the
guidelines unconstitutional. The court is expected to hear two cases in October
that could bring a definitive decision on the guidelines, Elikann said. Sue
Reinert may be reached at sreinert@ledger.com.

BASEBALL;
Strawberry Pleads Guilty To Tax Charge

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.,   Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section B;  Page 7;  Column 2;  Sports Desk

LENGTH: 533 words

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 9


Darryl Strawberry, who has been labeled in turn as a phenomenal baseball
prospect, an outstanding major league hitter, a violent husband and a persistent
drug abuser, became a convicted felon yesterday.

Standing meekly before a Federal judge in a courtroom here only three days after
being suspended from baseball and dropped by the San Francisco Giants for
renewed use of cocaine, the 32-year-old outfielder pleaded guilty to a single
count of tax evasion.

Strawberry, who was indicted in December on three counts of evasion and
conspiracy, entered the plea after negotiating an agreement designed to limit
his sentence to a three-month prison term followed by three months of home
confinement.

Had he been convicted on all three original counts he could have received as
much as 15 years in prison.

For Strawberry, who wore a conservative pinstriped suit, the only light moment
in an otherwise somber proceedings came when he entered the courtroom and was
asked where he had gotten his garish yellow tie.

"State prison," he said.

Strawberry, who otherwise declined requests for interviews before and after his
45-minute court appearance and a two-hour meeting with probation officers,
acknowledged that he had cheated the Government out of more than $100,000 by
knowingly failing to report more than $350,000 in income from autograph shows
and other promotional appearances from 1986 to 1990.

The agreement requires him to file corrected returns for all five years by Aug.
1 but does not explicitly require him to testify against his co-defendant, his
agent, Eric Goldschmidt, who is charged with participating in the tax fraud.

Accompanied by his pregnant wife, Charisse, and flanked by two lawyers,
Strawberry stood while Judge Barrington D. Parker questioned him closely about
his decision to waive his right to a trial and to plead guilty.

Yes, Strawberry, said, he had read and understood the five-page plea agreement.
Yes, he was satisfied with his lawyers and their advice. No, he had not been
promised anything not contained in the agreement, and yes, he knew the
implications of a guilty plea, that it could cost him his right to vote, his
right to hold elective office and his right to possess firearms.

Then, after assistant United States Attorney Carol L. Sipperly had outlined the
terms of the agreement and Parker had satisfied himself that the defendant had
indeed committed the crime he was charged with and knew what he was doing in
admitting it, Strawberry said, "I am guilty."

Although Parker made clear he was not bound by the agreement, he also indicated
that the specified penalties seemed to be within the binding Federal sentencing
guidelines. Barring an unexpectedly adverse probation report or other
development, he is expected to follow the agreement when he imposes sentence on
March 15.

If so, Strawberry will serve three months in prison, but it is unclear when the
sentence will begin. The agreement itself was silent on the issue, and
prosecutors said the ultimate decision would be up to the judge, but according
to recent reports on the plea negotiations, Strawberry had been assured he could
begin his term after the baseball season.

yesterday, where he pleaded guilty to one count of tax evasion. He will be
sentenced March 15. (Associated Press)

                               The New York Times

                 June 3, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

PROSECUTOR SAYS RETRYING PISANI ON 10 OPEN CHARGES IS UNLIKELY

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 42, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 388 words


United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his office was
unlikely to retry State Senator Joseph R. Pisani on 10 criminal counts that were
left unresolved late Friday by a jury that convicted the legislator on charges
of tax evasion and mail fraud.

''These convictions are more than enough to give the judge ability to impose an
adequate sentence,'' said Mr. Giuliani, the chief Federal prosecutor for the
Southern District of New York,

Mr. Pisani faces expulsion from his legislative seat, possible disbarment and a
lengthy prison sentence because of his conviction.

The verdict was delivered at the end of a five-week trial in Federal District
Court in Manhattan in which the prosecutors had argued that Mr. Pisani, a
Republican of New Rochelle, had embezzled money from the state, his campaign
funds and his former law firm.

The jury found the 54-year-old Mr. Pisani not guilty of 11 counts of the 39-
count indictment and guilty on 18 counts.

Mr. Pisani was convicted on nine counts of mail fraud involving fraudulent
filing of campaign funds, one count of mail fraud, involving the embezzlement of
thousands of dollars from his law firm and clients, and eight counts of tax
evasion and filing false returns.

Technically, Mr. Pisani could be sentenced to as much as 82 years in prison, a a
term that would be unusual for the charges.

Mr. Pisani's attorney, Robert Kasanof, said he would appeal the convictions.

Under state law, Mr. Pisani faces automatic expulsion from his Senate seat after
a felony conviction. He also faces the possibility of disbarment if the Federal
felony convictions are found to be equivalent to state charges. Mr. Pisani has
announced he would not seek re- election.

The jury reached its verdict after deliberating 34 hours over four days. Among
the counts on which the jury failed to find a verdict were charges Mr. Pisani
had used $20,000 in state funds to buy a summer house he shared with his friend
and co-defendant, Kathryn Godfrey.

Mrs. Godfrey, 54, of Manhattan, was was acquitted of one of three counts of
perjury. The prosecution said she had lied to the grand jury during its
investigation of the fraud and tax charges. The jury was deadlocked on the other
two counts against her.

The judge set Mr. Pisani's sentencing for June 14.

Hawaii: Alaska Plastic Surgeon Indicted on Tax Evasion Charges for Concealing
Bank Accounts in Panama and Costa Rica

LENGTH: 322  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Department of Justice, The State of Hawaii has issued the following news
release:

The Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) announced today that a
federal grand jury in Anchorage, Alaska, returned a superseding indictment
yesterday charging Michael D. Brandner, an Anchorage physician specializing in
plastic surgery, on three counts of tax evasion.  Brandner has also been charged
with seven counts of wire fraud in an indictment returned in September 2013.

According to the superseding indictment, Brandner engaged in various activities
to evade his taxes for 2008, 2009 and 2010, including making false and
misleading statement to IRS special agents and filing false tax returns for each
of the three years.  In the three false returns, Brandner failed to report the
existence of financial accounts in Panama and Costa Rica over which he had
signature authority, and also failed to report foreign interest income of more
than $9,000 for 2008, more than $150,000 for 2009, and more than $150,000 for
2010.  The indictment also alleges that Brandner attempted to evade more than
$600,000 in federal income taxes over the three years.

According to court documents, Brandner engaged in a scheme to hide and conceal
millions of dollars of assets from the Alaska courts and from his wife of 28
years who was divorcing him.  Shortly after the divorce was filed, Brandner left
Alaska and drove to Central America after converting assets into five cashier's
checks worth over $3,000,000.

An indictment is merely an allegation and the defendant is presumed innocent
unless and until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of law.  If
convicted, Brandner faces a statutory maximum sentence of five years in prison
for each of the three tax evasion charges and a statutory maximum sentence of 20
years in prison for each of the seven wire fraud charges.

For further information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/

HSBC India unit client faces US tax evasion charge

A San Jose, California, man faces charges of tax evasion after failing to report
$1.3 million in interest income from HSBC Holdings' India unit, US prosecutors

                               November 15, 2007

James Ortenzio Pleads Guilty to Tax Evasion

BYLINE: Azi Paybarah

LENGTH: 644 words


The former Manhattan Republican Chairman James Ortenzio just pleaded guilty to
tax evasion, according to the Manhattan District Attorney.

From a press release that just went out:

Mr. Morgenthau said that ORTENZIO's crimes occurred while he was the County
Chairman of the New York County Republican Committee. From 1999 to 2003,
ORTENZIO had served as the Chairman of the Hudson River Park Trust, a public
benefit corporation created to develop and maintain the Hudson River Park, which
stretches for about five miles along the Manhattan shoreline from Battery Place
to 59th Street.          Specifically, ORTENZIO was mandated by his position as
the Chairman of the County Republican Committee to file an Annual Statement of
Financial Disclosure with the New York State Ethics Commission.  In September of
2004, he was paid $100,000 by Fisher Brothers Management Co., located at 299
Park Avenue, New York, New York, for certain consulting services.

On June 13, 2005, ORTENZIO filed his calendar year 2004 Disclosure form, but
intentionally omitted his payment from Fisher Brothers Management in an effort
to prevent disclosing that he received the money.           Additionally, in
June of 2004, ORTENZIO was retained to arbitrate a business dispute involving
two companies that provide helicopter flight services in Manhattan, Air Pegasus
of New York, Inc. and Sightseeing Tours of America, Inc.  Both companies are
located on land belonging to the Hudson River Park Trust.  ORTENZIO was paid
approximately $80,000 in 2005 for his arbitration services.  Subsequently,
ORTENZIO filed false and fraudulent 2005 personal New York state tax returns by
intentionally failing to disclose the income received from his mediation
services.          Mr. Morgenthau said that the investigation leading to today's
guilty plea commenced in November of 2005.  Since then, the investigation has
resulted in several convictions.  On May 2, 2007, Dennis Pappas, former
Vice-President of Cipriani USA, pleaded guilty to Attempted Insurance Fraud in
the Second Degree for defrauding insurance companies out of more than
$1,000,000.  Pappas was sentenced on July 2, 2007 to 1 ¼É to 4 ¼É years in state
prison and the payment of $1,017,000 in restitution.          On July 31, 2007,
Arrigo Cipriani, the patriarch of the Cipriani family business, Giuseppe
Cipriani, the President and CEO of Cipriani USA, Inc., and three Cipriani
corporations pleaded guilty to tax evasion.  They were sentenced on October 10,
2007 to repayment of $10 million in back taxes.  An independent monitor was also
installed to ensure accurate tax treatment of all of the family's businesses.
ORTENZIO, who owns several meat processing companies, was a significant
distributor of meat and other food products to Cipriani restaurants.        Mr.
Morgenthau thanked the New York City Department of Finance and its Commissioner
Martha E. Stark, as well as its Assistant Commissioner for Tax Enforcement
Carlton Butler; the Director of Tax Enforcement, Maureen Kokeas; Manager,
Criminal Audit Tax Enforcement Division Robert Stahl; and Special Tax Auditor
Franklin Hayes.  The District Attorney also thanked the Acting New York State
Department of Taxation and Finance and its Commissioner, Barbara Billett; Deputy
Commissioner for Tax Enforcement William Comiskey, and Peter Farrell, Assistant
Deputy Commissioner for Tax Enforcement.        Assistant District Attorney Eric
Sei, Deputy Chief of the District Attorney's Rackets Bureau, and Assistant
District Attorney Brian J. Fields are in charge of the prosecution.  Financial
Consultant John a also assisted in the case, as did Senior Investigators James
Mauritzen, Julian Yannotti and Supervising Investigator Stephen McCallion of the
Investigation Bureau, which is headed by Chief Investigator Joseph Pennisi and
Deputy Chief Terry Mulderrig.

                               The New York Times

                           February 20, 2003 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Ex-Tyco Executive Indicted in New Hampshire in U.S. Tax Case

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

SECTION: Section C; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 412 words


The former chief financial officer of Tyco International, Mark H. Swartz, was
indicted yesterday by a federal grand jury in New Hampshire on a charge of tax
evasion, adding to state charges against him that include looting the company of
hundreds of millions of dollars.

The indictment is the first brought by the federal government against any of the
former Tyco executives, who until yesterday had only been charged in New York
State courts.

The United States attorney for New Hampshire, Thomas Colantuono, said Mr.
Swartz, 42, had been charged with one count of tax evasion, accused of filing a
tax return for 1999 that failed to report a $12.5 million bonus he received from
Tyco. The indictment said he avoided almost $5 million in federal taxes. If
convicted, Mr. Swartz could face up to five years in prison and a fine up to
$250,000.

He is scheduled to appear in court today for a bail hearing and a trial date.

His lawyer, Charles A. Stillman of Stillman & Friedman in Manhattan, said
yesterday that Mr. Swartz would deny the accusations.

"He will plead not guilty because he did not cheat on his tax return," Mr.
Stillman said. "He will plead not guilty because he does not owe any tax to the
government. He will be vindicated."

According to the indictment, Mr. Swartz received a bonus when Tyco forgave $12.5
million in loans that he owed the company. The loans were charged to Tyco's
so-called Key Employee Loan Program, which the company established to help its
executives and employees pay taxes arising from the vesting of stock.

Mr. Swartz resigned from Tyco last year. Yesterday's indictment comes on top of
charges filed last year in New York.

The Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, has accused Mr. Swartz
and the company's former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski, of misusing and
secretly forgiving loans in the employee loan program without authorization from
the board. The two face grand larceny charges in New York State. Mr. Kozlowski,
who resigned last June, has also been indicted on charges of evading New York
sales taxes.

After an internal investigation, Tyco recently decided to ask Mr. Swartz to
return the forgiven loan money.

"We reversed the forgiveness of the loan," a spokesman confirmed yesterday. It
is unclear whether reinstatement of the loan will play a role in the case.

The United States attorney's office in Concord, N.H., did not return calls
seeking comment about Tyco's decision to reinstate the loan.

                               The New York Times

              December 16, 1980, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

L.I. MAN GIVEN 20 YEARS FOR $6.8 MILLION TAX EVASION

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

SECTION: Section B; Page 9, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 424 words


A 20-year sentence was imposed yesterday on an insurance consultant who was
convicted in a $6.8 million tax case, which the Government described as
''perhaps the largest personal tax-evasion prosecution in American history.''

Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy, who sentenced Louis C. Ostrer in Federal District
Court in Manhattan, said the prison term ''may seem harsh'' but that it was
''more than merited.'' He also imposed a maximum $70,000 fine on the 58-year-old
defendant, a convicted stock swindler linked to organized-crime figures.

Evidence in a six-week trial showed that Mr. Ostrer had paid virtually no taxes
from 1965 through 1975, although he earned millions of dollars from insurance
fees and commissions, according to Philip Le B. Douglas and Richard F. Ziegler,
the prosecutors.

Had Filed Tax Returns

They said Mr. Ostrer had filed tax returns reporting his large income, but
failed to pay the taxes and used false names and shell corporations to conceal
his assets and prevent the Government from collecting.

He was found guilty of embezzling $1.2 million from welfare and pension funds of
Teamsters Local 918 in Brooklyn as well as evading $6.8 million in taxes,
interest and penalties.

The jury also convicted his wife, Rita, and an associate, Seymour Greenfield, of
participating in the tax evasion conspiracy. Judge Duffy has sentenced Mrs.
Ostrer to one year and Mr. Greenfield to three years.

Mr. Ostrer, who conducted his own defense, lives in Kings Point, L.I. Judge
Duffy set his bail at $3.4 million and sent him to jail while he appeals the
conviction. He recently served 18 months for a previous stock fraud.

'A Life of Self-Indulgence'

A sentencing memorandum by Mr. Douglas assailed ''Ostrer's practice of swindling
creditors of huge sums while living a life of luxurious self-indulgence.'' It
added that ''this white-collar defendant has for years supervised a veritable
industry of fraud and deceit to accomplish repeated tax evasions, embezzlements
and other swindles.''

The prosecutor said Mr. Ostrer had ''lined his own pockets'' by exploiting his
relationship with ''unsophisticated labor leaders who controlled huge financial
assets.''

Mr. Douglas also noted a 1976 report by a United States Senate committee saying
that Mr. Ostrer had designed insurance programs that gave him exorbitant fees
and provided ''questionable methods for mobsters to obtain huge amounts of
funds.''

                           February 14, 2017 Tuesday

Former Bergen County, New Jersey, Coin Dealer Admits Income Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 379  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, District of New Jersey has
issued the following news release:



  A former resident of Old Tappan, New Jersey, today admitted evading personal
income taxes on more than $400,000 in income in 2013, U.S. Attorney Paul J.
Fishman announced.





 William Dominick, 68, of Collier County, Florida, pleaded guilty before U.S.
District Judge Anne E. Thompson in Trenton federal court to an information
charging him with one count of tax evasion and one count of identity theft.



 According to documents filed in this case and statements made in court:



 Dominick owned and operated Westwood Rare Coin out of his home in Old Tappan.
He was required to include income earned by Westwood Rare Coin on his individual
IRS 1040 form. During calendar year 2013, Dominick failed to report $400,000 in
income earned by Westwood Rare Coin. He did this by using other people's
identities to open credit cards to purchase bulk quantities coins from the U.S.
Mint in order to corner the market. Dominick then sold those coins through his
business, retained the proceeds for his personal use, and failed to include the
proceeds on the tax return that he signed and filed with the IRS.



 The count of identity theft to which Dominick pleaded guilty carries a maximum
potential penalty of 15 years in prison; the count of tax evasion carries a
maximum potential penalty of five years in prison; both counts also carry a fine
of up to $250,000. Sentencing is scheduled for May 23, 2017.



 Under terms of his plea agreement, Dominick will file amended returns and make
full restitution for years 2010 through 2014.



 U.S. Attorney Fishman credited special agents of the FBI, under the direction
of special agent in charge Timothy Gallagher; special agents of IRS-Criminal
Investigation, under the direction of Special Agent in Charge Jonathan D.
Larsen; and inspectors of the U.S. Postal Inspection Service, under the
direction of Postal Inspector in Charge James V. Buthorn, with the investigation
leading to today's guilty plea.



 The government is represented by Assistant U.S. Attorney Shana Chen of the
Economic Crimes Unit in Newark.

                             April 7, 2016 Thursday

Gilcrest liquor store owner, co-conspirator sentenced for concealing $3.2
million in tax evasion

BYLINE: Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 528 words


April 07--DENVER -- A Gilcrest liquor store owner and his Johnstown
co-conspirator have been sentenced in U.S. District Court for their roles in a
$3.2 million tax evasion scheme.

United States Attorney for the District of Colorado John Walsh and IRS Criminal
Investigation Special Agent in Charge Stephen Boyd announced the sentencing
Thursday in a news release.

Renee Molinar, 48, of Johnstown was sentenced Wednesday by U.S. District Court
Judge Christine Arguello to three years of probation, 10 months of home
detention, 100 hours of useful public service, and she is required to undergo
mental health treatment. Molinar pleaded guilty on May 7, 2014, to one count of
conspiracy to defraud the United States.

Molinar was a co-conspirator in the scheme along with Alan Timothy Hershey, 50,
of Gilcrest, who was sentenced on March 22 to serve 71 months in federal prison,
followed by three years of supervised release. He was ordered to pay a fine of
$100,000 and $1.7 millioin in restitution to the IRS and the Colorado Department
of Revenue. Hershey and Molinar were charged on July 3, 2014. Hershey pleaded
guilty on May 13, 2015, to one count of conspiracy to defraud the United States
and two counts of tax evasion. As a condition of his plea agreement, Hershey
paid the restitution in full prior to his sentencing.

In March 2001, Hershey transferred ownership of Johnstown Liquor, 21 S. Parish
Ave., in Johnstown, to Molinar, but concealed from the IRS that he retained true
ownership of the store. For the next decade, Hershey and Molinar skimmed a
portion of Johnstown Liquor's cash sales and concealed the receipts using a
second record keeping system.

Hershey filed no federal income tax returns for the entire period and made no
payments of income taxes to the IRS. To conceal the gross receipts they were
skimming from the store, Hershey used nominees to purchase two other liquor
stores -- Liquor Plus in Greeley and Gilcrest Liquor in Gilcrest -- and a number
of houses with the cash he had skimmed from Johnstown Liquor's gross receipts.
Hershey controlled the operations of the stores, and he and Molinar collected
the rents from the houses. Hershey also ran Corona's and More, a liquor store in
Bennett. He failed to pay federal taxes on any of the four stores' $3.2 million
in taxable income.

When criminal investigators began questioning Johnstown Liquor employees,
Hershey told Molinar to remove all documents that would reveal the business'
true receipts from the store. They also transferred ownership of the business to
Johnstown Liquor, Inc., even though Hershey continued to control the operation
of the business as its true owner.

"Hershey engaged in an intricate multi-year scheme to evade paying over a
million dollars in income tax owed under the law," Walsh said in the release.
"Hershey deserves the stiff sentence he received because he not only defrauded
the United States, he defrauded every other honest American taxpayer who works
hard and pays taxes to support our country."

BRIEF: Fayetteville Goodyear worker enters guilty plea to tax evasion

BYLINE: Alan Wooten, The Fayetteville Observer, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 226 words


July 03--RALEIGH -- A plea for charges of evading state income tax while working
at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has been entered by a Fayetteville man.

Matthew L. Vaughan, 44, of 3647 Florida Drive Ext., pleaded guilty to three
counts of attempting to evade and defeat tax on Wednesday in Wake County
District Court.

Vaughan received a six-month minimum, 17-month maximum jail sentence from
District Court Judge Eric C. Chasse. The sentence was suspended and Vaughan
placed on supervised probation for 36 months.

Vaughan will be under electronic home monitoring the first 30 days, will have to
pay restitution of $13,767.39, a fine of $7,500 and complete 100 hours of
community service.

According to information in court, Vaughan knowingly and willfully maintained
with his employer, Goodyear, fraudulent Forms NC-4 Employee's Withholding
Allowance Certificate, during the tax years 2011 through 2013, claiming to be
exempt from North Carolina individual income tax withholding. Goodyear in turn
did not withhold state individual income tax from his wages.

The investigation was conducted by the state Department of Revenue's Criminal
Investigations Section in Raleigh.

                           November 13, 2014 Thursday

Audiologist Pleads Guilty To Tax Fraud

LENGTH: 371  words

DATELINE: Sacramento


United States Attorney's Office for the northern District of California has
issued the following press release:

Michael Ryan Trythall pleaded guilty to tax evasion today, announced United
States Attorney Melinda Haag and Internal Revenue Service, Criminal
Investigation, Acting Special Agent in Charge Thomas McMahon.

In pleading guilty, Trythall, 37, of Los Angeles, a professional audiologist,
admitted to embezzling more than $750,000 between 2009 and 2012 from his
employer at the time, a San Francisco audiology practice. During that period,
Trythall performed bookkeeping services for his employer, and had access to the
business's financial records. He was authorized to print business checks for
others to sign, but not to sign or issue checks on his own. Nevertheless,
Trythall issued business checks payable to himself, forged the signature of an
authorized signer onto the checks, and then deposited them into his personal
bank accounts. Trythall also caused credit card payments made by clients to the
business to be misdirected to an account he controlled. Trythall used the money
he embezzled to pay for vacations and shopping at luxury retailers.

Trythall concealed his embezzlement by omitting payments to himself from the
business's books, making false entries into the business's books, and failing to
disclose his embezzlement, even when confronted by others. Trythall did not pay
income taxes on any of the money he embezzled for calendar years 2009 through
2011, resulting in tax due and owing of over $230,000.

Trythall was charged by information on Sept. 25, 2014, with three counts of tax
evasion, and pleaded guilty to one county. Trythall's sentencing hearing is
scheduled for March 11, 2015, at 2:30 p.m., before the Honorable Edward M. Chen,
United States District Court Judge, in San Francisco. The maximum statutory
penalty for each count of tax evasion, in violation of 26 U.S.C. § 7201, is five
years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael G. Pitman is prosecuting the case. The
prosecution is the result of an investigation by the IRS, Criminal
Investigation.
