Washington: Former Finance Director of Pit River Tribe Indicted for Tax Evasion,
Failure to File a Tax Return, and Theft from the Pit River Tribe

LENGTH: 331 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: Federal Bureau of Investigation has issued the following news
release:



 Kenley Black, 41, formerly of Burney, California, was arrested today at his
home in Ft. Defiance, Arizona on charges of tax evasion, failure to file income
taxes, and embezzlement and theft from a tribal organization, United States
Attorney Benjamin B. Wagner announced.





 A federal grand jury returned a 25-count indictment on Thursday, March 24,
2016, against Kenley, who served as the the Finance Director for the Pit River
Tribe from 2009 to 2013. Black is not a member of the Pit River Tribe.



 According to court documents, while employed as Finance Director, Black earned
over $810,000 yet did not file income taxes and evaded paying over $225,000 in
taxes. He is charged with five counts of tax evasion and five counts of failure
to file income taxes. Additionally, he is charged with 15 counts of embezzlement
and theft from a tribal organization for embezzling $81,578 from the Pit River
Tribe in 2012 and 2013.



 This case is the product of an investigation by the Federal Bureau of
Investigation and Internal Revenue Service - Criminal Investigation. Assistant
United States Attorney Justin Lee is prosecuting the case.



 If convicted, Black faces a maximum statutory penalty of five years in prison
and a $100,000 fine for each count of tax evasion. Additionally, Black faces up
to one year in prison for each count of failure to file a tax return and up to
five years in prison for each count of theft from a tribal organization. Any
sentence, however, would be determined at the discretion of the court after
consideration of any applicable statutory factors and the Federal Sentencing
Guidelines, which take into account a number of variables. The charges are only
allegations; the defendant is presumed innocent until and unless proven guilty
beyond a reasonable doubt.

                      Orange County Register (California)

                             June 4, 2014 Wednesday

Riverside accountant sentenced for tax evasion

BYLINE: BY DEBRA GRUSZECKI, STAFF WRITER

SECTION: 1; Pg. A

LENGTH: 240 words



HIGHLIGHT: Embezzled funds were spent but not reported to the IRS.


Pablo Javier Moran, Jr., 45, of Riverside, was sentenced to 21 months in federal
prison Tuesday by U.S. District Court Judge Beverly Reid O'Connell for tax
evasion related to an embezzlement scheme.

In December 2013, Moran pleaded guilty to one count of tax evasion for the year
2008.

At sentencing, Moran was given two years of supervised release and ordered to
pay $194,791 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service.

According to charging information filed by the U.S. Attorney's office in Los
Angeles on the case, Moran evaded paying taxes owed to the federal government
from the period covering Jan. 1, 2008 through April 15, 2009.

The federal prosecutor's office also said that Moran, while working as a partner
in the accounting firm Moran & Sons, misused a client's credit card and used
checks drawn on the same client's checking account to pay for his own personal
expenses. Those embezzled funds were not reported on Moran's personal income tax
return, the charging information said.

Court records say Moran failed to report or correctly identify the source of
income, more than $10,000 a year, from his embezzlement of funds from Moran &
Sons and Claredi Corp. Moran admitted the loss of funds ranged from $175,000 to
$190,000.

Shea Jones, acting special agent in charge, said the government wasn't the only
victim in this case. "Moran used his position of trust to engage in thievery by
embezzling funds from his client," Jones said.

CALL 'EM CHEAPRIANIS. DAD & SON WHO OWN POSH EATERIES GUILTY IN TAX SCAM

BYLINE: BY BARBARA ROSS and DAVE GOLDINER DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITERS With Carl
Stampfl

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 406 words


THEY RUN THE FAMED Cipriani restaurants favored by celebrities like Diddy and 50
Cent.

But the father-and-son owners of the Rainbow Room and other plush Manhattan
eateries yesterday admitted there was a sleazy side to their glitzy empire -
millions in tax fraud.

Family patriarch Arrigo (Harry) Cipriani, 75, and son Giuseppe, 42, the boss of
their U.S. empire, agreed to pay $10 million in back taxes as they pleaded
guilty to a scheme involving their offshore parent company.

"The Ciprianis' tax evasion scheme involved illegal deductions," said Manhattan
District Attorney Robert Morgenthau.

The Cipriani restaurants, which include Cipriani Dolci in Grand Central
Terminal, Downtown Cipriani and Cipriani Wall Street, employ nearly 1,000
people.

The Ciprianis rub elbows with the rich and famous, but Morgenthau called their
ploy a shameless tactic to scalp hardworking average taxpayers.

Both Ciprianis pleaded guilty, along with three of their companies, to tax
evasion and will be placed on probation. A government auditor will oversee their
books for five years.

Defense lawyer Stanley Arkin pooh-poohed the scam and insisted the Ciprianis
only took the $40 million in deductions after their tax lawyer gave them the
green light.

He said the father and son, who are Italian citizens, would fight any effort to
strip them of their liquor licenses or deport them from the U.S. when they are
formally sentenced next month.

"If you close every store in this city that had a tax issue, we'd be a ghost
town," Arkin said.

The tax-fraud probe started when prosecutors received a detailed, anonymous
letter saying that Cipriani USA claimed it made $30 million in royalty payments
to its parent company in Europe, even though it never really paid a dime.

The scheme allowed the Ciprianis, who were once accused of paying thousands to
the mob to end a labor dispute, to avoid $4.5 million in taxes.

The same probe earlier netted Dennis Pappas, a reputed mob money adviser who was
vice president of Cipriani USA. He was sentenced last month to 1 1/2 to 4 1/2
years in prison for pocketing more than $1 million in bogus disability claims.

The Ciprianis were not charged in that case.

Diners at the popular restaurants shrugged off the tax scam, saying it wouldn't
keep them away from the fresh pasta and gelato.

"They're going to pay the fine, right?" said diner John Calandra, 40, as he left
Cipriani Dolci. "If they do, they're even."

                            The Independent (London)

                            January 28, 2011 Friday
                                 First Edition

HSBC staff accused of aiding tax avoiders

BYLINE: Stephen Foley in New York

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 367 words


HSBC,THE British-based banking giant, has become ensnared in a US tax evasion
investigation, after employees were accused of helping one of its American
clients hide money offshore.

Federal authorities are considering serving a broad legal summons on HSBC, to
examine if its bankers sold tax evasion services to dozens or hundreds of its
clients, it has emerged.

The moves come nearly two years after the Zurich-based bank UBS agreed to pay
$780m to the US government and revealed the details of 4,000 US clients' Swiss
bank accounts after admitting it helped those who wanted to evade US taxes. The
deal, under which UBS avoided criminal charges, blew a hole in Switzerland's
traditional banking secrecy, and encouraged 18,000 US residents to reveal their
offshore accounts in an amnesty offered by the Internal Revenue Service.

This week, the IRS said it will soon offer a second amnesty, under which it will
not prosecute Americans who reveal their offshore accounts, as long as they pay
back taxes owed. HSBC said last night that it complies with the law in all the
jurisdictions in which it operates, but declined to comment on any potential
investigation, or on whether it has disciplined bankers involved in the case
filed this week. The bank pointed out that it was not a party to the case, and
was not even named in the indictment.

"HSBC does not condone tax evasion and fully supports the US efforts to promote
appropriate payment of taxes by US taxpayers," a spokesman said. "As per policy,
we investigate all allegations of employee misconduct vigorously and take
appropriate action if breaches to HSBC policies are found."

On Wednesday, prosecutors in New Jersey filed charges against Vaibhav Dahake
which said that the businessman conspired with bankers of "one of the largest
international banks in the world" to hide accounts in India. The indictment
refers to five unnamed bankers who conspired with Mr Dahake: two in New York,
one in Fremont, California, and two in Thane, India. It is alleged that HSBC
suggested Mr Dahake open accounts in India to add to those he already held in
the British Virgin Islands, and that it helped him shuffle money out of the
sight of the US tax authorities.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            September 1, 2006 Friday
                                 THIRD EDITION

Lawyer is sentenced to 46 months, restitution

BYLINE: By William C. Lhotka ST. LOUIS POST-DISPATCH

SECTION: METRO; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 865 words


THE DEAL

Polk, above, will serve time for tax evasion and taking money from MSD. Some 21
other counts were dropped.

THE LETTER

Former U.S. Attorney General John Ashcroft provided a letter saying Polk was a
friend and a valuable aide.

---

If a handwritten letter to a judge from John D. Ashcroft made much difference in
the prison term imposed Thursday on his friend Charles E. Polk Jr., it wasn't
apparent.

Having agreed to accept a plea bargain with a cap of 47 months, U.S. District
Judge Stephen N. Limbaugh ordered the prominent former lawyer to serve 46 months
for tax evasion and taking money from the Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District.

Ashcroft, former U.S. attorney general and governor of Missouri, was not present
at the hearing downtown, and did not make any specific request in his Aug. 28
letter to Limbaugh. It said Polk "was a friend of mine (and still is) who I
found very helpful to me and the community of Missouri during my public service
there. He assisted me in my confirmation as U.S. Attorney General."

He also wrote that Polk "has a wonderful wife and family. I believe he could
still contribute greatly after his punishment. He is a good person."

The politically-connected Polk had assisted Ashcroft in his Senate confirmation
as attorney general, and was master of ceremonies when Ashcroft was sworn in.

But prosecutors for the Justice Department that Ashcroft once headed painted a
different picture. First Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Reap wondered aloud
whether Ashcroft or a prominent minister, whom Reap did not name, would have
written on Polk's behalf if they knew the full evidence.

In the plea agreement made in April, Polk, 45, of St. Charles, admitted that he
bilked MSD out of $45,190 when he was its counsel, and that he failed to pay
taxes on about $540,000 of income in 2002. He pleaded guilty to one charge each
of tax evasion and interstate transportation of funds obtained by fraud.

Limbaugh suggested in court that a range of punishment up to 78 months would be
more appropriate, but he stayed with terms worked out between Reap and defense
lawyer Scott Rosenblum.

In return for Polk's pleas on two counts, prosecutors dropped 21 others, which
Limbaugh dismissed Thursday. Those alleged several other fraud schemes and
claims of failing to pay taxes on an additional $1.4 million in income.

According to the indictment and testimony in a civil case in St. Louis County
Circuit Court, Polk had used connections to Ashcroft and other prominent
Republicans to bilk a Quincy businessman James Helenthal out of thousands of
dollars in a failed plan to win federal compensation for victims of the 1995
Oklahoma City bombing.

In court, Reap blamed Polk for a litany of wrongdoings and betrayals against
clients he represented, law firms for which he worked, and the public agency he
represented.

Reap said Polk not only took from law firms and wealthy clients but that he
betrayed the ordinary, such as the Faith United Church of the Living God, on
Lillian Avenue in St. Louis.

Polk helped the church get a $95,000 loan from a bank on which Polk was a board
member, and then demanded a $10,200 kickback from its minister, the prosecutor
said. The church ended up in bankruptcy and a trustee filed a public pleading
naming Polk.

Only then did Polk return the money, on a check written on an account in
Martha's Vineyard, an ocean resort community in Massachusetts, Reap explained.
Polk had opened that account, the IRS found and Reap told Limbaugh, with MSD
money Polk stole.

Rosenblum told Limbaugh that Polk was a loyal friend, loving husband, devoted
father and alcoholic in need of help.

Polk, who surrendered his law license, said, "I'm not going to be asking for my
law license back. ... I apologize to the court and the bar and a lot of folks I
have hurt." He said he took full responsibility.

Limbaugh said, "The totality of the circumstances in this case is enormous." He
added, "If clients and the public cannot depend on lawyers, we are in deep
trouble."

The judge ordered restitution of $178,623 to MSD and $382,000 to Helenthal.
Limbaugh also sentenced Polk to three years of supervision after prison, and
specified monthly restitution payments then of $500 or 10 percent of his
earnings.

Reap said it was "an appropriate sentence, and he fully deserves every bit of
it."

Polk declined comment after the hearing.

Rosenblum said Polk's wife, Cheryl, and three children have forgiven him. Cheryl
Polk did not attend the hearing, Rosenblum said, on his advice.

Cheryl Polk is chief operating officer of the United Way of Greater St. Louis,
and remains a defendant in a $3.6 million judgment Helenthal got against the
couple in St. Louis County. She has denied any involvement in her husband's
dealings.

Helenthal said he was pleased with the restitution order.

MSD spokesman Lance LeComb described the agency Thursday as "a much different
place" now, with new safeguards. He said Polk's activities cost the district
$317,000, with most of it recovered.

Limbaugh acceded to two defense requests: he will recommend a 500-hour alcohol
treatment program in prison, and will allow Polk to surrender later, when a bed
is available at a federal camp in Tennessee or Kansas.

                            September 1, 1989 Friday

BYLINE: AAP

LENGTH: 291 words


Queen dethroned A bodyguard clears the way with a pullover as Leona Helmsley
leaves court in New York after her conviction on tax evasion charges.

New York LEONA HELMSLEY, the billionaire Queen of New York who once boasted
"only little people pay taxes" has been proved wrong. It seems big people pay
them, too, according to a jury in the Manhattan US District Federal Court.

The high-living Helmsley, 69, faces a possible three to five-year prison
sentence for each of the 33 counts she was convicted on, and fines ranging up to
$7 million.

The Hotel Queen and two associates, Frank Turco and Joseph Licari, were found
guilty of tax evasion, aiding and abetting tax evasion, conspiracy to defraud
the Internal Revenue Service and filing a false tax return.

She was acquitted of conspiracy to commit extortion.

Helmsley's husband, Harry, 80, whose $5 billion real estate kingdom includes the
Empire State Building, was indicted with his wife but was not tried because he
suffers from severe memory loss.

Leona Helmsley controlled a hotel empire which includes 21 hotels in 15 cities
around the world.

The sensational two-month trial was the talk of Manhattan. Most New Yorkers
developed a dislike for the gaudy socialite as more evidence of her true
character was revealed in testimony.

Prosecutors portrayed her as a modern-day Marie Antoinette and a string of
witnesses described her as short-tempered, haughty, harsh and hot-headed. Her
own attorney even said people might regard his client as a "tough bitch".

New York Mayor Ed Koch - never one to miss the bandwagon - even described
Helmsley as the Wicked Witch of the West." Judge John Walker set sentencing for
November 14, with Helmsley remaining free on bail.

                     The Leader-Post (Regina, Saskatchewan)

                            August 21, 2007 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

'The Queen of Mean' Leona Helmsley, 87, dies

BYLINE: Shannon D. Harrington, Bloomberg News

SECTION: ARTS & LIFE; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 971  words


Leona Helmsley, the real estate developer and hotel operator convicted of tax
evasion and dubbed "The Queen of Mean,'' died Monday. She was 87.

Helmsley died of heart failure at her summer home in Greenwich, Conn. said
spokesman Howard Rubenstein. With her husband, Harry, she helped build a
property empire that was once valued at $5 billion. It included interests in the
Empire State Building, the Park Lane Hotel on Central Park South and the
Helmsley Hotel on 42nd Street in New York City.

"She was a tough lady,'' said Edward Koch, the former New York City mayor who
first met Helmsley in the late 1970s. "She set standards for hotels and
service.''

Her conviction in 1989 on federal tax evasion charges made her a symbol of the
excesses of the 1980s and put her on the front pages of the tabloids. She and
her husband were charged with writing off renovations to their $11-million US
Greenwich estate as business expenses.

Helmsley served 18 months in prison after an eight-week trial in which former
employees painted her as a cold-hearted boss who fired workers on a whim and
told a housekeeper at her estate that "only the little people pay taxes.''

The case was the basis for a 1990 made-for-television movie Leona Helmsley: The
Queen of Mean.

In a statement, developer Donald Trump said: "Leona was definitely one of a
kind. Harry loved being with her and the excitement she brought -- and that is
all that really matters.''

Helmsley was born Lena Rosenthal on Independence Day in 1920 to a hatmaker and
housewife, both Polish immigrants, in Marbletown, N.Y., wrote Michael Moss, a
New York Newsday reporter at the time, in his 1989 book Palace Coup: The Inside
Story of Harry & Leona Helmsley.

Her family moved to New York City as the economy in Marbletown, a cement mill
hamlet, started to decline, Moss wrote.

Helmsley claimed to have attended Hunter College in Manhattan, although school
yearbooks have shed little light on that period. She later claimed to have
worked as a Chesterfield cigarette model before taking a job as a secretary at
New York real estate company Pease & Elliman.

She rose through the ranks to saleswoman, selling co-ops and condominiums, and
worked early in her career for residential real estate broker Brown Harris
Stevens, Rubenstein said. She also headed the new co-op unit of Sutton & Towne
Residential, the New York Times reported in a 1988 profile.

While stories of how she met Harry Helmsley vary, she went to work for a
subsidiary of the Helmsley Organization in 1970 and married the real estate
mogul two years later.

It was her fourth marriage. The first was to attorney Leo Panzirer, with whom
she had her only son, Jay Panzirer, and she married garment industry executive
Joseph Lubin twice.

After marrying Harry Helmsley, Leona's responsibilities within the real estate
empire grew.

"Her greatest contribution to life would be the very warm, affectionate,
comfortable life she gave to her husband,'' Koch said.

She took on day-to-day operations of the 950-room Helmsley Palace when it opened
in 1981. The palace, a 51-storey gleaming glass tower melded with the Madison
Avenue landmark residences, became Leona's signature project.

She gained control of the others after a wager, the Times reported. She
challenged the hotels' decorator to a competition: she and the professional each
designed three rooms. After her husband picked hers, she was named president of
the hotels, the Times said.

Her attention to detail became legendary and so did her penchant for tirades,
employees would later say.

Those stories culminated in the late 1980s after a group of employees and
contractors on the Helmsley's Greenwich estate went to the New York Post with
records showing the couple dodged taxes by billing their companies for
renovation work on the estate.

In 1988, a Manhattan grand jury indicted the Helmsleys on charges that they
evaded more than $4 million US in income taxes by charging furnishings and
renovations for the 28-acre estate to the real estate business. Prosecutors also
alleged Leona Helmsley extorted kickbacks from hotel suppliers and contractors.

Harry Helmsley, almost 80 at the time of the indictment, was determined not
mentally competent to stand trial.

A jury convicted Leona Helmsley of evading $1.2 million US in federal income
taxes, though it acquitted her of extortion.

During her trial, Helmsley's reputation as a cruel boss became so well-known
that her defence team cited it in arguments, with attorney Gerald Feffer
reminding jurors in opening remarks that while his client might be an unpopular
woman she wasn't on trial for "being a tough bitch,'' the New York Times
reported.

Former employees testified at the trial about how they feared her, with one
recalling how she casually fired him while she was being fitted for a dress.

Helmsley's "Queen of Mean'' image stuck during her later years.

When her husband died in 1997, Leona took over his empire and began selling some
holdings. She had an estimated net worth of $2.2 billion US, according to Forbes
magazine, which in 2006 ranked her No. 350 on its list of the world's wealthiest
people.

A jury in 2003 awarded $11.2 million US in damages to a former manager of
Helmsley's five-star Park Lane Hotel who claimed Helmsley fired him for being
gay. A judge later reduced the award to $554,000 US, although Helmsley was also
ordered to pay more than $638,000 US of her former employee's legal expenses.

More recently, she donated $5 million US to the American Red Cross for Hurricane
Katrina relief. She also contributed $25 million US to New York Presbyterian
Hospital and $5 million US after Sept. 11 to help the families of firefighters.
In the late 1990s, she gave millions to rebuild African-American churches that
were set afire in the South, Rubenstein said.

Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced.

                        The International Herald Tribune

                            August 22, 2009 Saturday

U.S. accuses 2 Swiss men of assisting tax evasion;
Expanding challenge to banking secrecy moves beyond clients

BYLINE: LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: Pg. 13

LENGTH: 767 words

ABSTRACT

A private banking executive and a lawyer are accused of providing tax evasion
services sold to wealthy clients, opening a new front in Washington's crackdown
on Swiss banking secrecy.

FULL TEXT

The U.S. Justice Department has indicted a Swiss private banking executive and a
Swiss lawyer, accusing them of selling tax evasion services to wealthy clients.
The move opens a new front in Washington's challenge to Switzerland's tradition
of bank secrecy.

The indictment, filed Thursday in U.S. District Court in Fort Lauderdale,
Florida, charged Hansruedi  Schumacher, a director at NZB Neue Zürcher Bank of
Zurich, and Matthias W. Rickenbach, a Swiss lawyer, with one count each of
conspiring to defraud the United States.

It was filed a day after the giant Swiss bank UBS said that it had agreed to
disclose the names of 4,450 American clients and account details, and it
indicated that the American authorities were starting to pursue smaller players
who might have helped Americans hide money. Smaller Swiss banks have expressed
confidence that they could continue to work with American clients and find new
ways to protect their privacy.

''These conspiracy charges show that Justice is widening the net beyond UBS to
include other banks, and that it is also going beyond individual account holders
to the professionals who assist them,'' said Lee Sheppard, a tax lawyer in New
York and a writer for Tax Analysts, a trade publication.

Mr. Schumacher is a former top private banker for UBS who left around 2002 to
establish and oversee NZB's private banking operations. He worked at NZB until
at least last month, the indictment said. Mr. Rickenbach is a partner of the
Rickenbach & Partner law firm, with offices in Zurich and Geneva.

A Justice Department statement said the two men ''helped their clients obtain
offshore credit cards and created sham loan documents.'' It said they
''falsified bank documents to generate the appearance that assets of their U.S.
clients belonged to Swiss citizens, and they falsified documents to disguise
their United States clients' repatriation of offshore funds as inheritances from
foreign citizens.''

The statement said the defendants told clients ''that their assets and
identification would be safer at NZB because they had no presence in the United
States'' and were ''less likely to be pressured by the American authorities to
disclose the identities of their United States clients.''

The American authorities appear to be widening their attack on Swiss banking
secrecy. Switzerland is the world's largest repository of hidden wealth,
estimated to hold nearly one-third of the $7 trillion in assets that are
believed to be held offshore. Charges filed this summer against two American UBS
clients, Jeffrey P. Chernick and John McCarthy, included references to their
dealings with Mr. Schumacher, Mr. Rickenbach and NZB, but did not name them.

The new indictment charges the two Swiss men with helping Mr. McCarthy evade
taxes, in part through entities in Hong Kong linked to his UBS account.

Around 2007, the complaint says, Mr. Rickenbach's father hand-carried $5,000 to
New York to deliver to an unidentified client, illustrating one way that the
Swiss lawyer surreptitiously moved money across borders.

NZB was established in 2000 by former senior executives from Bank Julius Bär, a
prominent Swiss private bank. Over 2007 and 2008, Sarasin Group, another Swiss
private bank, acquired a 40 percent stake in NZB, while NZB employees own the
rest.

The indictment Thursday said that Mr. Schumacher, who was referred to but not
identified by name in the Chernick papers, was a former manager of UBS's
cross-border private banking division, the unit under scrutiny for having helped
Americans evade taxes.

Mr. Schumacher left UBS around 2002 to join NZB and help clients of UBS and
other firms to evade taxes, according to the charges against him.

The indictment said that Mr. Schumacher and Mr. Rickenbach paid $45,000 to a
''high-ranking Swiss government official'' in 2008 to learn whether Mr.
Chernick, their client, was on a list of 285 names to be disclosed to the
American authorities in February in a broad settlement with UBS. Mr. Chernick
paid the fee.

Mr. Schumacher, the Chernick filing said, told Mr. Chernick that because the
smaller bank had not entered into a special disclosure program with the Internal
Revenue Service, the U.S. tax collection agency, it would be subject to less
scrutiny by U.S. tax officials than UBS.

Douglas Shulman, the I.R.S. commissioner, said Wednesday that the agency was
looking at other banks and intermediaries in Switzerland.

                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

Guilty plea seen in Phila. charges;
Businessman Joseph Mammana is expected to admit to tax evasion and illegal gun

BYLINE: Robert Moran, Inquirer Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B07

LENGTH: 327 words


Joseph Mammana, a businessman who gained prominence for donating to criminal
reward funds, is expected to plead guilty next week to tax evasion and illegal
gun possession.

As part of his plea agreement, Mammana will forfeit his 2003 Lamborghini
Murcielago, according to a guilty plea memorandum filed by federal prosecutors
this week.

Mammana is expected to enter his guilty plea Tuesday in U.S. District Court. He
was under investigation for tax evasion when, on Nov. 29, IRS agents found a
loaded .357-caliber revolver in the master bedroom of his Yardley home.

Mammana, who owns an egg-processing plant in North Philadelphia, is a five-time
convicted felon and cannot possess a gun.

His convictions date back to the 1980s and early 1990s: two for larceny, two for
drugs, and the one for aggravated assault against his ex-wife.

He told IRS agents that it was his mother's gun and that she would stay
overnight in his bedroom and keep it in his nightstand, according to the guilty
plea memorandum.

After his arrest, a government motion cited records showing that Mammana had
$777,000 in a bank account in 2004 and purchased the Lamborghini, worth
$287,655, by making a cash down payment of $150,000. It also reported that he
had told federal officials that his annual income was only $100,000.

For illegal gun possession and tax evasion, Mammana faces a maximum 15 years in
prison and $500,000 in fines. He also has agreed to pay all taxes he owes,
according to the memorandum.

Prosecutor Michael Bresnick and defense attorney Jeffrey Lindy couldn't be
reached for comment yesterday.

In recent years, Mammana became known for making large contributions to Citizens
Crime Commission of the Delaware Valley and other reward funds for information
leading to convictions in some of Philadelphia's highest-profile murders and
kidnappings.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                             June 5, 2002 Wednesday

Ex-Tyco head facing tax charges

BYLINE: BARRIE McKENNA

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: INTERNATIONAL; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 679 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The former head of conglomerate Tyco International Ltd. - one of Corporate
America's highest-paid executives - is facing charges of ducking $1-million
(U.S.) in sales tax on pricey French art.

Prosecutors in New York City indicted Dennis Kozlowski, 55, yesterday on charges
of conspiracy, falsifying records, tampering with physical evidence and tax
evasion a day after he quit as Tyco CEO.

"To fail to pay over a million in sales tax is a serious crime," Manhattan
District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said. "There will be zero tolerance for tax
evasion . . . particularly those with offshore jurisdictions to avoid paying
taxes."

Mr. Kozlowski, dubbed "deal-a-month Dennis" at the height of Tyco's frenetic
rise, is the latest U.S. business idol to crash as the fallout that began with
the Enron Corp. scandal continues to shake investor faith in U.S. financial
markets.

He joins a growing list of once-celebrated business titans to walk the corporate
plank in recent weeks, including WorldCom Inc.'s Bernard Ebbers, John Rigas of
Adelphia Communications Corp., Chuck Watson at Dynegy Inc. and William T.
McCormick Jr. at CMS Energy Corp.

An avid sailor, motorcyclist and helicopter pilot, Mr. Kozlowski pocketed more
than $100-million in cash, shares and other perks from Tyco over the past three
years. He also collected more than 13 million stock options, which were worth
hundreds of millions of dollars before Tyco shares crashed earlier this year as
investors fretted about its complex accounting practices.

A leading executive compensation consultant has described Mr. Kozlowski's pay
package as "egregious," even by Wall Street standards

Mr. Kozlowski, the son a New Jersey policeman who built Tyco into a
manufacturing giant during the nineties' boom, spent at least part of those
earnings indulging an apparent taste for fine art.

According to the indictment, Mr. Kozlowski never paid New York taxes on half a
dozen Impressionist and Old Masters paintings he bought in 2001, including a
$4.7-million Renoir still life, Fleurs et Fruits, and a $3.95-million Monet
landscape.

Prosecutors allege that art dealers and unnamed Tyco employees helped Mr.
Kozlowski ship the paintings via the company's offices in New Hampshire, where
there is no sales tax, to Mr. Kozlowski's lavish 13-room Fifth Avenue apartment
in New York City. Tyco's legal headquarters is in the tax haven of Bermuda.

"Tyco employees were directed to sign false documents reflecting the receipt in
New Hampshire of artwork, in an effort to thwart tax auditors," Mr. Morgenthau
said.

Mr. Kozlowski, who faces fines and several years in jail on the felony and
misdemeanour charges, pleaded not guilty during a brief court appearance
yesterday. He was released after posting a $3-million bond and surrendering his
U.S. passport.

His next court appearance is set for June 26.

The indictment was the latest blow for embattled Tyco, which has been battling
intense investor skepticism over the company's heavy debt load and its complex
structure.

"The resignation . . . has driven volatility and further confusion," agreed Don
MacDougall, an analyst at J.P. Morgan Securities Inc. in New York.

But Mr. MacDougall said Mr. Kozlowski's departure is probably good news for Tyco
shares because it "removes most of the credibility issues associated with the
previous leadership."

Tyco shares, which plunged 27 per cent on the New York Stock Exchange Monday,
recovered a bit of their lost ground yesterday as investors heaved a sigh that
the charges are unrelated to the company's business operations.

They ended the trading session rising up 72 cents or 4.49 per cent at $16.77.

The company, which makes everything from undersea fibre-optic cable to valves
and pipes, has lost nearly $90-billion in stock market value this year.

Former CEO John Fort, 59, has returned to the boardroom as chairman and CEO
until a permanent successor is found.

Mr. Kozlowski led Tyco on a frenetic acquisition tear in the nineties, buying
out hundreds of companies and boosting its annual sales to $36-billion.

                            The Independent (London)

                              April 8, 2011 Friday
                                 First Edition

US demands HSBC give up potential tax evaders

BYLINE: Stephen Foley in New York

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 380 words


THE US is demanding that HSBC should reveal the names of potentially thousands
of Americans who have opened secret accounts with the bank in India, in a
widening investigation into tax evasion.

The US government filed a so-called "John Doe summons" on HSBC India last night
via a petition in a San Francisco court, which asked for the names of an unknown
number of people who may have engaged in tax fraud.

HSBC last night said it had not seen the summons but it would co-operate with
requests from the US authorities, while complying with the law in all the
jurisdictions it operates in, including India. It added: "HSBC does not condone
tax tax evasion and fully supports the US efforts to promote appropriate payment
of taxes by US taxpayers."

The petition is a repeat of a legal tactic first used against UBS, and comes two
years after the Zurich-based bank agreed to pay $780m (£478m) to the US
government and revealed the details of 4,000 US clients' Swiss bank accounts
after admitting it helped those who wanted to evade US taxes. The deal blew a
hole in Switzerland's traditional banking secrecy, and encouraged US residents
to reveal their offshore accounts in amnesties offered by the Internal Revenue
Service.

"The ability to hide accounts in foreign countries is rapidly dwindling," said
John DiCicco, deputy assistant attorney general for the Justice Department's tax
unit, announcing the move against HSBC. "We will continue working hand-in-hand
with the IRS to enforce the tax laws against those who are using offshore
accounts - wherever they are located - to evade taxes."

Earlier this year, prosecutors in New Jersey filed charges against Vaibhav
Dahake, claiming that the businessman conspired with bankers of "one of the
largest international banks in the world" to hide accounts in India. The
indictment refers to five unnamed bankers who conspired with Mr Dahake: two in
New York, one in Fremont, California, and two in Thane, India. It is alleged
that HSBC suggested Mr Dahake open accounts in India to add to those he already
held in the British Virgin Islands, and that it helped him shuffle money out of
sight of the US tax authorities.

Between 2002 and 2010, HSBC India ran two offices in the US soliciting
non-resident Indians to open accounts in the country.

Castroneves siblings in hot water with IRS over tax evasion

BYLINE: News Services

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 201  words

DATELINE: MIAMI


Helio Castroneves -- winner of both the Indianapolis 500 and reality TV show
"Dancing with the Stars" -- will soon be doing the tango with the IRS over multi
million-dollar tax-evasion charges in Miami federal court, U.S. authorities
said.

The famed Brazilian driver, who owns a Coral Gables mansion sporting his
auto-racing trophies and two checkered flags from his Indy 500 victories, was
indicted along with a relative and a Michigan attorney on Thursday, authorities
said.

The 33-year-old Team Penske star is charged with failing to pay taxes on more
than $5 million in income during a four-year period, authorities said. His
sister, Kati Castroneves, and his lawyer, Alan Miller, are accused of assisting
him in the alleged tax-evasion scheme.

The three defendants are expected to surrender to authorities and have their
first appearances in federal court on Friday morning. They could not be reached
for comment Thursday afternoon.

Castroneves was born in Sao Paulo. Race car driving has made him a rich man.

He won the Indianapolis 500 in both 2001 and 2002. He was the fifth driver to
achieve that milestone in consecutive years. He also finished second to teammate
and countryman Gil de Ferran in 2003.

                     Marin Independent Journal (California)

                            April 27, 2006 Thursday

15-month sentence for local lumber magnate

BYLINE: By Keri Brenner

SECTION: LOCAL; News; Marin

LENGTH: 295 words


Golden State's Nobmann guilty of tax evasion

North Bay lumber magnate Lee Nobmannwas sentenced this week to 15 months in
jail, fined $40,000 and ordered to pay $330,000 in restitution after pleading
guillty to tax evasion, federal officials said.

The 55-year-old Nobmann's Petaluma-based Golden State Lumber company has four
Bay Area locations including a store in San Rafael and was named "Business of
the Year" by the Marin Builders Association in 2001.

Federal IRS agents raided his San Rafael lumber store and other locations in
June 2002.

"Nobmann was indicted by a federal grand jury on Oct. 7, 2003 and will begin
serving his sentence on July 10," said U.S. Attorney Kevin Ryan at the
sentencing announcement Tuesday in San Francisco.

Nobmann could not be reached for comment.

According to Ryan, Nobmann under-reported income for Golden State Lumber between
1996 and 2000 by about $1.1 million and did not report that sum as personal
income on his own income tax returns during that period.

Nobmann's share of the unreported income was $910,000.

"He evaded some $330,000 in taxes as a result of his actions," Ryan said.

Nobmann admitted depositing rebate checks into his personal bank account from
vendors who did business with his company. He did not report the checks as
either company or personal income. He also admitted making other entries in the
company's books that benefited him personally, according to Ryan.

Authorities were alerted to Nobmann's illegal activity by Golden State Lumber's
fired chief financial officer, Ryan said.

Golden State Lumber is a California corporation with sales of $400 million a
year.

Read more San Rafael stories at the IJ's San Rafael city page.

Contact Keri Brenner at kbrenner@marinij.com . IJ news services contributed to
this story.

MOTION TO DISMISS FILED

IN TAX-EVASION RETRIAL The U.S. Attorney's Office yesterday moved to dismiss all
tax-evasion charges against the vice president of a regional building-inspection
firm who was granted a new trial after a federal judge ruled that his 1996 trial
was tainted by the perjured testimony of the government's key witness.

The retrial of Mark McLaughlin, 41, of Doylestown, was to have begun Wednesday.
Instead, Catherine M. Recker, the defense attorney, said she would ask Chief
U.S. District Judge James T. Giles to grant the motion to dismiss filed
yesterday.

In March, Giles ordered a new trial, writing that the outcome of McLaughlin's
trial was "strongly affected" by false statements made by accountant Melvin
Cherry.

McLaughlin owns Building Inspection Underwriters, a Holland-based company that
performs building inspections for municipalities in Pennsylvania and New Jersey.
McLaughlin and his brother Russell, 47, were indicted in 1995 on tax-evasion
charges and together with their sister, Robin, on conspiracy in an alleged
scheme to divert more than $1.5 million from the firm to evade federal income
taxes. Robin and Russell McLaughlin were acquitted; Mark McLaughlin was awaiting
sentencing when Giles ordered the new trial.

A STOLEN JEEP, FLEEING CRASH,

CRASHES INTO KING HIGH A stolen red Jeep plowed into Martin Luther King High
School in East Germantown yesterday after racing away from a nearby accident and
running down an embankment. There were no injuries, but students in five
classrooms were temporarily relocated as engineers checked the building for
structural damage.

Three people inside the Jeep jumped out and ran after the 8:30 a.m. crash,
police said. Police said the driver lost control while fleeing a minor accident
he had caused when he backed into a car.

The Jeep is owned by a construction company based in Doylestown, police said.
Investigators said that they found a book bag from Leeds Middle School inside
the Jeep and that they were questioning a youth who showed up at King, at
Stenton Avenue and Haines Street, after the accident.

S. PHILADELPHIA ARSON

MAY HAVE BEEN RETALIATION An arson at a South Philadelphia grocery yesterday may
have been in retaliation for last month's fatal shooting of an area man,
allegedly by the man who owned the store at 24th and Morris Streets, detectives
said.

Former store owner Martin Jaquez, 22, was charged with murder and related
offenses in the April 6 shooting of Gardner Taylor, 36. A neighborhood fixture,
Taylor swept the sidewalks and looked after neighbors. Police had, for a while,
put a detail on the store to prevent retaliation. The detail was recently
lifted, authorities said.

About 2:30 a.m. yesterday, police said, someone pried open the door at Jaquez
Mini Market, poured a flammable liquid inside and ignited it. The blaze was
quickly brought under control by firefighters but caused considerable interior
damage. An empty bottle believed to have contained the accelerant was found
nearby, police said. The business had recently changed hands and reopened but
carried the old name out front, police said.

Jaquez is alleged to have shot Taylor after an argument over a delivery truck
parked in front of the store, partially blocking handicapped access to the
sidewalk.

BERKS HEARING IS MAY 22

IN DEATH OF 4 TRAPPED BY TRAIN WEST READING - A preliminary hearing is set May
22 for Carlos Angel Diaz Santiago, the West Reading man accused of killing his
ex-girlfriend, her 2-year-old son and two other people by forcing their car in
front of a freight train.

The 22-year-old defendant is being held without bail on four counts of criminal
homicide and related charges. The April 20 deaths in Sinking Spring, just
outside Reading, followed an argument between Diaz and his former girlfriend,
leading to a brief high-speed chase that ended in the car-train crash.

A CHESTER UPLAND EMPLOYEE

CLEARED OF INDECENT ASSAULT Darren Alliston, 38, who had been suspended from his
job as a Chester Upland School District behavior specialist, was found not
guilty yesterday of indecently assaulting a Chester High School student, now 18,
at his home in January 1999.

Alliston, of Chester, told the Delaware County Court jury that he took the girl
to his home after a basketball game because her mother had asked him to counsel
her. Numerous character witnesses, including a school district administrator and
a pastor, testified on behalf of Alliston, who is active in the Chester
community as chaplain of a church choir.

                              The Washington Post

                     June 19, 1984, Tuesday, Final Edition

Md. Man's Mail-Order Church Scheme Preyed On IRS, U.S. Says

BYLINE: By Arthur S. Brisbane, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; B1

LENGTH: 987 words


Federal authorities say a Department of Health and Human Services computer
operations supervisor concocted an elaborate tax evasion scheme in which he used
the First Amendment and a mail-order church to preach tax evasion to dozens of
federal workers and others.

Robert L. Bocock, 47, of Columbia, Md., pleaded guilty last week to income tax
evasion and assisting in the preparation of a false return. In exchange for
having charges reduced from the original 32-count indictment, he agreed to
provide testimony to a grand jury investigating tax abuses tied to mail-order
churches.

Michael Schatzow, an assistant U.S. attorney in Baltimore, said Bocock helped
prepare 93 tax returns claiming $740,000 in deductions for bogus charitable
contributions to the Universal Life Church. The scheme deprived the U.S. coffers
of $226,000 in tax money.

The investigation into Bocock's activities is part of a continuing Internal
Revenue Service examination of tax cheating and mail-order churches.

Federal authorities say the First Amendment protection of religious freedom
sometimes has provided a cloak over the activities of those who would use
religion to shortchange tax collectors.

Domenic LaPonzina, an IRS spokesman, said the agency for two years has
instructed its tax examiners to scrutinize claims made for contributions to
mail-order churches. In some of those instances, no contributions were made. In
others, the contributions were made but were subsequently disallowed because the
church was not considered a legitimate establishment.

"We don't care if they worship tomatoes and cheese, so long as they have a
congregation and genuine worship is taking place and they have some sort of
creed," LaPonzina said.

A representative of the Universal Life Church in Modesto, Calif., said Bocock's
activities did not represent any creed to which his church adheres. Bishop
Robert Imbeau, the church's vice president, said the church had no knowledge of
Bocock's elaborate manipulation of First Amendment privileges and Form 1040.

"It's a dad-blamed shame that this sort of thing has to happen," Imbeau said.

Schatzow said the credentials of the Universal Life Church as a tax-exempt
institution were not an issue in this case. "In the Bocock case," he said, "the
contributions in fact were not made, so it wouldn't make any difference if you
were talking about the Universal Life Church or the Catholic Church or a Jewish
synagogue."

In another case in the area involving the Universal Life Church, Maryland tax
authorities in December disallowed deductions based on contributions made by
eight Prince George's County police officers and others to local Universal Life
Church congregation bank accounts. The state's tax court ruled that although the
contributions were made into congregation accounts, the accounts were a "tax
sham" used to shelter personal income.

Bocock declined to comment on his case. His scheme, U.S. authorities alleged,
worked like this:

Bocock, after hearing about the Universal Life Church on CBS' "60 Minutes"
television program and reading church literature on the tax advantages of
membership, obtained a mail-order charter from the church, making him a minister
with his own congregation. The charter was listed under the alias of Lew Scott.

"Lew Scott," complying with church regulations, filed quarterly reports
indicating contributions by Robert L. Bocock to Scott's congregation bank
account. Bocock then claimed the contributions on his tax returns over a period
of four years.

The government says Bocock's "contributions" were only paper transactions and
that there was no congregation bank account. The money went into an account
Bocock used for himself and his corporation, Adventures in Recreation Inc.

Bocock falsely claimed to have made $66,494.15 in contributions to the church
from 1978 through 1981, the government alleged. In a year in which his net
take-home pay was $9,877, Bocock claimed he gave the Universal Life Church more
than $20,000.

The sizable deductions caught the eye of an IRS examiner, triggering the
investigation of Bocock, LaPonzina said.

Bocock extended the scheme to about 25 federal coworkers plus others outside the
government, Schatzow said. Touting himself as a tax preparer, he told clients
they could claim phony contributions to the church and then deduct them from
their adjusted gross income on Form 1040. In some instances Bocock provided
bogus receipts for the contribution to the church; in others he offered to do
so.

For compensation, Bocock asked his clients to pay him 10 percent of their
combined state and federal tax refunds.

Hyattsville resident Bruce R. Francis, according to the government's statement
of facts in the case, was told by a friend that Bocock was a tax preparer who
could save him a lot of money.

Francis later told authorities that when Bocock came to his house in February
1982, Bocock showed him the tax "benefits" of joining the Universal Life Church
and making paper contributions to it. He allegedly presented Francis with two
sets of figures. One, based on legitimate deductions, indicated Francis would
receive a $3,000 refund; the other, buffered with contributions to the church,
promised a $22,000 refund.

Francis opted for the $22,000. Late in 1982, when the IRS informed Francis of a
pending examination of his tax return, Francis contacted Bocock and, the
government alleged, Bocock offered to provide him with receipts to cover the
$33,000 contribution he claimed to have made. Francis declined the offer.

Later still, after Francis was called to testify before a grand jury
investigating his tax preparer, Bocock told Francis to "stonewall" the jury, the
government says. Francis cooperated with the government, however.

The scheme had one more twist.

Bocock reportedly advised his clients they could deduct the fee paid to him--as
a charitable contribution to the church.

                               The New York Times

                 August 12, 1991, Monday, Late Edition - Final

Harry Helmsley: Unfit for Trial, but Fit for Business?

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1653 words


The people who worked with him are already beginning to talk about Harry
Helmsley in the past tense, and the United States Attorney in Manhattan has
dropped tax-evasion charges against him, citing what he regards as Mr.
Helmsley's mental incompetence. The man who was a kingpin of New York real
estate for more than five decades has receded from public view to the point of
vanishing.

Yet Mr. Helmsley's immense real-estate operation is still moving along, shrunk
in size, less vigorous, but possessing the many complex partnerships and service
contracts that have been the foundation of his wealth. And despite the possible
prison term that his wife, Leona, faces for tax evasion and his court-determined
incompetence to stand trial, Mr. Helmsley appears to continue at the head of his
companies.

'He Gives Us His Input'

"All major decisions are made by Mr. Helmsley," said Gerald N. Schrager, the
Helmsleys' real-estate lawyer and chief legal adviser and, since the legal and
business troubles involving him and his wife began, the Helmsley spokesman. "He
gives us his input every time he thinks it is appropriate."

If the 81-year-old Mr. Helmsley is in charge of holdings estimated at more than
$4 billion, still by far the largest commercial real-estate brokerage in New
York City, is he senile?

To what extent has Mrs. Helmsley's criminal notoriety, her infamous temper, her
description by her own defense lawyer as "one tough bitch" and her depiction in
a television movie as a cruel and dishonest "Queen of Mean" affected her
husband's business?

And who will determine the future of the Helmsley operation?

In withdrawing 47 charges of fraud and tax evasion, Federal prosecutors relied
on competency tests supervised by the State Supreme Court in Manhatttan, where
the Helmsleys had faced similar state charges that were dismissed. According to
court documents, those tests relied in part on evaluations conducted by doctors
hired by Mr. Helmsley and his lawyers. Those doctors said Mr. Helmsley could not
stand the strain of a trial.

No Comment by U.S. Attorney

Asked to comment on the apparent discrepancy between Mr. Schrager's account of
Mr. Helmsley's current abilities and the court finding of mental incompetence,
the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan declined to comment directly.
The office's public information officer, Deborah Corley Guzman, said, "I would
refer you to the wording of the motion to dismiss."

Mrs. Helmsley, who is now 71, was sentenced in Federal District Court in
Manhattan to four years in prison for her part in the tax-fraud scheme, in which
the Helmsleys' were accused of charging personal expenses to their business
ventures. On July 31 the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
upheld her conviction but sent her case back to the trial court for
resentencing.

Finding by Psychiatrist

On May 23, meanwhile, Dr. Murray A. Gordon, a psychiatrist, concluded that Mr.
Helmsley suffered from dementia caused by hypertension and poor cerebral blood
circulation. Dr. Murray wrote that the developer "lacks capacity to understand
the proceedings against him, or to assist in his own defense."

But Mr. Schrager said Mr. Helmsley still presided over a multimillion-dollar
property and services empire that was "stabilized." It is also one that has been
shrinking in recent years, and one that Mr. Helmsley is, by the available
evidence, trying to shrink further.

He has already shed some outlying brokerage holdings, his Manhattan real-estate
insurance operations and his long-term lease on the million-square foot former
Macy's warehouse in Long Island City, Queens. He is also seeking buyers for his
Harley Hotel chain and for his residential brokerage and management company,
Brown Harris Stevens Inc.

Perhaps most important in terms of prestige, Mr. Helmsley's partners in the
jewel in the crown, the Helmsley Palace Hotel, are trying to force the Helmsleys
out of control of the hotel and, Mr. Helmsley's consultants say, force the sale
of the Palace.

The Palace partners' assert that the Helmsleys' billing of the costs of
improving their Connecticut house to the hotel, and Mrs. Helmsley's criminal
conviction arising from those actions, were responsible for the hotel's
disappointing financial performance in recent years.

Major Role by 'Queen'

Several former Helmsley employees insisted in interviews that Mrs. Helmsley has
had a major impact, at first for the better, but more recently for the worse.
She was a brilliant if ruthless real-estate executive, they say, and the
nationwide advertising campaign that identified her as the "Queen" standing
guard over customer services at the Palace produced great dividends.

But her tightening control over the Helmsley operation and, by many accounts,
over Mr. Helmsley himself has been just as damaging, said these former
associates, who asked that they not be identified.

Trial Led to Defections

No one in the management of the company returned telephone calls for comment,
and Howard J. Rubenstein, Mr. Helmsley's public-relations consultant, referred
all questions to Mr. Schrager. Mr. Schrager did not respond to a request to
interview the Helmsleys.

Several former Helmsley-Spear associates were blunt in their criticism of Mrs.
Helmlsey, who is still listed as a broker at Brown Harris Stevens, but who does
not appear to have had a role in the company's day-to-day operations since her
1989 conviction for fraud and tax evasion.

The former employees' criticism focuses on both Mrs. Helmsley's actions within
the business, where she was noted for on-the-spot dismissals that Mr. Helmsley
occasionally reversed, and on her public notoriety before, during and after the
tax-evasion trial. The latter cost the company credibilty, said a former Brown
Harris Steven broker who was part of a mass dismissal last October, and who now
works at another management concern.

The broker said many shareholders in buildings managed by Brown Harris Stevens
read about Mrs. Helmsley's paying personal expenses out of business accounts and
no longer wanted the company to manage their building.

Perhaps as a consequence, and perhaps also because of a growing fragmentation of
the city's co-op management industry, Brown Harris Stevens's client list has
been shrinking, with a half-dozen trophy buildings forsaking the company for
other agencies.

Mrs. Helmsley meanwhile is in seclusion with her husband while her appeal is
pending.

"When the leader passes on," another former Helmsley-Spear broker said, using
the now familiar past tense when speaking of Mr. Helmsley, "there is still the
framework of a very big company there, even though the momentum and the energy
are drifting away. Now the company is just waiting for the next leader to come
along."

Associates Become Managers

Mr. Helmsley is childless, and with his wife facing a possible prison term,
day-to-day management of the company has fallen to two of Mr. Helmsley's oldest
associates, Irving Scheider and Alvin Schwartz. Both are major shareholders in
Helmsley-Spear and are reported to have an agreement to buy Mr. Helmsley's
position on his death.

Craig Panzirer, Mrs. Helmsley's grandson from one of her two earlier marriages,
is a salesman in the company but is not yet regarded as a potential successor to
the helm.

Mr. Schrager, the lawyer, declined to account for the discrepancy between the
court report of mental incompetence and Mr. Helmsley's reported command of his
business. He spoke only of Mr. Helmsley as contented and in control.

"From a global view, the Helmsley interests are stabilized," Mr. Schrager said.
"They are not exposed to the vagaries of the marketplace to the extent that the
rest of the real-estate busines has been. We are not undertaking any new
development projects at this time, because the marketplace doesn't call for any,
and we are basically focusing on managing the existing interests."

But what activity there is constitutes shrinkage.

The Harley Hotel chain of 14 hotels in the East and Middle West has been rumored
to be for sale for some time. Mr. Schrager offered only a faint denial, saying
it has "not been actively put on the market," though the company would enterain
offers.

Last year Mr. Helmsley sold Helmsley-Greenfield, a Philadelphia-based brokerage
with several mid-Atlantic branch offices, Mr. Schrager said, while Brown Harris
Stevens Inc., the residential management and brokerage company, has been on the
market for nearly a year.

Insurance Business Transferred

Helmsley-Spear's big insurance department, which wrote policies on both
commercial and residential properties, has also been transferred, under terms
neither side would reveal, to the Frank B. Hall Insurance Company, controlled by
Saul Steinberg, the financier.

Helmsley-Spear Inc., meanwhile, has been shrinking internally as well, perhaps
to a greater extent than the many other brokerage and management concerns that
have been forced to cut back in the current real-estate recession.

In 1986 a standard directory of Manhattan real-estate brokerages listed
Helmsley-Spear's headquarters at the Lincoln Building, 60 East 42d Street, 27
branch offices nationwide, 86 brokers and 145 sales people. The current
directory shows nine national offices, not counting the old Helmsley-Greenfield
affiliates, 67 brokers and 59 sales people.

Besides the hotels, the brokerage and the management agencies, Mr. Helmsley
controls a handful of important buildings, although real-estate ownership has
never been as large a part of his wealth as it has been for some of the city's
other real-estate leaders.

After seeing Mr. Helmsley not too long ago, Mr. Schrager reported: "He said,
'I've only had one job, but it's the only one I've needed, and I think it has
worked out fairly well.' And I said, 'It certainly has, Mr. H.' "

Helmsley-Spear Inc. and Helmsley-Noyes Inc., have refused to list these

buildings in which he has an interest, the annual Cushman & Wakefield Manhattan

provides a sense of his holdings. In 1991, the service listed 45 major Manhattan

                                US Official News

                            February 20, 2015 Friday

Vitter Pushes DOJ for Information on HSBC Drug Money Laundering, Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 879  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator David Vitter, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

U.S. Senator David Vitter (R-La.), member of the Senate Judiciary Committee,
today sent a letter to Attorney General Eric Holder pushing for information
regarding alleged tax evasion and money laundering by megabank HSBC in 2012.
HSBC was charged with allowing a massive billion dollar money laundering scheme
that involved Mexican drug cartels and international terrorist organizations,
but was punished with a minor monetary penalty. U.S. Attorney Loretta Lynch,
nominee to replace Holder as Attorney General, allowed HSBC to reach an
agreement that avoids prosecution, instead of immediately pursuing criminal
charges.

"This case has been completely swept under the rug, but it provides significant
insight into how Loretta Lynch would act as our country's top law enforcement
official," Vitter said. "If she completely ignored serious tax evasion
allegations against HSBC that put the identities of American citizens at risk,
we need to know a heck of a lot more about it."

Lynch's nomination was scheduled to receive a vote in the Senate Judiciary
Committee last week, but Vitter and others requested a hold-over. The vote on
her confirmation has been delayed.

Prior to the nomination hearings, Lynch failed to include in her questionnaire
an interview in which she defended the HSBC settlement. Vitter submitted a
question for the record asking Lynch how she will handle oversight of this
settlement given the role she played in negotiating it. Click here to read more.

In 2012, HSBC entered into an agreement for $1.26 billion and paid another $665
million in penalties to avoid criminal prosecution. These amounts represent a
small fraction of HSBC's assets. Vitter has been in touch with a whistleblower
who is a former HSBC employee. Click here to read more.

HSBC continues to face similar allegations around the world. Yesterday, Swiss
prosecutors raided HSBC's offices in Geneva based on allegations of tax evasion
and money laundering. Click here to read more.

The text of the letter is below.


The Honorable Eric H. Holder, Jr.
Attorney General
U.S. Department of Justice
950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW
Washington, D.C. 20530-0001

Dear Attorney General Holder:

As the Senate considers the nomination of the next Attorney General of the
United States, questions remain unanswered about potentially lax treatment of
HSBC Bank USA (HSBC) by the Department of Justice. The handling of this case is
particularly important given the insight it gives the Senate into the decisions
made by Loretta Lynch, who was in charge of the US Attorney's office and the
case at the time. To further the Senate's consideration of her nomination, I
request you supply me and the rest of the Senate Judiciary Committee with any
documents from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in regard to HSBC, as well as
the other documents enumerated below in regard to the HSBC settlement.

These decisions by the DOJ and Ms. Lynch's office raise troubling questions
about whether pertinent information of public concern regarding HSBC was "swept
under the rug", if justice was served, and why HSBC was given special treatment
that allowed it to walk away from such serious offenses unscathed. This case is
increasingly relevant and pressing now that Ms. Lynch has been nominated as the
next Attorney General.

If media reports are true, knowledge of HSBC shielding clients from US tax
liabilities was known to the Department of Justice at least as early as April
2010, yet no criminal charges have ever been brought against HSBC for tax
evasion. Moreover, in 2012 the US Attorney's Office run by Ms. Lynch negotiated
a Deferred Prosecution Agreement (DPA) with HSBC that allowed HSBC to admit
guilt for the crimes of money laundering and facilitating transactions with
sanctioned countries, but avoid criminal prosecution for those infractions.

Accordingly, as a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I request that the
Department of Justice (DOJ) provide the following information:

1) Copies of all documents and information in DOJ's possession reflecting when
the DOJ first learned that HSBC may be involved in tax evasion, including but
not limited to any recommendations from the IRS in regard to HSBC and tax
evasion;

2) Copies of all documents and information in DOJ's possession, including but
not limited to information received from French authorities or any other
persons, governments or entities, reflecting evidence that HSBC was shielding
clients from tax liabilities;

3) Copies of all documents and information relating to the negotiation of the
DPA with HSBC; and

4) Copies of all documents and information relating to why DOJ chose not to
prosecute HSBC for tax evasion, fraud, money laundering, facilitating
transactions with sanctioned countries or any other crimes.

Please deliver copies of this information to my Senate office in Hart Senate
Office Building Room 516, and in electronic form to Travis Johnson at
Travis_Johnson@Vitter.Senate.Gov by February 23, 2015. Should you have any
questions, please contact Travis in my office at (202) 224-4623.

Sincerely,


David Vitter
United States Senate

3 Swiss bankers charged in tax evasion row

LENGTH: 202 words

DATELINE: New York


New York, Jan. 5 -- The US prosecutors accused three Swiss bankers on Thursday
of conspiring with wealthy US taxpayers to hide more than $1.2 billion in assets
from tax authorities, and sources said the three worked for Wegelin & Co, one of
Switzerland's oldest private banks.

The office of the Manhattan US Attorney said that the indictment charges the
bankers with trying to capture business lost by UBS AG and another large
international Swiss bank in the wake of widespread news reports that the
Internal Revenue Service was investigating UBS in 2008 and 2009.

The charges signal that US authorities are moving closer to criminal charges
against some Swiss and Swiss-style banks that sold tax evasion services to rich
Americans. Wegelin was not identified in the single indictment filed against
Michael Berlinka, Urs Frei and Roger Keller. The three men, who reside in
Switzerland, worked for the unnamed between 2005 and 2010 and sold tax evasion
services from the bank's Zurich office, the indictment said. Published by HT
Syndication with permission from Daily Pak Banker. For any query with respect to
this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                            March 31, 2010 Wednesday
                                 METRO EDITION

Cook charged with fraud, tax evasion;
The Minneapolis money manager agreed to the charges related to a $190 million
Ponzi scheme.

BYLINE: DAN BROWNING; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1D

LENGTH: 932 words


Trevor Gilson Cook, a 37-year-old Minneapolis money manager who's been accused
by regulators of running a $190 million Ponzi scheme, was charged by federal
authorities Tuesday afternoon with one count of mail fraud and one count of tax
evasion.

Cook was not indicted, but rather, consented to charges filed by the U.S.
attorney's office, a process that usually means a plea agreement will follow.
The mail fraud charge carries a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison, and the
tax evasion charges carries a maximum of five years.

Cook has been in jail since Jan. 25 on civil contempt charges for refusing to
cooperate with a court-appointed receiver who's trying to recover the investors'
assets. Although a prosecutor can't require cooperation in a civil case, Cook is
nevertheless expected to cooperate with the government now as part of any plea
agreement.

The government charged that Cook raised money from more than 1,000 investors by
selling investments in a "purported foreign currency trading program." He
falsely told investors his program would yield annual returns of 10 to 12
percent with little or no risk to principal, the government alleged.

The tax charge against Cook says that in the calendar year 2008, he falsely
omitted $5,285,719 of taxable income, in effect dodging at least $1,844,571 in
taxes.

Pat Kiley, 71, promoted the investment program on his syndicated radio program
called "Follow the Money," which he produced in a home Cook owned in Burnsville.
Kiley's attorney, Peter Wold, declined to comment other than to note that his
client has not been charged.

Cook operated an unlicensed investment advisory business called Oxford Global
Advisors out of the Van Dusen mansion just south of downtown Minneapolis. He
promoted the investment at seminars in the mansion. Jason Bo-Alan Beckman, an
adviser who operates a firm called The Oxford Private Client Group, promoted
equities at the seminars and got "rebates" for referring clients into the
currency investment program.

Other area financial advisers also were drawn into program, including Ed Baker
of Mesa Holdings. A group of investors at Technical Niche Trading had explored a
partnership with Cook until his investment program imploded in July, when some
Ohio investors filed a federal lawsuit in Minneapolis saying he wouldn't return
nearly $5 million they'd invested. At least two Canadian firms, Kingz Capital
Corp. and Tanren Corp., also did business with Cook and his associates.

Neither Beckman nor any of those other financial advisers have been charged.

Investors want justice

Beckman has hired attorneys in Panama and Switzerland to try to recover
investors' funds. "I think that this is a positive first step," he said of
Cook's criminal charges. "We're not going to cease until Cook and all others
involved are brought to justice."

Jack Harper, an attorney with Messerli and Kramer who represents 135 investors
in the alleged scheme, said in an e-mail Tuesday that he and his clients "want
to see Mr. Cook and all others who were involved in this fraud brought to
justice. Further, we hope that the prospect of lengthy incarceration will change
Cook's mind about disclosing the whereabouts of investor funds and/or turning
over these funds to the Receiver."

According to the government, Cook withheld information from investors about the
precarious financial condition of Crown Forex SA, which was supposedly handling
many of the investors' currency accounts. Swiss regulators shut down Crown Forex
last year and forced it into bankruptcy. Swiss trustees are still unwinding the
company's affairs.

The charges say Cook never told investors he lost more than $35 million trading
currencies between July 2006 and the end of August 2009 through a Chicago firm
called PFG.

To keep the investment scheme going, the government says, Cook had account
statements sent to investors that misrepresented their holdings. He also "cause
a purported due diligence letter to be prepared falsely representing that Oxford
Global Advisors had in excess of $4 billion in assets under management and that
all accounts were 100% liquid," the charges say.

Gary Saunders, an attorney in Corona, Calif., wrote the letter. Saunders was a
partner of Cook's in some Panama land developments, including a plan --
interrupted by the government's investigation of Cook --to build that nation's
largest hotel-casino in Panama City.

The Crown Forex account

An attorney with the court-appointed receiver assigned to track down investors'
assets told Chief U.S. District Judge Michael Davis this week that Cook's
various business entities had no books, nor even a general ledger, making it
difficult to substantiate how much money he was managing.

The charges say Cook caused an account to be opened at Associated Bank in the
name of "Crown Forex LLC." That entity was never properly registered to do
business and listed a bogus Minneapolis street address. Kiley and his secretary
were signatories on the account, but the charges say Cook used it "for
depositing investor funds subsequently diverted for his personal use as well as
the personal use of others."

Cook used his investors' money to make interest and principal payments to other
investors, pay personal expenses, including "substantial gambling debts," and to
buy shares in two trading firms and real estate in Panama and the Van Dusen
mansion in Minneapolis, the charges say. The government says he also used some
of the money "in an effort to deceive Swiss banking regulators" about the assets
of Crown Forex SA. Cook reportedly owned just over half of that entity.

Dan Browning - 612-673-4493

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                      December 1, 2000 Friday CITY EDITION

NBA REFEREE FROM AFTON IS CONVICTED OF TAX EVASION

BYLINE: Todd Nelson, Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. 9C

LENGTH: 576 words


A veteran National Basketball Association referee from the Twin Cities was
convicted Thursday of tax evasion for failing to report extra income from
exchanging airline tickets.

Jurors, who began deliberating Tuesday in U.S. District Court in St. Paul,
convicted Ken Mauer, 45, of Afton, of three of four counts of tax evasion and
one count of obstructing an Internal Revenue Service audit.

Mauer was accused of exchanging first-class airline tickets provided by the
league for coach tickets and pocketing the difference without reporting the
extra income on his federal tax returns in 1991, 1992, 1994 and 1995.

Mauer is the first of about a dozen NBA referees who have faced such charges to
be convicted in a jury trial. His hope now is to avoid becoming the first of
those officials to go to prison.

He faces up to three years in prison for obstruction, five years for each tax
evasion count and a $250,000 fine on each count, Assistant U.S. Attorney Patrick
Hogeboom said. Judge Donovan Frank did not schedule a sentencing date.
The NBA suspended Mauer with pay after he was indicted in July, and his going
back to work likely hinges on not going to prison. At least 11 other NBA
officials have pleaded guilty to similar charges. Most paid fines of a few
thousand dollars, were placed on probation and ordered to pay back taxes. The
NBA has since reinstated several of those officials.
"None of the other referees who have been prosecuted have been sent to prison,"
said Mauer's attorney, Peter Thompson of Minneapolis. "I don't believe Judge
Frank will send Ken Mauer to prison."
Thompson said he found the jury's split verdict, acquitting Mauer of one
tax-evasion count, baffling.
"I always felt we were going to win," a disappointed Mauer said after the
verdict. "I don't feel I'm guilty of a criminal act."
Mauer plans to appeal.
"I intend to continue to fight it because I believe I'm innocent," said Mauer,
joined at his trial by fellow NBA referee Steve Javie of Philadelphia, who was
acquitted earlier of separate tax evasion charges, and dozens of family members
and supporters. "That's why I fought it to begin with. ... I intend to referee
in the NBA again."
The practice of downgrading first-class tickets is legal and is allowed under
the collective bargaining agreement between the referees' union and the NBA.
However, the referees are required to report the income.
Javie said the referees who pleaded guilty did so because of extenuating
circumstances, such as not having the resources to mount a legal defense, and
none felt they were guilty of a criminal violation.
In closing arguments this week, prosecutors contended that Mauer worked the
downgrading scheme with an accountant's precision, and knew full well that the
extra income, which helped build what they called an 8,000-square-foot luxury
home, was taxable. Along the way, prosecutors argued, Mauer made incomplete or
false statements to his tax preparers, IRS agents, NBA officials and to jurors
when he testified during his trial.
"The airport was Mr. Mauer's candy store," Hogeboom told jurors. "He was
maximizing the profit."
Thompson argued that Mauer had acted in good faith. Any mistakes Mauer made were
honest, Thompson said, and prosecutors failed to prove that Mauer had willfully
intended to evade taxes and had corruptly impeded the IRS audit.
Todd Nelson can be reached at tanelson@pioneerpress.com or (651) 228-5575.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                             April 9, 2016 Saturday

Former judge kroupa and her husband charged in an indictment.

LENGTH: 277  words


On Monday Former Judge Diane Kroupa and her husband, Robert Fackler, were
charged in an indictment unsealed; report the Minneapolis Star Tribune, Forbes
and the Twin Cities Pioneer Press. A U.S. Tax Court judge who retired in 2014
has been charged with tax evasion. Kroupa and Fackler are charged with
conspiracy, tax evasion, making and subscribing false tax returns, and
obstruction of an Internal Revenue Service audit.

They are accused of claiming nearly $1 million in fraudulent deductions from
2004 to 2010, a period during which Kroupa was a judge. TaxProf Blog links to a
press release announcing the charges.

Prosecutors allege Kroupa and Fackler claimed $500,000 in personal expenses such
as business expenses at Facklers lobbying and political consulting firm and
another $450,000 in business costs for which clients had reimbursed them.

Kroupa and Fackler are also accused of failing to report more than $44,000
received by Kroupa on a 2010 land sale, and of falsely claiming insolvency to
avoid paying tax on a $33,000 canceled debt. Personal expenses that were
deducted included money spent on Pilates classes, spa fees, clothing, home
renovations, a wine club, music lessons and vacations, prosecutors said. He told
the Pioneer Press that he had not yet read the indictment and couldnt comment in
detail. Any indictment is serious, of course, and we will take it seriously, he
said

Kroupa practiced tax law at Faegre & Benson before she became a tax court judge.
Her first appointment was to the Minnesota Tax Court. She was appointed in 2003
to the U.S. Tax Court in Washington, D.C. Tom Brever represents Kroupa and
Fackler. 2016 Legal Monitor Worldwide.
