                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                          November 30, 2011 Wednesday
                                  ROP Edition

BUSINESS IN BRIEF

BYLINE:

Patriot Ledger staff

SECTION: Business; pg. 13

LENGTH: 471 words


Company markets assets of Filene's Basement, Syms Corp.

Hilco Streambank has been picked to sell the Running of the Brides and Filene's
Basement trademarks as part of a liquidation of the assets in the Syms Corp. and
Filene's Basement bankruptcies.

Hilco Streambank has already begun marketing the assets. Bids will be considered
for the complete portfolio of Syms/Filene's Basement brands, as well as for
individual brands. Jack Hazan, executive vice president at Hilco Streambank,
said that both brands have a national presence, even though most of their stores
are east of the Mississippi.

Filene's Basement parent company Syms Corp. began going-out-of-business sales at
its nearly 40 remaining stores Nov. 16.

Get tickets to fly to Dallas for $11 today

Spirit Airlines is offering $11 fares on its website today to promote its new
flights from Logan Airport in Boston to Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport
in Texas. Miramar, Fla.-based Spirit will begin daily flights between the
airports on March 22. Boston will be one of four new markets that Spirit will
serve out of Dallas/Fort Worth.

Sandwich physician guilty of tax evasion

A Sandwich man was sentenced to nine months of home confinement and fined
$20,000 on Tuesday after he pleaded guilty to tax evasion in August.

Federal prosecutors accused Torrey Toltin, 58, of not filing a federal tax
return since 2001 even though he received more than $694,000 in income from 2003
through 2008 as a physician running Sandwich Pediatrics. To ditch the IRS,
Toltin created a bank account in the name of one of his adult children and
deposited revenues from his pediatric practice into that account.

Toltin must wear an electronic monitoring bracelet.

Mortgage trading firm celebrates ruling

Mortgage Electronic Registration Systems Inc., a Virginia-based company whose
controversial system allows for the rapid trading of home mortgages, is
celebrating a Boston federal court ruling that the firm says validates the MERS
system, particularly in foreclosure cases.

U.S. District Court Judge William Young ruled in favor of Aurora Loan Services,
deciding that Aurora had the right to foreclose on a MERS-assigned loan. The
company cited Young's statement that MERS works effectively as a land
registration system.

Braintree company to help end smoking at housing complexes

Peabody Properties Inc. of Braintree is working with building owner Jamaica
Plain Neighborhood Development Corp. to convert six affordable housing complexes
in Jamaica Plain that Peabody manages into smoke-free units.

Peabody, which manages the properties for JPNDC, is using a $20,000 grant from
the Boston Public Health Commission to convert the 238 housing units.
Twenty-five residents identified as smokers will have access to smoking
cessation support at no cost to them. The transition will take effect by Jan. 1.

                                US Official News

                           September 27, 2016 Tuesday

Washington: Maryland Man Sentenced to More Than Four Years in Prison for Tax
Fraud

LENGTH: 459  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



 A Chevy Chase, Maryland, man was sentenced to 54 months in prison today after
pleading guilty to a federal tax evasion charge stemming from his failure to pay
taxes on more than $4.8 million in income that he accrued over a six-year
period, announced Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Caroline D.
Ciraolo, head of the Justice Department's Tax Division, U.S. Attorney Channing
D. Phillips for the District of Columbia and Special Agent in Charge Thomas
Jankowski of the Internal Revenue Service-Criminal Investigation's (IRS-CI)
Washington, D.C. Field Office.





 Cornell M. Jones Jr., 59, pleaded guilty on Jan. 19 to one count of tax evasion
.  According to the government's evidence, Jones was the managing member of WFJ
LLC, a Washington, D.C., company that engaged in real estate transactions.  He
was also the executive director of Miracle Hands, a non-profit organization in
Washington, D.C.  In 2012, the IRS revoked Miracle Hand's tax-exempt status over
its failure to file tax returns for 2009 through 2011.



 The government's evidence showed that neither Jones nor WFJ filed returns for
2008 through 2013.  WFJ generated income through the sale and leasing of
commercial properties in Northeast Washington, D.C., and through payments it
received for consulting work purportedly done by Jones.  Jones used WFJ's income
for his personal benefit, which included more than $1 million in cash that he
withdrew from WFJ bank accounts.  During the years 2008 through 2013, Jones
received approximately $4,806,019.04 in taxable income that he failed to report
to the IRS.  The tax due and owing to the United States on this amount is
approximately $1,759,953.



 In addition to the prison term, U.S. District Judge Richard J. Leon for the
District of Columbia ordered Jones to serve three years of supervised release,
360 hours of community service and pay restitution to the IRS in the amount of
$1,759,953.



 Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo, U.S. Attorney Phillips and
Special Agent in Charge Jankowski thanked special agents of IRS-CI, who
conducted the investigation, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Anthony Saler for the
District of Columbia and Trial Attorney Kenneth C. Vert of the Tax Division, who
prosecuted the case.  Assistance was provided by Assistant U.S. Attorneys David
A. Last, Arvind K. Lal and Michael K. Atkinson; Criminal Investigator Juan
Juarez; Financial Analyst Bryan J. Snitselaar; and Paralegal Specialists C.
Rosalind Pressley and Toni Donato, all of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
District of Columbia.

contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com

             The government's evidence showed that neither Jones nor WFJ filed
returns for 2008 through 2013.  WFJ generated income through the sale and
leasing of commercial properties in Northeast Washington, D.C., and through
payments it received for consulting work purportedly done by Jones.  Jones used
WFJ's income for his personal benefit, which included more than $1 million in
cash that he withdrew from WFJ bank accounts.  During the years 2008 through
2013, Jones received approximately $4,806,019 in taxable income that he failed
to report to the IRS.  The tax due and owing to the United States on this amount
is approximately $1,759,953.

             In addition to the prison term, U.S. District Judge Richard J. Leon
ordered Jones to serve three years of supervised release, perform 360 hours of
community service and pay restitution to the IRS in the amount of $1,759,953.

             U.S. Attorney Phillips, Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General
Ciraolo, and Special Agent in Charge Jankowski thanked special agents of IRS-CI,
who conducted the investigation, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Anthony Saler for
the District of Columbia and Trial Attorney Kenneth C. Vert of the Tax Division,
who prosecuted the case.  Assistance was provided by Assistant U.S. Attorneys
David A. Last, Arvind K. Lal and Michael K. Atkinson; Criminal Investigator Juan
Juarez; Financial Analyst Bryan J. Snitselaar; and Paralegal Specialists C.
Rosalind Pressley and Toni Donato, all of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
District of Columbia.

Former Finance Director of Pit River Tribe Indicted for Tax Evasion, Failure to
File a Tax Return, and Theft from the Pit River Tribe

LENGTH: 335 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Office for the United States Attorneys, Eastern District of California has
issued the following news release:



  Kenley Black, 41, formerly of Burney, California, was arrested today at his
home in Ft. Defiance, Arizona on charges of tax evasion, failure to file income
taxes, and embezzlement and theft from a tribal organization, United States
Attorney Benjamin B. Wagner announced.





 A federal grand jury returned a 25-count indictment on Thursday, March 24,
2016, against Kenley, who served as the the Finance Director for the Pit River
Tribe from 2009 to 2013. Black is not a member of the Pit River Tribe.



 According to court documents, while employed as Finance Director, Black earned
over $810,000 yet did not file income taxes and evaded paying over $225,000 in
taxes. He is charged with five counts of tax evasion and five counts of failure
to file income taxes. Additionally, he is charged with 15 counts of embezzlement
and theft from a tribal organization for embezzling $81,578 from the Pit River
Tribe in 2012 and 2013.



 This case is the product of an investigation by the Federal Bureau of
Investigation and Internal Revenue Service - Criminal Investigation. Assistant
United States Attorney Justin Lee is prosecuting the case.



 If convicted, Black faces a maximum statutory penalty of five years in prison
and a $100,000 fine for each count of tax evasion. Additionally, Black faces up
to one year in prison for each count of failure to file a tax return and up to
five years in prison for each count of theft from a tribal organization. Any
sentence, however, would be determined at the discretion of the court after
consideration of any applicable statutory factors and the Federal Sentencing
Guidelines, which take into account a number of variables. The charges are only
allegations; the defendant is presumed innocent until and unless proven guilty
beyond a reasonable doubt.

Washington: Joe Usher Pleads Guilty to Federal Tax Offenses

LENGTH: 282  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

Zebbie Joe Usher, III, 46, of Knoxville, Tennessee, pleaded guilty on June 2,
2014, in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Tennessee at Knoxville
to a two-count information charging him with tax evasion and conspiracy to
commit tax evasion. The Honorable Pamela L. Reeves, U.S. District Judge,
scheduled a status conference for September 15, 2014, at which time a date for
sentencing will be scheduled.

Usher faces a possible prison term of up to 10 years, along with up to $500,000
in fines and the requirement to pay more than $29 million in restitution to the
Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

Usher was previously the chief executive officer of Service Provider Group and
was involved in the management of a number of companies, known as professional
employer organizations (PEOs), which were engaged in the employee leasing and
payroll processing business. According to a plea agreement on file with the U.S.
District Court in Knoxville, the PEOs collected federal payroll taxes from
employees and were required to turn over those funds to the IRS in a timely
manner. However, instead of doing so, Usher and his unnamed co-conspirators used
the funds for other company expenses and personal expenditures. In an attempt to
avoid discovery of their nonpayment of payroll taxes, Usher and his
co-conspirators submitted false documents to the IRS.

Usher's guilty plea is the result of an ongoing investigation by the IRS and
Federal Bureau of Investigation. Assistant United States Attorney Frank M. Dale,
Jr. represents the United States.

For more information please visit: http://www.fbi.gov

                              Late Edition - Final

U.S. Adding New Wrinkles In Shelter Case

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: Section C; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 701 words


Federal prosecutors overseeing a huge tax shelter case against former employees
of the accounting firm KPMG are seeking to introduce evidence that some of the
defendants received secret payments from three little-known investment
boutiques.

The move by federal prosecutors in Manhattan, outlined in a motion filed on
Friday, is an effort by the government to bolster its complex criminal case
against the 18 defendants, who are scheduled to stand trial in January.

In the filing, prosecutors also disclosed that former accountants at the
investment boutiques -- the now-defunct Chenery Associates of San Francisco; the
Diversified Group of New York; and Gramercy, a hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn. --
are expected to testify on the government's behalf. The prosecutors contend that
the firms have been promoters of aggressive tax shelters.

The accusations in the motion, which seeks the admission of certain ''other
crimes'' evidence, do not represent new charges but rather are intended to
support the charges made in the indictment handed up last year against the
defendants, who include an outside lawyer and an outside investment adviser.

It is unclear when the judge overseeing the case, Lewis A. Kaplan of United
States District Court in Manhattan, will decide whether to admit the evidence.

The 18 were charged last year with conspiring to design and sell four types of
illegitimate tax shelters that allowed hundreds of wealthy investors to evade at
least $2.5 billion in taxes from 1996 to 2002. Some of the defendants are also
charged with evasion of personal income taxes stemming from their shelter work.

Lawyers for the defendants, who include a former vice chairman of KPMG and a
former chief financial officer, among other senior executives, say that their
clients acted within the law.

The new filing shows how prosecutors are focusing not on the technical merits of
the complex tax shelters in question but rather on income tax evasion, among
other things.

A focus for prosecutors is Raymond J. Ruble, an outside lawyer who is charged
with one count of conspiracy and 43 counts of tax evasion, including receipt of
secret side payments totaling $4.8 million from 1998 through 2001. Prosecutors
now contend that Mr. Ruble, a pivotal figure in the case, also evaded taxes in
1996 and 1997, taking additional, previously undisclosed side payments from
Chenery and the Diversified Group. Accountants from those two firms are expected
to testify about the payments at trial, the government papers said.

The prosecution's filing also contained new assertions concerning previously
unknown or little-known aggressive tax shelters sold by the defendants and
known, as listed in the filing, as Permian Mud, Zens and triple bypass.
Prosecutors contend that with Chenery, Mr. Ruble helped sell Zens to a Northern
Marianas entity known as the United Micronesia Development Corporation around
1997.

They contend further that another defendant, Robert Pfaff, a former KPMG
partner, took $2.5 million in side payments from Chenery and the Diversified
Group, among others, for work promoting tax shelters. According to the filing,
Mr. Pfaff used a Philippine resident to set up secret offshore bank accounts to
filter his tax shelter income to his country club, landscaper, contractor,
children's trusts, art galleries and car dealerships, in a scheme called Somer
Leasing. The Philippine resident is now a government witness.

Lawyers for Mr. Ruble and Mr. Pfaff did not return calls seeking comment late
yesterday.

Prosecutors contend that a third defendant, Carl Hastings. took previously
undisclosed side payments from Gramercy for shelters sold with KPMG that
involved distressed debt.

A fourth defendant. David Greenberg, a former KPMG partner in Los Angeles who
remains in jail after failing to post $20 million bail, is now also accused of
selling an aggressive tax shelter known as triple bypass to the boss of a
defendant, Gregg Ritchie, another former KPMG tax partner, when Mr. Ritchie
later worked at the Pacific Capital Group. Pacific Capital was founded by Gary
Winnick, the founder of Global Crossing.

Lawyers for Mr. Hastings and Mr. Greenberg declined to comment yesterday.

                    August 22, 2003 Friday National Edition

'King' of N.Y. clubs sent back to Canada: 'He is a free man. He is not a felon.
At least he is not someone who is a danger to the community': Convicted of tax
evasion

SOURCE: National Post

BYLINE: Julie Smyth

SECTION: News; Crime and Punishment; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 777 words

Peter Gatien, a legendary club owner who has run some of Manhattan's most famous
bars, is being deported back to Canada after being convicted of tax evasion.

At the height of his career, Mr. Gatien, who left the small Ontario town of
Cornwall for the bright lights of New York, had 50,000 customers packing his
popular discos, the Tunnel, the Palladium and the Limelight, every week. At its
lowest, he was charged with drug conspiracy and racketeering over allegations
two of his clubs were being run as "virtual ecstasy supermarkets," faced
bankruptcy and served jail time for his tax conviction.

His trendy bars became the centre of attention when a colleague was convicted of
bludgeoning a regular club-goer to death over a drug debt.

Mr. Gatien, 50, was cleared of all racketeering and drug-related charges but in
1999, pleaded guilty to skimming US$1.3-million in taxes from his business.
Lawyers for the U.S. government argued this amounted to a felony fraud and
grounds for sending him out of the country.

On Wednesday, Mr. Gatien, who faced months of detention while his deportation
hearing played out in the courts, agreed in a New York court to return to
Canada. He will be in a Pennsylvania facility for the next few days until he is
sent across the border.

However, those close to Mr. Gatien say it will not be long before the man whose
lifestyle epitomized the New York party scene in the '80s and '90s is back in
business -- this time working out lucrative television and book deals and making
movies and a television series.

"He has many irons in the fire," Steven Weinberg, his lawyer, said in an
interview yesterday from his New York office.

"He's a free man. He is not a felon. At least he is not someone who is a danger
to the community. He would be free to be in Canada and do what he wanted."

He hinted a reality television series could be in the offing.

"Peter has a lot of ideas. He is a very talented man and he will come up on his
feet." Mr. Gatien has been quoted in the New York press saying he is working on
a television show about a nightclub, which he described as "Moulin Rouge meets
Cheers with a little Sex and the City thrown in."

Another one of his lawyers, Benjamin Brafman, was quoted yesterday saying he is
in negotiations to sell the rights to his life story to "some very prominent
people in the entertainment industry." Mr. Brafman did not return calls
yesterday.

In past interviews, Mr. Gatien has indicated he is fed up with the nightclub
business and is keen to get back into movies. Throughout his colourful career,
he has dabbled in magazines, owned a record label and produced a film, A Bronx
Tale, which was directed by Robert De Niro.

He is set to be the centre of a new film, titled Pursuit of Pleasure, based on
his life with his daughter, Jennifer, a filmmaker. It is being produced by the
company owned by Akiva Goldsman, the Oscar-winning screenwriter of A Beautiful
Mind. Keanu Reeves, Sean Penn and Ralph Fiennes have been tipped as potential
stars to play Mr. Gatien.

Mr. Gatien's American wife, Alessandra, and his children are expected to join
him in Canada, leaving behind their expensive apartment and high-living
lifestyle in New York. It is not clear where they will live.

When the National Post contacted his relatives in Cornwall, they declined to
comment and promptly hung up the phone.

Mr. Gatien, the son of a postman, began his empire with a $17,000 insurance
payment he received after losing his eye in a Junior A hockey game. He invested
the money in a jeans store in Cornwall, then sold that business to open a
nightclub in town, the Aardvark, reputed to be the meeting place for a local
chapter of the Outlaws motorcycle gang. He then headed for America, buying a
club in Hollywood, Fla.

In the early 1980s, he opened his first New York nightclub. As he rose to fame,
the tabloids named him the "King of Clubs."

In the book Clubland: The Fabulous Rise and Murderous Fall of Club Culture by
Frank Owen, published this year and excerpted in the National Post, Mr. Owen
describes being in the Limelight, one of Manhattan's best-known clubs during the
1990s.

From inside the bar, which had earlier housed an Episcopal church, he details
scenes of comatose partygoers, customers opening vials of white power on to
small mirrors and wildly dressed drag queens.

In the book, he describes Mr. Gatien's "crack-cocaine benders with $1,000-a
night prostitutes" adding that, in the press, he often came across as a
respectable entrepreneur and "clean-living family man" who took his children to
Disney World and went sailing at his country estate in Ontario.

                            August 23, 1994, Tuesday

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

SECTION: EDITORIAL, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 666 words


TRUCKERS FIGHT

FUEL TAX EVASION

I am writing in regard to your Aug. 11 article, "US Steps Up Its Efforts vs.
Motor Fuel Tax Cheats" (Page 3B).

The subject, a congressional hearing held the day before on the evasion of
federal and state fuel taxes, was a worthy one, but the article contained a
glaring inaccuracy that should not pass without correction.

Fuel tax evasion has been recognized for a decade as a serious problem
nationwide. The motor carrier industry has been an active supporter of the joint
federal and state efforts to combat it, which were described at the hearing. The
trucking industry, like all highway users, is a victim of fuel tax evasion,
which robs government of much needed road funding.

No one familiar with the problems of fuel tax evasion attributes the problem to
motor carriers, who are only rarely involved in such schemes and who rarely
benefit from them, directly or indirectly. Instead, the evasion commonly occurs
at various levels in the chain of fuel distribution, long before the product is
consumed on the road.

The federal officials who testified at the hearing did not blame truckers,
either explicitly or implicitly, nor did the state officials who testified, nor
did the petroleum industry witnesses. You unwittingly indicted the wrong
parties.

Robert C. Pitcher

Director, Dept. of State Laws

American Trucking Associations

Alexandria, Va.  WHY MARITIME

REFORM IS NEEDED

The House of Representatives has passed H.R. 4003 providing for the funding of
maritime reform. The Senate must follow through and pass S. 1945, a companion
bill. Failure to do so will result in a rapid decline of U.S. flag vessels
engaged in the foreign trades.

Specifically, failure to pass such legislation will:

* See the current fleet of 199 vessels decline to 77 vessels by Dec. 31, 1998, a
decline of 61 percent.

* See current billets (jobs) numbering 4,957 decline to 1,812, a decline of 63
percent.

* See seamen employed, assuming 2.5 seamen per billet (the industry standard),
decline from 12,393 to 4,530, a decline of 63.4 percent.

These declines are based on the following conditions:

* Maritime reform fails to pass.

* Phaseout of current Operating Differential Subsidy contracts.

* Announced reflagging of certain vessels.

* Construction Differential Subsidy-built vessels scrapped when CDS restrictions
expire.

* Military Sealift Command charters are maintained at current levels.

* Cargo preference laws maintained.

In closing, national pride, the economic defense of the country and military
defense of the country dictate that the presence of the American flag in the
foreign trades is paramount.

Capt. Warren G. Leback

Princeton, N.J.  DON'T PREACH TO THE

DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

In his Aug. 10 opinion piece, "Stopping Dominican Vote Fraud" (Page 8A), Andrew
Reding expands on a current Washington theme of arrogant self- righteousness. He
proposes that President Clinton ask for new Dominican elections and replacement
of the current Dominican Electoral Board.

Mr. Reding obviously believes the United States has a right to tell other
democracies how to run their internal affairs. The Dominican Republic is a
friendly democracy. The United States helped it to become one. Washington
financed its transition from dictatorship to democracy, even sending in the
military to assure the transition.

Now some observers claim vote fraud in the last presidential election. As a
Chicagoan of many decades, that claim is very familiar. In Chicago almost every
election is categorized as "fraud" by the losing party. But we do not entertain
recommendations by powers outside Chicago (state, federal or foreign) that we
hold another election.

With massive, entrenched problems in our own country, self-appointed experts in
academia should focus on solving America's problems, and stop insisting on how
our friendly, democratic neighbors should solve theirs.

William E. Kentor

Highland Park, Ill.

                                 FINAL EDITION

RAPE CHARGE LATEST OF TAYLOR'S TROUBLES

BYLINE: Palm Beach Post Wire Services

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2C

LENGTH: 435 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Thanks to Lawrence Taylor, such phrases as the blind side and strip-sacks became
part of football's vernacular. Offensive coordinators built game plans around
slowing the New York Giants linebacker down. Rarely did those tactics work.

He was one of the NFL's greatest players and became a first-ballot member of the
Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1999.

The only point of contention at the time: his off-field behavior.

While Taylor's arrest Thursday for third-degree rape and patronizing a
prostitute stands as the most shocking of his run-ins with the law, it is only
the latest. The list of charges he's faced, from drug cases to tax evasion,
dates back more than two decades to his playing career and includes several
recent entries. Taylor has been cited three times in Florida over the last six
months alone for infractions on the road.

Taylor's lifestyle already was an issue when he was still playing. In 1988, he
tested positive for cocaine and was suspended for 30 days by the NFL. Even
before then, there were whispers throughout the league that Taylor had a drug
problem, and that Bill Parcells, then the Giants coach and now the Dolphins'
executive vice president of football operations, weeded out any such players
except for LT after the 1983 season.

Taylor also was charged with criminal property damage in 1991 for allegedly
damaging a taxi in Honolulu. Five years later, he was arrested for buying crack
cocaine from an undercover officer in South Carolina. Two years after that,
Taylor was charged with the same crime in Florida. He has been arrested for
failure to pay child support and for tax evasion, and also has filed for
bankruptcy.

The off-field issues certainly were raised 11 years ago when Taylor became
eligible for the Hall, and several voters said they wouldn't even consider him.

Taylor, now 51, admitted to paying for sex at a suburban Holiday Inn where
police say he raped a 16-year-old runaway, federal prosecutors said Friday in a
criminal complaint against the girl's alleged pimp.

Authorities claim the Pro Football Hall of Famer told police following his
arrest Thursday that he had taken a car service from Newark International
Airport to the hotel north of New York City to meet "Victim-1."

Taylor told investigators that after "engaging in sex acts" with the victim, he
paid her $300 in cash, the complaint says. The man charged in the complaint,
Rasheed Davis, had told the Giants legend that the girl was 19, the court papers
say.

Houston: Texans linebacker Brian Cushing has been suspended four games without
pay for violating the NFL's policy on performance-enhancing substances.

                             May 27, 2009 Wednesday

ONE 'HEL' OF A RIDE FOR INDY 500 CHAMP

BYLINE: DAVID SATRIANO

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 77

LENGTH: 372 words


What a difference a month makes.

In April, IndyCar Series driver Helio Castroneves was on trial for six counts of
tax evasion for allegedly failing to report about $5 million of income to the
IRS from 1999 through 2004, unsure if he would face jail time or ever race
again. But when the news came on April 17 that he was acquitted of all tax
evasion charges - and a final count of conspiracy was dropped last Friday - it
was a huge relief to the Brazilian star.

"The whole month of May, everything was falling into place," Castroneves said
yesterday while celebrating his Indianapolis 500 victory at an event outside
Radio City Music Hall. "Certainly it will be a month I will never ever forget
and a year I will never ever forget."

On April 19, two days after his trial ended, Castroneves returned to the
racetrack. He finished seventh in the Toyota Grand Prix in Long Beach, Calif. A
week later, he finished in second place, followed by Sunday's third career
Indianapolis 500 triumph.

"I never thought about my career or never racing," Castroneves said. "I thought
maybe I'll have a pause in my career, but certainly I'll come back stronger. The
good news is, I only missed one race and I definitely came back stronger."

He led 66 laps of the Indy 500, including the first seven, after starting from
the pole position. After he regained the lead on lap 142 (of 200), he did not
relinquish it the rest of the race.

"As soon as I took the lead, I was just like, 'I don't wanna be second or third
anymore,' " Castroneves said. "Definitely the car was working up front, and the
team did a hell of a job to work and make everything great for me."

Castroneves said his third Indianapolis 500 victory felt very different from the
previous two.

"To win Indy is very special, and each one I have a great memory from it, but
the third one for me, after everything that happened in my life and my family
going through that as well, certainly has a different taste," he said. "I'm so
grateful for everything that's happened. The only message that I have to say
when I was in the down time, I never lost faith."

After collecting over $3 million in prize money from the race, you can bet
Castroneves will report those winnings to the IRS.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                               May 8, 2006 Monday
                                 SECOND EDITION

More problems for Polk: Law license may be taken

BYLINE: By Peter Shinkle ST. LOUIS POST-DISPATCH

SECTION: METRO; Pg. C5

LENGTH: 838 words


For a man who has made his living as a high-profile lawyer, it may be the
toughest blow yet.

Charles E. Polk Jr., who pleaded guilty last month to federal charges related to
tax evasion and fraud, appears near to losing his law license.

The Missouri Supreme Court gave him until May 16 to show why it should not
suspend the license Polk used to represent municipal governments and private
clients, work for high-powered firms, and ultimately commit fraud against the
Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District.

His attorney, Scott Rosenblum, said, "Mr. Polk is planning to surrender his
license with the hope to reapply at some later date."

Meanwhile, the United Way of Greater St. Louis is still conducting its review of
Cheryl Polk, his wife, who is a top official at the agency and became involved
in one of her husband's business ventures that led to criminal charges against
him.

Lisa Richter, spokeswoman for the charity, said the review continues. "To date,
there has been no indication that the legal matters involving Charles Polk have
any connection to Cheryl's work at the United Way," she said.

Prosecutors claim that Charles Polk failed to file income tax returns and
avoided paying $470,000 owed from 1998 to 2002.

Asked whether Cheryl Polk filed taxes jointly or separately from her husband,
Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Reap, the prosecutor on the case, declined to
comment. Rosenblum also declined to comment on whether she filed separately but
said prosecutors have indicated that Cheryl Polk is not a target of their probe.

Richter, the United Way spokeswoman, said she does not know the tax information
of Cheryl Polk, whose annual salary as chief operating officer was recently
reported at $168,420.

"Like many employers, the United Way doesn't ask for, and doesn't have,
employees' personal tax information," she said.

Charles Polk, 45, of St. Charles, pleaded guilty April 24 to charges he
defrauded MSD of $45,190 when he was its general counsel. He also pleaded guilty
to a tax evasion charge. He will be sentenced in U.S. District Court in St.
Louis on Aug. 31.

The Office of Chief Disciplinary Counsel, which enforces rules of professional
conduct for lawyers, asked for suspension of Polk's license because of his
pleas. It has been called to examine Polk's conduct before.

In 2002, Polk and a businessman launched a plan to win government compensation
for families of Oklahoma City bombing victims. But some Oklahomans complained
that Polk was using his relationship with John Ashcroft, then U.S. attorney
general, to impress potential clients.

Then another participant in the Oklahoma City venture, St. Louis attorney Doug
Dowd, announced he would drop out and file a complaint that Polk violated the
code of conduct by agreeing to split legal fees with a nonlawyer. No
disciplinary action resulted.

Ultimately, the federal indictment against Polk claimed that as part of the
Oklahoma City effort, he stole from his law firm at the time, Lathrop & Gage,
the $382,000 that the businessman invested in 2002.

The businessman, James Helenthal, paid $250,000 into a brokerage account owned
jointly by the Polks, and wrote a check for $132,000 to Cheryl Polk with a note
saying, "Martha's Vineyard/Cheryl," the indictment said. The couple owned a
vacation home on the Massachusetts island of Martha's Vineyard.

Charles Polk has pleaded not guilty to a charge related to the Oklahoma City
venture, and it is expected to be dismissed. Cheryl Polk was not named in the
criminal case.

But Helenthal filed a civil suit against the Polks, alleging fraud, and a St.
Louis County Circuit judge recently ordered the couple to pay him $3.6 million.

MSD case

The MSD plea came as vindication to Terry Follmer. While Polk was hobnobbing
with movers and shakers in Washington, Follmer was a little-known auditor at
MSD.

In 2003, after Follmer questioned Polk's handling of $318,000 in checks issued
by MSD, Polk charged that Follmer was conducting a "witch hunt" targeting
minority firms. Polk, who is black, denounced Follmer, who is white, for
pursuing a "misappropriation conspiracy theory involving blacks and MSD."

Follmer made reference to the Mexican woman he intended to marry and retorted,
"Anyone who tries to play the minority-race card against me is full of bunk."

For Follmer, now married to the woman and living in Chicago, Polk's plea has
brought a measure of satisfaction. But he also worries that taxpayers paid the
cost of the prolonged investigation and litigation.

"It's a lose-lose situation," he said. "There's not a happy ending for anybody.
"

Lance LeComb, an MSD spokesman, said the agency worked closely with the federal
investigation of Polk's dealings, and that it has recovered all but $30,000 of
the missing money.

Since Polk left his post as outside general counsel in 2000, MSD has hired new
auditors, set up new internal controls and implemented recommendations of two
state audits, LeComb said.

"The district is a different place than it was when Charles Polk was here," he
said. "It's a new day at the district."

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              June 20, 2003 Friday

United States

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: THE WALL STREET JOURNAL; What's News; Pg. B6

The federal tax-evasion case against former Tyco International Ltd. chief
financial officer Mark Swartz is likely to be dismissed, after federal
prosecutors in New Hampshire concluded they had filed the case in the wrong
court. William Morse, the assistant U.S. attorney handling the case in Concord,
N.H., said prosecutors had some concerns about proving that an "affirmative act
of tax evasion" had taken place in New Hampshire. Mr. Morse said the government
intends to reindict Mr. Swartz in another federal court, perhaps in Florida,
where the former Tyco finance chief lived and filed his tax returns, or Georgia,
which is the location of the Internal Revenue Service office where Mr. Swartz's
returns were sent.

                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                           January 19, 2006 Thursday

The Barrett report

BYLINE: Robert Novak

LENGTH: 633 words


WASHINGTON

The long-awaited final report by Independent Counsel David Barrett, to be
released today, was severely censored by court order but not enough to
sufficiently obscure its importance. As long forecast, it alleges serious
corruption in the Clinton administration's Justice Department and Internal
Revenue Service. The question is what was contained in 120 pages removed by the
judges.

These allegations explain why Barrett finally has closed down after 10 years the
last prosecution under the lapsed independent counsel statute. Its target, Henry
Cisneros, long ago resigned as secretary of Housing and Urban Development in a
plea bargain after admitting he lied to FBI interrogators to gain Senate
confirmation. What kept Barrett in business was what he and his prosecutors
contend is a Clinton administration cover-up of income tax evasion charges
against Cisneros.

Not only Barrett's stubbornness but also a tip from an IRS whistle-blower in San
Antonio, Texas, meant the case did not end with Cisneros' personal disgrace. But
for now, the cover-up has succeeded. No tax prosecution was brought against
Cisneros, and IRS conduct has not been questioned. Friends describe Barrett, a
Republican lawyer from Washington, as feeling that he has failed fully to
uncover the scandal and that it is now up to Congress to get out the truth.

This probably would have been just another undiscovered scandal had the whistle
not been blown by John J. Filan, chief of the IRS's Criminal Investigation
Division in the South Texas District. In a March 31, 1997, memo, Filan expressed
outrage that the IRS chief counsel's office in Washington on Jan. 15 had pulled
a tax evasion case out of San Antonio because it required "centralized review."
Filan wrote: "I am not aware of any other criminal tax cases that have been
pulled from experienced District Counsel attorneys."

With the case now in Washington, the IRS declined to prosecute. In a second memo
on April 25, Filan said IRS Assistant Chief Counsel Barry Finkelstein's
conclusions "are just plain wrong." Payments to Cisneros' former mistress and
money spent for other purposes exceeded declared income, said the
whistle-blower, and "clearly proves Cisneros knowingly and willingly signed and
filed false and fraudulent income tax returns" for 1991, 1992 and 1993.

That launched Barrett on four frustrating years of attempting tax evasion
prosecution in the face of Attorney General Janet Reno's obstructions. Permitted
by Reno to focus on only one year, the independent counsel could not make the
case of extended tax evasion.

Nevertheless, the question remains what the three senior federal appellate
judges with supervising authority over the independent counsel -- David Sentelle
(D.C.), Thomas Reavley (Texas) and Peter Fay (Florida) -- blacked out in 120
pages worth of redactions. Barrett and his lawyers would face judicial sanctions
if they disclosed anything that was redacted.

However, the judges have established an exception, or rather 535 exceptions, to
the rule that nobody can see what has been redacted. Any member of Congress can
read it merely by asking. Any such lawmaker who believes American taxpayers
should see the product of $23 million in expenditures presumably could then
publish the material without fear of legal sanction.

But will any senator or House member do it? Nobody is interested in further
prosecution of Henry Cisneros, an exceptional public figure who might well have
become the first Hispanic-American governor of Texas and perhaps even president
of the United States. Rather, an unredacted Barrett report is an opportunity to
observe how the Internal Revenue Service decides when to prosecute, a place
where Congress until now has feared to venture.

Robert Novak is a columnist for the Chicago Sun-Times.

                    SEPTEMBER 19, 1997 Friday SFCITY EDITION

MAN SENTENCED FOR TAX EVASION / THE FORMER OWNER OF 31 AREA CHECK-CASHING
CENTERS WILL PAY MORE THAN $4 MILLION IN TAXES AND PENALTIES.

BYLINE: Julia C. Martinez, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: CITY & REGION; Pg. B04

LENGTH: 329 words


The stealing started when he was a youngster who slipped a candy bar into his
pocket without paying for it, a weeping Adrian Rubin told a federal judge
yesterday as the former owner of Happy's Check Cashing Agency was about to be
sentenced for tax evasion.

It continued until recently, when he was caught slipping $4.4 million in income
past Uncle Sam to avoid paying $1.4 million in taxes, Rubin said.

Rubin, who owned 31 check-cashing centers in and around Philadelphia, was
sentenced to a year and a month in federal prison for what Assistant U.S.
Attorney Paul Sarmousakis called one of the largest tax evasion schemes ever
recorded in the country for a small business owner.

Rubin agreed to reimburse the IRS more than $4 million in back taxes, interest
and penalties and forfeit $263,974 for failure to file a currency transaction
report.

Rubin pleaded guilty in May to conspiracy to defraud the United States, six
counts of tax evasion, and failure to file the currency report.

Sarmousakis said Rubin has sold the check-cashing agencies and would use some of
the proceeds to pay his debt to the IRS. He has also relinquished interest in
cash and gold and silver bars seized in 1994 from his Montgomery County home.

During a lengthy discourse before U.S. District Judge Jan E. DuBois, Rubin said
there were many candy bar-type instances leading up to the tax evasion.

In addition to not reporting income between 1984 and 1994, Rubin induced Happy's
employees to accept part or all of their wages in cash, so he could avoid paying
payroll taxes.

Rubin, 39, of Huntingdon Valley, had been under investigation for several months
before charges were filed against him this spring. Convinced that he would be
charged and sent to prison, he surrendered to authorities in January and began
serving a voluntary prison sentence. The eight months he has served so far will
be applied to his sentence, along with time off for good behavior.

                              The Washington Post

                   February 09, 1995, Thursday, Final Edition

State Urged to Pull Educator's License; Board Votes on Counselor in Tax Evasion
Case

SECTION: Weekly - Virginia; Pg. V01

LENGTH: 716 words


The Alexandria School Board has recommended that the Virginia Board of Education
suspend the teaching license of James E. McClure, the former guidance director
at T.C. Williams High School who served 60 days in jail last year for tax
evasion.

If the state panel agrees, McClure likely could not be a guidance counselor or
teacher in Virginia. Currently, McClure, 55, of Springfield, is assigned to the
school system's central administrative offices.

The School Board's unanimous vote Feb. 2 followed a closed session two weeks
earlier, during which more than 25 people spoke in support of McClure, according
to school system and community sources.

At the closed meeting, sources say, Acting Superintendent Maxine J. Wood
recommended that McClure's teaching license be revoked. A motion to send that
recommendation to state education officials gained three votes instead of the
five needed to pass, sources say. A motion to urge a four-year suspension of the
teaching license passed, also on a split vote.

Last Thursday, in open session, the board unanimously affirmed the proposed
suspension, without specifically identifying McClure. Some members of the
audience booed board members after the vote was taken.

One shouted, "That stinks," and another said, "That was a bad move," as the two
and about 20 others walked out of the board meeting. School Board Chairman V.
Rodger Digilio responded, "I think that's out of order."

McClure's fate has been a sometimes emotional issue since last April, when he
was charged with several counts of federal tax evasion. In June, he pleaded
guilty to one count of felony tax evasion and began serving a 60-day jail
sentence.

His supporters say that he has been punished enough and that he should be
allowed to return to T.C. Williams, where he ran the guidance department for two
decades before being reassigned last spring. Some School Board members say it
would send a bad message to young people if he is reinstated at the high school.

McClure's lawyer, Gregory L. Murphy, said McClure will issue no public comment
on the status of his teaching license while the matter is under review. Murphy
said McClure has not decided whether to contest the proposed suspension with
state officials.

"Jim does not want to do something that is not in the community's best
interest," Murphy said. "He doesn't want to create a distraction or make it more
difficult for the new superintendent and the new School Board."

State and local authorities say that if a teaching license is suspended in
Virginia, it is reinstated automatically at the end of the suspension period.
McClure will be eligible for retirement about the time the suspension ends if
the state upholds the local recommendation, officials say.

However, state officials say they are not bound by the local board's
recommendation. They must hold at least one closed hearing on McClure's fate,
but they can impose a less severe or a more severe penalty, said Thomas Elliott,
chief for compliance of the state Department of Education.

Elliott said the state Board of Education normally takes up proposed license
revocations and suspensions quarterly, so it is possible that final action on
McClure's license won't be taken until late spring.

Murphy said he hopes that state officials will "listen to the voice of the
community" when ruling on the license question. He noted that former Alexandria
superintendent Paul W. Masem was among the people who testified on McClure's
behalf before the local School Board.

Several School Board members have said that they would be sending the wrong
message to students if McClure were allowed to return to T.C. Williams.

Pat Hennig, one of three School Board members from the city's West End, said
McClure backers who shouted at board members last week should be aware that
state laws and regulations make it difficult for convicted felons to retain
teaching or guidance positions.

Regardless of the outcome in Richmond, sources say, McClure has no guarantee
that he will have a school system job indefinitely. After working on a series of
projects in the central administration, McClure will be given duties that are
related to guidance counseling but that do not involve direct contact with
individual students, officials say.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     March 30, 1989, Thursday, City Edition

Grand jury indicts lawyer on tax evasion charges

BYLINE: BRUCE VIELMETTI

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; Pg. 10B

LENGTH: 512 words

DATELINE: TAMPA



TAMPA - Tampa defense lawyer Frank Ragano was indicted Wednesday by    a federal
grand jury on charges of tax evasion and obstruction of    justice. It is the
third time Ragano has faced tax charges.

     The indictment charges Ragano, 64, with underreporting his and his
wife's income by more than $ 107,000 on joint tax returns for the years    1982
and 1983. In 1982, according to the indictment, Ragano reported an    income of
$ 8,373, when he knew he actually had income of $ 91,620. That    amounted to a
savings of more than $ 24,000 in taxes owed to the    government, the indictment
alleges.

     A second count charges that in 1984, Ragano filed a joint tax    return
reporting income of $ 38,354, when the couple's actual income was    $ 62,864,
resulting in a tax shortage of more than $ 10,000.

     Two additional counts of the indictment charge Ragano with    obstructing
an investigation into the matter in late 1986 and early    1987, and with
obstructing a federal grand jury in November 1987 by    causing a witness to
give a false written statement that some of    Ragano's income was actually a
loan from the witness.

     Ragano is known for defending such high-profile clients as former
Teamster boss Jimmy Hoffa and the late Santo Trafficante.

     In a news release, Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman credited    IRS
special agents and Special Attorney Kevin R. March of the Miami    Strike
Force's Tampa office for investigating the case.

     Ragano did not return a telephone call to his office Wednesday.

     Ragano has faced similar charges before.

     In 1972, a federal court jury acquitted Ragano of tax evasion on    his
1967 return but convicted him of making a false statement. An    appeals court
later threw out the conviction.

     In 1973, Ragano was indicted again, on charges of conspiracy, tax
evasion and making false statements in connection with his 1967 and    1968
returns, and was later convicted.

     In 1974, the Florida Bar wanted Ragano suspended because of the
conviction, but the Florida Supreme Court refused. The Bar charged that    the
court overlooked its own ethics code when it relied on character    references
from six Hillsborough judges. Among the judges who wrote in    support of Ragano
was Arden Mays Merckle, whom Ragano later defended    when Merckle was charged
with taking bribes.

     A year later, after an appeals court upheld Ragano's 1974    conviction,
the Supreme Court did suspend Ragano. He was reinstated in    1981, over the
Bar's objection, but was given a new three-month    suspension for professional
misconduct in a 1970 divorce case.

     Ragano sued Time magazine in 1966 after the magazine published a    photo
of him and Trafficante, along with several other men, in a    restaurant. The
caption identified the group as "top Cosa Nostra    hoodlums." Ragano lost the
lawsuit.

                                US Official News

                          September 29, 2016 Thursday

Maryland Man Sentenced to More Than Four Years in Prison for Tax Fraud

LENGTH: 464  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, District of Columbia has
issued the following news release:



  A Chevy Chase, Maryland man was sentenced to 54 months in prison today after
pleading guilty to a federal tax evasion charge stemming from his failure to pay
taxes on more than $4.8 million in income that he accrued over a six-year
period, announced U.S. Attorney Channing D. Phillips, Principal Deputy Assistant
Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo, head of the Justice Department's Tax
Division, and Special Agent in Charge Thomas Jankowski of the Internal Revenue
Service-Criminal Investigation's (IRS-CI) Washington, D.C. Field Office.





             Cornell M. Jones Jr., 59, pleaded guilty on Jan 19 to one count of
tax evasion.  According to the government's evidence, Jones was the managing
member of WFJ LLC, a Washington, D.C. company that engaged in real estate
transactions.  He was also the executive director of Miracle Hands, a non-profit
organization in Washington, D.C.  In 2012, the IRS revoked Miracle Hand's
tax-exempt status over its failure to file tax returns for 2009 through 2011.



             The government's evidence showed that neither Jones nor WFJ filed
returns for 2008 through 2013.  WFJ generated income through the sale and
leasing of commercial properties in Northeast Washington, D.C., and through
payments it received for consulting work purportedly done by Jones.  Jones used
WFJ's income for his personal benefit, which included more than $1 million in
cash that he withdrew from WFJ bank accounts.  During the years 2008 through
2013, Jones received approximately $4,806,019 in taxable income that he failed
to report to the IRS.  The tax due and owing to the United States on this amount
is approximately $1,759,953.



             In addition to the prison term, U.S. District Judge Richard J. Leon
ordered Jones to serve three years of supervised release, perform 360 hours of
community service and pay restitution to the IRS in the amount of $1,759,953.



             U.S. Attorney Phillips, Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General
Ciraolo, and Special Agent in Charge Jankowski thanked special agents of IRS-CI,
who conducted the investigation, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Anthony Saler for
the District of Columbia and Trial Attorney Kenneth C. Vert of the Tax Division,
who prosecuted the case.  Assistance was provided by Assistant U.S. Attorneys
David A. Last, Arvind K. Lal and Michael K. Atkinson; Criminal Investigator Juan
Juarez; Financial Analyst Bryan J. Snitselaar; and Paralegal Specialists C.
Rosalind Pressley and Toni Donato, all of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
District of Columbia.

                                The Denver Post

                           February 11, 2016 Thursday
                              THU REGIONAL Edition

Jury convicts Ore. man who netted $3.5M

BYLINE: David Migoya

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 13A

LENGTH: 491 words


An Oregon man was convicted Tuesday of orchestrating an elaborate scheme that
exploited Colorado's flawed conservation easement program and allowed him to
pocket about $3.5 million.

Alan DeAtley, 60, of Medford, Ore., was convicted in Denver District Court on 22
charges that included forgery, theft and tax evasion, as well as one count
related to organized crime.

DeAtley, who was acquitted on three charges of tax evasion, faces up to 100
years in prison. He is scheduled for sentencing on April 7.

His victims include auto dealer John Medved, several real estate developers, and
Sheri and Richard Schmelzer, the inventors of Jibbitz, the charms that fit into
the holes of Crocs shoes.

The scheme wrapped around the early days of Colorado's conservation easement
program in which landowners donated property in return for tax credits they
could use to pay state income tax liabilities. The land would be protected from
future development. The tax credits could be sold if a landowner chose not to
use them.

DeAtley and two other men were accused of manipulating easement values and
selling tax credits that never existed.

The men allegedly purchased a 506 acre spread in Walden for $130,000, then
divided the property between 15 straw companies, according to their 2010
indictment.

Richard Davis and David Zamzow were charged under the same indictment. Charges
against Davis were dismissed. Zamzow pleaded guilty to a forgery charge, was
given a deferred sentence and the charge later dismissed, prosecutors said.

DeAtley was able to pull off the scheme by forging the signature of Kermit
Allard on appraisal documents that inflated the value of the land. Prosecutors
said Allard, the brother of former U.S. Sen. Wayne Allard, was certified to
appraise items related to business sales and divorces, not land for conservation
easement purposes.

Then, using the bogus appraisals that inflated the value of the partitioned
properties to more than $19 million, DeAtley brokered the tax credits to
unsuspecting buyers, who in turn used the credits against their own tax returns.

In several cases, DeAtley sold additional credits on property whose tax credits
had already been sold to other taxpayers, then pocketed the profits.

The Colorado Department of Revenue would not honor the credits the victims used,
saying the fraud was the result of a private transaction. About 20 families were
duped and all have been forced to pay the original $3.5 million in tax
obligations some nearly a decade after the fact. Several sued the state and
those cases are pending.

"It's beyond frustrating, not just that the man who scammed them got their
money, but the department of revenue still gets to collect," assistant district
attorney Joe Morales said. "They have to go to (DeAtley) to be refunded. That's
the law. But we found no money. All of it had been transferred around so much
that it's all gone."

David Migoya: 303 954 1506, dmigoya@denverpost.com or @davidmigoya

                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                           December 14, 2013 Saturday

Pair in IRS inquiry sell Manasota Key home

BYLINE: JOSH SALMAN

SECTION: D; ARCHIVES; Pg. D01

LENGTH: 430 words

DATELINE: MANASOTA KEY


ENGLEWOOD: Couple have been accused of evading taxes on med school sales

MANASOTA KEY

An Englewood couple indicted on federal charges related to an off-shore tax
evasion conspiracy will likely have a couple of extra millions to help pay their
fines.

David Fredrick and Patricia L. Hough sold their 5,814-square-foot home in
Manasota Key earlier this month for $2.2 million, court records show.

The married couple were indicted on federal charges after the IRS accused them
of hiding millions of dollars in proceeds from the sale of two Caribbean medical
schools in a Swiss bank account to skirt taxes.

The $35 million that the two doctors reaped when the schools were sold in 2007
made their case the largest since U.S. authorities led a crackdown on offshore
tax evasion in 2008, officials said.

Hough and Fredrick used the proceeds to buy an airplane, and homes in Sarasota
and North Carolina, after creating a foundation and other entities to hold money
in accounts at UBS and other foreign banks, while filing phony tax returns to
"conceal assets and income from the IRS," according to their indictments.

Hough was convicted by a jury in October and now faces a potential sentence of
five years in prison and a $250,000 fine for the conspiracy count, along with
another three years and a $250,000 fine for filing the false returns. Her
sentencing has been scheduled for early next year.

Fredrick reportedly fled after the indictment, leaving his wife to face trial
alone.

The IRS said their Englewood home sale this month was not tied to the criminal
investigation, and the transaction was not ordered by the federal government.

"This is not a part of the judicial forfeiture," IRS spokesman Miguel Rivera
said Friday. "It's not connected to any of the court proceedings against them."

Hough owned two Caribbean-based medical schools -- The Saba University School of
Medicine in Saba, Netherlands Antilles, and The Medical University of the
Americas in Nevis, West Indies.

The couple sold both schools and associated real estate in April 2007, "all of
which was deposited into undeclared accounts in the name of the nominee
entities," the Justice Department said.

"The majority of the sale proceeds were not reported to the IRS on their tax
returns and no tax was paid," the agency stated.

Fredrick also transferred more than $1 million to his relatives, the agency
noted.

As for their Englewood home, Frederick paid $500,000 for the property, at 7590
Manasota Key Road, in January 1997 and built the house there in 2001.

The buyer, Oxford Princess LLC, is a company from New Albany, Indiana.

                             May 9, 2012 Wednesday

Horicon business owner faces tax evasion charges

BYLINE: Don Lehman, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 292 words


May 09--HORICON -- The owner of a Brant Lake business was arrested Tuesday on
charges that allege he filed false federal tax returns and evaded nearly
$100,000 in taxes over the past 5 years, officials said.

Stuart A. Mead, owner of Mead's Cottages, was arrested at his Horicon home by
agents from the Internal Revenue Service and state troopers, according to
federal court records.

The charges came after an IRS investigation that began in 2009 when Mead's
then-girlfriend stole $117,000 in cash from him, authorities said. She was
arrested after she was found to have mailed large amounts of cash to relatives.

The woman, Holly G. Blandeaux of Horicon, was prosecuted and pleaded guilty to a
felony grand larceny charge. She was an employee of his business.

A federal grand jury indicted Mead earlier this spring on five felony charges of
tax evasion related to rental property income.

He pleaded not guilty during an arraignment Tuesday in U.S. District Court in
Albany and was released pending a May 14 arraignment with a lawyer, according to
court records.

The charges allege that he filed false tax returns each year between 2006 and
2010, underreporting his business's income by $78,000 to nearly $91,000 a year
in each of the years.

For instance, in 2010 he reported his 2009 income as $50,800 when the federal
investigation found it was actually $141,142. He paid $543 in taxes that year
when he owed $21,239, the indictment alleges.

The IRS had searched Mead's home in August 2010.

Mead could not be reached for comment Wednesday morning.

Each of the charges is punishable by up to 5 years in federal prison.

Former Aptos, La Selva Beach man arrested on tax fraud charges

BYLINE: Stephen Baxter, Santa Cruz Sentinel, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 292 words


Aug. 09--SANTA CRUZ -- A 61-year-old man who lived in Aptos and La Selva Beach
and allegedly did not pay state taxes during in the late 1980s and '90s was
arrested Saturday after returning from Thailand, where investigators said he had
fled after being charged with tax evasion.

Russell S. Broadwell was a sales manager at two software companies from 1989 to
1991 and earned more than $270,000 annually, said Franchise Tax Board spokesman
John Barrett. Broadwell did not file state income taxes from 1989 to 1991 and
owes the state more than $62,000, tax agents said.

Santa Cruz County prosecutors filed a criminal tax evasion complaint against
Broadwell in October 1995, and a warrant was issued for his arrest in November
1995, according to court records.

Broadwell fled the country after he was notified of the investigation, tax
officials said.

Thai authorities recently discovered that Broadwell had overstayed his visa. He
was flown Saturday from Bangkok to San Francisco International Airport, where he
was arrested at the airport, Barrett said.

Broadwell now lists his home address in Bellevue, Wash. Because the crimes are
alleged to have occurred in Santa Cruz County, he was taken to County Jail,
Barrett said.

Broadwell's bail was listed at $15,000 from the 1990s case. He posted bail after
he was booked, according to jail records.

Broadwell is due in court Aug. 16 for an arraignment, Barrett said.

NEW LONDON

Retired Lawyer Pleads Guilty To Tax Evasion

A retired city lawyer pleaded guilty to tax evasion in federal court Monday and
is likely to be sentenced to prison.

In a plea bargain, Gilbert Shasha, 69, who retired from the practice of law in
March, admitted that he claimed no taxable income for the calendar year 1999
when, according to prosecutors, he had gross receipts in excess of $200,000.

Shasha also was accused of depositing a portion of his law office income in
personal accounts and providing fraudulent income and expense records to
auditors from the Internal Revenue Service.

When Shasha is sentenced by U.S. District Judge Mark Kravitz in February,
prosecutors said they will recommend he serve between 10 and 15 months in prison
and pay a $30,000 fine.

Shasha also must reach an agreement with IRS to pay back taxes, plus penalties
and interest, for the years 1999, 2000 and 2001, according to the U.S.
attorney's office.

MANCHESTER

Hartford Man Faces Many Drug Charges

Police have charged a Hartford man with a host of drug charges after he
allegedly sold heroin in the parking lot of 91 Elm St. Monday afternoon.

As police moved in, Dyshawn Figueroa, 28, allegedly tried to swallow a small
quantity of crack cocaine, police said. A 17-year-old male was also taken into
custody with Figueroa, police said.

Police are also seeking arrest warrants for Figueroa, who police said sold
heroin five times to East Central Narcotics Task Force officers. Figueroa, of
182 Westland St., was in custody, with bail at $260,000, on charges of sale of
heroin, conspiracy to sell heroin, possession of heroin, conspiracy to possess
heroin, possession of crack cocaine, and conspiracy to possess crack cocaine.

PLAINVILLE

More Than 20 Arrested At Sobriety Checkpoint

Police at a sobriety checkpoint over the weekend charged more than 20 drivers
with a variety of crimes and traffic infractions.

Police checked drivers on Crooked Street from 7:30 p.m. Saturday to 2 a.m.
Sunday, and charged three with driving while intoxicated.

Officers charged one driver with possessing marijuana with intent to sell, three
with possessing marijuana, 10 with driving unregistered cars, two with driving
with suspended licenses, three with failing to wear seat belts and one with
unauthorized use of colored lights, Sgt. Charles Smedick reported. Police used a
state grant to pay overtime for the work.

The department will field nightly DUI patrols during the holiday weekend,
Smedick said.

WEST HARTFORD

Liquor Sales Violations At Four Stores

Four local stores licensed by the state to sell alcoholic beverages have been
cited for selling alcohol to minors during compliance checks Saturday, the state
Consumer Protection Commissioner Jerry Farrell Jr. said today in a prepared
statement.

Agents from the Liquor Control Division, officers from the West Hartford Police
Department, and a volunteer minor trained by the Governor's Prevention
Partnership checked 27 package stores and grocery stores, Farrell said.
Employees at four of the stores sold alcohol to the minor, who was 17 years of
age.

The alcohol compliance check operation is designed to identify licensed or
permitted locations that are selling alcoholic beverages to minors.

"Our compliance checks are an effective tool to combat underage drinking, as
demonstrated by these results," Farrell said.

The four stores cited were: Delicacy Market, 774 Farmington Ave.; Harvey's Wine
and Spirit Shoppe, 2542 Albany Avenue; Kingswood Package Store, 844-A Farmington
Avenue; Cheers Wines and Spirits, 772 Farmington Avenue

Each of the charged establishments will have the opportunity to address the
charges in an administrative hearing before the Liquor Control Commission at a
future date.

HARTFORD

Prayer Vigil Today On Sisson Avenue

A candlelight prayer vigil will be held today for a 21-year-old man who was
killed in Hartford this month.

Angel Caraballo was shot multiple times in the head Nov. 4.

The vigil will take place at 5:30 p.m. at 30 Sisson Ave., the site of the
shooting. In addition to prayers, clergy and members of the community are
expected to speak about violence in the city during the hour-long event.

For questions call the Rev. Henry Brown, director of Mothers United Against
Violence at 860-538-5490.

Stabbing, Shooting At Party Investigated

A 17-year-old was stabbed and a 21-year-old man was shot at a party at 5 Wolf
Ridge Gap over the weekend, state police said.

The shooting victim was in stable condition Monday at William W. Backus Hospital
in Norwich, and the stabbing victim was in stable condition at Lawrence and
Memorial Hospital in New London, state police said.

James H. Robertson Jr., 29, of New London, was charged with possession of a

possession of a loaded handgun, state police said.

Shawn D. Rucker, 20, of the Gales Ferry section of Ledyard, and Gilene Sablon,

said.

arrived at Lawrence & Memorial Hospital in New London with a stab wound to the
torso.

Moments later, multiple 911 calls were placed about a shooting at 5 Wolf Ridge
Gap, police said. An investigation revealed that the stabbing and the shooting
occurred at the party at that address.

Police pulled over several people in cars who were attempting to leave the area.

Anyone with information is asked to call Ledyard Police at 860-464-6400 or Troop
E 860-848-6500.

NEW BRITAIN

Messy Property Brings Jail Time

A local man was sentenced to two months in jail Thursday for failing to clean up
his property, despite repeated warnings from city inspectors.

Igor Bouziachvili, 54, was convicted in Superior Court in New Britain of
violating an order from the New Britain health director to clean up his property
at 19 Emmons Place.

Bouziachvili was sentenced to 60 days in jail and one year of probation. He was
also ordered to pay $1,000 to the city of New Britain to cover its cost for
cleaning up the property.

New Britain Health Inspector Brian Falkner began an investigation in March into
complaints from neighbors about rubbish and other debris on the Emmons Place
property.

                              Late Edition - Final

Treasury Chief: Tax Evasion Is on the Rise

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

SECTION: Section C; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 691 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18


Tax evasion by Americans using offshore accounts is rising and will increase,
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill testified today as he tried to persuade a
skeptical Democratic senator that he was committed to vigorously pursuing tax
cheats.

Mr. O'Neill said that decades of efforts to catch money launderers and other tax
criminals using offshore accounts had not worked. But he dismissed as
meaningless a document, based on government data, presented by the senator, Carl
Levin, a Michigan Democrat, indicating that fewer than 6,000 of more than 1.1
million offshore accounts and businesses were properly disclosed and therefore
legal. Pressed by Senator Levin about whether the disparity between reported
offshore accounts and their actual numbers was significant, Mr. O'Neill replied:
"I find it amusing."

His testimony, to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, came
before Robert M. Morgenthau, the district attorney in Manhattan, described a
scale of bank deposits in tax havens far greater than most experts suspected.
Citing previously secret Federal Reserve Bank data, Mr. Morgenthau said that
more than $800 billion of American money is on deposit in just one tax haven,
the Cayman Islands.

That sum, equal to one-fifth of all the bank deposits in the United States, he
said, is so large that it cannot be solely, or even primarily, the fruits of
criminal activity like drug dealing. Rather, Mr. Morgenthau said, these funds
must be the product of huge and growing tax evasion by wealthy Americans who
have little, if any, fear of prosecution.

He said his office's efforts to pursue tax cheats had often been stymied not
just by foreign governments, but by the federal government, especially the
Justice and State Departments and the intelligence agencies.

The hearing was prompted by Mr. O'Neill's balking in April at a plan by the
Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to pressure the Cayman
Islands and other tax havens into cooperating with criminal investigations of
tax evasion and money laundering. That plan was thrown into disarray after Mr.
O'Neill declared that the project was too broad and "not in line with this
administration's priorities."

Mr. O'Neill repeatedly insisted that his remarks had been misconstrued by
reporters to suggest laxity.  "We ought to pursue every tax cheat to the ends of
the earth," Mr. O'Neill testified. He cautioned, however, that "we should not
presume to interfere with the internal tax policies of sovereign nations."

Mr. O'Neill promised to return, within a year, with treaties in hand from half,
as he put it, of the five biggest offshore tax havens, that will help
prosecutors in the United States make cases.

He said the Treasury's inability to estimate reliably how much the government
spends investigating money laundering has made him skeptical about existing
efforts. He vowed to find more efficient and effective ways to combat money
laundering and tax fraud.

Mr. O'Neill and Senator Levin agreed on little except that tax fraud and money
laundering were significant issues and a growing problem. Senator Levin said
that "for years now, offshore tax havens have damaged U.S. interests by
facilitating crime, money laundering and tax evasion."

He said the United States loses $70 billion in taxes annually from such evasion
-- "a figure so huge that if even half that amount were collected it would pay
for a Medicare prescription drug program without raising anyone's taxes or
cutting anyone's budget."

Doubting that Senator Levin's attacks would result in improved enforcement, Mr.
O'Neill told him, "You are acting like you are going to do something without
really accomplishing anything."

Seven former Internal Revenue Service Commissioners sent Mr. O'Neill a letter in
June questioning his stance on the O.E.C.D. effort to make foreign tax havens
cooperate with investigations of tax crimes.  Mr. O'Neill said today that he was
"frankly thunderstruck when I got the letter; they responded to
misinterpretations in the press."

The letter came in response to an article, in the May 10 Washington Times, which
appeared under Mr. O'Neill's own byline.

                    December 15, 1994 Thursday Final Edition

Strawberry pleads not guilty to evading tax from card shows

SOURCE: FROM ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. D6

LENGTH: 338 words

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y.


Darryl Strawberry shook his head slightly from side to side and said "not
guilty" yesterday when arraigned in federal court on felony tax evasion charges.

With three lawyers at his side and his pregnant wife in the spectator section,
the star outfielder said little during a 20-minute hearing. He was released on
his own recognizance, but cannot leave the continental United States and must
abide by pretrial supervision rules.

He was fingerprinted, photographed and gave a urine sample during processing by
U.S. marshals.

"I'm not nervous because I know I'm not guilty," Strawberry said in a hallway
outside the courtroom.

His agent, Eric Goldschmidt, also pleaded not guilty to felony tax evasion,
which carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

Strawberry, a right fielder for the San Francisco Giants, is accused of evading
$146,000 in income tax by allegedly not reporting more than $500,000 in cash
payments from autograph shows and personal appearances.

Strawberry is the first baseball player to be charged with tax evasion since
Pete Rose was found guilty of avoiding taxes on $340,000 income. Rose served
five months in prison and was fined $50,000.

Federal prosecutors are reported to be investigating several other major
leaguers for not reporting cash income from autograph shows, a lucrative
business that has sprung up in the last 10 years at which fans pay to receive a
player's signature.

An indictment unsealed last Thursday charged Strawberry and Goldschmidt
concealed the existence of a bank account from accountants so a susbstantial
proportion of their income from card shows would not appear on their 1989 and
1990 tax returns.

Strawberry and Goldschmidt were indicted by a grand jury that heard testimony
from several current and former major leaguers. Strawberry previously played for
the New York Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers. Howard Johnson, his teammate on the
1986 champion Mets, is reported to be co-operating with prosecutors.
