                               The New York Times

               December 3, 1997, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

City Official and 100 Others Are Charged in Tax Scheme

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1310 words


The director of New York City's payroll processing department, who runs a huge
computer operation coordinating all of the city's financial records, was charged
yesterday along with nearly 100 current and former city employees in what
prosecutors called a wide-ranging scheme to avoid paying city and state taxes.

According to prosecutors, the payroll official, Joseph A. Messina, who makes
$133,000 year, claimed more than 40 allowances on his W-4 forms and failed to
file city and state tax returns from 1993 to 1995.

In addition, prosecutors said, 74 officers and captains in the city jail system
failed to pay taxes. Many of the corrections employees -- who carry guns and
took an oath to uphold the law -- were part of a nationwide tax protester
movement, whose adherents say they are somehow exempt from the laws of the
United States, officials said.

The others charged yesterday with tax evasion worked for a variety of city
agencies; three other people who are not city employees were accused of
recruiting city employees into the scheme by selling kits to evade taxes. The
kits, which are also sold for up to $2,000 through the Internet and scattered
protest movements, include videotapes, books and forms that provide advice on
tax evasion.

The charges were announced at an unusual City Hall news conference yesterday by
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District
Attorney, along with officials of the State Taxation Department and the State
Attorney General's office. Although only 40 of the city employees were actually
arrested yesterday, with the others scheduled to turn themselves in today,
officials said they decided to go ahead with the announcement after news of the
arrests began to leak out.

Although no Federal charges were filed, city officials said the Internal Revenue
Service and Federal prosecutors were looking into the case.

Officials said that while some of the employees were recruited into the scheme
as part of an organized effort, others simply heard about the technique through
friends and colleagues and decided to do the same. Just over a year ago, 11 New
York City police officers were charged in a similar case involving failure to
pay Federal taxes. In that case, the officers declared more than 90 dependents
on their W-4 forms and asserted that the Government had no right to tax them.

The latest investigation, which was conducted by a task force of seven city and
state agencies, began in February 1996, when an inspector with the city's
Department of Investigation noticed that several employees of the Sanitation
Department had submitted petitions to the payroll department claiming that they
were exempt from taxes.

The Investigation Department asked Mr. Messina, executive director of the city's
Financial Information Services Agency, to look at the records of all city
employees to see who had claimed an unusually large number of allowances, and
the Mayor said Mr. Messina was unaccountably slow in providing the information.

"He was the person who was asked to supply the information when the inquiry was
first broadened to include the entire city," Mr. Giuliani said. "And D.O.I.
experienced some delay in getting that information. You can imagine why there
was a delay."

When investigators finally got the information they were seeking, they found
that Mr. Messina had claimed 40 to 45 withholding allowances on his W-4 form,
far more than he was entitled to. The high number of allowances had the effect
of producing paychecks with no taxes withheld.

The city has since limited the number of allowances for employees to 14; those
who claim more will be subject to an inquiry.

City payroll records also showed that more than 100 employees had claimed up to
99 allowances on their forms, the maximum, or had claimed to be exempt from
withholding altogether, said Edward J. Kuriansky, the city's Commissioner of
Investigation. State and Federal tax laws permit only those with no tax
liability, such as students or some part-time employees, to be exempt from
withholding.

When city officials turned the list of names over to state tax officials, they
discovered that in each case, the employees had also failed to file a state and
city tax return, Mr. Kuriansky said. The total amount of state and city taxes
that had not been paid was more than $500,000, he said; an additional $2.1
million was owed in Federal taxes.

Prosecutors said that about half the city employees charged yesterday were
involved in various nationwide movements of so-called freemen, who claim they
cannot be required to pay taxes. The groups, which use such names as the Moorish
Nation, the Lions of Freedom and the Financial Empowerment Group, say that their
members are aliens who do not recognize the authority of the United States or
who believe that the tax laws are unconstitutional.

An Internet site connected to the Lions of Freedom sells an $89.95 home-study
course called the "Organic Sovereign American Freeman Compendium," which teaches
how to avoid all taxes and drop out of the Social Security system. The course
"brings you the amazing, true story, heavily documented, of how the American
people (and you) have been tricked into paying the Federal Income 'Tax' for the
past 50 years, when it didn't even apply to them, at all!" the Internet site
says.

Mr. Kuriansky said he found it appalling that corrections officers would
subscribe to such a philosophy.

"This is extremely offensive and serious conduct," he said. "For a sworn law
enforcement officer, who carries a gun, who takes an oath to the United States
and the state constitution, and for all other purposes claims the benefits of
citizenship, who has the gall not to pay his fair share -- I mean it's really
outrageous."

Efforts to reach an official of the union that represents corrections officers
were unsuccessful last night.

Mr. Morgenthau, however, added that many of employees claiming to be aligned
with the freemen movement probably do not really believe in its tenets but are
using them as an excuse to avoid taxes. Mr. Kuriansky agreed, saying there was
far more greed involved in the scheme than ideology.

He added that it was "ironic and sad" that the person in charge of the city's
payroll management system would be charged in such a scheme.  Mr. Messina was
appointed to his job in 1986 by the three-member board of the information
services agency, whose members are jointly appointed by the Mayor and the
Comptroller. Mr. Messina's position puts him on a par with city commissioners.

A person who answered a call last night at Mr. Messina's home in East Brunswick,
N.J., said, "I don't known anything about it."

Kevin Ryan, a spokesman for the city Department Investigation, said Mr. Messina
surrendered at Department of Investigation headquarters on 80 Maiden Lane
yesterday afternoon.

Along with Mr. Messina, those charged yesterday included 69 corrections
officers, 4 corrections captains, 10 sanitation workers, 3 sanitation police
officers, 3 traffic agents of the Police Department, 5 employees of the Housing
Authority and an employee of the Department of Environmental Protection. Seven
were former city employees.

They were charged with a variety of offenses, including scheming to defraud,
grand larceny, offering a false instrument for filing and failure to file a
return. The most serious charges carry a maximum four-year prison term, and
those charged will also be required to pay their tax liability with interest and
penalties.

The Mayor said all the city employees were suspended without pay and would
almost certainly lose their jobs after disciplinary proceedings.

Forty more city employees were also suspended yesterday for the same reason but
were not charged. Officials said they expected more charges and arrests in the
coming days.

                               The New York Times

                June 2, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

PISANI IS GUILTY ON 18 COUNTS, ACQUITTED OF 11

BYLINE: By MARCIA CHAMBERS

SECTION: Section 1; Page 27, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 518 words


A Federal jury last night convicted State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of income-tax
evasion and of embezzling money from his campaign funds and his law firm.

The jury convicted Mr. Pisani, a Republican of New Rochelle, N.Y., of 18 counts
and acquitted him of 11 counts on the 39-count indictment.

But the jury, which had deliberated 34 hours over the last four days in Federal
District Court in Manhattan, told Judge David N. Edelstein they were deadlocked
on a major part of the Government's case, whether Mr. Pisani was guilty of
charges that he had used $20,000 in state funds to buy a summer house he shared
with his friend and co- defendant, Kathryn Godfrey.

Jury Dismissed at 11:35


The judge discharged the jury at 11:35 P.M., and a mistrial was declared on the
remaining 10 counts.

One of the prosecutors, Michael S. Feldberg, said afterward that Mr. Pisani
could be retried or that the counts against him could be dismissed. Prosectors
would decide in the next week or so how to proceed, he said.

Mr. Pisani faces three years in prison for filing false tax returns and up to
five years in prison for each of the other guilty verdicts. These counts include
fraud and Federal tax evasion.

Judge Edelstein set July 17 for sentencing and released Mr. Pisani in his own
custody.

Mrs. Godfrey, who worked as a stenographer for Mr. Pisani, was acquitted of one
of three counts of perjury for lying to the grand jury during its investigation
of the fraud and tax charges. The jury was deadlocked on the other two counts
against her.

Under state law, Mr. Pisani, a State Senator for 12 years, faces automatic
expulsion from the Senate upon conviction of a felony. Mr. Pisani, a 54-year-
old lawyer, recently announced that he would not run for re-election this year
because of the time and expense required for the five-week trial.

''I think there has been some vindication by the verdict,'' Mr. Pisani said as
he left the courthouse. ''I will continue to fight for my total vindication.''

His lawyer, Robert Kasanof, said he would appeal the convictions.

In one instance, the jury found Mr. Pisani guilty of stealing $14,000 from the
escrow account of a client, Erma Jean Gina.

Possibility of Disbarment


He also faces the possibility of disbarment if the Federal felony convictions
are found equivalent to state charges.

The silver-haired Mr. Pisani was calm as Edgar Bartolucci, the foreman of the
jury of eight men and four women, read the verdicts in the nearly deserted
courtroom at 9:25 P.M.

Judge Edelstein then told the jury to resume deliberations, reminding them that
the trial had been long and expensive. Thirty-seven witnesses had been called
and 1,000 documents submitted.

But after two more hours of discussion, Mr. Bartolucci reported that the jury
was ''deeply disappointed'' that they were unable to reach a decision on the
remaining counts.  The Government's assertion that Mr. Pisani had used state
money for the upstate summer house rested largely on the testimony of Joseph L.
Mallon, who is awaiting sentence on a related charge.

                             Daily News (New York)

                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

DAILY NEWS SPORTS HALL OF FAME CANDIDATES. AND INTRODUCING THE CANDIDATES...
DARRYL STRAWBERRY

BYLINE: BY CHRISTIAN RED

SECTION: SPECIAL; Pg. 59

LENGTH: 281 words


The Hall of Fame seemed like a cinch when he first began his major league
career. With a sweet left-handed swing and plenty of raw power, Darryl
Strawberry hit at least 26 homers his first four seasons with the Mets,
including 27 in 1986 when his team stunned the Boston Red Sox in the World
Series.

And "Straw" was just getting started. There were back-to-back 39-homer seasons
in '87 and '88. The Mets' right fielder finished second to Dodger Kirk Gibson in
the '88 NL MVP voting. In 1990 - his final year in Flushing and the last season
the Mets were competitive before a near decade-long slide - Strawberry hit .277
with 37 homers and 108 RBI.

But like his Mets and Yankees teammate Dwight Gooden, Strawberry's baseball
success was matched with near intensity by his off-the-field woes: drug abuse,
income tax evasion, colon cancer and domestic disputes are some of the problems
that plagued Strawberry in the '90s. After violating MLB's drug policy in
February 1995, Strawberry was suspended and released by the Giants. He later was
sentenced to jail for tax evasion. But George Steinbrenner came to the rescue,
signing the troubled player to a contract with the Yankees. A year later,
Strawberry showed his menace at the plate, belting three homers in the '96 ALCS
against the Orioles after hitting 11 home runs in 63 regular season games.

CAREER HIGHLIGHTS.

Strawberry captures the 1983 NL Rookie of the Year award after batting .257 with
26 homers and 74 RBI for the Mets. He is the first non-Dodger to win the award
since 1978.

Strawberry crushes two home runs in Game 4 of the '96 ALCS vs. Baltimore at
Camden Yards, helping the Yankees to a 8-4 win and a commanding 3-1 series lead.

                                US Official News

                             March 20, 2015 Friday

Arizona: Former Head of Operations at New York Brokerage Firm Pleads Guilty to
Tax Evasion and Filing False Tax Return

LENGTH: 298  words

DATELINE: Phoenix


Department of Justice has issued the following news releae:

A former resident of North Bellmore, New York, pleaded guilty today in the U.S.
District Court for the Eastern District of New York in Long Island to one count
of tax evasion and one count of filing a false federal income tax return,
announced Acting Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo of the Justice
Department's Tax Division.

According to the indictment, Dominick Pannitti, 38, was head of operations at a
securities brokerage firm located in Syosset, New York. The brokerage firm used
an automated system designed to adjust customers' trading accounts for amounts
less than $1,000. During 2005 and 2006, Pannitti used the automated system to
credit his own trading accounts-set up in the name of a corporation that he
owned-more than 850 times in increments of less than $1,000. Pannitti was not
entitled to most of these credits, which totaled more than $570,000. Pannitti
failed to report the income on his 2005 and 2006 federal income tax returns.

Pannitti faces a statutory maximum sentence of five years in prison and up to a
$250,000 fine for the tax evasion count and a statutory maximum sentence of
three years in prison and up to a $250,000 fine for the false return count at
his sentencing before U.S. District Judge Arthur D. Spatt.

Acting Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo commended the special agents of
IRS-Criminal Investigation and the FBI, who investigated the case, and Trial
Attorneys Mark Kotila and Jeffrey Bender of the Tax Division, who are
prosecuting the case. Ciraolo also thanked the U.S. Attorney's Office for the
Eastern District of New York for their substantial assistance.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                             January 5, 2015 Monday

Bank Pays $400m Fine For Aiding US Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 399  words


A leading Israeli bank has agreed to pay the US government $400 million
compensation for helping US customers evade tax.
Bank Leumi confessed to advising 1,500 wealthy Americans how to evade taxes over
several years.


The bank ran secret meetings in hotels, restaurants and other places away from
offices in New York,  Los Angeles and Miami to cover up their business and to
avoid leaving a paper trail and witnesses to the subterfuge.
The fines and compensation include a $157 million settlement concerning tax
issues with US customer accounts in the bank's Swiss branch.
The bank's executives have also agreed to meet strict governance agreements laid
down by the US Justice Department.
FATCA pledge
Leumi will designate a liaison officer responsible for working with the US
Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and an officer at each branch who is responsible
for supervising reporting under the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA).
FATCA demands the bank registers as a compliant organisation and makes annual
reports on the financial affairs of US resident taxpayers controlling bank
accounts and investments with a balance of $50,000 or with a limit of $200,000
if they are a US expat.
Under US tax law, expats must report their worldwide income each year to the
IRS.
The bank has also had to agree not to open accounts controlled by US customers
unless the customers pledge to report their financial affairs to the IRS and not
to close accounts controlled by US customers who have not reported their assets.

Instead, the bank must disclose these assets under the FATCA regime.
Tax investigations
The US is also investigating alleged tax evasion by Israel's Bank Hapoalim and
the Mizrahi Tefahot Bank.
"This investigation has been underway for three years and has at last come to a
satisfactory conclusion," said a US Treasury Department spokesman.
"Along with action against dozens of Swiss banks, we hope the result shows out
resolve in dealing with tax evasion wherever it goes on in the world."
FATCA was introduced in 2010, but only requires foreign financial institutions
to report the details of American controlled accounts from July 2014.
Among the accusations against the bank and several subsidiaries was a claim that
employees helped US customers shield the true nature of the financial income
from the US tax authorities by setting up bogus companies in Belize. 2014 Legal
Monitor Worldwide.

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                            November 9, 2012 Friday
                                 METRO EDITION

10 years later, justice in fraud scheme

BYLINE: DAN BROWNING; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 828 words



HIGHLIGHT: Jim and Teresa Hoffman were sent to prison after pleading guilty to
federal charges.


Kevin and Kris Brown's trip to federal court began on their wedding day, Dec.
28, 2002. That's the day that they and their six children were evicted from
their home in Hastings by Jim Hoffman in an equity-stripping scheme.

On Thursday, they sat quietly in a Minneapolis federal courtroom to see Hoffman
and his wife, Teresa Gay Hoffman, sent to federal prison.

"We've been waiting for this day for a long time," Kevin Brown said afterward.

"It's amazing it's taken 10 years," Kris Brown added. "And he's kept hurting
people."

Jim Hoffman, 53, pleaded guilty in February to money laundering and tax evasion,
and Teresa Hoffman, also 53, pleaded guilty to tax evasion.

U.S. District Judge David Doty sentenced Jim Hoffman to 6 1/2 years in prison --
the top of the advisory guidelines' range -- followed by three years of
supervised release. He sentenced Teresa Hoffman to a year -- six months below
the minimum in the sentencing guidelines -- followed by two years of supervised
release.

The charges in the plea agreement fail to illustrate Jim Hoffman's trail of
crimes, Assistant U.S. Attorney David MacLaughlin argued.

"He is a true fraudster," MacLaughlin said, arguing for the stiff sentence.
Unlike some people who resort to fraud because of economic hardship, he argued,
"fraud is all that he has done since the 1990s."

Victims paid dearly

MacLaughlin noted in court filings that Hoffman had owned a dairy operation in
southern Minnesota in the 1990s and financed its operations by defrauding an
Iowa bank and by stealing employment taxes he'd withheld from its workers. Next,
he systematically stole the equity from large numbers of vulnerable people
facing foreclosure. He went on to operate a complex fraud scheme involving the
now defunct Lake Elmo real estate company Avidigm Capital Group Inc., inflicting
huge losses on investors and lenders.

Then he committed mortgage fraud schemes that led to his indictment, MacLaughlin
wrote. Finally, while awaiting trial on those charges, he launched a new fraud
scheme involving a nursing home in Muscatine, Iowa.

"Along the way, Mr. Hoffman lived in luxury homes that he did not pay for, drove
expensive cars titled in other people's names and inflicted great economic harm
on others to possess these luxuries, including a cocktail waitress and single
mother who bought for $1.2 million a home in Hastings so that Mr. Hoffman and
his family could live well, even as her credit rating was destroyed by her
predictable inability to make the mortgage payments on the home," he continued.

MacLaughlin said Jim Hoffman involved his wife in the mortgage fraud scheme and
his eldest son in the nursing home scam. And the government recovered documents
showing that he has used the identities of his minor children to set up various
entities that appear similar to those he has used in past fraud schemes.

Peter Wold, Jim Hoffman's attorney, said his client asked for only one thing:
mercy for his wife. "But your honor, I ask for some mercy for him."

In court filings, Wold said that Jim Hoffman has been a good husband, father,
son and friend. He's been generous with many. "His candor and truth in his
acceptance of responsibility are hallmarks of redemption," Wold said.

Losses set at $5 million

Doty agreed with MacLaughlin's request for a 78-month sentence and ordered him
to pay restitution of $344,409.

MacLaughlin objected, saying the amount reflected only the losses of victims
who've requested repayment. FBI special agent Eileen Rice conducted an
exhaustive review of his mortgage fraud deals and calculated the losses at $5,16
million.

Doty said it's unrealistic to think he'd ever repay that amount, not to mention
several million dollars in old debts, civil claims and judgments ranging from
banks to dairy suppliers and even the Convent of the Visitation School.

But Doty agreed to review the law on mandatory restitution to craft his final
order on the matter.

MacLaughlin took no position on Teresa Hoffman's sentencing.

Her attorney, Casey Rundquist, argued for probation, saying she's primarily been
a homemaker for the couple's four children. Since her indictment, she's become
the family's primary provider as three of her children attempt to finish
college, he said.

Doty said a year in prison was appropriate for Teresa Hoffman because she not
only failed to pay sufficient taxes, but she spent the money on unnecessary
items such as lawn care, country club fees, a boat, furniture and private-school
tuition. She also must pay $258,561 in back taxes.

The Browns attended the sentencing hearing along with a representative of the
state attorney general's office, which helped them get back into their home
seven months after Hoffman evicted them. They seemed satisfied with Jim
Hoffman's sentence, but said Teresa Hoffman got off too easily.

"I think she could've gotten more," Kris Brown said. "My kids have learned great
lessons from what we've been through. Their kids have learned nothing."

Dan Browning - 612-673-4493

                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                            October 27, 2008 Monday

Minneapolis / 3 guilty of plotting against judge

BYLINE: By Brady Gervais bgervais@pioneerpress.com

SECTION: NORTH ZONE STORIES; Crime and Court Stories

LENGTH: 292 words


A jury convicted three Twin Cities men Monday in federal court in Minneapolis of
trying to intimidate U.S. District Judge Ann Montgomery.

A jury found Robert Bonine Beale, 65, of North Oaks; Frederick Ogan Bond, 63, of
Champlin; and John Howard Pelton, 67, of Stillwater, guilty of one count each of
conspiracy to impede an officer and one count of obstruction of justice.

A fourth individual, Norman William Pool, pleaded guilty in September to one
count of conspiracy to impede an officer.

The group was accused of trying to prevent Montgomery from presiding over the
conspiracy and tax evasion trial of former millionaire Beale.

In April, Beale was found guilty of one count of felony conspiracy to defraud
the United States, five counts of tax evasion for failing to pay personal income
tax on more than $5 million in income and one count of failing to appear in
federal court. He was sentenced last month to more than 11 years in prison on
those charges. Beale will be sentenced in the intimidation case at a later date,
officials said.

The four were part of a group that operated a "common-law court," in which
Pelton is the leader, according to the U.S. attorney's office.

The group issued "arrest warrants" in an effort to have Montgomery arrested,
issued "false and fraudulent liens" and planned to disrupt court proceedings,
the U.S. attorney's office said.

Kurt Glaser, an attorney for Bond, said he plans to appeal.

"It was very disappointing," Glaser said of the outcome.

Bond and Pelton will be sentenced in February by North Dakota Judge Rodney Webb,
who presided over the case, Glaser said. They are not in custody.

The jury received the case Friday afternoon and returned the verdict Monday
afternoon.

Brady Gervais can be reached at 651-228-2171.

                                Birmingham Post

                            June 27, 2007, Wednesday
                                  1ST Edition

INTERNATIONAL: Fraud trial verdict awaited on Black and 'thieves in ties'

BYLINE: John Ashton

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 652 words


The jury in the pounds 30 million fraud trial of former media mogul Conrad Black
was expected to retire to consider its verdict last night. Lord Black and other
Hollinger International executives are accused of stealing EUR60 million (pounds
30million) from the company's shareholders.

The jury at the Dirksen Federal Courthouse in Chicago, Illinois, has heard the
money mainly came from the sale of hundreds of Hollinger-owned US and Canadian
community newspapers between 1998 and 2001, in which the buyers paid large sums
in return for agreements that Hollinger would not compete with the new owners.

The 62-year-old former Daily Telegraph owner and once-powerful chief executive
of the Hollinger newspaper empire denies charges of fraud, tax evasion,
obstruction of justice and racketeering.

His three co-defendants - former vice presidents John Boultbee and Peter
Atkinson, both of Toronto, Canada, and former corporate counsel Mark Kipnis, of
Chicago - also deny charges of fraud and tax evasion.

During the 14-week trial, the 11 women and four men on the jury heard the US
government label Black and his co-defendants as EUR60 million (pounds 30
million) "thieves wearing ties".

Black is also accused of cheating Hollinger International by taking the company
plane on a holiday to Bora Bora in French Polynesia, billing shareholders
EUR40,000 (pounds 20,000) for his wife's surprise birthday party and paying
below the market rate when he bought a company apartment on New York's Park
Avenue.

But defence lawyers said the US government was trying to sow prejudice among the
middle-class Chicago jurors by stressing the wealthy newspaper executive's
"Champagne and caviar" lifestyle.

Assistant US Attorney Julie Ruder, prosecuting, said: "We're not here because
somebody made a mistake, we're not here because somebody forgot to dot the I's
or cross the T's.

"It was stealing, plain and simple."

She said Black and his co-defendants had created a cover story to hide the fact
that they had been siphoning off millions of dollars in profits.

Ms Ruder told jurors: "It will be your job to expose this cover story for the
lie that it is".

The court heard most of the money from the non-compete payments went to
Hollinger International but millions were paid to Black, Boultbee, Atkinson and
David Radler, the company's number two and Black's long-term friend, who has
already pleaded guilty and was the government's star witness.

The US government accused the four men of deceiving Hollinger International's
board of directors, its lawyers and its accountants by claiming that the buyers
insisted that individual executives sign the non-compete payments.

Turning to the defence table and pointing at Black, Ms Ruder said: "It's a
pretty easy way for people who know how the system works to use it as part of a
cover story."

The jurors also heard how Black had removed 13 boxes of documents from his
Toronto offices despite a ban on taking away anything that could be federal
grand jury evidence.

"The rules don't apply to Conrad Black," Ms Ruder said.

"He wanted those documents out and he took them. Classic, classic Conrad Black."

Edward Greenspan, defending Black, urged jurors to ignore "the taint of
prejudice" over his client's wealth and luxury lifestyle and "treat and judge
Conrad Black the way you treat any of your neighbours".

He said the government did not have a "smoking gun" because there was not one.

Mr Greenspan said the case against Black was based on the unsupported word of a
former business partner who was "a serial liar".

Referring to Radler, the US government's star witness, Edward Genson, also
defending Black, said: "He's a liar, he's a liar, he's a liar."

Mr Genson described Black as "a little bit of a stubborn man but an innocent
man".

"Being wealthy doesn't make you a bad man," he said.

Judge Amy St Eve was expected to begin her directions to the jury yesterday
afternoon central standard US time.

                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                             May 21, 2005 Saturday

METRO & STATE BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled from staff and wire reports

SECTION: METRO/STATE; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 1453 words


CENTRAL TEXAS DIGEST

AUSTIN

Hooking his audience

White House press secretary Scott McClellan knew what territory he was in
Friday, flashing 'hook 'em' as he spoke at the College of Liberal Arts
Convocation at the Erwin Center on the University of Texas campus. The
convocation recognized the college's individual graduates.

Injury in trooper training

A Texas Department of Public Safety trooper trainee was hospitalized after
suffering a head injury during a training session Thursday morning, a DPS
spokesman said.

Jimmy Ray Carty, 29, was hit in the head about 5:30 a.m. by another trainee as
part of a drill on arrest and control tactics at the DPS complex on North Lamar
Boulevard, spokesman Tom Vinger said.

There were 123 recruits in the class, Vinger said. They were wearing protective
gear for the head and body.

Carty, who is from the East Texas town of Grand Saline, was taken to
Brackenridge Hospital, where he had emergency surgery. Vinger would not comment
on the nature of Carty's injuries.

"We are very concerned, and our thoughts and our prayers are with him and his
family," Vinger said.

Man pleads guilty to tax evasion

Steven D. Shanklin, an Austin man who the IRS says made $2.3 million from 1998
to 2001 but filed income tax returns claiming that he owed no taxes, pleaded
guilty to tax evasion in federal court Friday.

Shanklin, 48, a Cisco Systems Sales and Services Inc. employee, will have to pay
restitution on the unpaid taxes, including penalties and interest, under a plea
agreement with prosecutors.

In exchange, two counts of tax evasion will be dropped. The maximum penalty for
tax evasion is five years in federal prison.

Shanklin lives in a 3,000-square-foot house in the Circle C development in
Southwest Austin.

He wrote a letter with one of his tax returns that stated that he knew of "no
section of the Internal Revenue Code that . . . establishes an income tax
liability," court documents show.

Shanklin is among the approximately 300 people each year prosecuted in federal
courts after failing to file a tax return or citing frivolous legal arguments as
a reason for not paying taxes, IRS officials said.

Man sentenced in neighbor killing

A state district judge sentenced a 72-year-old Austin man to 25 years in prison
Friday for killing his neighbor in a dispute over the neighbor's maid.

This month, a Travis County jury convicted Pete Terrazas of killing Miguel Ruiz,
62, in the wee hours of New Year's Day 2004.

Terrazas' lawyer said the shooting was over his affection for Ruiz's maid, who
broke up with Terrazas because he drank too much. Prosecutors said that Terrazas
was convinced that Ruiz was having an affair with the woman, who was hired to
take care of Ruiz's invalid wife.

On New Year's Eve, Terrazas waited for Ruiz to come home before shooting him
twice with a .410-gauge shotgun.

The jury took about an hour to find him guilty of murder. The sentence was
levied by District Judge Jon Wisser.

Jets to fly over history museum

Three F-16 fighter jets will fly over the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum
today to celebrate National Armed Forces Day.

The museum is offering an afternoon of free family activities for the opening of
the IMAX film "Fighter Pilot: Operation Red Flag." From noon until 4 p.m.,
visitors can see a customized Air Force sport-utility vehicle, play interactive
computer games that model flight maneuvers and meet an Air Force honor guard
team.

The pilots flying the F-16s are from Ellington Field in Houston.

Beutel hired by Houston theater

Paul Beutel, former director of the Paramount Theatre, has been hired to run the
Miller Outdoor Theatre in Houston.

An Austin resident for more than three decades, Beutel, a native of Houston, was
an entertainment reporter for the Austin American-Statesman in the late 1970s
before becoming manager of publicity and promotions for the newly built
University of Texas Performing Arts Center in 1980. He joined the Paramount in
1985 and is credited with helping rescue the perennially cash-poor historic
theater from at least three near-death experiences.

He played a crucial role in the birth of Austin Musical Theatre (since deceased)
and revitalized the Paramount's summer classic movie series.

Three years ago he was elected to the Austin Arts Hall of Fame, and last year he
retired from the Austin Theatre Alliance, the company that manages the State and
Paramount theaters. More recently, he has contributed articles to the
American-Statesman, including the May 19 XL cover story on the Broadway show
"The Producers."

DPS: Pocket bikes are illegal

The Texas Department of Public Safety is warning motorists that mini-motorcycles
-- also known as pocket bikes and pocket rockets -- are illegal to drive on
public roads and sidewalks.

Although many people mistakenly think that the mini-motorcycles are considered
motor-assisted scooters, they are illegal because they cannot be registered as
vehicles and do not meet the equipment standards required by federal and Texas
law, DPS officials said.

Citations for driving the bikes could include operating an unregistered vehicle,
driving without a license or insurance and various equipment violations.

DPS officials said there have been a number of injuries involving pocket bikes
and a death in Laredo in January.

TRAVIS COUNTY

Horses test positive for disease

Two horses from a Travis County ranch have tested positive for a viral disease
that causes blisters to form in the animals' mouths and on their hooves, state
animal health officials said Friday.

The horses were brought home May 10 from a trail ride in Arizona, where the
Texas Animal Health Commission said they apparently were exposed to vesicular
stomatitis, which is rarely fatal. The virus can cause animals to develop
blisters and sores in their mouths and on their tongues, muzzles, teats and
hooves.

The country's first cases this year were confirmed April 27 in two horses in
southwestern New Mexico. Since then, infection has been detected in 17 horses on
11 sites in New Mexico, Arizona and Texas.

To prevent spreading, infected animals and other livestock at each site are
quarantined until at least 30 days after the sores heal.

ROUND ROCK

Spa worker accused of fondling

Police on May 13 arrested an employee of a local spa who is accused of touching
a client inappropriately.

Officer Eric Poteet said a Round Rock woman accepted an offer for a free haircut
and massage at Shear Style Day Spa on March 29. On the massage table,
25-year-old Tuong Vu Hoang began fondling her, Poteet said.

The woman thinks that Hoang followed her after the massage, Poteet said. At some
point, Hoang offered to pay the victim and her boyfriend to keep them from going
to police, he said.

Hoang was released from the Williamson County Jail on $1,500 bail and faces
charges of public lewdness, a Class A misdemeanor punishable by up to a year in
jail.

BELL COUNTY

One killed, one injured in wreck

A Killeen man was killed and his passenger was injured Thursday near milepost
554 of FM 439, west of Belton, when he drove into oncoming traffic after his
tire blew out, Department of Public Safety officials said.

Joe Thomas, 54, was driving a 1974 Chevy pickup west about 4:40 p.m. when his
left front tire blew out. His pickup was struck by a 1998 Mack Truck Tractor.

Thomas was pronounced dead at the scene at 6 p.m, DPS officials said. His
passenger was taken to Scott & White Hospital in Temple with injuries that were
not life-threatening.

TEXAS DIGEST

HELOTES

Three teens killed in wreck

Three teenagers were killed when their vehicle slammed into a tree, flipped into
the air, landed next to a house and erupted in flames in this San Antonio
suburb, authorities said.

Residents pulled the 21-year-old man driving the car out of the burning vehicle
Thursday night, and he was flown to Brooke Army Medical Center, where he was
reported in serious condition with burns.

The teens who died ranged in age from 13 to 16.

Investigators suspect that the vehicle was speeding and that alcohol may have
been a factor when the driver apparently lost control.

SAN ANTONIO

Jubilee for new Mormon temple

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints will hold "The Heart of Texas: A
Youth Jubilee" at 7 p.m. today at the Alamodome, 100 Montana St., to celebrate
the dedication of the city's new temple, a holy site for Mormons.

Church officials expect more than 3,000 Central Texas youths to participate in
the Texas-themed production with song and dance. The event is free and open to
the public. Gordon Hinckley, the church's worldwide leader, will dedicate the
temple Sunday. After the dedication, only Mormons may enter the temple. For more
information, go to http://youthjubilee.org.

                                   USA TODAY

                             May 11, 2016 Wednesday
                                 FIRST EDITION

Panama Papers report spurs more calls for scrutiny;
Senator demands info on companies in Nevada, Wyoming

BYLINE: Alan Gomez, and Jane Onyanga-Omara, USA TODAY

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 433 words


Officials in the United States and governments from at least four other
countries called Tuesday for closer examination of anonymous offshore accounts
highlighted by new Panama Papers' disclosures of how the rich and powerful hide
their assets.

In the USA, Sen. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., sent letters to the secretaries of State of
Nevada and Wyoming, demanding a full accounting of the anonymous companies
established in those states through the Panamanian law firm, Mossack Fonseca,
which had 11.5 million of its internal documents hacked. Monday, the
International Consortium of Investigative Journalists, which has handled papers,
released a massive database that contained the names of more than 360,000 people
and companies associated with offshore accounts.

Citing a USA TODAY analysis of 1,000 anonymous companies in Nevada and 24 in
Wyoming tied to the law firm, Wyden asked for information about the companies,
how the states regulate them and whether any of the companies has been
investigated for criminal activity.

"I have become increasingly concerned about the use of anonymous shell companies
as vehicles for terrorists' financing, tax evasion and fraud targeting major
government programs within the committee's jurisdiction, such as Medicare,"
wrote Wyden, ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee.

The fallout elsewhere:

Japan said it would draft a plan to fight international tax evasion. It said it
plans to propose measures to fight global graft at the Group of Seven economic
summit it will host in the cities of Ise and Shima on May 26-27.

In Australia, the federal Taxation Office is investigating about 800 Australians
named in the Panama Papers, according to the Herald Sun.

In India, D.S. Malik, a spokesman for the country's Finance Ministry, said
income tax authorities sent notices to all Indians listed in the database
seeking information and warning of possible investigations, the Associated Press
reported.

Canadian Revenue Minister Diane Lebouthillier said investigators were analyzing
the files. "We are looking into what's going on in these cases with a
fine-toothed comb," she told lawmakers Monday. "If we can lay criminal charges,
we will lay criminal charges."

A deputy director of Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko's confectionery empire
is a beneficiary of a company registered in the British Virgin Islands,
according to new information. The link to Sergei Zaitsev is potentially
embarrassing for Poroshenko because he said in April he wanted to pass a law
requiring Ukrainians to disclose all offshore holdings to force them to pay
taxes in their home country.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            September 4, 2015 Friday

Owners of Worcester Payroll Company Plead Guilty to Tax Evasion and Fraud

LENGTH: 765  words


The co-owners and former owner of a payroll company in Worcester pleaded guilty
in U.S. District Court in Worcester to defrauding the Internal Revenue Service
(IRS) and tax evasion. One of the co-owners also pleaded guilty to embezzling
client and employee funds.


William McCullough, 72, of Westborough, Mass., pleaded guilty to two counts of
conspiracy to defraud the IRS, four counts of false statements, four counts of
tax evasion, and one count of wire fraud. Robert McCullough, 43, also of
Westborough, the son of William McCullough, pleaded guilty to two counts of
conspiracy to defraud the IRS, four counts of false statements, and four counts
of tax evasion. Gary Davis, 74, of Jupiter, Fla., pleaded guilty to one count of
conspiracy to defraud the IRS, and three counts of tax evasion. On Aug. 31,
2015, William McCullough was charged in two Informations, and today, Robert
McCullough and Davis were charged in one Information. U.S. District Court Judge
Timothy S. Hillman scheduled sentencing for William McCullough on Dec. 1, 2015,
for Gary Davis on Dec. 8, 2015, and for Robert McCullough on Jan. 14, 2016.
The McCulloughs are co-owners of Harpers Data Services, a payroll company in
Worcester. William McCullough is also the treasurer and his son, Robert, is the
president. Gary Davis was a former owner and president of Harpers until his
retirement in 2010.
Beginning around 2006, William and Robert McCullough opened and operated two
corporate bank accounts at Webster Five Cents Savings Bank. From 2007 to 2012,
they funneled approximately $11 million of taxable income into these accounts.
The McCulloughs kept these accounts off of the corporation's books and concealed
their existence from the corporate accountant. Thus, the income deposited into
these accounts was not reported to the IRS on the corporation's annual tax
returns. As a result, the corporation failed to pay approximately $3.78 million
in taxes.
Also during that time, William McCullough wrote checks totaling approximately
$4.7 million from one of the Webster Five corporate accounts to himself, Robert
McCullough, and Gary Davis. In addition, from 2007 to 2011, William McCullough
wrote bonus and dividend checks from Harpers totaling approximately $2.7 million
to himself, Robert McCullough, and Gary Davis. William McCullough ensured that
none of this income appeared on the appropriate tax reporting forms, and as a
result, the defendants failed to pay approximately $1.7 million in taxes from
2007 through 2011.  In a separate Information, William McCullough pleaded guilty
to one count of wire fraud. From 2009 through 2011, Harpers maintained client
trust accounts and a client tax account. These accounts contained client funds,
which were to be used to pay employees' paychecks and employees' federal and
state taxes. From 2009 through 2011, William McCullough took approximately $1
million from the client trust accounts and deposited it into a Harpers account.
In 2010, he took $750,000 from the client tax account and deposited it into a
Harpers account. At the time William McCullough took this money, the funds
belonged solely to the clients of Harpers Data Services. McCullough's fraud
resulted in a theft of approximately $1.8 million dollars.
The charge of conspiracy to defraud provides a sentence of no greater than five
years in prison, three years of supervised release, and a fine of $250,000 or
twice the gross gain or loss, whichever is greater. The charge of false
statements in a tax return provides a sentence of no greater than three years in
prison, one year of supervised release, and a fine of $100,000. The charge of
tax evasion provides a sentence of no greater than five years in prison, three
years of supervised release, and a fine of $100,000. The charge of wire fraud
provides a sentence of no greater than 20 years in prison, three years of
supervised release, and a fine of $250,000 or twice the gross gain or loss,
whichever is greater. Actual sentences for federal crimes are typically less
than the maximum penalties. Sentences are imposed by a federal district court
judge based upon the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines and other statutory factors.
United States Attorney Carmen M. Ortiz; William P. Offord, Special Agent in
Charge of the Internal Revenue Service's Criminal Investigation in Boston; and
Joseph R. Bonavolonta, Acting Special Agent in Charge of the Federal Bureau of
Investigation, Boston Field Division, made the announcement today. The case is
being prosecuted by Karin M. Bell, Chief of Ortiz's Worcester Branch Office.

                                The Denver Post

                              June 24, 2011 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Daveco tax scam alleged The liquor superstore owners are named in a 52-count
theft and fraud indictment.

BYLINE: Monte Whaley The Denver Post

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 642 words


THORNTON - Hani "Henry" Sawaged likes to claim that his 102,000-square-foot
Daveco Liquors is the largest in the world.

When he finally got Guinness World Records to agree with him in 2008, he beamed
with pride.

"Now people know I am a man of my word," he said.

But all the while, authorities charged this week, he was running a tax-evasion
scam that cheated Thornton and the state out of at least $450,000 in sales-tax
revenue.

Sawaged and his brothers Ghassan "Gus" Sawaged and Bassam "Sam" Dahoud Sawaged
were listed on a 52-count indictment returned this week by a Denver County grand
jury charging the three with violating the Colorado Organized Crime Control Act.
The indictment also alleges several other felonies, including conspiracy to
commit theft and computer crime, theft-series, computer crime, tax violation,
filing a false tax return, tax evasion and conspiracy to commit tax evasion.

Prosecutors allege that from at least January 2007 through August 2008, the
Sawaged brothers logged fictitious merchandise returns and took $5.4 million in
cash from Daveco Liquors, which Hani Sawaged owned and operated.

They supposedly used at least $2 million of that cash to pay some of their
liquor distributors.

The result, say prosecutors, is the alleged underreporting and underpaying of
sales taxes to Thornton and the state, causing losses of more than $450,000.

"These are very serious allegations that involve a retail business that's very
high profile in the metro area," said Denver District Attorney's Office
spokeswoman Lynn Kimbrough. The Denver district attorney handled the indictment
because Daveco's bank account is with UMB Bank Colorado in Denver, Kimbrough
said.

The DA's office worked in conjunction with city of Thornton auditors and the
Department of Revenue.

The Sawaged family - which also own Davidson Liquors in Highlands Ranch - also
face allegations they have been operating a "hidden ownership," which is against
state liquor law. The Colorado Department of Revenue say family members acted as
agents for one another in purchases and contracts, even though they were not
licensed to do so.

A hearing on the Sawaged's liquor licenses is scheduled for October, said Mark
Couch, spokesman for the Department of Revenue. Of Thursday's indictment, Couch
would only say it "was significant."

Neither the Sawaged brothers nor their attorney Craig Truman could be reached
for comment.

Hani Sawaged - whose parents, four brothers and three sisters emigrated from
Jordan in 1979 - told The Denver Post in 2008 that he started Daveco in November
2006 to honor his father, David, who for years ran a 900-square- foot liquor
store in Thornton.

Hani Sawaged celebrated in 2008 when he received a certificate from Guinness
World Records declaring the store at Colorado 7 and Interstate 25 as the largest
liquor store in the world.

"I kept saying this is the world's largest liquor store, and people kept saying
'You can never prove that,"' Sawaged said.

Thornton auditors began looking at Daveco Liquors in September 2008 in a routine
check when they uncovered off-hour returns of merchandise and other suspicious
activity.

Prosecutors allege that 97 percent of all returns made at the store during the
scrutinized period were falsified. The indictment says most of the returns were
made either just before Daveco opened for the business day or immediately after
Daveco closed for the day.

The fictitious liquor returned includes Issac Hullio, Issac Heulio, Issac
Hiullio, Issm Beer, Don Pedro, DonPatro, Sddse, Wow Beer, Dss Beer, Base Beer,
Base Beer Acc, FYTU Wine and Good Wine.

Arrest warrants have been issued for all three brothers, and arrangements were
being made for their surrender, said Kimbrough. Their first court date has not
been set.

Staff writer Jessica Fender

contributed to this report.

Monte Whaley: 720-929-0907

or mwhaley@denverpost.com

                      Monterey County Herald (California)

                           February 4, 2010 Thursday

Ex-firm owner guilty of tax evasion

BYLINE: The Monterey County Herald Herald Staff Report

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 295 words


The former owner of a Salinas agricultural equipment firm has pleaded guilty to
a $221,000 tax evasion, admitting he diverted company money to pay for
Victoria's Secret purchases, a tae bo class and a trip to Legoland.

Curtis Leigh Parry, 66, entered the plea in federal court in San Jose, the U.S.
attorney and IRS announced. Parry, who was indicted in 2007, will be sentenced
May 13.

In his plea agreement, Parry admitted he diverted money from his company,
Salinas Valley Engineering & Manufacturing, Inc., through various schemes. Parry
owned the company from 1977 to 2003 and was its sole owner.

Parry had customers pay him directly for work or materials, then deposited the
money into his personal account, authorities said, without reporting it as
income.

Parry admitted he wrote corporate checks to himself and deposited the money in
his own account, falsely telling his bookkeeper that they were reimbursements
for business expenses.

Parry used an American Express corporate credit card for personal purchases for
himself and his family, the U.S. attorney and IRS said.

Parry admitted that starting in June 1999, he began sending money to Nigeria.
Between 1999 and 2002, he wired more than $300,000 in diverted corporate funds
overseas, authorities said. Parry conducted many of the transfers in structured
transactions in amounts less than $10,000.

Parry pleaded guilty to three counts of tax evasion and three counts of filing a
false corporate tax return.

The maximum penalty for tax evasion is five years in prison and a fine of
$250,000. The maximum penalty for each count of filing a false tax return is
three years imprisonment and a fine of $250,000. The sentence will be up to
Judge Jeremy Fogel.

Information about whether Parry made restitution was not available.

                                 Final Edition

Business Briefs

BYLINE: Hamilton Spectator wire services

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 1188  words


TAXATION

Ex-Frost Fence president fined for tax evasion

TORONTO Former Frost Fence president John Cameron has been fined $120,000 for
tax evasion. The former Burlington resident pleaded guilty.

He was charged after Canada Revenue Agency investigators found he did not
declare $441,992 of income from Frost Fence and other sources.

The investigation found, "that through the use of improper and omitted
accounting entries," money and inventory from Frost was used to pay Cameron's
personal debts and renovate his Burlington home.

The charges covered the tax years 1999 to 2001.

AUTOMOTIVE

Fort McMurray auto shops dinged over price-fixing

OTTAWA Canada's Competition Bureau has reached a settlement with six auto body
repair shops in Fort McMurray, Alta., over price fixing and price maintenance.

The agreement, which was announced yesterday, requires the companies to comply
with the Competition Act, stop setting fixed prices for vehicle repair work and
stop any communication on product prices or services.

The case involved Shamrock Maintenance & Hotshot Services Ltd., Pete's Custom
Coachwork, Birchwood Auto Body, Alberta Motor Products Ltd., Noral Motors and
Lane's Auto Shop.

The businesses agreed to run a corrective notice in a local newspaper.

"Conspiring to fix prices and price maintenance are criminal offences with
serious consequences," said Denyse MacKenzie, senior deputy commissioner of
competition.

UTILITIES

OPG profits surged to $490 million last year

TORONTO Ontario Power Generation said yesterday that full-year profits rose to
$490 million in 2006 as revenues declined.

For the year ended Dec. 31, the power generator said net income rose from $366
million a year earlier.

Revenues dipped to $5.6 billion from $5.8 billion. Earnings were affected by
lower gross margins from electricity sales due to lower average sale prices and
lower electricity generation from the previous year.

The provincial Crown corporation generated 105.2 terawatt-hours of electricity
over the year, compared to 108.5 terawatt-hours in 2005.

REAL ESTATE

Brookfield loses bid

for U.S. mall operator

INDIANAPOLIS Simon Property Group Inc. and Farallon Capital Management have
outbid Canada's Brookfield Asset Management to buy Maryland-based shopping mall
owner The Mills Corp. in a deal valued at $7.9 billion US.

The U.S. companies announced yesterday they had entered into a definitive
agreement to acquire The Mills for $25.25 US a share or about $1.64 billion in
cash. Including assumed debt and preferred stock, the deal has a value of $7.9
billion.

The Canadian company had agreed in January to buy The Mills for $21 US a share
or $1.35 billion.

INTERNET

Neteller dropping 220 jobs in Calgary

CALGARY Neteller PLC says it has cut 220 jobs in Calgary and is considering the
sale or partial lease of some of its facilities in the city as it responds to a
dramatic decrease in its North American business in recent months.

The online transaction processing company also announced yesterday that it will
cut 30 jobs in the United Kingdom as part of the latest downsizing move.
Neteller has been badly hurt by American legislation that makes it illegal to
pay for online gambling debts by credit card or debit card or other electronic
means.

RETAIL

Rona, workers hammer out nine-year contract

BOUCHERVILLE, Que. Hardware store chain Rona Inc. has signed a nine-year
collective agreement with employees at its Boucherville, Que., distribution
centre.

The contract was ratified by 92 per cent of the employees at the location.

The company has a workforce of more than 25,000 employees.

It generated $5.7 billion in annual sales last year.

FINANCIAL SERVICES

Scotiabank invests

in Puerto Rican growth

TORONTO Scotiabank said yesterday it will buy a 10 per cent stake in Puerto
Rico's First BanCorp. for about $94 million US.

The move is part of a plan to capitalize on growth in the Puerto Rican market.

The deal would give the Canadian bank an interest in the second-largest
financial holding company in the commonwealth. First BanCorp has total assets of
about $17.4 billion US.

FirstBank, a subsidiary of BanCorp, has portfolios in the commercial, consumer,
mortgage and auto areas, as well as insurance and auto leasing businesses.

The stake must meet regulatory approvals and other conditions.

Scotiabank already owns offices in Puerto Rico as part of its Scotiabank de
Puerto Rico subsidiary.

TELECOM

Telus Q4 profit soars

200 per cent to $236 million

VANCOUVER Telecom provider Telus Corp. reported yesterday a fourth-quarter
profit of $236.2 million, up 200 per cent or $78.5 million from a year ago on
strong growth in its wireless and data operations.

The Vancouver-based company said its earnings amounted to 69 cents per diluted
share, compared with 22 cents per share in the year-earlier period.

Actual revenues moved up 8 per cent to $2.25 billion from $2.09 billion in the
year-before period.

Telus said its earnings for the period included favourable tax-related
adjustments of about $20 million versus a charge of $33.5 million for financing
charges on its redemption of long-term debt and a one cent unfavourable impact
for tax-related adjustments.

ECONOMY

Falling energy prices

ease wholesale costs

WASHINGTON U.S. wholesale prices fell in January by the largest amount in three
months amid falling energy prices, while new home construction plunged to the
lowest level in nearly 10 years.

The U.S. Labor Department reported yesterday that wholesale inflation declined
0.6 per cent last month, helped by a 4.6 per cent drop in energy costs.

Meanwhile, construction of new homes and apartments plunged by 14.3 per cent in
January.

This pushed total activity down to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.408
million units, the slowest pace in nearly 10 years.

Applications for building permits, considered a good barometer of future
activity, fell as well in January, dropping by 2.8 per cent to an annual rate of
1.568 million units.

FORESTRY

Weyerhauser sells off

all of its Canadian centres

FEDERAL WAY, Wash. U.S. forestry giant Weyerhauser Co. is in final negotiations
to sell all its Canadian and 10 of its U.S. distribution centres to Los
Angeles-based Platinum Equity, the company said yesterday.

Financial terms were not disclosed.

The Canadian centres to be sold are: St. John's, N.L.; Dartmouth, N.S.; Sussex,
N.B.; Quebec City; Montreal; Ottawa; Brampton; Sudbury; Timmins; Regina;
Saskatoon; Winnipeg; Calgary; Edmonton; Kelowna and Langley, B.C.

TRANSPORT

American Airlines

on buyers' radar: magazine

DALLAS Shares of American Airlines' parent rose yesterday after Business Week
reported the company was the target of a private buyout bid by investors,
including Goldman Sachs and British Airways.

Analysts discounted the report that investors were trying to buy AMR Corp.,
noting that laws cap foreign ownership of a U.S. airline at 25 per cent.

The magazine reported in its Feb. 26 issue that the investor group is planning
to bid between $46 US and $52 US per share for AMR. That would represent a
healthy premium over AMR's closing price Thursday of $38.05. AMR shares closed
yesterday up 92 cents at $38.97 US. The magazine article was based on
unidentified sources.

                     The Columbian (Vancouver, Washington)

                             June 30, 2005 Thursday

Hotel owners convicted of federal tax evasion;
Couple 'declared independence from United States'

BYLINE: JOHN BRANTON, Columbian staff writer

SECTION: CLARK COUNTY/REGION; Pg. c1

LENGTH: 476 words


A Clark County couple who told jurors they weren't obligated to pay federal
income taxes on their hotel and motel business have been found guilty of tax
evasion and failing to file tax returns for five years.

The six-day trial of Kathy and Thomas Weathers in U.S. District Court in Tacoma
ended Tuesday.

The Weatherses own the Joyce and Kent hotels in Portland; the now-defunct
Century Plaza Hotel in Portland; and the Hudson Hotel and Oregon Way Motor Court
in the Longview area, said Katheryn Frierson, one of two assistant U.S.
attorneys who prosecuted the case. All are low-priced establishments, she said.

The Weatherses were indicted in September. They filed an income tax return in
1997, saying they owed about $103,000, but never paid it, officials said. For
1998 through 2002, they filed no tax returns.

Meanwhile, officials said, the Weatherses' lodging business was grossing more
than $1 million per year.

In the trial, Frierson said, "They said they declared their independence from
the United States, rejecting the authority of federal law."

During an investigation led by Vancouver Internal Revenue Service Special Agent
Dan Wardlaw, Thomas Weathers sent the IRS a document declaring that he was
"sovereign" and "not subject to any entity or jurisdiction anywhere," according
to a bulletin from the U.S. Attorney's Office in Seattle.

In addition, Frierson said, Thomas Weathers told officials that his name was his
own property and that Wardlaw was liable for fines of $500,000 for each time he
used the name.

"I think he said something to the effect that he had copyrighted his name,"
Frierson said.

Officials said the Weatherses filed false statements with the IRS and set up
shell corporations to avoid taxes.

The Weatherses, who told The Columbian they live in the Salmon Creek area, said
they likely will appeal the conviction.

"There's nothing in the tax laws that shows we are liable," Thomas Weathers said
Wednesday. He is 54 and his wife is 52.

Weathers said he decided around 1997 to stop filing income tax returns. He said
an explanation of his beliefs can be found in the book "Cracking the Code," sold
on the Lost Horizons Web site at www.losthorizons.com.

The $19.95 book claims that many Americans who believe they are subject to tax
laws are not. One chapter is entitled "Lies, Damned Lies, and W-2s."

A link to the Web site reads it's the "home of the startling and liberating
truth about the income tax."

The Weathers are free pending their sentencing in Tacoma on Sept. 14.

The Weatherses' tax evasion conviction carries a maximum sentence of five years
in prison, Frierson said. They also were convicted of five counts of failing to
file tax returns, which can bring a sentence of up to one year for each count.

John Branton covers crime and law enforcement for The Columbian. He can be
reached at 360-759-8012 or john.branton@columbian.com.

                                   USA TODAY

                    July 22, 1992, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

Helmsley visits ill husband

BYLINE: Bethany Kandel

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 2A

LENGTH: 209 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Imprisoned hotel queen Leona Helmsley had a special 12-hour prison leave Tuesday
to be at the bedside of her husband, Harry, who had emergency surgery.

Helmsley, 72, accompanied by two guards from the federal prison in Danbury,
Conn., had a teary reunion with her husband at New York Hospital.

When they saw each other, ''Harry broke out into tears,'' said Howard
Rubenstein, Helmsley's spokesman. ''He said, 'Leona, I really need you.' ''

After the operation - to relieve a buildup of fluid on the brain - Harry
Helmsley, 83, seemed alert and ''requested his favorite chicken soup,''
Rubenstein said.

By early afternoon, Leona Helmsley had to return to prison, where she is serving
a four-year tax evasion sentence.

Bureau of Prisons spokesman Dan Dunne said any non-violent inmate in prison more
than 90 days can request an ''escorted trip'' for medical or other reasons.

Helmsley had to pay for the trip herself, Dunne said.

She was convicted in 1989 of evading $ 1.7 million in taxes by billing personal
expenses, such as renovations on her mansion, to her companies. She began
serving her sentence in April and will be eligible for parole next year.

Her husband also was charged, but a judge ruled he was too ill to stand trial.

                               The New York Times

                July 19, 1986, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

POSNER CONVICTED ON TAXES

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section 1; Page 37, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 444 words

DATELINE: MIAMI, July 18


A Federal jury convicted the millionaire financier Victor Posner today of
evading $1.2 million in Federal income taxes on a gift of 22 acres to a small
Christian college.

The 12-member jury, which deliberated 14 hours over two days, found Mr. Posner
guilty on four counts of tax evasion, five counts of making false statements and
one count of conspiracy to defraud the Government.

The Miami Beach investor and corporate raider, who is 67 years old, could be
sentenced to as many as 40 years in prison and a $75,000 fine. Federal District
Judge Eugene P. Spellman set sentencing for Sept. 19.

The judge and prosecutors agreed to a defense request to allow Mr. Posner to
remain free while his lawyers appeal the verdict.

Value of Land at Issue

In the trial, the prosecution had argued that Mr. Posner evaded $1.2 million in
taxes by inflating the value of two tracts of land, totaling 22 acres, that he
donated to Miami Christian College.

In closing arguments Wednesday, the defense attorney, Edward Bennett Williams,
said the tax-evasion dispute should have been settled between Mr. Posner and the
Internal Revenue Service. He challenged the jurors to convict Mr. Posner of
everything or nothing.

Mr. Williams said that Mr. Posner had paid a higher percentage of his income to
the Government - 67 percent of $8.2 million in taxable income that he earned
from 1975 to 1979 -than almost every American.

Prosecutors noted that Mr. Posner's gross income in that time was $13 million.

The charges covered tax deductions on two parcels: 16 acres appraised by Mr.
Posner for tax deductions at $125,000 an acre and assessed for property taxes at
$7,500 an acre in 1975 and six acres appraised at $175,000 an acre and assessed
at $9,000 an acre in 1978.

Expectations of Development

Mr. Williams contended that Mr. Posner's deductions on the donated land had been
justified because the financier believed the land was suited for a shopping
center even though it carried residential zoning.

Mr. Posner, whose personal fortune has been estimated at $100 million, dropped
out of school in Baltimore at the age of 13 and made his first million by 25
through investments in real estate. Later, his aggressive investments and
mergers built his present network of more than 40 companies, forming a $4
billion multifaceted empire that has shown signs of unraveling recently.

The Evans Products Company, a building materials and transportation concern that
is 42.5 percent owned by Mr. Posner's NVF Company, filed for bankruptcy
protection last year. Another Posner holding, the Sharon Steel Corporation, has
said that it might seek protection from creditors.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                           November 5, 2015 Thursday

Alaska Plastic Surgeon Convicted of Wire Fraud and Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 391  words


Doctor Hid Millions in Secret Accounts in Panama

An Alaskan plastic surgeon was convicted today of four counts of wire fraud and
three counts of tax evasion by a federal jury sitting in Anchorage, Alaska,
announced Acting Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo of the Justice
Department's Tax Division and U.S. Attorney Karen Loeffler of the District of
Alaska.

Dr. Michael Brandner, 67, was convicted following a seven-day jury trial before
U.S. District Judge Sharon Gleason of the District of Alaska.  According to the
indictment and evidence introduced at trial, in late 2007, shortly after
Brandner's wife filed for divorce, he collected millions of dollars in marital
assets and secretly drove from Tacoma, Washington, to Costa Rica in Central
America.  In Costa Rica, he opened two bank accounts into which he deposited
more than $350,000 in cash and hid a thousand ounces of gold in a safe deposit
box.  He then traveled to Panama where he opened an account under the name of a
sham corporation and in 2008, deposited $4.6 million into the account.

Dr. Brandner concealed both the existence of the bank accounts and the interest
he earned on those accounts from the court in the divorce proceedings and from
the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).  Dr. Brandner owed the IRS $600,000 in
additional taxes for the 2008 through 2010 tax years.  He presented the divorce
court with a fabricated promissory note to mislead the court into believing he
had invested more than $3 million in the foreign corporation.

In 2011, once the divorce was final, Dr. Brandner repatriated more than $4.6
million, only to have the funds seized by Homeland Security Investigations
agents.  He then lied to federal agents about his control of the funds.

At his March 7, 2016 sentencing, Dr. Brandner faces a statutory maximum penalty
of 20 years in prison for each count of wire fraud and five years for each count
of tax evasion and a fine of up to $250,000, or twice the gain or loss caused by
the offense, on each of the seven counts of conviction.

Acting Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo thanked the special agents of
IRS-Criminal Investigation, who investigated the case and Trial Attorney Ignacio
Perez de la Cruz of the Tax Division and Assistant U.S. Attorney Bryan Schroder
of the District of Alaska, who prosecuted the case. 2015 Legal Monitor
Worldwide.

                               The New York Times

                  April 5, 1991, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Did Race Inspire The Flake Case? Maybe, He Says

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section B; Page 5; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 577 words


A day after the prosecution ended his embezzlement and tax-evasion trial, Floyd
H. Flake, the Queens Congressman and minister, said there could have been a
racial motive in his prosecution.

But Mr. Flake, who is black, also said that the motive could have been
"political," or that he could have been the target of prosecutors pursuing a
"high-profile case" for "career advancement."

Later, he was greeted warmly by his supporters at various stops in his
congressional district, the Sixth.

In a news conference at his office in St. Albans, Queens, Mr. Flake did not say
that Government investigators were giving him and other prominent blacks special
attention. But he did suggest that the standards for prosecuting black political
figures and those for white politicians were different.

"I wouldn't say they necessarily target them," he said when asked if he believed
that Federal prosecutors specifically set their sights on black leaders.

Distinction Drawn

But citing two major criminal cases in the last decade in which white members of
Congress were prosecuted, he said: "If you look at an Abscam or Wedtech, you're
talking about major scandals which involve numerous people, and it was very
clear that those were criminal cases. If you look at the majority of those black
indictments, they're not brought with major scandals; generally they're tax
issues." He did not cite specific cases in which blacks were indicted.

Many blacks, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, have viewed the Flake case as an
example of selective prosecution of black elected officials by the Federal
Government.

"I would not specifically say that," Mr. Flake said yesterday as reporters
pressed him on whether he believed there had been a racial motive in his
prosecution. But he then cited such a motive as one possibility among others,
like political and career advancement.

The United States Attorney in Brookyn, Andrew J. Maloney, whose office brought
the case, again vigorously denied that race or politics had figured in the
indictment of Mr. Flake and his wife, Margarett.

"I would bring this kind of case again tomorrow against any public official or
any individual," Mr. Maloney said.

The Flakes were charged with tax evasion and embezzlement of $75,000 in Federal
housing funds related to an apartment complex for the elderly operated by the
church where Mr. Flake is the pastor, the Allen African Methodist Episcopal
Church.

At the request of prosecutors, the charges were dismissed in Federal Court in
Brooklyn on Wednesday, days after the judge, Eugene H. Nickerson, hinted that
their case was shaky.

The Justice Department plans to review the prosecution, an agency official said
yesterday. Such a review occurs whenever the Government loses a major case,
those familiar with the agency's practices said.

Warm Greetings

As he had earlier, the 46-year-old Congressman said yesterday that any financial
irregularities had been innocent "bookkeeping" problems.

Later, he visited places in his district where some of his most ardent
supporters could be found.

Amid a burst of applause as he entered the lunchroom at the Allen Community
Senior Citizen Center, Mr. Flake was embraced by Sallie Wright, 70, who
exclaimed, "Thank God!"

In the House of Beauty, a salon on Merrick Boulevard, Mr. Flake kissed the women
there, and when he stepped back out on the street, a motorist honked his horn
and yelled, "Victory!"

charges of tax evasion and embezzlement on Wednesday, Representative Floyd H.
Flake, foreground, met with members of his church in Queens. (John Sotomayor/The

                               The New York Times

                February 23, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Fifth Guilty Plea in a U.S. Housing Inquiry

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 246 words

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 22


A former executive director of the Perth Amboy Housing Authority pleaded guilty
to bribery and tax evasion Wednesday, the fifth person in less than a week to
admit guilt in Federal District Court here to corruption involving contracts for
federally financed housing.

United States Attorney Samuel A. Alito Jr. has said more guilty pleas or
criminal charges can be expected involving at least four other municipal
agencies. The Federal Bureau of Investigation began the investigation in the
spring of 1987, partly on the basis of tips called in to a white-collar crime
hot line.

The former Perth Amboy official, Anthony J. Slotwinski, 55 years old, of Edison,
told Judge Harold A. Ackerman that he took about $100,000 in bribes from a
contractor, Alfred Bressaw, between 1984 and 1988 in exchange for $1.2 million
in contracts.

Last Friday Mr. Bressaw, 51, owner of an electrical repair company in
Woodbridge, pleaded guilty to one charge of income-tax evasion.

Mr. Slotwinski also pleaded guilty to one count of tax evasion for not paying
$17,000 in taxes owed on about $45,000 in bribes from Mr. Bressaw in 1985. He
faces a maximum of 15 years in prison and $500,000 in fines.

On Jan. 22, two days after a Federal audit uncovered millions in questionable
spending at the Passaic Public Housing Authority, Jack Kemp, the Housing and
Urban Development Secretary, suspended five Passaic housing officials and
ordered a review of all 80 New Jersey housing authorities.
