                                  The Business

                                  July 7, 2002

A LONG-AWAITED REPORT INTO IRELAND'S BIGGEST FINANCIAL SCANDAL, PUBLISHED
ONSATURDAY, PAINTED A DAMNING PICTURE OF LARGE-SCALE TAX EVASION BY MEMBERS OF
THEBUSINESS AND POLITICAL ELITE

LENGTH: 690 words


A long-awaited report into Ireland's biggest financial scandal, published on
Saturday, painted a damning picture of large-scale tax evasion by members of
thebusiness and political elite. The inquiry into an offshore banking scheme
which operated from the late 1970s to the late 1990s, has drawn huge interest in
Ireland amid allegations that a "golden circle" avoided paying millions when
Irish people faced some of the highest tax rates in Europe. In a statement,
Deputy Prime Minister Mary Harney said: "The report concludes unambiguously
thata variety of individuals and corporations knowingly promoted widespread tax
evasion." The report delves into the operations of the Ansbacher (Cayman) Ltd
Bank, naming 190 clients of the bank, among them former Prime Minister Charles
Haughey.

TROUBLED fund manager, Aberdeen Asset Management (AAM), will face a UK Treasury
Select Committee inquiry into split capital investment trusts this week. AAM is
the only company to be called to the hearing, with chief executive Martin
Gilbert set to give evidence on Thursday. The Financial Services Authority, the
main UK financial services regulator, and the Association of Investment Trust
Companies (AITC) have also been called to give evidence to the committee. AAM
has 19 split-cap trusts of which eight face serious difficulties.

DIY retailer Homebase has hit back against its former owners Sainsbury which is
suing it over a £240m (E375m) sale and leaseback property deal. Sainsbury issued
a writ in the High Court in January to claim back the £8.5m (E13m) it paid
Homebase for a Nottingham property in a disagreement over the freehold of the
property, as well as VAT and interest totalling another £2m (E3.2m). Now
Homebase has retaliated by issuing a counter writ to recover damages of £1.2m
(E1.9m) over losses caused by interruption to business during the December 2000
sale and leaseback agreement .

CSN, the Brazilian steel manufacturer which is holding merger discussions with
Anglo-Dutch steel maker Corus, is in parallel talks with US steel groups which
could affect any deal. CSN is in talks with Bethlehem Steel of Pennsylvania as
part of a plan either to buy the group's Sparrow Point mill or form a joint
venture in which Bethlehem would process cheap iron ore sourced from CSN.
Bethlehem filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last year after heavy
foreign competition. Talks have been going on for six months and CSN is also
thought to be in discussions with United States Steel about an alliance. Corus
said last week it is in early discussions about issuing new shares to provide
CSN with a 30-40% holding.

The number of shutdowns and bankruptcies by dot.com companies in the first half
of 2002 fell 73% from the same period last year, reports San Francisco
researcher Webmergers.com., fuelling US hopes that the internet sector may be
nearing the end of its shakeout.

British trade and industry secretary Patricia Hewitt announced the launch of a
public private alliance to protect the £5bn (E7.8bn) motor sport industry on the
eve of Sunday's British Grand Prix at Silverstone. The new partnership will work
to fight off competitive threats to the industry, and examine the best waysto
develop and enhance the UK's position in motor sport technology. The
announcement follows recent threats to the industry, which almost saw the UK
lose its annual grand prix. Hewitt also said that the British government will
launch a new independent study to highlight key issues facing the motor sport
industry.

ACTIVISTS called on Saturday for more funds to fight AIDS and the poverty
fuelling the epidemic on the eve of the 14th international AIDS conference. New
figures show 40m people are living with the virus and the numbers are expected
to rise to 100m within a decade. The majority of cases are in the world's
poorest countries.

SINGAPORE and the European Union have discussed the possibility of forming a
free trade pact, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said on Saturday. Goh met
EuropeanCommission President Romano Prodi on the second day of his three-day
first official visit to Singapore.

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                             April 26, 2016 Tuesday

Man dubbed Shurtleff's 'fixer' to stand trial

LENGTH: 666 words


By McKenzie Romero

Deseret News

SALT LAKE CITY - A man who once called himself a "fixer" for former Utah
Attorney General Mark Shurtleff was ordered Monday to stand trial on charges
including tax evasion and obstructing justice.

At the beginning of what was set to be a three-day preliminary hearing Monday,
Timothy William Lawson, 51, waived the hearing and an arraignment was set for
June 20.

Lawson is charged with pattern of unlawful activity, a second-degree felony; tax
evasion, a third-degree felony; retaliation against a witness, a third-degree
felony; and two third-degree felony counts of obstruction of justice.

A friend to both Shurtleff and his successor, John Swallow, Lawson was charged
in December 2013, about a month after Swallow resigned facing allegations the
two top law enforcers traded favors for preferential treatment by the attorney
general's office.

Shurtleff and Swallow were hit in July 2014 with felony charges ranging from
accepting bribes to destroying evidence. Swallow returns to court July 13, while
a jury trial for Shurtleff is set to begin Oct. 25.

According to prosecutors, Lawson used his friendship with Shurtleff and Swallow
to influence others using intimidation and aggressive tactics, mostly behind the
scenes. According to court documents, Lawson in 2008 represented himself as a
man close to Shurtleff to then-wealthy businessman Marc Sessions Jenson, who was
facing securities fraud charges at the time.

Court documents allege Lawson had a hand in coordinating a lenient plea deal
that Shurtleff personally proposed for Jenson, requiring a plea in abeyance with
no jail time or restitution.

A judge subsequently rejected the deal but approved an amended plea deal that
had no jail time but included $4.1 million in restitution. Jenson was ordered to
prison in November 2013 for failing to pay that restitution and was released on
parole in October. The Utah Board of Pardons and Parole last month found that
Jenson still hasn't paid restitution.

In the midst of Jenson's 2008 case, prosecutors say Lawson arranged for meetings
between Shurtleff and Swallow, who had not yet been elected, at the posh Pelican
Hill Resort in Southern California where the businessman lived, all on Jenson's
dime.

Lawson also allegedly got involved in the failed billion-dollar development
known as Mt. Holly Resort that Jenson and his brother, Stephen Jenson, tried to
build in Beaver County. When the deal crumbled, a Colorado doctor who had
invested in the project wanted his money back.

According to court documents, Lawson sent several aggressive text messages and
emails to the doctor to dissuade him from providing testimony for any possible
investigation or legal action. Lawson also threatened to reveal supposed illegal
activity in the doctor's medical practice.

A jury acquitted Jenson of fraud charges in connection from the failed resort
last year. His brother accepted a plea deal partway through he trial.

Last month, new charges were filed against Lawson alleging communications fraud,
theft by deception and making false or inconsistent material statements, all
second-degree felonies.

Lawson told the Social Security Administration's Office of Disability
Adjudication and Review on April 13, 2012, that he had not worked since January
of 2009, according to charging documents. In another hearing in 2013, he again
allegedly stated he hadn't worked since January of 2009 while also stating in
the same hearing that he works five hours a week.

Jenson, however, told prosecutors that he paid Lawson $120,000 in 2009 for
consultant work, according to the charges. In other court documents, prosecutors
have said that money was paid for access to Shurtleff.

Between February of 2014 and June of 2015, Lawson received more than $32,000
from the Social Security Administration, and his seven children received more
than $54,000, according to court records.

A scheduling conference in that case has also been set for June 20.

Twitter: McKenzieRomero

                              The Washington Post

                             March 17, 2009 Tuesday
                                Suburban Edition

Federal City Digest

SECTION: A-SECTION; Pg. A13

LENGTH: 491 words

Pyramid Power

In the wake of the exposure of pyramid schemes far more substantial and of
longer duration than anything that Charles Ponzi, shown at left in the 1930s,
ever dreamt up, the Senate Finance Committee holds a hearing today at 10 a.m. on
"Tax Issues Related to Ponzi Schemes and an Update on Offshore Tax Evasion
Legislation."

Sure to be on the table: draft legislation to crack down on offshore tax evasion
by increasing Internal Revenue Service reporting requirements that Sen. Max
Baucus (D-Mont.), who chairs the committee, began circulating earlier in March.
Sen. Carl Levin (Mich.) has also introduced legislation on the topic, taking the
different tack of proposing to tax offshore hedge and private equity funds
managed and controlled stateside.

Baucus and the panel's ranking Republican, Sen. Charles Grassley (Iowa), will
make statements before taking testimony from IRS Commissioner Douglas Shulman,
Government Accountability Office director of tax issues Michael Brostek, and
William Josephson of the law firm Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson.

WHAT TO WATCH

--  After President Obama's victory last fall, a song by Irish comic singers
Hardy Drew and the Nancy Boys (now known as the Corrigan Brothers) swept across
the Web. "There's No One as Irish as Barack Obama" hailed the new 44th
president's distant roots in the Irish village of Moneygall. Today, the
president who used to give out "O'Bama" shamrock buttons on St. Patrick's Day in
Chicago meets with Irish Taoiseach (Prime Minister) Brian Cowen at the White
House in the morning; later, the two attend the annual St. Patrick's Day lunch
hosted by the House speaker's office at the Capitol. In the evening, Obama hosts
the annual White House St. Patrick's Day reception.

--  Talk about a mobile home: YouthBuild AmeriCorps students do preliminary work
today building a "green" home on the Mall as part of a demonstration of the
skills learned in their growing green-jobs program. The home will then be
transported to Brownsville, Tex., for completion and given to a single mother
there whose mobile home was damaged last summer by Hurricane Dolly.

At 10:30 a.m., first lady Michelle Obama visits the building site near the
Capitol reflecting pool to delivers remarks; the stimulus bill included $50
million for the federal YouthBuild program.

--  Also at 10:30, the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on crime and drugs and the
Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control hold a joint hearing on "Law
Enforcement Responses to Mexican Drug Cartels." Experts from both sides of the
border testify.

--  At 11:15, Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.), above, lays out what he would have
done if he were president in a speech to the Heritage Foundation, "Generational
Theft: The Fleecing of America's Children." Topics include McCain's "own
stimulus plan . . . and an alternative vision for the proper role of the federal
government."

                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                           January 29, 2005 Saturday
                                 Idaho Edition

North Idaho businessman convicted;
Hinkson could get 20-year term for soliciting;
murder of judge, prosecutor, IRS agent

BYLINE: Bill Morlin Staff writer

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 594 words


A wealthy North Idaho businessman with ties to the militia movement was
convicted Friday on three counts of soliciting the murders of a federal judge, a
prosecutor and an IRS agent involved in a previous tax evasion case against him.

David Roland Hinkson, called a "hard-core patriot" by his anti-government
associates, faces up to 20 years in prison when he is sentenced in April for
soliciting the murders of Judge Edward Lodge, Assistant U.S. Attorney Nancy Cook
and IRS agent Steven M. Hines.

The 48-year-old multimillionaire, who lived in a rural area near Grangeville and
owned a company called WaterOz, was convicted Friday in Boise following a
three-week jury trial in U.S. District Court.

Defense attorney Wesley Hoyt said he would appeal the conviction.

"The evidence against Mr. Hinkson was presented by witnesses who had an economic
stake in the outcome in the sense that they were seeking to take over his
business or seeking large judgments from him," Hoyt told the Associated Press.

Trial testimony and evidence, including tape-recorded statements made by Hinkson
to an informant, revealed he offered a $10,000 bounty for the assassination of
each of the three federal officials.

Hinkson attempted to hire a hit man after he was indicted in July 2002 on
multiple counts of income tax evasion, and later released pending trial. The
solicitation was made to three individuals associated with a militia group known
as the Idaho County Posse, federal investigators said.

The IRS agent investigated the income tax case against Hinkson, and Cook
presented the case to a grand jury, resulting in the indictment. The case was
assigned to Lodge.

Hinkson's and his militia friends' anger toward the federal judge began after
Lodge dismissed a charge against an FBI sniper charged with the 1992 shooting
death of Vicki Weaver at Ruby Ridge, Idaho.

The jury acquitted Hinkson of three other counts related to a separate
solicitation to murder the same individuals and two counts of making threats
against the immediate family members of the prosecutor and IRS agent.

"Trying to put a hit on a federal judge, a prosecutor and an agent is an
egregious attack on our system of justice and the rule of law," Assistant
Attorney General Christoper Way said in a statement released by the Department
of Justice in Washington, D.C.

"We are grateful to the jury for recognizing this and providing justice for
these victims who were simply doing their jobs in the pursuit of justice," Wray
said.

Hinkson still awaits sentencing on a separate multiple-count conviction last
summer for selling adulterated and misbranded drugs, and income tax evasion.

He was arrested April 4, 2003, by agents of the Inland Northwest Joint Terrorism
Task Force, based in Spokane, and the Idaho County Sheriff's Department. He has
been in jail since then.

Hinkson lived in rural Idaho County, near his manufacturing plant that produced,
bottled and distributed WaterOz, an ionic water solution sold internationally
through multilevel marketing.

The water product was bottled with various minerals and marketed with claims it
could cure such maladies as AIDS, ringworm, multiple sclerosis, incontinence and
cancer.

The case was prosecuted by Michael P. Sullivan and Michael Taxay of the criminal
division of the Justice Department's headquarters. The U.S. Attorney's Office in
Idaho was excused from the prosecution because the charges stated that one of
its prosecutors was a victim.

The case was assigned to visiting Judge Richard C. Tallman because Lodge is a
judge for the District of Idaho.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                    July 28, 2004 Wednesday Michigan Edition

Man admits to offshore tax evasion;
Plea agreement with federal authorities calls for possible other trial
testimony.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW S. GALBRAITH; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D3

LENGTH: 396 words


SOUTH BEND -- A federal judge has accepted a South Bend man's guilty plea to tax
evasion charges and set sentencing for Dec. 21.

During that time, Douglas Gilman may be called to testify against individuals
who are due to stand trial in connection with an alleged offshore tax fraud
scheme.

Gilman, 45, faces up to a five-year sentence on each of the four tax evasion
counts he admitted Monday. His cooperation with the government and possible
testimony will work in his favor.

He also has agreed to pay restitution of $112,500, the amount of his tax loss.

A criminal complaint filed recently accused Gilman of filing false income tax
returns on behalf of himself and his wife, Gayle, each year from 1998 to 2001.

Gilman admitted in the plea agreement that he set up a series of companies,
including an offshore entity, for the purpose of decreasing the profits of a
corporation that were reflected in the couple's personal income taxes.

In court, Gilman said he paid $20,000 to participate in the scheme to Anderson
Ark, a Costa Rica offshore trust program the government has accused of helping
clients obtain more than $30 million in illegal tax refunds.

Several indictments have been returned in the United States in connection with
Anderson Ark.

Gilman's plea agreement is one of the first in the South Bend district to
include a Blakely waiver. That refers to a recent case before the U.S. Supreme
Court, Blakely v. Washington.

The court ruled that judges may consider only facts reflected in a jury's
verdict or a defendant's admission at the time of sentencing. One of the many
questions the decision has raised is whether it applies to the federal
sentencing guidelines.

The waiver in Gilman's case will allow U.S. District Judge Robert L. Miller Jr.
to find, among other things, the defendant was not a minor participant in the
offense and sophisticated means were used to accomplish it.

In his favor, the government will recommend to the judge that he has accepted
responsibility for his actions.

The judge will use those factors, plus any other government request for a
sentence reduction based on his cooperation, to determine the length of the
sentence.

The case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service's Criminal
Investigative Division.

mgalbraith@sbtinfo.com

(574) 235-6359

                                US Official News

                            December 15, 2014 Monday

Former Bellevue Developer Convicted Of Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 529  words

DATELINE: Richmond


United States Attorney's Office for the Western District of Virginia has issued
the following press release:

A former Bellevue based developer and lender who spent millions on gambling,
thoroughbred horse racing, private aircraft, country club fees, a Bellevue
penthouse, and two Palm Springs, California, homes was convicted late yesterday
of two counts of tax evasion following a nine day jury trial, announced Acting
United States Attorney Annette L. Hayes.   THOMAS R. HAZELRIGG, III, 68, of
Redmond, Washington, was indicted in July 2013.  The jury deliberated three and
a half hours before finding HAZELRIGG guilty.  He faces up to five years in
prison on each count when sentenced by U.S. District Judge Thomas S. Zilly on
March 12, 2015.

"This trial laid bare Mr. Hazelrigg's wide ranging deceit and manipulation --
all in the service of greed," said Acting United States Attorney Annette L.
Hayes.  "The failure to pay taxes -- especially by someone with this defendant's
financial means -- tears at the fabric of our public trust.  When Mr. Hazelrigg
chose not to pay his fair share, he effectively cheated everyone."

Evidence presented at trial described how HAZELRIGG first agreed to pay $533,454
in taxes owed for tax years 1989, 1990 and 1991 and then failed to pay the tax
debt while living a lavish lifestyle that included multi-million dollar property
purchases and remodels and expensive artwork. HAZELRIGG also evaded payment of
his taxes owed for 1994, for which he had filed a return showing tax owed, but
for which he made no payments.  According to testimony at trial, between 1997
and 2007, HAZELRIGG illegally funneled income from his businesses into accounts
that he controlled but that he kept secret from the IRS. HAZELRIGG used these
accounts to pay for the multimillion dollar purchase and remodel of a Bellevue
penthouse, two Chihuly glass chandeliers worth more than $460,000, and two
luxury homes in Palm Springs, California.  HAZELRIGG used these secret accounts
to pay various household expenses including the use of a butler.

"Thomas Hazelrigg III, wrongly thought he could hide from his tax liability,"
stated Special Agent in Charge Teri Alexander of IRS Criminal Investigation.
"What makes this case so egregious is that he consented that he owed the tax and
then immediately took exceptional actions to avoid his obligation to pay, all
while living a lavish lifestyle. This verdict today sends a strong message that
tax evasion will not and cannot be tolerated.  Americans who pay their fair
share can be confident that IRS Criminal Investigation will pursue those who do
not."

HAZELRIGG hid his assets for ten years, until the IRS liens expired.  After the
liens were removed, HAZELRIGG sent an email saying he was "legit again."
Following that email, HAZELRIGG took out loans in his own name, and purchased a
condo in his own name.

The case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation
(IRS-CI).  The case was prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorneys Matthew
Diggs and Brian Werner.

Man convicted on charges / of mail fraud, tax evasion

PEORIA -- A Gibson City man faces a Feb. 19 sentencing on federal mail fraud and
tax evasion charges.

Carl Keiser, 61, was convicted by a federal jury last week of mail fraud and
illegal application of a pesticide inconsistent with its labeling. He was
previously convicted of four counts of tax evasion.

The defendant owned and operated Aquatic Control of Illinois, a business located
at his Gibson City Fishing and Camping Club.

During a weeklong trial in October, federal prosecutors presented evidence that
Kieser purchased large quantities of Diuron 80DF, a pesticide used for weed
control.

According to the government, Kieser mixed the pesticide with other ingredients
and sold it as a product to control lake weeds and algae.

Kieser sold and distributed the product from July 2007 to September 2012 and
earned more than $400,000 but failed to pay federal income tax from 2008 to
2011, said a statement from the U.S. attorney's office for the Central District
of Illinois.

"The guilty verdict is the result of strong coordination between EPA and our law
enforcement partners," said Randall Ashe, special agent in charge of the
Environmental Protection Agency's criminal enforcement program in Illinois.

Kieser faces 20 years in prison and fines up to $250,000 on mail fraud; five
years and fines of $100,000 for tax evasion and a year in jail with $50,000
fines for labeling offenses.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Eugene L. Miller is handling the case.

                              Daily Nation (Kenya)

                            October 21, 2014 Tuesday

ONYONYI : Recognise and reward top taxpayers and you'll be on the way to total
compliance

BYLINE: KENNEDY ONYONYI -1

LENGTH: 739  words


Three years ago while trying to get my bearing at a train station in
Pennsylvania, USA, I approached a man for assistance. He happened to be heading
to the University of Pennsylvania which, coincidentally, was my final
destination.

Three years ago while trying to get my bearing at a train station in
Pennsylvania, USA, I approached a man for assistance. He happened to be heading
to the University of Pennsylvania which, coincidentally, was my final
destination.
He was a Kenyan working for the World Bank. When I told him I worked for the
Kenya Revenue Authority, there was a sudden glow on his face. He narrated an
incident during a World Bank mission to Kenya when KRA rejected a World Bank
grant to support its  reform programmes. That was the first time in his
five-year career at the Bank to witness a developing country rejecting aid.


Over-reliance on aid has trapped developing nations in a vicious cycle of
dependency, corruption, market distortion and further poverty leaving them with
nothing but the need for more aid.
However, Kenya has freed itself from the shackles of dependency. Besides
mobilising resources through taxes which currently stand at 24 per cent of the
GDP, Kenya has registered significant increases in remittance by its nationals
overseas, which currently by far outstrip aid inflow. As a result the government
is able to finance 95 per cent of its expenditure using internally generated
resources.
Top taxpayers were Tuesday feted by the President at a ceremony that has
entrenched itself in the calendar of priority activities of the government.
To appreciate the rationale behind honouring compliant taxpayers, one must
acknowledge the key deterrents of tax evasion.
There are three steps in the staircase to tax evasion: first the taxpayer must
have the will not to comply. Secondly not everyone with inclination to evade
taxes is able to do it, and lastly, individuals inclined to avoid tax seek
opportunities to do so.
Tax administrations have over the years employed the use of coercive instruments
to solve the social dilemma of tax evasion, and Kenya Revenue Authority is no
exception.
However, over the past decade, there has been a gradual shift from deterring
non-compliance to positive encouragement of compliance, therefore emphasising
the 'carrot' rather than the stick.
Instead of raising the relative cost of not paying taxes, the instrument of
rewards raises the benefits of doing so. Rewards could be more effective than
punishments in eliminating undesirable behaviour.
JAMES MWANGI
The value attached to recognition and reward is amazing. While at KRA, taxpayers
would approach me to advise them on what to do to be recognised as top
taxpayers. They would go out of their way and 'sacrifice' the massive 'gains' to
take a picture with the President.  Earlier this year, the Nation serialised the
wealthiest people in Kenya. After carefully going through the list, my findings
corroborated the theory that the more wealth one amasses, the higher the
intrinsic motivation to evade paying tax.
Ordinarily, one would expect the wealthiest Kenyans to be the top taxpayers.
From the list that was published, only Dr James Mwangi regularly features among
the top taxpayers! Where are the rest?
This puts the relevance of policy instruments in damaging intrinsic motivation
not to pay taxes to the fore. Tax morale is not dampened if stricter policy is
directed at dishonest taxpayers irrespective of their status in society.
Regulations which prevent free riding by others help to preserve tax morale.
The KRA compliance model is one of the most progressive in the world. Severe
action is taken against tax evaders while support is extended to the compliant.
What is unique about the model is that it gives prominence to recognition and
reward without compromising the importance of coercive instruments of
compliance.
The government has played a significant role in spurring compliance by
initiating visible development projects. To be ranked the third best performing
government in the continent after being in power for hardly a year is by no
means a minor achievement.
Taxpayers can see the product of their sacrifice. This conforms with the norm of
reciprocity. The more the government provides public services, the more
taxpayers are willing to comply.
Mr Onyonyi is the director of Institutional Development and Capacity Building at
the African Tax Administration Forum, Pretoria.

                               The New York Times

                            January 9, 2010 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

Ex-UBS Banker Reports to Prison

BYLINE: By BLOOMBERG NEWS

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 205 words


Bradley Birkenfeld, an informant in a federal investigation of offshore tax
evasion aided by UBS, reported to a federal prison in Pennsylvania on Friday to
start a 40-month prison term that he denounced as unfair.

Mr. Birkenfeld, who pleaded guilty in 2008 to conspiracy, told reporters he
should not be jailed for revealing how UBS  helped wealthy Americans evade
taxes.

UBS avoided prosecution in the United States by agreeing to pay $780 million,
disclosing data on more than 250 Swiss accounts, and admitting it helped foster
tax evasion. In August, UBS agreed to hand over data on another 4,450 accounts.

''I'd like to say how proud I am to be courageous enough to come forward to do
what I did to expose the largest tax fraud in the world,'' Mr. Birkenfeld, 44,
told reporters outside of the Schuylkill Federal Correctional Institution in
Minersville.

Mr. Birkenfeld, who was a banker at Zurich-based UBS for five years, was
sentenced to prison on Aug. 21 by Judge William J. Zloch of United States
District Court in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. A federal prosecutor, Kevin Downing,
recommended a 30-month sentence and said Mr. Birkenfeld's cooperation had
exposed a ''massive tax fraud scheme'' at UBS, Switzerland's largest bank.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                            December 25, 2009 Friday
                                  Main Edition

Yates tapped to replace Nahmias;
Nomination of acting U.S. attorney expected.;
Prosecutor had sent ex-Mayor Bill Campbell to jail for tax evasion.

BYLINE: Bob Keefe; Staff

SECTION: METRO NEWS; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 490 words


WASHINGTON --- The prosecutor who sent former Atlanta Mayor Bill Campbell to
jail on tax evasion charges has been nominated by President Barack Obama to be
the region's chief federal law enforcement officer.

Obama's nomination of Sally Quillian Yates as U.S. attorney for the Northern
District of Georgia had been expected.

She has served as acting U.S. attorney since August, when her predecessor, David
Nahmias, resigned to take a seat on the Georgia Supreme Court. Since then, she
has handled a number of high-profile cases.

Earlier this month, her office completed prosecution of two Atlanta area men on
terrorism charges. Ehsanul Islam Sadequee, 23, of Roswell was sentenced to 17
years in prison and co-defendant Syed Haris Ahmed, 25, of Atlanta was sentenced
to 13 years for providing support to terrorist groups and plotting terrorist
acts against the United States.

Yates' office in recent months also prosecuted a couple from Winston who pleaded
guilty to running a mortgage fraud operation; a Miami man sentenced for running
a million-dollar Medicaid fraud business; and an Ellenwood minister and his wife
accused of human trafficking and immigration violations.

Her most prominent prosecution, however, was of Bill Campbell, Atlanta's mayor
from 1994-2002.

Campbell had been charged with racketeering and bribery after an extensive
investigation and prosecution led by Yates. He was ultimately convicted only of
tax evasion. He served about two years in prison before being freed in October
2008.

Yates was recommended to Obama by the state's Democratic congressmen on the
advice of an advisory panel of 11 lawyers and elected officials.

But her recommendation didn't come without controversy. She was one of several
people recommended for the job. At one point, her recommendation was apparently
withdrawn at least in part because of pressure from Campbell supporters who
decried her prosecution of the former mayor as too aggressive.

In 2006, Yates defended her prosecution of the former mayor and denied
allegations by Campbell that she was on a "witch hunt."

"We would have been derelict in our duty if we had not tried this case," she
said at the time, according to news reports.

Yates has worked in the U.S. Attorney's Office in Atlanta since 1989. She has
served twice as acting U.S. attorney; she also held the role in 2004 before
Nahmias was tapped for the job.

From 1986 to 1989, Yates was an attorney at the private law firm of King &
Spalding. She graduated from the University of Georgia in 1982 and the
University of Georgia School of Law in 1986.

Her nomination is for a four-year term; it still requires Senate approval.

Yates' nomination was part of a flurry of judicial nominations announced by the
president before he left for Hawaii on vacation and the Senate adjourned for the
year.

The White House also announced the nomination of six other U.S. attorneys, two
judges and several other judicial appointments in other states.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            July 26, 2006 Wednesday
                                 SECOND EDITION

St. Louis area United Way clears official of wrongdoing Memo says Cheryl Polk
isn't connected to her husband's legal woes. He has admitted defrauding MSD and
evading taxes.

BYLINE: By Robert Patrick ST. LOUIS POST-DISPATCH

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B5

LENGTH: 382 words


The United Way of Greater St. Louis has cleared one of its executives of
wrongdoing after her husband pleaded guilty earlier this year to federal charges
related to tax evasion and fraud.

A memo to the charity's board of directors says that Cheryl Polk, executive vice
president and chief operating officer, was not involved in any impropriety or
conflict of interest, and that the organization is not connected to any of her
husband's legal troubles.

The United Way provided a copy of the July 19 memo, which was written by board
Chair David Steward and President and CEO Gary Dollar, to the Post-Dispatch on
Tuesday.

Polk's husband, Charles E. Polk Jr., pleaded guilty in April of defrauding the
Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District of $45,190 while working as general
counsel there. He also pleaded guilty to a tax evasion charge. Prosecutors claim
that he failed to file income tax returns and avoided paying $470,000 owed from
1998 to 2002.

Charles Polk's sentencing is set for Aug. 31 in federal court in St. Louis.

The Missouri Supreme Court's Office of Chief Disciplinary Counsel suspended
Charles Polk's law license June 14, pending the final outcome of his criminal
case.

Also, a St. Louis County circuit judge recently ordered the Polks to pay a
former business associate $3.6 million to resolve a civil suit over a failed
plan to represent survivors and heirs of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.

The couple presented no defense in the case, but Charles Polk acted as his own
lawyer in a two-day trial over the amount of damages.

Cheryl Polk, of St. Charles, could not be reached for comment. United Way
spokeswoman Lisa Richter declined to make Cheryl Polk, Steward and Dollar
available for an interview.

The memo says that no criminal charges have been filed or are pending against
Cheryl Polk, and that she has filed all her personal tax returns during the
years for which her husband has been investigated and since that time.

The memo says that a judge entered a default judgment in the civil case when
Cheryl Polk mistakenly thought she had a lawyer, and that the case is being
appealed.

"Cheryl Polk is a valued member of the United Way team, who has a strong
personal commitment to the St. Louis community," the memo says. "We look forward
to her continued service to our community."

                             Daily News (New York)

                           December 04, 1995, Monday

SLUGGER LEGENDS EYED IN TAX DODGE

BYLINE: By GREG B. SMITH

SECTION: News; Pg.  3

LENGTH: 711 words


Federal authorities believe a troupe of baseball legends pocketed nearly $
250,000 in cash for signing autographs and never reported it to the Internal
Revenue Service.

Hank Aaron, Ernie Banks, Reggie Jackson, Harmon Killebrew, Eddie Mathews, Frank
Robinson, Mike Schmidt and the late Mickey Mantle are among the stars believed
to have dodged the tax man, according to a confidential federal report obtained
by the Daily News.

Two other baseball stars listed in the report ex-Brooklyn Dodger Duke Snider and
ex-San Francisco Giant Willie McCovey have pleaded guilty to tax evasion charges
for hiding cash earned selling their autographs.

But attorneys and agents for some of the players say several may still be
indicted or hit with civil fines before the statute of limitations on the
charges runs out April 15.

The IRS zeroed in on the lucrative baseball memorabilia industry in the late
1980s as promoters offered huge cash fees for autographs and public appearances.

The report found that the elite players took home $ 243,100 during a three-day
memorabilia event called Super Show I, held Jan. 14-16, 1989, at the TropWorld
Casino and Hotel in Atlantic City.

Super Show I considered the biggest baseball memorabilia event ever featured the
11 living players who'd hit 500 home runs, plus Duke Snider and Cincinnati Reds
greats Pete Rose and Tony Perez.

So far, two of the event's promoters have pleaded guilty to tax evasion and
implicated nearly all of the participants, the report states.

Law enforcement sources say the players received their fees mostly cash ranging
from $ 3,600 for Ernie Banks to $ 57,000 for Mickey Mantle to sign bats, balls,
T-shirts and cards.

After a two-year probe, IRS criminal division agents concluded only two of the
players Willie Mays and Ted Williams reported payments on their tax forms. Mays
received $ 19,000, Williams an unspecified amount.

The report says promoters William Hongach and Michael Bertolini who both pleaded
guilty to tax evasion charges last year handed out envelopes of cash before the
players even lifted a pen.

With Robinson, for example, they delivered $ 26,500 of his total $ 39,000
payment in three bundles during the show, the report states.

None of the payments was reported as income on Robinson's 1989 return, the
report said.

Robinson, reached at the Baltimore Orioles' front office where he is now a vice
president, said prosecutors told him he won't be charged criminally. "I talked
to those people and it's been resolved," he said.

The report says Mantle received cash payments of $ 27,000 and $ 30,000. None of
the cash was declared on his tax forms.

Mantle's attorney, Robert Fink, confirmed that at least some of the income was
not reported, but said prosecutors declined to charge Mantle after Fink made a
"half-day presentation" showing Mantle knew nothing about what was reported on
his tax statements.

Reggie Jackson broke his left hand shortly before the show and couldn't sign
autographs but received $ 15,000 anyway, which the report says was not reported.
But his attorney, Jack Tigue, said the cash was deposited into Jackson's bank
account and showed up as income on his 1989 statement.

Schmidt allegedly did not report $ 5,000 of his $ 20,000 payment and structured
the other $ 15,000 through three Pennsylvania bank accounts "to avoid filing a
currency transaction report" required of all deposits of more than $ 10,000, the
report states.

Schmidt could not be reached for comment, but his agent, Arthur Rosenberg, said,
"As far as I can tell you, all the taxes were paid."

IRS agents could not determine whether Rose reported his $ 20,000 fee or Perez
declared the $ 4,500 he took home. The other players Aaron, Banks, Killebrew,
and Mathews failed to report their payments, the report states.

Bob Allen, agent for Aaron and Killebrew, said he was unaware that his clients
had failed to report the income and had no further comment. Representatives for
Banks and Mathews could not be reached.

Charles Franssen, chief of the IRS' New York criminal division, would not
comment on the continuing investigation except to say that it had been expanded.
"We're now looking at all sports memorabilia," he said.

                    The Salem News (Beverly, Massachusetts)

                             April 7, 2009 Tuesday

Couple charged with tax evasion

BYLINE: Julie Manganis, The Salem News, Beverly, Mass.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 383 words


Apr. 7--MIDDLETON -- A Middleton couple were arrested yesterday by federal
agents on tax-evasion charges involving millions of unreported dollars from a
scrap metal business they owned.

Joseph "Junior" Pingaro Jr., 53, and his wife, Christine Scola, 50, of 12 Jones
Road were named in a 67-count indictment alleging conspiracy, filing false tax
returns and tax evasion. A federal grand jury handed up the indictments last
week following a lengthy investigation by the FBI, the Internal Revenue Service
criminal investigation division and the U.S. attorney's office.

Prosecutors allege that over a five-year period between 2001 and 2006, the
couple transferred millions of dollars in income from their Roxbury business,
J&J Metals, to a personal checking account at the Saugus Federal Credit Union.

Scola then withdrew large amounts of the money, a total of approximately $3
million, in $9,900 increments, so she could avoid the transactions being
reported to regulators. The couple lived on that money, while dramatically
under-reporting their personal income to avoid paying taxes, prosecutors allege.

They also avoided business taxes by over-reporting the business's expenses,
prosecutors allege.

The couple also gave friends cash and asked them to purchase cashiers checks,
which the couple then used to purchase their Middleton home in 2004, prosecutors
allege.

The couple were arraigned yesterday in U.S. District Court in Boston, where
Judge Patti Saris released them on $100,000 bond. Pingaro's bond will be
secured, meaning he will have to pledge personal property and risks losing that
property if he defaults.

If convicted, the couple could face decades in prison.

Prosecutors are also seeking the forfeiture of $3 million in assets, as well as
the couple's home. Investigators had already seized more than $300,000 from the
couple's home in July 2006, during their investigation.

                        Las Cruces Sun-News (New Mexico)

                             March 8, 2008 Saturday

Washington State man arrested in Las Cruces on tax evasion charges

BYLINE: Sun-News report

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 361 words


To see court documents related to tax charges against Washington state man,
click here or here.

LAS CRUCES   A Washington state man wanted on charges of tax evasion was
arrested by IRS agents Tuesday in Las Cruces.

On Friday, a U.S. magistrate judge in Las Cruces released William Robertson, 67,
of Everett, Wash., on an unsecured bond and ordered him to appear in Seattle to
face the charges.

Robertson, who owned and controlled various restaurants operating under the Hot
Rod Café name, was indicted last month by a federal grand jury in Seattle on two
counts of willful failure to pay taxes and one count of tax evasion, according
to a news release.

According to the indictment, in 2004 and 2005, Robertson was the owner of the
Hot Rod Café in Mountlake Terrace, Wash. During those years, Robertson allegedly
withheld about $36,503 from employees' pay for Social Security, Medicare and
income taxes. Robertson failed to pay the money to the government for his
employees' taxes.

Additionally, in 2005, he controlled HRC Enterprises Inc. The company operated a
restaurant in Mukilteo, Wash., which was also called the Hot Rod Café. The
indictment alleges that Robertson withheld about $2,951 from employee checks,
but failed to make the payment for the Social Security, Medicare and income
taxes.

The final count of tax evasion concerns penalties assessed to Robertson in 1996
and 1997, again for failing to pay the trust fund portion of employment taxes
and withheld employee income taxes. Between 1992 and 1996, Robertson operated
various restaurants and was responsible for the tax payments. When he failed to
make the payments, the IRS imposed penalties totaling more than $491,000.

According to the indictment, Robertson tried to evade payment of these penalties
by hiding his ownership of two corporations: Seabill Inc. and SMB Enterprises
Inc., by filing false income tax returns, and by making false claims to IRS
agents.

Robertson faces up to five years in prison on each charge and a $250,000 fine.

The charges contained in the indictment are only allegations. A person is
presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a
court of law.

                                US Official News

                            February 20, 2015 Friday

Vitter Pushes DOJ for Information on HSBC Drug Money Laundering, Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 879  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator David Vitter, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

U.S. Senator David Vitter (R-La.), member of the Senate Judiciary Committee,
today sent a letter to Attorney General Eric Holder pushing for information
regarding alleged tax evasion and money laundering by megabank HSBC in 2012.
HSBC was charged with allowing a massive billion dollar money laundering scheme
that involved Mexican drug cartels and international terrorist organizations,
but was punished with a minor monetary penalty. U.S. Attorney Loretta Lynch,
nominee to replace Holder as Attorney General, allowed HSBC to reach an
agreement that avoids prosecution, instead of immediately pursuing criminal
charges.

"This case has been completely swept under the rug, but it provides significant
insight into how Loretta Lynch would act as our country's top law enforcement
official," Vitter said. "If she completely ignored serious tax evasion
allegations against HSBC that put the identities of American citizens at risk,
we need to know a heck of a lot more about it."

Lynch's nomination was scheduled to receive a vote in the Senate Judiciary
Committee last week, but Vitter and others requested a hold-over. The vote on
her confirmation has been delayed.

Prior to the nomination hearings, Lynch failed to include in her questionnaire
an interview in which she defended the HSBC settlement. Vitter submitted a
question for the record asking Lynch how she will handle oversight of this
settlement given the role she played in negotiating it. Click here to read more.

In 2012, HSBC entered into an agreement for $1.26 billion and paid another $665
million in penalties to avoid criminal prosecution. These amounts represent a
small fraction of HSBC's assets. Vitter has been in touch with a whistleblower
who is a former HSBC employee. Click here to read more.

HSBC continues to face similar allegations around the world. Yesterday, Swiss
prosecutors raided HSBC's offices in Geneva based on allegations of tax evasion
and money laundering. Click here to read more.

The text of the letter is below.


The Honorable Eric H. Holder, Jr.
Attorney General
U.S. Department of Justice
950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW
Washington, D.C. 20530-0001

Dear Attorney General Holder:

As the Senate considers the nomination of the next Attorney General of the
United States, questions remain unanswered about potentially lax treatment of
HSBC Bank USA (HSBC) by the Department of Justice. The handling of this case is
particularly important given the insight it gives the Senate into the decisions
made by Loretta Lynch, who was in charge of the US Attorney's office and the
case at the time. To further the Senate's consideration of her nomination, I
request you supply me and the rest of the Senate Judiciary Committee with any
documents from the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in regard to HSBC, as well as
the other documents enumerated below in regard to the HSBC settlement.

These decisions by the DOJ and Ms. Lynch's office raise troubling questions
about whether pertinent information of public concern regarding HSBC was "swept
under the rug", if justice was served, and why HSBC was given special treatment
that allowed it to walk away from such serious offenses unscathed. This case is
increasingly relevant and pressing now that Ms. Lynch has been nominated as the
next Attorney General.

If media reports are true, knowledge of HSBC shielding clients from US tax
liabilities was known to the Department of Justice at least as early as April
2010, yet no criminal charges have ever been brought against HSBC for tax
evasion. Moreover, in 2012 the US Attorney's Office run by Ms. Lynch negotiated
a Deferred Prosecution Agreement (DPA) with HSBC that allowed HSBC to admit
guilt for the crimes of money laundering and facilitating transactions with
sanctioned countries, but avoid criminal prosecution for those infractions.

Accordingly, as a member of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I request that the
Department of Justice (DOJ) provide the following information:

1) Copies of all documents and information in DOJ's possession reflecting when
the DOJ first learned that HSBC may be involved in tax evasion, including but
not limited to any recommendations from the IRS in regard to HSBC and tax
evasion;

2) Copies of all documents and information in DOJ's possession, including but
not limited to information received from French authorities or any other
persons, governments or entities, reflecting evidence that HSBC was shielding
clients from tax liabilities;

3) Copies of all documents and information relating to the negotiation of the
DPA with HSBC; and

4) Copies of all documents and information relating to why DOJ chose not to
prosecute HSBC for tax evasion, fraud, money laundering, facilitating
transactions with sanctioned countries or any other crimes.

Please deliver copies of this information to my Senate office in Hart Senate
Office Building Room 516, and in electronic form to Travis Johnson at
Travis_Johnson@Vitter.Senate.Gov by February 23, 2015. Should you have any
questions, please contact Travis in my office at (202) 224-4623.

David Vitter

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            July 26, 2006 Wednesday
                                 THIRD EDITION

United Way clears official of wrongdoing Memo says Cheryl Polk isn't connected
to her husband's legal woes.

BYLINE: By Robert Patrick ST. LOUIS POST-DISPATCH

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 370 words


The United Way of Greater St. Louis has cleared one of its executives of
wrongdoing after her husband pleaded guilty earlier this year to federal charges
related to tax evasion and fraud.

A memo to the charity's board of directors says that Cheryl Polk, executive vice
president and chief operating officer, was not involved in any impropriety or
conflict of interest, and that the organization is not connected to any of her
husband's legal troubles.

The United Way provided a copy of the July 19 memo, which was written by board
Chair David Steward and President and CEO Gary Dollar, to the Post-Dispatch on
Tuesday.

Polk's husband, Charles E. Polk Jr., pleaded guilty in April of defrauding the
Metropolitan St. Louis Sewer District of $45,190 while working as general
counsel there. He also pleaded guilty to a tax evasion charge. Prosecutors claim
that he failed to file income tax returns and avoided paying $470,000 owed from
1998 to 2002.

Charles Polk's sentencing is set for Aug. 31.

The Missouri Supreme Court's Office of Chief Disciplinary Counsel suspended
Charles Polk's law license June 14, pending the final outcome of his criminal
case.

Also, a St. Louis County circuit judge recently ordered the Polks to pay a
former business associate $3.6 million to resolve a civil suit over a failed
plan to represent survivors and heirs of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing.

The couple presented no defense in the case, but Charles Polk acted as his own
lawyer in a two-day trial over the amount of damages.

Cheryl Polk, of St. Charles, could not be reached for comment. United Way
spokeswoman Lisa Richter declined to make Cheryl Polk, Steward and Dollar
available for an interview.

The memo says that no improprieties were found in United Way contracts signed
between Jan. 1, 2004, and April 30, 2006. Polk started at the United Way before
2004 and has been performing her normal duties while the investigation was under
way, Richter said. Richter said she did not know why the Jan. 1, 2004, date was
chosen.

The memo says that no charges have been filed or are pending against Cheryl
Polk, and that she has filed all her personal tax returns during the years for
which her husband has been investigated and since that time.

                              The Washington Post

                     August 5, 1994, Friday, Final Edition

Alexandria School Split on Future Of Counselor Convicted in Tax Case

Steve Bates, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE D3

LENGTH: 683 words


Nearly two months after the guidance director at Alexandria's T.C. Williams High
School pleaded guilty to tax evasion, parents and school officials are divided
over whether he should keep his job.

Some parents are pushing to keep James E. McClure, 55, who has been the chief
counselor at the city's only public high school for more than 20 years, arguing
that students can learn from his mistake.

Others say his behavior shows he is not a proper role model.

"There are strong feelings on both sides in the community," School Board member
Stephen Kenealy said.

The case will force a tough choice by the city's first elected School Board,
which took office a month ago with a pledge to regain the public's confidence in
the 10,000-student system.

In April, McClure, of Springfield, was indicted on four counts of tax evasion.

The Internal Revenue Service said that he failed to report more than $ 125,000
in income over four years and that he provided false documents during an audit
in an attempt to support deductions.

McClure, who has agreed to make restitution, pleaded guilty in June to one
felony count of tax evasion and is scheduled to be sentenced Sept. 16 in U.S.
District Court in Alexandria.

He faces a maximum five years in prison and a $ 250,000 fine.

"Nobody is above making a mistake," said Carol LaSasso, a parent active in
school issues.

If McClure keeps his job, she said, he can show students that "if you make a
mistake, you're going to have to pay the consequences."

LaSasso and other backers are sending letters and making telephone calls to
Judge Albert V. Bryan Jr., who will sentence McClure, and to city and state
education officials, who will decide whether he'll lose his teaching license.

Mayor Patricia S. Ticer (D) said she would like to see McClure stay. "You want
the kids to know that there's right and wrong and to be responsible for their
actions," she said. "But you don't want them to think there is never redemption
or forgiveness."

Others said McClure has no place in school administration at a time when parents
and educators are calling for tougher standards in student behavior.

School Board member Charles W. Linderman said McClure's supporters should ask
themselves, "What does this look like to the families coming into the school
system" and to "our peers around the state?"

"It is a federal felony offense," School Board member Patricia Hennig said.
"There are people in the city who are out to canonize him, and there are people
in the city who are out to crucify him. I'm not a proponent of either, but don't
look for any puffs of white smoke."

McClure joined the school system in 1968 and has headed the T.C. Williams
counseling department since 1973. He continues to report to his office daily and
is paid about $ 65,000 a year.

McClure has developed a reputation not only for solving students' personal
problems and helping them get into college, but also for helping parents cope
with their children's woes.

He said that he has heard from parents who think he should leave but that most
who have contacted him want him to stay.

"I have a conscience," McClure said.

"I know that standards have to be set for young people. Philosophically
speaking, can I talk about honesty and integrity with the kids and be a
convicted felon at the same time? It could be very positive" to discuss how he
failed and students must not, he said.

Acting Superintendent Maxine Wood is preparing a report for the School Board on
McClure's case. The School Board can ask state education officials to consider
revoking McClure's teaching license. It also can consider its own disciplinary
action.

Parents who are lobbying to keep McClure at T.C. Williams said they are not
organized, just acting as concerned individuals.

"Jim is absolutely essential to the smooth functioning of the school system this
year," LaSasso said.

School Board member Henry Brooks said he has mixed feelings.

"It's not a violent crime. It's not a crime against children," Brooks said. But
he said, "If he's incarcerated, our options may be very limited."

Ja Rule: Pleads guilty in tax case

SECTION: ENTERTAINMENT

LENGTH: 128 words


Thursday March 24, 2011

NEWARK, N.J. -- Rapper and actor Ja Rule admitted Tuesday that he failed to pay
taxes on more than $3 million in income, pleading guilty to tax evasion in
federal court in New Jersey.

The platinum-selling rapper earned the money between 2004 and 2006.

As part of a plea agreement, the government dismissed two counts against him for
unpaid taxes on income earned in 2007 and 2008.

Ja Rule, 35, whose real name is Jeffrey Atkins, is expected to be sentenced on
the tax evasion charges in June. He faces up to one year in prison and $100,000
in fines on each count.

He also faces sentencing June 8 in New York on a weapon possession charge that
he pleaded guilty to in December. He has agreed to a two-year prison term in
that case.

-- The Associated Press

                                The Toronto Star

                    January 28, 1997, Tuesday, METRO EDITION

Tennis star Graf still target of tax-evasion probe

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. B10

LENGTH: 444 words


   German prosecutors said yesterday they were still investigating tennis star
Steffi Graf, whose father was found guilty last week of evading millions of
dollars in tax on her earnings.

Although the judge who sentenced Graf's father, Peter, on six counts of actual
and attempted tax evasion recommended the investigation be dropped, Mannheim
prosecutor Hubert Jobski said the probe would continue, adding, "I wouldn't like
to speculate about the outcome of the investigation."

Steffi Graf, whose career tennis earnings are estimated at more than $61
million, has told tax investigators she entrusted her financial affairs to her
father from an early age and had little idea how her money was managed. However,
Jobski said that, by law, she was still responsible for her own tax
declarations.

Peter Graf, 58, was sentenced last Friday to three years and nine months in jail
for evading $7.3 million in taxes on his daughter's earnings from 1989 to 1993,
and attempting to evade paying another $1.8 million. Former family tax adviser
Joachim Eckardt, 48, received a 30- month sentence after being convicted of
attempted tax evasion and being an accessory.

Jobski said he intends to appeal both sentences.

TRACK AND FIELD: Carl Lewis finished in a tie for seventh yesterday at 100-metre
race in Sydney, his second disappointing performance in three days. Lewis,
seventh in Auckland on Friday night in a time of 10.76 seconds, was across this
time in 10.56.

ALPINE SKIING: Bibiana Perez, one of the best downhillers on the Italian team,
sustained a concussion when she crashed during a training run at Cortina
d'Ampezzo, Italy, yesterday. While her condition was not serious, doctors
couldn't immediately say if she'd be able to start in next week's world
championships.

CURLING:

The countdown to the Labatt Brier in Calgary still has 40 days to go, but local
organizers have their arms raised in victory. Advance ticket sales have
surpassed the 155,000 mark, breaking the record of 151,538 set in Saskatoon in
1989.

* Agnes Charette and her Quebec rink remained unbeaten yesterday after five
rounds at the Canadian Senior Ladies Curling Championships in Thornhill. The
veteran skip from Buckingham, Que., earned her second win of the day last night,
a 10-0 shutout over Northern Ontario's Pat Dayes.

AUTO RACING: Davy Jones, injured last week in a crash during practice for the
Indy 200, remained in serious but stable condition with a closed head injury and
has been transferred from the Orlando Regional Medical Center to Methodist
Hospital in Indianapolis, which is known for its treatment of race-related
injuries.

                             July 28, 2016 Thursday

Washington: Fayetteville Man Sentenced to 18 Months for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 307  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



 Edward J. Purcell, Sr., age 65, of Fayetteville, New York, was sentenced today
to serve 18 months in prison for tax evasion.

The announcement was made by United States Attorney Richard S. Hartunian and
Shantelle P. Kitchen, Special Agent in Charge of IRS-Criminal Investigation's
New York Field Office.  U.S. District Judge David N. Hurd also sentenced Purcell
to 3 years of supervised release, to begin after his release from prison, and
also ordered him to pay $347,128 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service
("IRS").  In December 2015, Purcell pled guilty to one count of tax evasion.
During the years 2008 through 2010, Purcell owned and operated American Roofing
Company ("ARC") in the Syracuse area.  In this time period, he failed to report
any of the income he received from ARC by not filing federal income tax returns,
despite receiving taxable income in the amount of $655,937.  For the tax years
2008, 2009, and 2010, Purcell willfully evaded the payment of taxes on his
individual income, which totaled $150,980, $333,614, and $171,343, respectively.
The total tax loss for the years 2008 through 2010 was $231,362.  Purcell also
agreed to repay the IRS an additional $115,766, representing the tax loss for
2007.  Purcell concealed his income by depositing checks payable to ARC into
nominee bank accounts, which he controlled through powers of attorney.  Purcell
set up these bank accounts in the names of his close friends and family members
for the purpose of concealing his income from the IRS.  This case was
investigated by IRS-Criminal Investigation, and was prosecuted by Assistant U.S.
Attorney Ransom P. Reynolds.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                            March 21, 2013 Thursday

Woman gets 41-month sentence for embezzling funds from Lafayette employer

BYLINE: By Erin Ivie eivie@bayareanewsgroup.com

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 299 words


OAKLAND -- A Southern California woman was sentenced to 41 months in prison
Wednesday for a tax evasion and embezzlement scheme that defrauded the IRS and a
Lafayette-based real estate firm of nearly $2 million, attorneys said.

Kristie Gale Meyer, 56, of Woodland Hills, was ordered to pay $1.3 million in
restitution for her role in a complex scheme to defraud her employer,
Lafayette-based Ansil Realty & Investment, and its partner, KLP Properties,
United States Attorney Melinda Haag said. In addition, Meyer must pay $584,092
to the IRS for three years of continuous tax evasion.

While working as Ansil's secretary, office manager and bookkeeper, Meyer paid
her own credit card bills through the company's bank account, withdrew cash
advances for her own use and used company money on online gambling websites,
according to the plea agreement. She also made deposits directly to her own bank
account and wrote checks out of the company's accounts for her own purchases.

According to Haag, Meyer tried to hide the activity by destroying copies of the
fraudulent checks and then entering the transactions into the companies'
accounting system to make them look like legitimate business expenditures.

Meyer also admitted to dodging a large part of the income tax she owed from 2006
to 2008 by filing returns claiming her taxable income was far less than what she
was really earning, Haag said.

Meyer pleaded guilty on Nov. 21 to one count of mail fraud and one count of tax
evasion following her 2010 indictment on 10 counts of wire fraud and three
counts of tax evasion, Haag said. U.S. District Court Judge Phyllis J. Hamilton
sentenced Meyer to 41 months in prison followed by three years' supervised
release.

atTwitter.com/erin_ivie .

                               The New York Times

               September 16, 1995, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Extra Community Service, U.S. Tells Leona Helmsley

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

SECTION: Section 1;   Page 23;   Column 5;   Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 633 words


Concluding that Leona Helmsley's employees did some of the community service she
was required to perform as part of her penalty for tax evasion, a Federal judge
in Manhattan yesterday ordered another 150 hours of community work added to her
sentence.

But the additional time imposed by Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District
Court was far less than the 400 hours that Federal probation officials had asked
for, even though Mrs. Helmsley's lawyer, Arthur Liman, had previously agreed
that 400 hours was "fair and acceptable."

Judge Griesa further ordered yesterday that Mrs. Helmley not be made to do
menial work, like the envelope stuffing she was previously assigned, but work
commensurate with her talents as the manager of her husband, Harry's, hotel
empire.

He also directed that her community service be performed in the New York area,
where she can be more closely supervised.

It was Judge Griesa himself who raised the issue of how much time Mrs. Helmsley
should give to community service. He noted that it might be "wholly unnecessary"
for a judge to question an agreement reached between the prosecution and the
defense, but said he intervened "because it is uniquely the responsibility of a
judge to impose sentence." And, he added, "It has often happened that the judge
does not accept the agreement."

"It may be appropriate to impose an obligation now," Judge Griesa said, alluding
to the 400 hours, "but it also may be, in my view, too much."

Judge Griesa cited Mrs. Helmsley's age -- she is 74 -- as a factor in his
decision. He said she had already fulfilled the more severe parts of her
sentence, serving a 21-month prison term and paying a $6.3 million fine in
addition to $1.2 million in Federal taxes and $469,000 in state taxes, as well
as penalties.

Mrs. Helmsley was convicted in 1989 on charges of income tax evasion and mail
fraud for deducting personal expenses as business costs. She was sentenced to 30
months in prison, which Judge Griesa later reduced to 21 months because of the
ill health of her husband, Harry.

She entered Federal prison in Danbury, Conn., on April 15, 1992 -- the deadline
for filing income tax. After 18 months, she was sent to a Manhattan halfway
house for one month and then was confined for two months in her penthouse
apartment on Central Park South.

Afterward, as a condition of her three years of probation, Mrs. Helmsley was
required to perform 750 hours of community service, or 250 hours a year.

She was assigned to a hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz., near a Helmsley winter home
in Paradise Valley, Ariz., where she was required to stuff envelopes and to wrap
presents for volunteers to give to patients.

Her lawyer, Mr. Liman, told the court that Mrs. Helmsley had tried to carry out
the tasks "in good faith." But, he claimed, because she had been "vilified" in
the media, members of the hospital staff "gawked at her" and were "less than
charitable." As a result, the hospital could no longer "accommodate" her
presence.

She was them ordered to do the tasks in the Helmsley home. There, Judge Griesa
said, she "did obtain the help of household employees."

Judge Griesa said it was impossible to determine how many hours of community
service Mrs. Helmsley had actually performed. But, he added, the amount she
should be made to work must be realistic.

He suggested 100 hours.

The assistant United States Attorney, Cathy Seibel, did not agree. Then, Thomas
Eich, the supervising Federal probation officer, suggested 150 hours, noting it
would take any agency to which she was assigned time to train her.

Mrs. Helmsley was not present in court. Afterward, Mr. Liman refused to discuss
how she would react to the judge's ruling. Ms. Seibel, the Federal lawyer, also
declined to comment on the judge's ruling.

                                US Official News

                             March 1, 2014 Saturday

Washington: Massachusetts Dentist Charged with Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 480  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Justice, The Government of USA has issued the following news
release:

A federal grand jury in Boston has indicted George Fenzell for tax evasion and
corruptly endeavoring to obstruct the Internal Revenue Service (IRS), the
Justice Department and the IRS announced today following the unsealing of the
indictment. Fenzell, of Douglas, Mass., is a practicing dentist with offices in
Shrewsbury, Mass., and Brookline, N.H.

According to the indictment, from 1999 through 2012, Fenzell engaged in conduct
intended to obstruct the IRS from computing, assessing and collecting his income
taxes. He stopped filing timely tax returns and allegedly tried to conceal his
dental practice income in a variety of ways. The indictment alleges that Fenzell
used nominee entities, including River Valley Dental and Brookline Dental
Associates Trust, to conceal his dental practice receipts. The indictment also
alleges that he used multiple bank accounts in three separate states, including
commingled accounts maintained by third parties, to conceal his ownership of
funds. According to the indictment, Fenzell used nominees as trustees to make it
appear as though other individuals owned and controlled his assets and income.
Finally, Fenzell allegedly falsified his delinquent 2006 and 2007 tax returns
and made extensive use of cash in order to conceal his fraud.

The indictment further alleges that in 2007, Fenzell, prompted in part by a
Massachusetts Department of Revenue investigation, filed delinquent federal tax
returns for tax years 2000 through 2005. Those returns allegedly reported that
he owed approximately $129,000 in federal income taxes for these years, which
resulted in a total of more than $300,000 including interest and penalties.
According to the indictment, between 2007 and 2012, Fenzell allegedly sought to
evade IRS collection by making his business receipts payable to nominee entities
and by using nominee bank accounts in Florida and Rhode Island to divert and
hide collectible income and assets. The indictment also alleges that Fenzell
failed to file his 2008 through 2011 tax returns at that time required by law,
and used nominee entities and accounts in an effort to evade his taxes.

An indictment merely alleges that crimes have been committed, and the defendant
is presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt in a court of
law. If convicted, Fenzell faces a statutory maximum potential sentence of five
years in prison for each count of tax evasion and a statutory maximum potential
sentence of three years in prison for the count of corruptly endeavoring to
obstruct the IRS.

This case was investigated by IRS-Criminal Investigation Special Agents. It is
being prosecuted by Assistant Chief John N. Kane Jr. and Trial Attorney Robert
Kennedy of the Tax Division.

For more information please visit: http://www.justice.gov

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                           January 28, 2009 Wednesday

STATE BRIEFS;

BYLINE:

SECTION: Pg. B2

LENGTH: 695 words


ADAMS COUNTY GETS NEW TREASURER

HASTINGS - Adams County has named a new treasurer.

The Board of Supervisors has appointed Deputy Treasurer Beverly Davis to the
post.

Davis will be sworn in on Feb. 2. She replaces former Treasurer Julia Moeller,
who resigned earlier this month amid a tax evasion scandal.

Moeller is accused of working with her daughter, Michallan Parr, to avoid paying
sales tax on a new motor home.

Moeller faces charges of official misconduct, abuse of public records and tax
evasion.

TWO DEAD IN FIRE AT GRAND ISLAND

GRAND ISLAND - Grand Island fire officials say two people have died in a mobile
home fire.

Fire Capt. Bryan Stutzman said the two were found in a back bedroom of the home
after the fire was reported after midnight Tuesday.

Stutzman said the two appeared to be adults, but officials were not prepared
Tuesday afternoon to identify the victims.

The mobile home was engulfed in flames when firefighters arrived. Stutzman said
firefighters were unaware the home was occupied until a neighbor said someone
might be inside.

The State Fire Marshal's Office said careless handling of smoking materials
ignited a large overstuffed chair, starting the fire.

BLAIR MAN ACCUSED OF TEEN SEX ASSAULT

BLAIR - A 27-year-old Blair man is behind bars, accused of having a sexual
relationship with a 15-year-old girl he had taken to southwestern Missouri to
live with him.

Wayne Smith's bail has been set at $100,000. He is charged with first-degree
sexual assault of a minor, harboring an escaped juvenile and contributing to the
delinquency of a minor.

The girl's family reported her missing in July. She had been living with her
father in Blair, but at the time of her disappearance, the Nebraska Department
of Health and Human Services was conducting an evaluation to place her in the
state's care.

Detectives said they found the girl living near Purdy, Mo.

MAN ACCUSED IN FATAL CRASH NOW IN JAIL

NORTH PLATTE - A 36-yearold Nebraska man arrested last fall in the death of a
former Arapahoe volleyball coach is now in jail for driving drunk.

Herchel Huff was sentenced earlier this month in Lincoln County District Court
to 30 days in jail for his second DUI offense. He also was fined $500 and had
his license revoked for a year.

He still faces charges in the Oct. 3 death of Kasey Jo Warner of Arapahoe.

The Furnas County Sheriff's Office said Warner was walking with her 3-year old
daughter when Huff hit the pair with his car. Warner's daughter survived; Warner
was killed.

OMAHA MAYOR SAYS PENSION FUND IN PERIL

OMAHA - Omaha Mayor Mike Fahey is laying out challenges his successor will face,
including a pension fund in danger of collapsing.

The Democrat gave his State of the City address Tuesday. He's not seeking
re-election and leaves office in June.

The shortfall in the city's pension fund for police officers and firefighters is
more than $350 million. Fahey said the economic downturn and the current benefit
structure were to blame.

A major problem, he said, is so-called pension spiking. Workers put in many
hours of overtime in their final years to raise their base salaries and boost
their pensions.

MAN PLEADS NOT GUILTY IN ENTICEMENT CASE

NORTH PLATTE - A North Platte man accused of sending pornography to his
15-year-old daughter's cell phone has pleaded not guilty to charges in the case.

The man was in Lincoln County District Court on Monday to plead not guilty to
electronic enticement charges. He now faces trial on March 17.

The man was arrested in October after the girl told her mother of her father's
actions.

SUSPECTED BAR-BASED DRUG RING BROKEN UP

OMAHA - Local police and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have broken
up a suspected drug distribution network based out of a south Omaha bar.

Omaha police said Tuesday that 13 people had been taken into custody after a
six-month investigation into activities at Johnny Z's Bar. Large quantities of
methamphetamine and smaller amounts of cocaine and marijuana were found.

The suspects are being held on state charges for criminal conspiracy. Several
also face firearms charges.

Authorities also seized five firearms, six vehicles, one laptop computer and
more than $10,000.

Moeller faces charges of official misconduct, abuse of public records and tax
evasion.

TWO DEAD IN FIRE AT GRAND ISLAND

GRAND ISLAND - Grand Island fire officials say two people have died in a mobile
home fire.

Fire Capt. Bryan Stutzman said the two were found in a back bedroom of the home
after the fire was reported after midnight Tuesday.

Stutzman said the two appeared to be adults, but officials were not prepared
Tuesday afternoon to identify the victims.

The mobile home was engulfed in flames when firefighters arrived. Stutzman said
firefighters were unaware the home was occupied until a neighbor said someone
might be inside.

The State Fire Marshal's Office said careless handling of smoking materials
ignited a large overstuffed chair, starting the fire.

BLAIR MAN ACCUSED OF TEEN SEX ASSAULT

BLAIR - A 27-year-old Blair man is behind bars, accused of having a sexual
relationship with a 15-year-old girl he had taken to southwestern Missouri to
live with him.

Wayne Smith's bail has been set at $100,000. He is charged with first-degree
sexual assault of a minor, harboring an escaped juvenile and contributing to the
delinquency of a minor.

The girl's family reported her missing in July. She had been living with her
father in Blair, but at the time of her disappearance, the Nebraska Department
of Health and Human Services was conducting an evaluation to place her in the
state's care.

Detectives said they found the girl living near Purdy, Mo.

MAN ACCUSED IN FATAL CRASH NOW IN JAIL

NORTH PLATTE - A 36-yearold Nebraska man arrested last fall in the death of a
former Arapahoe volleyball coach is now in jail for driving drunk.

Herchel Huff was sentenced earlier this month in Lincoln County District Court
to 30 days in jail for his second DUI offense. He also was fined $500 and had
his license revoked for a year.

He still faces charges in the Oct. 3 death of Kasey Jo Warner of Arapahoe.

The Furnas County Sheriff's Office said Warner was walking with her 3-year old
daughter when Huff hit the pair with his car. Warner's daughter survived; Warner
was killed.

OMAHA MAYOR SAYS PENSION FUND IN PERIL

OMAHA - Omaha Mayor Mike Fahey is laying out challenges his successor will face,
including a pension fund in danger of collapsing.

The Democrat gave his State of the City address Tuesday. He's not seeking
re-election and leaves office in June.

The shortfall in the city's pension fund for police officers and firefighters is
more than $350 million. Fahey said the economic downturn and the current benefit
structure were to blame.

A major problem, he said, is so-called pension spiking. Workers put in many
hours of overtime in their final years to raise their base salaries and boost
their pensions.

MAN PLEADS NOT GUILTY IN ENTICEMENT CASE

NORTH PLATTE - A North Platte man accused of sending pornography to his
15-year-old daughter's cell phone has pleaded not guilty to charges in the case.

The man was in Lincoln County District Court on Monday to plead not guilty to
electronic enticement charges. He now faces trial on March 17.

The man was arrested in October after the girl told her mother of her father's
actions.

SUSPECTED BAR-BASED DRUG RING BROKEN UP

OMAHA - Local police and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms have broken
up a suspected drug distribution network based out of a south Omaha bar.

Omaha police said Tuesday that 13 people had been taken into custody after a
six-month investigation into activities at Johnny Z's Bar. Large quantities of
methamphetamine and smaller amounts of cocaine and marijuana were found.

The suspects are being held on state charges for criminal conspiracy. Several
also face firearms charges.

Authorities also seized five firearms, six vehicles, one laptop computer and
more than $10,000.

                       Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida)
