                                SARASOTA EDITION

New suit is eighth against Buchanan;
Ex-controller's charges include tax evasion

BYLINE: By CAROL E. LEE carol.lee@heraldtribune.com

SECTION: B SECTION; Pg. BN1

LENGTH: 615 words


A lawsuit filed in Sarasota County on Friday levies new allegations against U.S.
Rep. Vern Buchanan and his Florida car dealerships, including sexual harassment,
death threats and federal income tax evasion.

It is the eighth in a series of cases that former employees and one consumer
have brought against the freshman Sarasota congressman since May.

The new charges come from the highest-level former Buchanan employee yet to file
suit -- a former controller at Sarasota 500 LLC, the company registered with the
state to operate Sarasota Ford.

The ex-employee, Melissa Hacker, says she was fired in November 2006, after
about a year on the job, for refusing to ignore an IRS tax levy on a 20-year
employee for whom Sarasota 500 LLC had never withheld federal income tax. Her
lawsuit alleges that the employee, Moe Gingerich, was a personal friend of
Buchanan's who made more than $100,000 a year.

Hacker also says Buchanan's former business partner at Sarasota 500 LLC, David
Long, continued to sexually harass and verbally abuse her after she complained
to the company's lawyer. She says three employees made death threats against her
while she was with the company, including Gingerich, whom she says responded,
"What if I shoot you?" when she refused to ignore the IRS request.

Darrin Chrisman, Buchanan's business partner at Sarasota 500 LLC, said the
allegations in Hacker's 30-page lawsuit are false.

"To my knowledge, and I was not here at the time, none of what I see in here is
accurate or true," said Chrisman. "They're just trying to create as much damage
as possible."

Chrisman also said that Gingerich, who is currently a salesman at Sarasota Ford,
has an issue with the IRS but that it has nothing to do with the company.

"It was an issue of his personal income taxes," Chrisman said.

Buchanan's spokeswoman, Sally Tibbetts, said in an e-mail that the congressman
would not respond to the allegations.

"The managing owner of the dealership is the appropriate person to address the
issue," Tibbetts wrote, referring to Chrisman.

Hacker is being represented by Doug Lyons, the Tallahassee-based lawyer handling
the seven other cases against Buchanan.

Hacker said in an interview Friday that she decided to use Lyons after she
learned that other former employees were filing lawsuit.

She said that she did not come forward with these allegations sooner because she
thought there was nothing she could do.

"I was pretty traumatized," she said. "I just wanted to go and get my head
together."

As controller, Hacker was responsible for preparing financial statements and
served as office manager. She is seeking at least $1.6 million in damages,
including $1.2 million in lost wages.

She says she was forced to work long hours and weekends despite being told
otherwise before accepting the $115,000-a-year job, and was never reprimanded
prior to being fired.

Chrisman, who replaced Long about a week before Hacker was fired, said Hacker
was never written up because she was terminated for "significant accounting
discrepancies."

"And if you find that there's significant accounting discrepancies you don't
typically go through a warning process," he added.

Echoing other former Buchanan employees who have sued the congressman since May,
Hacker's lawsuit also accuses Buchanan of bilking consumers, violating federal
campaign finance laws and employing illegal immigrants. Her lawsuit also says
the business was often short on cash because Buchanan and his partner "treated
the dealership like a personal piggy bank."

Buchanan is currently running for re-election against Democrat Christine
Jennings in District 13, which includes all of Sarasota, DeSoto and Hardee
counties and most of Manatee County.

summarized the allegations in a new lawsuit against U.S. Rep. Vern Buchanan, his
car dealerships and employees of the dealerships. The allegations of sexual
harassment, death threats and tax evasion are made only against certain
employees of the dealership, and not Vern Buchanan. The lawsuit names Buchanan

                          Australian Financial Review

                          November 16, 2005 Wednesday
                                 First Edition

Costello steps up fight against tax fraud

BYLINE: Fleur Anderson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 434 words


The federal government used a high-level meeting of finance officials in
Melbourne yesterday to strengthen its anti-tax-fraud arsenal after the
uncovering of a multi-million dollar tax racket this year.

Australia will share information on criminal and civil tax matters with Bermuda
after an agreement signed in Washington a week ago in a move expected to clamp
down on tax evasion between the two countries.

In Operation Wickenby earlier this year, federal agencies uncovered an offshore
scheme that defrauded the commonwealth of $300 million in tax revenue.

At a closed meeting yesterday, Treasurer Peter Costello urged 140
representatives from 50 governments to reduce bank secrecy, which is used as a
cover for money laundering and terrorist financing.

He said that although countries were free to set their own tax rates and
systems, one that could be used to hide transactions, launder money or operate
banking activity beyond examination by government agencies could be undermined
by others.

"And of course, banking activity beyond the reach of lawful investigation can be
used for more than tax evasion - it also opens the door to organised crime and
terrorist financing."

However, his comments were strongly criticised by Dan Mitchell, a senior
political economist with US-based right-wing think tank the Heritage Foundation.
He described Mr Costello's link between tax havens and terrorist financing as
"disingenuous" and a strategy by wealthy high-tax nations to impose their own
tax systems on poorer, less developed nations.

Dr Mitchell said he was "very disappointed" by Mr Costello's speech because
there was no empirical evidence that tax havens helped hide terrorist financing,
which had been tracked to the Middle East, England, Germany and the US.

"The majority of money laundering occurs in New York, London and Los Angeles
because it's through drug money," Dr Mitchell said. "So if you can get your
money into banks in New York or London, why would you send it to a tax haven and
attract more attention?"

The Australian Taxation Office has been pursuing international tax
information-sharing agreements with several countries seen as tax havens.

Last financial year, the ATO conducted 300 risk reviews, which led to 150
taxpayer audits.

In addition, up to 30 people could face charges over the $300 million
tax-evasion credit-card scheme that used some tax havens and was revealed by
Operation Wickenby.

KEY POINTS

* Australia will share information on criminal and civil tax matters with
Bermuda.

* The Treasurer believes reducing bank secrecy could reduce money laundering and
terrorist financing.

                     Marin Independent Journal (Marin, CA)

                            January 28, 2005 Friday

Sheriff's deputy accused of tax evasion

BYLINE: Gary Klien, IJ reporter

LENGTH: 489 words


A Marin sheriff's deputy is facing up to nine years in prison after being
charged with state tax evasion, authorities said yesterday.

Matthew Allen, a 30-year-old Rohnert Park resident, surrendered to authorities
at the Sonoma County Jail yesterday and turned in his badge and gun, according
to the Franchise Tax Board. He posted bail of $10,000 and was released.

Allen has been charged with two felony counts of filing false tax documents and
one felony count of tax evasion, Sonoma County prosecutor Larry Scoufos said.
Each count carries up to three years in prison.

Allen has not entered a plea and is scheduled to appear in court Monday.

According to state tax investigators, Allen earned nearly $80,000 in 2003 but
did not file a state tax return. Investigators said Allen gave the Sheriff's
Office two W-4 Withholding Allowance Certificates claiming exempt status.

Allen owes more than $5,150 in unpaid state taxes, authorities said.

A spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service declined to comment on whether
Allen's federal tax returns are also under scrutiny.

"Disclosure laws preclude the IRS from talking about any taxpayer's issues until
they become public record," said Bill Steiner, an IRS spokesman in Sacramento.

John Barrett, spokesman for the state tax board, said Allen's reasons for
withholding his tax payments were in line with a widespread philosophical
movement that deems income tax withholding to be illegitimate. The movement,
fueled by various anti-tax groups and their Internet sites, has led to numerous
court rulings, all backing the government.

Barrett said he did not know if Allen was a member of any anti-tax groups.

"The kind of language that these individuals use is so specific to this kind of
philosophy, it's just obvious," he said.

Barrett said he did not consider it extreme for Allen to be arrested over a
$5,000 tab. He said state authorities arrest three or four suspected tax
cheaters a month and added that there are about 500 open investigations.

"The sad thing about this case is he's the kind of guy who's supposed to protect
us from these kind of people," Barrett said. "Tax evasion is not a victimless
crime. The victims are you and me and the other taxpayers in California. It's a
felony, I'm sorry. If you're not going to pay your tax bill, you have to face
the consequences."

Barrett said he has been with the tax board 14 years and cannot recall another
police officer being arrested in a tax-evasion case.

Allen could not be reached for comment yesterday.

Allen, who has worked for the Sheriff's Office for about three years, has been
placed on paid leave pending the outcome of an internal investigation,
Undersheriff Dennis Finnegan said.

"Of course we want everyone to pay their taxes," Finnegan said. "We want
everyone to be a law-abiding citizen."

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            October 6, 2016 Thursday

Owner of Tax Preparation Franchises in Illinois, Kansas and Missouri Convicted
of Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 512  words


Underreported More Than $1.5 Million in Gross Receipts

A federal jury sitting in St. Louis, Missouri, found the local owner of a tax
return preparation businesses guilty of two counts of tax evasion, announced
Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo, head of the
Justice Departments Tax Division.

While Semere Tsehaye was operating tax return preparation franchises in three
states, he was generating false financial summaries and filing fraudulent
returns to evade paying his own taxes, said Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney
General Ciraolo.  No one is above the law, and the department will continue to
prosecute those who seek to violate our nations tax laws.

According to the evidence at trial, Semere Tsehaye, 39, was the owner and
operator of at least 20 Instant Tax Service (ITS) franchise locations operating
in and around East St. Louis, Illinois; Kansas City, Kansas; and Kansas City and
St. Louis, Missouri, from 2005 to 2011.  ITS was a brand name of ITS Financial
LLC, a nationwide tax preparation business headquartered in Dayton, Ohio.
Tsehaye owned and operated his ITS franchise locations using two entities named
A&S Tax Service LLC (A&S) and ERI Enterprises LLC (ERI).

The evidence at trial showed that during the years 2010 and 2011, Tsehaye
generated fraudulent financial summaries that understated the gross receipts
generated by A&S and ERI and provided them to his tax return preparer.  The
evidence also showed Tsehayes tax return preparer used these financial summaries
to prepare Tsehayes individual income tax returns, which Tsehaye then filed with
the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).  These tax returns were false in that they
underreported A&S and ERIs gross receipts by a total of approximately $547,000
in 2010 and $1.03 million in 2011, causing a tax loss of more than $580,000.

Mr. Tsehayes attempt to evade his taxes by creating false financial summaries to
conceal over $1.5 million of income and by filing false tax returns is a theft
from the American public, said Special Agent in Charge Karl Stiften of
IRS-Criminal Investigation.  We all pay when others swindle the government.

In 2013, a Kansas City, Kansas, federal court permanently enjoined Tsehaye and
A&S from further operating a tax preparation business or preparing federal tax
returns.

Sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 4, 2017.  Tsehaye faces a statutory maximum
sentence of five years in prison for each count of tax evasion, as well as a
period of supervised release and monetary penalties.

Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo commended special agents of
IRS-Criminal Investigation, who conducted the investigation, and Senior
Litigation Counsel Corey Smith and Trial Attorney Mark McDonald of the Tax
Division, who are prosecuting the case.  Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney
General Ciraolo also thanked the U.S. Attorneys Office for the Eastern District
of Missouri for their assistance.

Additional information about the Tax Division and its enforcement efforts may be
found on the divisions website. 2016 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                           January 4, 2006 Wednesday
                                 THIRD EDITION

Political shockwaves sent through Congress

BYLINE: By Steven Thomma and Alison Young KNIGHT RIDDER NEWSPAPERS Deirdre
Shesgreen of the Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau contributed to this report.

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 955 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


THE PLEA Jack Abramoff pleads guilty of conspiracy, mail fraud and tax evasion.

THE DEAL He will help prosecutors in an inquiry that could implicate members of
Congress.

THE TARGETS Possibilities include Rep. Tom DeLay and Sen. Harry Reid, the
minority leader.

---

A well-connected lobbyist pleaded guilty Tuesday to federal criminal charges and
prepared to testify about members of Congress caught in his web of corruption.

Jack Abramoff, 46, invoked God as he apologized and pleaded guilty before a
federal judge to one charge each of conspiracy, mail fraud and tax evasion. He
faces a maximum of 30 years in prison. He also is expected to enter a plea in a
Florida indictment related to his purchase of a fleet of casino cruise ships
from a man who was murdered a few months later.

By itself, the fall of a high-flying lobbyist who collected $80 million in fees
from casino-rich Indian tribes, wined and dined politicians at his own
Washington restaurant and flew them abroad for golf outings was a dramatic tale.

But it was the likelihood that Abramoff now will help federal prosecutors go
after members of Congress that gripped official Washington.

"This is going to grow and multiply," said Bill Mateja, a former top official in
the Justice Department who is now a Dallas lawyer. "If I were on Capitol Hill, I
would be shaking in my boots. Because if anyone knows where the skeletons are
buried, it's Jack Abramoff."

Justice Department officials said they hoped their extensive investigation would
send a message about corruption.

"Government officials and government action are not for sale," said Alice
Fisher, an assistant attorney general. "The Justice Department will aggressively
investigate and prosecute these types of cases, which have a devastating impact
on the public's trust of government."

The scandal threatens to affect several high-ranking lawmakers from both major
political parties, including: - Rep. Bob Ney, R-Ohio, the chairman of the House
Administration Committee. He took a golf trip to Scotland on Abramoff's tab but
says he did nothing wrong. - Rep. Tom DeLay, R-Texas, who was forced to step
down last fall as House majority leader when he was indicted on a campaign
finance charge that isn't related to the Abramoff case. DeLay denies any
wrongdoing in taking overseas trips financed by Abramoff. His spokesman said
Tuesday that all of DeLay's actions were approved by the House ethics committee.
- Rep. John Doolittle, R-Calif., the secretary of the House Republican
Conference, who took campaign contributions from Abramoff and whose wife was
hired by an Abramoff foundation. Doolittle denies that his intervention in a
California Indian casino case, which would have helped Abramoff, was connected
to his relations to the lobbyist. - Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., the Senate minority
leader, who has denied that his intercession in an Indian casino case that would
have helped Abramoff was linked to a $5,000 contribution from an Abramoff
client.

Abramoff would serve 9 1/2 to 11 years of his sentence under federal guidelines.
He also faces a fine of more than $750,000 and mandatory restitution estimated
to be about $26.7 million -- $1.7 million of that to the Internal Revenue
Service for evading taxes, plus an undetermined amount of back taxes.

The lobbyist was contrite as he faced U.S. District Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle.

"Your honor, words will not be able to ever express how sorry I am for this, and
I have profound regret and sorrow for the multitude of mistakes and harm I have
caused," he said.

The most far-reaching charge said Abramoff corruptly influenced public officials
and their relatives.

"Abramoff and others would offer and provide things of value to public
officials, including trips, campaign contributions, meals and entertainment in
exchange for agreements that the public officials would use their official
positions and influence to benefit defendant Abramoff's clients and . . .
businesses," the federal charge said.

It didn't identify any public officials by name.

But it did say Abramoff influenced a House Committee chairman identified as
"Representative A." It said Abramoff used "a lavish trip to Scotland to play
golf on world famous courses, tickets to sporting events . . . regular meals at
Abramoff's upscale restaurant, and campaign contributions" to win official
favors from the congressman.

Representative A is apparently Ney.

An Abramoff partner, Michael Scanlon, who formerly had worked for DeLay, pleaded
guilty in November to conspiring to bribe Ney. Ney has denied wrongdoing.

The plea bargain also said Abramoff had defrauded several Indian tribes by
charging them huge fees while lying about his work or the way that money was
funneled to him. For example, it said he urged them to hire other firms while
concealing that he got a 50 percent kickback from more than $54 million that the
tribes paid those firms.

Abramoff greased his relationships with golf trips, meals at his restaurant and
seats in his luxury sky boxes at Washington sports events.

With the investigation threatening to spread, several members of Congress
recently returned campaign contributions to Abramoff, a trend that House Speaker
Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., joined Tuesday evening. He announced that he would
return $70,000 in contributions from Abramoff-related clients, including Indian
tribes.

The head of Rep. Roy Blunt's leadership PAC, called Rely on Your Beliefs Fund,
took a step Tuesday toward donating contributions of $8,500 from Abramoff to a
charity.

Burson Taylor, Blunt's spokeswoman, said, "Because the donor of these funds has
admitted to activities which are illegal . . . the executive director of the
Rely On Your Beliefs will recommend that the board donate these funds to a
charity."

From Toronto mansion to Denver court

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D04

LENGTH: 264 words

DATELINE: DENVER


A former Denver businessman who fled the United States after being accused of
evading as much as $27 million (U.S.) in state and federal taxes - and ended up
in a Canadian jail - has pleaded guilty to 112 counts of tax evasion and mail
fraud.

Thomas Quintin, 57, could receive up to 12 years in prison and a $125,000 fine
at an Oct. 29 sentencing.

The amount he is accused of evading was worth about $37 million (Canadian) at
yesterday's exchange rate.

His court-appointed defender, Edward Harris, said Quentin should receive
probation because he has been behind bars since 1998, most of it spent in a
Canadian prison.

Quintin was the owner of Max Oil Inc., which ran now-defunct Pit Stops and Mini
Stop stations in Nebraska, Wyoming and Colorado.

"I became involved in a scheme that did not pay all the taxes due on the fuel,"
Quintin told U.S. District Judge Wiley Daniel.

"In the end, I made a stupid move by leaving the country and moving to the
Cayman Islands" in 1991.

Quintin and his wife, Sandra Westphal, fled Colorado while under investigation
in California for alleged tax evasion.

The two moved to Toronto in 1998, bought a mansion and made plans to start a
chain of jewelry stores.

Canadian authorities nabbed the two while they were getting into a limousine to
attend a performance of Les Miserables, a musical about a fugitive, said
Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Brown.

Westphal suffered a serious auto accident after posting bond in Canada. Her
treatment and a "supposed friend" who drained his remaining assets left him
broke, Quintin told the court.

                               The New York Times

                 June 7, 1989, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

Judge Finds Helmsley Incompetent for Trial

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section B; Page 5, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 168 words


A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday found Harry B. Helmsley mentally
incompetent to stand trial on tax evasion charges, separating the real-estate
executive from the coming trial of his wife and two others.

''To try the defendant would deprive him of his basic rights,'' said Judge John
M. Walker Jr. in United States District Court after finding that the 80-year-old
Mr. Helmsley was unable to assist in his own defense because of memory lapses
and reasoning difficulties.

Citing the reports of several doctors, including a court-appointed
neuropsychologist, Judge Walker noted that Mr. Helmsley's condition had been
aggravated by ''a series of slight strokes.'' But the court ruling did not
dismiss the 47-count indictment against Mr. Helmsley; it only delayed his trial
indefinitely.

Mr. Helmsley, and his wife, Leona, 68, were indicted in April 1988 and accused
of personal income-tax evasion by disguising about $4 million in renovations to
their Greenwich, Conn., mansion as business expenses.

                                US Official News

                            August 13, 2013 Tuesday

Georgia: Pair Already Facing Medicaid Fraud Charges Accused of Income Tax
Evasion

LENGTH: 288  words

DATELINE: Atlanta


Office of The Attorney General, The State of Georgia has issued the following
news release:

Fulton County Grand Jury indicted Derrell Jackson and Shayla Darrington-Jackson
for two counts of Income Tax Evasion (O.C.G.A. § 48-7-5). The Jacksons are also
facing charges in Gwinnett County for Medicaid Fraud for allegedly obtaining
over $600,000 of Medicaid funds by submitting false billing to the Georgia
Medicaid program over the course of three years.

According to the Gwinnett County Medicaid Fraud indictment, their company,
Project Focus, LLC, was enrolled in the Georgia Medicaid program to provide
in-home mental health counseling to youths diagnosed with severe behavioral
disorders. The State's investigation determined that they received Medicaid
billing payments in 2008 and in 2009. The Fulton County indictment charges that
they have not filed state tax returns or paid state income taxes owed for the
income they earned from Medicaid billing during those years.

Income Tax Evasion is punishable by one to five years imprisonment and a fine of
up to $100,000 for each count.

The case is being prosecuted by Assistant Attorney General Greg Lohmeier. Nora
Benavidez and Lohmeier presented the case to the Fulton County Grand Jury. The
case was investigated by Douglas Legg of the Georgia Department of Revenue.

Members of the public should keep in mind that indictments contain only
allegations against the individual(s) against whom the indictment is sought. A
defendant is presumed innocent until proven guilty, and it will be the
government's burden at trial to prove the defendant guilty beyond a reasonable
doubt of the allegations contained in the indictment.

For further information please visit: http://law.ga.gov/

                         Mail Tribune (Medford, Oregon)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 9, 2011 Wednesday

Ashland resident can't promote tax evasion, court says

BYLINE: Sanne Specht, Mail Tribune, Medford, Ore.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 617 words


Nov. 09--Ashland resident Robert Pendell escaped jail time when a judge tossed
out his recent conviction in a tax fraud trial.

But a federal court has permanently barred him from promoting any scheme that
assists or advises customers to attempt to violate tax laws.

The Oregon Department of Justice on Monday announced the civil injunction order
was entered by Judge Owen M. Panner of the United States District Court in
Medford.

The United States charged Pendell and fellow Ashland resident Eugene "Gino"
Casternovia, along with Mark Lyon of Williams, and their company, the Southern
Oregon Resource Center Educational Services (SORCE) in April 2008 to stop them
from promoting a scheme to conceal their customers' assets from the Internal
Revenue Service.

Following a monthlong trial in Pensacola, Florida, Casternovia in April 2010 was
convicted of conspiracy to defraud the United States and to commit wire fraud
and conspiracy to commit money laundering. He faced a possible 25-year prison
sentence and $750,000 in fines. Casternovia in September 2010 was sentenced to
seven years in prison by a Florida federal court for his part in the tax and
debt elimination scheme. Williams, another employee, previously pleaded guilty
to all charges filed against him and agreed to testify for the prosecution in
the cases.

U.S. District Judge Margaret C. Rodgers set aside a jury verdict against
Pendell, who was a former employee of Casternovia's, and acquitted him of all
counts.

Department of Justice prosecutors alleged that the defendants promoted
fraudulent schemes through Pinnacle Quest International, also known as PQI and
Quest International. (PQI was described as an umbrella organization for vendors
who sold tax and credit card debt elimination scams.)

Prosecutors said some of the PQI vendors, including Casternovia's Southern
Oregon Resource Center for Education (SORCE), sold bogus theories and strategies
for tax evasion. For fees starting at $10,000, they said, SORCE assisted clients
in the creation of a series of sham business entities in the United States and
Panama.

According to the court, injunctions were previously entered against Casternovia
and Lyon. In recommending that Pendell's activities also be blocked, United
States Magistrate Judge Mark D. Clarke cited a 2005 videotaped interview in
which Pendell equated the payment of taxes to slavery and stated that SORCE
products enabled customers to "reclaim their sovereign rights."

The court found that SORCE had at least 350 customers and, according to its
internal records, made more than $1.6 million in 2005 through the sale of its
programs.

The programs weren't tax planning, they were criminal activity, Victor S.O.
Song, chief of the Criminal Investigation Division of the Internal Revenue
Service, said after the verdicts.

According to the evidence presented, none of the defendants filed tax returns
while they were involved in the PQI conspiracy.

Prosecutors said another PQI vendor, MYICIS, operated as a computerized
"warehouse bank" in which PQI clients pooled their money to hide their assets
from the Internal Revenue Service. MYICIS had 3,000 clients and approximately
$100 million in deposits over a three-year period, they said.

According to evidence presented at trial, PQI purported to sell only CDs and
tickets to offshore conferences. However, PQI clients seeking the tax evasion
and debt elimination vendors were required to join PQI, with the cost of
membership ranging from $1,350 to $18,750.

Reach reporter Sanne Specht at 541-776-4497 or e-mail sspecht@mailtribune.com

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                            October 4, 2008 Saturday
                                  Main Edition

ROAD ATLANTA REPORT: Castroneves pleads not guilty to tax charges

BYLINE: RICK MINTER; Staff

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 2D

LENGTH: 520 words


Braselton --- Two-time Indy 500 champion Helio Castroneves wasn't at Road
Atlanta on Friday for qualifying. Instead, he was in federal court in Miami
facing charges of tax evasion and tax fraud.

The Associated Press reported that the Indy Racing League star from Sao Paulo,
Brazil, who is expected to participate in today's Petit Le Mans, is accused of
using offshore accounts to avoid paying taxes to the Internal Revenue Service.

The AP reported that Castroneves, 33, pleaded not guilty to six counts of tax
evasion for allegedly failing to report to the IRS about $5.5 million in income
between 1999 and 2004. Each count carries a maximum five-year prison sentence.

Penske Racing vice president Bud Denker said Castroneves was scheduled to return
to Georgia on Friday night and prepare to co-drive the team's No. 5 Porsche with
Australian Ryan Briscoe. Briscoe qualified the car first in the LMP2 class and
fourth overall for today's race.

Denker declined to speculate on what effect the court proceedings would have on
Castroneves' relationship with the team.

"It's premature to speculate on what will happen," he said. "He's still our
driver, and we're going ahead as planned."

However, Castroneves likely will miss a scheduled appearance in an exhibition
race in Australia on Oct. 24-26 because he will be surrendering his passport,
according to team officials.

Sticking with a schedule

The Braselton-based American Le Mans Series, of which the Petit Le Mans is the
marquee event, took a page from an old NASCAR playbook when it announced that
the circuit's 2009 schedule will be virtually identical to the lineup from this
year and previous years.

That allows the circuit to build on established race dates and venues just as
NASCAR has done over the years with major events such as the Daytona 500 and
Coca-Cola 600.

The 2009 schedule begins with the Mobil 1 Twelve Hours of Sebring on March 21
and ends Oct. 10 at Mazda Raceway Laguna Seca. Because of the way the 2009
calendar falls, some events move up or back a week. The Petit Le Mans will run
on Sept. 26.

"We have established a strong, consistent schedule to which fans are getting
accustomed," said the circuit's chief operating officer, Tim Mayer. "That
certainly helps establish our fan base as well as foster growth and tradition."

Fellows favors Corvette

Corvette driver Ron Fellows is familiar to NASCAR fans because of his
appearances in races on the road courses at Watkins Glen, Infineon Raceway in
California and in Montreal, where he won a Nationwide Series race this year. He
said driving the nimble sports cars requires a completely different approach
than the more powerful NASCAR racers.

He tested a Dale Earnhardt Inc. car at Road Atlanta in July and ran 10 seconds a
lap slower than in his Corvette.

"The NASCAR car was faster on the straightaways, but it's 1,000 pounds heavier
and has half the downforce and doesn't have carbon-fiber brakes," he said. "The
biggest difference is the speed in the corners."

He said both cars put on a good show for the fans, but he'd rather drive the
sports car.

"You can be ultra-aggressive and get away with it," he said.

Ex-Executive Is Found Guilty In Nassau Insurance Case

BYLINE:  By PATRICK HEALY

SECTION: Section B; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 417 words

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Jan. 21


A former health insurance executive accused of being the mastermind in an
insurance scam that cost Nassau taxpayers millions of dollars was found guilty
on Wednesday of evading $1 million in income taxes, prosecutors said.

A jury convicted the executive, Albert E. Isernio, the former president of the
Benefit Plan Administrators Company, on two counts of tax evasion and two counts
of structuring bank deposits to avoid reporting requirements, said Joseph
Conway, an assistant United States attorney. Prosecutors have said that Mr.
Isernio forged documents, paid bribes and covered up wrongdoing to win a health
insurance contract with Nassau County, a deal that eventually cost Nassau
taxpayers $70 million.

Mr. Isernio's first trial on charges of bribery and fraud ended with a hung
jury, and he will be re-tried on those charges within the next two weeks, Mr.
Conway said. In fact, it was his testimony at the earlier trial that spurred
prosecutors to examine Mr. Isernio's tax returns, leading to the charges of tax
evasion.

"They had the guy, and they were going to get him one way or the other on
something," said a Nassau legislator, Lisanne Altmann, whose questions helped
uncover the insurance scheme during the late 1990's. "If they can't get you on
something, they get on income tax fraud."

In his defense, Mr. Isernio said that he had merely forgotten to report some
six-figure bonuses, and blamed his accountant for omitting capital gains from
his tax returns, prosecutors said.

Prosecutors had said Mr. Isernio lost hundreds of thousands of dollars betting
on blackjack at casinos in the Bahamas, Atlantic City and Nevada, sometimes
wagering $5,000 on a single hand. But his lawyer insisted that Mr. Isernio was
not addicted to gambling and only lost what he could afford, the Associated
Press reported.

After an eight-day trial, jurors deliberated just two and a half hours before
delivering their guilty verdicts on Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Conway said.

Mr. Isernio's lawyer asked Judge Joanna Seybert for a one-day stay of the
conviction so Mr. Isernio could get his affairs in order and kiss his children
goodbye, said Bob Nardoza, a spokesman for the Eastern United States District
Attorney's Office.

Prosecutors had argued that Mr. Isernio posed a flight risk because of his
pending trial and the fact that he faces $2 million in back taxes. The judge
ordered that Mr. Isernio be taken into custody.

The judge said that Mr. Isernio's wife could drive herself home, Mr. Nardoza
said.

                              The Washington Post

                   December 15, 1994, Thursday, Final Edition

Backers Try to Save School Official's Job

Steve Bates, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C3

LENGTH: 458 words


Supporters of James E. McClure, an Alexandria school official who pleaded guilty
in June to federal tax evasion, are beginning a major lobbying effort to prevent
his possible demotion or firing.

In letters to some city residents and in an advertisement scheduled to appear
today in a local newspaper, McClure's allies demand that he be retained as
guidance director at T.C. Williams, Alexandria's only public high school.

Under state law, people convicted of a felony such as tax evasion could lose
their state teaching license and no longer would be eligible to teach or be a
guidance counselor.

However, they are entitled to hearings before their school board and state
education officials.

Even if McClure retains his license, the superintendent and School Board could
vote to discipline him, such as by demotion or firing.

McClure's attorney, Gregory L. Murphy, had asked Alexandria school officials for
a public hearing Saturday, but spokesmen for both sides said yesterday they plan
to postpone the hearing until early 1995.

Neither Murphy nor school officials would say whether they would settle the
matter privately. McClure was unavailable for comment.

Nevertheless, residents are forging ahead with their campaign, arguing that
McClure, 55, of Springfield, can do more good than harm if he keeps his post.

"Yes, Jim made a serious mistake. However, he has paid the legal penalties and
suffered public humiliation," says the ad, which is addressed to the School
Board and is scheduled to appear in today's Alexandria Gazette Packet.

"Please make room for redemption while you deliberate this case," concludes the
ad, which is signed by about 400 residents.

McClure, who was released last month after serving 60 days in jail, has been
moved from the high school to the central administrative offices while his fate
is deliberated in Alexandria and in Richmond. McClure, who has been in the top
guidance post at T.C. Williams for 21 years, is paid $ 65,000 annually.

In a letter he sent to some city residents last week, he said he was ready to
return to his job at the high school.

While in jail, he advised some students by telephone and counseled other
inmates.

"Walking into my cellblock in the Alexandria Jail was, at times, like walking
into the T.C. Williams cafeteria," wrote McClure, who said the experience made
him realize that many young people are "falling through the cracks. ... Some of
the young men I met there had once been T.C. Williams students."

Acting Superintendent Maxine Wood also was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Sources familiar with the case said she had not yet made a recommendation on
whether McClure should lose his state teaching license or be disciplined by the
school system.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                             July 14, 1992, Tuesday

Promoter found guilty of tax evasion

BYLINE: By Bill Montgomery STAFF WRITERradio; finances; taxation; investigations

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Section F; Page 4

LENGTH: 353 words


A federal court jury Monday convicted College Park record promoter Gregory
Johnson of income tax evasion, but acquitted him of payola charges linked to an
Atlanta radio station.

The mixed verdict brought declarations of vindication from both Johnson and the
federal prosecutor.

"We lost a few fingers and toes on the payola charges, but the guts of our case
were felonies of more than $ 550,000 in unreported income, and we're delighted
the jury agreed," said Assistant U.S. Attorney Martin Weinstein.

After more than seven hours of deliberations Friday and Monday, the jury
acquitted Johnson of two other tax evasion counts. A third tax charge was
dismissed by Judge Jack Camp during the weeklong trial.

Johnson testified he was "too busy paying bills and paying the people who worked
for me" to keep adequate tax records.

"It was a mistake, but I was trying to get records played," said Johnson.
"That's what I'm good at."

"If Gregg had been a better record keeper, he would have walked out of here,"
said his defense attorney, David Jones. The defendant, who has been free on $
25,000 bond, was released pending sentencing Sept. 29.

3 alleged instances of payola

Johnson was indicted last January on tax evasion charges and three instances of
alleged cash payoffs in 1989 and 1990 to Sidney Wood, then music director of
WVEE-FM (V-103). Mr. Wood resigned from the "urban contemporary" format station
in the fall of 1990. The payoffs, Mr. Wood testified, totaled $ 900.

Johnson and his attorney said Mr. Wood lacked credibility because of his
inability to relate exactly where the alleged payoffs from Johnson took place.

Under defense cross-examination, Mr. Wood acknowledged he testified to a federal
grand jury last October of five other instances of where he was allegedly given
payola by other record promoters, including in a promoter's office, at a hotel
and outside a radio station.

Mr. Weinstein refused to discuss any allegations of payola other than those
against Johnson.

"They knew this guy was a liar," said Johnson, who added he hopes to continue
his record-promoting business.

Washington: East Lyme Fisherman Sentenced to Federal Prison for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 314  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:





    Deirdre M. Daly, United States Attorney for the District of Connecticut,
announced that PETER TORRES, 48, of East Lyme, was sentenced today by Chief U.S.
District Judge Janet C. Hall in New Haven to three months of imprisonment,
followed by three years of supervised release, for tax evasion.



    According to court documents and statements made in court, from 2006 to
2011, TORRES failed to file tax returns and report to the Internal Revenue
Service approximately $1.27 million in gross income generated through his work
as a commercial fishing boat captain.

    On November 30, 2015, TORRES pleaded guilty to one count of attempted tax
evasion, admitting that he was issued Forms 1099 that documented the income paid
to him for each tax year, but he failed to timely file his tax returns as
required and report the income and tax due to the IRS.  In his plea agreement,
TORRES agreed that the tax loss for this period is between $250,000 and
$550,000.

    TORRES also admitted that, in an effort to conceal his income from the IRS,
he negotiated checks he received as payment for his fishing services by
depositing them in the bank and, on the same day, withdrawing cash or obtaining
bank checks in varying amounts under $10,000.

    As part of his guilty plea, TORRES acknowledged that he attempted to evade
the assessment and payment of his taxes for the 2006 through 2011 tax years.  He
will enter into a payment plan with the IRS to repay the back taxes and
applicable penalties and interest.

    This case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service - Criminal
Investigation Division, and was prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Anastasia
E. King.

                          manchestereveningnews.co.uk

                    February 25, 2016 Thursday 10:37 PM GMT

Eight arrests after police seize more than 130,000 illegal cigarettes;
HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) officers raided 11 premises in the Strangeways,
Cheetham Hill and Bury areas

BYLINE: By Alexandra Rucki

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 357 words


Eight men have been arrested after police seized more than 130,000 suspected
illegal cigarettes.

HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) officers seized the goods during a series of raids
in Strangeways , Cheetham Hill and Bury on Wednesday.

The officers seized material in relation to suspected tax evasion including
137,600 cigarettes, 73 kilos of tobacco, counterfeit cash and four vehicles.

They recovered the items during searches of nine retail properties, one domestic
address and a storage container.

Officers from Immigration Enforcement also arrested six men for immigration
offences.

Counterfeit goods worth an estimated £2m were seized from 11 premises and 49,350
individual doses of unlicensed medicines were retrieved.

Greater Manchester Police seized two vans and issued several dispersal notices.

The huge operation involved investigations into a number of suspected offences
including tax evasion, smuggling, immigration and counterfeiting.

Mike Parkinson, assistant director of Fraud Investigation Service for HMRC,
said: "HMRC has significant criminal and civil powers to disrupt criminality and
tackle tax evasion on many levels.

"Sharing intelligence on suspected criminal activity with other agencies and
working together is key to our enforcement work.

"Combined with the powers of our partners we are able to take effective action
to ensure nobody is acting above the law."

Coun Nigel Murphy, executive member for neighbourhoods at Manchester council,
said: "Counterfeiting is not a victimless crime and such goods are often poor
quality or unsafe.

"Consumers are also completely unprotected with little chance of getting their
money back and the illegal trade undermines and jeopardises legitimate traders.

"Operations such as this, working with partners at GMP and HMRC, are vital to
get fake items off the street and I'd like to praise those involved."

Rebekah Sutcliffe, Assistant Chief Constable for GMP, added: "The Strangeways
area is one of the largest counterfeit goods suppliers in the UK and the sale of
these products has a huge impact on local taxpayers and businesses, as well as
potentially funding more serious and violent crime."

                                  ALL EDITION

BLAZER BANNED FOR LIFE BY FIFA;
SOCCER

BYLINE:  Staff, wire reports

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 463 words


Chuck Blazer was expelled by FIFA's ethics committee on Thursday for widespread
corruption, finally ending the career of the longtime most-senior American in
world football.

The lifetime ban from football duty was a formality after Blazer's guilty plea
to racketeering and tax evasion charges was unsealed in May by United States
federal agencies.

FIFA's ethics panel made its ruling in Zurich using evidence from the American
federal case which has plunged FIFA and international football into crisis.

"(Blazer) was a key player in schemes involving the offer, acceptance, payment
and receipt of undisclosed and illegal payments, bribes and kickbacks as well as
other money-making schemes," the FIFA ethics committee said in a statement.

Blazer pleaded guilty to 10 counts including racketeering conspiracy, wire fraud
conspiracy, money laundering conspiracy and income tax evasion.

He was a cooperating witness with United States federal agencies since 2011
after his tax affairs were investigated.

AUTO RACING

Crafton prevails in Trucks race

Matt Crafton earned his ninth career NASCAR Camping World Truck Series victory
at Kentucky Speedway in Sparta in a race stopped early because of a wreck that
damaged the catch fence.

NASCAR called the race with five laps to go after Ben Kennedy's truck clipped
and bent portions of the catch fence in Turn 1. Kennedy's truck lifted off the
ground and slid on top of the SAFER barrier after making contact with the trucks
of David Gilliland and John Wes Townley.

Kennedy was not injured in the crash.

Crafton, the two-time defending series champion, had passed Erik Jones for the
lead on a restart with six laps to go. Jones finished second.

TRACK AND FIELD

Gatlin routs field in 100 meters

Justin Gatlin easily beat two big-name rivals by clocking 9.75 seconds in the
100 meters at the Athletissima Diamond League meet in Lausanne, Switzerland.

The in-form Gatlin left runner-up Asafa Powell of Jamaica trailing in 9.92, the
same time as his fellow American Tyson Gay in third.

The time was 0.01 outside Gatlin's world-leading season-best and the 2004
Olympic champion remained unbeaten in the 100 since 2013.

LOCALLY

Jacob Werlein , who will be a freshman this fall at Waunakee High School, shot a
69 to give him a nine-stroke lead in the 13-14 age group and a five-stroke
cushion on two golfers overall entering today's final round of the Madison City
Junior Golf tournament at Hawks Landing Golf Club.

                          February 11, 2015 Wednesday

New Jersey: Doctor with offices in Jersey City, North Bergen admits tax evasion

LENGTH: 431  words

DATELINE: Trenton


Bergen County, The State of New Jersey has issued the following news release:

A doctor who owns three immediate care facilities in Hudson County today
admitted making millions of dollars' worth of cash deposits and fraudulently
transferring his residence to a family member to evade taxes, authorities
announced.

Medhat El Amir of Saddle River pleaded guilty before U.S. District Judge Jose L.
Linares in Newark federal court to corruptly endeavoring to impede the Internal
Revenue Code, and tax evasion, in connection with an individual income tax
return from 2007.

U.S. Attorney Paul J. Fishman and Tax Division Principal Deputy Assistant
Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo announced the guilty plea today, some 10
months after El Amir was arrested and charged with tax evasion in April.

According to documents filed in this case and statements made in court, El Amir
was a primary care doctor and 60 percent owner of Immediate Care P.C., which
provided urgent health care services for patients at an office in North Bergen
and two offices in Jersey City.

From Feb. 11, 2005 through Dec. 31, 2010, El Amir attempted to impede the
internal revenue laws in a number of ways, authorities said. He admitted he
fraudulently transferred his residence in Saddle River to his sister for $2.5
million to keep the property out of the reach of the IRS and the payroll taxes
he owed through his former practice, according to authorities.

El Amir also admitted cashing $7,261,083 in Immediate Care insurance company
checks at a check cashing facility, depositing the majority of that income into
a number of bank accounts to which he had access and using a portion of the
money for personal expenses, authorities said.

El Amir admitted he failed to report taxable income of more than $2 million from
2007 through 2010, resulting in a $502,160 tax loss to the government.
Despite earning a significant income from his practice, El Amir did not file
personal income tax returns for calendar years 2007, 2009 and 2010.

El Amir did file a personal income tax return for 2008, but substantially
under-reported the income he received from Immediate Care and claimed interest
deductions to which he was not entitled.

The count of corruptly endeavoring to impede the due administration of the
Internal Revenue Code carries a maximum potential penalty of three years in
prison and a $250,000 fine. The count of tax evasion carries a maximum potential
penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

Washington: Jersey County Man Sentenced for $1.2 Million Tax Evasion and
Unlawful Firearms Possession

LENGTH: 479  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

A Jersey County resident was sentenced to federal prison for tax evasion and
possession of a firearm by a user of controlled substances on December 19, 2014,
the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Illinois, Stephen R.
Wigginton, announced today. David Ray, 55, of Fieldon, Illinois, was sentenced
to 37 months in federal prison, a $7,500 fine, $1,272,904.83 in restitution, a
$200 special assessment and three years of supervised release. Ray also
forfeited a gun collection valued between $75,000-$100,000.

"In stealing from all of us by failing to pay his fair share of taxes, Ray not
only ended up forfeiting his gun collection, but he forfeited his privilege to
live in his mansion for the much harsher living conditions of federal prison."
noted United States Attorney Wigginton.

Ray waived his right to face a grand jury indictment and pled guilty to charges
brought directly by the U.S. Attorney's Office on July 23, 2013. Documents filed
in District Court established that Ray committed tax evasion by using his
various businesses to pay personal expenses, by vesting ownership of personal
assets in the name of his businesses, and by filing false tax returns with the
IRS or refusing to file a U.S. Individual Tax Return all together. In tax years
2005-2010, Ray concealed income from the IRS for the purpose of limiting his tax
liability resulting in him avoiding $1,272,904.83 in federal income taxes that
he otherwise would have been required to pay. Ray agreed to make full
restitution to the IRS as a condition of his guilty plea.

Ray was also convicted for possessing firearms while being a cocaine user.
Evidence presented at the plea hearing established that federal agents seized 96
firearms and more than 2,500 rounds of ammunition from Ray's home when it was
searched on February 13, 2012. In addition, agents also seized 110 grams of
cocaine from Ray's home. Ray admitted possessing the firearms as a hunter and
gun collector. But he also acknowledged a serious cocaine habit, admitting that
he purchased and used 3-5 ounces of cocaine every 2-3 weeks prior to his home
being raided. Under federal law, drug users are categorically prohibited from
possessing firearms.

Ray was ordered to remain in custody of the United States Marshal pending his
transfer to federal prison.

The investigation was conducted by agents from the Internal Revenue
Service/Criminal Investigations, the Jersey County Sheriff's Department, the
Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the Drug Enforcement
Administration, and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The case was prosecuted
by Assistant United States Attorney Steven D. Weinhoeft.

                           December 4, 2013 Wednesday
                              WED REGIONAL Edition

Business Briefs

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 16A

LENGTH: 673 words


LENNAR WINS $1 BILLION IN DEFAMATION CASE

A Florida jury has awarded homebuilder Lennar Corp. $1 billion in damages in its
civil lawsuit against a California developer who Lennar alleges orchestrated a
smear campaign against it in 2008 and 2009.

The Circuit Court jury in Miami late Monday awarded $802 million in compensatory
damages and $200 million in punitive damages against Nicolas Marsch III and his
company, Briarwood Capital LLC. The award is the latest twist in a seven year
saga that included the 2011 guilty plea and jailing of self styled fraud
investigator Barry Minkow.

of Internet infrastructure services, announced Tuesday it has reworked its
credit agreement, including adding $150 million to its loan facility and
reducing interest on its revolving credit facility.

The $1.6 billion term loan facility was increased by $150 million to $1.75

loans on behalf of lenders.

The CFPB already oversees banks that service student loans, but it says most
student loans are serviced by nonbank companies.

                            February 12, 2010 Friday

Cole Camp man gets five years for fraud, tax evasion

BYLINE: The Sedalia Democrat, Sedalia, Mo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 458 words


Feb. 12--A Cole Camp man has been sentenced to serve five years in prison for
wire fraud and tax evasion related to a nearly $950,000 scheme selling farm
equipment at bargain prices.

Robert Thomas Bain, 44, was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Nanette Laughrey on
Wednesday to five years in federal prison without parole. The court also ordered
Bain to pay $1,267,394 in restitution to 23 victims and the IRS.

Bain pleaded guilty to wire fraud and tax evasion Feb. 8, 2008 in U.S. District
Court in Kansas City. He admitted that he developed a fraud scheme to offer
propane, fertilizer and other farm supplies to customers at prices below the
market rate, according to a news release from the office of the United States
Attorney Western District of Missouri.

Bain operated Heartland Farm Supply and in February 2004, he incorporated
Heartland Farm Services Inc., a retail business selling propane and farm
equipment.

Bain offered customers low-cost supplies, which he knew he could not purchase to
encourage customers to pay a membership fee and join Heartland, according to the
U.S. Attorney's Office.

Customers were required to pay a deposit and on some occasions pay the full
amount of the ordered farm supplies. Bain did not deliver all of the ordered
products and did not intend to, the release states.

The full amount of the loss to Bain's customers totals $948,737.

The wire fraud charge refers to a $172,500 wire transfer from Illinois to Bain's
Heartland bank account, which was for the purchase of potash fertilizer that he
never delivered.

During 2004, approximately $3 million in Heartland gross receipts were deposited
into the business checking account. Business expenses for 2004 totaled $2.76
million.

Bain did not file a 2004 federal income tax return on $285,000 of income and
failed to report business gross receipts of $4,849 of expenses. He also did not
report business expenses totaling $18,077 for A Taste of Germany, a business
that his wife operated, the release states.

In 2003, Bain did not report his Heartland business profits, causing his 2003
federal income tax to be false. In 2003, Bain had a federal taxable income of
$39,309 and owed $13,138 in federal tax.

The case was investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, IRS-Criminal
Investigation and the Missouri Attorney General's Office.

                            January 26, 2009 Monday

Stanford Law grad-turned-escort pleads guilty to tax evasion

BYLINE: By Josh Richman Oakland Tribune

SECTION: MY TOWN; Alameda; Crime; News; Local

LENGTH: 473 words


A former Bay Area woman who worked as a high-priced call girl to pay off her
Stanford Law School loans has pleaded guilty to tax evasion, ending almost five
years of cat-and-mouse with federal prosecutors.

Cristina Warthen, 35, now of Los Angeles but formerly of Palo Alto and Oakland,
entered her plea Monday before U.S. District Judge James Ware of San Jose; she's
scheduled to be sentenced June 15. The maximum penalty is five years in prison
and a $100,000 fine, but Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation
Division Special Agent Arlette Lee said Monday that Warthen's plea agreement
indicates she will pay the government $313,133.74 and serve three years of
probation including one year of home confinement.

In her plea agreement, Warthen   nee Cristina Schultz, before she married
millionaire Ask.com co-founder David Warthen in May 2004   acknowledged she ran
an escort business in which she exchanged sexual acts for money. The
TouchofBrazil.net Web site in 2004 featured photos of her in various states of
undress while offering pricing for her company and her nationwide travel
schedule; it described her as a "Portuguese-speaking entertainer and physical
model."

Warthen now admits that she grossed more than $133,000 from her escort business
in 2003 but didn't file a tax return for that year, and she acknowledges she
tried to hide her income by storing cash in a safe-deposit box and buying postal
money orders in amounts designed to avoid federal currency transaction reports.

Clients posting reviews of Brazil's services at another Web site gave her rave
and sometimes, explicit   reviews up through February 2004, a month after IRS
agents seized evidence and $61,171 from her apartment, her storage locker and
her safe deposit box. The Justice Department in July 2004 sued to keep that
money under federal civil asset forfeiture laws that let the government keep
property or money representing a federal crime's proceeds even if the owner
hasn't been charged with the alleged crime.

That forfeiture complaint had said Schultz operated an interstate prostitution
business since at least August 2001   three months after earning her Stanford
Law School degree   by charging as much as $1,300 for two hours, $5,000 for
overnight and $15,000 for three days to serve clients in the Bay Area, Los
Angeles, Washington, D.C., New York City, Chicago and Seattle. Her own April
2003 posting to an escort-reviews Web site had said that when she finished her
law degree, she "owed over 300 thousand in loans and hated the prospect of being
a lawyer for the next twenty yrs."(sic)

A federal judge dismissed the civil forfeiture action in 2006 as Warthen and the
government reached a secret settlement. Prosecutors filed the tax evasion charge
against Warthen in September.

Kaiser cuts 175 jobs in IT unit

BYLINE: Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 427 words


Kaiser Permanente confirmed that it has eliminated 175 information technology
jobs in Pleasanton. The health care giant has dismissed some IT workers already,
said Kaiser spokesman Jim Caroompas. Others will depart soon.

Kaiser said the IT employment cuts are part of an overall strategic effort by
the organization. Kaiser's IT workforce totals 5,600.

Regulatory

John Frances Griffin, 43, chief executive of a Livermore startup company called
VaporTech Inc., was sentenced to 30 months in federal prison on two counts of
tax evasion. The charges result from a joint investigation by the Internal
Revenue Service and the FBI.

Griffin, an Orinda resident, was indicted in 2006 on multiple counts of tax
evasion and mail fraud. Griffin later pleaded guilty to the two counts.

According to the plea agreement, Griffin's VaporTech company was researching and
developing technologies that convert fuel to hot water, high-quality steam or
super-heated water vapor.

Griffin raised more than $2.5 million from investors. During 2004 and 2005, the
plea disclosed, Griffin received taxable income in excess of $1.2 million, yet
he failed to file federal income tax returns.

A federal judge ordered Griffin to pay $747,000 in restitution to VaporTech. The
judge also ordered Griffin to forfeit a variety of items. These include $75,000
in cash, a diamond ring valued at $30,000, a gold tennis bracelet worth $3,400
and thousands of dollars worth of clothing and wine.

Groceries

Pleasanton-based Safeway Inc. expects profit to rise more this year than its
long-term growth target, Chief Financial Officer Robert Edwards said Wednesday.

Safeway forecast last month that earnings per share this year would be at the
top end of a forecast of $1.95 to $2, which would exceed the 12 percent to 15
percent growth the company projected for coming years.

The presentation didn't include a change to the company's 2007 earnings
forecast, Melissa Plaisance, senior vice president of finance for Safeway, said
after the meeting.

Safeway shares rose 56 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $32.57 at 2:44 p.m. in New York
Stock Exchange composite trading. The shares had dropped 7.4 percent this year
before Wednesday.

Quick hit

Pioneering plug-in hybrid vehicle technology and transmission systems developed
at UC Davis will be put to work by Palo Alto-based Efficient Drivetrains Inc.,
which leased the technology under an agreement negotiated by the UC Davis
InnovationAccess unit.

                     July 27, 1989, Thursday, Final Edition

Democrats Spar in N.Y. Mayoral Debate;
Koch Assailed for 'Corrupt Administration,' Dinkins for 'Tax Evasion'

BYLINE: Howard Kurtz, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A3

LENGTH: 708 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK, July 26, 1989


Mayor Edward I. Koch and Manhattan Borough President David N. Dinkins traded
verbal blows today in their first debate of the campaign for the Democratic
mayoral nomination, with Koch accusing Dinkins of "tax evasion" and Dinkins
assailing the mayor for "the most corrupt administration since Jimmy Walker."

Dinkins, who is seeking to become New York's first black mayor, turned in a
confident, fact-filled performance that did nothing to disturb his front-runner
status in the Sept. 12 Democratic primary. But Koch, deftly mixing biting
criticism and humor, overshadowed Dinkins and two lesser rivals while fending
off their combined assaults.

In a typical slap at Koch's 12-year tenure, former city transit chief Richard
Ravitch told the mayor: "You've worn out your welcome. We need someone who's a
unifier, not a divider."

Questioned repeatedly by a panel of journalists about racial tensions here, Koch
insisted that the climate is better than in Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles and
Boston, and that he had named numerous blacks to high office. "Occasionally, my
rhetoric may be insensitive. . . . Where I have erred, I apologize. I'll try to
do better," he said.

The mayor, glasses perched atop his head, said he had "wept" over the corruption
scandals that have scarred his third term and that he had done his best to root
out wrongdoing.

The gray-haired Dinkins, never deviating from his low-key style, smoothly
fielded a question about his failure to file tax returns from 1969 through 1973.
"I made a mistake a long time ago, almost 20 years. . . . I'm sorry it happened.
It was my fault. I blame no one. It is not something I'm proud of, I wish it had
never happened, but clearly I'm not guilty of tax evasion," he said.

But Koch, who worried aloud last week that he might be labeled a racist for
attacking Dinkins, showed no reticence today. "If you are a lawyer and you don't
pay your taxes . . . year after year for four consecutive years, what else would
be an appropriate description? Negligence? Forgetfulness?"

Dinkins, asked if his strong union support might lead him to "give away the
store" in contract talks, said: "It is true I am supported by those persons who
clean the bedpans and tend the frail elderly and drive our buses and taxis."
But, he added, "My friends in labor . . . will get nothing to which they're not
entitled."

After the opening minutes, Dinkins muted his criticism of Koch. When the mayor
boasted that his administration is renovating 250,000 apartments, Dinkins
charged him with "sleight of hand," saying: "Many of those are apartments that
are simply going to be painted."

As the front-runner, the Harlem politician was apparently following his own
script. When the panel failed to ask about abortion, Dinkins raised the issue
himself, saying his support for publicly funded abortions would distinguish him
from Republican-Liberal candidate Rudolph W. Giuliani in November. The others
echoed their agreement.

The harshest exchange erupted between Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin,
who have apparently detested each other for years. It began when Goldin
ridiculed Koch for insisting "that everything is hunky-dory. Ed, go outside.
Fall over the bodies in the streets of this city sleeping outside."

Koch quickly rattled off four past investigations of Goldin. "While there have
been no criminal charges against him so far . . . he is the most investigated
comptroller in the city's history," Koch said.

Goldin, clearly livid, slowly pronounced the names of several convicted Koch
aides. "They haul 'em off in manacles. They throw 'em in jail. You dismiss them
in disgrace. That's a record you can't laugh away."

The candidates' contrasting styles were highlighted by a question about how they
could identify with the poorest New Yorkers. "I'm the product of a broken home,"
Dinkins said. He said his mother and grandmother "were domestics, worked six,
seven days a week for $ 7 or $ 8 a week. I sold shopping bags on the corner of
125th Street. . . . I shined shoes, washed dishes, washed cars, worked in
factories, waited tables."

Koch fielded the same question like a stand-up comic, saying: "I talk like a New
Yorker, I walk like a New Yorker, I think like a New Yorker."

                 April 7, 1989, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Rose: Indicted Man Is No Longer a Friend

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 26, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 379 words

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, April 6


Pete Rose distanced himself today from former acquaintances who face prison
sentences on drug and tax charges. The Cincinnati Reds manager, who is under
investigation by the baseball commissioner, said after a 4-1 loss to the Los
Angeles Dodgers that he was not as close to the acquaintances as indicated in
news reports.

''I'm guilty of one thing: I wasn't a very good picker of friends,'' Rose said.
''I'm not their friends anymore. Every time something happens, you guys act like
they're my best friends.''

The latest former acquaintance to land in trouble is Thomas P. Gioiosa, who as a
teenager lived with Rose and his family several years ago. Gioiosa was indicted
in Federal court in Cincinnati today on charges of tax evasion and conspiracy to
distribute cocaine from Florida to the Cincinnati area.

The five-count indictment accuses him of income-tax evasion and conspiring with
others to arrange cocaine deliveries from Florida to Cincinnati between January
1985 and January 1987.

There has been no suggestion that Rose was involved with drugs. The
investigation reportedly centers on gambling, including accusations that he bet
on baseball games.

Several people formerly associated with Gold's Gym in Cincinnati, where Rose
used to work out, are serving prison sentences. Donald Stenger, former co-owner
of the gym, pleaded guilty March 24 in Federal court in Cincinnati to smuggling
cocaine and was sentenced to 10 years in prison. Federal prosecutors said
Stenger was the head of the cocaine ring of which Gioiosa allegedly was a part.

Another co-owner, Michael Fry, is serving an eight-year Federal prison sentence
for cocaine trafficking and income-tax evasion.

The indictment against Gioiosa alleges that he falsely claimed $47,646 in
gambling earnings from the winning ticket on a Jan. 16, 1987, race at Turfway
Park in Florence, Ky., and falsely listed it as income on his Federal tax return
for 1987. The indictment charges that Gioiosa claimed the entire amount as
income and offset a portion of that claimed income with gambling losses which
would otherwise be non-deductible.

The indictment accuses Gioiosa of conspiring with others to prevent the Internal
Revenue Service from determining whom to assess income tax for the winning
ticket.

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                              May 4, 2013 Saturday
                                 METRO EDITION

Ex-manager at trucking firm gets 16 years in $400K fraud

BYLINE: PAUL WALSH; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 507 words



HIGHLIGHT: Judge says man faked serious illness to avoid both trial and
sentencing for defrauding Eagan employer.


A Texas man faces more than 16 years in federal prison for his role in a scheme
to bilk nearly $400,000 from his former Eagan employer, Advantage
Transportation.

Clayton "Craig" Hogeland, 43, also obstructed justice by faking a
life-threatening medical condition, U.S. District Judge Patrick Schiltz found.
That caused delays for both his trial and sentencing hearing.

Hogeland, now of Aurora, Texas, was convicted in December 2011 of mail fraud,
conspiracy to commit mail fraud, conspiracy to commit money laundering, and
income tax evasion. He was sentenced Friday in federal court in Minneapolis.

His friend Jeffrey Cole Bennett, 52, of Arlington, Tenn., was found guilty of
the same charges and was sentenced to nearly eight years in prison. He and
Hogeland, who was his boss, must make restitution totaling $393,183. Hogeland's
wife, Jennifer Rose Hogeland, 39, was convicted of three counts of income tax
evasion and sentenced to 15 months in prison.

Advantage Transportation connects freight companies with trucking firms
nationwide. It's part of the Dart Transit Co.

The prosecution argued that Hogeland, a former general manager at Advantage,
created four companies - three of them shams - and had them bill Advantage for
products, most of which were never provided. Hogeland approved payment and
Bennett paid the Hogelands kickbacks, which Jennifer Hogeland deposited in their
bank accounts.

Defense attorneys told jurors a different tale, alleging retribution by a
spurned boss and arguing that any tax issues were simple errors.

In a presentencing filing that asked the court to increase his sentence to 21
years in prison, prosecutors alleged that Hogeland created a "fictitious,
life-threatening medical condition" in an effort to avoid being tried and again
to dodge sentencing.

"It is the stuff of pulp fiction, acted out in reality," they wrote.

Bags of potassium chloride

And how did Hogeland allegedly fake serious illness?

On the eve of an April 12, 2011, trial date in Minnesota, Hogeland checked
himself into a Texas hospital for dangerously high blood potassium levels. The
trial was delayed until the following June for medical reasons, then September
before finally starting in November 2011.

Further health-related delays stretched out the trial before his conviction on
Dec. 6, 2011. He was placed in custody Jan. 8, 2013, and the erratic blood
potassium readings stopped. Six days later, his wife reported to federal
authorities that she found in his belongings four zip-top bags of what turned
out to be potassium chloride.

Despite his continuing complaints about symptoms after being jailed, tests
revealed no abnormal blood potassium levels, the prosecution said.

"There is no denying that Hogeland's failure to have any episodes after he was
incarcerated is damning proof that Hogeland self-induced previous episodes," the
prosecution said.

The defense called that allegation a "fantastical theory" and suggested that
Hogeland's wife was setting him up because of tension over her having had an
affair.

                                US Official News

                            August 27, 2013 Tuesday

Washington: Local Venture Capitalist Pleads Guilty to Tax Charges

LENGTH: 624  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

Burton Douglas Morriss pled guilty to tax evasion charges associated with his
evasion of taxes on millions of dollars of income he earned between 2006 and
2009. According to his plea agreement, the tax liability Morriss attempted to
evade in 2007 was $2,888,483. The total tax due and owing by Morriss for all tax
years is $5,559,386.

According to court documents, Morriss was a venture capitalist living in St.
Louis County. Morriss admitted that, through his work, he was versed in tax
laws. As a venture capitalist, he would discuss tax consequences of buying and
selling investments to sophisticated investors. Moreover, he had been dealing
with advisers and lawyers regarding his personal taxes for many years before
2006.

For the tax year 2007, which is the tax evasion count to which he pleaded
guilty, Morriss earned substantial income from his venture capital activities.
In order to reduce his tax liability for that year, he claimed $18,160,613 in
losses associated with a number of entities, including Morriss Holdings, MIC
Aircraft, Tech Aircraft, and MIC Real Estate. These entities were established as
single member limited liability companies for Morriss's mother. Additionally,
Mrs. Morriss had already claimed these passive losses for her own benefit in
previous years. In addition to these 2007 tax losses, Morriss admitted to
evading millions more in taxes on income from his venture capital companies in
subsequent tax years.

Morriss did not timely file tax returns for 2006, 2007, 2008, and 2009. On June
27,2011, Morriss filed the delinquent 2007 tax return that is the subject of the
guilty plea, along with delinquent 2008 and 2009 tax returns.

Sybil A. Smith, the Special Agent in Charge of IRS-Criminal Investigation,
stated, "To build faith in our nation's tax system, honest taxpayers need to be
reassured that everyone is paying their fair share. IRS-Criminal Investigation,
together with the Department of Justice, will diligently investigate and
prosecute those who knowingly violate our tax system for their own enrichment."

Morriss, 50, Creve Coeur, Missouri, pled guilty to one felony count of tax
evasion before United States District Judge Rodney Sippel. Sentencing has been
set for November 22, 2013.

This charge carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and/or fines up to
$100,000. Restitution is mandatory. In determining the actual sentences, a judge
is required to consider the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines, which provide
recommended sentencing ranges.

Morriss' plea comes shortly after a judgment of permanent injunction was ordered
against him in the case of Securities and Exchange Commission v. Burton Douglas
Morriss in the Eastern District of Missouri. On August 13, 2013, United States
District Judge Carol E. Jackson ordered that Morriss, among other things, is
prohibited from acting as a officer or director of certain companies issuing
securities. The SEC matter was filed in 2012 in the wake of the collapse of the
Acartha Group LLC and other venture capital companies run by Morriss. The SEC
complaint alleged that Morriss had fraudulently transferred millions of investor
dollars to himself for person use. In addition to the director/officer bar, the
SEC will ask the court to order disgorgement of ill-gotten gains and civil
penalties at a future date.

In addition to the SEC, this case was investigated by Internal Revenue
Service-Criminal Investigation, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the
United States Postal Inspection Service. Assistant United States Attorney Tom
Albus is handling the case for the U.S. Attorney's Office.

For more information please visit: http://www.fbi.gov
