                                The Denver Post

                             April 17, 2007 Tuesday
                                 FINAL EDITION

You can e-file, but don't e-vade

BYLINE: Al Lewis Denver Post Staff Columnist

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C-01

LENGTH: 713 words


The only thing worse than tax returns are tax-evasion charges.

As many of us scramble to the post office today, Denver lawyer Gordon Sanchez,
52, will be turning himself in to authorities.

Sanchez is scheduled to appear today on one count of tax evasion and one count
of failing to file a federal income- tax return, evading more than $32,000 in
income and self-employment taxes for 2000. A grand-jury indictment alleges he
sold a home in Denver and netted a capital gain of more than $135,000 that he
never reported.

Sanchez did not return phone calls. He served as a deputy district attorney in
Denver in the 1980s and later became a defense lawyer for accused drug dealers.

He also once operated the Oasis Cabaret, a strip club in unincorporated Adams
County. Now, he's a poster child for tax evasion and faces up to six years'
incarceration on the two charges.

"Everyone should know better," U.S. Attorney Troy Eid said. "But those of us who
are sworn to carry out the law are held to the highest standards. In this
particular case, it's a reminder that if you don't pay your taxes, you can go to
prison."

The U.S. attorney's office in Denver prosecutes only about a dozen tax-evasion
cases a year. Scarce resources ensure that such prosecutions remain few and far
between, said Kevin O'Brien, a former Internal Revenue Service agent who is now
an accounting and law professor at the University of Denver.

"What I was taught (as an IRS agent) is that it's always great if you can get a
high-profile person for tax evasion," he said. "It helps the IRS let people know
that people are prosecuted for evasion."

Suitably high-profile

In this sense, Joseph Francis, whose companies produce the popular "Girls Gone
Wild" videos, makes a much more interesting poster child than Sanchez.

Francis - who was indicted for tax evasion by a grand jury in Reno, Nev., last
week - allegedly deducted more than $20 million in false business expenses on
his companies' 2002 and 2003 corporate income-tax returns. This is a guy who
finds young women so drunk that they rip off their clothes for his cameras. His
expense reports surely merit a video series of their own.

Francis now faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines.

Perhaps one of the most infamous tax evaders ever is New York hotelier Leona
Helmsley. She became a symbol of greed in the 1980s when her housekeeper came to
court and quoted her as saying, "Only the little people pay taxes."

After her conviction, Helmsley received 18 months in the not-so-luxurious
accommodations of a federal prison.

The IRS is increasingly making sure that the little people, or at least the
middle class, pay their taxes. The agency audited nearly 436,000 middle-class
taxpayers last year, up from about 147,000 returns in 2000, according to a
recent report in The New York Times. If you are making between $25,000 and
$100,000 a year, your odds of being audited in 2006 were about 1 in 140, up from
1 in 377 in 2000. The odds for those making more than $100,000 were 1 in 59, and
for those making more than $1 million, it was 1 in 16.

It pays to be a nobody

For those caught dodging their taxes, most differences with the IRS can be
resolved without criminal charges.

"It's very difficult to bring a (criminal) tax case," said John Voorhees, a
lawyer with Patton Boggs in Denver, who used to work for the U.S. Justice
Department in the 1980s targeting mob figures for tax-evasion charges.

"First, you have to get authority from Washington, and it's not the easiest
prosecution to get authorized," he said. "The authorization process is pretty
detailed."

O'Brien recalls working on a case in the late 1970s involving a gas-station
owner in a Colorado mountain town. The gas- station operator had bragged of his
tax-dodging prowess while playing pool in the local tavern. Apparently, this is
not a wise thing to brag about in a bar.

"We got so many telephone calls the following week from people turning him in,"
O'Brien said.

O'Brien recommended the case for criminal prosecution, but the IRS decided to
pursue a civil settlement instead.

"There weren't enough resources," O'Brien said. "He wasn't high-profile enough."

                                Contra Costa Times

                      May 14, 2005 Saturday FINAL EDITION

MCCANN GETS 6 MONTHS IN DANVILLE TAX EVASION;
JUDGE FINDS "BLATANT CONFLICT OF INTEREST AND SELF-DEALING" IN MACHINATIONS OVER
PLANNED ARTS CENTER

BYLINE: NATHANIEL HOFFMAN, TIMES STAFF WRITER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 485 words

DATELINE: MARTINEZ


William McCann may have wanted to build a children's theater in Danville eight
years ago, but he ended up undermining the project in a failed attempt to enrich
himself, a Contra Costa Superior Court judge told the developer before
sentencing him to jail Friday morning.

The judge sentenced McCann to 180 days in jail, a $10,000 fine, $32,000 in back
taxes and fines and five years' court probation for claiming a false $150,000
charitable donation to the Belasco Theatre Company on his 1997 tax returns.

It was less jail time than special prosecutor William Denny asked for, but Denny
said it would show the public that attorneys and real estate developers like
McCann are not above the law.

"My goal is to make sure he serves some jail time," said Denny, an Alameda
County deputy district attorney who prosecuted the case for the state Attorney
General's Office. "It's important that a community leader be held accountable."

McCann declined comment after the hearing. His attorney, William Du Bois, said
his client already has paid for his indiscretions by settling with the aggrieved
parties, paying large attorney fees, losing his license to practice law and
paying back taxes and penalties.

His wife also left him, Du Bois said.

"As a direct result of this case, he has been financially ruined," Du Bois said.

Judge John W. Kennedy said the large civil settlement did not adequately
compensate the defrauded Belasco Theater Company for its damaged reputation and
lost revenue.

He said McCann, then director of the Belasco board, engaged in a "severe and
blatant conflict of interest and self-dealing" when he got the visually impaired
theater director to sign $3.36 million in donated land over to him and his
partner Jay Gordon Bingham.

McCann then purchased the rest of the lot where the theater was to be built and
planned to put an office building on it.

At the same time he claimed a $150,000 charitable donation to the children's
theater on his taxes, when the theater only had recorded $250 in donations from
McCann in 1997, Denny said.

McCann was charged with grand theft, embezzlement and tax evasion. In a plea
agreement, he agreed to plead guilty to the tax evasion charge.

The 58-year-old father of four and recent grandfather, who holds dual U.S. and
Irish citizenship, is expected to turn himself in to the Sheriff's Office on
June 2 after attending his daughter's engagement party in Cabo San Lucas,
Mexico.

He is now living in Genoa, Nev., but must remain in California to serve his
sentence and until the Nevada authorities agree to accept his probation, Kennedy
said.

Meanwhile, the Mt. Diablo Region YMCA has taken over the lease of the unfinished
theater on La Gonda Way in Danville and is working to secure funding to complete
the project.

Nathaniel Hoffman covers crime. Reach him

at 925-945-4782 or nhoffman@cctimes.com.

                          September 10, 2016 Saturday

East Lyme Fisherman Sentenced to Federal Prison for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 311  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, District of Connecticut has
issued the following news release:



  United States Attorney for the District of Connecticut, announced that PETER
TORRES, 48, of East Lyme, was sentenced today by Chief U.S. District Judge Janet
C. Hall in New Haven to three months of imprisonment, followed by three years of
supervised release, for tax evasion.





 According to court documents and statements made in court, from 2006 to 2011,
TORRES failed to file tax returns and report to the Internal Revenue Service
approximately $1.27 million in gross income generated through his work as a
commercial fishing boat captain.



 On November 30, 2015, TORRES pleaded guilty to one count of attempted tax
evasion, admitting that he was issued Forms 1099 that documented the income paid
to him for each tax year, but he failed to timely file his tax returns as
required and report the income and tax due to the IRS.  In his plea agreement,
TORRES agreed that the tax loss for this period is between $250,000 and
$550,000.



 TORRES also admitted that, in an effort to conceal his income from the IRS, he
negotiated checks he received as payment for his fishing services by depositing
them in the bank and, on the same day, withdrawing cash or obtaining bank checks
in varying amounts under $10,000.



 As part of his guilty plea, TORRES acknowledged that he attempted to evade the
assessment and payment of his taxes for the 2006 through 2011 tax years.  He
will enter into a payment plan with the IRS to repay the back taxes and
applicable penalties and interest.



 This case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service - Criminal
Investigation Division, and was prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Anastasia
E. King.

Fayetteville Man Sentenced to 18 Months for Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 314  words

DATELINE: New York



 Office for the United States Attorneys, Northern District of New York has
issued the following news release:



   Edward J. Purcell, Sr., age 65, of Fayetteville, New York, was sentenced
today to serve 18 months in prison for tax evasion.





 The announcement was made by United States Attorney Richard S. Hartunian and
Shantelle P. Kitchen, Special Agent in Charge of IRS-Criminal Investigation's
New York Field Office.



 U.S. District Judge David N. Hurd also sentenced Purcell to 3 years of
supervised release, to begin after his release from prison, and also ordered him
to pay $347,128 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service ("IRS").



 In December 2015, Purcell pled guilty to one count of tax evasion.



 During the years 2008 through 2010, Purcell owned and operated American Roofing
Company ("ARC") in the Syracuse area.  In this time period, he failed to report
any of the income he received from ARC by not filing federal income tax returns,
despite receiving taxable income in the amount of $655,937.



 For the tax years 2008, 2009, and 2010, Purcell willfully evaded the payment of
taxes on his individual income, which totaled $150,980, $333,614, and $171,343,
respectively.  The total tax loss for the years 2008 through 2010 was $231,362.
Purcell also agreed to repay the IRS an additional $115,766, representing the
tax loss for 2007.



 Purcell concealed his income by depositing checks payable to ARC into nominee
bank accounts, which he controlled through powers of attorney.  Purcell set up
these bank accounts in the names of his close friends and family members for the
purpose of concealing his income from the IRS.



 This case was investigated by IRS-Criminal Investigation, and was prosecuted by
Assistant U.S. Attorney Ransom P. Reynolds.

                       Sarasota Herald Tribune (Florida)

                             April 6, 2010 Tuesday

Ex-employees say lawyer printed out firm's payroll // Responsibility for payment
is an issue in Uhl tax case

BYLINE: Aaron Nicodemus

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 602 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


WORCESTER - Two former employees of Worcester lawyer Christopher M. Uhl
testified in U.S. District Court yesterday that they saw him print out the
payroll for his law firm, undercutting his defense in his tax evasion trial that
his college-age son was in charge of payroll.

Former employees Madelyn Bedard of Ashburnham and Christina P. Florence of
Palmer each testified that they witnessed Mr. Uhl entering data into the
computer and printing out the weekly payroll checks. They testified they never
saw Steven Uhl, Mr. Uhl's son, have anything to do with payroll. On
cross-examination by defense lawyers Christopher LoConto and John M. Goggins,
both witnesses testified that they thought Steven Uhl might have helped install
the computer software used to print out the payroll checks.

Mr. Uhl is charged with five counts of tax evasion. If convicted, he faces up to
5 years in prison on each count, and up to 3 years' probation. In his opening
statement, Mr. LoConto said that Mr. Uhl has admitted he did not pay more than
$230,000 worth of payroll and other taxes to the federal government over six
years, and that he owes the money. During that time, Mr. Uhl withheld money from
his employees' paychecks but did not turn it over to the Internal Revenue
Service.

Mr. LoConto argued that his client thought his son was paying the taxes and
filing the correct paperwork. He argued that Mr. Uhl made a mistake, but did not
commit a crime, when he did not pay taxes on his employees' pay from 2000 to
2005. He paid his taxes in 1998 and resumed paying his taxes in 2006, Mr.
LoConto said.

According to U.S. Attorney David Hennessy, Mr. Uhl paid his taxes for the first
quarter of 1999 but not the rest of the year; however, he is not charged with
tax evasion for that year.

Mr. Uhl was charged with tax evasion in September 2008, and a federal grand jury
delivered a superseding indictment in January.

In previous testimony, IRS agent Joy Chambers said that the IRS had launched an
investigation against Steven Uhl for allegedly making false statements to
investigators and aiding tax fraud. Steven Uhl has not been charged in
connection with his father's case.

Ms. Chambers said Steven Uhl told her that while he was a student at
Northeastern University, and while holding down other jobs, he rode the commuter
train from Boston to Worcester every Thursday to print out the payroll for his
father's law office. He told investigators he took the 5:40 p.m. train, and then
returned to Boston later that night. He said he did this every Thursday for six
years.

Prosecutors found an MBTA train schedule from that time period that showed no
trains to Worcester left Boston after 3 p.m. until the next day. They also
showed that the checks were printed on every day of the week, not just
Thursdays.

During Ms. Chambers' testimony, Mr. LoConto and Mr. Goggins asked why she chose
to interview Steven Uhl in a Boston bar, located close to the IRS' Boston
office. Steven Uhl was apparently allowed to drink alcohol during the interview.
Ms. Chambers said she would have preferred to interview him in her office, "but
given the choice between interviewing a witness in a bar, and not interviewing
him at all, I'll conduct the interview in a bar."

Mr. Uhl's trial on tax evasion charges is expected to wrap up today, with two
more witnesses called by U.S. attorneys Hennessy and Karin M. Bell. The defense
does not plan to call any witnesses, Mr. LoConto told Judge F. Dennis Saylor IV.

Judge Saylor told the jury yesterday that they can expect to begin deliberations
tomorrow.

Kaiser cuts 175 jobs in IT unit

BYLINE: Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BUSINESS; Local; News; Breaking

Kaiser Permanente confirmed it has eliminated 175 information technology jobs in
Pleasanton. The health-care giant has dismissed some IT workers already, said
Jim Caroompas, Kaiser spokesman. Others will depart soon.

Kaiser said the I.T. employment cuts are part of an overall strategic effort by
the organization. Kaiser's I.T. work force totals 5,600.

Regulatory

John Frances Griffin, 43, chief executive of a Livermore startup company called
VaporTech Inc., was sentenced to 30 months in federal prison for two counts of
tax evasion. The charges result from a joint investigation by the Internal
Revenue Service and the FBI.

Griffin, an Orinda resident, was indicted in 2006 on a multiple counts of tax
evasion and mail fraud. Griffin later entered a guilty plea on the two counts.

According to the plea agreement, Griffin's VaporTech company was researching and
developing technologies that convert fuel to hot water, high-quality steam, or
super-heated water vapor.

Griffin raised more than $2.5 million from investors. During 2004 and 2005, the
plea disclosed, Griffin received taxable income in excess of $1.2 million yet
failed to file federal income tax returns.

A federal judge ordered Griffin to pay $747,000 in restitution to VaporTech. The
judge also ordered Griffin to forfeit a variety of items. These include $75,000
in cash, a diamond ring valued at $30,000, a gold tennis bracelet worth $3,400,
and thousands of dollars worth of clothing and wine.

Groceries

Pleasanton-based Safeway Inc.expects profit to rise more this year than its
long-term growth target, Chief Financial Officer Robert Edwards said Wednesday.

Safeway forecast last month that earnings per share this year would be at the
top end of a forecast of $1.95 to $2, which would exceed the 12 percent to 15
percent growth the company projected for coming years.

The presentation didn't include a change to the company's 2007 earnings
forecast, Melissa Plaisance, senior vice president of finance for Safeway, said
after the meeting.

Safeway rose 56 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $32.57 at 2:44 p.m. in New York Stock
Exchange composite trading. The shares dropped 7.4 percent this year before
Wednesday.

at the University of California, Davis, will be put to work by Palo Alto-based
Efficient Drivetrains Inc., which leased the technology under an agreement
negotiated by the UC Davis InnovationAccess unit.

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                            September 7, 2007 Friday
                                  ALL EDITIONS

Lawyer admits to tax evasion;
Fraud counts included in plea

BYLINE: Lee Hammel, TELEGRAM & GAZETTE STAFF

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 637 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


A disbarred lawyer who has been named in a state criminal case against the
former chairman of the Worcester Election Commission has agreed "to cooperate
fully with law enforcement agents and government attorneys."

The agreement is part of the guilty plea entered yesterday by Alan Mason, 61, of
26 Pine Hill Road, Princeton, in a separate case in U.S. District Court. Mr.
Mason, who operated Alan Mason Legal Services Inc. on Shrewsbury Street in
Worcester, pleaded guilty to federal income tax evasion and two charges of wire
fraud. Judge F. Dennis Saylor IV set sentencing for Nov. 29 in Boston.

Assistant U.S. Attorney Mark J. Balthazard alleged Mr. Mason defrauded at least
10 lenders and Stewart Title, a real estate title insurance company, of more
than $6.2 million between June 2001 and June 2006. Despite the plea agreement,
Mr. Mason disputes that he received more than $1 million from the fraud or that
it involved 10 or more victims - contentions that would affect the length of any
prison sentence.

Mr. Mason is charged with evading $99,215 in income tax in 2003. But he agreed
with findings of the investigation by the Internal Revenue Service and the FBI
that the government's tax loss from 1995 through 2003 totaled $5.9 million.
While he agreed that figure can be used to calculate his sentence, Mr. Mason
reserved the right to argue to the IRS that his tax liability is less.

Mr. Mason also said he agreed with the government's allegation that he received
loan proceeds from lenders that were intended to pay previous lien holders of
properties but converted some of that money to his own use. That meant that the
lender was not the first lien holder and that Stewart Title, for which Mr. Mason
was an agent, had to make payments for the defective titles.

In a separate case, former Election Commissioner Lawrence Trapasso, 45, of 4
Lawton St., is facing three charges of bribery in Suffolk Superior Court and one
charge each of extortion and larceny over $250. That is in connection with
alleged efforts to get people's driver's licenses reinstated and to aid them in
court cases in exchange for payment.

In that case, Mr. Mason allegedly contacted Mr. Trapasso after Jamie Brown, a
courier who worked for Mr. Mason, had problems with her driver's license. Mr.
Trapasso is charged with taking money to fix Ms. Brown's license problems.

It is alleged that Mr. Mason told Ms. Brown to pay Mr. Trapasso for the services
and that Mr. Trapasso collected the money from her at Mr. Mason's office.

If Mr. Mason "provides substantial assistance in the investigation or
prosecution of another person who has committed a criminal offense," his plea
agreement states that the U.S. Attorney's office will file a motion so that
Judge Saylor can impose a sentence below the sentencing guideline range. Even if
such a motion is not filed, the government agreed to recommend a prison sentence
and fine at the low end of the sentencing guideline range, which has not yet
been calculated for Mr. Mason.

In addition to Mr. Mason's federal tax liabilities, he was named in 2005 as
owing $2.76 million in taxes to the state, placing him among the top 10 tax
delinquents in the Commonwealth. Since then, the state has collected $1 million
of his debt through property liens and attaching his bank account, according to
Robert R. Bliss, spokesman for the state Department of Revenue.

Nonetheless, "in the meantime the meter is running" and Mr. Mason's liability,
including penalties and interest, is even greater than before: $3.2 million, Mr.
Bliss said. While the updated information for other top tax delinquents was not
available yesterday, Mr. Bliss said Mr. Mason's "place is certainly secure on
the top 10 list."

Mr. Mason declined to comment after his guilty plea yesterday. He is represented
by James M. Merberg, a Boston lawyer.

                               The New York Times

                              June 21, 2004 Monday
                              Late Edition - Final

John C. Cheasty, Star Witness In Teamsters Case, Dies at 96

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

SECTION: Section B; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 685 words


John C. Cheasty, who became the government's star witness after James R. Hoffa
of the Teamsters union recruited him to spy on a Senate committee investigating
labor racketeering in the 1950's, died June 14 in Bahama, N.C. He was 96.

The cause was congestive heart failure, Mr. Cheasty's family said. He died at
the home of a daughter with whom he had lived for several years, the Rev.
Patrice Cheasty-Miller, the pastor of St. Paul United Methodist Church in
Durham.

A New York lawyer and investigator, Mr. Cheasty (pronounced CHASE-tee) figured
in an episode that began with Hoffa's offer of big-money bribes. Mr. Cheasty
took the first payment straight to Robert F. Kennedy, the chief counsel to the
committee Hoffa wanted Mr. Cheasty to infiltrate. Hoffa was arrested after what
he believed was a clandestine meeting with Mr. Cheasty in a Washington hotel.

But a federal jury acquitted Hoffa of bribery and conspiracy charges, fanning a
long-running feud between Hoffa and Kennedy.

Mr. Cheasty began his career as a Treasury agent in the 1930's. After graduating
from Manhattan College and Fordham Law School, he worked with the Treasury team
that built a tax-evasion case against Enoch L. (Nucky) Johnson, the Republican
boss of Atlantic County, N.J.

As a Navy commander in World War II, he was put in charge of the military base
at Luzon, in the Philippines. He was a Navy lawyer in 500 courts-martial after
the war before he contracted an illness that was diagnosed as a heart problem
and he retired on disability.

Back home in Brooklyn, after realizing he was not dying, he opened a law
practice. He handled tax-evasion cases for Joe Bosano, a nephew of Albert
Anastasia, the New York Mafia leader, among others.

He also made friends with a lawyer named Hyman I. Fischbach, who said a client
wanted to infiltrate the Senate committee and find out what it was looking into.

''I asked him, 'Who is your client?''' Mr. Cheasty later testified. ''He opened
an address book and said 'Jimmy' or 'James Hoffa,' and two phone numbers. I
whistled and said, 'Wow, Mr. Big himself.'''

Mr. Cheasty flew to Detroit for a meeting with Hoffa, then called Kennedy, who
arranged for him to join the committee's staff. Kennedy later said Mr. Cheasty
had felt Hoffa ''was asking him to betray his country.''

With Mr. Cheasty's testimony and undercover film showing Hoffa accepting a
packet of Senate material, the case seemed solid. Kennedy said he would ''jump
off the Capitol dome'' if the government lost.

But on the day Hoffa testified, the former heavyweight champion Joe Louis walked
into the courtroom, threw an arm around Hoffa and told reporters he wanted to
''see what they're doing to my good friend Jimmy Hoffa.''

Louis's appearance ''undoubtedly had a strong effect on the black members of the
jury,'' Walter Sheridan wrote in ''The Rise and Fall of Jimmy Hoffa'' (Saturday
Review Press, 1972).

However, the jury of eight blacks and four whites told reporters that race was
not a factor in their verdict; they said that they voted to acquit Hoffa because
they did not believe Mr. Cheasty. (Bribery and conspiracy charges against Mr.
Fischbach were later dropped.)

Federal agents kept watch on the Cheasty household for more than a year. Mr.
Cheasty's relatives say the F.B.I. gave him the code name Cat.

After the Hoffa verdict, Mr. Cheasty's old client Mr. Bosano asked for a
meeting. He told Mr. Cheasty that a contract had been taken out on him but that
''Uncle Albert'' -- Mr. Anastasia -- had blocked it.

Mr. Cheasty worked on John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign in 1960 and later
moved his law practice to Washington for a few years before returning to New
York. After he retired at 87 in 1994, he told his family that in the 60's and
70's he had been a contract employee of the Central Intelligence Agency.

In addition to Ms. Cheasty-Miller, he is survived by two other daughters,
Virginia Lucey of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Mary Kornman of New York; two sons,
John C., of Clarksville, Tenn., and Robert C., of Berkeley, Calif.; and 16
grandchildren. Mr. Cheasty's wife, Virginia, died in 1998.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

LAW & ORDER

SECTION: METRO ; Law & Order Column; Pg. C2

ST. LOUIS

Businessman gets two-year sentence in bankruptcy and tax-evasion case

Richard E. Gray, the former chairman of an aluminum siding company in Fenton,
was sentenced Thursday in federal court in St. Louis to two years in prison for
tax evasion and a bankruptcy-related crime. Gray, 55, formerly of New York, had
been chairman of HomeStar Industries of Fenton, which was forced into bankruptcy
in 1997 by creditors.

Authorities said that in the months before the bankruptcy, the company's former
owner died, and HomeStar received more than $1 million in life insurance
proceeds. Gray defrauded the creditors and customers by transferring those
proceeds to other companies and accounts he controlled, according to the U.S.
attorney's office.

When Gray was asked about it in the bankruptcy case, prosecutors said, he made
false statements under oath to disguise the transfers as a loan.

He pleaded guilty July 24 to one count of making false statements under oath
during bankruptcy proceedings. Gray also pleaded guilty to one count of tax
evasion. He evaded paying income taxes for the years 1984 through 1987 in the
total amount of $370,927, according to the U.S. attorney's office. Gray's
attorney, David Harlan, said he and his client had no comment.

ST. LOUIS

Motorist dies from gunshot wounds

A motorist who suffered gunshot wounds Thursday evening drove to the curb at
Jefferson Avenue and Potomac Street and asked a bystander to call police.

The victim, 37, then died at the scene moments later from wounds to his head and
hand. His name was withheld pending notification of relatives.

A police spokesman said the attack happened about 5 p.m. He said the victim
handed the bystander a cell phone and said, "Call the police. I've been shot."
The man was dead when police arrived.

Investigators had no motive or suspects late Thursday.

ST. LOUIS

Customer is shot to death in restaurant

Police were looking for a gunman who shot and killed a customer Thursday
afternoon in a Chinese restaurant on North Kingshighway near Cabanne Avenue.

The victim, 18, was shot at least three times. His name was being withheld until
relatives could be notified.

A Police Department spokesman said the shooting occurred about 3 p.m. in the
1100 block of North Kingshighway. Police had no suspects or motive late
Thursday.

JEFFERSON COUNTY

De Soto teenager dies in crash on Highway 21

A De Soto teenager is dead after the pickup he was driving swerved into oncoming
traffic and collided with another vehicle early Thursday morning. It was the
latest of several deaths in recent years on Highway 21, Jefferson County's
so-called "Blood Alley."

Matthew Steven Baisch, 19, was found dead at the scene. Rodney Louis Kelly, 18,
also of De Soto, was a passenger in Baisch's car and was treated at St. John's
Mercy Medical Center in Creve Coeur and released. The driver of the second car,
Marcaline Rion, 33, of Hillsboro, was treated at St. Anthony's Medical Center in
south St. Louis County and released.

Police said Baisch's truck crossed the center line and struck Rion's northbound
car at about 2:15 a.m., just north of Lake Lorraine Road in central Jefferson
County.

GRANITE CITY

Mother of accident victim sues police officer, city

The mother of a man killed last year in a collision with a Granite City police
car filed a suit Wednesday in Madison County Circuit Court seeking $200,000 each
from the city and the police officer who drove the patrol car.

David Ortiz, 24, of Granite City, was killed Oct. 21 when he turned his car into
the path of Sgt. Kenneth Rozell's unmarked police car, authorities said.
Rozell's warning lights were on as he headed down Madison Avenue to the scene of
an armed robbery, police explained.

The suit claims that Rozell had a known history of traffic violations but the
Granite City Police Department never disciplined him for them. Officials said
Thursday that an investigation found that Rozell had not violated any department
policies.

                               The New York Times

                  June 1, 1989, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Judge Charged In Tax Evasion And Perjury

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 881 words


A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, William T. Martin, was indicted by a
Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of tax evasion, perjury and distribution
of cocaine.

The nine-count indictment, announced at a news conference by Benito Romano, the
United States Attorney for the Southern District, charged that Justice Martin
and his former law partners used safe-deposit boxes to hide cash they received
as legal fees, including money from a convicted drug dealer, James Jackson.

Mr. Jackson, who is now serving 25 years in prison and is in the Federal Witness
Protection Program, cooperated with prosecutors, as did Justice Martin's former
law partners, Mark Weinstein and Michael Nedick. The law partners each pleaded
guilty last month to one count of tax evasion.

Plans to Surrender

Justice Martin, who is 37 years old, was also charged with lying to a grand jury
about the source of $50,000 in bail he posted for Mr. Jackson on a drug charge
in Virginia, and with distributing cocaine to an individual in his law office in
the summer of 1985. Mr. Romano said he could not be specific about the drug
charge, but that it involved ''quantities'' of cocaine.

Justice Martin's lawyer, Murray Richman, said his client would surrender to
Federal marshals for arraignment this morning at Federal District Court in
Manhattan.

''Essentially, it's a tax-evasion indictment with all the other little add-ons
to actually further prejudice any possibility of a fair trial,'' Mr. Richman
said. ''I am distressed at what this does to a hard-working, rather decent man,
and what it does to the entire judicial system. It causes the public to lose its
faith.

''What is most distressing,'' he said, ''is that it literally destroys the life
and potential effectiveness of the youngest State Supreme Court judge in New
York. Had he not been a judge, I submit he would not have been charged.''

Asked about the drug charge, Mr. Richman said he had not yet seen the
indictment, but ''I understand it was the alleged personal use by the partners
of the law firm.''

''It was not distribution to the general public,'' he said. He said he could not
answer specific questions about the other charges.

Justice Martin is a former assistant Bronx district attorney who in 1987 tried
to run against his former boss, Mario Merola, the Bronx District Attorney, who
died in office. Mr. Martin was ruled off the ballot because of defective
petitions.

The indictment yesterday shocked lawyers and politicians in the Bronx. Robert J.
Saltzman, a lawyer, said Justice Martin had an excellent reputation as a lawyer
and judge. ''I've known him as a hard fighter in the courtroom,'' Mr. Saltzman
said. ''He always gave the district attorney's office a run for its money.''

Mr. Saltzman said he had never tried a case before Justice Martin, but other
lawyers had spoken highly of him. ''I think he's an excellent judge,'' he said.
''He gives an excellent trial, very fair.'' 'Sense of Hurt and Disbelief'

Assemblyman Larry B. Seabrook, who placed Justice Martin's name before the Bronx
Democratic Party judicial convention that nominated him in 1987, said: ''I've
known him for well over 10 years, even longer. It's really a shock, a sense of
hurt and disbelief.''

He said he had known Justice Martin ''to be a very upstanding and decent
individual and a good lawyer.''

''He had been actively involved in the community, with the N.A.A.C.P. and
various other groups,'' he said.

Justice Martin was a founder of the Black Bar Association of Bronx County and
served as its president in 1983. The current president, Hugh Campbell, declined
to comment on the matter.

At the news conference, Mr. Romano said Justice Martin and his former partners
''allegedly used safe-deposit boxes'' in lower Manhattan and the Bronx to hide
cash legal fees they received. He said he could not be specific about the amount
involved because it was not detailed in the indictment.

Questions on Money's Source

Mr. Romano said Justice Martin was also charged with lying to a Federal grand
jury in July and October of 1987 in connection with his representation of Mr.
Jackson. ''Particularly,'' Mr. Romano said, ''Martin is charged with lying about
the source of $50,000 in cash that he posted as bail for Jackson.''

Asked if the $50,000 came from drug profits, Mr. Romano said, ''I don't think I
could comment on that other than to say that the proof as to Mr. Jackson was
that basically all his money came from drug dealing.'' In his appearance before
the grand jury, Justice Martin testified that the bail money came from ''some
members of what I perceived to be his family.''

Mr. Romano said the drug charges against Justice Martin do not involve the sale
of cocaine. Asked if the distribution occurred more than once, he said, ''I
think you'd find that most people understand quantities to mean distribution on
more than one occassion.''

Justice Martin was nominated for the judgeship in September 1987 when a
coalition wrested control of the judicial convention from the Democratic
organization. The move represented a serious slippage of power for the
organization, which for months had been engulfed in the city's corruption
scandals. Justice Martin won his seat in a special election in January 1988.

                                US Official News

                           September 23, 2016 Friday

New York: New York Restaurant Entrepreneur Pleads Guilty to Ten-Year Investment
Fraud Scheme and Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 882  words

DATELINE: New York



 Albany: Department of Justice,The New York State has issued the following news
release:



  A Watertown, New York food and restaurant entrepreneur and franchisor pleaded
guilty today to one count of wire fraud and one count of tax evasion announced
Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo, head of the
Justice Department's Tax Division, and U.S. Attorney Richard Hartunian for the
Northern District of New York.





 According to the criminal information and plea agreement filed with the U.S.
District Court in Utica, New York, between 2005 and 2015, Christopher Swartz,
46, engaged in a promissory note scheme to defraud lenders and investors, as
well as a scheme to evade taxes and obstruct the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).




 "Mr. Swartz used his business enterprises to steal from lenders, investors, and
the United States, hiding behind an elaborate web of entities and financial
transactions," said Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo.  "This
case serves as clear notice that no one is above the law, and those individuals
who seek to evade their tax obligations will face prosecution and incarceration,
regardless of the complexity of their schemes or economic status."



 "The defendant's wide-ranging, persistent, and lengthy fraud and tax evasion
schemes cost investors and the IRS millions of dollars," said U.S. Attorney
Hartunian.  "My office is pleased to be part of the efforts by the Tax Division
and IRS-Criminal Investigation to hold him accountable for his brazen conduct."



 "As highly trained and experienced financial investigators, IRS special agents
are particularly adept at tracing the flow of funds and uncovering hidden
assets," said Special Agent in Charge Shantelle P. Kitchen of IRS Criminal
Investigation, New York Field Office.  "Mr. Swartz's conviction serves as
warning to anyone who schemes to divert money from a business in order to
conceal income and evade taxes."



 Swartz, using his multiple interests in various food and restaurant businesses,
raised money by fraudulently inducing lenders with the promise of repayment at
high interest rates and ownership interests in his companies.  Swartz
misappropriated and diverted funds received and when lenders and investors
sought the return of their funds, Swartz attempted to lull them with false and
fraudulent excuses, assurances, and partial payments, including payments by
checks that he knew would bounce.  Swartz also concealed his assets and income
to avoid seizure and collection by lenders, investors, and judgment creditors,
thereby attempting to prevent recovery of their funds.



 As one part of the scheme, in 2009, Swartz used a promissory note and the offer
of an equity interest in the Jreck Subs franchise to induce an investor group
from New York City to provide $1.5 million in funds, including funds for the
construction of new stores and the growth of the chain.  Swartz misappropriated
and diverted a substantial portion of the funds.  Swartz then solicited
additional loans from this same group, fraudulently inducing them with a series
of additional promissory notes, which he failed to honor while misappropriating
funds.  Swartz purported to secure some of the notes with fictitious and forged
rebate agreements.



 Swartz admitted that between 2005 and 2015, he also engaged in a 10-year tax
evasion scheme, filing false tax returns that understated his personal income.
Swartz diverted money from business accounts and disguised these diversions in
the company records as, among other things, loans and business expenses.  He
made extensive use of cash to diminish the traceability of funds and concealed
his ownership of various assets using multiple entities and nominees.  Swartz
also falsified partnership tax returns and attempted to impede the IRS's ability
to collect employment taxes.



 U.S. District Judge David N. Hurd scheduled sentencing for Jan. 19, 2017.
Swartz faces a statutory maximum sentence of 20 years in prison for his
conviction on the wire fraud count, and five years in prison on the tax evasion
count, as well as a period of supervised release and monetary penalties.  As a
condition of the plea agreement, Swartz agreed to an order of restitution
payable to any individuals and entities determined to be, at the time of
sentencing, victims of his schemes.



 The district court entered a preliminary order of forfeiture of assets,
including forfeiture of Swartz's interests in the Jreck Subs franchisor
corporate business, which receives royalty payments from store owners based on a
percentage of store sales.  Under current law, if a final forfeiture order is
entered, criminally forfeited assets may be used as a source of funds to pay
restitution to victims.  According to court documents, the number of victims may
be in excess of 130.



 Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo and U.S. Attorney Hartunian
thanked special agents of IRS-Criminal Investigation and the FBI, and an IRS
revenue agent, who conducted the investigation, as well as Assistant Chiefs John
N. Kane, Jr. and Andrew Kameros, and Trial Attorney Abigail Burger Chingos of
the Tax Division, who are prosecuting the case.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            February 12, 2016 Friday

Former Plan Trustee Sentenced for Embezzling over $1 Million, Income Tax
Eevasion

LENGTH: 484  words


DAYTON  Timothy Hock, 51, currently of Chicago, was sentenced to 42 months in
prison and ordered to pay more than $1.3 million in restitution for his role in
the embezzlement from a bankruptcy estate and income tax evasion.

Hock was ordered to pay approximately $1 million in restitution to Domin-8
Enterprises Solutions, Inc. (Domin-8) and approximately $326,000 in restitution
to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

Carter M. Stewart, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Ohio, Guy
A. Ficco, Acting Special Agent in Charge, Internal Revenue Service Criminal
Investigation, and Angela L. Byers, Special Agent in Charge, Federal Bureau of
Investigation, Cincinnati Field Division, announced the sentence handed down
today by U.S. District Judge Thomas M. Rose.

According to court documents, Hock, who was a Certified Public Accountant, was
the controller for Domin-8 when the company (and five other related entities)
filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September 2009. Domin-8 was a Mason,
Ohio-based company that provided software to companies that managed rental
properties.

During the bankruptcy proceedings, Hock was responsible for handling the
companys liquidation and transfer of assets, completing claims reviews and
making appropriate distributions to various creditors of the company.

He embezzled approximately $1,080,289.73 which belonged to the bankruptcy estate
of Domin-8 through a variety of means, including writing checks to himself from
the trusts bank accounts.

These checks were deposited into Hocks personal bank account and then used for
his personal expenditures. In addition, Hock wrote cashiers checks from the
trusts bank accounts in order to purchase several personal vehicles, including
two luxury vehicles, a 2006 Land Rover, a 2009 Jaguar XF and a 2010 Honda Civic
for his daughter. Hock attempted to conceal his activities by submitting four
false post confirmation reports in which he did not include all the payments he
made to himself and all expenses paid on his behalf.

Hock committed tax evasion on his 2010, 2011 and 2012 tax returns by claiming
that his taxable income was much less than it actually was. In total, he
attempted to evade paying approximately $326,000 in federal income taxes for
those years.

Hock pleaded guilty to the embezzlement and tax evasion charges on August 19,
2015.

Tax evasion and bankruptcy fraud of this magnitude and with this degree of
trickery, dishonesty and deceit, deserves to be punished, said Guy A. Ficco,
Acting Special Agent in Charge, IRS Criminal Investigation, Cincinnati Field
Office. The IRS, FBI, and U.S. Attorneys Office remain determined and vigilant
in ferreting out such schemes to cheat the honest taxpayers."

U.S. Attorney Stewart commended the cooperative law enforcement investigation,
as well as Assistant United States Attorney Alex R. Sistla, who is prosecuting
the case. 2016 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

                                US Official News

                           January 15, 2014 Wednesday

Hawaii: Court Rejects Banking Associations' Challenge to Regulations Addressing
Offshore Tax Avoidance

LENGTH: 263  words

DATELINE: Honolulu


Department of Justice, The State of Hawaii has issued the following news
release:

District Court in the District of Columbia dismissed a challenge filed by the
Florida Bankers Association and Texas Bankers Association challenging 2012
amendments to the Department of the Treasury's interest-reporting regulations.
The regulations require U.S. banks to report to the Internal Revenue Service
(IRS) information about accounts earning more than $10 of interest beginning in
2013 that are held by nonresident aliens of all countries with which the United
States has a tax treaty or other information exchange agreement.  These new
reporting requirements help the United States' ability to comply with requests
from its treaty and exchange partners and implement the Foreign Account Tax
Compliance Act.

"This ruling advances the Department of Justice's and Internal Revenue Service's
continuing efforts to pursue taxpayers trying to evade taxes through offshore
accounts," said Assistant Attorney General Kathryn Keneally of the Tax Division.
"The court's opinion today represents an important step in our commitment to
work with our treaty partners to eliminate cross-border tax evasion."

The court upheld the regulations' 2012 amendments, finding that the IRS
"reasonably concluded that the regulations will improve U.S. tax compliance,
deter foreign and domestic tax evasion, impose a minimal reporting burden on
banks, and not cause any rational actor - other than a tax evader - to withdraw
his funds from U.S. accounts."

For further information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/

Court briefs: Charges delayed in baby's slaying

BYLINE: The Monterey County Herald

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 269 words


Charges delayed in baby's slaying

Charges against a Monterey man suspected of killing an 8-month-old boy were
delayed Tuesday.

Terry Spitz, chief assistant district attorney, said his office received a
lengthy report from Monterey police early Tuesday. He said the prosecutor
assigned to the case, Rolando Mazariegos, wanted to review evidence before
filing charges.

William Aguirre Fajardo, 24, remains in Monterey County Jail in lieu of $1.5
million bail on suspicion of murder and assault causing the death of a child.

He is also suspected of engaging in unlawful sex with the 17-year-old mother of
the baby, who was found unconscious in a Monterey motel late Friday.

Spitz said his office must file formal charges today or sheriff's officials will
set him free.

Woman pleads guilty to tax fraud

A Salinas woman pleaded guilty to tax fraud in a San Jose federal court Monday,
the U.S. Attorney's Office for Northern California said.

Lydia Hernandez admitted she prepared false returns so clients of her tax
service could reduce their taxable income and obtain larger refunds.

Hernandez was indicted by a federal grand jury in January 2008 and charged with
three counts of tax evasion and 39 counts of willfully preparing fraudulent
income tax returns.

Under an agreement reached with prosecutors, she pleaded guilty to one count of
tax evasion and one count of preparing fraudulent returns.

Hernandez faces up to three years in prison and a fine of $100,000 for preparing
fraudulent returns and up to five years in prison and a fine of $250,000 for tax
evasion on her 2004 return.

She is to be sentenced Nov. 2 in San Jose.

                         Hartford Courant (Connecticut)

                            January 3, 2008 Thursday
                               STATEWIDE EDITION

HE'S GUILTY IN THEFT OF THE HARTFORD'S FURNITURE

BYLINE: DIANE LEVICK; Courant Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 477 words


A former manager of The Hartford who had been honored with an employee award
pleaded guilty Wednesday in a scheme to steal company furniture, sell or give it
to other firms and take hundreds of thousands of dollars in kickbacks.

Todd Olynciw, 42, of Somers, pleaded guilty to one count of mail fraud and one
count of tax evasion before U.S. District Judge Stefan R. Underhill in
Bridgeport.

Olynciw was project management manager at The Hartford Financial Services Group
Inc. until he was fired in 2005. He was responsible for removing and installing
furniture and flooring at The Hartford's facilities and awarding contracts to
firms to set up or renovate the company's offices.

From 1998 through July 2005, Olynciw conspired with others to defraud The
Hartford, according to a release from Kevin J. O'Connor, U.S. attorney for
Connecticut.

In total, The Hartford lost $876,437 as a result of the scheme. Olynciw received
more than $395,720 in illegal kickbacks. He misappropriated and transferred
furniture owned by the company to two individuals and six entities in return for
directing business from The Hartford to them, the U.S. attorney's office said.

The office also said Olynciw failed to report the kickbacks on his personal
income tax returns for tax years 2000 through 2005, resulting in the tax evasion
charge.

Olynciw received kickbacks of $187,396 in exchange for misappropriating and
illegally transferring furniture owned by The Hartford, and another $208,324 for
directing business from The Hartford to certain vendors, according to a court
document.

Olynciw, who is to be sentenced March 24, faces up to 25 years in prison. It is
expected he will be ordered to make restitution to The Hartford, and he must pay
the IRS back taxes of $88,607, plus penalties and interest.

In 2002, Olynciw received a Chairman's Award from The Hartford as part of a team
that re-established a New York City regional office for the company after its 7
World Trade Center officer was destroyed as a result of the Sept. 11, 2001
attack.

Joshua King, a spokesman for The Hartford, declined to comment on Olynciw's
activities, but noted that scores of employees companywide receive a Chairman's
Award each year.

"We reacted immediately when we learned of his alleged activities, investigated
and alerted authorities," King said. "We are pleased that justice has taken its
course in this matter."

Olynciw declined comment Wednesday.

A court document says he misappropriated furniture and gave it free to a firm
that was owned by a friend of his brother-in-law. Olynciw got several other
companies to perform free services at his home in exchange for his directing
business from The Hartford to them, the document states.

The case was investigated by the FBI and Internal Revenue Service. The Hartford
Insurance Co. assisted the investigation.

Contact Diane Levick at dlevick@courant.com

              December 23, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

MAYOR OF UNION CITY GUILTY OF CONSPIRACY TO RIG BIDS

BYLINE: By ALFONSO A. NARVAEZ, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 5; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 671 words

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 22


The Mayor of Union City was convicted today by a Federal jury of conspiracy,
mail fraud and income tax evasion in connection with a bid-rigging scheme in
Hudson County.

The Mayor, Robert C. Botti, was indicted in September, seven weeks after taking
office.  He became Mayor following the ouster of William V. Musto from his City
Commission post. Mr. Musto, a longtime Union City Mayor and State Senator, had
been sentenced to a seven-year prison term on Federal racketeering charges.

The jury in the Botti case deliberated two hours before reaching guilty verdicts
on all 18 counts in the indictment. Mr. Botti was charged with conspiring to
steer $50,000 worth of contracts for janitorial supplies for the Hudson County
Vocational and Technical School to the company for which he was a commission
salesman.

Judge H. Curtis Meanor of Federal District Court set sentencing of Mr. Botti for
Jan. 24. The 42-year-old official faces up to five years in prison and fines of
$1,000 to $5,000 on each of the 18 counts. Judge Meanor said he would inform the
State Attorney General's office of the Mayor's conviction.

Faces Ouster as Mayor

''We will move for forfeiture upon sentencing,'' said Virginia D.  Sederis,
deputy public information officer for the Attorney General's office, referring
to Mr. Botti's position as Mayor.

Mr. Botti was convicted of 1 count of conspiracy, 15 counts of using the mails
to defraud and 2 counts of tax evasion. The crimes were committed between July
1977 and January 1980, according to the indictment.

During the trial, William C. Cagney, the assistant United States attorney
prosecuting the case, produced witnesses who testified that Mr. Botti had
conspired to rig bids on janitorial and maintenance supplies for the Hudson
County school by submitting supposedly competitive bids from fictitious
companies.

Mr. Botti was accused of conspiring with John J. Powers, the secretary of the
school, and Milton Reid, owner of the Eastern Supply and Equipment Company,
where Mr. Botti was a commission salesman, to have company employees submit the
bogus bids. Mr. Powers was a codefendant in Mr. Musto's racketeering trial and
was convicted along with him. They are appealing the conviction.

Company Employees Testify

Employees of the supply company testified that at Mr. Botti's behest they had
typed letters quoting prices for janitorial supplies, tables and metal folding
chairs from a dozen fictitious companies and mailed them to officials at the
school.

Mr. Botti was also found guilty of getting about $15,000 in commissions from the
deals, paid to him through banks in Puerto Rico, and of failing to declare the
money on his Federal income tax returns for 1978 and 1979.

His attorney, S. M. Chris Franzblau, had tried to show during the trial that the
school was in such poor financial condition and officials were so slow in paying
its bills that no one wanted to sell anything to the school. In his summation,
he said that there had been no evidence presented to show that the school had
lost any money because of the bidding practices, which he said were known to
officials at the school.

Says Tax Returns Rectified

On the mail fraud charges, he told the jury of seven women and five men that no
one had shown which of the letters quoting prices had been mailed and which had
been hand-delivered to school officials.

He also told the jury that Mr. Botti had not received statements on sales
commissions paid to him through the banks in Puerto Rico, and should not be held
criminally liable for such an oversight. He said Mr. Botti had rectified his tax
returns for the two years after he was made aware of it.

On Monday, Mr. Botti testified that he had never conspired to use the mails to
defraud and that he had never knowingly violated any laws in his dealings with
the school.

                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                           December 15, 2011 Thursday

Dentist's wife spared lengthy prison term;
Couple pleaded guilty to felony tax evasion

BYLINE: HEATHER RAWLYK; Staff Writer

SECTION: Pg. A1

LENGTH: 416  words


They pleaded guilty to the same crime.

But a federal judge yesterday spared Susan Hustead from the two-year prison
sentence he handed down to her husband, Annapolis dentist Dr. Jay Hustead, last
week. Instead, sentencing her for felony tax evasion, he gave her six months in
prison with a recommendation for community confinement with work release.

Judge William M. Knickerson also sentenced Hustead, 57, to two years of
supervised release and six months home detention. Like her husband, she must pay
$65,913 in restitution and pay the Internal Revenue Service the full amount of
taxes due: $1.9 million.

Her sentence begins Feb. 13.

In a hearing at U.S. District Court in Baltimore yesterday, Knickerson indicated
that Dr. Hustead bore more responsibility for the tax evasion scheme the couple
pleaded guilty to in June 2010, federal court officials said. According to court
testimony, Hustead was vulnerable to her husband, who was more assertive.

According to the plea agreement, Hustead's husband is the president and owner of
Distinctive Dental in the Festival at Riva shopping center in Parole. Susan
Hustead is responsible for business management, including working with company
accountants on tax issues.

The couple's practice, which employs other dentists as well as technicians and
office workers, used a payroll service from 2001 to 2006 to process $1
million-plus annual payrolls and prepare quarterly employment tax returns. This
included withholding employment taxes from employee wages on behalf of the
practice.

The payroll service mailed the quarterly employment tax returns to the dental
office with instructions for filing the returns, the plea says.

The couple admitted that for the tax years from 2001 through the first half of
2005, they did not file quarterly employment tax returns. They also admitted
that when Internal Revenue Service agents asked them to file delinquent
employment tax returns, they falsely stated that all employee taxes were paid.

Additionally, the couple did not file quarterly tax returns for the remainder of
2005 or 2006. Those returns were filed in 2007.

Federal court officials said that from 2001 to 2006, the practice paid $25,000
in employment taxes and owed an additional $1.9 million.

Distinctive Dental remains open for business, but it filed for bankruptcy under
Chapter 11 last week and there is an ongoing effort to sell the practice,
according to Dr. Hustead's attorney, Harry Trainor.

Dr. Hustead's sentence begins Feb. 6.

                                American Banker

                            October 28, 2011 Friday

Latest Round in Tax Evasion Fight Pits Banks vs. IRS

BYLINE: Kevin Wack

SECTION: REGULATION & REFORM; Pg. 2 Vol. 176 No. 209

LENGTH: 987  words


WASHINGTON - An IRS proposal to require U.S. banks to report the interest earned
by certain foreign depositors has revived a decade-old fight in the battle over
how far authorities should go to fight tax evasion.

It is an issue with much more emotional resonance than most matters that come
before the House subcommittee on financial institutions. At a hearing Thursday,
witnesses who oppose the proposed regulation said that it might lead to
kidnappings in foreign countries, while a supporter of the IRS proposal argued
that its opponents have a vested interest in shielding criminals.

Under the proposal, banks would have to report interest earned in individual
accounts by a category of individuals known as non-resident aliens. Often these
people spend part of the year in the United States, but they are citizens and
residents of another country.

Bankers, particularly those in Florida and Texas, which have a large share of
deposits from residents of Latin American countries, argued the plan may spark a
flurry of withdrawals from American banks, hurting lending and potentially
imperiling institutions that rely heavily on foreign deposits.

"I don't understand why this was proposed at a time when our economy is soft and
we're trying to create jobs," said Alex Sanchez, president and chief executive
officer of the Florida Bankers Association.

But supporters argue the plan would allow the IRS to catch tax evaders in other
countries. Interest on foreign bank deposits is not taxable in the United
States, but the money in those accounts could be evidence of tax evasion in
another country. If the IRS had information on such bank accounts, they could
share it with authorities in nations with which the United States has tax
treaties.

Rebecca Wilkins of Citizens for Tax Justice, which supports the regulation, said
that people who are paying taxes in their home countries have nothing to fear.

"Only depositors who are tax evaders, money launderers, drug dealers, human
traffickers, other criminals will have an incentive to move their funds," she
said.

But the witnesses who opposed the IRS regulation said that it would require
banks to invest in new technology. Their arguments got a sympathetic hearing
from both Republican and Democratic members of the subcommittee.

"Why should we be worried about collecting taxes for other countries?" asked
Rep. Blaine Luetkemeyer, R-Mo. "That's not our problem, is it?"

But Wilkins argued that it is in the interests of the United States to help
other countries recover the taxes they're owed. She cited an estimate from a
2008 Senate report that the United States loses approximately $100 billion each
year to tax evasion, and said that American officials need to be able to show
that they're helping other countries fight tax evasion in order to expect help
in return.

Ten years ago, the IRS attempted to impose the same regulation, but it received
blowback from Congress. The regulation that the IRS ultimately adopted in 2002
limits the rule's application to depositors from Canada.

Canada is a safer, less corrupt place than Mexico and Venezuela, the only two
nations in the Western hemisphere that have tax-sharing treaties with the United
States, opponents of the regulation argued. They and their congressional
supporters said that if the U.S. government shares personal financial
information with authorities in those countries, the account holders and their
relatives could be the targets of kidnappers.

"For us to think that Mexico and Venezuela under Hugo Chavez respect our privacy
laws is absurd," Sanchez said.

House Financial Services Chairman Spencer Bachus made a similar argument.

"Now, every day we read about a kidnapping in some of these countries, and in
some cases the death of the victim. Do we really want this blood on our hands?"
he asked.

But Wilkins responded forcefully to that argument, saying: "I want to tell you,
the U.S. already has blood on its hands."

"For every dollar of tax revenue that is taken out of the governments of
developing countries, it impairs the ability of those countries to provide
health and safety measures, to feed its citizens, to provide sanitation, to
provide health care, to provide military and police that is not corrupt," she
said. "Every time we facilitate a dollar coming out of those economies, we have
blood on our hands."

Neither side in the debate was able to cite an estimate on the amount of bank
deposits that would leave the United States as a result of the IRS proposal. The
plan's opponents said they have pressed U.S. officials for a cost-benefit
analysis, but the government has never produced one.

Thomas Cardwell, former commissioner of the Florida Office of Financial
Institutions, cited a survey that found that at 16 state-chartered banks in
Florida, 41% of the deposits were from non-resident aliens.

"What would happen if these deposits, or some subset of them, were lost?"
Cardwell asked. "A deposit run of 15% would put an institution in jeopardy."

Wilkins responded that she thinks the risk of a lot of capital leaving the
United States is small.

"But you don't know that?" asked Rep. James Renacci, R-Ohio.

Wilkins acknowledged that she didn't have solid numbers, but said that her
opponents don't, either.

The IRS regulation was proposed back in January, but it has yet to be finalized.
Opponents of the plan include the Independent Community Bankers of America and
the American Bankers Association.

"Individuals have a choice among solvent, stable banking systems in which to
keep deposits, which are easily transferred from one country to another," the
ICBA said in a statement submitted to the subcommittee. "Any adverse change in
terms may be enough to make them revisit their choices, or at a minimum, demand
higher rates."

Bills to stop the regulation have been introduced in both the House and Senate.
The House bill was referred to the Ways and Means Committee, which has yet to
act on the measure.

                        The International Herald Tribune

                             April 9, 2011 Saturday

U.S. seeks names of clients at HSBC India;
Request is part of inquiry into offshore tax havens of Indian-Americans

BYLINE: BY LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 774 words

ABSTRACT

The request is part of a widening investigation into private services sold by
Swiss and Swiss-style banks that helped wealthy Americans avoid income taxes by
hiding money offshore.

FULL TEXT

Switzerland. The Caribbean. India?

The world of offshore tax havens have gained a surprising new contender now that
the U.S. Justice Department has asked a district court for permission to compel
HSBC, the global bank based in London, to turn over the names of wealthy
Indian-American clients suspected of evading taxes through offshore accounts at
the bank's affiliate in India.

The request, from the civil tax division of the Justice Department, is part of a
widening investigation into private offshore services sold by Swiss and other
banks that helped wealthy Americans avoid income taxes by hiding money offshore.

The lawsuit is an indication that the U.S. authorities are broadening their
scrutiny to include countries and regions beyond tax havens like Switzerland,
Liechtenstein, Singapore and much of the Caribbean.

India is not usually thought of in that category and does not appear on lists
compiled by research groups and government agencies.

The lawsuit shows that tax evasion ''is not Swiss-centric,'' said Lawrence S.
Horn, the chairman of the business crimes and tax litigation departments at
Sills Cummis & Gross, based in Newark, New Jersey. ''It shows that the I.R.S. is
moving east,'' referring to the U.S. Internal Revenue Service.

The U.S. authorities filed a similar request on UBS, the Swiss banking giant, in
2008. The government dropped the lawsuit last August after the Swiss government
agreed to turn over the names of 4,450 U.S. clients in connection with a broad
investigation into the bank's offshore private banking services. The bank also
paid $780 million to settle criminal accusations that it had defrauded the
I.R.S. by allowing wealthy Americans to hide billions of dollars in taxes in
secret offshore bank accounts.

Pressure on HSBC, one of the largest banks in the world, threatens to expose
more layers of  banking secrecy, a tradition that began in the Middle Ages and
that has spread around the world.

Last July and September, the Justice Department mailed ''target'' letters to
about 50 Indian-Americans with offshore bank accounts, telling them that they
were under scrutiny because of suspicions of offshore tax evasion through
accounts in India, Mr. Horn said.

Credit Suisse and Swiss cantonal banks are also under scrutiny. Robert Katzberg,
a white-collar criminal defense lawyer in New York, said that the pressure on
HSBC showed that ''the fallout of the UBS scandal, which still has far to go
within Switzerland, has spread to other countries.''

The request, made in papers filed Thursday in the U.S. District Court in San
Francisco, seeks to compel HSBC's main U.S. affiliate, HSBC Bank USA, to turn
over details of accounts held by wealthy Americans from 2002 through 2010
through the bank's affiliate in India, HSBC India. Approval from a U.S. District
Court judge is required before the Internal Revenue Service can issue the
summons.

HSBC Bank USA operated representative offices for HSBC India under the name
N.R.I. Services - N.R.I. stands for Non-Resident Indian - in New York and
Fremont, California, according to court documents. The private banking services
were offered to people of Indian origin living outside India.

In a statement, HSBC said that ''while we haven't seen the summons, HSBC does
not condone tax evasion and fully supports the U.S. efforts to promote
appropriate payment of taxes by U.S. taxpayers.'' It continued, ''While
complying with the law in all the jurisdictions in which it operates, including
India, HSBC cooperates with requests from U.S. authorities.''

The statement added: ''We have been engaged in a constructive dialogue with U.S.
authorities. We hope any 'I.R.S. Summons' issues can be resolved
expeditiously.'' A bank spokeswoman, Juanita Gutierrez, declined to comment
further.

In January, U.S. prosecutors indicted a former HSBC client, Vaibhav Dahake, who
was born in India and became a naturalized American citizen in 2006. Mr. Dahake,
according to court papers, told prosecutors that HSBC had sought out wealthy
Indian-Americans for undeclared offshore banking services through N.R.I.
Services. The bank was not identified in the papers but was confirmed at the
time as HSBC by people close to the matter. Mr. Dahake, according to his
indictment, told prosecutors that his banker had told him that no U.S.
disclosure forms were required, that the account was not taxable in India and
that no forms reporting the interest income would be filed with the I.R.S.

                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                                 March 2, 2009

Commentary: In economic news, following the sounds that are all too familiar

BYLINE: Richard Cotton

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 839  words


The chickens are coming home to roost. And, you better have the coop in order
because come home, they must.

An almost daily diet of dire economic news has steeled me somewhat to
revelations of late. I stopped months ago asking myself, "What next?" The answer
I always got was, "Anything. "

Still, there have been surprises.

Several recent developments, though not directly related to each other,
exemplify the volatile times in which we live. In the end, however, they are
related, if in no other way than being signs of the times.

The end of Swiss banking?

It appears the once safe haven for criminal income tax evasion is coming to an
end, and before the dust settles it's likely that tens of thousands of tax
cheats will either be paying up handsomely or spending some years in federal
prisons or both.

The I.R.S. wants from UBS, Switzerland's biggest bank the names of 53,000 U.S.
citizens suspected of tax evasion (as of this writing, the bank had agreed to
only 250-300 names, but that is likely to change as public outrage grows).

It should be noted that Swiss banks are far from pristine, squeaky-clean
financial institutions above reproach; many will recall them being forced to
admit complicity helping Nazis move Jewish assets into those fascists' private
accounts during World War II.

The fact that UBS - in time, other banks will follow - is being forced to come
clean is itself an earthshaking phenomenon. That wealthy Americans are greedy
enough to seek refuge from paying taxes on the money they earned in their own
country is downright reprehensible.

I look for Mississippians to be caught in the shakeup as offshore depositors are
listed in the public record.

"The man behind the curtain"

I live about seven miles from Baldwyn in Saltillo, but am temporarily in
Houston, Texas. On Feb. 17, the local Texas and national news media were ablaze
about the raid and closure of Houston-headquartered Stanford Financial Group.

Imagine my surprise when I checked Mississippi papers online, as I do daily, to
learn that No. 2 and No. 3 - James Davis and Laura Pendergest-Holt - in the
Stanford house-of-cards financial empire are residents of tiny Baldwyn, working
out of an office in Tupelo. Both were named in the suit.

In the darkest tradition of Bernie Madoff, here were two Mississippians running
a company whose primary function appears to be bilking as many people as
possible out of as much money as possible. Poof, it's gone.

R. Allen Stanford, it seems, was the wizard of his own Oz. Even if no other
Mississippians are named in future suits or indictments, there are likely many
who have lost substantial sums of money in the scheme.

Maybe they would have been better off putting their money into Swiss accounts.

Last, but not least

The $787-billion economic stimulus package was signed into law Feb. 18. The
majority of Mississippi's congressional delegation and its governor opposed the
American Recovery and Reinvestment Act.

I doubt they will oppose getting the funds. Sure, they are kicking up some dust
about some of the particular issues and complain about "strings attached," but
they'll be right at the front of the money line.

Which brings me to my personal apprehension: It appears that each state governor
will be given substantial autonomy to decide where the funding goes.
Unfortunately, we in Mississippi aren't blessed with a governor whose
funding-direction apparatus necessarily operates in the best interests of its
citizens and small businesses, both of which are oft excluded.

Haley Barbour's decision to pull $600 million out of Katrina housing replacement
funding and spend it on expanding the Port of Gulfport is a good example. Suit
was filed in December against the state for that decision; whether people's
homes or ships' berths is the correct use for those funds may be decided in
court.

That is only the latest of numerous funding and taxation decisions that tend to
lend credence to the murmur that Barbour's interests are often at odds with what
is best for Mississippians.

Handing him billions more dollars could be problematic.

Fortunately, the ARRA architects included provisions for oversight by state
legislatures. Denying governors' spending priorities and even the right to
override rejection of receiving funds a governor declines are the rights of
those bodies.

Already, in neighboring Louisiana, Gov. Bobby Jindal has seen his $308-million
list of ARRA road and bridge projects wholly rejected by that state's joint
legislative spending committee. Among the package items was $1 million Jindal
earmarked for construction in rural West Carroll Parish for "a bridge at the end
of a mud road that serves a private enterprise," according to a Baton Rouge
Advocate newspaper story.

One state senator, continued the story, "said he wants to know who the unnamed
private enterprise on the other side of the bridge contributed to in order to
get on the administration's list. "

That sounds all too familiar.

Richard Cotton is a freelance journalist from Saltillo. He can be reached at
rcotton4@earthlink.net

                                The New York Post

                             July 15, 2006 Saturday

BONDS' LAWYERS BRACE FOR WORST

BYLINE: BRIAN COSTELLO

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 47

LENGTH: 514 words


Barry Bonds' day of reckoning appears to be near, and his legal team is bracing
for the impending fight.

Bonds' legal team believes the Giants slugger could be indicted on charges of
tax evasion and perjury as soon as next week. Attorney Laura Enos told The
Associated Press yesterday that the lawyers believe the grand jury investigating
Bonds will expire next Thursday.

"We are very prepared," Enos said. "We have excellent tax records and we are all
very comfortable that he has not shortchanged the government at all."

The grand jury has been investigating Bonds, second on the career home run list,
for at least the last four months. It is believed they are looking into whether
the Giants outfielder perjured himself before the BALCO grand jury in December
2003 when he testified he never knowingly used steroids, according to leaked
grand jury testimony that appeared in The San Francisco Chronicle.

Bonds also is believed to be under investigation for tax evasion in connection
with money he allegedly provided to former girlfriend Kimberly Bell. The money
is alleged to have come from memorabilia and autograph sales, income Bonds never
reported to the IRS.

Stephen Hoskins, a childhood friend of Bonds' and his former business partner,
reportedly testified against the Giants slugger. Hoskins and Bonds had a
memorabilia business together, but the two had a falling out in 2003.

Bell also testified against Bonds and told the grand jury that Bonds said he
used performance-enhancing drugs and that he had "roid rage," according to
testimony obtained by The San Francisco Chronicle.

Enos told the AP yesterday those allegations are false and called Bell's
testimony "pillow talk."

"It's a he-said, she-said thing," Enos said.

One person who refused to testify against Bonds is his childhood friend and
trainer Greg Anderson. He served three months in prison for steroid distribution
after entering into a plea bargain in the BALCO case. Anderson went back to
prison on July 5 after refusing to testify to the current grand jury
investigating Bonds. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday refused to
free Anderson.

Bonds, who turns 42 on July 24, has remained quiet on his legal troubles. He did
comment this week to MLB.com.

"I don't usually comment [on the case] because I don't know how to comment on
it," said Bonds. "I don't know why the government is doing what it's doing. It
doesn't make any sense to me. I don't know how to discuss the case. I really
don't. Maybe later on I'll be able to. I try not to think about it. I try to
keep my mind as clear as I can and as positive as I can."

Bonds said the possible indictment has not affected him on the field. He's
batting .249 this season with 12 home runs and 38 RBI. He has 720 career home
runs, 35 shy of Hank Aaron's record.

"Anything outside [the game] I really don't worry about," he said. "I can't deal
with it. I don't really know how to deal with it. One day I will. One day I'll
be able to. When I have time. I just have to stay strong, that's all. Stay
focused. And just keep on producing."
