                               The New York Times

                           January 27, 2011 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

HSBC Is Said to Be the Focus of a Tax-Evasion Investigation

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 655 words


Federal authorities are considering whether to serve a broad legal summons on
HSBC to ascertain whether it sold tax-evasion services to scores of wealthy
American clients, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

The legal action was being considered as a federal indictment was announced
Wednesday of an affluent client of an unidentified international bank on charges
of conspiracy to defraud the United States by keeping hidden bank accounts in
India and the British Virgin Islands, an offshore tax haven, from about 2001
until this year.

The people who had been briefed on the matter said that the international bank
was HSBC, which is based in London but has Swiss-style private banking
operations around the world.

The indictment, of Vaibhav Dahake, by federal prosecutors in United States
District Court in Newark, said the unnamed bank had identified wealthy
Indian-Americans as clients for undeclared offshore banking through N.R.I.
Services, a United States division of the bank. The division, court papers said,
encouraged United States citizens to open undeclared bank accounts in India.

Mr. Dahake, of Somerset, N.J., was born in India and became a naturalized United
States citizen in 2006. He is a principal of Tricolor Inc., an information
technology business in Somerset.

It was not clear how many client names would be covered under a summons, which
would have to be issued by the Internal Revenue Service and enforced by the
Justice Department. Last August, authorities dropped a similar summons against
the Swiss bank giant UBS that had sought to require the bank to disclose the
names of as many as 52,000 wealthy American clients.

HSBC said, ''HSBC does not condone tax evasion and fully supports the U.S.
efforts to promote appropriate payment of taxes by U.S. taxpayers.''

In 2001, Mr. Dahake received from the international bank ''an unsolicited letter
advertising bank accounts in India that paid high interest rates,'' court
documents said.

The indictment cited as unindicted co-conspirators five unidentified bankers:
three Americans, in New York and Fremont, Calif.; and two Indians, in Thane,
near Mumbai, India.

One of the bankers advised Mr. Dahake to transfer money between his accounts in
smaller amounts ''to stay below the radar'' of rules requiring banks to report
to American customs officials transfers of $10,000 or more, according to the
documents.

Other bankers advised him not to file required forms to the I.R.S declaring the
money, and told him that money transferred between the British Virgin Islands
account and the India account would not be processed through the United States
banking system, further evading scrutiny.

One of the bankers told Mr. Dahake that he did not have to worry about bringing
his money from the India account back to the United States because, according to
court papers, the I.R.S. ''would be looking for undeclared accounts maintained
in the Caribbean rather than in the Far East,'' and his ownership of and the
structure of the British Virgin Islands account would be unknown to authorities.

The international bank, the papers said, also counseled Mr. Dahake about holding
money in Singapore and Hong Kong, two Asian tax havens.

Lawrence S. Horn, a lawyer for Mr. Dahake, said in a statement on Wednesday that
he saw the 10-page court document ''as something much more than just an
indictment of Mr. Dahake.'' He added that ''the timing of this indictment
appears to be a 'clubbed invitation' for American citizens with undisclosed
accounts to apply for admission into the second initiative of the voluntary
disclosure program or risk prosecution once that bank eventually discloses his
or her name to the I.R.S.''

On Monday, the I.R.S. said that it would soon announce a new amnesty program
aimed at encouraging wealthy Americans with hidden offshore bank accounts to
come forward, declare their money and pay taxes owed in exchange for reduced
fines and penalties.

SECTION: LOCAL; EAST/NORTH/SOUTH; Pg. B-4

LENGTH: 638 words


EAST

Park Foundation to help fund Flight 93 National Memorial

The National Park Foundation board of directors announced Wednesday that it will
set up a challenge grant to help fund the Flight 93 National Memorial being
built in Somerset County.

The foundation said it will match donors dollar for dollar up to $2 million. The
public can donate at www.honorflight93.org.

Chris Sullivan, chairman of the Flight 93 National Memorial Campaign, said the
group has raised about $52 million in public and private funds, with a goal of
approximately $60 million.

It hopes to complete fundraising by Sept. 10, when dedication of the first phase
of the memorial in Shanksville, Pa., is scheduled.

Mr. Sullivan said that work on the memorial has come in under budget so far.
That means that if the fundraising goal is reached, it will include a tower
marking the entry to and exit from the site at Route 30.

The "Tower of Voices" is designed to house 40 wind chimes, and would be
illuminated at night to commemorate the 40 passengers and crew who died on
Flight 93, according to the architects.

The first phase of the memorial includes a ring road leading to the site, a
memorial plaza, and a parking area.

President Barack Obama is expected to visit the Flight 93 Memorial on Sept. 11,
and Vice President Joe Biden is scheduled to attend the dedication the day
before.

Chiropractor charged with fraud, tax evasion

Federal prosecutors on Tuesday filed fraud and tax-evasion charges against a
Westmoreland County chiropractor operating two clinics in West Virginia.

Joseph Yurigan, 60, of New Alexandria, operates clinics in Weirton and Wheeling.

Prosecutors allege Mr. Yurigan made money from procedures he didn't perform,
then drew cash from his businesses and hid them in his children's bank accounts
to evade taxes.

He faces 33 charges of healthcare fraud, four tax-evasion charges and one charge
of interfering with revenue laws. Prosecutors seek to confiscate some of Mr.
Yurigan's properties, including real estate and two Mercedes-Benz cars.

If convicted, Mr. Yurigan could face up to 10 years in prison and millions of
dollars in fines.

NORTH

Teens escape from youth home, ride off in limo

Police said a group of teens, still on the lam after stealing a limousine to
escape a youth home in Butler County, likely started an early morning fire to
distract the facility's personnel.

Adams police said the teens may have started a small fire around 4:30 a.m. in a
girl's room at the Mars Home for Youth, a non-secured facility for troubled
children. Workers managed to douse the flames before firefighters arrived.

Police said the teens then called for a limousine, which arrived around 6:15
a.m. When the driver realized the three boys had no money, he ordered them out.

As he exited the vehicle to throw out their bags, two more teens leaped into the
limo and sped off, police said.

The limousine was later located at Pittsburgh Oliver High School in the
Manchester section of the city around 6:30 p.m. Four teens were taken into
custody. Police are still searching for another teen and an adult.

Administrators at the Mars Home for Youth said they are conducting an internal
investigation into the escape.

SOUTH

New sentencing hearing for death row inmate

A new sentencing hearing is scheduled for Aug. 24 for a Washington County man on
death row in the murder of a woman outside a tavern more than a quarter-century
ago.

Thomas Gorby, 52, of Eighty Four was sentenced to death for the December 1985
stabbing murder of 38-year-old Drayton Sphar of East Washington outside the
Somerset Inn.

The Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled in 2006 that Mr. Gorby must be resentenced
because his attorney during his trial did not raise his mental health as an
issue.

Defense attorney Dennis Paluso told the (Washington) Observer-Reporter that the
Aug. 24 hearing was scheduled.

                         Hartford Courant (Connecticut)

                            April 17, 2008 Thursday
                               STATEWIDE EDITION

GUILTY PLEA IN THEFT OF FURNITURE CONSPIRACY INVOLVED DESIGN FIRM OWNER, MANAGER
AT THE HARTFORD

BYLINE: DIANE LEVICK; Courant Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E2

LENGTH: 345 words


A Windsor man pleaded guilty Wednesday in a conspiracy with a former manager of
The Hartford that involved the theft of furniture from the insurance company and
tax evasion.

Terrance Healy, 62, of Windsor and formerly of Suffield, pleaded guilty in
federal court in Bridgeport to conspiracy to transport the furniture across
state lines and to defraud the IRS, said Kevin J. O'Connor, U.S. attorney for
Connecticut.

Healy was the owner and operator of Sundrop Corp. in Suffield, an interior
design and furniture installation firm. He conspired with Todd Olynciw, who was
a project management manager at The Hartford Financial Services Group and was
responsible for managing office renovations.

From 1998 to 2005, Healy paid Olynciw a total of $71,854 for furniture owned by
The Hartford, the U.S. attorney's office said.

Olynciw pleaded guilty Jan. 2 to mail fraud and tax evasion in a conspiracy with
others. He admitted receiving kickbacks for misappropriating and transferring
The Hartford's furniture and for directing business from the company to certain
people and firms.

The Hartford lost $876,437 as result of Olynciw's schemes, and he got more than
$395,720 in illegal kickbacks.

In some instances, Olynciw had stolen furniture transported from a Massachusetts
facility to Healy in Connecticut, prosecutors said. Healy initially paid Olynciw
50 percent, and later a little less, of the resale value of the furniture. Healy
knew that Olynciw would keep the money for personal use and not report it as
income on his federal tax returns, authorities said.

Healy hand-delivered 12 checks to Olynciw for furniture, and then about 33 cash
payments, according to a court document. Healy would provide Olynciw with
computer designs for office set-ups for Sundrop's customers, and Olynciw would
let him know what furniture was available.

U.S. District Judge Stefan R. Underhill has scheduled Healy to be sentenced July
3. He faces up to five years in prison and a fine of as much as $250,000.
Olynciw is scheduled for sentencing April 30.

CEO pleads guilty

BYLINE: Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BUSINESS; Local; News

LENGTH: 341 words


The chief executive of a startup company with offices in Livermore and San Ramon
pleaded guilty to tax evasion for failing to report taxable income of more than
$1.1 million, federal prosecutors said Friday.

John Frances Griffin, 41, an Orinda resident, was CEO of VaporTech Inc., which
was engaged in developing a "dirt eater" that could be used to clean toxic soil.
VaporTech also was developing a device that would use steam to extract oil from
wells.

During 2004 and 2005, Griffin received taxable income of nearly $1.2 million but
failed to file any federal income tax returns, according to prosecutors. Griffin
admitted he evaded assessment and payment of income taxes by paying for personal
items with cash, cashier's checks and a VaporTech debit card.

Griffin was charged in May 2006 with three counts of mail fraud. Then in
November 2006, he was charged with 15 counts of mail fraud, one count of wire
fraud and two counts of tax evasion. Griffin pleaded guilty to both counts of
tax evasion.

Griffin, who was in charge of the company's day-to-day operations, also raised
$2.5 million from numerous investors.

Through the guilty plea arrangement, Griffin also agreed to forfeit numerous
items. Those include $75,000 in cash, jewelry such as a $30,000 diamond ring and
a $3,400 gold tennis bracelet, electronic gear and thousands of dollars worth of
clothing and wine.

CFO quits

Oplink Communications Inc. said its chief financial officer, Bruce Horn, has
resigned to pursue other interests. Fremont-based Oplink promoted Shirley Yin,
its controller, to acting chief financial officer. A search has begun for a
replacement for Horn.

Nasdaq compliance

San Ramon-based SBE Inc. said it has regained compliance with the Nasdaq Stock
Market. The company's bid price has been $1 a share or more for at least 10
consecutive days. The hardware and software maker is closing in on a deal to be
sold to Neonode, a Sweden-based company.

Compiled from wire and staff reports. Got Bay Area business news? Reach Drew
Voros at 925-943-8099 or dvoros@cctimes.com .

                                US Official News

                            November 4, 2016 Friday

Washington: Embezzler Sentenced to 3 Years for Fraud & Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 435  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: US Department of Justice has issued the following news release:



  John W. Vaudreuil, United States Attorney for the Western District of
Wisconsin, announced that Lisa Buchholz, 48, Luck, Wis., was sentenced yesterday
by Chief U.S. District Judge William Conley to 36 months in federal prison for
wire fraud and income tax evasion.  Buchholz pleaded guilty to these charges on
July 28, 2016.  Judge Conley also imposed a three-year term of supervised
release, and ordered Buchholz to pay restitution of $193,909.96 to the victim of
her fraud scheme.



  In February 2016, a federal grand jury sitting in Madison, Wis., returned a
13-count indictment against Buchholz.  The indictment alleged that while
employed as a bookkeeper for Four Seasons Wood Products (FSWP) in Frederic,
Wis., from May 2008 until June 2012, she devised a scheme to defraud the
company.  The indictment further alleged that Buchholz failed to file income tax
returns for 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2011, and that she committed income tax evasion
in 2011 by making false statements to an IRS criminal investigator during an
interview in 2013.

  At yesterday's sentencing hearing, Judge Conley found that Buchholz caused a
fraud loss of $172,176.94 to FSWP, and a tax loss of $111,553 to the IRS.  FSWP
also incurred more than $21,000 in investigative costs due to Buchholz's
misconduct.   Michael Broten, the owner of FSWP, testified at the sentencing
hearing, and told Judge Conley that Buchholz's conduct nearly destroyed his
family business.  He told the judge she betrayed Broten's trust and her
embezzlement caused Broten to lay off employees because the company had no money
due to Buchholz's criminal conduct.

  Judge Conley rejected Buchholz's claim that she engaged in the criminal
conduct because she was a victim of abuse, finding that her last-minute
allegations were not supported by any other witnesses, and in fact, were
contradicted by other facts in the case.  Judge Conley told Buchholz he found
that she had engaged in an outrageous fraud over a long period of time. He also
found that she executed the fraud in a very calculated and sophisticated manner.
Judge Conley also noted that Buchholz has been fired by her last three employers
for engaging in fraud.

 The charges against Buchholz were the result of an investigation conducted by
IRS Criminal Investigation and the Polk County Sheriff's Office.  The
prosecution of the case has been handled by Assistant U.S. Attorney Daniel
Graber.

                          September 28, 2006 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

As Bonds Finishes Play, Grand Jury Is at Work

BYLINE: By CAROL POGASH; David Cay Johnston contributed reporting.

SECTION: Section D; Column 5; Sports Desk; BASEBALL; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 1278 words


As Barry Bonds moves toward the final weekend of his 21st season in the major
leagues, his legal troubles remain unresolved. His defense lawyer dismisses talk
of possible tax-evasion charges, while his former trainer remains locked up in
an 8-by-10-foot prison cell for refusing to testify about Bonds, the 42-year-old
slugger.

Playing with a surgically repaired knee and enduring the disdain of fans just
about everywhere but San Francisco, Bonds has put together a respectable enough
season, with his 26 home runs leaving him 21 short of Hank Aaron's revered
record of 755.

While Bonds will not be part of the October postseason -- and has never been on
a World Series winner -- he is in a good position to pass Aaron in 2007,
assuming San Francisco or another team is willing to sign him to a new contract.
He appears intent on playing, and his agent, Jeff Borris, said Tuesday that he
expected the Giants to contact him once the season ends.

Meanwhile, not far from the stadium where Bonds will shortly be cleaning out his
locker, a federal grand jury continues to look into his affairs and those of
other sports figures. The question is what charges the jurors might ultimately
produce against Bonds, who is shadowed by two issues -- whether he funneled
thousands of dollars in unreported income to a former girlfriend, and whether
his testimony about steroids before a previous grand jury has left him
vulnerable to perjury charges.

The former girlfriend, Kimberly Bell, has stated that Bonds gave her $80,000 in
cash that he received from signing baseballs. The money was for a down payment
on a house and he advised her to deposit it in different bank accounts in
amounts of less than $10,000 to avoid detection by authorities, she said. Bell
has not said whether she knows if Bonds reported the income; she testified twice
before the first grand jury in San Francisco that investigated the Bay Area
Laboratory Cooperative steroid-distribution case.

Michael Rains, Bonds's defense lawyer, said there was no evidence that federal
authorities are going after Bonds on tax-evasion charges, noting that none of
Bonds's financial records have been subpoenaed. He said that while the federal
government would ''take pleasure'' in arresting Bonds for spitting on the
sidewalk, ''the income tax thing isn't there.''

Laura Enos, Bonds's personal business lawyer, said she and Rains have not been
contacted by the Internal Revenue Service. ''I don't think there is a tax case
here,'' she said.

In one sense, Bonds would be an inviting target for investigation as a tax
cheat. Elliott Kajan, a criminal tax lawyer in Beverly Hills, Calif., said the
Internal Revenue Service tries to bring cases that will get wide attention in
order to deter others from cheating.

''The deterrent effect for an indictment of Barry Bonds for tax evasion would be
awesome,'' Kajan said.

On the other hand, tax evasion is rarely prosecuted. Federal grand juries hand
up fewer than 600 indictments annually where a tax crime is the major charge,
government data posted by the Transactional Records Access Clearinghouse at
Syracuse University showed.

Both Enos and Rains contended that any tax-evasion case against Bonds would be
greatly flawed because Bonds did not give Bell any cash to buy a house. They
said the money was actually given to her by Steve Hoskins, Bonds's former close
friend and business partner. Hoskins is now derided by Bonds's lawyers as a liar
and schemer who turned on Bonds to keep himself out of legal trouble.

According to Enos, it was Bonds who confronted Hoskins in June 2003 over the
suspected forging of Bonds's signature on various contracts, and it was Bonds
who then took his complaints to the United States attorney in San Francisco and
the F.B.I. Hoskins's lawyer, Michael Cardoza, said it was Hoskins who later told
federal investigators that Bonds was a heavy steroids user who flew into ''roid
rages.''

As for Kimberly Bell, Cardoza said that it was Bonds who gave Hoskins the money
to give to her.

''The cash went through Steve Hoskins, the taxpayer of record,'' countered Enos,
a reference to the fact that Bonds's memorabilia sales were made through a
company run by Hoskins. ''The main witness here may have a tax problem of his
own.''

Bonds's lawyers have previously attacked Hoskins, and Enos did so again last
week, stating that the relationship between Bonds and Hoskins fell apart after
Bonds learned of business deals made without his awareness. Enos said the
subsequent confrontation with Hoskins led to a termination of their business
dealings but that Hoskins continued to sell fabricated Bonds memorabilia.

''I couldn't figure out why the feds wouldn't pursue it,'' she said of the
complaint Bonds lodged with law enforcement authorities.

''I'm not going through every little thing,'' Cardoza said when asked about
Enos's statements. ''The feds investigated and found my guy did nothing wrong.
I'll put my guy up against Barry when it comes to truth and veracity any time,
any place, anywhere, especially under oath should we get there.''

Whatever the outcome of the tax-evasion issue, it is the perjury question that
goes to the heart of the steroid controversy surrounding Bonds. His former
trainer, Greg Anderson, pleaded guilty last year to steroid distribution and
money laundering in connection with the Balco scandal and was sentenced to three
months in prison and three months of home confinement.

Anderson's lead lawyer, Mark J. Geragos, stated that it was an explicit part of
Anderson's plea agreement that Anderson would not have to testify further,
presumably about Bonds and steroids.

But Anderson was summoned to testify again, and he ended up serving 15 days in
federal prison in Dublin, Calif., for refusing to testify. He left prison July
20 but went back to Dublin on Aug. 28 when he took the same stance with the new
grand jury. He was sent there by Judge William Alsup, who said the incarceration
was intended to be coercive, not punitive.

A transcript of the Aug. 28 hearing, held in open court, shows Alsup accusing
Anderson and Geragos of ''playing a game with the system.''

''There's a wealth of stuff in the public domain saying that your client
injected steroids into Barry Bonds,'' Alsup maintained. He also asserted that he
had seen Anderson on television and that Anderson had issued ''press releases
where it says it doesn't matter what my lawyer says, I'm not going to answer
those questions anyway.''

Geragos adamantly responded that Anderson had done no such thing.

In any case, Anderson is now housed in a small cell with a roommate and a slit
window. And he is finding life in prison more difficult than before, said Paula
Canny, who is one of Anderson's lawyers and visits him several times a week.

She said Anderson had been unnerved by a recent prison fight that led to a
two-day lockdown and that he had become claustrophobic. Canny said Anderson also
missed attending his son's soccer games and had seen his plans to be married put
on hold.

The new grand jury could run for 18 months, which means Anderson could be
washing dishes in the prison kitchen -- his current job -- for months to come,
provided he does not relent and decide to testify. Canny says he will not.

''In America the only thing worse than being a cheat is being a snitch,'' she
said. ''He's never going to say anything -- not because of Barry but because of
Greg.''

As Anderson sits in prison, Bonds will take his last at-bats of the season,
looking to move one or two home runs closer to Aaron's mark. That quest will
presumably continue in 2007; meanwhile, the grand jury continues its work as
well.

                           February 5, 2009 Thursday

BRIEF: Area man guilty of tax evasion

BYLINE: The Dominion Post, Morgantown, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 232 words


Feb. 5--A Terra Alta resident pleaded guilty to tax evasion in an appearance
Tuesday before U.S. District Court Judge Irene M. Keeley.

Melvin L. Owens, 64, entered the plea to a charge that he failed to report any
personal income or pay any federal income taxes for tax year 2005, U.S. Attorney
Sharon L. Potter said in a news release.

Instead of filing a personal income tax return (Form 1040), Owens filed a
fraudulent trust return (Form 1041) that reported income of a nonexistent trust
named "Melvin L. Owens," she said.

In this, he claimed deductions that equaled the purported income of the trust,
resulting in $0 taxable income and $0 tax due. Even after IRS Special Agents
confronted him in April 2007, Potter reported, Owens continued to file
fraudulent trust returns and refused to either report personal income or pay
federal income taxes.

Owens is free on bond pending sentencing. He faces a maximum sentence of five
years in prison and a fine of $100,000.

Couple in New Hampshire Convicted of Tax Evasion

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

SECTION: Section 1;  Page 34;  Column 5;  Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 705 words

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., April 14


Three days before the deadline for filing 1994 income taxes, a Federal jury
today convicted a couple of evading Federal income taxes for four years.

Stuart Tulchinsky, 47, and his wife, Cathie Schneider, 41, of Chester, N.H., the
owners of what prosecutors called two drug paraphernalia shops, put forth a
defense that they "sincerely believe" that the Federal income tax system is
voluntary.

Such defenses have become common in tax protest cases since 1991, when the
United States Supreme Court held that such a belief, however unreasonable, is a
complete defense in tax-evasion cases if jurors find that it is sincerely held.

In six trials in the last three years, eight tax protesters have been convicted,
one was acquitted and seven resulted in hung juries, Carl Stern, the Justice
Department's senior spokesman, said. The Government plans to retry the seven,
Mr. Stern said.

Mr. Tulchinsky and Ms. Schneider, who call themselves "tax awareness advocates,"
will be sentenced in the Federal District Court here on July 13.

"It's another strike against freedom," Ms. Schneider said as she left the
courthouse.

William Cohan, one of the couple's lawyers, said he expected that the couple
would be sentenced to "substantial" prison time and lose most or all of their
assets, including a lakefront home that figured prominently in the two-week
trial.

"I don't like to argue with juries," said Mr. Cohan, of Encinitas, Calif., who
has won other such cases or had cases that ended in hung juries. "But in this
case there are some very hard things to overcome. The Government had the jury
look at the pictures of their big house and all the money they made, unlike some
of the other people in this movement who are not prosperous."

Neither the lead prosecutor, Seth D. Uram, nor any of the six men and six women
on the jury would comment.

Mr. Cohan and the other defense lawyer, Bruce Kenna, repeatedly tried to get
Government witnesses to point to a section of the Internal Revenue Code that
requires that income tax returns be filed. Mr. Cohan told jurors that the
defendants repeatedly asked the I.R.S. to show them such a law but they were
rebuffed, an argument the Government did not dispute.

"Are you required to obey a law that the Government won't show you? Mr. Cohan
asked the jury. "I would like to see the statute that imposes a duty to file
income tax returns. You haven't been shown one shred of evidence of it. Why
won't the Government show it?"

Mr. Kenna, a former Federal prosecutor, said in an interview that the Government
was unwilling to respond to such questions in part because an answer requires
linking four sections of the tax code. The Government, he said, contends that
the arguments are frivolous and that linking the four sections is overly
complex.

In other tax protest cases, Federal prosecutors have said that the requirement
to pay taxes is so obvious that challenges to it are not worthy of a response.

In the last five years, 46 of 49 felony defendants in tax protest cases were
acquitted or the juries were unable to reach a verdict, according to Mr. Stern
of the Justice Department and other lawyers who represent tax protesters. Some
of the 46 were convicted of misdemeanor counts, Mr. Cohan noted.

Mr. Tulchinsky and Ms. Schneider were indicted in November on four counts each
of tax evasion for not filing returns for 1986-89. The case against them began
when a former employee told the I.R.S. that the couple did not pay taxes.

The couple stopped paying taxes after attending seminars by Irwin A. Schiff, a
Connecticut insurance salesman and author who contends that the income tax
system is voluntary.

The couple's net worth during the four-year period grew to $607,266 from
$184,426, according to calculations by a revenue agent, Tama Mitchell, that the
defendants did not dispute.

The couple should have paid at least $133,250 in Federal income and
self-employment taxes over the four years, the agent testified.

Mr. Uram said that even though Mr. Schiff had been convicted on tax charges
three times, the defendants did not re-examine their beliefs because "they were
looking for any excuse to stop paying their taxes" once their business became
profitable.

LOAD-DATE: April 15, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: April 17, 1995, Monday

CORRECTION:

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about the
convictions of a New Hampshire couple on tax evasion charges misattributed a
statement that 46 of 49 felony defendants in tax-protest cases were acquitted or
that the juries were unable to reach a verdict. The statement was made by
William Cohan, a criminal defense lawyer, not Carl Stern, a Justice Department
spokesman.

                             Goshen News (Indiana)

                            April 25, 2015 Saturday

Businessman sentenced for tax evasion

BYLINE: Goshen News, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 349 words


April 25--A Mishawaka businessman was sentenced for tax evasion in federal
court.

Michael Smith, 60, Mishawaka, was sentenced to 27 months in prison and ordered
to pay $429,795 in restitution to the Internal Revenue Service for tax evasion
and structuring financial transactions. In addition, Smith will forfeit $656,019
in cash to the United States.

According to court documents, Smith, the owner of a heating/cooling business in
Mishawaka, evaded more than $400,000 in taxes during a five-year period by
failing to report business income on his tax returns. Smith also structured
multiple cash transactions to avoid bank reporting requirements. He pleaded
guilty on Dec. 11, 2014 to a count of tax evasion and one count of structuring
financial transactions.

Theft/burglary reports

--Employees at Hershberger Painting Inc., 57571 C.R. 29, Goshen, reported to
Elkhart County police someone stole a Graco 1595 airless paint sprayer with a
hose between 5 p.m. Wednesday and 10 a.m. Thursday.

--Barbara Harley of Goshen told Elkhart County police someone fraudulently used
her debit card between April 15 and Thursday.

--Vickie Fletter, 634 Pringle Drive, Goshen, told Goshen police someone stole
items from a vehicle at her residence at approximately midnight Thursday.

--David P. Bickel told Goshen police someone stole the stereo out of a vehicle
while it was parked outside his residence at 1804 Westplains Drive in Goshen.

Vandalism report

--Corina Morelock, 536 Van Gilst Drive, Goshen, told Goshen police someone broke
a window at her residence at 10:51 a.m. Thursday.

OWI arrests

--Laura Lehman, 51, 111 Gum St., LaGrange, was arrested by LaGrange police on a
charge of operating a vehicle while intoxicated Thursday and booked into the
county jail.

--Gerald Jaworski, 59, 597 Maple Ridge, LaGrange, was arrested by LaGrange
police on charges of driving while intoxicated and driving with a suspended
license-prior Thursday and booked into the county jail.

BIG 10 for the week of June 7-14, 2013

BYLINE: J.D. Sumner, The Albany Herald, Ga.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 403 words


June 16--These are the most-read stories at albanyherald.com for the week of
June 7 through June 14, 2013. Click on the headlines to read the full stories.

1. Digging for artifacts lands man in jail

ALBANY, Ga. -- One man's efforts to excavate arrowheads and other Native
American artifacts for what investigators claim was commercial gain has landed
him in the Dougherty County Jail.

2. BOE approves hiring of four new principals

ALBANY, Ga. -- The Dougherty County School Board approved Monday the hiring of
four new principals: Brandi Barrett at Albany Middle School, Angela Shumate at
Lamar Reese Elementary, Vontressa Childs at M.L. King Elementary and Ronald
Lewis at Morningside.

3. Miller County sheriff found dead near home

COLQUITT -- Miller County Sheriff, H.E. "Buddy" Glass was found dead near a pond
at his rural home Saturday.

4. Former Lee doctor convicted of tax evasion

ALBANY, Ga. -- Robert B. Sperrazza, a former anesthesiologist and resident of
Lee County, has been convicted of tax evasion and other federal charges.

5. Firefighters rescue kitten for philanthropist Willson

ALBANY, Ga. -- Businesswoman Jane Willson has dedicated a large portion of her
adult life to philanthropic pursuits. Perhaps it was karma, then, that brought
Willson a return on her good deeds recently.

6. Smallcakes hoping to savor the sweet life

ALBANY -- Less than 24 hours before its Albany debut, the staff and owners of
Smallcakes: A Cupcakery were busy learning the delicate techniques of cupcake
perfection.

7. Students sue to soften 'cruel' truancy policies

DALLAS -- Several students from northeast Texas said they plan to file a federal
complaint on Wednesday accusing their school districts of cruel and unusual
punishment by prosecuting them in criminal court for missing school or being
late for class.

8. Miller Sheriff's death ruled an accident

COLQUITT, Ga. -- Miller County Sheriff H.E. "Buddy" Glass was a victim of
drowning and possibly of heart disease, according to the Georgia Bureau of
Investigation.

9. Two rescued in kayak accident

ALBANY -- Albany police and firefighters responded to a 911 call at the Flint
River Saturday to rescue two kayakers.

10. Dougherty County Jail Report -- May 29-June 6, 2013

These are individuals who were booked into the Dougherty County Jail May 29-June
6, 2013.

                  April 7, 1996, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

It's a Tough Time for the Democratic Party in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

SECTION: Section 1;  Page 12;  Column 1;  National Desk

LENGTH: 746 words

DATELINE: BOSTON, April 6


These are trying times for state Democratic legislators in Massachusetts. For
starters, the Governor, William F. Weld, is a Republican. But last week things
got a whole lot worse.

Charles F. Flaherty, the popular and powerful Democratic Speaker of the
overwhelmingly Democratic Massachusetts House, pleaded guilty to a Federal tax
evasion charge involving a 13-year-old tax return, and announced that he would
step down at the end of June.

Then, with Mr. Flaherty's top two lieutenants fighting to succeed him, one of
them, Thomas M. Finneran, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, did the
unspeakable: He announced that he had the support of a coalition that included
34 Republicans.

Joan Menard, a state representative for 18 years, is the chairwoman of the state
Democratic Party. "It's like letting the Democrats go to the Republican national
convention to choose a Republican candidate for President," she said, referring
to Mr. Finneran's surprise move. "It's not done. Everyone was hysterical when we
found out. We had no clue."

The calmest person at the State House here last week, at least outwardly, was
Charles Flaherty. "What am I going to do, have them investigate me for another
three years?" he said when asked why he had pleaded guilty to the tax evasion
charge.

The charge was brought by the United States Attorney's office after a three-year
public corruption probe that found no evidence that Mr. Flaherty had used his
office to enrich himself, or that he had traded his power for personal gain.

At age 57, Mr. Flaherty, who has four grown children and is divorced, lives in a
two-room apartment in Cambridge overlooking a supermarket parking lot. In
Federal court last week, he had on the same off-the-rack suit that he wore five
years ago when he was sworn in as Speaker.

"I've always been broke," he said, talking in his office, with the photographs
of the 81 former Speakers on the mahogany paneled walls. "I'm more broke now."
He says he has $2,000 in the bank, and one credit card to his name. He owes the
Federal Government $24,000 in fines and back taxes.

He owes an additional $26,000 fine to the State Ethics Commission in connection
with New England vacations he took in houses provided by friends who were
lobbyists.

Mr. Flaherty entered the Legislature 30 years ago, following the path of his old
friend, the late Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill, who came from the same North Cambridge
neighborhood. Like Mr. O'Neill, who went from being Speaker of the Massachusetts
House to Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, Mr. Flaherty
built a reputation as the champion of the working class, and the poor. Two years
ago, Mr. Flaherty led the successful move to oppose Governor Weld's effort to
reinstitute the death penalty.

In an interview in his office last week, Mr. Flaherty brushed off the tax
evasion charge, and said he had done nothing wrong. "I signed a document," he
said, referring to papers he said his lawyer had prepared in 1987 when his 1983
tax return was audited. "It's a mistake on a tax form."

The United States Attorney, Donald K Stern, said in a statement: "Mr. Flaherty
admits that he lied under oath and submitted bogus diaries and meal receipts to
the Internal Revenue Service as part of a scheme to cheat on his taxes."

The Federal investigation followed a series by The Boston Globe that detailed
Mr. Flaherty's vacations with lobbyists.

The investigation has stirred outrage among longtime political observors, and in
legal circles. "It's ethics run amok," said Tom Kiley, a prominent Boston lawyer
and former first assistant state attorney general.

Jack Beatty, the writer of a biography of James Michael Curley, the legendary
Boston mayor and Massachusetts Governor who went to Federal prison for mail
fraud, said he thought Mr. Flaherty had been "railroaded."

"When Charlie Flaherty first got to the Legislature, corruption was defined as
brown bags full of cash," Mr. Beatty said. "Now it's defined as not keeping your
restaurant receipts. He was a bad accountant. Today people are being arrested in
politics for being bad accountants."

Mr. Flaherty, meanwhile, has been quoting his mother, Anna Flaherty, who lives
near him in Cambridge. He said she telephoned him after the news conference in
which he announced that he would step down as Speaker. "She said, 'This is the
matriarch of the family calling,' " Mr. Flaherty recalled. " 'Don't let them
bother you, dear.' "

(Associated Press)

                                US Official News

                           November 24, 2016 Thursday

Ohio: Accountant Pleads Guilty to Embezzling more than $1 Million

LENGTH: 621  words

DATELINE: New York



 Columbus: Department of Justice, The State of Ohio has issued the following
news release:



  Deborah Yosick, 60, currently of Davenport, Florida, pleaded guilty in U.S.
District Court to embezzling more than $1 million. She pleaded guilty to one
count each of wire fraud and income tax evasion.









 Benjamin C. Glassman, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Ohio,
Kathy A. Enstrom, Special Agent in Charge, Internal Revenue Service Criminal
Investigation (IRS), and Angela L. Byers, Special Agent in Charge, Federal
Bureau of Investigation, Cincinnati Field Division, announced the plea entered
into yesterday before U.S. Magistrate Judge Sharon L. Ovington.



 According to court documents, Yosick embezzled money from her employer, Donald
C. Wright Investments, LLC and its sister company Don Wright Realty, LLC. Don
Wright's businesses are family-owned and are based in Centerville, Ohio. Don
Wright provided various commercial, industrial, and residential services in the
Dayton, Ohio-area.







 Between approximately 1985 and October 2015, Yosick was Don Wright's accountant
and was principally responsible for handing its accounts payables and accounts
receivables, including making journal entries relating to receivables, crediting
tenant accounts as rents were received and preparing deposit slips and making
deposits on behalf of Don Wright. Yosick was personally responsible for
depositing rental receipts (whether they were cash or check) into the
appropriate Don Wright bank account.







 Between 2010 and approximately October 2015, Yosick devised a scheme to defraud
and embezzle money from Don Wright by using rental payments to pay her personal
American Express bill, by initiating ACH transfers from a Don Wright bank
account. She used a portion of the cash she embezzled to purchase money orders
from supermarkets, Wal-Mart and post offices and use the money orders to pay her
personal American Express credit card bills.







 Also, between March 2013 and approximately October 2015, Yosick embezzled funds
from Don Wright by causing approximately 70 electronic transfers (ACH payments)
from a company bank account to American Express in order to pay her personal
credit card bill.







 In total, between 2010 and approximately October 2015, Yosick embezzled
$1,098,778.23 from Don Wright.







 Additionally, Yosick committed income tax evasion by filing a false income tax
return for the 2014 income tax year by underreporting her taxable income by
approximately $303,808, which resulted in tax due and owing of approximately
$94,601, which represented the embezzled funds from Don Wright.







 In total, Yosick attempted to evade paying $255,571 in federal income taxes to
the IRS for the 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013 and 2014 income tax years.







 Yosick agreed to pay restitution to Don Wright Realty LLC in the amount of
$1,098,778.23 and to the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in the amount of
$255,571.







 Wire fraud is punishable by up to 20 years imprisonment, and income tax evasion
is punishable by up to 5 years imprisonment.







 "Tax evasion and embezzlement schemes of this magnitude and with this degree of
trickery, dishonesty and deceit, deserves to be punished," said Kathy A.
Enstrom, Special Agent in Charge, IRS Criminal Investigation, Cincinnati Field
Office. "The IRS, FBI, and U.S. Attorney's Office remain determined and vigilant
in ferreting out such schemes to cheat the honest taxpayers."







 U.S. Attorney Glassman commended the cooperative law enforcement investigation,
as well as Assistant United States Attorney Alex R. Sistla, who is prosecuting
the case.

                                  UNK Edition

Douglas Bruce due in Denver Monday for probation revocation hearing

BYLINE: Jesse Paul

SECTION: Z; Pg. 0Z

LENGTH: 273 words


Douglas Bruce, the author of Colorado's Taxpayer's Bill of Rights, is due in
court Monday on accusations he violated conditions of his probation in a 2012
felony tax evasion conviction.

State prosecutors allege he violated six terms of his probation, including
failing to timely report a law enforcement contact, not returning a financial
disclosure form and not properly disclosing financial obligations and funds.

Bruce, a former legislator, also is accused of failing to provide copies of his
income tax records for two years.

Monday's hearing is billed as a litigated probation revocation hearing. Bruce
was convicted in 2012 of attempting to influence a public servant, tax evasion
and filing a false tax return

Bruce said at an April 10 court hearing in the probation case that he planned to
represent himself during the revocation hearing.

Bruce was charged with assault in Denver after that April hearing, where he was
captured on video grabbing a cell phone out of the hands of Dede Laugesen,
executive director of Colorado Springs Government Watch.

The confrontation happened as Bruce,a Colorado Springs Republican, left the
Lindsey Flanigan Courthouse.

Denver's city attorney's office dropped those charges in May because it said
there was no likelihood of conviction.

In April, news also surfaced that Bruce is wanted out of an Ohio housing court
on a $5,000 bond building code violation arrest warrant, records there show.

The warrant, ordering Bruce's arrest, was signed by a judge March 19. It was
issued after Bruce failed to appear in court for code citations.

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                           September 8, 2009 Tuesday

Former Pleasanton investor who fabricated Hollywood background pleads guilty

BYLINE: Sophia Kazmi Contra Costa Times

SECTION: BREAKING; My Town; Alameda; Crime; News; Local

LENGTH: 315 words


OAKLAND   A former Pleasanton man, who faked a glamorous Hollywood background to
win clients, has pleaded guilty to federal wire fraud and tax evasion charges.

Prosecutors with the U.S. Attorney's Office say Brice Carrington told investors
that he was an Academy Award-winning sound effects engineer   going so far as to
commission a jeweler to create a fake Oscar statuette with his name on it.

Carrington now lives in Ojai, but while he was in Pleasanton he promised 10
investors that he would double or triple their returns on sound effects design
projects. After he received more than $4 million from his investors from 2001 to
2005, prosecutors say he only used about $430,000 toward the projects.

Instead, Carrington, 46, used a substantial portion of the money for personal
expenses, including the purchase of three high-end vehicles: a Lamborghini
Murcielago, a Hummer H2 and a Mercedes-Benz SL500R.

The U.S. Attorney's Office said the cars were props used to draw new investors.

Carrington, who made his guilty plea on Friday, told investors he was a
three-time Oscar winner and was involved in many Hollywood projects. He
displayed Oscars and photos of himself with the statuettes at his Pleasanton
home during fundraising parties. Carrington also admitted that he failed to
report $581,500 on his 2003 tax return.

He was charged Aug. 4 with five counts of wire fraud and four counts of tax
evasion. Under a plea agreement he pleaded guilty to one count each of wire
fraud and tax evasion, agreed to a four-year sentence, to pay $4,184,367 in
restitution and to forfeit the three luxury cars.

He could have faced up to 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine for each count
of wire fraud and five years of prison and a $250,000 fine for each count of tax
evasion and restitution.

Carrington will be sentenced Jan. 8.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                              April 3, 2009 Friday
                           4 State / Suncoast Edition

THE CASE AGAINST DRIVER HELIO CASTRONEVES

SECTION: ST. PETERSBURG GRAND PRIX; Pg. 4X

LENGTH: 426 words


Penske Racing driver Helio Castroneves has won the St. Petersburg Grand Prix
twice along with two Indianapolis 500 trophies. He will miss this year's grand
prix because he is on trial in Miami on tax evasion and conspiracy charges.

* * *

Who's on trial

Castroneves, his sister/former business manager Katiucia Castroneves, and their
lawyer, Alan Miller.

* * *

The allegation

Prosecutors contend Castroneves helped mastermind an elaborate tax fraud scheme
involving companies in the Netherlands and Panama.

* * *

How it worked

Castroneves' original contract with Penske Racing, signed in 1999, paid him $1
million directly as a race car driver. It also was to pay $5 million from a
marketing deal to a Panamanian company, Seven Promotions. The prosecution
contends that Castroneves, his sister, and at least one other family member
created and controlled Seven Promotions, which under Panamanian law was set up
without producing a public record of the incorporating party's name or
identifying shareholders. Prosecutors also say Miller, the lawyer, later helped
devise a scheme to keep Penske from withholding taxes from the $5 million by
having it instead paid to a Dutch company. They allege Castroneves planned to
move to a tax haven such as Monaco after his career and accept the money at that
point without paying taxes.

* * *

The defense

Led by well-known criminal defense attorney Roy Black (former counsel to William
Kennedy Smith), the defense insists Seven Promotions was created and controlled
by Castroneves' father, Helio Sr., who had financed his son's early racing
career, and that money received by Seven Promotions is not taxable to Helio Jr.
The defense contends the driver was concentrating on his career and didn't
understand the financial dealings. To prove tax evasion, the prosecution must
prove Castroneves willfully evaded taxes.

* * *

At stake

Castroneves, 33, could face up to 61/2 years in prison and because he is not a
U.S. citizen could be deported upon release from prison. A conviction would ruin
his racing career and cost him millions in endorsements.

* * *

Outlook

According to Sports Illustrated, prosecutors obtain convictions in more than 90
percent of tax evasion cases. But Castroneves is an affable celebrity who became
broadly known through racing and his victory on Dancing with the Stars and he
has a high-profile defense team that has had success in celebrity cases. The
prosecution rested its case on Monday.

Information from the Miami Herald, New York Times, South Florida Sun-Sentinel
and Sports Illustrated was used in this report.

                                The Toronto Star

                             March 28, 2006 Tuesday

Ex-KPMG partner guilty

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D05

LENGTH: 221 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


A former partner at accounting firm KPMG pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy
and tax-evasion charges for his role in creating and marketing fraudulent tax
shelters meant to help wealthy clients avoid paying taxes.

David Rivkin, 42, pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy and one count of tax
evasion at a hearing in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. As part of his plea,
Rivkin has agreed to co-operate in the government's investigation of the
shelters prosecutors say cost the United States $2.5 billion (U.S.) in lost
taxes.

Rivkin told Judge Lewis Kaplan that he conspired with others to market the
shelters, which were meant "to allow wealthy taxpayers to claim phony losses."

He faces up to 10 years in prison, but federal prosecutors can recommend a more
lenient sentence in exchange for his co-operation.

Rivkin, who is a certified public accountant and worked in KPMG's San Diego
office from July 1999 to April 2004, initially faced 39 counts of tax evasion
and one count of conspiracy. Eighteen others have been charged in what the
prosecutors have described as the largest criminal tax case ever filed.

Rivkin helped clients claim $235 million in losses from fraudulent investments
in Cayman Islands entities or through foreign-currency transactions, court
documents said. Rivkin is scheduled to be sentenced next year.

IN BRIEF&gt;&gt; SHORT SHOTS

SECTION: SPORT; Pg. 74

LENGTH: 458  words


Hall of famers

BASEBALL: Rickey Henderson, Major League Baseball's all-time stolen base leader,
and Jim Rice, breaking through in his final year of eligibility, were elected to
the US National Baseball Hall of Fame. Henderson, considered among the top
lead-off batters to play the game, received 94.8 per cent, named on 511 of 539
ballots in his first year on the ballot. His 2295 runs scored and 81 lead-off
home runs are also career records.

Hot shots on way

GOLF: Exciting American Anthony Kim and prolific British winner Colin
Montgomerie are the latest additions to the field for next month's Johnnie
Walker Classic in Perth. Kim, who started 2009 as runner-up to Geoff Ogilvy at
the Mercedes-Benz in Hawaii, has rocketed to No.9 in the world after only two
full years on the US Tour. The Johnnie Walker will be played at The Vines from
February 19-22 and the field already includes world No.8 Camilo Villegas,
11th-ranked Lee Westwood and Greg Norman.

New Power drive

MOTORSPORT: Australian driver Will Power will step in for Brazil's Helio
Castroneves at Team Penske while the two-time Indianapolis 500 champion fights
tax evasion charges in court, The Indianapolis Star reported on Monday. Power,
whose deal with KV Racing Technology expired at the end of last season, will
handle testing for Penske's No.3 car. Castroneves, who won US TV's Dancing With
The Stars in 2007, has pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy and tax
evasion.

Captain Hoiles

RUGBY: Wallabies backrower Stephen Hoiles has been appointed captain of the
Brumbies for the 2009 Super 14 rugby tournament. Hoiles takes over the captaincy
from Australian skipper and centre Stirling Mortlock. He has missed only one
match for the Brumbies since transferring from the Waratahs for the 2007 season.

Broncos coach

NFL: Josh McDaniels, offensive co-ordinator for the New England Patriots, was
named coach of the Denver Broncos on Monday, becoming the youngest coach in the
National Football League at 32. McDaniels, who becomes the third-youngest coach
in NFL history, agreed to a four-year contract to replace Mike Shanahan, who was
fired on December 30 after 14 seasons with the Broncos. McDaniels assembled New
England's record-shattering attack a season ago, with the Patriots scoring a
record 589 points in a perfect 16-0 regular season.

Ferrari's finest

MOTORSPORT: Ferrari unveiled its 2009 Formula One race car on Monday, getting a
jump on rivals in the hope of reclaiming the driver's title Felipe Massa lost to
Lewis Hamilton in the final race of last season. The car -- named the F60 for
Ferrari's 60th year in F1 -- was tested for the first time on Monday by Massa on
the Mugello track. Usually the team debuts its new cars in Fiorano, but snow
forced a move south this year.

                               The New York Times

                 March 12, 1991, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Prosecutor Calls Flake a Tax Cheat

BYLINE: By ARNOLD H. LUBASCH

SECTION: Section B; Page 3; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 559 words


Representative Floyd H. Flake and his wife, Margarett, were portrayed by a
prosecutor yesterday as tax cheats who abused their position of trust.

"Ladies and gentleman, this case is about tax evasion and fraud," the
prosecutor, Andrew M. Luger, said in his opening statement at the trial of Mr.
and Mrs. Flake in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

But defense lawyers told the jury that the defendants were a dedicated,
hard-working couple who accomplished much for their Queens community, where Mr.
Flake is pastor of the 6,100-member Allen A.M.E. Church.

As the trial began, the large wood-paneled courtroom was crowded with 100
spectators, many of them supporters of Mr. Flake who arrived at the courthouse
in a special bus. Some supporters have assailed the charges as part of a pattern
of singling out prominent black officials for prosecution.

Ministerial Expense Fund

Mr. Flake and his wife are charged with embezzling $75,000 from a
church-sponsored housing project, obtaining $66,000 from the church for personal
expenses and evading income taxes on the money.

The prosecutor said that Mr. and Mrs. Flake diverted the money to a bank
account, called the ministerial expense fund, which was supposedly for the
church but which Mr. Luger called a sham.

"The ministerial expense fund was nothing less than the defendants' personal
bank account," the prosecutor said. He said they used it to pay for personal
expenses, including clothes, furs and jewelry.

A major part of the scheme, he contended, involved overbilling and diverting
payments for providing transportation services for residents of a
church-sponsored housing project called the Allen Senior Citizens Apartments.

Varied Community Services

A defense lawyer, Gustave H. Newman, declared in his opening statement that Mr.
Flake worked "seven days a week, 17 hours a day" performing services for the
church and the community.

"It is my honor, it is my privilege, to represent the Rev. Floyd Flake in these
proceedings," Mr. Newman said, placing a hand on Mr. Flake's shoulder at the
defense table.

Mr. Flake carried out church projects to build housing, establish a health
center, open a church school and provide other community services, Mr. Newman
told the jury.

All the money for the projects was handled openly and honestly, Mr. Newman
continued. If there were any errors, he said, they were innocent mistakes, not
intentional crimes.

'This Is a Strange Case'

The lawyer for Mrs. Flake, Theodore V. Wells Jr., described her as "an innocent
person with no involvement in most of the facts in the case."

"This is a strange case, this is a strange prosecution," Mr. Wells told the
jury. He said Mrs. Flake was on trial "only because she is the Reverend Flake's
wife."

The case against Mr. Flake is weak, the lawyer said. By charging Mrs. Flake, he
said, the prosecution was "trying to shore up that weak case."

Judge Eugene H. Nickerson explained that the case involved conspiracy,
embezzlement and tax-evasion charges.

If convicted, the defendants could each face prison sentences of up to 5 years
for conspiracy, 10 years for embezzlement and 5 years for each of several
tax-evasion counts.

Representative Flake was elected to Congress as a Democrat from the Sixth
District in Queens in 1986 and has served since 1976 as church pastor.

                                US Official News

                             June 23, 2016 Thursday

San Jose Resident Pleads Guilty To Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 419  words

DATELINE: New York



 Office for the United States Attorneys, Northern District of California has
issued the following news release:



  Walter Rhodes pleaded guilty today to tax evasion, announced United States
Attorney Brian J. Stretch and Internal Revenue Service, Criminal Investigation,
Special Agent in Charge Michael T. Batdorf.





 According to the plea agreement, Rhodes, 64, of San Jose, admitted he attempted
to evade the payment of more than $300,000 that he owed in federal income tax
liabilities for the years 2002 through 2007.  Rhodes admitted that between 2006
and 2011, he received numerous notices from the IRS explaining that he owed
income taxes for the years 2002 through 2007.  In 2009, the IRS levied his bank
account. Subsequently, Rhodes opened a bank account using the name and social
security number of another person.  Rhodes also used that other person's name
and social security number to obtain employment as the vice president of an
energy company.  In an effort to further evade payment of his employment taxes,
Rhodes arranged for the salary he received from his employment to be deposited
into the account he opened in the other person's name. As of September 24, 2013,
Rhodes owed $514,476 in taxes and interest for 2002 through 2007.



 Rhodes was indicted on July 25, 2015.  He was charged with one count each of
tax evasion, in violation of 26 U.S.C. § 7201; obstructing administration of
Internal Revenue Laws, in violation of 26 U.S.C. § 7212(a); social security
fraud, in violation of 42 U.S.C. § 408(a)(7); and aggravated identity theft, in
violation of 18 U.S.C. § 1028A.  Pursuant to today's agreement, Rhodes pleaded
guilty to tax evasion. The remaining charges will be dismissed.



 The maximum penalty for a violation of 26 U.S.C. § 7201 is five years in prison
and a fine of $250,000.  Additional monetary assessments and supervised release
may be imposed; however, any sentence following this conviction will be imposed
by the court only after consideration of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines and the
federal statute governing the imposition of a sentence, 18 U.S.C. § 3553.
Rhodes' sentencing is scheduled for October, 11, 2016, before the Honorable Beth
Labson Freemen, U.S. District Judge.



 Assistant U.S. Attorney Jos&eacute; A. Olivera is prosecuting the case.  The
prosecution is the result of an investigation by the Internal Revenue Service,
Criminal Investigation.

                            March 17, 2016 Thursday

Con Ed Contractor Pleads Guilty To Bribery And Tax Evasion Charges

LENGTH: 442  words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Office for the United States Attorneys,Eastern District of New York has issued
the following news release:



  Earlier today in federal court in Brooklyn, Rodolfo Quiambao, the President
and Chief Executive Officer of the engineering and design firm Rudell &
Associates, Inc. (Rudell), pleaded guilty to two counts of federal programs
bribery in connection with his scheme to pay bribes and kickbacks to supervisors
at Consolidated Edison of New York (Con Ed) in exchange for receiving lucrative
contracts and other benefits from the public utility services provider.
Quiambao also pleaded guilty to two counts of tax evasion.  As part of his plea
agreement, Quiambao agreed to pay a total of over $5 million in forfeiture and
restitution.  When sentenced, he faces up to 30 years in prison.  Today's plea
proceeding took place before United States District Judge Allyne R. Ross.





 The plea was announced by Robert L. Capers, United States Attorney for the
Eastern District of New York; Angel M. Melendez, Special Agent-in-Charge, U.S.
Immigration and Custom Enforcement (ICE), Homeland Security Investigations
(HSI), in New York; Shantelle P. Kitchen, Special Agent-in-Charge, Internal
Revenue Service, Criminal Investigation (IRS-CI), New York; and Michael Nestor,
Inspector General, The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Office of the
Inspector General.



 According to court filings and facts presented during the plea proceeding,
starting in approximately 2000, Quiambao, whose company specializes in
electrical design, surreptitiously and regularly gave Con Ed supervisors
hundreds of thousands of dollars in cash and checks in exchange for securing
work, including lucrative "sole source" contracts, for his company.  The
defendant also engaged in tax evasion by first concealing and then deducting the
bribe payments he paid to the Con Ed supervisors as business deductions on his
companies' tax returns.



 Quiambao's guilty plea is the latest conviction in the government's
investigation of bribery and kickback schemes involving employees and
contractors of Con Ed.  Since 2008, thirteen Con Ed supervisors and employees
and three Con Ed contractors have been convicted.



 In announcing the guilty plea, U.S. Attorney Capers extending his grateful
appreciation to the participating law enforcement agencies.



 The government's case is being prosecuted by the Office's Public Integrity
Section.  Assistant United States Attorneys Lan Nguyen, Tali Farhadian, and
Claire S. Kedeshian are in charge of the prosecution.

                                   USA TODAY

                            February 21, 2011 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Simplifying federal tax code will help reduce fraud

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 459 words


USA TODAY's article "Inmates stole $39 million from the IRS in 2009" serves to
highlight that  the wealthy are not the only ones trying to get extra money
back, avoid taxes or  pay less than their obligation  under the current federal
tax system.  Income tax evasion and fraud cut across all income tax brackets
(News, Cover story, Wednesday).

A complex system of exemptions, deductions and credits creates a mentality that
others aren't paying their fair share, so why should I? It creates a false
perception  of tax evasion and fraud as victimless crimes. But the victims are
the countless taxpayers  who pay and file their taxes in a timely, accurate
manner. They are subsidizing all the tax cheats.

It is time to simplify the tax code and stop using it to advance political
agendas or to accomplish social engineering.

Every year, I pay my Pennsylvania income tax, and I am reminded how simple and
fair it is. Take your income and multiply it by the current tax rate, a flat
3.07%, and arrive at your tax obligation.  Simple. There are very few
adjustments, credits or exemptions. The system is fair. Low-income
Pennsylvanians have their tax obligations forgiven.  For Pennsylvania retirees,
Social Security and pension income do not count as taxable income.

By using the Pennsylvania income tax system, much of the fraud and abuse that
occur with the current federal income tax system could be eliminated

Mark J. Shulkosky

St. Marys, Pa.

Scams hurt honest taxpayers

USA TODAY's cover story on  inmates and tax fraud just added to my distress.  So
much fraud exists in Social Security and Medicare, too.

I would like to see much more money added to the budget and slated for searching
for and  eliminating fraud in all government programs.  Many people depend on
Social Security and Medicare payments.  The benefits should not be cut for those
who have contributed to and deserve  them. Fraud in IRS filings, and in
entitlement programs, hurts everyone.

Peggy Ward Rawheiser

Wilmington, Del.

Who is minding the store?

Your article on inmates stealing money from the IRS through the use of
fraudulent tax refund requests was interesting, but it failed completely to
identify and answer three key questions:

*Why did Iowa, with  8,485 prisoners, have  $0 of fraudulent tax refunds issued?

*Why did Georgia, with about half the number of  prisoners as Florida, rank
second?

*Why did the Federal Bureau of Prisons rank near the top of the list, regardless
of the number of inmates they have?

Who  is watching the store? Shouldn't it be fairly easy to tell if someone is in
prison? And, if someone is, then shouldn't that be a clue  for the IRS to check
the paperwork carefully? Maybe the IRS should turn over  its  duties to Iowa!

Frank L. Bracy Jr.

Three Rivers, Mich.

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

Contra Costa Times Oct. 27 Letters from our readers

BYLINE: Letters From Our Readers Contra Costa Times

SECTION: LETTERS; Opinion

LENGTH: 689 words


Medicare for all

If we didn't know before, it should be apparent now: Health insurance companies
are not our friends.

They are, in fact, little different from the tobacco companies, who, after years
of telling us lies, were exposed as purveyors of death who cared only about
profits.

The tobacco companies are devious and evil. The same can now be said about
health insurance corporations. They don't care about us; they only care about
their profits.

Some 44,000 members of our communities die yearly because they don't have
insurance. And for many of those who do have insurance, it's inadequate. That's
44,000 yearly, 122 daily and five people hourly. It needs to stop   now!

If terrorists were running loose in our communities, killing five people every
hour, we'd be in the streets demanding an end to their wicked, deadly ways.

Make no mistake about it, we are losing friends and family members to the profit
motive. The only answer to the problem is universal health care.

The best way to accomplish that is to open and extend Medicare to all   everyone
in, nobody out. Let the vile, self-serving health insurance companies pass out
of existence, and the sooner the better.

George Russell

San Pablo

Tax evasion?

The Times reports that a fellow from Livermore will be serving a five-month
sentence and paying restitution for tax evasion? This is very disconcerting; I
didn't think tax evasion was a punishable crime. If it is, wouldn't we be shy a
Cabinet member and at least four congressmen?

Seriously, we either turn the fellow from Livermore loose and apologize, or
immediately arrest Tim Geithner, Charlie Rangel, Tom Daschle, Pete Stark and
Robert Wexler. Like Geithner, Daschle and Rangel, I plan on under reporting my
income; like Stark and Wexler I'll be using Maryland or Florida as my state of
residence.

If the IRS questions my veracity, I will simply cut and paste the apparently
effective explanations given by our esteemed leaders.

David Fore

San Ramon

Risible boondoggle

The Times reported on Sept. 29 that several regional theaters in the Bay Area
have grave financial difficulties. Should Livermore persist in its plans to
build a 2,000-seat theater for the Livermore Valley Performing Arts Center? That
project was merely foolhardy back in the days of the housing bubble boom, but is
now risible as California sinks into the mire of recession. It's a small wonder
then that the boosters of that boondoggle are not as overtly promoting it as
they once did.

Henry D. Shay

Livermore

Deficit debacle

This year, according to the White House Office of Management and Budget, 40
percent of your federal income taxes will go to pay interest on the national
debt, not provide services, but just to pay interest on the national debt.

Think of it as paying the "minimum payment" on your credit cards, and the
deficit continues to grow.

The Congressional Budget Office estimated in August that it will be $1.4
trillion this year, $9 trillion over the next 10 years (an optimistic view).

Most economists believe that other than devaluing the dollar and drastically
increasing taxes and inflation, there will be no way to pay down this bill.

Yet the Obama administration just keeps spending and adding expensive new
entitlements that will only grow the deficit. "Hope and change," it's not.

Hal Bray

Brentwood

Tunnel vision

We're about to go through another Caltrans project that will only do half the
job it should. One often wonders how someone gets a job in engineering there
considering some terrible traffic routes in the Bay Area.

For those of us who travel east during commute hour through the Caldecott Tunnel
in the afternoon, you have to experience a huge backup even though there are two
tunnels open.

This traffic problem will continue even if a new tunnel is constructed. The
extra tunnel will only help those driving westbound, which is good but again the
eastbound will continue after millions of dollars are spent on this new tunnel.

Caltrans needs to engineer a better way so the afternoon eastbound traffic can
flow better to keep the traffic going. Also, I hope they finally clean the dirty
walls of all tunnels.

George L. Ramas

Walnut Creek

                               The New York Times

                            August 22, 2002 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Judge Casts Doubt on the Manhattan Prosecutor's Right to a Bronx Tax Case

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SAULNY

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 846 words


District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan might be facing a rare
setback on a matter of jurisdiction. As early as next week, a state judge could
deny his request to prosecute a car dealer based in the Bronx on charges of tax
evasion.

"The evidence submitted to the grand jury is sufficient to support all the
substantive counts in this indictment," the judge, Justice William Wetzel of
State Supreme Court in Manhattan, wrote in a pending decision distributed to
lawyers in the case last week. "The lack of jurisdiction is the sole,
insurmountable impediment to prosecution of the case in New York County."

The judge's decision raises a question that many have asked quietly: Why was the
Manhattan district attorney trying to prosecute a case from another county? For
years, Mr. Morgenthau has used what some consider slim connections to Manhattan
to reach beyond its boundaries and bring defendants back to its courts. Once, he
even won the conviction of three Venezuelan bankers on charges that they
defrauded depositors in South America.

Sometimes other prosecutors have objected, but the district attorneys in New
York City often bow to the greater expertise and resources of Mr. Morgenthau's
office. In the tax evasion case, for example, the Bronx district attorney,
Robert T. Johnson, has been working with him, and stands ready to pursue it if
there is a jurisdictional problem, said Steven Reed, a spokesman for Mr.
Johnson.

The judge's pending decision, reported yesterday in The Daily News and The New
York Post, involves the indictment of Richard G. Gidron, a Bronx car dealer
charged with evading more than $1 million in state taxes. At some point, court
papers said, there was an electronic transfer of funds to accounts situated and
administered in Manhattan, which Mr. Morgenthau's office argued gave him
jurisdiction. But in the judge's view, those are "details of inconsequential
significance."

The possible dismissal of the case at a hearing on Monday could have
implications for another high-profile case in which Mr. Morgenthau has been
accused of overstepping boundaries: his indictment of State Senator Guy J.
Velella, also of the Bronx, on charges that he used his influence to help obtain
financing for public works projects. Among the Manhattan connections cited in
the indictment were the involvement of the Triboro Bridge and Tunnel Authority,
a state agency based in Manhattan, and a meeting at Smith & Wollensky, the
Manhattan steak house.

Justice Wetzel's decision has generated a great deal of buzz around the city's
courts. It is a quiet buzz, as lawyers are fearful of angering Mr. Morgenthau.
"To be quite candid," one lawyer said, "it does seem that the district attorney
of a particular county has assumed the jurisdiction of everything that comes to
his knowledge."

Even before Mr. Morgenthau was elected in 1975, the office of the Manhattan
district attorney enjoyed an almost mythically large reputation, in part because
of its sheer size but also because of the array of corporate, political and
mob-related cases it handled. The office has been lionized in books, movies and
on television, including the long-running NBC series "Law and Order."

Mr. Morgenthau, 82, is seen by many as the unquestioned super district attorney,
known for his creative thinking. "On the one hand, he's the Manhattan district
attorney, but on the other hand, he's America's district attorney," said Michael
Dowd, a criminal defense lawyer in Manhattan. "He's certainly one of a kind.
He's got to be. He aptly and uniquely fits Manhattan, whose impact goes far
beyond the county."

Not everyone is a fan. David L. Lewis, a Manhattan lawyer in private practice
who is the former president of the New York State Association of Criminal
Defense Lawyers, openly praised Justice Wetzel's questioning of jurisdictional
limits. "Frankly, it should be done more often," he said. "We rely on the
discretion of the D.A. not to overstep the boundaries. This office has problems
with overstepping the boundaries."

In the past, Mr. Morgenthau and his supporters have responded to such criticism
by saying that they are simply responding to modern white-collar crime. In an
age of globalization, they say, when computers can move money and information in
an instant, prosecutors who are inhibited by local or national borders risk
being outrun by criminals.

For instance, in the 1997 case won against the Venezuelan bankers, business was
never conducted in New York. But Manhattan prosecutors persuaded a state judge
that they had the power to bring the case here because many of the transactions
involved checks drawn on banks in New York or electronic transfers of funds that
passed through banks in New York.

But critics like Mr. Lewis do not accept this line of thought. "The fact of the
matter is that you could make an argument that everything touches Manhattan," he
said. He added that there are constitutional reasons for limits on jurisdiction:
"The jury composition, control of a courthouse and a judge's deference to D.A.'s
are different across counties."

                              The American Banker

Butz Still Hitting Speaking Circuit

                             June 2, 1981, Tuesday

Midwestern Bureau

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Despite his conviction earlier this month for tax evasion, Earl L. Butz, former
secretary of agriculture, continues on the speaking circuit at banking
conventions.

The Illinois Bankers Association said this week the former agriculture secretary
will deliver a previously scheduled talk at its 90th annual convention June 16
at the Chicago Marriott Hotel.

Mr. Butz, who served in the Cabinet post under Presidents Ford and Nixon until
resigning in 1976, pleaded guilty May 22 to a charge of Federal tax evasion for
failing to pay $74,000 in 1978 income taxes.

The case was brought in a Federal court in Fort Wayne, Ind., with the 71-year
old Mr. Butz awaiting sentencing.

A spokesman for the Illinois BA said Mr. Butz had "offered to withdraw" as a
speaker at the convention but the offer was turned down.

"The guy still has something to offer. He still has a right to his reputation,"
said the spokesman.

News reports on the tax evasion court case came as Mr. Butz was speaking to the
annual convention of thc North Dakota Bankers Assocation meeting May 18-19 in
Fargo.

                          The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 11, 2014 Tuesday

Lebanon woman pleads guilty to tax evasion charge

BYLINE: The Lebanon Democrat, Tenn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 252 words


March 11--A Lebanon woman and president of City Limits Café in Lebanon pleaded
guilty Monday to sales tax evasion in Wilson County circuit court.

Judge David Durham accepted N. Rosie Cannon's guilty plea per an order of
deferment to one count of sales tax evasion. That means final judgment will be
held open for two years pending Cannon's successful completion of Durham's
orders. Cannon, 72, was ordered to pay $10,000 in restitution to the state. She
was placed on two years of supervised probation.

"The Department of Revenue is committed to applying Tennessee's tax laws and
policies uniformly to all taxpayers to ensure a level playing field," Revenue
Commissioner Richard Roberts said. "The department cannot and will not allow
people engaged in fraudulent tax activities to have a competitive advantage over
honest business people."

Roberts expressed his appreciation for the help of District Attorney General
Tommy Thompson's office in prosecuting Cannon's case.

The Department of Revenue is responsible for the administration of state tax
laws and motor vehicle title and registration laws and the collection of taxes
and fees associated with those laws. The Department collects about 87 percent of
total state revenue. During the 2013 fiscal year, it collected $11.7 billion in
state taxes and fees and more than $2.2 billion in taxes and fees for local
governments.

                            October 10, 2010 Sunday

EDITORIAL: What's next, an avenue for Tony Sopran?

BYLINE: The Daily Progress, Charlottesville, Va.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 243 words


Oct. 10--Leave it to New Jersey.

There, an Atlantic City councilor is hoping to get a stretch of street named for
a Prohibition crime boss.

Enoch "Nucky" Johnson had Atlantic City under his thumb during the speakeasy
era, when corruption kept the liquor flowing. He's currently the subject of an
HBO series, "Boardwalk Empire."

Councilor Dennis Mason thinks he's worthy of having a section of street named
after him. He plans to introduce a motion to take a one-block portion of Belmont
Avenue and rename it Nucky's Way.

Nucky sure had his way 80 years ago. But his history doesn't phase the
councilor.

"It was just tax evasion" Nucky was convicted of. "He didn't actually murder
anyone," Mr. Mason told the Press of Atlantic City.

Maybe Mr. Mason's forgotten that tax evasion was usually the only charge that
federal authorities could make stick, even though they knew that worse crimes --
including murder -- occurred under the mob bosses.

Nucky Johnson, criminal. Now, there's a role model for you.
