                               The New York Times

             December 14, 1983, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

COMPUTERS CATCH NEW YORK CITY TAX EVADERS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL GOODWIN

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 857 words


New York City officials, alarmed for years by the widespread evasion of city
business and income taxes, are collecting millions of dollars through a
computerized program aimed at thousands of residents and businesses that have
avoided payment.

More than 55,000 individuals and companies have paid more than $43 million in
delinquent taxes and penalties since the program was established two and a half
years ago, according to Philip R. Michael, the city's Finance Commissioner.

The largest number of taxpayers and the largest dollar amounts collected
involved payments of the commercial rent tax, which is a levy of up to 6 percent
on the office rents that companies pay.

''It started out on speculation,'' Mr. Michael said of the program. ''We
suspected there were a lot of people not paying, and we thought this could be a
profitable program. But this has exceeded our expectations.''

He said his department planned to expand the program - called TACS, for Taxpayer
Automated Compliance System - to the tax records of doctors, lawyers,
accountants, contractors and consultants.

Preliminary comparisons of payments made by city agencies to accountants and
consultants, he said, found that many of the professionals reported less total
income than they earned alone from the city agencies.

''We have run the names of accountants who have received contracts from the
Human Resources Administration for doing audits,'' Mr. Michael said. ''Some may
get $20,000 or $30,000 for the job. We, in turn, have looked at their business
income tax return and we don't even see income of that amount reported.''

Similar checks will be directed at doctors suspected of not reporting as much as
several hundred thousand dollars of income received from Medicaid, Mr. Michael
said. Others he believes are avoiding taxes are contractors doing busines with
the city and lawyers who receive large fees from negligence cases against the
city.



Tax Evasion a Longstanding Problem

The problem of tax evasion has been a traditional thorn in the side of municipal
government, with Mr. Michael's agency estimating two years ago that as much as
$600 million was going uncollected each year. While that amount is only about 5
percent of the $10 billion that is collected by the city from all taxes,
officials have long sought ways of adding at least some of it to the city
treasury.

Although aides to Mayor Koch are calling the results impressive, they concede
that the effect is marginal in a budget of nearly $17 billion. Indeed, most of
the results were anticipated in the budget under the heading of management and
productivity improvements.

''We don't mean to say that the program is a budget savior,'' said Deputy Mayor
Nathan Leventhal. ''Nevertheless, the results are real and they mean that we
will be getting more taxes on an annual basis.'' He added that the program was
''long overdue.''

Mr. Michael estimated that the city would be collecting up to $20 million each
year from the 55,000 taxpayers the program has put back on the rolls.

He said the cost to the city was minimal - as low as 5 cents for each dollar
collected - because the program was fully computerized and did not rely on
time-consuming and expensive field audits. The cost to the city, apart from the
computers, he said, was limited to salaries for the 70 people hired for the
program, and mailing costs. About 640,000 people and companies have received
questionnaires asking for tax information.

The program is based on the notion that individuals and companies are paying one
or more city taxes but not others. For example, computers match lists of
companies paying sales taxes with lists of companies paying commercial rent
taxes. A company that shows up on one list but not the other is then sent a
questionnaire. Companies not paying any taxes have a better chance of getting
away with it, he conceded.

A Check for $500,000

In many cases, Mr. Michael said, replies to the questionnaires have included
checks for the delinquent taxes, with one company sending a check for $500,000.
Mr. Michael said tax laws prohibited him from identifying any individuals or
companies involved.

According to the Finance Department, computer matches have produced these
results:


- The lists of filers of corporation and unincorporated business taxes were
matched against the commercial rent tax list to determine which companies had
not paid the rent tax. The result has been 13,000 taxpayers paying $18.4
million.


- A reversal of that match turned up 1,800 businesses that had paid the rent tax
but not the business taxes. They have since paid $5.1 million.


- Companies that had paid the rent tax in the past but not in subsequent years
were sent questionnaires. The result has been the payment of $4.7 million by
9,000 taxpayers.


- Questionnaires were also sent to 330,000 taxpayers who filed business tax
returns in 1976 but not in subsequent years. Payment of $11.2 million by 30,000
taxpayers has resulted.

Based on the results, Mr. Michael estimates that about one person or company out
of every 10 queried will owe the city money.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       TELEGRAM & GAZETTE (Massachusetts)

                             April 6, 2010 Tuesday
                                  ALL EDITIONS

Ex-employees say lawyer printed out firm's payroll;
Responsibility for payment is an issue in Uhl tax case

BYLINE: Aaron Nicodemus, Telegram & Gazette Staff

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 600 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER


Two former employees of Worcester lawyer Christopher M. Uhl testified in U.S.
District Court yesterday that they saw him print out the payroll for his law
firm, undercutting his defense in his tax evasion trial that his college-age son
was in charge of payroll.

Former employees Madelyn Bedard of Ashburnham and Christina P. Florence of
Palmer each testified that they witnessed Mr. Uhl entering data into the
computer and printing out the weekly payroll checks. They testified they never
saw Steven Uhl, Mr. Uhl's son, have anything to do with payroll. On
cross-examination by defense lawyers Christopher LoConto and John M. Goggins,
both witnesses testified that they thought Steven Uhl might have helped install
the computer software used to print out the payroll checks.

Mr. Uhl is charged with five counts of tax evasion. If convicted, he faces up to
5 years in prison on each count, and up to 3 years' probation. In his opening
statement, Mr. LoConto said that Mr. Uhl has admitted he did not pay more than
$230,000 worth of payroll and other taxes to the federal government over six
years, and that he owes the money. During that time, Mr. Uhl withheld money from
his employees' paychecks but did not turn it over to the Internal Revenue
Service.

Mr. LoConto argued that his client thought his son was paying the taxes and
filing the correct paperwork. He argued that Mr. Uhl made a mistake, but did not
commit a crime, when he did not pay taxes on his employees' pay from 2000 to
2005. He paid his taxes in 1998 and resumed paying his taxes in 2006, Mr.
LoConto said.

According to U.S. Attorney David Hennessy, Mr. Uhl paid his taxes for the first
quarter of 1999 but not the rest of the year; however, he is not charged with
tax evasion for that year.

Mr. Uhl was charged with tax evasion in September 2008, and a federal grand jury
delivered a superseding indictment in January.

In previous testimony, IRS agent Joy Chambers said that the IRS had launched an
investigation against Steven Uhl for allegedly making false statements to
investigators and aiding tax fraud. Steven Uhl has not been charged in
connection with his father's case.

Ms. Chambers said Steven Uhl told her that while he was a student at
Northeastern University, and while holding down other jobs, he rode the commuter
train from Boston to Worcester every Thursday to print out the payroll for his
father's law office. He told investigators he took the 5:40 p.m. train, and then
returned to Boston later that night. He said he did this every Thursday for six
years.

Prosecutors found an MBTA train schedule from that time period that showed no
trains to Worcester left Boston after 3 p.m. until the next day. They also
showed that the checks were printed on every day of the week, not just
Thursdays.

During Ms. Chambers' testimony, Mr. LoConto and Mr. Goggins asked why she chose
to interview Steven Uhl in a Boston bar, located close to the IRS' Boston
office. Steven Uhl was apparently allowed to drink alcohol during the interview.
Ms. Chambers said she would have preferred to interview him in her office, "but
given the choice between interviewing a witness in a bar, and not interviewing
him at all, I'll conduct the interview in a bar."

Mr. Uhl's trial on tax evasion charges is expected to wrap up today, with two
more witnesses called by U.S. attorneys Hennessy and Karin M. Bell. The defense
does not plan to call any witnesses, Mr. LoConto told Judge F. Dennis Saylor IV.

Judge Saylor told the jury yesterday that they can expect to begin deliberations
tomorrow.

                                The New York Sun

                             April 1, 2008 Tuesday

Cigarette Tax Hike: 'Gold Mine' for Smugglers

BYLINE: BENJAMIN SARLIN -, Special to the Sun

SECTION: NEW YORK; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 681 words


The proposed tax hike on cigarettes in the state budget would create a "black
market gold mine" for smugglers and force New York smokers to pay the highest
taxes in the nation, experts warn.

Facing a $5 billion budget gap, state lawmakers see doubling the state's
cigarette tax, to $3 a pack, as a way to help weather a difficult economic
period. The $3 tax would be the highest of any state in America, $0.42 higher
than New Jersey, which currently holds the record, and $2.93 higher than South
Carolina's lowest-in-the-nation $0.07 tax. Smokers in New York City, which adds
a $1.50 surcharge on cigarettes, would pay $4.50 a pack in taxes.

The tax hike, the first in six years, is expected to earn the state between $200
million and $300 million. A pack of premium cigarettes in New York City now
costs $7 or $8; prices would rise to above $9. Opponents of the tax increase
argue that higher prices would drive smokers to seek ways to evade the law and
purchase cheaper cigarettes from smugglers or in neighboring states, blunting
potential revenue gains for the state. "It's a black market gold mine," a senior
fellow at the Manhattan Institute, E.J. McMahon, said of the proposed tax. "You
have to invest resources in scores of attorneys, cops, and auditors, who are all
part of the tax enforcement you need."

"By raising cigarette taxes you help fund the mob," the president of Americans
for Tax Reform, Grover Norquist, said. "Cigarettes are easier than liquor, as
they're lighter and smaller per container. It leads to smuggling and smuggling
is done best by organized crime."

Mr. Norquist said New York's proximity to states with lower taxes would lead
smokers to cross the border to buy cigarettes, reducing tax revenue below state
projections.

New York has seen significant increases in its cigarette tax rates before. In
2002, New York City's cigarette tax increased to $1.50 from $0.08, as part of an
initiative by Mayor Bloomberg to encourage smokers to give up the habit.
Although the taxes produced an increase in city and state revenue, some smokers
took illegal measures to avoid paying the new tax, costing taxpayers tens of
millions of dollars.

A 2007 report by the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan city agency that
analyzes the city's finances, found that 27% of city smokers and 34% of upstate
smokers sometimes bought "under-taxed" cigarettes in 2006. These smokers avoided
the tax by buying cigarettes from other states, ordering cigarettes over the
Internet, and purchasing cigarettes at Indian reservations. The city lost an
estimated $40 million in tax revenue as a result of cigarette tax evasion in
2006, according to the report.

"It encourages people not to be ripped off," the founder of Citizens Lobbying
Against Smoker Harassment, Audrey Silk, said of cigarette taxes. "Any consumer
who's so abused will look for ways to avoid it, making outlaws out of normally
law-abiding citizens."

Supporters of the cigarette tax note that despite lost revenue to smuggling and
other tax evasion methods, net tax revenue has increased in every state that has
raised prices, though not always as much as predicted. In the city's case, tax
revenue from cigarettes rose to $160 million from $30 million between 2002 and
2003, even after taking into account an agreement with the state that sent 46%
of the city's cigarette tax revenue to Albany.

"Despite any smuggling or tax evasion going on, the state or local governments
still make a big chunk of money from increasing their tax rates on cigarettes,"
the director for policy research at Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, Eric
Lindblom, said. "That's not to say there isn't any smuggling or tax evasion.
There is."

Mr. Lindblom said certain methods reduce tax evasion. Governor Spitzer, for
example, reached agreements with wholesalers, credit card companies, and postal
services during his tenure as attorney general to restrict sales to illegal
online cigarette retailers. Sales at Indian reservations pose a greater problem
in New York State, Mr. Lindblom added, but can be addressed by better
legislation and enforcement.

                                The Irish Times

                                 July 31, 2004

Tax advisers and tax evasion

SECTION: CITY EDITION; EDITORIAL PAGE; LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Pg. 13

LENGTH: 276 words


Madam, - As reported in The Irish Times of July 23rd, Mr Frank Daly, Chairman of
the Revenue Commissioners, indicated in his discussions with the Dail Public
Accounts Committee that Revenue "would love" to take an aiding and abetting
charge against those who facilitated tax evasion. He also said that Revenue
would be seeking new powers to this effect in the next Finance Bill.

In light of Mr Daly's comments, we wish to state clearly that any suggestion
that there is a tax evasion industry in which tax advisers are systematically
assisting people to evade their taxes, is misguided. More than any other
professional grouping, tax advisers have fostered an environment of tax
compliance and promoted informed public opinion in regard to the civic duty of
all citizens to pay their fair share of taxes.

No other profession has its work scrutinised more closely by an arm of the State
than the tax profession. Practitioners go to great lengths to ensure their
clients are in full compliance with the law. The success of the recent Revenue
investigation campaigns has been achieved because of the support and
co-operation given by tax advisers, both to their clients and to Revenue.

With regard to the specific charge of aiding and abetting tax evasion, it should
be noted that Revenue already has very significant powers of investigation and
prosecution. Should it wish to prosecute such cases, it faces the same obstacles
that all regulatory bodies face in conducting similar actions. There can be no
justification for any special rules. - Yours, etc.,

Frank Hussey, President, Irish Taxation Institute, Sandymount Avenue, Dublin 4.

                                The Irish Times

                               September 27, 2003

Hidden worlds: a short history of tax evasion

SECTION: CITY EDITION; WEEKEND; Pg. 50

LENGTH: 509 words


Ansbacher

Clients: Only high rollers were invited into the Rolls-Royce of tax evasion.

What we know: The ultimate offshore scheme, which operated from the early 1970s
until discovered, in 1997, allowing clients to hide money offshore while
retaining the convenience of withdrawing it at home. The late Des Traynor used
it to hide Charles Haughey's money; the creme de la creme of business at the
time were also members of the Cayman tax evaders' club.

Where's the money?: The Revenue is investigating 289 cases. It has settled 51 of
these and collected 125.6 million.

National Irish Bank Clients: Those with a few bob to invest, including many
business people, professionals and farmers.

What we know: During the late 1980s and early 1990s NIB marketed an unauthorised
scheme, selling Clerical Medical International life-assurance schemes to more
than 400 investors. Many were used to evade tax. Three investors have been
prosecuted; two received suspended jail sentences. A report by two High Court
inspectors - former Supreme Court judge John Blayney and accountant Tom Grace -
is expected to be finalised by the end of the this year. The High Court has been
told that some people against whom adverse findings may be made have not
co-operated fully with the inspectors.

Where's the money?: The Revenue has investigated 452 cases, of which it has
settled 379, with 142.3 million collected and a further 14.9 million paid on
account. An additional 11.2 million has been collected in capital-gains tax
related to compensation payments made by NIB to some account holders.

Bogus non-resident accounts

Clients: Anyone and everyone with an "uncle" in Boston, an "aunt" in Birmingham
or a "brother" in Brisbane. As many as 80,000 names on some 40,000 accounts.

What we know: The way the ordinary Joe and Josephine used to hide money from the
Revenue. Go to the local bank and open an account in the name of an overseas
relative. For years banks turned a blind eye or sometimes actively encouraged
it, as highlighted by the Public Accounts Committee inquiry chaired by the late
Jim Mitchell. The banks paid 1220 million to the Revenue to settle their DIRT
liabilities.

Where's the money? The Revenue has collected 1670 million including the money
from the banks, a further 1227 million from a voluntary-disclosure scheme and
1223 million from subsequent investigations.

And there's more . . .

Slowly but surely the extent of past tax evasion is coming to light. The
Revenue's latest target is offshore trusts, used by many people to evade - or
avoid - tax. In some cases there is clear tax evasion - customers of Bank of
Ireland in Jersey recently paid 18 million after an investigation was launched -
whereas in others taxpayers will argue that the structure they have set up is
within the law. And then, of course, there is the ongoing battle against those
who simply choose not to declare all their earnings to the Revenue. This is
combated through Revenue audits, which last year yielded 1286 million from
16,000 cases.

                              The Washington Post

                   September 1, 1994, Thursday, Final Edition

T.C. Williams Guidance Director Reassigned;
Transferred to Central Administrative Office, He Awaits Sentencing in Tax
Evasion Case

Steve Bates, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: VIRGINIA WEEKLY; PAGE V3

LENGTH: 386 words


James E. McClure, the T.C. Williams High School guidance director who pleaded
guilty to tax evasion in June, is being transferred temporarily to the school
system's central administrative office.

Alexandria school officials said that McClure, 55, will work on projects for
Acting Superintendent Maxine Wood until further notice. The officials indicated
that the change will be in effect at least until Sept. 16, when McClure is
scheduled to be sentenced in U.S. District Court in Alexandria.

Some School Board members and others in the community had said privately that
they hoped McClure would be barred from the high school before the start of
classes on Sept. 8. They said that for McClure to remain in the building would
send the wrong signal to young people, and that to remove him after the start of
classes would be disruptive.

Others have rallied support for McClure, saying that his efforts are needed at
the city's only high school and that his crime has nothing to do with his job or
with children.

Wood made the decision to transfer McClure to the central office, apparently
without any change in pay, effective Tuesday. Sources said the decision was made
in consultation with some School board members.

McClure said he is "going to be very positive, very upbeat" about the temporary
transfer. He said that he and Wood "talked about it, and I feel good about it."
He said on Monday that he had not yet learned exactly what he will be doing at
the central office, which is on Beauregard Street in the city's West End.

McClure said he hopes that he is given probation instead of a jail sentence and
that he will be allowed to return to the high school and resume his duties as
guidance director.

In April, the Springfield resident was indicted on four counts of tax evasion.
The Internal Revenue Service said he failed to report more than $ 125,000 in
income over four years, and that while undergoing an audit, he attempted to
support the deductions with false documents.

McClure pleaded guilty in June to one felony count of tax evasion, and he faces
a maximum sentence of five years in prison and a $ 250,000 fine. Judge Albert V.
Bryan Jr. is expected to determine McClure's sentence Sept. 16, and local and
state education officials will consider any personnel actions against him.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                           September 20, 2016 Tuesday

New York Restaurant Entrepreneur Pleads Guilty to Ten-Year Investment Fraud
Scheme and Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 877  words


Defendant Deceived Investors, Diverted Funds and Dodged Tax Obligations

A Watertown, New York, food and restaurant entrepreneur and franchisor pleaded
guilty today to one count of wire fraud and one count of tax evasion announced
Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo, head of the
Justice Departments Tax Division, and U.S. Attorney Richard Hartunian for the
Northern District of New York.

According to the criminal information and plea agreement filed with the U.S.
District Court in Utica, New York, between 2005 and 2015, Christopher Swartz,
46, engaged in a promissory note scheme to defraud lenders and investors, as
well as a scheme to evade taxes and obstruct the Internal Revenue Service (IRS).

Mr. Swartz used his business enterprises to steal from lenders, investors, and
the United States, hiding behind an elaborate web of entities and financial
transactions, said Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo.  This
case serves as clear notice that no one is above the law, and those individuals
who seek to evade their tax obligations will face prosecution and incarceration,
regardless of the complexity of their schemes or economic status.

The defendants wide-ranging, persistent, and lengthy fraud and tax evasion
schemes cost investors and the IRS millions of dollars, said U.S. Attorney
Hartunian.  My office is pleased to be part of the efforts by the Tax Division
and IRS-Criminal Investigation to hold him accountable for his brazen conduct.

As highly trained and experienced financial investigators, IRS special agents
are particularly adept at tracing the flow of funds and uncovering hidden
assets, said Special Agent in Charge Shantelle P. Kitchen of IRS Criminal
Investigation, New York Field Office.  Mr. Swartzs conviction serves as warning
to anyone who schemes to divert money from a business in order to conceal income
and evade taxes.

Swartz, using his multiple interests in various food and restaurant businesses,
raised money by fraudulently inducing lenders with the promise of repayment at
high interest rates and ownership interests in his companies.  Swartz
misappropriated and diverted funds received and when lenders and investors
sought the return of their funds, Swartz attempted to lull them with false and
fraudulent excuses, assurances, and partial payments, including payments by
checks that he knew would bounce.  Swartz also concealed his assets and income
to avoid seizure and collection by lenders, investors, and judgment creditors,
thereby attempting to prevent recovery of their funds.

As one part of the scheme, in 2009, Swartz used a promissory note and the offer
of an equity interest in the Jreck Subs franchise to induce an investor group
from New York City to provide $1.5 million in funds, including funds for the
construction of new stores and the growth of the chain.  Swartz misappropriated
and diverted a substantial portion of the funds.  Swartz then solicited
additional loans from this same group, fraudulently inducing them with a series
of additional promissory notes, which he failed to honor while misappropriating
funds.  Swartz purported to secure some of the notes with fictitious and forged
rebate agreements.

Swartz admitted that between 2005 and 2015, he also engaged in a 10-year tax
evasion scheme, filing false tax returns that understated his personal income.
Swartz diverted money from business accounts and disguised these diversions in
the company records as, among other things, loans and business expenses.  He
made extensive use of cash to diminish the traceability of funds and concealed
his ownership of various assets using multiple entities and nominees.  Swartz
also falsified partnership tax returns and attempted to impede the IRSs ability
to collect employment taxes.

U.S. District Judge David N. Hurd scheduled sentencing for Jan. 19, 2017.
Swartz faces a statutory maximum sentence of 20 years in prison for his
conviction on the wire fraud count, and five years in prison on the tax evasion
count, as well as a period of supervised release and monetary penalties.  As a
condition of the plea agreement, Swartz agreed to an order of restitution
payable to any individuals and entities determined to be, at the time of
sentencing, victims of his schemes.

The district court entered a preliminary order of forfeiture of assets,
including forfeiture of Swartzs interests in the Jreck Subs franchisor corporate
business, which receives royalty payments from store owners based on a
percentage of store sales.  Under current law, if a final forfeiture order is
entered, criminally forfeited assets may be used as a source of funds to pay
restitution to victims.  According to court documents, the number of victims may
be in excess of 130.

Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo and U.S. Attorney Hartunian
thanked special agents of IRS-Criminal Investigation and the FBI, and an IRS
revenue agent, who conducted the investigation, as well as Assistant Chiefs John
N. Kane, Jr. and Andrew Kameros, and Trial Attorney Abigail Burger Chingos of
the Tax Division, who are prosecuting the case.

Additional information about the Tax Division and its enforcement efforts may be
found on the divisions website. 2016 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

Washington: Former Bellevue Developer Indicted For Tax Evasion And Social
Security Fraud

LENGTH: 428  words

DATELINE: Olympia


United States Attorney's Office for the Western District of Washington has
issued the following press release:

A former Bellevue based developer and lender who spent millions on gambling,
thoroughbred horse racing, private aircraft, country club fees and a Bellevue
penthouse, has been indicted for tax evasion and social security number fraud.
THOMAS R. HAZELRIGG, III, 67, of Rancho Mirage, California, will appear in U.S.
District Court in Seattle today at 1:30 following his indictment for two counts
of evading and defeating payment of tax, and two counts of Social Security
number misuse.

The detailed indictment, returned by the grand jury last week, describes how
HAZELRIGG first agreed to pay $533,454 in taxes owed for tax years 1989, 1990
and 1991 and then failed to pay the tax debt while living a lavish lifestyle
that included private jets, multi-million dollar remodels, expensive artwork and
high roller casino junkets.  The Indictment also alleges that HAZELRIGG evaded
payment of his taxes owed for 1994, for which he had filed a return showing tax
owed, but for which he made no payments.  The indictment alleges that between
1997 and 2007, HAZELRIGG illegally funneled income from his businesses into
accounts that he controlled but that which he kept secret from the IRS and other
creditors. HAZELRIGG used these accounts to pay for the multimillion dollar
purchase and remodel of a Bellevue penthouse, two Chihuly glass chandeliers
worth more than $460,000, more than one million dollars in chips at various
casinos, country club memberships for himself and associates, the leasing of
private jets, the use of a butler, and more than $160,000 on race horses.

The two counts of Social Security number misuse relate to HAZLERIGG opening bank
accounts in 2009, using the Social Security number of his deceased father.
HAZELRIGG allegedly used the number to hide the resources from the IRS.

The tax evasion counts are punishable by up to five years in prison.  The misuse
of Social Security number counts are also punishable by up to five years in
prison.

The charges contained in the indictment are only allegations.  A person is
presumed innocent unless and until he or she is proven guilty beyond a
reasonable doubt in a court of law.

The case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation
(IRS-CI).

The case is being prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorneys Susan Loitz
and Robert Westinghouse.

For more information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/usao/waw

                                US Official News

                             August 6, 2013 Tuesday

Washington: Former Bellevue Developer Indicted For Tax Evasion And Social
Security Fraud

LENGTH: 428  words

DATELINE: Olympia


United States Attorney's Office for the Western District of Washington has
issued the following press release:

A former Bellevue based developer and lender who spent millions on gambling,
thoroughbred horse racing, private aircraft, country club fees and a Bellevue
penthouse, has been indicted for tax evasion and social security number fraud.
THOMAS R. HAZELRIGG, III, 67, of Rancho Mirage, California, will appear in U.S.
District Court in Seattle today at 1:30 following his indictment for two counts
of evading and defeating payment of tax, and two counts of Social Security
number misuse.

The detailed indictment, returned by the grand jury last week, describes how
HAZELRIGG first agreed to pay $533,454 in taxes owed for tax years 1989, 1990
and 1991 and then failed to pay the tax debt while living a lavish lifestyle
that included private jets, multi-million dollar remodels, expensive artwork and
high roller casino junkets.  The Indictment also alleges that HAZELRIGG evaded
payment of his taxes owed for 1994, for which he had filed a return showing tax
owed, but for which he made no payments.  The indictment alleges that between
1997 and 2007, HAZELRIGG illegally funneled income from his businesses into
accounts that he controlled but that which he kept secret from the IRS and other
creditors. HAZELRIGG used these accounts to pay for the multimillion dollar
purchase and remodel of a Bellevue penthouse, two Chihuly glass chandeliers
worth more than $460,000, more than one million dollars in chips at various
casinos, country club memberships for himself and associates, the leasing of
private jets, the use of a butler, and more than $160,000 on race horses.

The two counts of Social Security number misuse relate to HAZLERIGG opening bank
accounts in 2009, using the Social Security number of his deceased father.
HAZELRIGG allegedly used the number to hide the resources from the IRS.

The tax evasion counts are punishable by up to five years in prison.  The misuse
of Social Security number counts are also punishable by up to five years in
prison.

The charges contained in the indictment are only allegations.  A person is
presumed innocent unless and until he or she is proven guilty beyond a
reasonable doubt in a court of law.

The case was investigated by the Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation
(IRS-CI).

The case is being prosecuted by Assistant United States Attorneys Susan Loitz
and Robert Westinghouse.

For more information please visit: http://www.justice.gov/usao/waw

                             The Hollywood Reporter

                          November 14, 2007 Wednesday

news digest

BYLINE: null

LENGTH: 485  words


Allen makes the cut for editors' award

Dede Allen will receive the Motion Picture Editors Guild's Fellowship and
Service Award, created to acknowledge a member who exhibits exemplary skill in
the craft of editing and a set of values that include professionalism,
collaboration, mentorship, generosity of spirit and commitment to the labor
movement. Allen's credits include "Bonnie and Clyde" and "Serpico." The award
will be presented Jan. 5 at the guild's annual board of directors installation
dinner at the Loews in Santa Monica.

VIP duo guilty of tax evasion

COLOGNE, Germany -- Andreas Schmid, former head of German film fund VIP, was
found guilty of multiple counts of tax evasion and sentenced to six years in
prison Tuesday. His business partner, Andreas Grosch, also was found guilty and
handed a two-year suspended sentence. Schmid was released on [euro]4 million
($5.8 million) bail pending his appeal. He already has served more than two
years in jail after he was arrested in late 2005.

Cartoon shows land plush deal

NEW YORK -- Cartoon Network Enterprises, the network's global branding and
merchandising arm, has announced its first foray into the amusement park
distribution channel via a multibrand deal with KellyToy USA to create plush
sporting goods and novelty items based on such Cartoon Network shows as "Ben 10"
and "Foster's Home for Imaginary Friends."

'Smart' tops TV-DVD nods

A complete-series boxed set of "Get Smart" won the top honor Monday at the
fourth annual TV-DVD Awards, while shows featuring Jim Henson's Muppet
characters won three awards. The TV-DVD Awards were presented by Home Media
Magazine in cooperation with The Hollywood Reporter, TVShowsOnDVD.com and DEG:
The Digital Entertainment Group. "Get Smart: The Complete Series," a
collaboration between Time Life and HBO Video, earned the best-of-show prize.
"Smart" was edged out for best complete-series set by 20th Century Fox Home
Entertainment's "M*A*S*H: The Martinis & Medicine Collection."

Stanley heads showbiz at L.A. law firm

Former reality show producer and studio executive David Stanley will head the
entertainment transactional practice at the Los Angeles law firm of Greenberg
Glusker. Stanley, a 1976 graduate of Golden Gate University School of Law, has
been with the firm for two years. He replaces veteran transactional attorney
Robert Marshall, who remains at the firm.

Local focus for NBC stations group

The NBC owned-and-operated stations group has changed its name to NBC Local
Media Division and tapped Brian Buchwald and Mark French for senior positions.
NBC Local Media Division president John Wallace said the new name better
reflects the scope of the unit's business. Buchwald has been named senior vp
local digital media and multiplatform, while French has been named senior vp and
GM of NBC Everywhere, a new unit focusing on the company's "digital place-based"
network. Both report to Wallace.

                                American Banker

                            February 6, 2015 Friday

Morning Scan: UBS in Tax-Evasion Hot Water Again; Somali Remittances

BYLINE: Andy Peters

SECTION: NATIONAL/REGIONAL Vol. 1 No. F306

LENGTH: 557  words


Receiving Wide Coverage ...

The Swiss and Taxes: And you wonder how the Swiss banking industry got its
reputation as a haven for tax evaders? The Justice Department and the Federal
Bureau of Investigation are examining Swiss bank UBS for allegedly helping its
American wealth-management clientsavoid taxesby putting their money into
investments that are banned in the U.S., theWall Street Journalreported. This
isn't the first time UBS has run afoul of U.S. tax laws; back in 2009, UBS paid
$780 million to settle a tax-evasion probe. Now, the U.S. Attorney's office in
Brooklyn is looking into UBS's usage of so-called bearer securities, which were
phased out in the U.S. starting in 1982 because the securities were often abused
to foster tax evasion. That's largely because the identity of the holder of
bearer securities can be kept anonymous. The DOJ and FBI are also looking into
whether UBS's alleged use of bearer securities was conducted during the time
when it was stillunder a deferred-prosecution agreementstemming from the 2009
settlement, theFinancial Timesreported.

Wall Street Journal

Rep. Keith Ellison, D-Minn., spoke at a briefing Wednesday for members of
Congress on theSomali remittance situation, and Ellison reiterated toAmerican
Bankerthat the decision by $81 million-asset Merchants Bank of California in
Carson to close accounts of companies that wire money to Somalia would be
"catastrophic for the Somali community." Ellison also said at the Congressional
hearing that he's informed several regulators of the situation, including
Comptroller of the Currency Thomas Curry. In a statement released Wednesday, the
Office of the Comptroller of the Currency said it doesn't force banks to close
specific accounts. Even so, banks must have the proper controls in place. "The
Somali situation is a terrible human tragedy that cannot be solved by bank
regulators; rather, it requires an international government and private-sector
effort," the OCC said in the statement.

At least the dollar's rise in value makes it more affordable for Americans to
travel abroad, right? Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said the dollar's rise
in value is a "complicating factor" in the Fed's effort to raise inflation to
its 2% target. Even so, Rosengren said he's "reasonably confident" the inflation
target will be met. Rosengren made the comments on Thursday morning in at a
conference in Frankfurt.

Cyberattacks aren't just something for banks and retailers to worry about.
Anthem, the No. 2 U.S. health insurance firm, said that about 80 million of its
customers and employees werehit in a data breach. The hackers are believed to
have taken tSocial Security numbers but not credit-card or bank-account numbers.

Elsewhere ...

Des Moines Register:A federal judge orderedU.S. Bancorp to pay $18 millionto
customers of an Iowa financial firm that ran a Ponzi scheme. The Commodity
Futures Trading Commission had sued U.S. Bancorp for allegedlyhelping Russell
Wasendorf run the Ponzi schemethrough his firm, Peregrine Financial Group in
Cedar Falls, Iowa. U.S. Bancorp failed "to meet its own responsibilities to
safeguard Peregrine's customer funds that it held," the CFTC said in a
statement. The $18 million payment waspart of a settlementthat U.S. Bancorp
reached with the CFTC and which was approved by U.S. District Court Judge Linda
Reade.

                                 SOONER EDITION

MAN INDICTED ON CHARGES HE THREATENED AN FBI AGENT

BYLINE: Torsten Ove, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B-1

LENGTH: 337 words


A federal grand jury in Ohio has indicted a New York man on charges of stalking
and threatening a Pittsburgh FBI agent who led the investigation into his
cousin, a prominent New Jersey lawyer sent to prison for the rest of his life
for racketeering, murder of an FBI informant and tax evasion.

Ron Bergrin was arrested by the FBI last month in Cleveland and faces a federal
detention hearing there today.

A grand jury on Tuesday charged him with cyber stalking, threatening a federal
law officer and making interstate threats, all in regard to Shawn Brokos, a
Pittsburgh FBI agent who transferred here from the Newark, N.J., office in 2013.

She was the lead investigator in the government's prosecution of Ron Bergrin's
cousin Paul Bergrin, a high-profile Newark defense attorney who has represented
rap stars, drug gangs and U.S. soldiers accused of abusing Iraqis.

Federal prosecutors said Paul Bergrin led his own drug ring, enlisting his
clients to help his operation and carry out murders to protect it.

A onetime federal and state prosecutor, he is serving six life terms for murder,
witness tampering, drug trafficking, racketeering and tax evasion. He had also
previously pleaded guilty to running a prostitution ring.

Federal agents say Ron Bergrin, who has homes in New York and Florida, is out
for revenge against Agent Brokos because of her role in putting him away.

After efforts to get a reduced sentence for his cousin failed, the FBI said he
repeatedly called the Newark FBI in office in 2013 to harass Agent Brokos. After
her transfer, he sent four Easter cards to her new home in the Pittsburgh
region.

He also sent an email last month to a cousin in Cleveland that the FBI considers
threatening.

"I'm going to teach her that I could crush her like the bug she is, if I wanted
to," the email said. "She will never sleep at night again. She will have
nightmares. I'm going to investigate her neighbors - like she did to mine."

The FBI arrested him the next day as he walked into a hotel on Carnegie Avenue
in Cleveland.

                      Orange County Register (California)

                             July 25, 2013 Thursday

Man gets 22 years for trafficking, tax evasion

BYLINE: By VIK JOLLY, ORANGE COUNTY REGISTER

SECTION: SUNPOST; Pg. B

LENGTH: 274 words


A federal judge Monday sentenced a San Clemente man known as "Pops" to nearly 22
years in prison for drug trafficking and tax evasion in connection with running
a string of nine illegal marijuana storefronts that authorities say earned him
about $25 million.

After listening to pleas for leniency from friends of 56-year-old John Melvin
Walker, U.S. District Judge James Selna said it was clear to him that there were
two John Walkers - the one who supported his family and friends and the man who
led and organized "major drug activity."

The sentence addresses "not only the good John Walker but also the bad John
Walker," Selna said.

Selna also ordered Walker to pay the Internal Revenue Service $2.4 million and
the California State Board of Equalization $1.8 million in restitution.

Walker, who had two previous state drug-trafficking convictions, pleaded guilty
in April to two federal charges - one count of conspiring to distribute more
than a ton of marijuana and maintaining drug-involved premises, and one of tax
evasion.

He was among 14 people indicted by a federal grand jury in fall 2012, most of
whom have pleaded guilty.

The indictment outlined a drug-trafficking conspiracy led by Walker, who owned
and operated at least nine marijuana stores in Los Angeles and Orange counties,
prosecutors said.

Walker lived in a multimillion-dollar gated mansion in San Clemente, described
in documents as having six bedrooms and four bathrooms, with a large pool and
casita in the backyard.

Defense attorney Kate Corrigan read a letter from Walker to Selna in which he
apologized and expressed the "deepest regret for all the wrongs I've committed."

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            December 5, 2006 Tuesday

Ex-CEO indicted on fraud, tax charges;
Orinda man alleged to have spent thousands of company's dollars on items such as
gold jewelry and expensive clothing

BYLINE: Josh Richman, MEDIANEWS STAFF

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. F4

LENGTH: 318 words


An Orinda man has been indicted on mail fraud and tax evasion charges, with
federal prosecutors claiming he conned people into investing in his Livermore
startup company as he embezzled and bought luxury items.

John Frances Griffin, 43, was arrested in May after a former Contra Costa County
prosecutor who went to work for VaporTech Inc. uncovered the CEO's alleged
misdeeds.

VaporTech develops steam, vapor and high-pressure technology for uses such as
cleaning toxic soil or forcing oil from wells. An indictment handed up last week
by a federal grand jury in Oakland claims Griffin from 2004 to 2006 falsely told
investors he loaned $275,000 to his own company in order to entice them to
invest as well; he also allegedly told VaporTech employees he put about $1
million into the company, and the indictment claims he was saying this to cover
his own embezzlement.

Federal prosecutors are seeking forfeiture of items Griffin bought with the
company's cash, including a $30,359 diamond ring; a $3,425 gold tennis bracelet;
two televisions worth more than $3,700 each; and more than $17,000 worth of
clothing from Nieman Marcus.

The indictment filed Thursday adds two counts of tax evasion to the three counts
of mail fraud charged back in May. Griffin allegedly dodged his federal income
taxes in 2004 and 2005 by failing to give VaporTech's chief financial officer
his Social Security number; cashing his salary checks instead of depositing
them; and using cash and cashier's checks to prevent his income from being
detected.

Griffin is in the custody of a halfway house, and is scheduled to be arraigned
on the new indictment Friday. Each mail fraud count is punishable by up to 20
years in federal prison and a fine of up to $250,000 plus restitution; each tax
evasion count is punishable by up to five years and $250,000.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                    July 14, 2004 Wednesday Marshall Edition

Local man admits tax evasion, offers help;
He apparently will offer information about offshore scheme to hide income.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW S. GALBRAITH; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D3

LENGTH: 386 words


SOUTH BEND -- A South Bend man has offered to plead guilty to tax evasion and
help the government in a complex offshore tax fraud case, according to a
proposed plea agreement filed Monday in federal court.

Douglas Gilman's petition to enter a guilty plea was filed along with a criminal
complaint charging him with four counts of tax evasion.

In the eight-page plea petition, Gilman, 45, admits that he and his wife, Gayle,
reduced the amount of income tax owed by a corporation they own through the use
of other companies, including an offshore entity.

If the plea agreement is approved, the Gilmans would share information about
Anderson Ark, a Costa Rica offshore trust program the government has accused of
helping clients move and conceal taxable income.

Several indictments have been returned in the United States in connection with
Anderson Ark, which the U.S. Department of Justice says helped some 2,000
clients obtain more than $30 million in illegal tax refunds from 1998 through
2001.

A plea hearing for Gilman is scheduled for July 26 before U.S. District Judge
Robert L. Miller Jr.

Because each count carries up to a five-year sentence, he would face up to 20
years in prison and a $1 million fine. He has agreed to pay restitution of
$112,500, the amount of his tax loss.

The charges accuse Gilman of filing false income tax returns on behalf of him
and his wife for the years 1998, 1999, 2000 and 2001.

In each year, the reported joint taxable income, and the tax owed based on
income, were substantially lower than the actual amounts, according to the
government.

For example, he reported income of $141,533 and taxes of $38,187 in 2001 when he
allegedly knew the income amount was much higher.

In the plea agreement, Gilman says he filed false income tax returns for an S
corporation called Allied Agency Inc. in those years.

The tax evasion, he explained, involved the setting up of a limited partnership
in Nevada called DG&S, an offshore entity called Investt Chevy S.A., and a
foreign financial account.

Justice department reports on Anderson Ark say the organization used shell
corporations, trusts and partnerships to transfer, conceal and repatriate
taxable income.

                               The New York Times

                           January 18, 2003 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

City Seeks to Recoup Tax Money From Internet Cigarette Vendors

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL

SECTION: Section B; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 433 words


Seeking to recoup millions of dollars in uncollected tax revenues, the city
filed suit yesterday against several companies that sell cigarettes over the
Internet but, the suit alleges, do not properly report the sales to the
authorities.

Lawyers for the city said they believed it was the first time a locality had
taken such strong aim at Internet cigarette tax evasion. Mayor Michael R.
Bloomberg said that the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, was
intended to punish companies that advertise tax-free cigarette sales through the
Internet.

"We're not going to be the only ones," Mr. Bloomberg said on his weekly radio
show on WABC. "Every state has a problem that nobody's paying sales tax on the
purchases over the Internet."

The city's complaint accuses several operators of about a dozen cigarette retail
Web sites of engaging in a huge tax evasion scheme by failing to file reports
that alert state tax authorities to out-of-state cigarette purchases. Some of
the sites falsely state that cigarettes bought over the Internet are tax-free,
the suit charges, despite laws that require purchasers to pay excise and sales
taxes on cigarettes bought for use in the state.

"Internet vendors don't notify the customers that that's the case," said Gail
Rubin, chief of the affirmative litigation division at the city's Law
Department. "In fact, they tell them just the opposite."

The suit seeks triple the amount officials estimate the city has lost in
revenues from the defendants, which could amount to more than $15 million,
officials said.

Eric Proshansky, deputy chief of the affirmative litigation division, said that
collecting cigarette taxes had traditionally been problematic, and that the only
other Internet case he had come across was the State of Washington's suing a
single vendor.

"Any time you have differences in the tax rate across state lines, there's an
incentive for people to cross states lines" to take advantage of the lower tax
rate, he said.

One site, BuyDiscountCigarettes.com, advertises itself as selling cigarettes
tax-free because it is located on the Jemez Pueblo, a federally recognized
American Indian sovereign nation, it says. But Mr. Proshansky said that
non-Indians must still pay tax on cigarettes bought there, and that the company
should be filing reports of Internet sales.

"We file reports with appropriate taxing authorities," said Kai Gachupin, the
owner of a company that operates the site along with four others named in the
suit. Mr. Gachupin said that cigarettes were no different from other goods that
are sold tax-free on the Internet.

                                US Official News

                           November 22, 2016 Tuesday

Psychiatrist sentenced to 18 months in prison for tax evasion

LENGTH: 363  words

DATELINE: New York



 Washington: Office for the United States Attorneys, Northern District of Ohio
has issued the following news release:



  A psychiatrist from Oregon, Ohio, was sentenced to serve 18 months in prison
for tax evasion, announced Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Caroline
D. Ciraolo, head of the Justice Department's Tax Division, U.S. Attorney Carole
S. Rendon for the Northern District of Ohio, and Kathy A. Enstrom, Special Agent
in Charge, IRS Criminal Investigation, Cincinnati Field Office.





 According to court records, from as early as 2005, Sandra Vonderembse failed to
pay taxes and filed and caused to be filed with the Internal Revenue Service
false and fraudulent tax returns that included false statements regarding her
income and the amount of tax due and owing.  Additionally, from 2009 through
2011, Vonderembse falsely claimed to have no taxable income and to owe no taxes,
despite earning more than $240,000 each year while working as a psychiatrist.
Vonderembse used nominee entities to conceal income from the IRS, and sent fake
financial instruments to the IRS in purported payment of her taxes.  In total,
from 2005 through 2011, she attempted to evade more than $360,000 in income tax
liabilities.



 "Tax evasion is not a victimless crime," Enstrom said. "We all pay when others
swindle the government.  Tax evasion and tax fraud of this magnitude and with
this degree of trickery, dishonesty and deceit, deserves to be punished.  The
IRS and Department of Justice remain determined and vigilant in ferreting out
such schemes to cheat the honest taxpayers."



 In addition to the prison term imposed, Vonderembse was ordered to serve one
year of supervised release and to pay restitution to the IRS in the amount of
$565,128.



 Principal Deputy Assistant Attorney General Ciraolo and U.S. Attorney Rendon
commended special agents of IRS-Criminal Investigation, who conducted the
investigation, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Noah Hood and Trial Attorneys Jack
Morgan and Jeffrey McLellan of the Tax Division, who are prosecuting the case.

                                   USA TODAY

                              May 31, 2013 Friday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Germany to share bank data with U.S.;
IRS to be informed about Americans who have accounts there

BYLINE: Charles McPhedran, Special for USA TODAY,

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 640 words


Germany will sign a landmark agreement with the U.S. government today, allowing
the bank account details of U.S. citizens living in that nation  to be
transferred to the IRS to help in the hunt for tax cheats.

The deal is part of a move by the U.S. government in the past three years to
tighten reporting requirements of financial assets abroad belonging to Americans
living overseas, as well as U.S. nationals residing domestically with foreign
accounts.

"This is an important step on the path to a united war against tax evasion,"
said the German government after reaching a consensus Wednesday to sign the
agreement.

The clamping down on tax evasion has led to serious problems for American
expatriates, whose numbers are estimated at more than 6 million. It is difficult
for Americans in Germany, Switzerland and elsewhere in Europe to get brokerage
or retirement accounts, mortgages or to hold joint accounts with their spouses
because it's too costly and complicated for the banks to meet the reporting
requirements.

"Deutsche Bank has turned me down twice for brokerage accounts in the past year,
and my 16-year-old daughter's college savings account was closed,"  said
Genevieve Besser, who has lived in Germany for decades with her German husband
and daughters. She says she has no access to her husband's German retirement
account, because if she did, the bank would close it. Meanwhile, she owes no
taxes to the U.S. "It feels like we are being persecuted," she added.

The crackdown has also caused issues for American executives abroad with signing
authority on company accounts, whether they work for American multinationals or
foreign ones. Attorneys who advise multinationals say there has been hesitation
about hiring Americans for high-level positions.

As a result, Americans have been renouncing their citizenship in record numbers.
Almost 1,800 individuals did so in 2012 -- six times more than in 2008,
according to the U.S. Treasury Department.

Meanwhile, the cost of complying with the rules, as well as the penalties for
unknowing violations, has cost businesses and individuals millions of dollars,
says  Sen. Rand Paul, R-Ky., who introduced legislation to repeal the Foreign
Account Tax Compliance Act,  which took effect in January. It  requires foreign
banks to report to the IRS (sometimes via their governments) or face  penalties.

FATCA, as well as other rules, require the disclosure of financial assets
overseas after the amount reaches $10,000 for bank accounts and $250,000 dollars
for other assets.

"FATCA is a textbook example of bad law that doesn't achieve its stated purpose
but does manage to unleash a host of unanticipated destructive consequences,"
said Paul,  calling it "a violation of Americans' constitutional protections.
Tax evasion is a problem that should be addressed, but not in such an egregious
way," he said. "FATCA violates important privacy protections and will cost the
U.S. economy hundreds of billions of dollars in compliance costs, and discourage
overseas investment in the United States."

Even so, the move to root out tax cheats, one of President Obama's  campaign
promises in 2008, is inspiring European governments to do the same by sharing
banking data  with each other.

Earlier this month, European Union officials said they would create a law
allowing for the automatic information transfer among the 27-member states, as
well as those outside the bloc but on the continent, such as known tax-havens
Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Monaco.

Meanwhile, round two against tax evasion will go after foreign multinationals
such as Google and Facebook.

"At a time of fiscal pressure and social tension, fighting tax evasion is a
matter of fairness and credibility," said European Council President Herman van
Rompuy. "The amounts are staggering; hundreds of millions go missing each year."

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                     July 14, 2004 Wednesday Metro Edition

South Bend man admits tax evasion;
He apparently will offer information about offshore scheme to hide income

BYLINE: By MATTHEW S. GALBRAITH; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 386 words


SOUTH BEND -- A South Bend man has offered to plead guilty to tax evasion and
help the government in a complex offshore tax fraud case, according to a
proposed plea agreement filed Monday in federal court.

Douglas Gilman's petition to enter a guilty plea was filed along with a criminal
complaint charging him with four counts of tax evasion.

In the eight-page plea petition, Gilman, 45, admits that he and his wife, Gayle,
reduced the amount of income tax owed by a corporation they own through the use
of other companies, including an offshore entity.

If the plea agreement is approved, the Gilmans would share information about
Anderson Ark, a Costa Rica offshore trust program the government has accused of
helping clients move and conceal taxable income.

Several indictments have been returned in the United States in connection with
Anderson Ark, which the U.S. Department of Justice says helped some 2,000
clients obtain more than $30 million in illegal tax refunds from 1998 through
2001.

A plea hearing for Gilman is scheduled for July 26 before U.S. District Judge
Robert L. Miller Jr.

Because each count carries up to a five-year sentence, he would face up to 20
years in prison and a $1 million fine. He has agreed to pay restitution of
$112,500, the amount of his tax loss.

The charges accuse Gilman of filing false income tax returns on behalf of him
and his wife for the years 1998, 1999, 2000 and 2001.

In each year, the reported joint taxable income, and the tax owed based on
income, were substantially lower than the actual amounts, according to the
government.

For example, he reported income of $141,533 and taxes of $38,187 in 2001 when he
allegedly knew the income amount was much higher.

In the plea agreement, Gilman says he filed false income tax returns for an S
corporation called Allied Agency Inc. in those years.

The tax evasion, he explained, involved the setting up of a limited partnership
in Nevada called DG&S, an offshore entity called Investt Chevy S.A., and a
foreign financial account.

Justice department reports on Anderson Ark say the organization used shell
corporations, trusts and partnerships to transfer, conceal and repatriate
taxable income.

                  July 22, 1999, Thursday, THREE STAR EDITION

BANKS' TAX EVASION TRIAL IS DELAYED FOUR MONTHS

BYLINE: Virginia Young; Post-Dispatch Jefferson City Bureau

SECTION: METRO, Pg. B2

LENGTH: 486 words

DATELINE: JEFFERSON CITY


Sen. J.B. "Jet" Banks' trial on charges of tax evasion has been delayed until
Jan. 10, despite protests from the prosecutor.

Cole County Circuit Judge Byron Kinder set the new trial date during a meeting
with attorneys in his office on Wednesday. Banks, D-St. Louis, was charged in
May with failing to pay state income tax on $ 61,000 in 1994 and 1995.

Kinder discarded a Sept. 15 trial date because he is leaving for a vacation in
mid-September. He ruled out the rest of the year because of the vacation plans
of Donald Wolff, Banks' attorney. Wolff said he will be traveling in Europe from
mid-October through late November.

That means Banks' trial will get under way three blocks from the Capitol shortly
after the legislative session's opening speeches and hoopla. Lawmakers meet from
Jan. 5 to May 12. Wolff said the trial will last at least two weeks.

Cole County Prosecutor Richard Callahan had pressed for an earlier trial date.
He said in an interview that he had hoped to avoid conducting the trial during
the legislative session out of "a sense of respect for the business of the
General Assembly."

A separate charge - accusing Banks of lying to a grand jury - is pending before
a different judge and is scheduled for trial on Sept. 8. But at a hearing
earlier Wednesday, Wolff warned that he may ask for a delay in that case, too.

"I'm making every effort to be ready ... but this case is extremely complex and
weighted with paper," Wolff told Senior Judge George Flanigan, a retired Court
of Appeals judge from Springfield.

Flanigan scheduled a pre-trial hearing in the perjury case for Aug. 3. The
Missouri Supreme Court appointed Flanigan to hear the case after Banks
disqualified one Cole County judge and the prosecutor disqualified the other.
Both sides can ask for one change of judge without giving a reason.

Banks, 75, has represented parts of St. Louis for nearly 30 years. He was the
first black to hold the post of Senate majority leader. He is now chairman of
the Senate Public Health Committee.

In the perjury case, he is accused of lying to a grand jury at an appearance
April 30, 1988, when he said he paid $ 150,000 to buy Premier Service Corp., a
limousine business, in 1982. The indictment says the purchases price was $
60,000 or less. Overstating the purchase price affects the tax basis for the
value of an asset that is later sold.

The state Ethics Commission asked Callahan to investigate Banks' finances in
1997. The request stemmed from a complaint based on a Post-Dispatch report that
more than $ 100,000 had disappeared from Banks' campaign treasury without a
paper trail. No charges were filed based on the campaign reports, but during
that investigation, Callahan uncovered information that led to the tax evasion
charge.

All the charges against Banks are felonies, punishable by prison terms of up to
seven years and maximum fines of $ 5,000.

                               The New York Times

                March 2, 1985, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

GOVERNOR SEEKS BIG CRACKDOWN ON TAX EVADERS

BYLINE: By MAURICE CARROLL

SECTION: Section 1; Page 27, Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 506 words

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 1


Saying cheating on New York State taxes is ''in the billion dollar range,'' the
Cuomo administration today proposed a package of bills to crack down on tax
evasion.

''This is not penny ante pilferage,'' Governor Cuomo said at a news conference.
''It's hundreds of millions of dollars a year.''

The head of the State Tax Commission, Roderick G. W. Chu, pointed to charts
showing the results of a computer comparison of Medicare and Medicaid checks
received by doctors with income tax returns filed by doctors.

The charts, to the right of the dais in the old Court of Appeals room in the
Capitol, showed 91 doctors who had not filed returns and who owed an estimated
$17.6 million. The charts showed 1,800 more who had underreported taxes owed by
more than $70 million.

Using national studies to estimate the state level, Mr. Chu said, shows that tax
cheating in New York is ''somewhere in the billion-dollar range.''

No Amnesty for Evaders

Mr. Cuomo described the main bill in the package, the Omnibus Tax Equity and
Enforcement Act, as ''the first comprehensive overhaul of the criminal and civil
penalties for tax evasion in state history.'' It is a reworked version of a
measure that he introduced late in the 1984 legislative session.

The package did not include amnesty for tax evaders who came forward and paid
their taxes, an idea that has been put forward by the Republicans, who control
the State Senate.

Asked about the possibility of including an amnesty provision, Mr. Cuomo did not
rule out talks about it during negotiations to shape the budget for the fiscal
year starting April 1.

But he warned against the temptation to ''create overly generous estimates'' of
the money an amnesty might bring in.

Key Points in the Package

The package included these provisions:


- An omnibus bill that would increase penalties, tighten tax-registration
controls, provide for the early collection of sales taxes from flea-market
vendors, permit the seizure and sale of vehicles used to bootleg motor fuel and
expand the investigatory powers of the Department of Taxation and Finance.


- A measure to establish a revenue crimes bureau in the Tax Department to focus
on violators and speed the preparation of cases for local prosecutors. It would
also provide funds for informants and ''buy money'' for use in criminal
investigations.


- A bill to eliminate what the tax people call a ''daisy chain'' in which,
through a series of paper transactions, taxes are evaded on motor fuel. The bill
would require that the taxes be paid on the initial sale in the state.


- A measure to impose a 100 percent tax on illegal income. This provides an
incentive for local governments to report suspicious activity. A locality would
get 25 percent of any taxes collected as a result of its report.

James A. Quaremba, president of the state's Retail Council, praised the
proposals, saying they would ''eradicate the wrongful economic advantage'' held
by many flea-market and transient vendors.

                            The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             May 15, 2014 Thursday

Rindge man pleads guilty to tax evasion, faces prison time and fines

BYLINE: The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 394 words


May 15--CONCORD -- A Rindge man accused of swindling investors of nearly $28
million pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court in Concord Thursday to four counts
of tax evasion.

Aaron E. Olson was also fined $200,000 from an order filed against him by the
N.H. Securities Bureau after two years of investigation.

The charges against Olson span four years and involve two investment firms he
owned: AEO Associates and KMO Associates.

He obtained $27.8 million from individuals and organizations supposedly to
invest on their behalf,  according to a news release from the U.S. Attorney's
Office.

To entice them to invest more money with him, Olson sent them false earnings
statements that showed significant gains on their investments, according to the
U.S. Attorney's Office.

Olson used $2.6 million of investors' funds for his own benefit and to pay fake
earnings to other investors while he lost people's money on investments that
performed poorly, the news release said.

Olson is charged with falsely reporting his income taxes in the years from 2007
to 2010. He reported owing $35,900 during those years when his actual tax
liability totaled $664,912 more, according to the release.

The N.H. Bureau of Securities Regulation issued a consent order Thursday against
Olson for violations of N.H. securities laws, including fraud and failure to
license.

The bureau said Olson mingled investors' money with his own, recommended and
traded risky investments and failed to maintain adequate records of investments
and sent some investors false statements.

Olson did not register either AEO or KMO with the state as investment firms and
he was not licensed in New Hampshire or any other jurisdiction as an investment
broker, the news release said.

"By avoiding the licensure requirements, Mr. Olson was able to avoid scrutiny of
his illegal activities for several years," said Eric Forcier, the bureau's staff
attorney.

Olson must pay any restitution ordered by the U.S. District Court and back taxes
before the bureau's fine. He has been barred for life from getting a securities
license.

Olson is scheduled to be sentenced in September.

The maximum penalty for each tax evasion charge is a five-year prison sentence,
and a fine of $250,000.

                            March 19, 2005, Saturday

Multi-level marketing executives convicted of tax evasion charges

BYLINE: By Pamela Manson

LENGTH: 290 words



The founders of an international multilevel marketing company based in Utah were
convicted Friday by a federal jury of income tax evasion and conspiracy to
defraud the Internal Revenue Service.

The former corporate counsel of Neways Inc. also was found guilty of conspiracy,
as well as of corruptly impeding the due administration of tax laws.

Prosecutors said the three -- Thomas E. Mower and his former wife, Leslie D.
Mower, who were officers in the Salem-based company, and James Thompson, its
lawyer from fall 1995 through summer 1997 -- concealed more than $ 1 million in
receipts received from Neways Australia and more than $ 3 million in commission
income the couple received from U.S., Australian and Malaysian distributorships.

The Mowers, who divorced in July 2000, were accused of using the unreported
income to buy assets, including 1,400 acres in Utah County's Hobble Creek Canyon
and a warehouse in Salem used as the company's manufacturing facility.

Neways manufactures, markets and sells personal care and nutritional products in
the United States and about two dozen foreign countries.

Sentencing by U.S. District Judge Dale Kimball is set for June 21. The maximum
penalty for conspiracy and tax evasion is five years in prison and a $ 250,000
fine and three years and a $ 250,000 fine for impeding the IRS.

                               The New York Times

                 December 5, 1997, Friday, Late Edition - Final

Investigators Press Search For 2 Sought In Tax Case

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 497 words


Two men accused of helping to promote a tax evasion scheme that so far has led
to the arrest of 88 current and former city employees have failed to surrender
as promised, and investigators widened their search for the men yesterday.

The men, Anthony Davis and Leroy Gordon, are believed to be members of the
Moorish Nation, a black separatist movement, and are charged with selling
so-called tax kits that come with instructions on how to avoid paying taxes,
either by filling out tax forms with false information or by informing the
government that it has no right to collect taxes.

Investigators say both men had indicated plans to surrender.

Meanwhile, law enforcement officials said that their investigation was
continuing and that more arrests were expected. One official, speaking on the
condition of anonymity, said that as many as 100 more city employees might be
implicated in the case.

The arrests this week of employees in the City Departments of Correction,
Sanitation and Environmental Protection -- many of whom serve in law enforcement
capacities -- raised the troubling picture of a city government peppered with
people trying to dodge the very taxes that pay their salaries. Many are charged
with claiming an excessive number of tax withholdings.

Adding to the embarrassment was the arrest of Joseph A. Messina, executive
director of the city's Financial Information Services Agency, which monitors
city disbursements. Investigators said Mr. Messina, who was charged with evading
taxes, hampered their case by not providing pertinent information about the
city's payroll.

In addition to Mr. Davis and Mr. Gordon, a Manhattan businesswoman, Esther Hart,
has been charged with promoting the tax evasion scheme. Ms. Hart, 41,
surrendered to the authorities on Wednesday.

Investigators are still piecing together how the scheme spread through city
government and, particularly, in the Correction Department. Almost half of the
74 correction officers arrested this week said they had been initiated into the
Moorish Nation; some cited the teachings of Hakim H. Y. Bey, the organization's
spiritual leader, who advocates black separatism.

An investigator said yesterday that the authorities were interested in speaking
to Mr. Bey, who sells audio tapes of his lessons from a Web page on the
Internet. Those who buy his items are instructed to mail their money orders to a
post office box in the Bronx.

Several weeks ago, two men believed to be acolytes of Mr. Bey -- Mr. Davis and
Mr. Gordon -- sued the Manhattan District Attorney's office in Federal District
Court in Brooklyn in an attempt to block their imminent arrests. The two men
contended in their written complaint that the District Attorney had violated
their constitutional rights during the course of the office's investigation.

The constitutional argument is ironic, investigators say, given their
association with an organization that does not recognize the United States
Government.

                               The New York Times

              November 11, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

RICHMOND SENTENCED TO A YEAR AND A DAY AND FINED $20,000

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 750 words


Former Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn was sentenced yesterday
to a year and a day in prison and fined $20,000 for income-tax evasion,
marijuana possession and making an illegal payment to a government employee.

He had pleaded guilty to these charges and agreed to resign from Congress and
not seek re-election in a plea bargaining with Federal prosecutors on Aug. 25.
They agreed not to prosecute him for other matters that they had also been
investigating.

No date was set for him to begin serving his term, although he will probably
have to begin doing so in a few weeks, officials said.

Judge Is Typically Informal

As Chief Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn
pronounced the sentence, Mr. Richmond, who will be 59 years old Monday, gazed
somberly at the judge from across a polished wood conference table, at which the
participants in the case were seated.

Judge Weinstein normally conducts sentencings and hearings at this table in his
courtroom, rather than from his bench, and, in another typical manifestation of
his informality, he was not wearing his judicial robes.

''You have done commendable things for many people,'' the 61-yearold judge said.
''For this you received personal gratification, affection, respect and high
office. You have committed criminal acts. For this you must be punished.''

Judge Weinstein then sentenced Mr. Richmond to one year each for the marijuana
possession and illegal-payment pleas and to a year and a day for tax evasion. He
said the prison terms were to run concurrently because this was required by
standards of the American Bar Association and the uniform practice of the
Federal Court in Brooklyn in sentencing for nonviolent crimes.

The judge did not explain why the extra day was added, but a parole official,
Ralph Kistner, later said this was a technicality related to regulations
governing possible early release for good behavior in prison.

Mr. Kistner said Mr. Richmond would be eligible to seek release on parole after
serving four months, but the prosecutor, Francis J.  Murray, said he expected
Mr. Richmond to serve about 10 months.

Moments before the sentencing, the former four-term Democratic member of the
House of Representatives had shaken his head no when Judge Weinstein asked if he
had anything to say before sentencing.  After the term was pronounced, Mr.
Richmond declined to comment to reporters, hurriedly leaving the courthouse on
Cadman Plaza East in downtown Brooklyn.

An Appeal for 'Understanding'

One of Mr. Richmond's lawyers, Kalman Gallop, had appealed to Judge Weinstein to
show ''understanding and compassion'' in sentencing Mr.  Richmond, who faced up
to five years in prison and $20,000 in fines for the three Federal crimes to
which he had confessed.

''Fred Richmond comes to this court tortured, humiliated, defeated,'' Mr. Gallop
said. ''His life has been ruined. He faces an uncertain future.''

Mr. Gallop cited what he called a long array of civic and charitable
contributions that Mr. Richmond - considered one of the wealthiest members of
the House - had made over the years, as a civic-minded New Yorker as well as a
Congressman.

These ranged, Mr. Gallop said, from playing key roles in the drive to save
Carnegie Hall in Manhattan and the Brooklyn Home for the Aged to financing
housing-rehabilitation efforts on Harlem, contributing to families in need and -
''probably his greatest achievement'' in Congress - making ''tireless efforts''
to preserve the Federal food-stamp program.

'Contrast With His Crimes'

Mr. Murray, who is the head of the economic crimes unit in the United States
Attorney's Office in Brooklyn, told Judge Weinstein that other things also had
to be kept in mind.

''Mr. Richmond's charitable deeds on the one hand have to be contrasted with his
crimes that violated Federal statutes,'' the prosecutor said. He added that
''there has to be recognition that there is a wrong that has occurred here and
that a very sacred trust has been breached by this man not once but on numerous
occasions.''

Judge Weinstein then told the former Representative, a reddishhaired man wearing
a bluish-gray suit, light blue shirt and blue patterned tie, that a prison term
was in order.
