                           December 12, 2013 Thursday

Plea entered in tax evasion case

BYLINE: Michael R. Moser, Crossville Chronicle, Tenn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 420 words


Dec. 12--CROSSVILLE -- A Crossville businessman presented Clerk of Courts Larry
Sherrill a check for $75,000 prior to his appearance in Cumberland County
Criminal Court as a down payment on restitution the state says he owes in a tax
evasion case.

Vipul Manubhai Patel, 33, owner of JASH Corporation, which is doing business as
Tobacco and Beverage Mart in Crossville, pleaded guilty to one felony count of
sales tax evasion. The remaining 22 counts were then dismissed.

Terms of the sentencing agreement allowed Patel to plead guilty in exchange of
being placed on judicial diversion. Patel is to serve one year on supervised
probation during which time he is to pay an additional $24,774.03 restitution
for sale tax still owed.

At the end of that year, if restitution is paid in full and other conditions of
probation are met, Patel will be eligible to petition the court to have his
record cleared of the charge. That expungement is not automatic, but must be
agreed to by a judge.

The Special Investigations Section of the Tennessee Department of Revenue
conducted the investigation that led to Patel's plea and sentencing.

The case stems from failure to pay sales tax owed the state from February 2008
through December 2010.

In a press release, the following statement was issued: "This investigation
serves as a reminder that retailers are not entitled to use or keep sales tax
monies," said Revenue Commissioner Richard H. Roberts. "Sales tax revenues
collected by retailers are never property of the retailer and are always the
property of our state and local governments. These taxes must be remitted to the
state as required by law."

The department pursued the criminal case in cooperation with District Attorney
General Randy York's office. Citizens who suspect violations of Tennessee's
revenue laws should call the toll-free tax fraud hot line at (800) FRAUDTX
(372-8389).

The Department of Revenue is responsible for the administration of state tax
laws and motor vehicle title and registration laws and the collection of taxes
and fees associated with those laws. The department collects about 87 percent of
total state revenue. During the 2013 fiscal year, it collected $11.7 billion in
state taxes and fees and more than $2.2 billion in taxes and fees for local
governments.  To learn more about the department, visit www.TN.gov/revenue.

Drug kingpin gets 22 years for trafficking, tax evasion

BYLINE: By VIK JOLLY, ORANGE COUNTY REGISTER

SECTION: CAPOVALLEY; Pg. A

LENGTH: 280 words



HIGHLIGHT: John 'Pops' Walker ran illegal pot shops that brought in $25 million.



A federal judge Monday sentenced a man known as "Pops" to nearly 22 years in
prison for drug trafficking and tax evasion in connection with running a string
of nine illegal marijuana storefronts - including in San Juan Capistrano - that
authorities say earned him about $25 million.

After listening to pleas for leniency from friends of 56-year-old John Melvin
Walker of San Clemente, U.S. District Judge James Selna said it was clear to him
that there were two John Walkers - the one who supported his family and friends
and the man who led and organized "major drug activity."

The sentence addresses "not only the good John Walker but also the bad John
Walker," Selna said.

Selna also ordered Walker to pay the Internal Revenue Service $2.4 million and
the California State Board of Equalization $1.8 million in restitution.

Walker, who had two previous state drug trafficking convictions, pleaded guilty
in April to two federal charges - one count of conspiring to distribute more
than a ton of marijuana and maintaining drug-involved premises, and one of tax
evasion.

He was among 14 people indicted by a federal grand jury in fall 2012, most of
whom have pleaded guilty.

The indictment outlined a drug-trafficking conspiracy led by Walker, who owned
and operated at least nine marijuana stores in Los Angeles and Orange counties,
prosecutors said.

Walker lived in a multimillion-dollar gated mansion in San Clemente, described
in documents as having six bedrooms and four bathrooms, with a large pool and
casita in the backyard.

Defense attorney Kate Corrigan read a letter from Walker to Selna in which he
apologized and expressed the "deepest regret for all the wrongs I've committed."

                                US Official News

                          February 11, 2015 Wednesday

New Jersey: Doctor with offices in Jersey City, North Bergen admits tax evasion

LENGTH: 431  words

DATELINE: Trenton


Bergen County, The State of New Jersey has issued the following news release:

A doctor who owns three immediate care facilities in Hudson County today
admitted making millions of dollars' worth of cash deposits and fraudulently
transferring his residence to a family member to evade taxes, authorities
announced.

Medhat El Amir of Saddle River pleaded guilty before U.S. District Judge Jose L.
Linares in Newark federal court to corruptly endeavoring to impede the Internal
Revenue Code, and tax evasion, in connection with an individual income tax
return from 2007.

U.S. Attorney Paul J. Fishman and Tax Division Principal Deputy Assistant
Attorney General Caroline D. Ciraolo announced the guilty plea today, some 10
months after El Amir was arrested and charged with tax evasion in April.

According to documents filed in this case and statements made in court, El Amir
was a primary care doctor and 60 percent owner of Immediate Care P.C., which
provided urgent health care services for patients at an office in North Bergen
and two offices in Jersey City.

From Feb. 11, 2005 through Dec. 31, 2010, El Amir attempted to impede the
internal revenue laws in a number of ways, authorities said. He admitted he
fraudulently transferred his residence in Saddle River to his sister for $2.5
million to keep the property out of the reach of the IRS and the payroll taxes
he owed through his former practice, according to authorities.

El Amir also admitted cashing $7,261,083 in Immediate Care insurance company
checks at a check cashing facility, depositing the majority of that income into
a number of bank accounts to which he had access and using a portion of the
money for personal expenses, authorities said.

El Amir admitted he failed to report taxable income of more than $2 million from
2007 through 2010, resulting in a $502,160 tax loss to the government.
Despite earning a significant income from his practice, El Amir did not file
personal income tax returns for calendar years 2007, 2009 and 2010.

El Amir did file a personal income tax return for 2008, but substantially
under-reported the income he received from Immediate Care and claimed interest
deductions to which he was not entitled.

The count of corruptly endeavoring to impede the due administration of the
Internal Revenue Code carries a maximum potential penalty of three years in
prison and a $250,000 fine. The count of tax evasion carries a maximum potential
penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

Washington: Former Deputy Constable Charged with Tax Evasion

LENGTH: 292  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Federal Bureau of Investigation, The Government of USA has issued the
following news release:

Vernon Matthews has been charged with using dependent information of people he
contacted during his time as a deputy constable to file false tax returns,
announced United States Attorney Kenneth Magidson. Matthews is a 21-year veteran
of law enforcement and was a former Precinct 6 deputy constable.

Matthews was charged in a five-count indictment returned Tuesday, February 11,
2014. He surrendered to authorities this morning and is set to make an initial
appearance before U.S. Magistrate Judge George C. Hanks at 2:00 p.m. today.

The indictment alleges Matthews obtained names and identifying information of
the children of parents he contacted during his service as a deputy constable.
Matthews then allegedly claimed the children as dependent nephews and nieces on
his 2007, 2008, 2010, and 2011 tax returns. He also claimed "child care" and
educational expenses for his non-existent relatives and made false statements to
the FBI when questioned about the claims in a March 2013 interview, according to
allegations.

If convicted, Matthews faces up to five years in federal prison on the false
statement charge and each of the four counts of tax evasion. Making a false
statement also carries a possible $250,000 fine, while the tax evasion charges
could result in a $100,000 fine on each conviction.

Internal Revenue Service-Criminal Investigation, FBI, and the Texas Rangers
investigated. Assistant United States Attorney James McAlister is prosecuting.

An indictment is a formal accusation of criminal conduct, not evidence. A
defendant is presumed innocent unless convicted through due process of law.

                                WEB ONLY EDITION

Two former Pittsburghers charged with harboring illegal workers

BYLINE: Paula Reed Ward, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 347 words


This story appears in a shorter version in today's print edition of the
Post-Gazette. This web version below contains more information and is being
included in the library database for that reason.


Two men who ran staffing services businesses in Pittsburgh have been indicted in
federal court for harboring illegal workers from Eastern Europe.

Yaroslav Rochniak, 51, and Gregory Kucher, 62, both of Brooklyn, N.Y., and
formerly of Pittsburgh, are charged in each of the 37 counts.

They operated Citiwide Management Group, formed around October 2001, which later
changed its name to Citiwide MNGM Group Inc. in 2005; Bazil Services Inc.,
formed in November 2002; and Monro Services Inc., formed on Sept. 12, 2005.

Mr. Rochniak and Mr. Kucher are among six people indicted on Nov. 19 on charges
that include conspiracy, money laundering and tax evasion. The indictment was
unsealed yesterday.

According to the filing, the men set up a number of businesses in Western
Pennsylvania and Ohio in which they would contract with various businesses to
provide employees.

Though they did have some legitimate employees, they also employed at least 100
"out-of-status" aliens from Russia, Ukraine, Estonia and Lithuania, which means
that they entered the United States legally, but their visas had either expired
or they were not permitted to work while here.

The indictment also alleges that the men set up housing for the aliens and
arranged their transportation for work.

The defendants are accused of collecting more than $6.8 million on behalf of all
their workers and paying them nearly $5 million.

Other defendants include:

? Roman Kucher, 38, of Lakewood, Ohio

? Alexander Litt, 44, of Miami, Fla.

? Roman Litt, 63, of Staten Island, N.Y., and

? Yakov Shakhanov, 70, of Delray Beach, Fla.

Mr. Rochniak and Gregory Kucher's tax evasion charges stem from the failure to
pay more than $1.4 million in federal income tax, the indictment said.

The men are scheduled to be arraigned Dec. 22 before U.S. Magistrate Judge Amy
Reynolds Hay.

Paula Reed Ward can be reached at pward@post-gazette.com or 412-263-2620.

Jailhouse Notes

BYLINE: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

SECTION: Section E; Column 0; The Arts/Cultural Desk; ARTS, BRIEFLY; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 195 words


The rapper the Game was sentenced on Monday to 60 days in jail after pleading no
contest to felony possession of a firearm in a school zone, The Associated Press
reported. Under a plea agreement, two other counts against him were dropped, but
his sentence also includes 150 hours of community service and three years of
probation. The Game, 28, above, whose real name is Jayceon Terrell Taylor, was
accused of pulling a gun on an opposing player during a pickup basketball game
at a south Los Angeles school nearly a year ago. ... A three-judge court in Los
Angeles has denied an appeal by the R&B singer Ronald Isley of his 37-month
federal sentence for tax evasion. Mr. Isley, 66, a member of the Rock and Roll
Hall of Fame and one of the Isley Brothers, whose hits included ''Twist and
Shout,'' argued that his sentence was unreasonable because of his age and poor
health. The appellate court said the trial judge correctly ''balanced the need
to sanction Mr. Isley's 'pathological' tax evasion against the need to
accommodate Mr. Isley's poor health.'' Mr. Isley is in the Federal Correctional
Institution in Terre Haute, Ind. His projected release date is April 2010.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              May 11, 1982 Tuesday

Prosecutor   sums up   Moon case

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 223 words

DATELINE: New York NY


NEW YORK  (Reuter) - A prosecutor yesterday asked a jury to find
 Unification Church leader Rev. Sun Myung Moon guilty of tax evasion and
 conspiracy, saying he deliberately failed to report $150,000 in income.

In a long and emotional summation, prosecutor Jo Ann Harris asked the
 10-woman, two-man jury to reject defence claims that the money, earned on
 bank deposits made in Mr. Moon's name between 1973 and 1975, belonged to
 the church.
    'You can't always see the hands pulling the strings,' she told the
 jury at the end of the seven-week-long case, adding there was no doubt
 that in this case, Mr. Moon was pulling the strings.

She added there were 'too many closed doors, too many closed minds and
 too many closed mouths' for the prosecution to be able to show every bit
 and piece of what happened. But she maintained that the prosecution had
 proved its charges against Mr. Moon and co-defendent Takeru Kamiyama, a
 close aide.

Mr. Moon, a Korean-born evangelist who took up residence in the United
 States in 1973, is charged with tax evasion and conspiracy.

The prosecution contends that Mr. Moon deposited $1.6-million in
 accounts at a U.S. bank that bore his name. These accounts earned interest
 of $150,000 between 1973 and 1975 which was not reported as income.

The defence contends the money belonged to the church and was tax
 exempt.

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                             April 14, 2009 Tuesday

Man admits to $500,000 tax evasion

BYLINE: Erin L. Nissley, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 363 words


Apr. 14--A Wayne County businessman will have to pay more than $500,000 in back
taxes after he admitted today to lying on Internal Revenue Service documents in
2003 and 2004.

Richard Harsche, 44, of Paupack Twp., pleaded guilty in federal court to tax
evasion. He remains free pending sentencing, a date for which has not been set.

In 2003, Mr. Harsche filled out tax return documents listing his taxable income
as $30,475, according to information provided in court this morning. But IRS
investigators say his taxable income was actually $411,983 and that he owed an
additional $140,479 in unpaid taxes.

Assistant U.S. Attorney William Houser said Mr. Harsche hid taxable income from
the IRS by writing off the purchase of a vacation home in Florida as a business
expense. Mr. Harsche also deposited about $103,000 into Swiss bank accounts,
writing them off as "interest expenses."

Mr. Harsche also admitted to lying in IRS documents pertaining to a settlement
he proposed for taxes he owed in 1992 through 1994. Mr. Houser said Mr. Harsche
offered to pay $65,340 but failed to list his ownership interest in a number of
corporations he controlled, including Home Consultants Inc. The corporations had
real estate holdings of more than $1 million. Home Consultants Inc., also known
as HCI Mortgage, also had a net value of more than $1 million, Mr. Houser said.

Because of the misrepresentations, Mr. Harsche underpaid by more than $110,000,
Mr. Houser told U.S. District Judge Edwin M. Kosik.

Mr. Harsche's attorney, Ernest Preate Jr., said his client received "bad advice"
from several people and will take responsibility for his actions.

"That's why he was here today," Mr. Preate said. "He will pay the money back."

Read more in Wednesday's Times-Tribune.

                               The New York Times

                 June 20, 1998, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

Four Executives Are Convicted in a Fuel-Tax Scheme

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

SECTION: Section B; Page 4; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 651 words

DATELINE: NEWARK, June 19


Four fuel company executives were convicted today for their roles in a scheme
that cheated the Federal and state governments out of more than $140 million in
fuel taxes.

The case centered on a fuel company based in Brooklyn that prosecutors said was
owned by Russian organized crime figures, and it revealed the growing reach of
the Russian mob throughout the metropolitan region.

Federal law enforcement officials praised the verdict by a jury in Federal
District Court in Camden, N.J., and called the fraud case the largest involving
oil taxes. Federal prosecutors are committed to "bringing to justice those who
rip off state and Federal taxing authorities," said Robert J. Cleary, the first
assistant United States attorney for the District of New Jersey.

The conspiracy hinged on a tax code provision under which oil is sold tax free
as home heating oil but is taxed when sold as diesel fuel for other uses.
According to the evidence presented by the prosecutors, the Brooklyn company,
Kings Motor Oils Inc., bought 666 million gallons of home heating oil tax free,
and the oil was later resold as diesel fuel. Customers buying the diesel fuel
were charged the heavy taxes, the prosecutors said, and the conspirators
pocketed the money instead of turning it over to the state and Federal
governments.

The fuel was passed through a series of middle companies, creating a trail of
invoices and other paperwork that falsely indicated that the taxes had been
properly paid, the prosecutors said. Ultimately, the oil was sold to Petroplus
Petroleum, a family-owned business in Deptford, N.J., which reaped huge profits
both by keeping part of the diverted tax money and reselling the oil to
customers at reduced prices.

The president of Petroplus, Daniel Enright of Mullica Hill, N.J., was one of the
four executives convicted today after a nine-month trial before Judge Joseph E.
Irenas. Mr. Enright was convicted of 38 charges, including tax evasion, money
laundering, wire fraud and conspiracy.

Robert G. Stahl, a special assistant United States attorney who prosecuted the
case, said that Mr. Enright and his company had received more than $50 million
in the scheme, the largest single share of the diverted taxes. Mr. Enright, like
the other suspects, was indicted in 1995 after a long undercover investigation
by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Internal Revenue Service.

"Enright was one of the largest people in this bootleg fuel business," Mr. Stahl
said. Petroplus reduced its prices so much that it was able to woo customers
from the major oil companies and attract buyers up and down the East Coast, Mr.
Stahl said.

The owners of Kings Motor Oils, Igor Erlikh of Brooklyn and Aaron Misulovin of
East Hills, N.Y., both Russian immigrants, are fugitives. The Federal
authorities are seeking them, but believe they have fled the country. One of
their partners, Demetrios Karamanos, a Greek citizen who lived in Norwood, N.J.,
was convicted today on tax evasion, fraud, laundering and conspiracy charges.
Investigators said Mr. Karamanos was an expert on the fuel industry who helped
mastermind the scheme.

The jury also convicted Mary Ingram of Woodbridge, N.J., the president of
American Minority Petroleum, a wholesale oil distributor in Woodbridge, of tax
evasion, wire fraud, laundering and conspiracy charges. Richard Pedroni of
Clermont, N.J., who was president of Pedroni Fuel Company in Vineland, N.J., was
convicted of conspiracy.

The various charges carry potential maximum sentences ranging from 5 to 10 years
and fines of as much as $250,000 on each count. The Federal Government is also
seeking $2.6 million from the executives based on the money-laundering and tax
evasion charges.

The jury acquitted John Ruocco of Jackson, N.J., who was an employee of American
Minority, and Michael Lipkin of Manhattan, who had worked for Kings Motor Oils.

                                The Toronto Star

                     June 13, 1995, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Helmsley servants 'worked community service

BYLINE: AP)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 323 words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Leona Helmsley's employees say they were made to do the community service the
hotel queen was ordered to perform as part of her tax-evasion sentence, the New
York Daily News reports.

Helmsley, 74, instructed the domestic workers to do chores such as wrapping
gifts to be given to patients at an Arizona hospital and stuffing thousands of
envelopes for a charity drive, the newspaper said yesterday, citing unidentified
employees.

Helmsley then allegedly misled probation officers into thinking she had done the
work herself, the newspaper said.

She was released from a Connecticut prison in October, 1993, and was put on
three years' probation that included 250 hours of community service a year.

Some of the gifts to be distributed by volunteers at Scottsdale Memorial
Hospital were wrapped at Helmsley's home in Paradise Valley, Ariz., one employee
told The Daily News.

Another worker said that as many as 700 small boxes - some containing key chains
Helmsley bought - were wrapped by maids, handymen and other domestic workers.

The second employee was quoted as saying Helmsley referred to the work "as her
community service. She laughed about it."

Helmsley's personal assistant, Hubie Weyer, told The Daily News his boss had no
comment on the allegations.

Ed Mahoney, deputy chief of the U.S. Probation Office in New York, said he was
prohibited from discussing the terms of Helmsley's community service.

But he denied that his office was lax in supervising her.

"She would be the last one we would let slip through the cracks," he said.

Helmsley was convicted in 1989 of tax evasion and sent to a federal prison in
Danbury, Conn., on April 15, 1992 - tax day.

The poor health of her husband, Harry, led a federal judge to reduce her
sentence to 21 months from 30 months.

She served 18 months in prison, a month in a halfway house and two months of
house arrest in her own posh Manhattan hotel.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                            February 5, 2016 Friday

Sports briefs for Feb. 5, 2016

BYLINE: Joe McLaughlin BDN Staff

LENGTH: 592 words


Louisville self-imposes postseason ban for 2016


Louisville has self-imposed a postseason ban on its men's basketball team for
this season, the school announced Friday.


The penalties come amid the NCAA's ongoing investigation into an alleged
recruiting scandal involving paid escorts at Louisville.


The school informed the team's players in a meeting Friday and announced the
sanctions at a news conference Friday afternoon.


Head coach Rick Pitino's No. 19 Cardinals have an 18-4 record and are in second
place in the Atlantic Coast Conference.


"I recognize that this is a significant penalty for our program," said
university president James R. Ramsey, who was accompanied at Friday's news
conference by athletic director Tom Jurich and Pitino.


According to the Courier-Journal, the coaches told the players before the
announcement that they only had nine games left, which is the remainder of the
regular season. The Cardinals host Boston College on Saturday.


Cowboys not interested in Manziel


Embattled quarterback Johnny Manziel continues to have off-the-field issues that
have made it a certainty the Cleveland Browns will be releasing him.


The Dallas Cowboys have been frequently mentioned as a possible landing spot for
Manziel. But that apparently might not be an option, according to a report in
the Fort Worth Star-Telegram.


The newspaper stated that the Cowboys had no interest in Manziel even before his
latest issues, which include an altercation with ex-girlfriend Colleen Crowley
at a Dallas hotel last Saturday.


Crowley said she was hit by Manziel during the incident. Police filed a report
but decided against filing charges against Manziel because Crowley declined to
cooperate.


Manziel was dumped by agent Erik Burkhardt in the aftermath. In addition, Paul
Manziel, Johnny's father, expressed publicly that his 23-year-old son needs
professional help and might not "live to see his 24th birthday."


But because Cowboys owner Jerry Jones professed a liking for Manziel and lobbied
for the club to choose the former Texas A&M star in the first round of the 2014
NFL Draft, speculation persists that the Cowboys are an option.


Burress receives probation for tax evasion


Former NFL receiver Plaxico Burress was sentenced to five years' probation for
tax evasion, a judged in New Jersey ruled on Friday.


Burress was given five years to repay the state of New York $56,000 in back
taxes or face a prison sentence.


Burress will receive a 364-day jail sentence if he fails to make the
reimbursements.


The former Super Bowl hero with the New York Giants admitted that he didn't pay
$46,000 in state taxes when he made $1 million in 2013.


Suns sign NBA D-League all-star


The Phoenix Suns signed NBA Developmental League all-star guard Orlando Johnson
to a 10-day contract on Friday.


Johnson has spent this season with Austin in the D-League and averaged 15.2
points in 28 games. He was named to the all-star team on Jan. 29. The two-year
NBA veteran played for the Indiana Pacers in 2012-13 and the Sacramento Kings in
2013-14. In 96 NBA games, Johnson has averaged 3.2 points and 1.7 rebounds, with
a career high of 15 points for the Pacers in a 2013 game against the Atlanta
Hawks.


Johnson also spent last season with Austin, averaging 17.4 points in 43 games,
and previously played professionally in Spain and the Philippines.


Bruins send forward to AHL


The Boston Bruins assigned forward Joonas Kemppainen to Providence of the
American Hockey League.


Kemppainen, 27, is in his first NHL season and has appeared in 35 games with
Boston, tallying one goal and two assists.

                         The Herald-Sun (Durham, N.C.)

                           February 3, 2016 Wednesday

Man pleads guilty to tax evasion, being uncertified pilot

SECTION: W-STATE; A; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 333  words


WASHINGTON - Federal prosecutors say a North Carolina man has pleaded guilty to
tax evasion and operating as a pilot without proper certification.

The Department of Justice said 53-year-old Paul Douglas Tharp of Greensboro
entered his plea on Tuesday.

Court documents say Tharp attempted to evade payment of an outstanding federal
income tax debt by filing false documents, including false federal tax returns
from 2011 through 2014. After Tharp failed to file tax returns for the years
2003 through 2006, the Internal Revenue Service assessed income taxes for those
years.

The court documents said Tharp owed more than $300,000 in taxes for the years
2003 through 2007. In 2011, Tharp provided a false statement to an IRS revenue
officer assigned to collect his unpaid taxes, on which he failed to report that
he owned an airport and an investment firm, and concealed his business bank
accounts and rental income he had received under penalty of perjury.

In 2012 and 2014, Tharp also filed tax returns for the 2011 through 2013 tax
years on which he omitted significant income that he received from his airport
and rental properties.

As part of his plea, Tharp - who surrendered his pilot license in 2012 - also
admitted he served as a pilot without the required certification at least four
times that year.

In May 2014, Tharp pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court, Charlotte, North
Carolina, to serving as an airman without an airman's certificate and providing
false statements to a Federal Aviation Administration investigator. The
following March, he was sentenced to 60 days incarceration, three years of
probation, and ordered to pay a $5,000 fine.

In his current case, Tharp is scheduled for sentencing on April 22. He faces up
to five years in prison for the tax evasion charge and three years in prison for
each count of serving as a pilot without an airman's certificate, as well as a
maximum fine of $250,000 for each count of conviction. He must also pay
$281,366.62 in restitution to the IRS.

                               The New York Times

                             April 16, 2010 Friday
                              Late Edition - Final

2 Charged in International Tax Evasion Scheme Said to Involve HSBC

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: Section B; Column 0; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 858 words


Federal authorities arrested two property developers, a father and son, on
Thursday and charged them with participating in a multimillion-dollar tax
evasion scheme through a large international bank.

The property developers  --  Mauricio Cohen Assor and his son, Leon Cohen-Levy
--  were taken into custody in New York, a day after they were jointly charged
in a criminal complaint filed in Federal District Court in Fort Lauderdale,
Fla., court papers show.

The bank was identified as HSBC by a person who was briefed on the matter but
spoke on condition of not being identified because the investigation is
continuing.

The arrests underscore how federal authorities are broadening their
investigation into offshore tax fraud to include private banks other than the
Swiss giant UBS, the focal point of the Justice Department's crackdown on
financial firms that sell tax evasion services.

In addition to UBS, prosecutors have been scrutinizing HSBC, one of the world's
largest private banks, which is based in London but has large Swiss operations,
and other Swiss institutions.

The two developers have been embroiled in a long-running legal dispute over
their involvement with the Flatotel, a luxury apartment-style hotel in Midtown
Manhattan. They sold the hotel around 2000 for $33 million but routed the
proceeds through accounts concealed by sham entities established in Panama, the
British Virgin Islands, Liechtenstein, Switzerland and the Bahamas, court papers
show. They did not pay taxes on the sale.

From 1987 through at least 2001, the men opened various accounts in the names of
the foreign entities and shell companies and used unidentified Swiss lawyers as
signatories for some of the accounts.

The bank knew that the two men were the true owners of the accounts and
entities, court papers said, but it allowed them to pretend otherwise for tax
purposes. ''The bankers who handled the accounts knew and documented'' that
Mauricio Cohen Assor  in particular was the real owner behind the entities and
accounts, the complaint said.

The complaint against the  developers describes how federal agents used wiretaps
--  an unusual move in tax cases  --  in 2007 to record their phone
conversations with an  unidentified banker.

Both men are Spanish natives; Leon Cohen-Levy, who lives part of the year on
Fisher Island, Fla., became a United States citizen in 2003, and Mauricio Cohen
Assor, of Miami Beach, won permanent residency status in 2005. Their lawyers
could not be reached for comment.

Court papers said that  a large international bank knowingly allowed the men to
engage in tax fraud through the bank while acquiring their citizenship and
residency papers because the bank did not require them to fill out the necessary
disclosure forms with the Internal Revenue Service.

The men appear to have routed at least $65 million in cash and bonds through
their offshore accounts, court papers show. They used their accounts ''to fund a
luxury lifestyle for themselves and for their family members,'' including
purchases of a $188,000 Bentley and $67,000 Dodge Viper, the complaint shows.

HSBC declined to comment.

Leon Cohen-Levy sought in recent years to build a 93-story apartment-hotel
skyscraper called Empire World Towers in downtown Miami, a project that would
have been one of the tallest residential high-rises in the world.

But  the deal stalled in 2008 when a New York State Supreme Court judge ruled
against him and his father over separate fraud accusations brought by a French
lender regarding the Flatotel. The judge rendered a $266 million default
judgment against the men.

Separately Thursday, the authorities charged five former American clients of UBS
with evading taxes in offshore accounts at UBS's private bank. Two other former
clients waived indictment and pleaded guilty. The group of seven collectively
evaded taxes on $100 million in assets, court papers show.

UBS paid a $780 million fine last year and admitted criminal wrongdoing in
connection with offshore tax evasion services sold to wealthy Americans through
its private bank.

The UBS clients indicted on Thursday in the Southern District of New York were
Shmuel  Sternfeld, of Tel Aviv; Sybil Nancy Upham, of New York; Ernest Vogliano,
of New York; Richard Werdiger, a jewel merchant from Purchase, N.Y.; and Kenneth
Heller, a disbarred maritime lawyer in New York.

The two other former UBS clients who pleaded guilty are Federico Hernandez, a
former money manager in New York; and Jules Robbins, a watch distributor from
Jericho, N.Y.

The actions bring to 16 the number of American former UBS clients charged in the
Justice Department's investigation.

The UBS clients were variously accused of using sham offshore entities in Hong
Kong, Panama and elsewhere, including one known as Real Cool Investments Ltd.,
to further disguise their ownership of the UBS accounts.

Prosecutors also accused some of them of shifting assets out of UBS to smaller
banks in Switzerland and Liechtenstein when UBS came  under scrutiny in 2008,
and of  carrying cash by hand into the United States from Switzerland without
declaring it.

                               The New York Times

                               May 2, 2004 Sunday
                              Late Edition - Final

A Sour Note

BYLINE: By JEREMY PEARCE

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1805 words


FOR the last week, barely a sound has been coming from the New Jersey Symphony
Orchestra.

Although bristling with 30 antique string instruments -- including rare Italian
violins by Stradivarius, Guarneri del Gesu and other master makers -- the
orchestra's administrators were sending a muted message about their recent
multimillion-dollar purchase from Herbert R. Axelrod, who has been indicted on
federal charges of tax evasion and fled to Havana.

Lawrence J. Tamburri, the former executive director and a past trustee of the
orchestra -- who was the principle broker of the deal -- declined to comment on
the controversy. Dr. Victor Parsonnet, chairman of the orchestra's board, had
this to say, ''We had appraisers of our own that said one way or another that we
were getting good value.''

Retreat may be an understandable response, given the status of Mr. Axelrod, the
orchestra's benefactor and a storyteller of bravura scale, who is himself now an
international fugitive from justice. Mr. Axelrod, a millionaire publisher of pet
books and violin collector, sold his instruments to the orchestra for $18
million last year. The deal was consummated only after a fitful courtship in
which the entrepreneur boasted that rival European symphonies were waiting in
the wings to as much as $50 million.

More than a week ago, when federal authorities indicted him on charges of tax
evasion, the 76-year-old Mr. Axelrod fled from his multimillion-dollar home in
Deal, on the Jersey Shore, to the mobile refuge of a yacht moored at the Marina
Hemingway in Havana, where he said he planned to spend his newfound retirement
deep-sea fishing and composing fresh tunes rather than face the possibility of
five years in prison and fines of $250,000.

''It is difficult to represent someone in absentia,'' conceded Michael B.
Himmel, a lawyer from Woodbridge who is defending Mr. Axelrod in the tax case.
Mr. Himmel added that he had not heard from the pet publisher since April 21,
when a federal judge in Trenton issued a warrant for his client's arrest.

But the grander question of the moment was to measure what, if any, aftershock
from Mr. Axelrod's public implosion would reach the striving New Jersey Symphony
Orchestra. Just last year, the orchestra began a five-year fund-raising campaign
with the intention of attracting $51.2 million for its endowments as well as to
pay off the $18 million borrowed to acquire the Axelrod collection.

In recent years, the shaky economy has proved especially difficult for the arts,
and the symphony accrued a budget deficit of $2 million during the last fiscal
year. A spokesman for the orchestra credited the arrival of the new instruments
and the appointment of a renowned conductor, Neeme Jarvi, with a boon of $11
million in donations in the past year.

Still, things are not so simple. Since Mr. Axelrod's disappearance, symphony
officials have rushed forward to declare the authenticity of the instruments.
Yet they have been willing to say little more, leaving open-ended whether the
institution's reputation will suffer embarrassment or something worse by
association with their fugitive donor.

In the wider world of the arts, news of the symphony's situation brought mixed
reactions, shaded perhaps by the performers' traditional conviction that
publicity of any stripe results in larger audiences.

Lawrence Goldman, president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing
Arts Center, which is home to the symphony, said: ''I think this is actually
going to help future fund-raising. Acquiring these instruments was a long-range
decision.''

Preferring to look toward the horizon, Mr. Goldman added: ''When all the dust
clears, this is all about 30 golden-age instruments. Ten years from now, 50
years from now, that's all anybody is going to care about.''

But Ann Marie Miller, executive director of Artpride New Jersey, a Bordentown
advocacy group that lobbies for arts financing, sounded more circumspect, even
as she said the symphony was not likely to suffer harm in the longer term.

''If anything, this sends a signal to the arts community at large to be
careful,'' said Ms. Miller, who has worked as a fund-raiser for the McCarter
Theater in Princeton. ''It is a forewarning and a caution to the rest of the
nonprofit world. All donations carry some level of risk, and everyone in our
world is accountable, even the trustees, who are accountable to the greater
audience.''

Dr. Parsonnet has previously hinted that the actual value of the collection
might lie closer to $25 million, or about half of what Mr. Axelrod claimed the
instruments were worth. For now, the orchestra has insured the instruments for
$48.9 million, which is what Mr. Axelrod had them insured for with Lloyd's of
London.

''My sense is that a price of $50 million is way out of bounds,'' said Claire
Givens, a violin dealer in Minneapolis who was attending an instrument auction
in New York last week. ''Otherwise, the seller wouldn't have settled for $18
million.''

Yet one trustee did step forward to deny that any collusion took place that
would have heightened the collection's value for Mr. Axelrod's tax benefit.
Scott A. Kobler, a Newark lawyer and trustee who helped represent the symphony
during the sale, cited the institution's ''scrutiny and due diligence.''

''We were completely and categorically not in complicity with Dr. Axelrod,''
said Mr. Kobler, a former chairman of the New Jersey Public Broadcasting
Authority. ''We never agreed with Dr. Axelrod about his valuation of the
instruments, but he did provide an appraisal of an internationally recognized
person.''

As he explained, ''the symphony has no knowledge if Dr. Axelrod ever took a tax
deduction for those instruments. In fact, we never gave him a receipt.''

One symphony official who declined to be identified said the collection had been
examined by three experts in the course of negotiations, but that an actual
appraisal had not been conducted. The official added that Mr. Axelrod's past
appraisals were reviewed, although not accepted as accurate. Still, it was
decided that the costs of commissioning a fresh appraisal -- a percentage of the
valuation of all the instruments -- would been prohibitive. In a characteristic
flight of fancy, Mr. Axelrod himself suggested that the collection could soar in
value to $100 million over the next decade.

But in the end, the orchestra will be paying somewhat less than the decided
price. It borrowed $9 million from Commerce Bank, another $5 million from the
Prudential Foundation and the remaining $4 million from Mr. Axelrod, who, before
fleeing, forgave $1 million and assigned $3 million in notes to several
nonprofit groups, in effect making a donation as he departed the country. That
left the final price at $17 million.

Gabriella Morris, president of the Prudential Foundation and a symphony trustee,
said that she had seen the instruments' valuations and was fully satisfied with
the deal.

''There was no complicity here,'' she said, echoing Mr. Kobler's phrase.

She paused before continuing: ''As far as we're concerned, we don't really care
what they're worth, above the $18 million. Our process was a credible one, and
the values were supported. Appraisal by media is not credible.''

Not accountable at the moment is Mr. Axelrod, who holds a doctoral degree in
education from New York University and prefers the honorific doctor. In his
50-year ascent in the publishing world, Mr. Axelrod, a native of Bayonne,
crested the wave of post-war American pet mania, writing such guides as ''Dr.
Axelrod's Atlas of Freshwater and Aquarium Fishes'' and creating T.F.H.
Publications, which stands for ''tropical fish hobbyist.'' His carefully tended
biography details him as an inventor, explorer, scientist, musician,
environmentalist, bon vivant and a once-favored companion of such notables as
Emperor Hirohito and Winston Churchill.

But the facts were often at variance with Mr. Axelrod's claims, according to an
article in The Sunday Star-Ledger last week. Although he earned his doctorate in
education from N.Y.U., he regularly told people that he had earned a Ph.D. in
medicine. Moreover, charges of plagiarism have followed some of his books, and
through the years Mr. Axelrod has been accused of unscrupulous business
practices. The latest charges, detailed in the federal indictment, include
accusations that he employed a Swiss bank account to hide hundreds of thousands
of dollars in income.

Though he accumulated his share of detractors, Mr. Axelrod also won over many,
using part of his wealth for philanthropic purposes. For instance, he donated a
collection of fish fossils to the University of Guelph, in Canada, although a
former university official now says that he exaggerated their value of $24
million.

In 1997, he donated a quartet of string instruments -- two violins, a cello and
a viola, all made by the great Stradivarius -- to the Smithsonian. At the time,
the quartet was valued at about $50 million, a figure that has not been
questioned. In New Jersey, he has also given to hospitals and community centers
as well as the orchestra.

It was the Axelrod collection of instruments that has been credited with helping
lure Mr. Jarvi, the Estonian musician who was previously maestro at the Detroit
Symphony, to Newark. Mr. Jarvi announced his appointment as music director
designate in October, and cited his excitement at the prospect of deploying New
Jersey's new array of instruments.

Jill Woodward, a spokeswoman for the Detroit Symphony, said it was rare for any
American orchestra to own a quartet of string instruments, much less 30 period
instruments that include 24 violins, 4 cellos and 2 violas made by some of
Italy's pre-eminent makers of the 17th and 18th centuries. It is estimated that
fewer than 7,000 Italian instruments of such pedigree exist in the world.

''It would be unusual to ever see New Jersey's situation again,'' Ms. Woodward
said. ''The donor would have to be Bill Gates.''

Time and court proceedings should tell if Mr. Axelrod's legacy is ultimately
remembered as the Axelrod collection. Some of the instruments are scheduled to
be played today, in Plainsboro as part of a children's concert called ''Carnival
of the Animals,'' composed by Saint-Saens. Still, it is almost certain that the
family name will continue to pop up in headlines and at other venues.

In Ocean Township, at the Ruth Hyman Jewish Community Center, builders are
nearing completion of a 600-seat concert hall. Jess Levy, executive director of
the center, said that Mr. Axelrod and his wife, Evelyn Miller Axelrod, had both
given ''generously'' toward the construction, although he declined to say how
much. The whereabouts of Mrs. Axelrod are unknown, according to lawyers.

''I will say,'' Mr. Levy said, ''that the concert hall will bear their name.''

              August 21, 1985, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. RELEASES MOON, ENDING PRISON TERM ON TAX FRAUD COUNT

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 340 words


The Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the Korean evangelist who heads the Unification Church,
was released today from a Brooklyn halfway house after serving 13 months of an
18-month sentence for tax evasion.

Mr. Moon, 65 years old, was convicted in May 1982 of failing to report $162,000
in income on his Federal tax returns. He appealed to the Supreme Court, but it
refused to hear his case, and he began serving his sentence on July 20, 1984.

He spent 11 1/2 months in the medium-security Federal prison in Danbury, Conn.,
then was moved to the halfway house. He had to report to the house every evening
but was allowed to conduct church business during the day.

Jeff Garbow, a spokesman for the Danbury prison, said Mr. Moon was given time
off for good behavior.

In Washington yesterday, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, head of the Moral Majority, and
the Rev. Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership
Conference, called on President Reagan to pardon Mr. Moon. They said government
was increasingly intruding in religious matters.

In another action involving the church, a South Korean national who admitted
kidnapping a top assistant of Mr. Moon last year was sentenced to 15 years in
prison yesterday after he pleaded guilty to conspiracy and attempted extortion
charges.

The man, Yung Soo Suh, 49, admitted in Federal District Court in Manhattan that
he led a group that kidnapped the church official, Col. Bo Hi Pak, in Manhattan
last September and held him in upstate Orange County.

Colonel Pak, who served as acting head of the church during the imprisonment of
its leader, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, on tax-evasion charges, was held for two
days. He was rleased when he agreed to transfer $500,000 in church funds to his
kidnappers' secret Swiss bank account.

Six men, all Korean natives, were arrested two months after the kidnapping.
Charges were dropped against three and another was acquitted of kidnapping
charges. The last defendant, a retired South Korean Marine general, Sang Whi
Nam, is to go on trial Nov. 18.

Girls Gone Wild" jailbird Joe Francis had his first good news in a while

"I'm very pleased with the events today. It's a sign of things to come," Francis

will be another [similar lawsuit] that will follow it."

Brooke Patsolic and Christina Brose had claimed they were plied with alcohol
(before they were 21) and did not know their sexual antics would end up on

But after Francis posted video of them consenting to be filmed on his Web site,

Along with his tax evasion problem in Nevada, Francis also faces a contempt of
court rap relating to dropped felony charges in Florida.

                              May 10, 2016 Tuesday

Olson appeals sentence on tax evasion charges; his attorney wants out

BYLINE: Alyssa Dandrea, The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 784 words


May 10--A Rindge man who swindled roughly 100 people out of millions of dollars
in a Ponzi scheme is appealing his prison sentence on related convictions for
attempted tax evasion.

Aaron E. Olson's appeal, filed in the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First
Circuit in Boston, comes just weeks after a U.S. District Court judge sentenced
him to five years in prison instead of the 3 1/2  years attorneys had jointly
recommended.

The appeal is the latest in a case that has spanned two years, three different
lawyers and included multiple delays.

The latest attorney to ask to leave Olson's case is Michael J. Connolly, who
represented Olson at his April 1 sentencing in Concord. Connolly filed a motion
Thursday to withdraw from the case, citing irreconcilable differences and a
breakdown in the attorney-client relationship.

Kevin E. Sharkey, who represented Olson until February, provided the court with
similar reasoning in his motion to withdraw, which a judge granted.

Connolly is the third lawyer to represent Olson since the U.S. Attorney's Office
levied criminal charges in early 2014. Connolly has until May 20 to file
documentation in support of his motion, which the appellate court initially
denied without prejudice Friday absent those filings.

Olson was next scheduled to appear May 26 in Concord for a restitution hearing
to determine how much his victims are owed; however, he recently waived that
constitutional right.

Court documents do not detail why Olson chose to waive his appearance at the
hearing, which as of this morning was still scheduled for May 26 at 3 p.m.

U.S. District Court Judge Landya B. McCafferty granted April 20 Olson's request
to be excused from the hearing and ordered him immediately transferred to FMC
Devens, a federal correctional facility in Ayer, Mass., to serve out his time.
Olson had been incarcerated at the Strafford County jail in Dover before his
transfer.

At his sentencing last month, Olson heard emotional statements from two of the
more than 100 people who invested with his illegitimate firms, AEO Associates
and KMO Associates, between 2007 and 2010.

Federal prosecutors estimate Olson swindled investors out of nearly $28 million
in those years, but his victims say they lost millions more before the collapse
of the Ponzi scheme in early 2012. One victim maintains in court documents that
he alone lost $45 million, but Olson refutes that claim.

Olson was originally scheduled to be sentenced in September 2014 on four counts
of attempted tax evasion, for understating the federal income taxes he owed from
2007 through 2010 by more than $664,000. Though he pleaded guilty, he later
withdrew his pleas after saying he'd misunderstood the maximum prison term he
could face.

He re-entered guilty pleas to those charges in March 2015.

Olson remained out of jail on bail conditions until last month. But on the
afternoon of April 1, U.S. Marshals took him away in handcuffs after McCafferty
handed down a sentence of five years in prison and three years probation. She
disagreed with attorneys from both sides, who recommended a sentence of 3 1/2
years as part of a plea agreement.

She told Olson he had two years, while out of prison on bail conditions, to show
remorse and begin paying back his victims.

He did neither, she said.

"I don't question you're genuinely remorseful in your heart," she said. "I can't
question that."

But McCafferty did question why Olson hadn't written apology letters, or set
aside $10 or $100 a week in a victims' fund to show he was making an effort to
right his wrongs.

"You've been blessed with many gifts," she said, while referencing the large
family, as well as the close-knit, religious community, he grew up in. "Rather
than using these gifts, you actually exploited them with personal gain."

After he was charged, Olson had focused his attention on reopening the
long-dormant Webb Hill Quarry in Fitzwilliam that he purchased in September 2011
through KMO Associates. From the start, though, that plan was met with strong
opposition from residents who vocally opposed the plan, which they believed
would open the door to mining in their backyards.

Olson tried unsuccessfully to delay the start of his prison sentence until later
this month to close a prospective $100,000 sale of previously quarried stone
from Webb Hill. McCafferty denied the request, saying it was too speculative and
provided her with no assurance that Olson's victims would benefit.

Alyssa Dandrea can be reached at 352-1234, extension 1435, or
adandrea@keenesentinel.com Follow her on Twitter @ADandreaKS.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            October 23, 2015 Friday

Federal Grand Jury Adds Wire Fraud and Tax Evasion Charges, as Well as New
Victims, to Fraud Case Against Orange County Attorney

LENGTH: 541  words


LOS ANGELES--An attorney who was indicted in September for allegedly stealing
several million dollars from clients was named yesterday in a new indictment
that adds additional wire fraud counts, as well as tax evasion and identity
theft charges, to the case.

Stephen Young Kang, 46, of Newport Beach, is now charged in a 30-count
superseding indictment that was returned yesterday afternoon by a federal grand
jury.

The indictment filed in United States District Court in Los Angeles charges Kang
with 22 counts of wire fraud, three counts of money laundering, two counts of
aggravated identity theft and three counts of tax evasion. The indictment also
contains forfeiture allegations that would require Kang to surrender ill-gotten
gains if he is convicted of criminal charges.

The new indictment re-alleges wire fraud and money laundering charges contained
in the original indictment, which was filed on September 1 and alleged that Kang
defrauded a corporation and a couple seeking to make investments related to
applications for EB-5 visas (see: http://go.usa.gov /3SdpJ).

The new fraud allegations concern three additional victims--including one who
came forward in response to the FBI's call for additional victims when Kang was
initially indicted--who collectively suffered losses of more than $1 million.
The three additional victims gave money to Kang for investment purposes, but the
attorney allegedly used the money for his own personal and business expenses.

The superseding indictment further alleges that Kang committed identity theft
when he used the names and forged signatures of two individuals without legal
authority during and in relation to the alleged fraud scheme.

Kang is now also charged with receiving substantial taxable income and willfully
attempting to evade paying his taxes in the years 2012 through 2014.

Kang was arrested on August 10 by special agents with the FBI and IRS--Criminal
Investigation at Los Angeles International Airport as he attempted to board a
flight to Seoul, Korea. He is currently free on a $750,000 bond.

Kang will be summoned to appear in United States District Court to be arraigned
on the superseding indictment in the near future. At present, he is scheduled to
go to trial in this case on November 3.

If convicted of the charges in the indictment, Kang faces a statutory maximum
penalty of 20 years in federal prison for each of the wire fraud charges, up to
10 years in prison for each of the money laundering offenses, five years in
prison for the each of the tax evasion charges, and a mandatory two-year
consecutive term of imprisonment for the identity theft charges.

An indictment contains allegations that a defendant has committed a crime. Every
defendant is presumed innocent until and unless proven guilty in court.

Based on the evidence in this case, investigators believe Kang may have
victimized others in locations where he practiced law or resided, including
California, Texas, and Seoul, Korea. Anyone who believes they may have been
victimized by Kang should contact the FBI's Los Angeles Field Office at (310)
477-6565.

The case against Kang is the product of an ongoing investigation by the Federal
Bureau of Investigation and IRS--Criminal Investigation. 2015 Legal Monitor
Worldwide.

                           January 19, 2011 Wednesday

[Exclusive] Korea seeks US help to combat overseas tax evasion

BYLINE: By Kim Jae-won

LENGTH: 448 words


Victor Song, chief of U.S. Internal Revenue Service Criminal Investigation
(IRS-CI), will visit Seoul next week to discuss cooperation with Korean tax
officials in cracking down on offshore tax evasion.

According to a source in the National Tax Service (NTS), Song's visit follows
the NTS announcing its intention to track unreported capital transfers involving
companies and individuals.

The NTS has vowed to increase tax revenue by 1 trillion won by cracking down on
overseas tax evasion.

Song is scheduled to meet two assistant commissioners, who are responsible for
executing overseas initiatives, a high-ranking official of the agency said
Wednesday on condition of anonymity.

'The two assistant commissioners are responsible for international taxation and
investigation,' said the official. Park Yun-joon is in charge of the
International Taxation Bureau, while Kim Yeon-keun is head of the investigation
division.

The visit comes after the NTS unveiled its plan to get tough with large
businesses and affluent individuals who try to evade paying taxes on overseas
funds.

The U.S. is one of the most preferred destinations where Koreans'
unaccounted-for money ends up.

The NTS signed a Simultaneous Criminal Investigation Program (SCIP) agreement
with the IRS-CI in August 2010 to jointly investigate tax criminals by sharing
information on suspects and their associated parties engaging in economic
activities in both Korea and the U.S.

Song, the operations head of the SCIP, has full access to a wide range of
financial information, thus his visit is expected to help the NTS better detect
and track down criminal cases including the embezzlement of corporate funds
using U.S.-based vehicles.

The NTS detected hundreds of overseas tax evasion cases last year valued at 600
billion won ? it imposed 300 billion won in punitive and back taxes.

Song, a Korean American, joined the IRS in 1981 and became a special agent in
1983. The son of Korean immigrants has been in charge of numerous IRS-CI offices
before becoming a senior executive in 2004.

He became deputy chief in 2007, took the helm of the division in January 2010.
Song has a bachelor's degree in communications from the University of Hawaii.

Conglomerates and rich individuals have been criticized for dodging taxes using
overseas affiliates or accounts in foreign nations, respectively.

Hyosung Group is one example. The group has been under investigation by the
prosecution since 2009 over allegations that it created a slush fund through
subsidiaries in the United States. Cho Hyun-joon, president of the group and
first son of group Chairman Cho Suck-rai, allegedly used some of the money to
purchase a luxury house in California.

                        The International Herald Tribune

                            April 17, 2010 Saturday

HSBC linked to tax evasion charges against father and son in Florida;
Case shows how U.S. is looking beyond UBS in its investigations

BYLINE: BY LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: FINANCE; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 889 words

ABSTRACT

The arrests underscore how the U.S. authorities are investigating offshore tax
fraud by private banks other than the Swiss giant UBS, the focus of a U.S.
Justice Department crackdown.

FULL TEXT

The U.S. authorities have arrested two property developers, a father and son,
and charged them with participating in a multimillion-dollar tax evasion scheme
through a large international bank that is said to be HSBC.

The property developers - Mauricio Cohen Assor and his son, Leon Cohen-Levy -
were taken into custody in New York a day after they were jointly charged in a
criminal complaint filed in Federal District Court in Fort Lauderdale, Florida,
court papers show.

The bank was identified as HSBC by a person who had been briefed on the matter
but who spoke on condition of not being identified because the investigation was
continuing.

The arrests underscore the way the U.S. authorities are broadening their
investigation of offshore tax fraud to include private banks other than the
Swiss giant UBS, the focal point of the U.S. Justice Department's crackdown on
financial firms that sell tax evasion services.

In addition to UBS, prosecutors have been scrutinizing other Swiss institutions
and HSBC, one of the world's largest private banks, which is based in London but
has large Swiss operations.

The two developers have been embroiled in a long-running legal dispute over
their involvement with the Flatotel, a luxury apartment-style hotel in Midtown
Manhattan. They sold the hotel around 2000 for $33 million but routed the
proceeds through accounts concealed by sham entities established in Panama, the
British Virgin Islands, Liechtenstein, Switzerland and the Bahamas, court papers
show. They did not pay taxes on the sale.

From 1987 through at least 2001, the men opened various accounts in the names of
the foreign entities and shell companies and used unidentified Swiss lawyers as
signatories for some of the accounts.

The bank knew that the two men were the true owners of the accounts and
entities, court papers said, but it allowed them to pretend otherwise for tax
purposes. ''The bankers who handled the accounts knew and documented'' that
Mauricio Cohen Assor in particular was the real owner behind the entities and
accounts, the complaint said.

The complaint against the developers describes how U.S. agents used wiretaps -
an unusual move in tax cases - in 2007 to record their phone conversations with
an unidentified banker.

Both men are from Spain; Leon Cohen-Levy, who lives part of the year on Fisher
Island, Florida, became a U.S. citizen in 2003, and Mauricio Cohen Assor, of
Miami Beach, Florida, won permanent-resident status in 2005. Their lawyers could
not be reached for comment.

Court papers said that a large international bank had knowingly allowed the men
to engage in tax fraud through the bank while acquiring their citizenship and
residency papers because the bank had not required them to fill out required
disclosure forms with the Internal Revenue Service.

The men appear to have routed at least $65 million in cash and bonds through
their offshore accounts, court papers show. They used their accounts ''to fund a
luxury lifestyle for themselves and for their family members,'' including
purchases of a $188,000 Bentley and a $67,000 Dodge Viper, the complaint shows.

HSBC declined to comment.

Leon Cohen-Levy sought in recent years to build a 93-story apartment-hotel
skyscraper called Empire World Towers in downtown Miami, a project that would
have been one of the tallest residential high-rise buildings in the world.

But the deal stalled in 2008 when a New York State Supreme Court judge ruled
against him and his father over separate fraud accusations brought by a French
lender regarding the Flatotel. The judge rendered a $266 million default
judgment against the men.

Separately Thursday, the authorities charged five Americans who were former
clients of UBS with evading taxes in offshore accounts at UBS's private bank.
Two other former clients waived indictment and pleaded guilty. The group of
seven collectively evaded taxes on $100 million in assets, court papers show.

UBS paid a $780 million fine last year and admitted criminal wrongdoing in
connection with offshore tax evasion services sold to wealthy Americans through
its private bank.

The UBS clients indicted Thursday in the Southern District of New York were
Shmuel Sternfeld, of Tel Aviv; Sybil Nancy Upham, of New York; Ernest Vogliano,
of New York; Richard Werdiger, a jewel merchant from Purchase, New York; and
Kenneth Heller, a disbarred maritime lawyer in New York.

The two other former UBS clients who pleaded guilty were Federico Hernandez, a
former money manager in New York, and Jules Robbins, a watch distributor from
Jericho, New York.

The actions brought to 16 the number of American former UBS clients charged in
the Justice Department's investigation.

The UBS clients were variously accused of using sham offshore entities in Hong
Kong, Panama and elsewhere, including one entity known as Real Cool Investments,
to disguise further their ownership of the UBS accounts.

Prosecutors also accused some of them of shifting assets out of UBS to smaller
banks in Switzerland and Liechtenstein when UBS came under scrutiny in 2008 and
of carrying cash by hand into the United States from Switzerland without
declaring it.

                             Daily News (New York)

                           December 18, 1995, Monday

BASEBALL GIANTS SETTLE WITH IRS

BYLINE: By GREG B. SMITH

SECTION: News; Pg.  4

LENGTH: 460 words


Some of baseball's biggest stars have agreed to pay nearly $ 250,000 in
back-taxes, fines and interest for hiding thousands in cash fees earned at a
1989 Atlantic City autograph show from the IRS.

Charles Franssen, chief of the Internal Revenue Service criminal division's
Brooklyn office, confirmed that some players agreed to pay after admitting they
didn't report cash pocketed at a January 1989 event called Super Show I.

"Some of the players have paid fines, some are still in the process," he said,
declining to detail who paid what.

Players who paid fines or are expected to do so include former Milwaukee Braves
third baseman Eddie Mathews, ex-Baltimore Orioles star outfielder Frank Robinson
and former Phillies third baseman Mike Schmidt, according to sources familiar
with the investigation.

The late Yankees superstar Mickey Mantle who reportedly pocketed $ 57,000 at the
show paid no penalties because the feds couldn't show he deliberately did not
report the income.

Still, Mantle did pay back-taxes and interest, says his lawyer, Robert Fink.

The Atlantic City show has been under investigation since October 1989, when the
IRS realized the event's promoters, William Hongach and Michael Bertolini,
handed out huge piles of cash for a show featuring the 11 living players who'd
hit 500 home runs in their careers.

Prosecutors ultimately dragged several players before a federal grand jury in
Brooklyn. Hongach and Bertolini pleaded guilty to tax evasion last year.

Franssen confirmed that some players got immunity from prosecution after they
agreed to provide information on the lucrative baseball memorabilia industry in
general and on other players. He declined to name those who cooperated.

"Some players were granted immunity through their cooperation," he said.

Two players ex-Brooklyn Dodger Duke Snider and ex-San Francisco Giants slugger
Willie McCovey pleaded guilty to tax evasion stemming from the Atlantic City
show.

Snider who was sentenced to two years probation two weeks ago will pay the IRS
about $ 27,000. McCovey won't be sentenced until next year, but will pay about $
21,000, federal documents show.

The feds concluded that besides Snider and McCovey, eight other major league
legends failed to report more than $ 240,000 in cash pocketed at the Atlantic
City show, according to a confidential federal report obtained by the Daily
News.

But in many instances, the feds couldn't show the players intentionally
underreported their incomes.

Several players deny wrongdoing and say they made no deals to pay back the tax
man, including former Yankees slugger Reggie Jackson, ex-Atlanta Braves homerun
king Hank Aaron, and former Minnesota Twins first baseman Harmon Killebrew.

                             Daily News (New York)

                             June 23, 1995, Friday

NEW TAX-CHEAT CASE EYED FOR MAN CLEARED ON APPEAL

BYLINE: By BARBARA ROSS

SECTION: Suburban Pg.  1

LENGTH: 524 words



Federal prosecutors this week are trying to decide if they will appeal a
Brooklyn judge's decision overturning the conviction of a Williamsburg man on
tax-evasion charges.

U.S. District Court Judge Jack Weinstein ruled late Monday that Sam Pfeiffer, a
member of the Pupa Hasidic community, did not get a fair trial because his
attorney, Jeffrey Hoffman of Hoffman and Pollack, had a serious conflict of
interest.

Citing recent appeals court decisions, Weinstein said Hoffman should have
disclosed his conflict to the court and his client during Pfeiffer's trial in
late 1993.

While Hoffman was representing Pfeiffer, he was advising mortgage broker John
Souto on how to respond to a subpoena for records that investigators needed to
prosecute Pfeiffer.

Souto worked with Pfeiffer on a number of real estate deals in the mid-1980s.
Part of his work included preparing applications to banks for mortgages.

Pfeiffer did not discover the conflict until last summer, when with the aid of
new attorneys Judd Burstein and Michael Perle he was going through Hoffman's
files to prepare an appeal.

Weinstein vacated Pfeiffer's conviction on three counts of conspiracy, filing a
false return for 1985 and tax evasion for that year, and granted his request for
a new trial.

Marvin Smilon, a spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office in Manhattan, said
prosecutors were studying Weinstein's ruling and had not decided whether to
appeal.

Perle, a Weehawken, N.J., attorney, said he was "gratified" by Weinstein's
decision, which came after several days of testimony from parties involved in
the case.

Pfeiffer's case is noteworthy because it is one of many that federal authorities
have tried to press in recent years in a bid to stop members of religious groups
from using their organizations to hide taxable income.

When Weinstein sentenced Pfeiffer to serve two years in jail last June, he said
he was trying to "send a message" to the local Hasidic and Orthodox communities
that money laundering would not be tolerated.

For years Pfeiffer has insisted that he gave the millions that he made in real
estate deals in the mid-1980s to Pupa sect communities in Borough Park and
Montreal.

Assistant U.S. Attorneys Robert Cleary and his wife, Margaret Cleary, have
contended that the donations were a ruse for Pfeiffer to hide millions from the
Internal Revenue Service.

During Pfeiffer's trial, one critical document introduced by prosecutors was a
financial statement submitted to a bank that gave Pfeiffer a mortgage.

The document, like other financial statements prepared for Pfeiffer around this
time, listed his real estate holdings. However, the other statements noted that
the Borough Park Pupa community had a stake in the properties. This notation was
missing from the document prosecutors used at Pfeiffer's trial.

Perle said Hoffman's conflict prevented him from challenging the document
aggressively because the challenge could have hurt his other client, Souto.
Prosecutors said the document proved that the Pupas had no stake in Pfeiffer's
buildings and he owed taxes on the profits made when he sold them.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                     October 21, 1994 Friday FINAL EDITION

METROPOLITAN AREA NEWS IN BRIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 780 words


HIGH COURT HEARS 2 SIDES

IN VETERAN-HIRING CASE

A state law giving veterans preference in being hired for state jobs was the
focus of arguments yesterday before the state Supreme Court at its chambers in
City Hall in Philadelphia.

Mark Tunnell, lawyer for Gordon Brickhouse, argued that the law makes clear that
Brickhouse, as a veteran, should have won a teaching job in 1990 in the
Spring-Ford school district in Montgomery County because he meets state
requirements to teach in public schools. Jeffrey Quinn, lawyer for the school
district, argued that to win the job teaching high school social studies,
Brickhouse needed to show that he was as qualified as other applicants.

Brickhouse, of Spring City, Chester County, now holds a job teaching computer
science at a private school in Montgomery County. A decision in the case isn't
expected for several months, Quinn said.

SIMONE PLEADS GUILTY

TO TAX-EVASION CHARGE

Robert F. Simone, a lawyer known for his high-profile defense of many of
Philadelphia's most notorious mobsters, pleaded guilty yesterday to two counts
of federal income-tax evasion, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

Simone, 61, was sentenced by U.S. District Judge Stewart Dalzell to 15 months in
prison on the charges, and ordered to pay $160,140 in back taxes, plus interest
and penalties. He had initially pleaded not guilty to a 12-count indictment that
was unsealed in March 1992, according to a statement by U.S. Attorney Michael R.
Stiles.

Simone pleaded guilty to evading $24,507 in 1985 taxes and $29,000 in 1989
taxes. He was acquitted in 1984 in an earlier case in which he was charged with
tax evasion. Simone also faces four years in prison for his 1992 conviction in a
failed scheme to extort $1 million from waterfront developer Willard G. Rouse in
1986.

RARE TITANIC MEMORABILIA

GOES ON VIEW AT CONFERENCE

Rare memorabilia from the RMS Titanic, the ocean liner that struck an iceberg
and sank in 1912 with a loss of more than 1,500 lives, will be displayed at 10
a.m. tomorrow during a conference of Titanic International, a nonprofit
historical society based in Freehold, N.J. The meeting will be held at the
Philadelphia Maritime Museum, 321 Chestnut St., and is open to the public.

Titanic International (TI) trustees Charles Hass and Jack Eaton, who
participated in an expedition to the Titanic, will answer questions about the
wreck. Hass and Eaton wrote the 1987 book Titanic: Triumph and Tragedy. A
nine-foot section of rope recovered from a Titanic lifeboat will be displayed at
the event, along with postcards and dozens of other ship-related items.

The conference also will delve into the 1934 fire aboard the Morro Castle that
left more than 100 passengers dead. Authors Robert McDonnell and Fred Rasmussen
will present their findings on what really happened. Their book on the tragedy,
which occurred off the coast of New Jersey, will be published next year. Tickets
to the conference are $3 for TI members, $5 for nonmembers.

PLAN TO GIVE FREE BIBLES

TO PUPILS DRAWS ACLU FIRE

The planned distribution of free Bibles in the Waynesboro elementary schools
next month has drawn criticism from some who say it violates the separation of
church and state.

The Waynesboro Area school board last week approved the giveaway by the Gideon
organization. Fifth graders will be able to pick up the Bibles Nov. 3 without
hearing the preaching of specific religious beliefs, school officials said. The
American Civil Liberties Union planned to challenge the distribution, and ACLU
legal director Stefan Presser threatened a lawsuit in federal court. "A letter
is being sent to the school board telling them to abandon the idea," Presser
said.

Bibles are offered in nearly half of Pennsylvania's 501 public school districts
although none are offered in schools themselves, a Gideon spokesman said. "We
are not mixing church with state," Gideon spokesman Harry Horst said. In a 5-3
vote, the school board called the distribution a matter of free speech rights.
Board president Leland Lemley said an "overwhelming majority" of district
residents supported it.

JURORS STILL DELIBERATING

IN THIRD PELULLO FRAUD TRIAL

A federal jury weighing fraud and racketeering charges against Leonard A.
Pelullo, a Chester County businessman, is scheduled to resume deliberations
today. The 12-member panel met for more than six hours yesterday without
reaching a verdict.

Pelullo is charged with misusing more than $2 million in funds borrowed for a
hotel restoration project in Miami in 1984. Two previous convictions were thrown
out on appeal. The trial is in its third week.

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                           November 9, 2006 Thursday

Neways sold to owner of Herbalife

BYLINE: By Linda Fantin and Pam Manson The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 269 words


Posted: 12:09 PM- Days before they begin serving prison terms for tax evasion,
Thomas and Leslie Mower have sold Neways International to the San
Francisco-based owner of Herbalife.

Golden Gate Capital did not disclose the financial details behind its
acquisition of Springville-based Neways. But the private equity firm paid $685
million for Herbalife in 2002.

The Mowers said in a statement that selling the dietary supplement and personal
care company they founded in 1992 was "one of the hardest decisions of our
lives."

The couple disclosed plans to sell the company two months ago in court filings,
citing "personal differences."

The Mowers, who divorced in July 2000, came from humble beginnings but together
built one of the largest multilevel marketing companies in the world in Utah
County.

In 2005 they were convicted on six counts of tax evasion and one count of
conspiracy to defraud for concealing more than $1 million in receipts received
from Neways Australia and more than $3 million in commission income the couple
received from U.S., Australian and Malaysian distributorships.

On Sept. 14, U.S. District Judge Dale Kimball rejected the Mowers' pleas for
probation and sentenced Thomas Mower to 33 months in prison and a $75,000 fine.
His ex-wife, Dee, was ordered to spend 27 months behind bars and pay a $60,000
fine. Their prison terms begin Monday.

Kimball also sentenced James Louis Thompson, an Orem lawyer who served as
counsel for Neways from 1995 to 1997, to 366 days in prison. Thompson, now
disbarred, was found guilty of conspiracy and of corruptly impeding the due
administration of tax laws.
