                                The New York Post

                              June 9, 2015 Tuesday

Ring me up more 'sales suppression' busts

BYLINE: John Crudele

SECTION: All Editions; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 857 words


How many restaurants are cheating New York City and the Empire State out of
sales tax?

Answer: a lot more than the tax cops think.

Last week Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance became the first New York law
man to look into so-called sales-suppression software, or - as the cool people
call them - "zappers."

Zappers are sophisticated high-tech cash registers, aka point-of-sale (POS)
terminals. I've been writing about them for years but nobody in New York seemed
to care - even though they have cost the state billions in lost sales tax.

Perhaps now folks will care.

The concept behind the tax evasion is simple: Using high tech POS software,
restaurants make a sale disappear. A restaurant can, for instance, have the
zapper miss every third drink sold. Or, every fourth entrée can disappear.

And if the sale is missed, the state won't collect its 4 percent stake and the
city won't collect its 4.78 percent piece of the action.

And in case the city or state is smart enough to check a restaurant's inventory
of pasta or vodka to see whether it's in line with sales, a zapper can reconcile
the two.

And what if you are about to get caught by the tax cops? Well, the zapper's hard
drive can be crashed - with the sales records going into a digital Neverland.

"Sorry, Mr. Cuomo and de Blasio. These computers are finicky."

So, as I was saying, Vance last week surprised me when he announced that a grand
jury - after a yearlong investigation - had indicted one of the makers of
zappers. And 10 restaurants had pleaded guilty to tax evasion.

Ten? There are around 24,000 restaurants in New York City. Again, I ask: How
many restaurants are cheating New York City and the Empire State out of sales
tax?

Was the cash you forked over for your last restaurant meal properly accounted
for? Or did a zapper allow too much to go right into the pocket of the
restaurant owner?

Anyway, the most important thing I want you to know today is that there might be
more crooked restaurants than honest ones. Let me tell you a little story that
few people know.

Back in 2009, the state's tax collector started a sting operation targeting
zapper sellers. Back then, there were 26 different cash-register makers who
offered these sophisticated machines.

State investigators, under Tom Stanton, the then-head of tax enforcement,
pretended to be setting up four restaurants - in Buffalo, Albany, Dutchess
County and New York City - and interviewed all 26 companies.

"Of the 26 targets, 25 offered that they could help us evade taxes and showed us
in detail how to do it," says Stanton. "Then the last one called us back and
said, 'By the way, there's something else I can do for you.' "

They were offered zappers.

"It's a competitive market and the big thing they could do for you was tax
evasion," says Stanton. Some of the companies involved in the scam were part of
big publicly held companies.

The state never followed through on that investigation. And I doubt Vance even
knows about it. But video tapes from those stings still exist and Vance is
welcome to them.

And restaurants are probably not the only ones evading taxes through these
high-tech machines.

Vance says his investigation is continuing. He never named the people he already
snagged. But I'd bet that the zapper maker who got caught is probably squealing
right now. And there are at least 25 more who should be expecting a call from
the Manhattan DA.

Look, we all hate taxes. But just think of all the good things that can be done
with the billions in missing sales tax. Kids could be educated, people fed and
housed, the state budget balanced - the city might even fix that pothole that's
been outside the Lincoln Tunnel for the past year.

n

Congress has been trying to get rid of Todd Zinser, the inept inspector general
of the Commerce Department, for quite a while. I've been trying even longer
because he had oversight over the equally incompetent Census Bureau.

Last week, it happened: Zinser was forced out.

Zinser is the guy who was in charge when the House Committee on Oversight and
Government Reform undertook the probe of Census that I caused. That
investigation was "obstructed" by Commerce, according to a congressional report.

So what now?

The first thing Congress needs to do is investigate the whistle-blowers that
Zinser failed to protect from retaliation. I know of three at Census alone.

Then it needs to figure if Zinser helped conceal any wrongdoing - and start with
the 120 computers that went missing from Census in the months before the 2012
presidential election.

Those computers contained sensitive data and could have been used to change
vital economic statistics before the last vote. Zinser should have been all over
that, but there's no indication that he took even a peek.

And just before Zinser got the heave-ho, Census did one more thing that needs
investigating. Suddenly the Bureau has an e-mail system that erases messages
automatically after a short period of time.

Having asked to see those e-mails via Freedom of Information requests, I find
this development very curious.

Former student sues WVU over expulsion

MORGANTOWN - A former student is suing West Virginia University over his
expulsion for violating the school's Student Code of Conduct.

The lawsuit filed in Monongalia County Circuit Court seeks to force WVU to
reinstate Taylor Camp so that he can complete his degree.

According to the lawsuit, Camp was expelled May 23 after the Student Conduct
Board determined he had violated the conduct code. The decision followed a
hearing by the board on allegations of sexual misconduct.

Camp's lawyer, Ed Rollo, tells The Dominion Post that the board ignored evidence
that there wasn't any sexual misconduct. Rollo says the hearing process was
"fatally flawed."

Attorneys for the WVU Board of Governors asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit.
University spokesman John Bolt says WVU doesn't comment on pending litigation.

Woman charged with murder in robbery

WHEELING - A woman charged with murder in a botched pharmacy robbery in Wheeling
is scheduled to go to trial in December.

According to WTOV-TV, Melody Fisher was arraigned Wednesday in Ohio County
Circuit Court. She pleaded not guilty to all charges.

Police say Fisher and Kevin Walnoha were attempting to rob the Elm Grove
Pharmacy on May 25 when Walnoha was fatally shot by a pharmacist. Investigators
say Fisher was at the wheel of the getaway car.

An investigation concluded the pharmacist was justified in shooting Walnoha.

Fisher was indicted earlier this week on a charge of felony murder, among other
counts.

Her trial is scheduled for Dec. 17.

3 state groups get drug-abuse grants

Three West Virginia community coalitions are receiving federal grants to reduce
youth drug abuse.

Community Connections Inc. received $125,000 for the Creating Opportunities for
Youth Coalition in Bluefield.

Another $125,000 went to the Strong through our Plan Coalition in Gilbert.

The United Way of the River Cities Inc. also received $125,000 for the Cabell
County Substance Abuse Prevention Partnership in Huntington.

U.S. Sens. Jay Rockefeller and Joe Manchin and Rep. Nick Rahall, all D-W.Va.,
announced the grants Thursday.

The funding comes from a program administered by the Office of National Drug
Control Policy.

Railroad retiree gets jail time for tax evasion

MARTINSBURG - An ex-railroad worker from Maryland who ran a West Virginia scrap
yard while collecting disability checks will spend 18 months in prison for tax
evasion.

Fifty-year-old Kenneth Harold Hogan of Oldtown, Md., was sentenced in U.S.
District Court in Martinsburg earlier this week on a misdemeanor count of making
false statements and a felony count of tax evasion.

Hogan retired with a back injury in 1995 and collected disability, claiming he
had no income.

Prosecutors say he fraudulently collected federal benefits from 2006 through
2008. They say the government overpaid him more than $128,000 after he started
Scrap Brothers Inc. in Paw Paw.

Judge Gina Groh also ordered Hogan to repay the U.S. Railroad Retirement board
and pay the Internal Revenue Service nearly $91,000.

Hogan will self-report to prison.

Dozens of buildings being torn down

HUNTINGTON - Several abandoned buildings in Huntington are about to meet the
wrecking ball.

The buildings in the Fairfield neighborhood are being demolished as part of a
local, state and federal project to revitalize the area. Crews from the West
Virginia National Guard and the state Division of Highways brought in heavy
equipment this week to begin the month-long process.

National Guard Maj. Brent Schultz said about 50 homes will be torn down.

Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin and U.S. Attorney Booth Goodwin planned to speak at the
site Thursday afternoon.

CSI academy on hunting accidents planned

LOGAN - Call it CSI woodlands.

A Hunting Incident Academy will bring 40 wildlife officers from 16 states to
West Virginia next week to learn the finer points of investigating a
hunting-related shooting.

Nine instructors from seven states will share their skills, knowledge and
techniques on how they go about investigating a shooting incident involving a
hunter. The instructors have more than 350 years of experience and have
investigated more than 2,000 hunting-related shootings.

Organizers say one aim of the training is to reduce hunting accidents.

The training begins Sunday at Chief Logan State Park Lodge and runs through
Sept. 20. It is sponsored by the West Virginia Division of Natural Resources and
the International Hunter Education Association.

                  March 02, 2001, Friday, 2 Late Tampa Edition

Evans co-defendant's tax evasion trial begins

BYLINE: JEFF TESTERMAN

SECTION: TAMPA & STATE; Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 423 words

DATELINE: TAMPA



Developer C. Hayward Chapman is charged with evading $ 843,957 in taxes. A
conviction could mean five years in prison and a $ 100,000 fine.

A day after convicting Tampa developer C. Hayward Chapman of giving illegal
gratuities to a public official, the same jurors began hearing testimony
Thursday in his tax evasion case.

Chapman, 64, faces a charge of income tax evasion stemming from $ 2.1-million in
income channeled from Bradley and Bradley Development Corp. in 1997 to Concorde
Inc., a contracting company Chapman controlled.

Federal prosecutors say Chapman failed to file a timely IRS return on the income
and evaded $ 843,957 in income tax.

On Thursday, jurors heard testimony from Terry Keirn, who is Chapman's daughter
and Concorde's sole shareholder. She testified that checks written on Concorde's
business account at the direction of Chapman included $ 16,000 for a cash
present to her daughter, $ 19,478 for a Harley Davidson motorcycle for Chapman
and $ 133,760 for a property purchased in Georgia in Keirn's name.

If convicted of the income tax evasion charge, Chapman could face a five-year
prison term and a $ 100,000 fine.

Chapman already faces as many as eight years behind bars after being convicted
this week of paying four gratuities through Concorde to Audley Evans, former
executive director of both the Tampa Housing Authority and a non-profit housing
agency called Meridian River Development Corp.

Concorde obtained contracts worth $ 700,000 from Meridian River in 1996 and
1997. Chapman's gratuity convictions stem from his pledge of a $ 25,000
certificate of deposit for an Evans bank loan and his direction to Keirn to send
three checks totaling $ 125,000 from the Concorde account to pay off mortgages
Evans owed.

Chapman's attorney, Frank Winkles, said he will file a motion to overturn the
gratuity verdicts because Evans was not a public official while at the helm of
Meridian River Development. Prosecutors say Meridian River was a public agency
because it received HUD money from some tenants.

Evans, 48, the boss of the Tampa Housing Authority from 1988 to 1996, was
convicted Wednesday of bribery, conspiracy, accepting illegal gratuities and
making a series of false statements to a federal agency.

Evans' attorney, Arnold Levine, said he will seek to have the verdicts set
aside.

Evans, who was following the Chapman proceedings in the courtroom Thursday,
faces a maximum sentence of 77 years in prison. District Judge James S. Moody
has scheduled his sentencing for May 21.

                              Late Edition - Final

Ex-Tyco Chief to Settle Tax Evasion Charges

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

SECTION: Section C; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 482 words


The former chairman of Tyco International, L. Dennis Kozlowski, agreed yesterday
to pay $21.2 million to settle charges of avoiding New York sales tax on 12
paintings, including a Monet, a Renoir and a Bouguereau.

The accusation of tax evasion was the beginning of the trail that turned Mr.
Kozlowski into a name synonomous with the lavish-spending chief executive,
epitomized by such items as a $6,000 shower curtain.

In June 2005, Mr. Kozlowski, and Tyco's former financial chief, Mark H. Swartz,
were convicted of stealing $600 million from the company and were sentenced to
up to 25 years.

But Mr. Kozlowski was initially indicted in June 2002 on charges of failing to
pay sales tax on millions of dollars in artwork.

In the settlement of that case yesterday with the Manhattan district attorney,
Robert M. Morgenthau, Mr. Kozlowski agreed to pay $3.2 million in sales tax and
interest on the 12 paintings, of which more than $2 million is sales tax.

He also agreed to pay $17.9 million in state and city income tax, interest and
penalties, of which $8.3 million represented the tax liability. Though he was
never charged with income-tax fraud, it is part of the agreement.

The settlement was announced in a hearing before Justice Michael Obus of State
Supreme Court, who asked if Mr. Kozlowski, who was not present, would be able to
meet a Sept. 19 deadline for payment. Judge Obus also oversaw the trial of Mr.
Kozlowski and Mr. Schwartz.

Mr. Kozlowski's lawyer, James R. DeVita, told the judge that it was ''not 100
percent clear'' that his client could meet that deadline, but that Mr. Kozlowski
was liquidating assets, and had transferred more than $90 million into an escrow
account.

After being convicted in the Tyco criminal cased, he was ordered to pay $97
million in restitution and a fine of $70 million, amounts that are separate from
the money he agreed to pay yesterday. Mr. Morgenthau said the charges would be
dropped if Mr. Kozlowski kept up his end of the settlement.

''We don't believe we're looking a gift horse in the mouth,'' Mr. Morgenthau
said. ''The case won't be dismissed unless he comes up with the dough.''

This month, Tyco International sold two paintings listed as part of yesterday's
agreement at a Sotheby's auction: ''Fleurs et fruit,'' by Pierre Auguste Renoir,
sold for $2.8 million, and ''Pres Monte Carlo,'' by Claude Monet, sold for $5
million. The list of 12 paintings also included ''Enfant tressant une
couronne,'' by William-Adolphe Bouguereau.

Mr. Kozlowski's sales tax case was part of a broader investigation by the
district attorney into nearly a dozen galleries and more than 300 customers who
evaded sales tax, chief of investigations for the Manhattan district attorney's
office, Dan Castleman, said yesterday.

As a result of that investigation, prosecutors have collected $37.5 million in
state and city sales taxes and fines.

                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                             August 5, 2013 Monday

Norway Gets U.S. Help Chasing Citizens Dodging Income Law: Taxes

LENGTH: 731  words


Norway is catching more tax dodgers abroad with fresh help from the U.S. legal
system.
Federal courts in six states have allowed the Internal Revenue Service to issue
summonses to U.S. banks at the request of the Norwegian government, and the
banks may now have to give up information on people who used some kinds of
credit and debit cards, Bloomberg BNA reported, citing the Justice Department.


The development signals increasing cooperation between governments to stop
offshore tax evasion. The cases show that the U.S. is willing to reciprocate as
officials escalate efforts to find U.S. taxpayers hiding money overseas with the
cooperation of other governments, said Kevin Packman, an attorney with Holland &
Knight LLP in Miami.
"It's highly noteworthy," Packman said. U.S. tax officials are sending the
message that "it's not a one-way street, and we'll help you too."
Countries are increasingly working to stop tax evasion together. At a June
meeting of the Group of 8 nations, leaders of the world's wealthiest economies
including President Obama announced a commitment to tackle tax evasion by
multinational companies. The G-8 leaders said one goal would be to "share
information automatically to fight the scourge of tax evasion."
The U.S. Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act, known as Fatca, may lead to dozens
of agreements between countries to exchange information on bank accounts. The
law requires foreign banks to turn over information to the IRS about their
U.S.-owned accounts or potentially face withholding taxes.
Seven PetitionsUnder the aegis of Fatca, the U.S. has signed at least nine
agreements for government-to-government information exchange -- a phenomenon
that is gaining momentum in the world of tax administration. Negotiations are in
the works with as many as 80 other nations.
Another source of information is a U.S. program where taxpayers volunteer
information about offshore accounts in exchange for a set penalty and the chance
to avoid criminal prosecution. That has yielded data not just on individuals,
but on the banks and promoters who help in the avoidance.
The Justice Department said July 29 that courts in Minnesota, Texas,
Pennsylvania, Oklahoma, Virginia and California have approved seven of 10
government petitions to let the IRS seek the information in court at the request
of the Norwegian government. Three are still pending, in California, Mississippi
and New Hampshire.
A total of 18 U.S. financial institutions are identified in the government's
filings, initiated at the request of the Norwegian government under a treaty
between Norway and the U.S., the Justice Department said. The filings don't
allege that the banks have violated any U.S. laws, the department said.

Unusual MoveThe development is significant because the U.S. government went to
federal court in eight states at Norway (NOUE)'s request, practitioners told
BNA.
In one example of financial institutions that could be facing scrutiny, the U.S.
District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania said on July 22 that the
IRS can issue summonses to PNC Bank N.A. and RBS Citizens N.A. In a memorandum
filed in the Pennsylvania court, the U.S. called the suit "out of the ordinary"
because it was done at Norway's request, and pointed out that a U.S.-Norway
treaty allows it.
"It's fairly unusual that you see this, but it's becoming more common as you see
governments cooperate," said John Harrington, a partner with Dentons in
Washington.
Cross-border information exchange will become more common under Fatca, and
Norway has signed an intergovernmental agreement under that act, Harrington
said.
"These are the kinds of requests that will ultimately be supplanted by automatic
exchange of information," Harrington said.
Norway's EvidenceNorwegian authorities described an arrangement using payment
cards that it said has already generated evidence of extensive tax avoidance in
Norway, according to a declaration accompanying the petition from Michael
Danilack, a deputy commissioner at the IRS said.
"The Department of Justice and IRS are committed to working with our treaty
partners to fight tax evasion wherever it occurs," Kathryn Keneally, assistant
attorney general for the Justice Department's tax division, said in the agency's
July 29 statement. "All taxpayers should know that our efforts in this area are
global, coordinated and will continue."

Brown smashes window

Singer Chris Brown smashed a window in a studio on Tuesday after a "Good Morning
America" anchor asked him about a criminal case, according to ABC News.

New York police said Tuesday they were not called to the set of "Good Morning
America" after Chris Brown went on a rampage in response to a question about his
criminal case involving ex-girlfriend Rihanna.

Law enforcement sources familiar with the case said a police report and
assessment of whether a crime was committed would be crucial in determining
whether Brown violated his probation.

"Once backstage, according to insiders, Brown stormed into his dressing room and
started screaming and tearing the room apart," ABC reported. "Workers in the
building called security. Before they arrived, insiders say Brown smashed a
window in his dressing room, with the glass shattering and falling onto 43rd and
Broadway."

R&B singer Brown had completed a court-mandated domestic violence education
program in January.

He was sentenced to the 52-week program, along with five years' probation and
180 hours community service, after pleading guilty in August 2009 to felony
assault of then-girlfriend Rihanna after a party.

When asked about the case on "Good Morning America," he responded: "It's not
really a big deal to me now, as far as that situation. I think I'm past that in
my life."

Washington to speak to grads

PHILADELPHIA | Two-time Oscar winner Denzel Washington has been selected to
deliver the commencement speech at the University of Pennsylvania.

College officials announced Tuesday that Washington will address about 5,000
graduates and receive an honorary degree at the May 16 ceremony.

Washington's son Malcolm is a sophomore at the Ivy League school in
Philadelphia.

Author Joyce Carol Oates and New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof are among
several others also slated to receive honorary degrees at the ceremony.

Rapper pleads to tax evasion

NEWARK, N.J. | Rapper and actor Ja Rule has pleaded guilty to tax evasion in New
Jersey.

The platinum-selling rapper admitted Tuesday that he failed to pay taxes on more
than $3 million in income earned between 2004 and 2006.

He entered his guilty plea in a federal courtroom in Newark.

As part of a plea agreement, the government has dismissed two counts against him
for <0x000A>unpaid taxes on income earned in 2007 and 2008.

The 35-year-old Ja Rule is expected to be sentenced on the tax evasion charges
in June.

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

                            March 23, 2006 Thursday

Ex-49ers star accused of fraud;
EMBEZZLEMENT ALLEGED

BYLINE: Rodney Foo, Mercury News

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 565 words


Ray Wersching, the retired San Francisco 49ers kicker who booted field goals in
two Super Bowl victories, was indicted Wednesday on federal charges of
embezzling $8 million from an insurance company and tax evasion.

Wersching, 55, the owner of Ray Wersching Insurance Agency in Redwood City, is
accused of diverting premiums earmarked for Farmers Insurance from 1997 to 2000.
He is also alleged to have evaded paying taxes on $3.6 million in corporate
income from 1999 to 2000.

Wersching has been served with a summons to appear Monday in U.S. District Court
in San Francisco before Magistrate Judge Bernard Zimmerman, said U.S. Department
of Justice spokesman Luke Macaulay.

``This action,'' Insurance Commissioner John Garamendi said in a statement,
``makes it clear that in California, no one -- whether an average citizen or a
former football star -- will escape prosecution if they are suspected of
insurance fraud.''

Wersching, an ex-University of California football star, faces six allegations
-- embezzlement; permitting a felon convicted of dishonesty to participate in an
insurance business; failing to file a corporate tax return; and two counts of
tax evasion.

The penalties carry a range of prison sentences from one to 10 years, and fines
of $250,000 plus restitution.

The Mercury News was unable to reach Wersching for comment.

The indictment ends a five-year investigation conducted by the state justice
department, the FBI, the California Department of Insurance and the Internal
Revenue Service.

Authorities allege Wersching diverted money from premiums to be paid to Farmers
into his own company's account.

Wersching had opened the insurance agency in February 1995, and a month later
hired Mary Ann Locke, also known as Mary Ann Diaz, giving her a 50 percent stake
in the firm.

In March 2001, Farmer's ended its affiliation with Wersching. Locke left the
company two months later.

Locke had been convicted of forgery in 1992, Macaulay said.

Last year, Locke was arraigned in federal court on insurance fraud, wire fraud
and money laundering, related to the embezzlement scheme. She used the money to
pay Nevada casinos for gambling debts, state insurance department officials
said.

Wersching's troubles stand in stark contrast to his accomplishments on the
gridiron. He played 15 years in the NFL -- four of them with the San Diego
Chargers -- before retiring from the 49ers after the 1987 season. He was a
member of the 1981 and 1984 championship teams. He still holds the record for
most career field goals in Super Bowls, five. Wersching trails only legendary
49er wide receiver Jerry Rice as the team's leading scorer.

The accusations stunned those who knew Wersching.

``There was never a more respected guy on the team,'' said Dr. Harry Edwards, a
staff consultant with the 49ers for the past 20 years. ``He was a guy they
leaned on in tight games to get it done and nine times out of 10, he got it
done.

``From what I know of him, I could not begin to fathom what could possibly have
brought him to this situation. I hope that . . . he gets through this thing.''

John McVay, who served as 49ers general manager when Wersching was with the
team, said, ``This is a good man, and he has been for a lot of years. Knowing
him, this just doesn't add up.''

Mercury News Staff Writer Dennis Georgatos contributed to this report. Contact
Rodney Foo at rfoo@mercurynews.com or (408) 920-5258.

Former 49ers kicker indicted for $8M insurance fraud

BYLINE: Rodney Foo, Mercury News

                              The Washington Post

                     August 26, 1988, Friday, Final Edition

2 Charged In Coca-Cola Fraud Case

BYLINE: Paul W. Valentine, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; PAGE C7

LENGTH: 460 words

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Aug. 25, 1988


Two former managers of a Coca-Cola syrup-making plant were charged today with
defrauding the parent Coca-Cola Co. of more than $ 5 million by submitting
fictitious bills during a seven-year period for work never done and supplies
never provided at the syrup plant here.

Through an elaborate scheme of phony invoices, sham bank accounts and kickbacks
from companies doing business with the syrup plant, according to charging papers
filed in federal court here, the two former managers took in almost $ 1 million
a year between 1980 and 1987, converting the money to "their own personal
benefit."

Prosecutors described the case as one of the largest commercial fraud cases in
Maryland history and said more suspects are involved.

"The investigation is ongoing," said Assistant U.S. Attorney David P. King. The
criminal charges parallel a civil suit filed here by The Coca-Cola Co. seeking $
6 million from the two former managers and others.

The former managers, Hillis A. Smith, 52, of Glen Burnie and Lewis H. Addison
III, 46, of Westminster, have signed agreements to plead guilty to the charges,
according to King and U.S. Attorney Breckinridge Willcox.

In addition to three mail fraud counts, Smith is charged with one count of tax
evasion. He faces a possible maximum sentence of 20 years in prison and $ 1
million in fines.

Addison is charged with two counts of mail fraud and one count of tax evasion
and could receive up to 15 years in prison and $ 750,000 in fines. Both also
face a possible order to make restitution to The Coca-Cola Co.

According to the court papers, several unidentified individuals and businesses
were recruited by Smith and Addison to submit false invoices for equipment and
services never provided the syrup-making plant, such as safety shoes, work
gloves and repair and replacement of pallets used for storing and moving
supplies in the plant.

The individuals and businesses provided Smith "with extensive personal gifts and
favors," according to the charging papers, and "Smith reciprocated by approving
invoices which fraudulently overbilled for work, inflated labor hours on jobs
and charged for work that was not performed."

The papers did not specify what gifts and favors Smith received, and prosecutors
today would not say what they were.

Smith and Addison also were charged with tax evasion and understating their
income in 1986 by hundreds of thousands of dollars each.

The plant formerly managed by Smith and Addison is one of about 20 in the
country that manufacture the concentrate of flavorings and other ingredients of
Coca-Cola and combine them with sweeteners, according to a company spokesman in
Atlanta. The Baltimore plant is operated by Coca-Cola USA, a division of The
Coca-Cola Co.

                             The Guardian (London)

                                October 12, 1984

Biggest US tax evasion costs 200 million dollars / Fugitive Swiss oil trader
Marc Rich and US lawyer Pincus Green still sought

LENGTH: 400 words


The two Marc Rich companies yesterday agreed to pay the US Government about
dollars 200 million in fines and interest to settle the biggest tax evasion case
in American history.

But criminal charges against the Swiss oil trader Mr Marc Rich and his partner,
Mr Pincus Green remain, the US Attorney for Manhattan, Mr Rudolph Giuliani, told
a federal court in New York.


Judge Shirley Kram accepted the settlement stemming from illegal oil trading by
Marc Rich and Company of Switzerland and its US subsidiary, Marc Rich and
Company International. The settlement includes dollars 150 million in back
taxes, dollars 21 million in fines already paid for failure to produce the
subpoenaed documents, plus interest on back taxes.

Mr Giuliani told the judge that the settlement was 'the largest amount ever
recovered in a US income tax case.'

As part of the settlement, each company pleaded guilty to 38 counts of making
false statements to the US Internal Revenue Service relating to crude oil
transactions.

In addition, the US subsidiary, now known as Clarendon Ltd, pleaded guilty to
two counts of tax evasion totalling dollars 48 million.

In accepting the pleas, Judge Kram imposed additional maximum fines of dollars
380,000 on the parent company and dollars 400,000 on its US subsidiary. The two
companies were also requested to pay nearly dollars 33,000 in court costs.

As part of the settlement, both companies will be permitted to resume their US
operations, which were suspended when the charges were brought in September
1983.

But Mr Rich and Mr Green, said to be fugitives, still face charges of tax
evasion.

Both men are living in Switzerland.

In rejecting a US request to extradite Mr Rich two weeks ago, Swiss authorities
said the charges against him were not among extraditable offences in their
treaty with the United States.

The case began more than two years ago with a government investigation of
allegations that Mr Rich had schemed to violate US oil price regulations and
evade dollars 48 million in American income tax.

The defendants were all charged with racketeering, punishable by up to 20 years
in prison for individuals and fines for the companies. Among the accusations was
that they bought dollars 200 million of oil from Iran during the US hostage
crisis, when President Jimmy Carter declared it illegal to trade with Iran.

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                           December 21, 2010 Tuesday

Utah man gets prison for tax evasion church scheme

BYLINE: By Melinda Rogers The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; State

LENGTH: 419 words


A federal judge has ordered a Tremonton man to spend 42 months in prison for tax
evasion, after he transferred property deeds to a "private church" called The
Order of Tranquility as a way to avoid paying taxes from 1995 to 2001.

U.S. District Judge Clark Waddoups imposed the sentence on John Gauruder, 54,
Monday. He ruled Gauruder must pay $409,685 to the IRS as a penalty for tax
fraud.

Gauruder, a former Marine, was a licensed chiropractic physician at Tremonton
Chiropractic Center before his arrest, according to records from the Utah
Division of Occupational and Professional Licensing.

His wife, 57-year-old Jana Gauruder, and Rulon DeYoung of Salt Lake City, 68,
were also charged in the case.

According to a September 2008 indictment, the Gauruders avoided paying $336,843
in income taxes when Jana Gauruder transferred the title of the couple's home to
The Order of Tranquility, which is controlled by DeYoung.

DeYoung was charged with aiding the Gauruders and others to transfer their
properties to his "church" to conceal their property ownership and to avoid
paying taxes. He pleaded guilty in May to four counts of tax evasion and one
count of corrupt interference with the due administration of Internal Revenue
laws. Prosecutors said his actions cost the government $1.4 million in taxes.
Waddoups in August ordered him to serve a three-year prison term.

Jana Gauruder pleaded guilty to a lesser tax evasion charge and was sentenced
earlier this month to 36 months of probation. In a sentencing memorandum, her
attorney said she'd been duped into participating in her husband's scheme.

John Gauruder put his wife in charge of a trust he created in 1997 called High
Teton Trust just after she gave birth at age 44 to their ninth child, an
11-pound baby who caused her health problems, according to court documents.

She followed her husband's direction to transfer their property and the trust to
The Order of Tranquility, court documents state. A judge granted her probation
so she could continue to care for her children, including one child who is
disabled. The IRS seized the family's home.

At his sentencing last summer, DeYoung represented himself and told Waddoups he
didn't believe he'd broken any laws and questioned the judge's authority over
his organization, which he described as a private church.

Attorneys for Jana Gauruder and Rulon DeYoung have both filed appeals to the
10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals.

                               The New York Times

              December 2, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

CODY SENTENCED TO 5-YEAR TERM AS A RACKETEER

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1247 words

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, L.I., Dec. 1


John A. Cody, one of the New York metropolitan area's most influential labor
leaders, was sentenced today in Federal District Court to five years in prison
for labor racketeering and tax evasion.

His family, including two young grandchildren, were present in a packed
courtroom as Judge Jacob A. Mishler also fined Mr. Cody $80,000.

For a decade, he has been the $100,000-a-year president of Local 282 of the
International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The local is one of the most powerful in
the construction industry because it controls the flow of materials to building
sites.

Could Be Free in 20 Months

A baldish 62-year-old man, Mr. Cody gripped the rail before Judge Mishler's
bench, his shoulders hunched, and said before the sentence was imposed that he
had no comment to make.

Mr. Cody must serve at least one-third of the five-year sentence, or 20 months,
before becoming eligible for parole.  On Oct. 7 a jury found him guilty here of
seven of eight charges of engaging in a ''pattern of racketeering'' since 1968,
as well as evading Federal income taxes and violating the Taft-Hartley Law by
accepting gifts from contractors who did business with his union.

On the seven counts, Judge Mishler imposed sentences totaling 17 years, but he
ordered all to be served concurrently. The longest sentences, five years each,
were given for violating the Racketeer Influence and Corrupt Organization Act
and for tax evasion involving $150,000 in kickbacks.

Appeal Is Planned

After the sentencing, Mr. Cody was surrounded by his relatives and friends.
Hugging some of the hundred supporters who attended the hearing, he said,
''We'll appeal, we'll appeal.''

Mr. Cody's chief counsel, Stephen P. Scaring, said: ''The evidence was a lot of
hogwash. We're confident this verdict will be reversed.''

The Federal prosecutor in the case, Michael A. Guadagno, had called for a
''substantial prison sentence'' as a deterrent to labor racketeers. Mr.
Guadagno, an attorney with the Organized Strike Task Force in the Eastern
District of New York State, said Mr. Cody had links to ''high-echelon members of
organized crime.''

The defendant, the prosecutor told told Judge Mishler, was concerned not with
''the good of his union members, but only with lining his own pockets.''

In appealing for leniency, Mr. Scaring said, ''John Cody had done a lot of good
things in his life, and a lot of prayers are being said for him today.''

Law-enforcement authorities and union reformers doubt that the conviction will
have any immediate impact on the widespread corruption they say afflicts the
local construction industry.

The officials maintain that campaigns to prevent graft and payoffs are thwarted
mainly by the fears of contractors and employees of economic reprisals if they
speak out.

Dissident union members say that employees who turn to law-enforcement agenices
often are blacklisted from jobs. Fourteen members of Mr. Cody's union who have
publicly raised charges of corruption against Mr. Cody have been without steady
employment in the last five years.

''Everyone in construction in New York knows that if you complain, you lose your
job,'' said Herman Benson, executive director of the Association for Union
Democracy, an independent group that aids union insurgents. ''They face
blacklisting, suspensions and fines in their unions, sometimes even murder.
There is no government agency that can protect them.''

Local a Powerful Unit

The activities of Mr. Cody's local, No. 282, have been particularly scrutinized
by government agencies because in the last decade, under his leadership, the
local has emerged as the most potent building trades unit in New York.

The 4,000-member local controls the delivery of concrete and other vital
supplies to all major building sites in the city and on Long Island. Thus a
strike or slowdown called by the local's leadership - such as a two-month
walkout last summer - can instantly cripple multimillion-dollar building
projects from the Battery to Montauk Point.

Ted Katsoras, one of the Local 282 insurgents who gave Federal officials
information about alleged irregularities at the local, has had little work as a
cement truck driver since 1975, the year he first opposed Mr. Cody as president.
Mr. Katsoras said he had earned about $1,500 in each of the last two years,
instead of the $20,000 to $25,000 that most Local 282 members get annually.

'Shape Up' System Used

Mr. Katsoras and other members of a dissident group called FORE (Fear of
Reprisal Ends) said Mr. Cody's administration controlled jobs through a daily
''shape up'' system in which the union leadership can largely determine who gets
hired. The 42-year-old Mr.  Katsoras said that the union hierarchy also could
''pressure'' employers into dismissing employees.

''Our firings are a warning to the members,'' Mr. Katsoras asserted.''You can't
buck the administration and keep a job.'' As president, Mr. Cody obtained vast
patronage powers. He appointed teamsters to more than 300 supervisory jobs as
shop stewards and foremen, jobs that pay up to $75,000 yearly.

Another member of FORE, John W. Kuebler, who has been in the local for 40 years,
said he lost his job last April after complaining to a shop steward about unsafe
working conditions.

'Seniority Has No Meaning'

''They stripped me of my seniority rights in 1977, and I have had job problems
ever since,'' said Mr. Kuebler, who is 60 years old.  ''This is a union where
seniority has no meaning.''

Lawyers and Federal prosecutors who are familiar with labor laws said Mr. Cody
would probably be able to continue as head of the local until his appeals of the
conviction are decided. That legal could take up to one year.

The second highest-ranking official in the local, Robert Sasso, who is
secretary-treasurer, said the unit had no plans to replace Mr. Cody. ''He is our
leader, and he is going to be vindicated,'' said Mr. Sasso, who was elected on
the same slate with Mr. Cody last year.

In the mid-1970's the FORE group alerted the Labor Department and the Justice
Department to improper loans by the local's Welfare Pension Fund and its
questionable purchase for $6.5 million of a country club. Mr. Cody is a trustee
of the $55 million fund, and he was found guilty in the Federal trial of
extorting kickbacks from real-estate brokers who handled transactions for the
fund.

Reforms Are Doubted

Despite Mr. Cody's conviction, Mr. Katsoras said he doubted there would be
reforms in the local.  ''The membership is a lot wiser now,'' he said, ''but
many of them think this is a tough industry and you need a tough leader like
Cody, Many of us are at our wit's ends. We may have to get other jobs or join
other locals to survive. We still don't know where to turn and who in the
governnment will protect our rights.''

According to Mr. Benson of the Association for Union Democracy, employers and
employees in the construction industry view occasional drives to clean up the
construction industry as ''fads'' that pass quickly.

                             Daily News (New York)

                              May 24, 2009 Sunday
                              SPORTS FINAL EDITION

BACK IN DRIVER'S SEAT Free from tax troubles, Castroneves is sitting in the pole
position

BYLINE: BY RICHARD HUFF DAILY NEWS STAFF WRITER With News Wire Services

SECTION: SPORTS; Pg. 58

LENGTH: 867 words


Standing outside a Miami federal courthouse last month, Helio Castroneves broke
down. With his sister Katiucia by his side, Castroneves, the two-time Indy 500
champion from Brazil who had waltzed his way through America in 2007 on "Dancing
With the Stars," was letting it all go. He wept, uncontrollably.

A jury had just found him not guilty of tax evasion; the years of prison time he
faced had been washed away.

The experience, Castroneves recently told the Daily News, changed his life.

"I'm not even sleeping anymore," he says. "I want to enjoy every minute of
(life). It's been quite the journey."

And this past Friday, the federal government dropped the remaining conspiracy
charge that had been hanging over him by a deadlocked jury.

"It just opened up my perspective on life," he says.

"Now waking up in the morning, it can be raining, it can be sunshine, it doesn't
matter," he says.

Going through a tax evasion case, which threatened to put him behind bars for up
to 35 years, can do that to a guy.

It started in October when the 34-year-old Castroneves and his sister, who also
serves as his business manager, were charged with six counts of failing to pay
income tax on more than $5 million in earnings he racked up between 1999 and
2004 from Penske Racing and one count of conspiracy to defraud the government by
hiding income.

Prosecutors charged the money had been diverted to a Panamanian "shell"
corporation called Seven Promotions to avoid paying income tax.

While Castroneves' father, Helio Sr., claimed Seven was his undertaking and was
created to help expand his son's profile in Brazil and serve as a means to
generate revenue for himself, the feds produced documents in which Helio Jr.
claimed he was the proprietor of Seven, and was therefore required to pay taxes
on his Penske earnings.

The money, however, was invested into a Dutch deferred income account.

Castroneves was also charged with making $1,000 worth of improper tax deductions
and failing to disclose Hugo Boss clothes and airline tickets he received as
income. Each count carried a maximum of five years in jail. Castroneves'
attorneys pleaded ignorance on the part of their client, claiming Castroneves
was barely aware of his financial deals.

In the end, after a six-week trial and six days of deliberations over the
complex case, the jury sided with Castroneves.

And now, the man they call "Spider-Man," a nickname he got for scaling racetrack
fences after his wins, is back in his environment in a big way. He sits on the
pole for today's Indianapolis 500 with a four-lap average speed of 224.864 mph,
leaving the IRS spinning.

"The jury finds him not guilty, then he wins the pole position at Indy, and now
the government drops the case completely," says Castroneves' attorney Roy Black.
"All he has to do now is win the race and climb the fence."

It's been one hell of a run.

"I didn't appreciate all the things before," Castroneves says. "I always
realized I liked racing, but I love racing. This is where I belong. This is what
I want, to be around racing forever. This is my environment."

He's also regained the confidence, the swagger and the desire he had before the
IRS came calling.

"Yes, there was a fear," he says, hesitating. "Not that I would lose, but that
there would be a stop in me doing my career.

"Emotionally, no question it changes you. I do feel I'm strong. Obviously, I'm
the same person."

Castroneves says while he was going through the court system he'd gotten "so
many positive messages and prayers" from fans.

"I just say its incredible to be in this situation, I just feel the need to give
this back, hopefully by winning Indy."

He's won there before, once as a rookie in 2001 and again the very next year,
becoming the fifth driver in history to go back-to-back at The Brickyard.

"I think he's got more intensity and more love for the sport and driving race
cars than he had before the issues that he had with the government," says former
driver Scott Goodyear, who will work ABC's telecast of the race (pre-race
coverage starts at noon).

Goodyear says Castroneves is the favorite because of his experience at the
track, and how well his car has run in the sessions leading up to the race. On
Friday, he posted the fastest speed in the final practice, at nearly 224 mph.

Going in, the odds certainly appear to be in Castroneves' favor. He's got a
strong car. He's on the pole for the third time in his career, and he's won the
Indy 500 twice before.

"No question," he says, "being out in front you have less things to worry
about."

Indy, however, is a place where favorites' dreams can end in a heartbeat. In
1992, for instance, polesitter Roberto Guerrero lost control of his car on the
second parade lap - before the start.

Castroneves says he goes into today's race a changed man, but the memory of the
past year will never go away.

"I don't think so," he says. "The scars are there. I don't think I'm going to
forget it. I'll move on, I'll turn the page. It's hard to forget things like
that. For me its now important to take a good positive thing from that, to look
at that scar, and say, 'listen, I'm here, I'm stronger, and that's made me
realize, what I love in life.'" -

                            February 12, 2016 Friday

Doctor accused of tax evasion

BYLINE: Pocono Record, Stroudsburg, Pa.

SECTION: LIFESTYLE

LENGTH: 262 words


Feb. 12--SCRANTON -- A former Wayne County doctor has been charged with evading
payment of his income taxes and with filing a false document with the Internal
Revenue Service, according to a press release from the U.S. Attorney's Office
for the Middle District of Pennsylvania.

Dr. Robert Gorrell, who formerly worked for Wayne Memorial Hospital in Honesdale
as a vascular surgeon, was charged Friday.

The indictment was returned by a federal grand jury in Scranton last Dec. 8, but
remained sealed until Gorrell was found and arrested in Texas on Feb. 11.

According to U.S. Attorney Peter Smith, the indictment charges Gorrell, 65, with
engaging in a years-long pattern of activities to avoid paying over $148,000 in
tax deficiencies. The grand jury charged Gorrell with, among other things,
causing his tax preparer to file Form 1040 tax returns and Form 433-A collection
statements that falsely claimed Gorrell paid for his own medical malpractice
insurance. he also failed to report the extent of his bank accounts, and failed
to report his ownership of a Porsche Cayenne, the indictment says.

Gorrell also allegedly lied to IRS agents and submitted forged documentation to
the IRS in support of his claims.

The activities occurred between October 2006 and April 2012.

The investigation was conducted by the IRS, Criminal Investigations.

The case is being prosecuted by Assistant U.S. Attorney Phillip J. Caraballo.

                     Pittsburgh Post-Gazette (Pennsylvania)

                             April 27, 2008 Sunday
                                TWO STAR EDITION

MOSCOW FREES FORMER ATOMIC ENERGY LEADER;
ADAMOV, UNDER INDICTMENT IN PITTSBURGH, UNLIKELY TO BE TRIED HERE, U. S.
OFFICIALS SAY

BYLINE: Torsten Ove, Pittsburgh Post-Gazette

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B-1

LENGTH: 1430 words


Once considered such a risk to reveal nuclear secrets that a grandstanding
Russian politician wanted commandos to "liquidate" him, a former Russian atomic
energy minister under indictment in Pittsburgh is a free man after serving two
months of his 5 1/2-year prison sentence.

A Moscow court released Yevgeny Adamov last week after suspending his sentence
on a conviction of defrauding the Russian government of $31 million in a plot
involving the sale of Russian uranium on the world market.

U.S. authorities will not comment on the release.

But Mr. Adamov remains charged here with money-laundering, conspiracy to
transfer stolen securities and tax evasion in connection with another scheme to
steal $9 million in U.S. funds intended to upgrade outdated nuclear reactors in
Russia, Ukraine and Lithuania.

In 2005, a grand jury in Pittsburgh said Mr. Adamov, 67, and a partner, Mark
Kaushansky, 56, of Monroeville, diverted the money into two shell companies with
accounts in Pittsburgh, Delaware, France and Monaco.

Mr. Kaushansky, a Ukrainian immigrant and former Westinghouse nuclear power
plant engineer who looked up to Mr. Adamov as a "father figure," is scheduled to
be released in October from federal prison in Morgantown, W.Va., where he's
serving 15 months for tax evasion.

But in Moscow, according toRussian news sources, Mr. Adam-ov continues to insist
on his innocence. He has vowed to appeal the verdict, seek acquittal and
"investigate" those responsible for bringing the charges.

In February, a Moscow judge said Mr. Adamov and two Russian co-defendants
conspired to essentially steal a majority of the shares in a U.S.-Russian joint
venture, Global Nuclear Services and Supply, which was created to remove uranium
from Russian nuclear weapons, downgrade it and use it in power plants in the
United States.

Both of the accused co-conspirators were convicted but also given suspended
sentences.

With Mr. Adamov no longer in custody, it's not clear what will happen to the
U.S. charges, but he will probably never appear for trial here. The United
States has no extradition treaty with Russia and the case likely will remain in
limbo.

Mr. Adamov's lawyer for the U.S. case, Lanny Breuer, former White House counsel
for President Bill Clinton, didn't return messages last week, but he has argued
that Senior U.S. District Judge Maurice Cohill Jr. should dismiss the
indictment.

The judge has already expressed doubts about the government's case, saying
prosecutors can't prove that Mr. Adamov or Mr. Kaushansky skimmed international
funds.

In determining a sentence for Mr. Kaushansky on tax evasion, he accepted the
arguments of Mr. Kaushansky's lawyer, Fred Thieman, now Buhl Foundation
president, that the men weren't hiding nuclear-safety money for themselves but
trying to protect it from Russian banks.

Mr. Adamov said he funneled the money through Pennsylvania and Delaware
companies he created so he could pay his scientists as head of NIKIET, the
Research and Design Institute for Power under contract to improve power plant
safety.

Had the money been paid directly to NIKIET scientists, many of whom were living
below the poverty level, most of it would have disappeared into what Judge
Cohill agreed was a "dysfunctional Russian banking system." No one trusted the
banks, it seems.

Sergei Bocharov, who left NIKIET to become head of the International Atomic
Energy Agency in Vienna, said he kept $25,000 in cash savings at his house
instead of putting it in a Russian bank. When he wanted to transfer it to a
Swiss bank, he gave it to NIKIET, which transferred it to Mr. Adamov's Delaware
company, which in turn wired it to a Vienna bank.

Judge Cohill said the system that Mr. Adamov set up seemed to work. While other
Russian scientific institutions were suffering, NIKIET thrived, even
constructing a new building.

Judge Cohill said he doesn't believe the government's claim, built largely on
evidence put together by Ed Reiser, considered among the best agents in the
Criminal Investigation Division of the IRS, that the money transfers through
various corporate entities and bank accounts was an "elaborate fraudulent
scheme."

"The defendant's theory provides an alternative framework, one which we find
plausible while we find the other unproved," the judge ruled. "We must give the
defendant the benefit of the doubt."

The case, which Mr. Thieman, a former U.S. attorney, considers the most
fascinating of his legal career, is ultimately rooted in the 1986 nuclear
accident at Chernobyl and the upheaval following the collapse of the Soviet
Union.

NIKIET had designed the RBMK reactor used at Chernobyl and at other plants
throughout the former USSR.

Fearing another disaster, the United States and other nations in 1993 started
the "Lisbon Initiative" to provide money and technical help to upgrade 15 power
plants. Congress gave the effort $50 million a year.

Mr. Adamov, described as charismatic and brilliant, had been appointed head of
NIKIET just after the Chernobyl accident and was hailed in Russia and abroad for
cleaning up the site and redesigning the RBMK reactor to improve its safety.

He ran the agency until 1998, when President Boris Yeltsin appointed him to run
the Federal Ministry of Atomic Energy.

But his career hit a rough patch in 2001 after the Russian Duma, which is
equivalent to the U.S. House, issued a report that he had "openly demonstrated
aspirations toward monopoly management of the government enterprise for his own
personal gain."

The report caused a stir in Russia, but in his ruling in the Kaushansky case
Judge Cohill said he doesn't believe it, noting that the Russian attorney
general later found no evidence to support the allegations.

"We are not persuaded that the Duma Report is an accurate account of Adamov's
activities," Judge Cohill wrote.

Still, Mr. Adamov left his post and eventually returned to running NIKIET.

After his indictment here in 2005, he became the focus of an eight-month
extradition battle in Switzerland, where he had been arrested at the request of
the United States.

American authorities wanted him to face trial in Pittsburgh, but Russian
officials were afraid he'd reveal state secrets, including classified
information about Russia's construction of a nuclear reactor in Iran, if he were
extradited to America.

One legislator from a Russian political party known for outlandish statements
even suggested that special forces kill Mr. Adamov rather than let him be
extradited.

Some legislators feared he might give up sensitive information in exchange for
leniency or under torture. Russia won the battle and Mr. Adamov has been there
ever since.

But the trial and last week's early release has generated new suspicions in
Russia that the prosecution there was little more than a show.

Environmental groups in Russia that have accused Mr. Adamov of corruption have
said from the beginning that they didn't have much faith in the Russian court
system.

"I don't think the investigation was carried out adequately and that Adamov will
be subjected to adequate punishment," Vladimir Silvyak, co-chairman of
Ecodefence environmental group, told the Web site for Bellona, a nonprofit that
fights nuclear contamination in Russia."I am sure that they didn't turn him over
to American authorities and instead trumped up a case in Russia in order that he
not be subjected to more severe punishment."

Mr. Silvyak told Bellona that the spread of corruption under Mr. Adamov was
"unbelievable" but that "nobody paid any attention to it so long as the
Americans didn't bring him to account -- in Russia, it simply didn't interest
anyone."

For his part, Mr. Adamov has always maintained that he's a champion of nuclear
responsibility.

After the Chernobyl cleanup, he spoke at international conferences on the
subject and in fact first met Mr. Kaushansky at a presentation he gave for
Western scientists in 1988 in France.

When Westinghouse began courting NIKIET for business, Mr. Kaushansky became Mr.
Adamov's translator, friend and business partner. The men and their wives grew
so close that they became the shareholders in one of the U.S. corporations they
established to manage investments, Omeka Ltd., of Monroeville. Omeka is one of
the entities that the IRS here said was a shell company controlled by Mr.
Adamov.

True or not, he's now free, the prosecutor in Russia says he won't appeal and
the U.S. attorney's office can't do much about any of it, although $2.5 million
in a Monaco account remains frozen.

Mr. Adamov apparently isn't going anywhere. According to news accounts, he's
right back where he started -- running NIKIET.

OCEANSIDE

Menorah

gets display

at City Hall

A15-foot tall menorah will be displayed at City Hall to celebrate Hanukkah,
alongside Santa Claus and his sleigh.

The handmade symbol of the Jewish holiday will be lit with real flames one night
and have electric lights on the rest of its 10-day run in December.

SACRAMENTO

Referendum allowed

on slot machines

A Sacramento County Superior Court judge has ruled that voters should be allowed
to weigh in on a deal between Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and one of the state's
richest Indian tribes.

The deal would allow the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians in Palm Springs
to install thousands of additional slot machines. In exchange, the tribe would
share a percentage of its profits with the state.

Judge Lloyd Connelly said Tuesday that a referendum on the deal can go before
voters Feb. 5.

LOS ANGELES

Lawyer gets 3 years

for tax evasion

A civil-rights lawyer known for high-profile cases against police and President
Bush was sentenced Tuesday to three years in prison for federal tax evasion,
bankruptcy fraud and money laundering.

Stephen Yagman, 63, had been found guilty of trying to avoid paying more than
$100,000 in federal income taxes while living what prosecutors painted as a
lavish lifestyle.

PASADENA

Man gets life for

killing three in family

A former Marine has pleaded guilty to first-degree murder for the March 2004
shooting deaths of his wife, adult son and father-in-law.

After Tuesday's plea, a Pasadena Superior Court judge immediately sentenced
59-year-old Murray Smith to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

Smith shot and killed the three family members in Duarte on March 14, 2004.

SANTA ANA

City to pay $50M

to paralyzed women

The city of Dana Point said Tuesday it will pay $50 million to two women who
were paralyzed after a car struck them while they jogged in a bike lane.

Carol Daniel, 42, and Stacy Neria, 35, both of San Clemente, will split the
money under a settlement agreement.

The women were jogging along Pacific Coast Highway with two other friends on
April 8, 2006, when driver William Todd Bradshaw hit them from behind.

                              Late Edition - Final

Guilty Plea Made in Trial Over Shelters From KPMG

BYLINE: By LYNNLEY BROWNING

SECTION: Section C; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 675 words


A businessman pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiracy and fraud and
agreed to help federal prosecutors pursue indicted former employees of the
accounting firm KPMG in a widening investigation into questionable tax shelters.

The businessman, Chandler Stuart Moisen, who appeared in Federal District Court
in Manhattan, is the third person to enter a guilty plea in the tax shelter
investigation, which has ensnared accountants, bankers, lawyers and investment
advisers.

An assistant United States attorney, Stanley Okula, told the court yesterday
that Mr. Moisen was expected to testify against some of the 16 KPMG defendants
who are scheduled to stand trial in September over questionable tax shelters
that prosecutors say deprived the Treasury of billions of dollars in taxes.

Although Mr. Moisen is a relatively minor figure in the tax shelter inquiry, his
offer to cooperate with the prosecution could have major consequences for the
KPMG defendants, in particular for Robert Pfaff, a former KPMG partner with whom
Mr. Moisen worked closely to sell questionable tax shelters.

Mr. Moisen lived recently in Park City, Utah, and has lived in Colorado,
Southern California and abroad.

The charges against Mr. Moisen refer to a Denver accountant and a former KPMG
partner but do not name Mr. Pfaff. Mr. Moisen's lawyer, Thomas H. Beinert Jr.,
however, confirmed that Mr. Pfaff is the Denver accountant referred to in the
court filing.

David Scheper, a lawyer for Mr. Pfaff, could not be reached for immediate
comment.

In exchange for pleading guilty to one count of tax fraud conspiracy and one
count of wire fraud for making and selling bogus tax shelters, Mr. Moisen, 51,
waived his right to a trial and will not be indicted. He faces as much as 35
years in prison.

In a statement before the court, Mr. Moisen said, ''During the 1990s and up to
the early 2000s, I was involved with several individuals in creating tax
shelters.'' He said his involvement included marketing the shelters, finding
wealthy investors to buy them, referring clients to Mr. Pfaff, among others, and
hiding money earned through selling the shelters. The shelters were known as
ZENS, for zero enhanced note structure; 357c; and Midco.

According to the felony information filed against Mr. Moisen, from 1993 to 2002,
he enabled millions of dollars to be transferred to companies in the Philippines
and in Norway that served as ''puppets'' to carry out the bogus tax shelters for
wealthy investors.

Mr. Moisen also worked with several co-conspirators, including a former senior
banker at the HVB Group, Domenick DeGiorgio. In August 2005, Mr. DeGiorgio
pleaded guilty to charges of conspiracy, fraud and tax evasion for making and
selling bogus tax shelters while at the New York office of HVB, the large German
bank. In March, David Rivkin, a former partner at KPMG in San Diego who was
indicted with the 16 other former KPMG employees, pleaded guilty to charges of
conspiracy and tax evasion and agreed to help prosecutors against his indicted
former colleagues.

According to the felony information, Mr. Moisen, Mr. DeGiorgio and Mr. Pfaff had
elaborate fee-splitting arrangements for the millions of dollars they earned
from their sales of tax shelters.

In the felony information, prosecutors also cite an August 2001 e-mail message
from Mr. Moisen to Mr. DeGiorgio titled ''Us getting rich.'' In it, Mr. Moisen
writes: ''Dom, one of my recurring nightmares involves you/me and our receipt of
$. The first used to be that somehow the bank would catch you and we would all
go to jail because we were violating federal banking laws.''

Apparently referring to Mr. Pfaff, he went on: ''That concern of course was
started by Bob and has largely dissipated. The second nightmare is that the
I.R.S. catches on and you/we are nailed for income tax evasion. People go to
jail for that one.''

Mr. Moisen then wrote, ''I would assume that the government would not have a lot
of mercy, considering that the source of the funds was profits from tax
shelters.''

                          December 20, 1997, Saturday,

FATHER, SON PLEAD GUILTY TO FRAUD;
 THE OWNER OF MAINELY PAYROLL AND HIS SON WERE ACCUSED OF DIVERTING UP TO $ 2
MILLION IN PAYROLL TAXES TO THEIR PERSONAL USE.

BYLINE: Betty Adams Guy Gannett Service

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE, Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 450 words

DATELINE: AUGUSTA


A year and a half after Mainely Payroll closed and left 125 businesses holding
the bag for back taxes and payroll checks, the company's owner and one of his
sons pleaded guilty to federal income tax evasion and other charges.

Clifford Levesque, 54, owner of Mainely Payroll, and Michael Levesque, 28,
entered guilty pleas in U.S. District Court in Portland Friday morning and were
released on personal recognizance until their sentencing.

''Instead of paying the IRS as the clients expected, (Clifford Levesque)
diverted $ 2 million for his personal use and to invest in businesses owned by
his son,'' said U.S. Attorney Jay McCloskey at a press conference in Augusta
Friday afternoon.

McCloskey said it was the largest case of federal tax evasion filed in Maine. He
estimated the Levesques' actions resulted in a total tax loss of between $ 2
million and $ 2.5 million.

Mainely Payroll, an Augusta firm that processed payroll checks and tax
withholding payments for companies in Central Maine, shut down in May 1996 and
Clifford Levesque filed for bankruptcy shortly afterward.

The abrupt closing left 186 creditors claiming they were defrauded of upwards of
$ 1 million.

Both Levesques pleaded guilty to tax evasion, banking offenses and mail fraud.
Clifford Levesque also pleaded guilty to bankruptcy fraud and his son pleaded
guilty to theft of government funds.

The two former Augusta residents are now living in Old Orchard Beach.

McCloskey said that in the interim between the bankruptcy and the pleas, two IRS
agents and a Social Security agent sorted through ''virtually a room full of
documents.''

''Even though Clifford Levesque admitted his involvement, that was not sowith
his son,'' McCloskey said. ''The cases were made by intensive investigation.''

According to the criminal court documents, Clifford Levesque had employees fill
out income tax and tax withholding forms in pencil. He then erased the numbers
and reported smaller amounts of taxes due, funneling the difference to
businesses in which he and Michael had an interest.

They included Lube Plus, an oil-change business, Subs Plus, and a used car
business.

___________________________________________________________________________

They hoped to recover money Clifford Levesque had been diverting from Mainely
Payroll accounts since the fall of 1993.

The Levesques face prison terms of up to 30 years and a fine of $ 1 million on
each mail fraud charge and banking offense.

Tax evasion and bankruptcy fraud charges carry maximum prison terms of five
years and fines of up to $ 250,000. Theft of government funds carries a maximum
prison term of 10 years and a fine of up to $ 250,000.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      July 28, 1994 Thursday FINAL EDITION

METROPOLITAN AREA NEWS IN BRIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 799 words


WOMAN FOUND SLAIN, MAN

HURT IN KENSINGTON HOUSE

Philadelphia homicide detectives early today were investigating the shooting
death of a woman inside a West Kensington house in the 3500 block of Ella
Street.

Police were called to the scene at 11:21 last night. They found the woman dead
of multiple gunshot wounds and a man, also inside the house, suffering
from a beating. He was taken to Temple University Hospital for treatment.

Investigators withheld their names pending notification of relatives. The motive
for the shooting and beating was not immediately known. Police reported no
arrests.

HAIR-REPLACEMENT WORKERS

PLEAD GUILTY TO TAX EVASION

A manager and an employee of a South Jersey hair-replacement company pleaded
guilty to income tax evasion yesterday in federal court.

Robert S. Calderone, 50, of Pennsauken, office and marketing manager for
International Cosmetics Labs of Cinnaminson, pleaded guilty to charges of
conspiracy to defraud the United States and two counts of filing false tax
returns. ICL employee James J. O'Neill Jr., 34, of Sewell in South Jersey,
pleaded guilty to two counts of filing false tax returns. U.S. District Judge
John R. Padova set sentencing for both men for Oct. 27.

On July 18, they were accused of tax evasion by the U.S. Attorney's Office in a
criminal information. Also named were ICL president Frank T. Polsenberg, 52, of
Harleysville, Montgomery County, and two other employees. All are expected to
plead guilty. The information alleges that Polsenberg and Calderone conspired to
hide ICL's receipts from tax officials by encouraging customers to pay with cash
or blank cashier's or treasurer's checks.

STATE PLANS TO GIVE PHILA.

$415,000 FOR AIDS HOME

The governor's office said yesterday that the state would provide $415,000 to
help Philadelphia operate the Betak nursing home for people with AIDS while city
officials developed a long-range plan. The city will be able to use the
funds to begin planning for health and support services for young adults who are
homeless, or at risk of becoming homeless, because of AIDS.

"This is a real opportunity for the entire community to continue its
partnership, together with the state, to assure a stable and viable service
system for people with AIDS," said Philadelphia Health Commissioner Estelle
Richman.

The state provided $100,000 in June to keep the home open through July. The city
contributed $50,000, and $80,000 was contributed by four area health-care
organizations. Betak is owned and operated by the Lutheran Home of Germantown.

DEATH OF A PHILA. MAN

IS 23D LINKED TO HEAT

Michael Thomas, 40, became the 23d person in Philadelphia whose death was
related to extreme heat this summer, the city Health Department said yesterday.

Thomas, of Germantown, died at 1:48 a.m. Tuesday in the intensive-care unit of
Albert Einstein Medical Center, according to Health Department spokesman Jeff
Moran.

Moran said that officials yesterday determined that the primary cause of Thomas'
death was an adverse reaction to drugs, but that extreme heat also contributed.

CASEY BACKS LEGISLATION

TO EASE ADOPTION RULES

Gov. Casey opened an adoption conference yesterday in Harrisburg by announcing
his support for legislation that he said would make adoptions easier.

The legislation is sponsored by Rep. Kevin Blaum (D., Luzerne). It would reduce
the six-month waiting period for adoptions, expand access to adoption-
counseling services, allow children age 12 and older to petition for termination
of parental rights, and establish a central registry of birth parents and people
seeking to adopt.

SMOKE BRINGS FIREFIGHTERS

TO HIGH-RISE WHERE 3 DIED

Philadelphia firefighters experienced some anxious moments yesterday afternoon
when they responded to a fire report on South Penn Square and spotted smoke
coming from the fourth-floor of the former One Meridian Plaza office building.
Three of their co-workers died battling a fire there in February 1991.

A search of the scarred and vacant building revealed no fire. However, in the
third subbasement of the adjoining Two Mellon Bank Center building, left vacant
by the same deadly blaze, firefighters found the source of the smoke: smoldering
wire.

Fire officials said vandals had set fire to some wiring in an effort to burn off
the insulation. Once the protective cover is gone, the vandals rip out the wire
and sell it to junkyards for its value in copper, officials said. Smoke from the
wire followed pipe routes to the fourth floor of the 22-story Meridian building,
officials said. The fire, reported at 4:32 p.m., was placed under control at
5:39 p.m. It caused traffic to be temporarily rerouted from the area, setting
off major rush-hour tieups in Center City.

                     The Leader-Post (Regina, Saskatchewan)

                          February 23, 2011 Wednesday
                                 Final Edition

Greek banker faces U.S. charges

BYLINE: Kim Dixon, Reuters

SECTION: BUSINESS & AGRICULTURE; Pg. C4

LENGTH: 173  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


A Credit Suisse banker was arrested in New York and was being moved to Florida
for a court appearance, according to a law enforcement source familiar with the
case.

The banker, Christos Bagios, is being transferred to Fort Lauderdale in Florida,
where several high-profile tax evasion cases have been tried, including those
involving the government's tax fraud cases against UBS AG.

The New York Times reported on Monday that Bagios, a Greek citizen, has been
charged with conspiracy and fraud in connection with Credit Suisse's work in
offshore accounts.

The law enforcement source had no details about charges against Bagios.

Credit Suisse declined to make a comment.

Bagios previously worked for UBS AG, according to that bank's website.

The United States has been looking for other banks that may be aiding Americans
evade taxes abroad after UBS paid $780 million and agreed to hand over nearly
5,000 account names to the U.S. government to settle tax evasion charges.

A UBS representative said the bank was unaware of any new probe of the bank.

                             999 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                            March 13, 2008 Thursday

Neways asks U.S. district court to dismiss trademark infringement suit

BYLINE: By Pamela Manson The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 246 words


The 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Wednesday upheld the tax evasion and
tax fraud convictions of the founders of Neways Inc., a Springville multilevel
marketing company, and its former corporate counsel.

The Denver-based court rejected the appeals of the three - Thomas E. Mower; his
ex-wife, Leslie DeeAnn Mower; and James Louis Thompson, a now-disbarred Orem
attorney - who claimed they were convicted by a jury on insufficient evidence.

At a 2005 trial, federal prosecutors alleged that the three concealed more than
$1 million in receipts received from Neways Australia and more than $3 million
in commission income the Mowers received from U.S., Australian and Malaysian
distributorships.

Neways manufactures, markets and sells personal-care and nutritional products in
the United States and about two dozen foreign countries.

The jury convicted each of the Mowers of one count of conspiracy to defraud the
United States and six counts of tax evasion. Thompson was convicted of one count
each of conspiracy and of corruptly impeding the due administration of tax laws.

Thomas Mower was sentenced to 33 months in prison, while his former wife was
ordered to spend 27 months behind bars. The two also were ordered to pay back
taxes.

Thompson, who served as counsel for Neways from 1995 to 1997, was sentenced to a
year and a day in prison.

The Mowers sold Neways in 2006 to Golden Gate Capital, a San Francisco-based
company that had invested in Herbalife.

                             1000 of 1000 DOCUMENTS


                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                           November 9, 2006 Thursday

Neways sold to California investors

BYLINE: By Linda Fantin and Pam Manson The Salt Lake Tribune

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 294 words


Posted: 2:46 PM-

Two months before they begin serving prison terms for tax evasion, Thomas and
Leslie Mower have sold Neways International to the San Francisco-based company
that has invested heavily in Herbalife.

Golden Gate Capital did not disclose the financial details behind its
acquisition of Springville-based Neways. But the private equity firm, along with
Whitney & Co., paid $685 million for Herbalife in 2002 then took the company
public.

The Mowers said in a statement that selling the dietary supplement and personal
care company they founded in 1992 was "one of the hardest decisions of our
lives."

The couple disclosed plans to sell the company two months ago in court filings,
citing "personal differences."

The Mowers, who divorced in July 2000, came from humble beginnings but together
built one of the largest multilevel marketing companies in the world in Utah
County.

In 2005 they were convicted on six counts of tax evasion and one count of
conspiracy to defraud for concealing more than $1 million in receipts received
from Neways Australia and more than $3 million in commission income the couple
received from U.S., Australian and Malaysian distributorships.

On Sept. 14, U.S. District Judge Dale Kimball rejected the Mowers' pleas for
probation and sentenced Thomas Mower to 33 months in prison and a $75,000 fine.
His ex-wife, Dee, was ordered to spend 27 months behind bars and pay a $60,000
fine. Their prison terms were to begin Monday, but Nov. 1 the judge extended the
deadline to Jan. 8.

Kimball also sentenced James Louis Thompson, an Orem lawyer who served as
counsel for Neways from 1995 to 1997, to 366 days in prison. Thompson, now
disbarred, was found guilty of conspiracy and of corruptly impeding the due
administration of tax laws.
